HEADLINE: A Crime of Passion

BYLINE: By Jack Miles; Jack Miles, Mellon Visiting Professor of Humanities at the California Institute of Technology, was a consultant and participant in the 1996 KPCC radio series on race relations, "Shades of L.A."

 BODY:

THE HOUSE GUN
 By Nadine Gordimer.
 294 pp. New York:
 Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24. 
 The end of apartheid has left much unchanged in South Africa, a technologically advanced country whose revolution has been accomplished without a revolutionary war. A passively liberal white couple like the one at the center of Nadine Gordimer's latest novel -- Claudia and Harald Lindgard, a physician and a business executive with decades of marriage behind them -- might almost regard Nelson Mandela's victory over F. W. de Klerk in 1994 as just another election.
And yet something has changed for them after all. As Patti Waldmeir describes it in "Anatomy of a Miracle: The End of Apartheid and the Birth of the New South Africa": "The main difference, for whites, was the surge in violent crime, which took the murder rate to 10 times the U.S. level. Whites felt politically secure, but physically threatened."
People like the Lindgards were safe and comfortable under de Klerk; under Mandela, they are, by and large, still safe and comfortable. Yet on a drowsy evening when one of their son's friends comes to the door -- "Someone's been shot. He's arrested. Duncan." -- Harald and Claudia react as if they have been waiting for something like this to happen. The brutal and instantaneous transformation of their mood is one Americans can only too easily recognize.
Duncan, 27, the Lindgards' only child, has been living with his girlfriend, Natalie, in the guest house of a residence shared by three gay men. Carl Jespersen, the oldest of the three, a Scandinavian roue with a vague background in filmmaking, has been shot dead. Duncan has confessed to the murder and has already engaged a lawyer, Hamilton Motsamai.
The murder appears to be a classic crime passionnel: Duncan, having found Carl and Natalie fornicating on the sofa in the main residence, has shot Carl with "the house gun," which by unhappy accident had been left out on the coffee table. Later Harald learns from Nkululeko (Khulu) Dladla, one of the two other housemates, that Duncan and Carl had briefly been lovers -- an idle dalliance for the older man; a poignant, exceptional affair for the younger. When Duncan found Carl with Natalie, he felt doubly humiliated, doubly mocked. The gun happened to be lying there. In the anguish and fury of the moment, he used it.
The murder is not a political act, then, but this elegantly conceived, flawlessly executed novel surely is, for it arrives in the heat of a major South African debate. A nascent gun control movement has been arguing that the more guns there are in private hands, the more dangerous South Africa will become, while the entrenched South African gun culture invokes the country's staggering murder rate to come to just the opposite conclusion: the more guns, the less crime; let there be no house without its house gun.
Analogous to the gun control debate is the death penalty debate. Does capital punishment deter violence or does it, as an example of violence, teach what it would deter? While Duncan awaits trial, Harald goes, "as if to a clandestine rendez-vous," to sessions of the Constitutional Court where the death penalty (abolished in the 1996 South African Constitution) is under review. Harald is obsessed with the debate because he wants one particular confessed murderer, his son, to live. But whether they are considering defense or deterrence, Harald and Claudia only fleetingly ask what has made their country so violent in the first place. Americans, again, will read with a painful sense of recognition.
South Africa, like the United States, has both the Netherlands and England in its cultural genealogy, but neither the Netherlands nor England is remotely as violent as the United States or South Africa. Is this because neither European country executes its criminals and both restrict citizen access to arms? Or is it because neither has a black population as large as the South African or the American? This is the racial question that haunts Gordimer's novel.
She does not answer it by writing a work of fiction with a slogan buttoned to its lapel. Her answer emerges as an inference -- possible, not necessary -- from two of her literary decisions. First, by portraying the murder of one white man by another, she reminds her readers that, even granting that race has played a key role in the genesis of South Africa's violence, this violence is by now intraracial as much as interracial. Whites in South Africa are by now acculturated to kill other whites at a higher rate than their cousins do in Europe. Second, the fact that two blacks -- Hamilton Motsamai, Duncan's lawyer, and Khulu, his loyal friend -- bring a measure of peace into the ravaged Lindgard family suggests that blacks and whites are not chemical elements that must explode on contact. In other words, the roots of South African violence lie in the history of race relations rather than in the biology of race. Gordimer's guarded hope is that what history has done over time, history over time can also undo.
Gordimer's more recent, post-apartheid fiction is no less political or more personal than the work that won her the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1991. "The House Gun," like her 1994 novel "None to Accompany Me," does indeed explore personal relations across racial lines in South Africa, but what, if not that sort of thing, did her earlier work ever do? Though she has been honored, and rightly so, for her political engagement, Gordimer has as a novelist the detachment to see that the human situation into which she has been born, whatever its morality, is one of enormous natural fascination and not infrequent comedy. If she has not had, before now, the opportunity to portray a black lawyer -- a black establishment lawyer, a rich black establishment lawyer -- representing a guilty white defendant, nearly 50 years at her desk writing 11 novels and nine volumes of short stories have prepared her to make the most of the opportunity, now that it has come along.
Harald is taken aback at Duncan's choice of Motsamai: "In the muck in which they are stewing now, where murder is done, old prejudices still writhe to the surface. Looking at the appointment of someone called Motsamai that way, he can find an answer within its context. Could be an advantage. If there's one of the black judges on the bench."
Ho! This is a novel that Johnnie Cochran could read with interest. Yet past the (wittily, watchfully enacted) first meeting between the murderer's parents and his lawyer, the material of their interaction is often made of other than racial stuff. For example, Claudia, a physician, does not enjoy being anybody's client: "The advocate knows the accused's mother is accusing him: of being too measured. He's accustomed to this kind of reaction, fear turned to resentment. In her case no doubt exacerbated by the fact that she is accustomed, as he has reminded her, to being the professional adviser instead of the victim. He looks away, flicking aside the shred of irrelevancy."
"The House Gun" crackles with interactions of this sort. Race is not essential to them, but -- especially as South Africa's political correction is followed, haltingly, by an economic correction -- race adds richly to their interest, their comic believability, almost to their fun.
Duncan has inherited his mother's desire to save lives, we learn, but Natalie, whom he has rescued from suicide by drowning, has not lost her death wish. She stays with him because she finds him a fate worse than death. She can only kill herself by somehow destroying him first. Motsamai puts this story together (or makes it up) by probing deeper into four lives -- Harald's, Claudia's, Duncan's and especially Natalie's -- than any one of them would wish. He takes all the indecent liberties that legal defense in a free society must take.
A long the way, using to brilliant effect the jagged abruptness of her prose style, Gordimer tells a love story unlike any I have ever read. Claudia and Harald are so married that they are almost one person. At the start, they are simply "she" and "he," and Gordimer's exposition accordingly jumbles their thoughts and words. But this fusion has ceased to be the expression and has become the suffocation of their love. Duncan splits them apart with his crime, as perhaps only he could. If there is no gap, there can be no spark jumping the gap. Murder opens such a gap between Claudia and Harald -- and the spark jumps.
As for Duncan himself, he is an absent presence until the last pages of the novel, known only through others' memories of him and testimonies about him -- his parents', Khulu's, Natalie's, even Motsamai's. We turn the pages, waiting for him to speak up, and eventually he does. This novel of physical violence and spiritual turmoil ends with Duncan's composure. Silent in his prison cell, Duncan remembers Carl, then thinks of the child in Natalie's womb. Carl's child or his? He doesn't know, he may never know, but he has found what he believes he had to find: in the novel's final, haunting words, "a way to bring death and life together."

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

BYLINE: By Ruth Bayard Smith 

 BODY:

Radio Voices
 American Broadcasting, 1922-1952.
 By Michele Hilmes.
 University of Minnesota,
 cloth, $49.95; paper, $19.95. 
 In the introduction to her well-documented book, Michele Hilmes bemoans the lack of analytical attention paid to radio: "No other medium has been more thoroughly forgotten, by the public, historians and media scholars alike." "Radio Voices" traces the development of early radio, addressing such subjects as technological advances and the impact of popular comedies and dramas. Hilmes, who teaches communication arts at the University of Wisconsin, looks at radio and the power of advertising; the conflict between highbrow and lowbrow programming; and the role of women, blacks and immigrant groups. She also addresses many of the reasons radio has been neglected in the television years, focusing primarily on politics and economics as the main culprits. Unfortunately, Hilmes's analysis often gets overwhelmed by her cumbersome inclusion of material, not all of it necessarily salient. The text has too many phrases like "radio's dystopian potential," "containment of the transgressive possibilities" and "subaltern counterpublic." Still, the book is valuable for placing radio within a cultural and historical framework. Ruth Bayard Smith

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
The Byzantine World Of Airline Fares

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
CUSTOMERS shopping for the lowest air fares have grown accustomed to good deals if they buy well in advance and lock in specific flights, while paying extravagant prices to fly at the last minute with freedom to change plans. Now a consumer-advocacy organization with members on college campuses across the country says a test it conducted shows that airline pricing is much more complicated than this, so complicated that even savvy consumers cannot be sure they are getting the best deal, or even a good deal, unless they spend an inordinate amount of time shopping.
Volunteers for the United States Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit consumer and environmental research and advocacy organization based in Washington, called travel agents and airlines on a Friday last fall seeking the best deal on flights departing the next Thursday around 5 P.M. and returning Sunday evening. 
 Reservations made six days before departure usually do not qualify for significant discounts, although airlines sometimes offer three-day advance-purchase discounts. Still, the fares varied widely.
The volunteers looked at flights between 73 city pairs involving 28 cities. For each pair they called 8 to 10 travel agents and as many as 5 airlines. In all, they placed 910 calls. They were quoted 590 prices. The biggest difference was flying from Indianapolis to San Francisco and back. The fares quoted ranged from $220 to $1,547.
The volunteers also requested the cheapest ticket for both one-week and three-week advance-purchase fares. All requests involved the same Thursday-to-Sunday pattern that includes the Saturday-night stay often required for the best deals.
The researchers found that it cost more to fly round trip from Portland, Ore., to Boston than from Boston to Portland, and that travel agents were much likelier than airlines to give the lowest price.
Paul Stephen Dempsey, vice chairman of Frontier Airlines, a tiny carrier based in Denver that flies to 14 cities including New York, called the sevenfold price difference between Indianapolis and San Francisco astounding. But in an interview about the survey he said that he was not surprised that 910 telephone calls made on the same day resulted in 590 different price quotes.
"Airlines manipulate fares all the time,' he said. "If you called an airline for a price and called back 45 minutes later the fare bucket could have constricted or expanded and the price you are quoted could have dropped or gone up."
"Buckets" is an airline term for the different fare classes, like Y for unrestricted coach and V for highly restricted advance-purchase fares. Computers allow airlines to quickly change the number of seats available at each fare based on such factors as how many seats have sold by a particular date and the effect of holidays on travel patterns.
Ulrich Boser, a staff member of the consumer advocacy group, criticized the sevenfold difference on the Indianapolis-San Francisco route as an illustration of how the airlines engage in deceptive pricing. But Clifford Winston, a transportation economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, saw it differently.
"In the hands of a so-called public interest group, you get this crazy idea that fares are all over the place and people are getting ripped off left and right," Mr. Winston said. "What they encountered is simply yield management, in which the airlines adjust prices according to demand in an attempt to fill every seat, a practice which actually benefits consumers."
He said that fewer than 20 percent of flyers pay the highest fares and that the ones who do are usuallybusiness people traveling on the company's dime, not paying out of their own pockets.
Mr. Winston said it was not surprising that travel agents tended to quote cheaper fares than the airlines, given the way the research group set up its study, which focused on specific times and dates.
"Airline personnel are trained to answer the question you ask, so if you cite a specific time they do not try to figure out how to rearrange your travel to get the lowest price," he said. "Travel agents want you as a repeat customer, so they will look at how flexible you are on travel times, at whether you can leave 10 minutes earlier or take a connection that may get you the lowest fare."
The Public Interest Research Group filed its findings with the Department of Transportation, in support of a "truth in air fares" rule proposed last fall by Consumers Union, another nonprofit research and advocacy organization. The rule would require airlines to tell customers who ask the average and lowest fares for each class of service between city pairs in the previous 90 days.
Consumers Union, which publishes Consumers Reports magazine, says that disclosing average fares will have a big impact on people's ability to spot the best deals and to evaluate how good a deal they can make.
American Airlines and TWA have filed formal objections to the proposed rule, saying it would increase costs and cause consumers to get misleading information -- because prices vary by season, the airlines say, the previous 90-day period is not a reliable indicator of present pricing. An American spokesman, Tim Smith, called the proposed rule a dumb idea.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:

PARIS AND PROVENCE -- An 11-day package offered by Country Cottages, a Florida company, combines a two-night stay in a Paris hotel with seven nights in a villa in Provence. For each of two people sharing a one-bedroom villa, the price starts at $1,099 and includes air fare from New York, Newark or Boston; accommodations, and a rental car for a week. (The car can be picked up in Paris or in the South of France.) The flights are on British Airways to Paris via London. Departures are from late March to early May; travel on April 1 or later costs $169 a person extra. For each of eight people in a four-bedroom villa, the price starts at $899; for each of four in a two-bedroom, $999. The hotel in Paris is the Holiday Inn St.-Germain on the Rue de Vaugirard, where Continental breakfast, tax and service are included. The type of car depends on the party's size. Information: (800) 674-8883 or (561) 988-4000.

FREIGHTER DISCOUNTS -- Ivaran Lines' Americana is marking the 10th anniversary of what it calls luxury freighter travel with discounts this spring. Voyages No. 77 and 78, which depart from New Orleans April 6 and 28, are reduced almost 20 percent. Round-trip rates will start at $3,464 for an inside single cabin, with a standard outside double costing $3,979 a person. Repeat passengers receive an extra 5 percent discount. The itinerary on the cruise, which runs about 21 or 22 days depending on cargo requirements, includes Mexico, Costa Rica, South America and the Southern Caribbean. Shorter segments are available. The ship has a pool, sauna, sun deck and lounge. Information: (800) 451-1639. 

CANARIES PACKAGES -- A company called Canary Islands Holidays is offering six-night packages in the archipelago that start at $699 a person, double occupancy, including air fare from New York, hotel, daily buffet breakfast and airport transfers. That price is for February, March or late April departures with lodging at the Apartment Hotel Las Piramides on Tenerife, or late April departures with accommodations at Las Dalias on Tenerife. The program runs until April 25, with departures on Saturdays. Flights are nonstop on Air Europe, a Spanish carrier, from New York to Tenerife. Information: (888) 767-8822.
 
DISCOUNTS TO ASIA -- Overseas Adventure Travel has cut prices by as much as $400 on Thailand, Borneo and Indonesia trips; the company says it renegotiated prices because of the Asian economic crisis. A 15-day Discover Thailand tour now costs $2,590 or $2,790; a 17-day Legendary Borneo trip, $3,390 to $3,590; an 18-day Indonesia Odyssey, $3,690 or $3,990. Round-trip flights from Los Angeles are included, as are hotels, most meals and sightseeing. Most departures are in spring or fall. Information: (800) 873-5628. JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: Q&A/Robert W. Elliott;
Reaching Beyond One's Own Bailiwick

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
MAYOR Robert W. Elliott of Croton-on-Hudson is a person who gets involved in big ways with many organizations. He is the president of the New York State Conference of Mayors, chairman of the Tri-County Association, which links Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and president of the Westchester Municipal Officials Association.
Mr. Elliott, who is in his fourth term as Mayor of his village in the town of Cortlandt, was recently appointed to the Small Cities Committee of the National League of Cities. He has been involved with the establishment of the Westchester Council of Governance, a body recommended by Westchester 2000, which County Executive Andrew J. Spano is creating. And he was at the forefront of establishing Historic River Towns of Westchester, which promotes communities from Yonkers to Peekskill along the Hudson River. He demonstrates that he believes in inter-government cooperation. 
 Recently, his name was mentioned as a Democratic challenger to Representative Sue W. Kelly, a Republican, in the 19th Congressional District, which includes northern Westchester, Putnam and parts of Dutchess and Orange Counties.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Elliott, whose part-time position is supplemented with consulting work in economic development:
Q. Why do you feel it is important to get involved with so many inter-municipal groups?
A. It is coincidental that I would be involved with so many at one time. It is just the way things happened. But it is important, I think, for communities to get together to work together for a number of reasons. On the one hand, people want small government; they want government they can understand and get their arms around. On the other hand, they want a more efficient government. There is a cry particularly in the state of New York to limit the number of levels of government there are. Everybody would like to get rid of everybody else's level. But by working together you can provide real efficiencies and at the same time still keep small governments that most residents really like. The only way, really, I think, you get a lot done these says is to work together. You not only get more accomplished but you also get recognition and funding a lot easier for the initiatives if they are planned well. Such funding can come from other layers of government or private foundations. They are more apt to work with a group of communities rather than one community.
Q. An example is Historic River Towns. Describe what it does.
A. Historic River Towns is a good example. The communities initially came together looking for ways to solve economic development problems, problems of their downtowns and their Main Streets. These are the communities along the Hudson River from Yonkers to Peekskill. We started out when the economy had really bottomed out. We were searching for ways to deal with this problem, and having very little in the way of resources, we began to take a step back and take an inventory of what we had. We began to focus on tourism, which would not require us to draw on outside resources. We didn't have to wait for the Federal Government to come and solve our problems, or the state or the bio-tech industry.
We had an awful lot in common, from historical sites to cultural sites to the aqueduct to the trail systems, the Old Albany Post Road to our Main Streets, to our restaurants to the hotels, to Metro-North and, of course, the Hudson River. If you look at us as a whole, we're as legitimate a major tourist destination as any other place in the country. Of course, one of the markets is our own residents. We're largely looking at those who are interested in history and scenic beauty of the area.
Q. So you have joined together. Has it brought in money?
A. Yes, it has brought in joint money. We get great support from the county, and we work with the County Planning Department, and we've gotten funding from private foundations and others. The planning we do is all voluntary and from the bottom up. No one is telling anyone what to do. You buy in or subscribe to as much or as little of this as you like.
Q. Is there a shortage of people who are willing to take on the top leadership roles?
A. I haven't found that. What I like to do in any organization that I end up being president of or chairman of is to fill it with lots of good people. You like to have a succession of people to follow you, so it gives the organization life.
Q. Why don't you say no to one or two of these groups?
A. Each one fills a different need that cries out, particularly River Towns cries out. It's one of those things that if you step back and look at it you wonder, Why hasn't this been done before? Municipal Officials for Westchester is an organization that in recent years, due to many of my predecessors, has moved municipalities along in working with the county and the state on working on issues that are important to all of us. It's very difficult to influence legislation as a single community, for example. As a group, we can move things along.
Q. What about this talk of you as a possible candidate for Congress?
A. A number of people have approached me about that and asked me to consider it, and I said I would consider it. But it's very premature to say anything at all.
Q. If not this, do you have an interest in a higher office?
A. I really enjoy public service. And, frankly, having come out of the private sector, I began without a lot of respect for municipal government. But once getting into it, I now have enormous respect for both the paid professionals and the elected officials. They are wonderful people, and they do great things.
Q. Before you became Mayor, you were, it is said, a small business person who was a victim of the malls. What happened?
A. I took over a small family business just about the time the economy turned. I struggled through a very difficult time. As a matter of fact, Main Streets throughout the country and certainly throughout Westchester struggled. As it happened, I really began to wonder what could be done. How could small businessmen fend for themselves and what could local government do to assist them, and other levels? I really became a student of the dynamics of small downtown economics. That really led me to not only becoming Mayor but also to getting involved with organizations that deal with these issues, such as the Conference of Mayors. They began to sponsor conferences and we began working with communities and eventually that is how River Towns got started. Little by little, each community is repositioning itself and its Main Street, trying to find a niche. They had all become victims of the big shopping malls.
Q. You are active in Westchester 2000, which recently issued a report urging consolidation of governments, not to save money but to simplify things. What is your feeling.
A. There are too many levels of government -- there is no question about that. But as I said, everybody else's level is the one that people think should be eliminated. I do think over the next few years there will be a few consolidations of towns and villages, but not a whole lot. But with technology and with a few other things that are coming down the road, you'll see more efficiency. With the new county government, I think you will see greater cooperation between the municipal governments and the county. I think you will find a lot of rethinking about the delivery of services to make it more efficient.
Q. If you proposed that Croton merged with Buchanan or that both villages disbanded and let the Cortlandt town government run things, would you be thrown out of town?
A. Yeah, I don't think you'd find a gentle acceptance of that at this time. What you might find is -- and I'm not referring specifically to Croton and Cortlandt -- you might find one community providing more services for the other. One would do police services, and the other won't. It's very common with fire districts to have that. You may find this with roads, where it makes sense. Right now, if you're driving down a road, you don't know if you're on a Federal highway, a state highway, a county road, a village road or a town road. All you know is there is a pothole there.
Q. What about reassessment? Your own Legislator was instrumental in getting Gov. George E. Pataki to veto a bill in 1996.
A. I think there is a need to have it done -- the system is so unfair. The Governor, when he vetoed it, left the door open for it to be presented again. I think you will see in the future a cooperative effort among local and county governments and the private sector, the school sector and the state to get together.

HEADLINE: HOME ENTERTAINMENT;
At Mickey's House, A Quiet Welcome For Distant Cousins

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

 BODY:
THERE'S AN AIR OF ANTICIPATION in the land of anime, the risque and warlike corner of Japanese animation that has become hugely popular on video in the United States. Amid characters like the genetically enhanced M. D. (Most Dangerous) Geist, liberator of the devastated planet of Jerra, and Doreimon, a scantily clad android from the 22d century, a youngster named Kiki is about to arrive -- representing, of all things, the forces of civic-minded youth.
Kiki, the young star of "Kiki's Delivery Service," isn't from Jerra but from a magic kingdom many galaxies removed called the Walt Disney Company. The film, which will be released straight to video later this year, represents Disney's cautious entry into Japanese animation. But don't call the film anime. Disney officials are skirting the term as if it were radioactive. Kiki is actually a good witch who flies around doing good deeds. "A sweet, sweet story," said Tanya Moloney, a vice president of Buena Vista, Disney's video arm. 
 These days, anime refers strictly to "adult" Japanese animation, aimed primarily at young men. But those films make up only a small fraction of the enormous body of work turned out every year by Japanese animators. Recently, Disney secured the rights to "Kiki's Delivery Service" and seven other films by Hayao Miyazake, one of Japan's more Disney-like animators. Ms. Moloney emphasized that the company was not only giving a wide berth to racy, battle-ravaged anime but was entering, in a limited way, the family-oriented precincts of Japanese animation. "We are merely recognizing the talents of one particular animator, Hayao Miyazake," she said.
Nevertheless, presented with coattails the length of Disney's, the purveyors of anime are hailing any degree of participation by the world's best-known giant of animation as an imprimatur of all things animated emanating from Japan. In a great gorge-vaulting leap worthy of one of its towering armored juggernauts, anime aims to land squarely in the American animated heartland. "Disney adds legitimacy," said Greg Forster, the marketing director of Manga Entertainment, a Chicago distributor of anime.
No skull-faced, spike-limbed 40-foot brute with rack-and-pinion steering may ever stride around bearing Disney's logo, but that's not the point. By importing samples from the vast selections of child-oriented animation from Japan, Disney may well clear shelf space for all kinds of work from Japan. "They'll bring anime into the mainstream," Mr. Forster said.
But no one from anime's marketing legions can really predict the outcome of Disney's tentative interest. Realistically speaking, most Americans will probably never broaden their concept of animation as anything more than children's territory. In Japan, by contrast, the animation industry springs from a long association with the comic book, both for grown-ups and for youngsters.
More than half the books published in Japan are comics, and they embrace all adult genres. "America is the only country in the world that has this preconceived notion that comic books are intrinsically for children," said John O'Donnell, managing director of Central Park Media, a New York distributor of anime and one of its leading importers. That notion, he said, extends to animation. "In America, cartoons are for kids; in Japan they slice up the market into both sexes and every age group."
A typical year in Japanese animation yields 20 to 30 feature films, 300 to 400 direct-to-video titles and 50 television shows, which run virtually around the clock. Films and shows range from sitcoms and family dramas to noir and the graphically violent and sexual. "In Japan they run everything on TV," Mr. O'Donnell said. "If people don't like it, they don't watch it."
In this country, of course, animation on television is geared primarily to children. The VCR, however, opened the way for Japanese films with mature themes and made it economically possible for distributors to profit from small markets.
Interviewed in Tokyo by phone through an interpreter, Koichi Ohata, the director of the anime film "M.D. Geist II," said that Japanese animators paid no attention to American tastes. They are too busy satisfying their own enormous and varied market. "I have no idea what foreigners want," he said.
He did say, though, that much anime of the late 1980's was influenced by the American "Star Wars" movies and that current darker tales were influenced by American films like "Robocop" and "Blade Runner." And Japanese animated characters have oversize eyes, a vestige, Mr. O'Donnell said, of the old American animated heroine Betty Boop.
WHATEVER IS produced, importers choose what they want, from "Kiki" to sci-fi Armageddons and "pornimation," as some of the steamier romps with Western-looking women, from college girls to the princesses of sci-fi legend, are sometimes called in the United States.
Mr. O'Donnell said that Americans' narrow attitude about animation could be traced to their experience with the comic book in the 1950's, when a Congressional committee headed by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee declared that much of the country's juvenile delinquency problem could be linked to comic strips. "So for a lot of reasons, the cartoon in America got ghettoized," Mr. O'Donnell said. Truly adult material went underground, breaking out only occasionally in work like Robert Crumb's Zap Comix.
Now anime's popularity proves that there is a demand for adult animation. Perhaps even a qualified step like Disney's experiment with "Kiki's Delivery Service" is a sign of an eventual explosion for all sorts of Japanese animation here. "We say anime is all violence and sex," Mr. O'Donnell said, "and so far that's right, because the other 95 percent hasn't been released here yet."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 9; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2162 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Few Favorite Things the Musical Left Out

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

DATELINE: STOWE, Vt.

 BODY:
JOHANNES VON TRAPP OFFERED SOME perspective.
"I'm the youngest and I'm 59," he said, amused at the inevitable gasp. 
 It is hard to believe that those terminally adorable von Trapp children of "Sound of Music" fame, the same ones who piped "Auf Wiedersehen, good night" before dancing off to bed, ever grew up. But not only is Agathe, the oldest girl, no longer 16 going on 17 -- she is 84 going on 85.
"The Sound of Music" opened on Broadway on Nov. 16, 1959, with a score by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d and a book by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse. Mary Martin starred as Maria, the novice nun sent to teach the seven children of the widowed Baron von Trapp. Despite mixed reviews, which Johannes von Trapp remembers upsetting the opening night party that he and his mother attended at the St. Regis Hotel, the musical went on to defy its critics and run for an impressive 1,443 performances. It also became one of the most popular family films ever made, starring Julie Andrews and Christopher Plummer.
Now, for the first time on Broadway since the original production, a revival of "The Sound of Music" is to open on March 12 at the Martin Beck Theater. Previews of the show begin on Friday, with Rebecca Luker as Maria and Michael Siberry as the Baron, directed by Susan H. Schulman. This time, however, the von Trapp children will not all be there to see it.
Sitting down to lunch at the Trapp Family Lodge, a hotel and ski resort that overlooks the Stowe valley, Mr. von Trapp, its principal owner and general manager, talked of his mother and his family tree.
Indeed, it would seem that "How do you solve a problem like Maria?" was more than a lyric. The real Maria, her son says, was "a much more complex person, a more extreme person than Julie Andrews portrayed."
"Everything she did was larger, louder, bigger, faster," he said, working his way through an enormous plate of pinkelwurst, similar to scrapple, piled high on a mound of mashed potatoes. "She was the sort of person who when she walked into a room, everyone stopped talking and looked at her.
"When the family came to America, their economic survival depended on their staying together. Any influence that might lead off to an individual life was sternly suppressed by my mother. It was like bottling up a volcano. Eventually it blows. But at the same time there was that discipline, which kept us all functioning together. We're still very attached to each other."
Maria Augusta Kutschera came to the von Trapps when she was in her early 20's. Baron Georg von Trapp had been married to Agathe Whitehead in Salzburg, Austria, and they had seven children: Rupert, Agathe, Maria, Hedwig, Werner, Johanna and Martina. (In "The Sound of Music" the names were changed.) After his wife's death, the Baron arranged for Maria, a novice at the Nonnberg Abbey, to teach and care for the children, especially his daughter Maria, then 5, who had had scarlet fever.
The Baron and Maria married in 1927 and had three children: Rosmarie and Eleonore were born in Salzburg, Johannes in America.
The family's exodus from Austria, recounted by Maria in her 1949 autobiographical book, "The Story of the Trapp Family Singers," was more complicated than "The Sound of Music" version. In 1934, the von Trapps' bank went bankrupt and the family lost its fortune. To meet expenses, they took in boarders and met Father Franz Wasner, the priest who became their musical director. He helped turn the family's singing hobby into their livelihood as the Trapp Family Choir, performing throughout Europe.
But when Germany invaded Austria in 1938 and the Baron, a decorated submarine commander in World War I, was offered a post in the Nazi Navy, he refused. He and his family left Austria for a purported mountain-climbing holiday in Italy; from there they left for America, where they were booked to tour as the Trapp Family Singers. In 1942, they settled in Stowe, building their home themselves. The Lodge opened in 1950.
MR. VON TRAPP HAS been here ever since. A graduate of Dartmouth College and the Yale Forestry School, he was "going to go on for a doctorate," he said, "but I thought I would first install professional management here." He smiled ruefully. "But professional management didn't want to stay with my family telling them what to do."
He leaned back in his chair. "There are no perfect mothers," he said. "I have no sympathy for people who blame everything on their mother. Having said that," he paused, and his piercing blue eyes filled briefly with tears, "I miss the terrific friendship that we had. It was really wonderful." He blinked. "Part of the time. Other times we had huge battles. She loved to make people happy. She would read about someone in trouble and invite their widow and six children for Christmas. I would say, 'Mother, why not the first week in December when we have no guests?' And she would say, 'Johannes, you don't understand, it's Christmas that's important to children.' And I would say 'That may be, but we need the revenue.'
"Her willpower was incredible. During the summer of '59 Mary Martin was here with a photographer from Life and the photographer wanted my mother up on the slope. She had slippery shoes on, fell and broke her arm. She insisted that I drive her to the doctor, where he set her arm, with no painkillers, and with the cast on she came back up and finished the shoot."
Mr. von Trapp was 8 when his father died in 1947 of lung cancer at the age of 67. "My memories are of a huge man, very gentle, very kind. He always had high expectations. Even at that age I sensed that. 'The Sound of Music' portrayed him as a martinet, and he really was not that. The whistle he used to summon the children was a convenience." He sighed. "I felt bad about Father Wasner being left out of the musical. Really, without his musical and spiritual direction we never would have achieved a level of performance that anyone would have walked across the street to listen to."
Mr. von Trapp's frustration at his family being forever frozen in one moment of movie history has been building for decades. "People really do expect the family to be the ages they are in the film," he said. "Especially their children, and they're very disappointed to find that we're not. I've gotten used to it. I say only half jokingly, if I were the first person to set foot on the moon, people would still say, 'Which one were you in the film?' "
While tea was served, Mr. von Trapp explained what became of his siblings in their post-"Edelweiss" lives.
RUPERT WAS A DOCTOR, a general practitioner, who had six children and lived in Massachusetts. He died in 1992. Agathe still lives near Baltimore, where she ran a kindergarten for years. She never married and neither did Maria, who is 83 and lives about a half mile down the road from the Lodge. She was a missionary in New Guinea who retired in 1987. Hedwig, a teacher, died in 1972. Werner, 81, is a retired farmer who lives in Waitsfield, Vt. He also had six children. Johanna married, had seven children and moved back to Austria. Martina died in childbirth, as did her baby, when she was 28. Eleonore, 66, also lives in Waitsfield. She had six children. Rosmarie, 68, lives there, too. She nursed her mother through a number of strokes during the last years of her life when she still lived at the Lodge, close by to Johannes's two children. The Baroness died in 1987 at the age of 82.
Though the family no longer performs together, Rosmarie leads singalongs at the Lodge twice a week. Does she include songs from the musical? Mr. von Trapp nodded. "She does, much to my, I won't say shame, but to my irritation." Why is that? "Because it's something we never sang," he said. "You know, if Universal Studios owned the place they could turn it into a 'Sound of Music' theme park. That's fine, but it's not what my family was about."
And what was that? He thought a moment. "Good taste, culture, all these wonderful upper-class standards that people make fun of in movies like 'Titanic.' We're about environmental sensitivity, artistic sensitivity. 'Sound of Music' simplifies everything. I think perhaps reality is at the same time less glamorous but more interesting than the myth. There are people who come here and ask why aren't we hearing 'Climb Ev'ry Mountain' on the ski trails? And I say, 'I'm happy to play some Mozart, too. He came from Salzburg as well. Remember him?' "
Salzburg is important to Mr. von Trapp; as he walks through the Lodge he points out paintings and antiques from the city. The original Lodge building burned down in 1980 and was reconstructed in 1983. "Mother was never comfortable in the new hotel," he said, leading the way to a suite of rooms where she had lived until her death. "Here," he said, pointing to a photograph of her. "You can see the vagueness in her face during those last years."
He also pointed out a picture of the other Maria, who lives down the road. "She was beautiful, wasn't she?" he asked. "You don't think about that when it's your sister."
Maybe not, but even at 83, Maria von Trapp is still a beautiful woman. With her white hair braided across the top of her head, she looks like she stepped off a postcard. Her brown eyes are warm and belie her somewhat formal Austrian-accented English. She sat on the couch in the living room of her small house.
"For 'The Sound of Music' they wanted to take some things from our life and make a new story," she said. "I always say they took the raisins out of the dough and made a new dough. First, we were really angry. My father was very fatherly always with his children, especially after my mother died. He taught me the accordion. It was music all the time in the house before the second mother came. My mother, her whole family was musical."
Did she like Maria? She nodded. "When she first came it was heaven on earth," she recalled. "She sang, she knew new songs. We learned the different parts."
Did she want her father to marry Maria? She shook her head. "I loved my mother and I thought he should not marry again. I wanted Maria to stay as a bigger sister. But that was not possible. We never talked about this, of course, we just let it happen.
"When we lost our money we were pushed into the public. My second mother, she smelled the bread and butter if we stayed on the stage. We sang for the people like it was our living room. I enjoyed singing. I always felt a certain peace come over the audience."
It seems that her stepmother's will was formidable. She nodded. "Her plan had to be done. If we were all like her we would have followed our own plans and left. But it was necessary, you know. I really believe everything was arranged by God. That we were so willing to stay together. He wanted that choir. I don't know why. We didn't even aim for going to America. When my father in Salzburg got the offer to go he said, 'I will ask each one if they want to go and if one says no, nobody goes. We stay together.' He really wanted to know if it was in God's plan. So he opened the Bible and where did he hit? It said, 'God speaks to Abraham: Take your family and go into the land I have prepared for you.' That was a real consolation for my father."
Maria was 23 when the family emigrated. It would be almost 20 more years before she started her missionary work. "I had wanted to go to Africa and be a missionary when I was a child," she said. "Then when we were singing I thought maybe this is the mission. When we were in Sydney we met the priest from New Guinea and I felt such a pull. I was already 42 years old when I finally found my real life."
She was there when "The Sound of Music" opened. "They changed the names and ages," she said. "When someone would ask Rupert, who was the oldest, 'Who are you?' he would take his trousers, make a curtsy and say 'I am Liesl.' "
SHE SMILED GENTLY. "People think they are part of the family, they think they know everything from 'The Sound of Music.' And if you say, 'No, that's not true,' they say, 'I don't want to know the truth. I like "The Sound of Music" and that's it.' The nice thing is that it's kept the memory of the family among the people. Everyone loves you, even if they don't know what you really are."
Is it true that she remembers all the signals her father used to blow on his whistle to summon them? She nodded and went to the bedroom, where she found her silver whistle. "Each one had a call," she said, "and there was one that called everyone."
She sat on the couch and started. "For the oldest it was one low, one high." She did it, then went on down the line. When she finished, she laughed in spite of an almost worried look in her eye, since that last call meant she was to come too, a signal she knew to obey. It seemed for a moment she might actually run, threatening the braid to fly behind her. But although she stayed seated, the child flashed by anyway, if only on her face.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 6; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1388 words

HEADLINE: With Stand-Up Comedian, Sparks Fly at 'Rosie O'Donnell'

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
Mornings, Joey Kola is the funny rodeo clown, bounding up and down the stairs, microphone in hand, dancing, joking and doing the wave with the studio audience at "The Rosie O'Donnell Show" in Manhattan. Evenings, Mr. Kola's darker side comes out, venting frustrations and observations about life on the comedy club circuit.
Mr. Kola, 36, is a "blue collar comedian" from North Bellmore, on the edge of stardom. 
 "I'm a Southern State Parkway kind of guy. Sunrise Highway is my home," he said, launching into a routine about Long Island women putting on makeup in traffic, Dairy Barns and cigar aficionados.
At 8:30 on a weekday morning, Mr. Kola, wearing a red polo shirt, jeans and sneakers, is working the ticketholders' line inside the lobby at 30 Rockefeller Center. Thirty million fans watch "The Rosie O'Donnell Show" every day. An additional 180 spectators line up as early as 6 A.M. in the lobby of NBC Studios in Rockefeller Center to be part of the audience.
"Hey guys. How ya doing? Anybody here like 'The Sound of Music?' You do? We got 'The Sound of Music' here today. Like we say on Long Island, it's going to be a . . .," he quips in an exaggerated Long Island accent, using an expletive, to the mostly female crowd waiting to go through security and upstairs to the eighth-floor studio where the show is taped. "Afterward, I'll take you to the diner. You wanna go to the diner?"
While the syndicated program doesn't go on the air until 10 A.M., Mr. Kola starts the show with his lobby antics, fielding questions, cracking jokes and looking for the day's announcer, whom he chooses from the waiting throng.
"The warm-up is integral," Ms.O'Donnell said in an interview after a recent taping. "It sets the tone for the entire show. Every guest who sits down on our show says this audience is so nice and so happy and it's because of him. I always say it's the snack cakes, and that doesn't hurt either." Every member of the audience gets a Ring Ding snack cake and a carton of lowfat milk.
"It's our general philosophy before the show," she said. "He meets them on the line and gets them excited and is kind to them and takes their questions and is always entertaining.
"The people always call and say, I know Joey Kola, can I get to do the opening announcement? Well, if you know Joey Kola you don't need me, because he's the guy. He handles it. I don't have anything to do with it. It's been a blessing and a curse for him."
Mr. Kola and Ms. O'Donnell met 16 years ago on the stand-up comedy circuit. In the early 1980's, Ms. O'Donnell and Mr. Kola often traveled together, singing as they made their way from club to club, performing two or three times a night.
"I was doing stand-up at the East Side Comedy Club and I was the headliner at that time," she said. "He was a brand-new comic, the open mike guy. He came over to me and said: 'How does it feel to have your picture in the paper. My picture was like the size of a stamp, in Newsday, about that big. Your family must feel proud of you. How does it feel? Does it feel good? 'Cause I want to do that one day. I want to be like you. I want to be a headliner.' And I'm like, oh god, kid, shut up."
"So he sort of became a little tag-along kid from that day on," she continued. "I always knew him. He always listened to me. A lot of the other comics didn't. When I got this job, I knew I wanted somebody who had a like mind in terms of what was important. He was the first guy I thought of and I called him up."
While moonlighting for "The Rosie O'Donnell Show" gives Mr. Kola a steady job and benefits, stand-up comedy is his main source of income. Mr. Kola has been the opening act for Robin Williams, Julio Iglesias, David Brenner, Jay Leno and and Robert Klein.
He performs as a headliner at the Brokerage in Bellmore, Caroline's Comedy Club and Stand-Up New York in Manhattan and Rascals in New Jersey. He plays to sellout crowds on weekends at comedy clubs in Milwaukee, Detroit, Cleveland and Chicago.
He has appeared on television on "The Late Show With David Letterman," MTV, VH-1, "Comedy Central," "Showtime Comedy Club" and "The Pat Sajak Show" on CBS. In his 16 years on the circuit, Mr. Kola has done cruise ships, Las Vegas and Atlantic City.
"We've been following him for about three years," said Pat Cipollina of Franklin Square, who, with her husband, John, was watching Mr. Kola's act at the Brokerage on a recent weeknight. "Whenever he's in town or playing at a club, we try to go out and see him," she said. "I think his comedy is geared toward Long Island. I don't think it would go over in Louisville."
Another fan watching the show first saw Mr. Kola on cable television a few years ago.
"I'm Italian," said Karen Rizzo, a mortgage broker from West Hempstead. "He reminds me of my family. He says stuff that just cracks me up. It's so everydayish. It's really funny to hear it from him."
There is a rich history of stand-up comedians on Long Island, many of whom got their start on the local comedy club circuit. Ms. O'Donnell, is from Commack, Jerry Seinfeld is from Massapequa. Rodney Dangerfield is from Babylon, Eddie Murphy is from Freeport and Lenny Bruce came from Bellmore.
Born in Brooklyn, Mr. Kola grew up in Bay Shore and graduated from Islip High School. He says he was the class comedian, not the class clown.
"The class clown runs across the football field nude," he explained. "The class comedian was the guy who talked him into doing it."
He attended Suffolk Community College and graduated from C. W. Post with a degree in economics and finance. He has been married to his wife, Leonora, for 10 years. They have a 6-year-old daughter and a 4-year-old son.
"I'm half-German, half-Italian," he said. "I'm taking over the world, but I'm going to eat first. My stand-up is really about the evil Joey Kola because I get to talk about reality and things that are in the news. Funny people aren't necessarily happy people. I don't want to paint any kind of picture that everything is rosy, no pun intended. My whole act I'm a domestic suburban warrior. All of my comedy is based in anger, but it's harmless."
"I'm very happy, but all of us to some extent are dissatisfied in some way," he continued. "All of us are wounded somehow. Mentally, physically, financially, somehow everybody's wounded. Stand-up comedy is my psychotherapy; that's the way of healing my wounds. I do it because I love it and luckily, it's paying the bills. I'm not a rich man, but I'm a happy guy. I get to go fishing whenever I want, that's my real passion."
Mr. Kola surfcasts for striped bass and bluefish off Jones Beach almost every afternoon.
"My stand-up is my alter ego," he said. "It's the more realistic part of my life. 'Rosie's' a very G-rated show. 'The Rosie O'Donnell Show' is a show about fun. It's very Mike Douglas, it's very Merv Griffin. We want the audience to have fun and raise a lot of money for charity. It works because it's a show that focuses on the 99 percent of society who are really good people in their hearts and really want to get along and have fun together, not the 1 percent that you see on the news and all these other shows hating each other.
"I know what Rosie wants from the audience," Mr. Kola continued. "I know what kind of tone she wants to set. If you get people together in a room and you give them a little music and some entertainment, people put their worries on the side. I tell the audience every morning that whatever problems you have, financial, medical, we all have the same problems. Lose them for an hour of your life and let us take you to Rosieville. And it works. We shoot Koosh balls, we eat snack cakes."
Mr. Kola's interest in comedy began with the family gatherings of his childhood. His biggest influences were his uncle Ralph, his father, his uncle Angelo and his mother.
As children, Joey Kola and his younger brother would perform in front of the family. Years later, he found himself recreating the act in front of strangers.
Ms. O'Donnell would like Mr. Kola to maintain a happy medium between performing and family life.
"I hope he never takes it to the next level," she said. "I always say, 'Joey, you know what, you get a sitcom offer, you tell me how much they're going to pay you and I'll match it.' "

HEADLINE: Rough Navigating Around Bridgeport's Sunken Barges

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE

 BODY:
THE Port Authority of Bridgeport Harbor has a billion-dollar redevelopment project on the drawing board. Hotels, office buildings, museums, cruise ships, high-speed ferry boats and more are in the plans. But the Port Authority and the city's harbor master, Joseph Savino, are occupied with a nagging bit of the past: three barges lie on the harbor bottom, at the mouth of the Pequonnock River, and the National Register of Historic Places must be navigated before they can be removed.
Since the barges sank, in 1974, they have rotted away so that now only a few waterlogged timbers can be seen above the water, and then only at low tide. Below the surface, divers documented gaping holes in their hulls. They are Erie Canal barges, however, among only a few still in existence, and their historical significance has proven to be something of a complication, not for the major part of the harbor redevelopment plan, but for the fringes of it where city officials would like to provide direct access to downtown Bridgeport for boaters. 
 "If I have to leave them there," Mr. Savino said, "it will limit the recreational boating I can get in there." He said he has asked the Connecticut Historical Commission to remove them from the National Register.
John W. Shannahan, director of the commission, has replied that his office appreciates the city's desire for economic and recreational improvements in Bridgeport Harbor and "also acknowledges that the long-term preservation of these vessels will best be accomplished through their relocation."
But relocating them may not be an easy task. Mr. Savino said the three barges -- the Elmer S. Dailey, the Priscilla Dailey and Berkshire No. 7 -- are in such poor condition that he believed they would fall apart if an attempt were made to haul them out. Such a salvage operation would also be expensive, no matter what its prospects for success.
Then too, he asked, "Where am I going to put them? Who would want them?" Enter James Correnti, a graduate student who learned of the barges' existence while studying marine affairs and archeology. Mr. Correnti, whose area of academic study is focused on the management of maritime cultural resources, said the three large wooden barges are of a design typical of the transition between small wooden barges of the 19th century and large, modern metal barges. "They're rare in that case," he said.
Mr. Correnti said the city could attempt to salvage the boats and try to find someone to restore them. Or, if the boats are too deteriorated, videotapes, photographs and documents could be compiled for posterity. Mr. Shannahan, on the other hand, suggested they could be relocated offshore in Long Island Sound as a "marine habitat and underwater archeological preserve."
Either way, Mr. Correnti said, "before anything can be done, a marine archeologist has to do down there and determine if they can be salvaged without breaking up."
Only one of the three barges, the Elmer S. Dailey, built during World War I, ever plied the Erie Canal. The Priscilla Dailey, built in 1929, worked the Champlain Canal, and the Berkshire No. 7, built in 1935, never worked either canal. The three were used to haul bulk cargo along the New Jersey, New York and Connecticut coasts from 1941 until 1972, when they were tied up in Bridgeport.
The boats range in size from the Elmer S. Dailey's 105 feet and 100-ton displacement to the Priscilla Dailey's 111 feet and 311 tons. Only the Elmer S. Dailey was motorized, the result of a retrofit in 1928. The other two were towed by tugs.
In 1974 they sank at their dock, and have rested there ever since. Shortly before they went down, their owner, George W. Koenig (who has since died), had the three vessels placed on the National Register of Historic Places.
Mr. Savino said a recent survey of the barges, done by State Police divers in training, convinced him that they are beyond repair and should be broken up and removed. "I don't dispute that they're historic Erie Canal barges," he said, "but in that condition, nobody can enjoy them or even see them." He is worried the city would be required to recover them whole, which would be expensive as well as difficult.
These aren't the only barges known to be sunk in Bridgeport waters. There are five others, two in Johnson's Creek, an inlet off Bridgeport Harbor, and three in Black Rock Harbor. At a cost estimated at more than $100,000 each, removal "would cost the city almost $1 million," Mr. Savino said. But if it were done, it would provide space for many recreational boat moorings, open up new fishing spots, and avoid the navigational hazard posed from waterlogged timbers breaking from the vessels and floating just under the surface. He noted that the state is considering establishing a fund that municipalities can use to remove sunken barges.
None of the other sunken barges would impede the city's Bridgeport Harbor redevelopment project, which is called Harbour Place. The developer, Alex Conroy, of the Conroy Development Company in Greenwich, said he believed only a project as large as his could succeed. "You can't do it piecemeal," he insisted, "you need to create a new destination."
Mr. Conroy, a resident of Fairfield, said he was familiar with Bridgeport Harbor, and that he had always thought it should be developed. When he talked to prospective business tenants, he said, he found them interested in a large-scale project. He didn't get his chance, however, until October 1996, when Bridgeport and the United Illuminating Company, backed by the state, began a search for a developer for the utility company's Steel Point property. Mr. Conroy's proposal was selected last fall.
The site of a former electricity generating plant, added to other land the Port Authority says it will obtain, encompasses a 50-acre peninsula on the eastern side of the harbor. The peninsula is accessible by large ships, which has been noted in the plan.
The project will cost $900 million to $1 billion, about $200 million coming from the city and the state, and the rest from private investors. The public money will pay for land acquisition, parking and site preparation.
Mr. Conroy said the project would include two hotels, office buildings, a marina and a New England fishing village-style cluster of shops for artists and artisans. Mr. Conroy also said he is planning a conference center with a 2,000-seat ballroom as well as a multiplex theater and other entertainment.
The Discovery Museum, with its art and technology exhibitions, would move there from north Bridgeport, and the city's Board of Education would establish a magnet high school program for teaching boat building. Also planned are high-speed commuter ferry service to Manhattan, and cruise ship service to take passengers to other points in New England and in Canada. A boardwalk is to line the harbor, and an ocean liner -- a "visual centerpiece" for the city says the Port Authority's executive director, Joseph Riccio -- with restaurants is to tie up there.
Since the harbor project was announced, the Port Authority says it has lined up several other companies to join it, including a newsprint recycling plant and the expansion of the Tallmadge Brothers oyster company.
"For years," Mr. Riccio said, "people have said the development of Bridgeport will come through development of the harbor area, and it's finally going to come to pass."
Work is scheduled to begin in about two years, and the project is expected to take six years to complete. The wait gives Mr. Savino time to do something about the three barges.
While some may consider their historic status a nuisance, Mr. Correnti saw poignancy in the designation that their last owner, Mr. Koenig, obtained for them.
"He loved those barges," Mr. Correnti said, "and he had them put on the Historic Register. I believe he cared about them so much he didn't want to see them just waste away. But when the fellow died, nobody cared about them."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In Bridgewater, a Mix of Uses for Old Cyanamid Site

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
IN 1992, American Cyanamid began cleaning up its heavily polluted 565-acre site in the Somerset County Township of Bridgewater under orders issued earlier by the Federal Government.
Since then 140 acres have been remediated and the rest is being or will be cleaned, bit by bit, over time. 
 Now, a plan is being advanced to turn the cleaned portion of the site -- at the intersection of Interstate 287 and Route 28, with access from Route 22 -- into a mix of retail, hotel, entertainment and public uses. It was worked out over the last two and a half years by the township, a private developer and the American Home Products Corporation, based in Madison, which acquired American Cyanamid four years ago.
The township rezoned the site from office use in 1996. But the proposal still must receive final approval from the planning board and Township Council, which is expected this spring.
At that point, the private developer -- the Krame Development Company of Paramus, in partnership with the Price Reit, a Los Angeles-based real estate investment trust -- will begin construction of an $80-million mixed-use center called Bridgewater Promenade on half of the site. It will comprise 625,000 square feet of retail space and 75,000 square feet of hotel or office space.
The $80 million investment includes the cost of site acquisition, which neither side would disclose. But William G. Krame, president of Krame Development, said he had paid a "premium" price.
The other half will be deeded to Bridgewater for use as open or public space, the latter including a new public works complex. In turn the township will transfer 20 acres to Somerset County to build a 6,300-seat minor league baseball stadium.
As the remaining acres, which are zoned industrial, are cleaned and the existing manufacturing buildings are closed and razed, that property will be deeded to the township. A portion, edging the Raritan River, will go to the county's parks commission.
"It all bodes well for the future of Bridgewater," said Mayor James T. Dowden, noting that for years the township had battled with American Cyanamid to clean the site of its chemical-manufacturing wastes. In the short term, he said, the mixed-use proposal puts a portion of the site back to productive use and in the long term gives the township, if needed, a potential "future ratable."
The proposal is indicative of the blending of public and private interests to spur the recycling of old industrial sites. But the time it took to get to this point shows that the development climate is becoming more complex as communities search for ways to diversify their tax bases and address quality of life concerns. Those concerns range from preserving open space to controlling traffic, both of which are issues in the Bridgewater project.
"The plan is structured to be economically viable for us and for the seller while giving back a significant amount of land to the community," said Mr. Krame, the developer. The partners have agreed to make an estimated $5 million in road improvements to accommodate the project.
Mr. Krame called the site's location "phenomenal," adding that there was a void in the market for the "convenient, value-oriented" retail space the project will offer.
THE 625,000 square feet of retail space will be configured as a power center -- defined by the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan as an open-air retail strip with 250,000 to 750,000 square feet of space and three or more big-box retailers.
The focus of retail activity in the township is now the 900,000 square foot Bridgewater Commons Mall, which is to be expanded by up to 750,000 square feet. Bridgewater Promenade, which will not compete with the mall, is moving ahead at a time when the retail market in Bridgewater and central Somerset County is heated.
Eight projects, mostly power centers, are in various stages of the approval process. If realized they could add a total of about 3.6 million square feet of stores into the area, much of it in Bridgewater, according to the Somerset County Planning Department.
Retail brokers say the area could handle more development. They cite demographics. "There has been tremendous housing and job growth in that market," said Jonathan B. Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization, a brokerage in Woodbridge. "But it is underserved in terms of big-box and discount retailers."
Projections are that the county's population will grow to 296,000 by the year 2010, up from 260,790 in 1996, according to county figures.
The county also reports that 2.8 million square feet of office space has been proposed in central Somerset, which means additional shoppers. Much of the proposed new office space is in Bridgewater.
Mayor Dowden said all of the proposed retail projects, along with the mall's expansion, had been planned for and, with additional road improvements by developers, could be accommodated in the 32-square-mile township.
Despite the area's favorable demographics, Mr. Schultz said, there are not enough tenants to fill all the projects. As retailers shop for projects that are in the best locations and likely to be among the first to come to fruition, the other projects will be dropped and reshaped into alternative uses, he said.
The developers of Bridgewater Promenade say they feel timing and location are on their side. That the site is clean and the project is far along in the approval process is an advantage, said Jerald Friedman, senior executive vice president at the Price Reit.
Mr. Krame added that some 242,000 people with an average household income of $81,000 live within a seven-mile radius of the proposed center.
At its peak in the 50's and 60's the former Cyanamid complex was among the largest employers and taxpayers in Bridgewater. In 1983, after it was put on the Federal Superfund list -- made up of sites demanding priority cleanup because of heavy pollution -- Cyanamid begin razing offices and laboratories there. Though there is still some manufacturing on the property, that will end in the next year and a half, said Lowell Weiner, a spokesman for American Home Products.
HE said the site was among the more than 3,000 acres in New Jersey his company took over when it acquired American Cyanamid. He said the policy concerning surplus properties has been to sell or donate them rather than develop them "since we are not in the real estate business."
The current development team was chosen from 18 companies that expressed interest in the site, he added, noting that the mixed-use plan "is the best use to put the property to."
But residents in that section of Bridgewater, known as Finderne, were not so sure. A citizens group called the Finderne Advisory Committee was formed in response to the project to make sure that the traffic it would generate would not over run their neighborhood.
To that end the developers, working with the group over the last year, nearly doubled the amount of traffic improvements they would make to the current level of $5 million.
They include rebuilding a bridge over I-287 and widening the ramps leading to and from it, installing new traffic lights and improving intersections.
Allen F. Krudyla, co-chairman of the group, said his organization supported the improvements and was hopeful that the developers would deliver them. But he said concerns remain over the cumulative impact all the proposed projects could have.
Those concerns are shared by Somerset County's Planning Department. It is now devising a plan to coordinate future development with road and traffic improvement and calls for enhanced mass transit links, said Robert Bzik, its planning director. He said the plan also called for enhanced mass-transit links.
As now planned, Bridgewater Promenade will comprise 12 buildings connected by landscaped pedestrian walkways. Natural buffers will be created throughout the site and around its border to help shield it from Main Street.
It will be home to some 25 tenants, made up mostly of regional and national retailers, occupying 20,000 to 130,000 square feet each as well as smaller shops and restaurants with 3,000 to 10,000 square feet. There will be parking for 3,600 cars.
Mr. Krame said rents per square foot were expected to range from the low to the high teens. The center is to open by the summer of 1999, the same time as the baseball stadium.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Philadelphia's Airport Is a Hub of Development

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
WHEN PNC Bank opened its new operations center across from the city's airport on Jan. 22, it left little space for new construction in the Eastwick commercial/industrial area, just a 15-minute drive from downtown and less than a half-hour from the corporate and financial hub of Wilmington, Del.
The airport itself has beeen an economic magnet in recent years as United Parcel Service and US Airways have built regional hubs there. Flights by US Airways, which also has an international hub there, represent 60 percent of the traffic. 
 About 1,000 PNC Bank employees moved into the $70 million, 280,000-square-foot building's first phase, which processes more than 3.5 million checks and other financial transactions for the Pittsburgh-based institution and other companies. The five-story back-office operation, which has 527-foot-long floors, functions around the clock.
Construction is to begin this spring on the 161,000-square-foot second phase, where as many as 500 more employees will work. The 30-acre PNC Bank site is being developed by Liberty Property Trust under a 17-year lease from the site's owner, Korman Commercial Property.
The site was chosen over others in Pennsylvania and New Jersey because of its proximity to the airport, I-95 and the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said Mark Eyerly, a PNC Bank spokesman.
The site's shape "allowed us to have a horizontal footprint, rather than vertical," Mr. Eyerly said. "Prior to this, we handled items in a Center City high-rise. Items would come in on the third floor, go up to 10 and down to six."
One drawback to the new building's site, said Mr. Eyerly, is a lack of amenities. "We have a very nice cafeteria with a two-story room that looks out over the airport, but once you're in the building it's inconvenient to go out for lunch or go shopping," he said. But, he added, "there's a buzz around town that more hotels and retailers are looking at the employment base there."
The PNC Bank project benefited from $6.5 million in state funds for road and site improvements and job training; $5.3 million in low-interest loans from the city and $5.6 million in city grants for land acquisition and road construction. To accommodate new companies in the area, the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority opened an Eastwick rail station on the line that links downtown with the airport.
PNC Bank has 6,400 employees in its Philadelphia regional headquarters area, including 1,000 at Eastwick, and could add as many as 700 new jobs at the Eastwick center within a few years.
TWO hotels are already operating adjacent to the PNC Bank site and three more are nearing completion nearby, part of an 80-acre site dubbed Airport Interplex. Extended Stay America is adding 140 rooms and will be joined by a 140-room Hampton Inn and a Studio Plus property with 85 rooms, said Jerry Segal, senior vice president of Korman Commercial Properties Inc. Other off-airport lodging includes Embassy Suites, Marriott, Westin and Days Inn.
"These are replacing lots of rooms that were very old, said Mr. Segal. "They can support the convention center because they're so close to downtown with the Eastwick rail station."
Michael G. French, a principal with Coopers & Lybrand LLP in Philadelphia, said aging hotels near the airport and the nearby sports complex have been renovated thanks to capital programs by hotel chains like Promus Corp. and HFS, which recently purchased properties, or chains that own hotels there.
"The airport market in Philadelphia even in the worst of times always operated at healthier occupancy levels than Center City or other surrounding markets, largely because for a long time it was under-supplied compared to other airport markets," said Mr. French.
"In 1991-92, the hotels were being operated by asset managers on behalf of banks or going through restructurings, but even then the airport markets did well. The average occupancy is close to 80 percent, and for that market it's at capacity because things are always soft on Sunday nights. Commercial travelers are increasingly inclined to come in, have a meeting and get out."
In 1996, the Airport Council International reported Philadelphia had 1.6 million inbound and outbound international travelers, a 27 percent gain over the year before. And US Airways, the dominant airline serving Philadelphia, intends to improve both its service and facilities here. Nevertheless, many Philadelphia-area travelers depart from Newark or New York airports because of a limited number of international departures.
Construction is under way in two of the airport's five terminals to add moving sidewalks and a 45,000-square-foot retail mall. In addition, the airport has announced a $300 million expansion of its international terminal. And US Airways has disclosed plans for a new commuter-flight facility, the addition of flights to Amsterdam and increased service to Frankfurt, Rome, London and Paris, among other destinations.
Much of Eastwick is devoted to junkyards, car dealerships and related businesses that stretch for more than a mile along Essington Avenue. CarMax is planning to open a primarily used-car dealership on a 20-acre site, and Dobbs, an airline caterer, built a $7 million facility several years ago.
Pat Green, senior vice president of Jackson Cross/Oncor International, a real estate brokerage, said the disappearance of industrial space in the suburbs had led many manufacturing and distribution companies to Eastwick, where space is much less expensive and is within the city.
Instead of more than $5 per square foot per year for warehouse space in the suburbs, the limited space in Eastwick rents for $3 to $4 per square foot, Mr. Green said. About 26 acres of developable land remains in the area within the city limits, he added.
Eastwick, at Philadelphia's southwest corner at the confluence of the Schuylkill and Delaware Rivers, was largely swampland until a site was dredged to create the airport, starting in 1925. A waterfront parcel was saved at Fort Mifflin, a preserved installation that served in both the Revolutionary and Civil War. The area is dotted with the sights and smells of oil refineries, gas tank farms and a sewage treatment plant.
Less than a mile from the PNC Bank site is the John Heinz Natural Wildlife Refuge at Tinicum, a wooded area with streams and wildlife named for the late United States Senator and heir to the Pittsburgh food company. Canoers and fishermen treasure the secluded spot, directly across I-95 from the airport's runways. Just north of the refuge, near the city's border with Delaware County, is a development of single-family homes and town-house apartments.
Despite esthetic concerns, Eastwick is one of few locations available to companies whose workers rely on mass transit, said George Robinson, president of Henry H. Ottens Manufacturing Company. He is considering moving his factory/headquarters there from its current downtown locationinto a yet-to-be-built structure that shields visitors from the industrial landscape.
"We want to remain in an area that's reachable by all current employees and there wasn't a whole lot of choices because of zoning restrictions," said Mr. Robinson, whose company produces flavorings for food and pharmaceuticals, among other things. "Parts of Eastwick are in the flood plain, so companies building there incur costs above the price of construction. But staying in Philadelphia offers land at one-third the cost of outlying suburbs."
Another long-anticipated boost for the area is the prospect that shipbuilding will return to the now-closed Philadelphia Naval Ship Yard. Kvaerner ASA, a Norwegian conglomerate that includes shipbuilding, plans to take over acres of docks and buildings directly across the Schuylkill River from Eastwick. Current plans estimate 700 jobs at the shipyard, starting in the year 2000.
