SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: Yeas And Nays for Tax-Free Apparel

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
IT was Round 3 in the fight for apparel tax repeal as all of the state's 62 counties and 21 cities -- oops, make that all but 1 of the state's cities -- waived the levy on clothing and shoes selling for under $500 late last month. White Plains, the fashion capital of Westchester, was the sole holdout, disappointing shoppers and infuriating merchants who lost business.
White Plains, however, was not the only municipality to object in principle to the experimental tax holiday, even though the others joined in. Grumbling was heard in many quarters as the seven-day period, a warm-up for the real thing next year, drew to a close. 
 County Legislator Richard G. Wishnie called the tax reprieve a fiasco. Finance Commissioner James LaPerche of Yonkers reported that his city lost close to $500,000 in revenue for the period. And financial experts throughout the state scratched their heads, wondering how to make up for the vanished tax dollars.
In White Plains, Councilwoman Mary Ann Keenan said that very simple arithmetic dictated the city's decision to continue collecting its 2 cents worth on every dollar while other municipalities forfeited their sales tax and the state gave up its 4 percent. Common Council members realized they could ill afford to sacrifice an estimated $250,000 in revenue for the Jan. 17-23 period.
As Mr. Wishnie, the chairman of the Board of Legislators' Committee on Budget and Appropriations, observed: "When you reduce one tax, you often have to increase another. It's like giving with one hand and taking with the other."
Estimates are that the county lost between $750,000 and $1 million during that week by forfeiting its 1.5 percent sales tax on apparel under $500. If the sales tax is permanently lifted, those numbers would soar, the Legislator said.
"I appreciate that getting rid of the sales tax on selected items will help New York retailers compete," Mr. Wishnie said. "But what benefits one segment of the economy can hurt another. The loss isn't budgeted for, and it comes on top of a county budget that's already underfunded."
In Yonkers, where the sales tax is 2.5 percent, Commissioner LaPerche said that a survey by the New York State Association of Counties projected that Yonkers would lose $3 million a year when the tax proposals take effect. To compensate for that loss on the tax rolls, the city would have to raise property taxes about 2 percent, or $80 a year on an average tax bill.
In Mount Vernon, where the local tax is also 2.5 percent, Finance Commissioner Howard Rattner worried that the city, anticipating new mall development, stood to lose revenues when the tax proposals take effect. But he said: "We're keeping an open mind. We'll have to see what the final numbers are."
In an effort to compete with New Jersey and Connecticut, which offer tax breaks on apparel sales, the New York State Legislature voted last year to abolish the sales tax on clothing purchases under $100 beginning in December 1999. The experimental weeks -- two last year, one so far in 1998 -- were a trial run.
Some officials, like Mayor Rudolf W. Giuliani in New York City, are not only pleased with the results so far but are also pushing for the repeal to apply to purchases of up to $500.
Merchants, too, extolled the virtues of the tax reprieve. Lydia Howie, marketing director of the Jefferson Valley Mall in Yorktown Heights, described retail activity last month as unbelievable.
"We were packed. They came out in droves," she said, observing that business at the Macy's, Sears and 105 specialty shops was up more than 20 percent over a typical January week. "It was more like two weeks before Christmas."
Unfortunately, the opposite was also true. While retail activity was brisk throughout most sections of the county, it looked much like any other lackluster January shopping week in upscale suburban White Plains -- home to a Bloomingdale's, Nieman Marcus, Saks Fifth Avenue, Macy's, Tiffany and Nordstrom, to name but a few of the big-name stores there.
"Our merchants kept a stiff upper lip, even though there was plenty of resentment and disappointment," said Paula Kelliher, a spokeswoman at the Galleria at White Plains, where J. C. Penney, Macy's and 150 specialty shops struggled to compete with malls in cities like Yonkers, which canceled the local sales tax.
At Limited Too, a children's clothing store in the Galleria, Judith Lundy, a manager, said: "It's absolutely a down time after Christmas. We needed the boost."
At Contempo, a women's clothing store in the mall, Tiwana Floyd, the manager, reported that sales were up "but not as much as we hoped for."
At another White Plains mall, The Westchester, Robert Guerra, the general manager, was more than a little piqued with the city. "Frankly, it has been a tough week because of their decision," he said. "White Plains made things very difficult for us."
Even though The Westchester offered free parking and discount coupons, and many merchants like Banana Republic and Williams Sonoma "ate the local 2 percent sales tax," Mr. Guerra said business was flat.
He explained that many shoppers assumed White Plains was charging the full sales tax -- its levy and the state's -- and stayed away in protest. Some White Plains merchants fought in vain to dispel that notion, reminding shoppers that they would absorb the sales tax. They took out advertisements and attempted to reassure edgy consumers.
In most sections of the county, however, consumers shopped heartily, and merchants, who have long complained about the better tax deals in Connecticut and New Jersey, cheered in response. As Elmire Zamis, a college student who was shopping last weekend, said, "There are the same stores, the same merchandise, so why not the same tax benefits here as in New Jersey? The tax hiatus, she added, "gives me the opportunity to shop closer to home."
In most ways, shoppers -- except perhaps some in White Plains -- were pleased with the tax-free week. Many said they had saved their Christmas gift money for the occasion. Others said they were grateful for an excuse to go to the malls and beat the mid-winter blues.
"It's getting me out of the house at a time of year when I usually don't shop," Maryanne Karaman, a dental assistant from Yonkers, said.
In answer to critics who oppose the tax breaks, claiming it diminishes revenue sources, proponents say that localities more than make up the difference in other sales taxes collected when shoppers visit an area and spend on gas, food and other taxable items.
"The localities make up for it in increased traffic," said Ted Potrikas, vice-president of the Retail Council of New York, a trade association and lobbying group in Albany.
"Let's face it, the majority of shoppers will drive to the best bargain. They're a mobile bunch of consumers who don't hesitate to jump in their car and go someplace else."
Last January, there were several holdouts among the local taxing powers during a levy-free week. This year, he observed, only White Plains balked.
"From a marketing point of view, White Plains was a pain in the neck," he said. "But sometimes, you just can't fight City Hall."

HEADLINE: New Supermarket Aids Mount Vernon Corridor

BYLINE: By F. ROMALL SMALLS 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
RECENTLY residents of this city and those of Pelham, New Rochelle and parts of the Bronx witnessed the opening of the largest Shop Rite Supermarket in Westchester. The 70,000-square-foot, hilltop store is the latest single project in redeveloping the Sanford Boulevard business corridor.
To celebrate the opening of the market, which is on the former site of the Westchester Regional Service Center of the United States Postal Service, Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon and Joseph V. Fisher, president of Big V Supermarkets, parent company of Shop Rite, were hosts at a black-tie, pre-opening party inside the huge building. 
 Amid sounds of classical music and hundreds of well-dressed guests, the two men talked about the all-in-one services and potential economic impact of the $10 million installation on the local economy.
"We have six other stores in Westchester, and we believe that this one area in Westchester was really underserved," Mr. Fisher said. "We believe that this type of state-of-the-art store, a Shop Rite Fresh Market, gives the consumer of today what they are looking for, which is more than just a Shop Rite."
Mr. Fisher pointed out what he called the marketplace cafe, which encompasses a large fresh-produce center with more than 450 varieties of fruits and vegetables. In the food court with its grouping of tables and chairs are a bakery, a delicatessen and places to buy Chinese and Italian food and oven-baked pizza.
The Mount Vernon Shop Rite is the first of its kind in Westchester operated by Big V Supermarkets and the largest of the chain's 32 stores. The center will also have a video rental store, a pharmacy and a full-service bank. This all-in-one approach to consumer shopping is a growing trend across the United States, Mr. Fisher said.
After the Postal Center and an Edwards supermarket down the street closed, there was a large gap in the city's revenue and an outcry for a replacement market, Mayor Davis said. "There was a big clamor about the area being underserved in terms of supermarkets. We have now satisfied the market with the opening of Shop Rite." The former Edwards location is now a CVS Pharmacy.
To develop the sprawling site vacated by the Postal Center, Mayor Davis called on the property's owner, Sal Pepe of the Bianco & Pepe construction concern, a personal friend. After zoning changes were obtained, an agreement was made with Big V Supermarkets, and the project was finished in a year.
Approximately 200 new jobs are being provided. Many employees come from the local area and were recruited through a job-referral bank set up at the Mount Vernon City Hall.
"When you bring people into the area, they spend in other places," Mayor Davis said. "So what we are doing is developing the Sanford Boulevard corridor so that other things can come in. We are working on a 14-screen movie theater right now, and we are also redeveloping Memorial Field Stadium."
The Mayor said he hopes that the stadium will house professional soccer and baseball teams. He cited the opening last year of an ice skating rink built to National Hockey League standards as another example of how the city is redeveloping the Sanford Boulevard area into a major retail and entertainment district.
During the Shop Rite grand opening on Jan. 3, cars entered and left the supermarket, which overlooks a tree-lined residential neighborhood. Shoppers were greeted at the door and were given many product samples. Business was brisk, and the parking lots were full.
Some customers had complaints. The entranceway, which one woman described as fortress like, has no pedestrian walk, forcing people to amble up a long, two-way road.
The added traffic on the boulevard is also raising concern. Some residents say there is a need for some type of traffic control along the busy thoroughfare. Mayor Davis said that both of the problems would soon be taken care of.
The feeling among many Mount Vernon residents and community leaders was that the Shop Rite Supermarket is an example of the city's continued growth and development. Mayor Davis said: "The city is definitely alive and exciting. This city is going to live up to its potential."
Big V Supermarkets said it was planning to open other Shop Rites in Somers and either Ardsley or Hastings-on-Hudson.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/North Stamford, Conn.;
In a Bustling City, a Rural Haven

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
UNLIKE most rural areas of Fairfield County, North Stamford has the best of two worlds: deep country with a vibrant city just a short drive away.
Stamford's urbane downtown, fully emerged from an identity crisis dating back to urban renewal in the 70's, is now established as the business, entertainment, financial and shopping hub of Fairfield County. 
 Rural North Stamford, which stretches from the Merritt Parkway north, east and west to Stamford's borders, comprises one third of its 40 square miles. It was a village until 1949, when it became part of the City of Stamford. A haven of quiet, wooded hills and meadows, punctuated by rock outcroppings, veined with streams and dotted with ponds and lakes, it is entirely residential save for a few grandfathered gas stations, restaurants and food markets, commercial uses that zoning now forbids.
During the early part of this century, when Stamford was a blue-collar factory town, north end real estate was cheap, bought mostly by working people on modest incomes. Beginning in the 20's, many New Yorkers looking for summer homes turned to back country Stamford. Among them were Josh Logan, the theatrical producer; Gutzon Borglum, the Mount Rushmore sculptor; Ezio Pinza, Metropolitan Opera star; members of the Sulzberger publishing family; Vivian Vance, the Ethel Mertz of "I Love Lucy"; Alex Raymond, creator of the "Flash Gordon" comic strip; the actor Gene Wilder; singers Cyndi Lauper and Michael Bolton and Jackie Robinson, the baseball star.
Housing now includes subdivisions of raised ranches and colonials built since the 50's on minimum one- to three-acre parcels, selling for $375,000 to $550,000. Large homes on several acres approach or exceed the $1 million mark; only two houses in North Stamford are currently listed under $300,000, one in a small district of half-acre lots created before the upzoning in 1951.
Multifamily housing is prohibited by zoning, and of the 5,500 single-family homes "there are only 130 available," said Robert Jegier, a local Coldwell Banker broker, "about a five-month inventory given the rapid rate of sales."
Near the city's northern border a National Historic District called Long Ridge Village contains 36 homes and out-buildings dating from 1750 to 1925. Benny Goodman, the clarinetist band leader, lived there for many years. The 165-year-old Long Ridge Tavern was recently restored; it won a three-and-a-half star restaurant rating from The Stamford Advocate newspaper.
Incoming downtown businesses continue to bring new residents like Martin Vahsen, an executive with Citibank in Harrison, N.Y., who will divide his time between Citibank's new Stamford office and Harrison. This month he and his family will move into a 10-room colonial on 1.25 acres next to a bird sanctuary. "It's not cheap, but I got great value and standard of living," said Mr. Vahsen.
Gary Di Silvestri, 30-year-old principal in Di Silvestri Asset Management of Stamford and Geneva, bought a $1.2 million house on 1.5 acres through Juner Properties' Roxbury Road office. It has 5 bedrooms, 4 baths, a gym, a 3-car garage, 2 large entertaining rooms, a wine cellar, music room, media room, maid's apartment and a study.
"I looked from Greenwich to Southport," said Mr. Di Silvestri. "This house was the only one that met European construction standards that matched a custom home I had built in the French Alps."
With existing homes at a premium, new development is accelerating. "Young couples, both working, want new," said Gail Stone of the Long Ridge office of William Pitt Real Estate. "They don't want somebody else's dirt and they don't want major work." Now under construction by North Ridge Associates are custom homes for $900,000 and up on one-acre lots at Heming Way. And Harry Webski is building six homes on Haviland Road, priced from $750,000 to over $1 million. Square footages vary from 3,500 to 5,000 or more.
Residents of north end subdivisions typify Stamford's traditionally feisty citizenry, organizing over the years into some 20 neighborhood associations involved in lobbying for or against issues that affect them.
T HE preservation of open space and the proliferation of cell-phone towers are our major concerns," said Kit Martinsen, president of the North Stamford Association. Now that the city recently added 36 acres to an existing 1,646 acres of open space by buying the former Stamford campus of the University of Connecticut, North Stamford residents want the few remaining large tracts preserved. And they are seeking input into the process of approving sites for more than the two existing cellular phone towers in the area.
The associations are also fighting the expansion of the private Children's School, citing zoning restrictions on commercial properties.
For north end residents, there is a rich mix of cultural and entertainment activities in downtown Stamford. In their own area, attractions include the Stamford Museum and Nature Center -- the former mansion of the late Henri Bendel, the department store owner -- with its restored 18th century barn, animal farm, lake, art and science exhibits and indoor and outdoor concerts. The Nature Conservancy's trails cover 136 acres of woods and fields, and the Bartlett Arboretum offers 62 acres of specimen trees, plants, flowers, and wetlands, plus lectures and guided nature walks.
On Sunday mornings the place for gathering and gossiping is Giovanni's sprawling old market, crammed with high-grade meats, vegetables and groceries. It operates the old-fashioned way, with charge accounts. Giovanni's is also the name of the family's north end steak and seafood house, where Maine lobsters can occasionally run to 18 pounds, serving six people.
An abundance of additional food and household shopping is available south of the Merritt Parkway on High Ridge and Long Ridge Roads, as well as in the 874,000-square-foot Stamford Town Center mall downtown, which is anchored by Saks Fifth Avenue, Filene's and Macy's; there is also a free-standing Lord & Taylor between High Ridge and Long Ridge Roads.
Children in North Stamford attend one of three public elementary schools in the north end, each with about 700 pupils from kindergarten through fifth grade; they go on to Turn of River Middle School and either Westhill or Stamford High School.
Enrollment citywide increased by 25 percent in the last 10 years, mostly at the elementary level in poor downtown neighborhoods, generating a 20-year integration program in which students are bused to north end schools where Spanish-speaking children learn English and English-speaking children learn Spanish. Last June, 87 percent of the high school graduates went on to higher education. The scool's combined S.A.T. score average of 950 last year was well below the state's 1,116 average and the national average of 1,016.
Among north end day private schools is the Mead School on 13 acres, with 230 children from 6 weeks old through 9th grade. Emotional development is emphasized as well as academics and the arts. The pupil-teacher ratio is 5.3 to 1, and tuition ranges from $3,500 to $15,000 a year.
The Holy Spirit Roman Catholic School has 180 students from pre-kindergarten through fifth grade, 40 percent of whom are not Catholic. When appropriate, accelerated or remedial programs are designed for individual pupils. Tuition is $2,540 for Catholics, $3,490 for non-Catholics.
THE Bi-Cultural School offers a strong academic curriculum and a parallel curriculum in Judaic studies to 376 children from kindergarten through eighth grade. It ranked first in a NASA math competition, and at present holds an advanced math class for one student. Tuition is $6,500 to $7,300.
King & Low-Heywood Thomas, a traditional college-prep school on 40 acres that traces its foundation back to 1865, has 635 students from 18 foreign countries and the United States. Up to 20 percent are in special programs for mild learning difficulties. Tuition from pre-kindergarten through 12th grade is $8,000 to $15,000.
Children's School, which takes pupils from 3 to 8 years old, is operated in a manner similar to the Montessori philosophy of letting the child select a particular focus. Tuition ranges from $3,900 to $9,900.
Citywide, a full program of children's and adult baseball, softball and soccer, is run by the Recreation Department. Ice skating at the Terry Conners rink costs $4, children $ 2: it is free, seasonally, on the north end's frozen ponds. A $10 parking sticker admits residents to 3 beaches and a season tennis permit for 45 city courts costs $50. There are also private tennis and swim clubs, and stables that board horses and give riding lessons. Windswept Farm charges $45 for a two-hour trail ride on its horses.
Boating opportunities include the 108-year-old private Stamford Yacht Club. Yacht Haven Marine Center's 650 slips are open to the public for $85 a foot up to 120 feet. The city operates three marinas with a total of 663 slips charging $250 to $1,110 a season for up to 28 feet, and a boat launch for $35 a season plus a $5 launch fee.
The Sterling Farms and E. Gaynor Brennan municipal courses offer season permits of $20, plus daily play for $10 weekdays and $11 on weekends.
Renee Kahn, a north end resident, said that she and her husband, Samuel, "came up from New York 35 years ago when there were remnants of farms."
"Scenically it's still fabulous," she said, "but the reason we chose to live here was and is the interesting mix of old and new houses, and the mix of people socially, racially, ethnically, religiously, that's been historically constant."

RURAL PROGRESSIVES: Predating women's suffrage by 16 years, the Long Ridge Woman's Suffrage Club was founded in North Stamford in 1904, meeting at the home of Susan Thurston Cooper, its organizer and first president. Dues were 25 cents a year. It was, according to John L. DeForest's book, "Once Upon a Long, Long Ridge," "the only such organization in Stamford and one of the few in Connecticut." It was nonpartisan, nonsectarian, dedicated to obtaining information on the legal rights of women as voters and sworn not to support women on the ground of sex only. At that time women in Connecticut could vote on school matters, but, Mr. DeForest wrote, "only 12 females registered and only 5 or 6 voted." As far as anyone knows the club left no records past 1912.

HEADLINE: Derelict Theater, Hope for a Neighborhood

BYLINE: By STEPHEN L. PURDY 

 BODY:
AS with other members of the West End Civic Association, Chris Larsen Nelson was frustrated that the Hartford neighborhood group couldn't reach a consensus on the fate of the Colonial Theater on Farmington Avenue. By last year, the 1,200-seat area cinema, vacant for a decade, had come to symbolize an urban neighborhood in search of itself.
A costume designer by training, Ms. Larsen Nelson all for its renovation. "I've seen the inside of a lot of theaters, and they're in my blood," she said. On the other hand, she understood the group's concerns with other urban issues, like retail decline, traffic and crime, that threatened the once-gracious residential and commercial neighborhood. After all, it was the real estate plunge and her husband's mugging that had brought her to the association in the first place. 
 Gradually though, she and others in the 20-year-old advocacy group, whose individuals, small-businesses and academic institutions claim success in anti-drug education and redevelopment, came to accept that the old theater's and the neighborhood's futures went hand-in-hand. "We realized we couldn't save the building without saving the avenue," said Barnaby W. Horton, a lawyer on the association's executive board.
Then, last year, the building's owner, Philip Schonberger, a developer, received a serious offer from an auto parts business, whose plans included razing the existing structure. "We all went nuts," says Ms. Larsen Nelson.
The West End Civic Association began holding weekly meetings on the Colonial. Mr. Horton advised against confrontation. "A campaign of lying in the streets, when the bulldozers were coming down, wasn't going to work for us," he said. Rather, the group decided to promote the building's physical prominence, sentimental value and, most important, its advocates' grass roots energy.
"This is a neighborhood fighting for itself," Mr. Horton said. "This isn't Donald Trump coming in and developing from outside."
With the help of William R. Breetz, also a lawyer, three association members -- Bob Rulli, a real estate agent; Philip Will, an architect, and Ms. Larsen Nelson -- founded the Colonial Theater Renaissance Corporation last June.
Mr. Schonberger did his part. On June 30, the developer donated the theater and sold an adjacent house on Sherman Street to the new corporation. Though the house was valued at $100,000, Mr. Schonberger took back a $95,000 mortgage on it and Colonial raised the balance. Ms. Larsen Nelson says that, in "passing the hat" at a West End meeting, they raised about $1,200 -- in checks ranging from $10 to $500 -- in 20 minutes.
With these two properties and the hope of more, the new group's goal is a complex for performance, business and housing -- a focal point for neighborhood growth. Mr. Rulli says the corporation has a letter of intent from the Hartford Children's Theater, a drama group and school without a permanent home, to be the complex's principal tenant.
Geoffrey Sheehan, the theater company's artistic director, says the collective neighborhood effort is right for his theater. "We attract families and children from all over the greater Hartford area," he said.
The theater currently exists independent of the public schools, but Mr. Rulli hopes to involve them too. "I would foresee a partnership, offering internships for theater education programs, both performing and technical," he explained.
With a targeted completion date for the fall of 1999, Mr. Rulli envisages a complex that, in addition to a 600-700 seat performing arts theater, will have 29 units of market-rate and 20 of affordable housing, a 5,000-square-foot restaurant, 15,000 square feet of commercial/office space and a parking garage with truck access. Parking, he emphasizes, will make the complex and neighborhood safer.
As active as Colonial is becoming in the West End, it's only part of a series of initiatives along Farmington Avenue, including the Asylum Hill neighborhood. Mr. Will, president of the newly formed Farmington Avenue Business District, sees the theater's proximity to cross streets and Interstate 84 as an anchor to the region. "It's a gateway, into Hartford and the West End," he said. In turn, the Business District and the Asylum Hill Organizing Project link up to the West End Civic Association to comprise the Farmington Avenue Joint Committee. Toni A. Gold, a community investment consultant who convenes the joint committee, says its goals for the street include unifying its two neighborhoods, rezoning and the addition of light rail.
The Colonial Theater, she says, already reflects needed zoning standards such as architectural significance and potential use as anchor to numerous businesses. "It's complementary to the bigger picture," she said. "While the long-range plan could probably go forward without the Colonial, it would be helped a lot by that project."
But Business District member Alyssa Peterson emphasizes it was the Colonial that galvanized businesses. "It wasn't until the 11th hour of the auto parts store that they came out," she said.
Ms. Nelsen Larson suggests Colonial is already providing interest inother vacant buildings in the neighborhood. And Mr. Breetz, who teaches at the University of Connecticut Law School, says the college has created a clinical program for urban revitalization encouraged, in part, by Colonial's efforts.
Mr. Rulli underscores his center will support itself and subsidize its theater, further strengthening the latter's foundation money. In housing especially, Mr. Rulli emphasizes, Colonial will reflect the area's blend of social groups, businesses and educational facilities, owners and renters. "Beyond our project being a cultural center, and an economic revitalization," he says, "it makes people aware of the world around them today." He adds that neighborhood property owners generally live north of Farmington Avenue, renters to the south.
Mr. Will suggests that Colonial can build on the presence of a strong middle class, owners and renters, on both sides of Farmington Avenue.
Colonial is awaiting its initial funding, a $50,000 feasibility study grant which was approved by the state's Department of Economic and Community Development in late December. In addition to this initial boost, the corporation anticipates an extra $10,000 grant from the Hartford Economic Development Corporation, plus $10,000 in Federal Community Block Grant Development money, both for the study. The study, in turn, is critical to obtaining city and state support as well as Federal National Mortgage Association construction funding. Also eagerly anticipated is half of the $500,000 in state-managed Urban Act Funds, applied for by the West End association. The association will turn over $250,000 to Colonial, where its uses will include demolition, asbestos abatement and the installation of temporary parking, facade work basic to Fannie Mae, debt reduction and tax repayment.
In addition, the corporation hopes these funds will help in its acquisition of adjacent properties. In early January, it agreed to purchase the structure immediately east of the theater, and expects a March closing.
The temporary parking lot wouldraise not only cash, Ms. Larsen Nelson emphasized, but also the perception of progress. A self-described optimist, she maintains only good can come out of the project. "In the long run, even if we end up with a tiny, homespun theater that puts on wonderful children's programs, we'll be better off than we are now," she said.
Mr. Rulli has bigger plans. "I'm satisfied," he says, "that once the study is completed, the city and state will appreciate it is a priority project."
With overall cost estimated at $30 million ($10 million for the theater alone), the initial funding and studies are just a start. Colonial, emphasizes Mr. Rulli, must be a combination of public, private and foundation monies. If Fannie Mae financing is obtained, he says, the corporation will pursue both traditional financing and foundation grants based on the presence of a children's theater in an urban area.
Hartford City Councilman Steven Park, also a West End resident, says he has been involved in talks among Colonial, Fannie Mae, the city and state. "Funding is the critical challenge," he says, adding city funding won't help unless it can be leveraged into greater assistance. Mr. Park adds there has been a shift at City Hall, from dictating to the neighborhoods to listening to them. "I try to give the message that this is one of the city's priorities."
The project, Mr. Rulli realizes, will not attract a huge anchor retail chain like the Nordstrom at nearby Westfarms mall. What it will do is boost the block with specialty shops, arts and entertainment, all within walking distance of each other.
Mr. Park cautions that "We're still in the struggling, early stages." Compared to other city neighborhoods like areas of Frog Hollow and the North End, the West End is seen as calm. Still, he thinks the time to move is now. "An urban planner would say it's a place that needs stabilization to prevent it from becoming one of those embattled zones," he explained.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, Not Just a Plan

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: HILLSBOROUGH

 BODY:
When Patricia Curran was growing up near this sprawling township in southern Somerset County, she remembers buying raw milk from the dairy farmer down the road. Towering green cornstalks covered the gently rolling hills. Tractors slowed down the few cars that traveled along narrow country lanes.
"It was all farmland as far as you could see," said Mrs. Curran, 44, who moved to the Belle Meade section from nearby Franklin Township 14 years ago. "It was absolutely beautiful. Now, it is houses. That's it. Houses, traffic, traffic lights. There is no beauty left in this area. The only beauty that is left is over on the west side of the township. If they ever open that up, all the beauty that the people came here for will be gone." 
 Determined to preserve at least part of the community's rural character, Mrs. Curran and other residents banded together two years ago to try to curb development in the township's vanishing countryside.
The group, calling itself the Friends of Hillsborough, is now fighting a developer's proposal to turn 756 acres of farmland just west of Route 206 into a 3,000-unit retirement community. Mrs. Curran said she feared the project would overwhelm the town's already congested roads, drive up property taxes and pave the way for even more suburban sprawl.
Their battle is viewed by New Jersey Future, a nonprofit statewide organization that promotes open space and managed growth, as a test of whether state government is serious about helping shape what New Jersey will look like for decades to come.
Governor Whitman offered new hope to those working to slow suburban sprawl by devoting much of her inaugural address last month to their concerns.
In her speech, which began her second and final term, Governor Whitman vowed to curtail development in rural corners of the state and new suburbs while promoting it in areas where there is existing infrastructure, like roads and sewers.
She promised to direct state money to support development and redevelopment in cities, older suburbs and communities that have been designated "town centers." She further pledged to spend $400 million to help cities reclaim abandoned buildings. And she said the state would preserve 300,000 more acres of farmland and other open space during her next term with an ultimate goal of protecting 1 million acres over the next decade.
Most important, she renewed her commitment to the State Development and Redevelopment Plan. Originally approved almost six years ago, the plan has been largely ignored by the very state agencies that are supposed to depend on it to determine where government dollars should be spent on infrastructure improvements and where they should not, where development should be encouraged and where it should be controlled.
"It is what I have been waiting to hear some governor say for 15 years, and she finally said it," said James G. Gilbert, the former chairman of the State Planning Commission who oversaw the creation of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan adopted in 1992. "I think that she has finally realized that her core constituency supports the notion of an overriding strategic plan for the state so that we do not continue to move in a foolish direction."
Patrick O'Keefe, executive director of the New Jersey Builders Association, sees it differently. He said Mrs. Whitman had only added confusion to a system that already makes it difficult for developers and builders to do business in the state.
"It would be difficult to disagree with the Governor's overall goal of balancing the various demands that are made on the economy and on the state, in terms of development and land preservation," he said. "Where it breaks down is, what the Governor wants and what the plan proposes are almost diametrically opposed. The state plan doesn't work."
 
The War Ended. The Boom Began.
It was not until World War II that municipalities in New Jersey began to use local zoning laws to restrict where houses and businesses could be built. Until then, most New Jerseyans lived in thriving city neighborhoods, small towns or rural villages.
But the new zoning laws had little impact on New Jersey's landscape as the post-World War II boom spilled urban residents into the countryside. With the G.I. Bill of Rights providing returning soldiers with low-cost mortgages, the state's residents dispersed in pursuit of the popular ideal of a house and car in the suburbs. They moved west and south, along suburban rail lines and new highways, transforming sleepy agricultural communities into burgeoning suburbs.
Shopping centers and office parks soon followed. Suburban malls vanquished downtown department stores. The cities began their long decline. In 1940, the state's six largest cities accounted for 33 percent of the state's population. Today, it is 12 percent. Only 3.6 percent reside in Newark, the state's largest city.
New Jersey has had a long history of drawing up statewide plans, beginning in the 1930's, but they were not used to manage growth effectively. Virtually all decisions about development were made by local officials.
There was little consideration given to adopting a more comprehensive regional approach that could have taken account of the broader impact of various development projects on neighboring communities. As a result, roadways became congested. Property taxes skyrocketed to meet the growing demand for public schools. The cities deteriorated while 210,000 acres of farmland disappeared between 1970 and 1995.
Then, in 1985, the Kean Administration and the state Legislature agreed to put together a comprehensive statewide plan.
What New Jersey came up with is not a regulatory document like the growth-management plans adopted by other states. It was never intended to be used by the state as a hammer to halt development. For the most part, land-use decisions remained in the hands of municipalities, in keeping with New Jersey's long tradition of home rule.
Rather, the state plan was envisioned as a way to give state agencies a way to fuel or slow development through decisions on how money from the state's capital budget should be spent and where affordable housing, required under the Mount Laurel decision, should be built.
Take sewers as an example. With them, developers can increase their profits by building at a much higher density on undeveloped land. Without them, their construction options -- and their profits -- are limited. State and local governments restrict the use of one possible alternative, septic systems, because of concern about the impact on ground water and water quality. And those same government officials have the final word on where sewers are built.
Then there are decisions about highways. When the state built Routes 287, 78, 80 and 295 in the 1960's, development followed, opening even more rural regions to residential and commercial building.
"The Interstates demonstrate very clearly what happened," said Candace Ashmun, a longtime environmental activist and member of the Pinelands Commission. "They destroyed the rail system, and just gave us sprawl."
It took almost six years before the state Planning Commission adopted a State Development and Redevelopment Plan in 1992. Officials say it is one of the few state plans that is a "bottom-up" document because it was created after consultation with each of the state's 567 municipalities and 21 county governments.
In the plan, the state seeks to channel infrastructure and new development into "centers," ranging from the state's largest cities to its older suburbs to rural villages. It also seeks to control development in primarily rural areas and in sections of the state designated "environmentally sensitive."
State agencies were supposed to change their policies, and regulations, along with their budgets, to help support the plan.
But that did not happen right away, and some would argue, it has not happened at all. It was not until two weeks before Gov. Jim Florio left office in 1994 that he issued an executive order, directing state agencies to conform with the plan.
Even now, senior Whitman administration officials acknowledge that the plan has pretty much gathered dust, sitting on a shelf, for the last four years. They say it has been disregarded in the development of zoning ordinances by too many municipalities and in decisions on spending by state agencies.
"What we concluded is that they are implementing the state plan, at the margins," said Barbara Lawrence, executive director of New Jersey Future, a nonprofit organization that was formed in 1987 to promote the plan and growth management policies. "The heart of their programs, from capital spending to regulatory programs, have not been touched by the state plan. In each case, the department gives out small grants to promote it. That's lovely. But that's not enough."
Ms. Lawrence said she was heartened by Mrs. Whitman's promise to direct state government agencies to use the state plan as their "fundamental guide." But she said that much remains to be done before it is used effectively.
"It is not written as a document that can be readily translated into a yes or no," she said. "It is a filter through which other things have to pass. That is a lot of work. It will require each department to use the state plan in a much more sophisticated way."
Mrs. Whitman chose her words carefully in her speech. She never said that the plan would be used to block development. But she said that her administration would expedite permits and other approvals for developers and towns as long as their projects are in areas that the state plan recognizes as appropriate for development. That does not mean, however, that her administration would necessarily oppose development in an area designated, for example, as "rural." Those projects would just fall to the end of the line during the approval process.
Mr. O'Keefe, who represents the builders, said that Mrs. Whitman's inaugural address only further muddled an already confusing and complex process for developers.
"The plan has been on the books for five and a half years," he said. "No matter which way you go, the plan is not working. Throughout her first term, Governor Whitman had the plan on the books. Her speech implied that it is working. Yet her agencies say they are not using it. They will do it sometime in the future; therefore, they are contradicting the Governor. The citizenry has no way to know how the laws are being interpreted and how decisions, like permitting decisions, are being made."
The Governor's renewed commitment to the state plan is certain to prompt a flurry of lawsuits and perhaps debate in the Legislature over the role that statewide land-use planning should play in New Jersey.
Assemblyman Gerald J. Luongo, a Republican who is mayor of Washington Township in Gloucester County, said that he intended to introduce legislation giving municipalities more power to impose a two-year moratorium on development projects if local officials determine that their schools, roads and other municipal services just can't handle any more new residents. He said that some communities embrace development without recognizing the huge costs over the long term, particularly the effect on property taxes.
The spotlight that Mrs. Whitman shone on the state plan also raises questions about how aggressive New Jersey should be in shaping its future.
Do taxpayers want to give the state more power to rein in suburban sprawl and protect open space? Are they willing to give up some local control of their communities? Do they want to limit the options that the market now offers them about where they can choose to live? How does the state provide equity to farmers and landowners who want to sell their property to developers at a price that farmland preservation programs can't offer? If the state is encouraging redevelopment and sending infrastructure dollars back to cities and older suburbs, how can their public schools and other services be enhanced to attract more young families? And what about the economic impact on construction workers and others whose livelihoods depend on continued growth?
"When it comes to the development of areas around the state, you have to balance the economic realities with what we have," said Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican who lives on a farm in rural Salem County. "I could support the total shutdown of development around me because I love my life. I love that all of this is going on around me. That's nice to say because I have a teaching job. What about the jobs that depend on a further economic expansion?"
Mr. Collins said that he welcomes Governor Whitman's vision and her plan to speed up permits and approvals for those areas that have been designated to be appropriate for further development. "We do have a plan that needs to be responded to. But to go further, to put some teeth in it, then you need the Legislature. I don't know if that would happen."
In Hillsborough, the Governor's words offered new hope to citizens who are concerned about protecting their community's rural character. But it is unclear what impact Mrs. Whitman and her administration will ultimately have on what their town will or will not become.
New Jersey Future, the advocacy organization, filed a lawsuit last year that challenges a decision made by a state agency, the Council on Affordable Housing, in support of a portion of the project that many here oppose. That state decision bolstered the developer's efforts to one day make the 3,000-unit retirement community on Mill Lane a reality.
"We chose it to take a stand because you can see the role of the state agencies when the state agencies are not following the state plan," said Ms. Lawrence, who heads New Jersey Future. "Since the real teeth in the state plan is having state agencies abide by it, here is a case, where you can say state agencies are not abiding by the plan, and here are the consequences."
 
756 Acres And the Bottom Line
Ninety-five percent of the 756 acres of farmland under consideration for the project is designated "rural" under the state plan, which recommends that such property be protected from high-density development.
To help win early support for the proposal from the township committee in 1991, the developer promised that the complex would include 160 units of affordable housing, meeting the town's requirement to provide such housing under the Mount Laurel decision.
The Council on Affordable Housing approved the affordable housing component of the township's plan, even though the new units would be built on land designated "rural" and did not conform with the state plan. The lawsuit, brought by New Jersey Future, argues that the council violated its own policies by approving a project inconsistent with the state plan. The courts have now sent the matter back to the council for another review.
Township officials, over the years, have waffled on their support for the development. Last year, they withdrew their recommendation that sewers be extended onto the property. So the developer, U.S. Homes Corporation, the fifth-largest home builder in the nation, has filed its own request for sewers with the state Department of Environmental Protection. Its decision is expected in the next few months. Without sewers, the project is dead.
Meanwhile, the debate has created divisions between some of the township's newer residents and some of the older ones, particularly those landowners who want to sell their farms to the developer. There are five different farmers and landowners who have decided over the years to combine their 756 acres to sell for development of the retirement community.
Many of the farms have been in the same family for generations.
"They would like to have it for nothing," said Richard Doyle, 83, about the residents who want him to keep the 175-acre farm that has been in his family for five generations. "Pretty much, that's what it adds up to."
Mr. Doyle, who decided to sell a decade ago, said that he and other farmers in the area can no longer earn enough money by cultivating the land, while selling it would insure financial security for him and his three grown children. He said he liked the idea of his land becoming a retirement development so older residents would have an option to remain in Hillsborough.
"I was trying to keep open space as long as I could," he said. "But you can't earn enough from the farm. Your insurance is high. The taxes are high."
For now, it is a waiting game on both sides. The citizens group is closely watching whether the state will approve the sewer expansion. In the meantime, Gregory A. Snyder, president of the New Jersey division of U.S. Homes, said his company was drawing up blueprints and maps to pursue further town and state approvals. Mr. Snyder would not discuss what his company had agreed to pay for the land. But town officials estimate that the market price ranges from $5,000 to $20,000 per acre.
Describing what he believed the project would bring to Hillsborough, Mr. Synder said: "It allows residents of Hillsborough to be able to move from larger homes and enjoy a home in a community with recreation centers, clubhouses, social activities, exercise rooms, and an indoor-outdoor pool. As far as the benefits to the township, once this community is built out, because of the age restriction -- 55 and over -- it will produce no children, but the tax revenues will be there."
Brett A. Radi, mayor of Hillsborough, said he could not comment on the matter because it is in litigation. He said he did not know whether the township committee and planning board would ultimately approve the project, even if the state did allow the sewer expansion.
Mrs. Curran said she doesn't want to see the farmers hurt financially. But she asked whether government dollars should be used to significantly increase the land's value by putting in sewers and making other infrastructure improvements. And she wondered why the state would grant such approvals when the state plan seems to recommend otherwise.
"I am not telling the farmers what they can and cannot do," she said. "They have their rights. But they also have to follow the laws."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 881 words

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
A Real-Life Toy Story, Animated Nonetheless

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
FEBRUARY is a big month for toy makers -- a time to wheel, deal and show their stuff at shows like the American International Toy Fair, held annually in Manhattan. So it makes sense for G. Wayne Miller to start his story of Hasbro Inc. at a toy show held two years ago this month, when the company was at a crossroads of sorts.
"Toy Wars: The Epic Struggle Between G.I. Joe, Barbie and the Companies That Make Them" (Times Books, $25), begins at a 1996 toy conference buzzing with the news of Mattel's attempted merger with Hasbro, the Pawtucket, R.I., parent of G. I. Joe and Mr. Potato Head. Then the book draws back the curtain to show how Hasbro -- and the toy industry -- got to that point. 
 Ignore the subtitle. Mr. Miller, who writes for The Providence Journal-Bulletin, doesn't really give equal time to both Fortune 500 companies. He concentrates on the home team, Hasbro, which granted him generous access. Nor is the struggle to rule toyland really "epic" here.
But while the drama is a bit forced, the narrative isn't. This is an absorbing, lively chronicle of a family-owned company and its inanimate offspring -- some famous, some flops. It's also a look at changing notions of how children should play, and the marketing deals that determine what children will clamor for.
Hasbro began early in the century as Hassenfeld Brothers, after Hillel and Henry Hassenfeld were persuaded by pogroms to leave their Polish shtetl in 1903. The two settled in Rhode Island, lured by its history of religious tolerance. They made pencil boxes and, eventually, the pencils that went inside them. By the time Henry's son took over in 1943, the company had branched out into toy nurse and doctor bags and cosmetics boxes for little girls. The signature toys began showing up in the 1950's, when Hassenfeld became Hasbro and bought Mr. Potato Head from a Brooklyn inventor; back then, the toy required a real potato.
Mr. Miller is entertaining and informative in writing about this and Hasbro's subsequent hits and flops: We learn that Flubber, a bouncy substance introduced in 1962 after a Disney movie, failed because it caused rashes. The problem had not surfaced during safety tests on inmates at Alcatraz.
G. I. Joe, a hit the next year, was never to be called a "doll," even internally, and was advertised as a miniature composite of real-life Medal of Honor winners. In fact, the author says, the model was "a good-looking but otherwise ordinary guy."
There is also an accounting of more recent Hasbro toys that came from the factory floor, as well as from acquisitions and licensing deals -- a rare chance to read about grown men strategizing earnestly over products with names like "No More Boo Boos Betsy."
The book is also a family saga, with a focus on the two modern-day Hassenfeld brothers: Steve, who modernized the company's inventory, cash-flow and product strategy after he took over in 1974, and Alan, 49, who became chief executive after his brother died in 1989. (The author describes affectingly Steve's secret, brave battle with AIDS.)
"Toy Wars" also looks at America's increasing tolerance for violent toys and the movie and fast-food links that dominate the industry.
This engagingly written book is marred somewhat by its jump-cut organization: the numerous flashbacks, thumbnail biographies of minor characters and asides-within-asides. All this dilutes the Hasbro-versus-Mattel drama, as the two giants fight for licenses, markets and dominance in toyland. But while the denouement falls rather flat, with Mattel withdrawing its 1996 stock-swap bid after a short time, the details are well told. We're there for the hostile faxes, the harried meetings and the relief afterward, when Hasbro executives joked that they survived "Barbies at the Gate."
 
FROZEN ASSETS February is also the month of the World Economic Forum in the mountains of Switzerland. The perfect time -- as top executives and bankers schmooze and ski with world leaders -- to settle in with a novel about Swiss banking.
"Numbered Account," by Christopher Reich (Delacorte, $24.95), a smart and sophisticated financial thriller, will more than make up for the fact that your invitation to Davos got lost in the mail.
Talk about following the money. Nick Neumann, a Harvard Business School star, takes a job at a Zurich bank to unravel the financial threads that led to his father's murder years earlier. Meanwhile, a mysterious account-holder, his identity protected by Swiss law, is transferring cash -- and depositing corpses -- around the globe. As drug enforcement agents lean on the bank to give up its secrets, as Nick searches the bank's archives for answers and as a rival bank threatens a takeover, the plot elements commingle smoothly.
The author, who once worked in Swiss banking, creates a wonderfully credible premise, in part by providing a primer on how "numbered accounts" work. But he is also at home with the demands of his genre: the tough-guy hero (Nick is a former Marine), the depraved villain, the international intrigue.
The action moves swiftly and satisfyingly through Zurich and Beirut, with greed, sex, betrayal and murder mussing up everybody's business suits. And how often do you read a thriller that ends with an annual meeting?

SECTION: Section 14; Page 2; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 767 words

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.

BYLINE: By DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:

Fur-Coated Cinema
 
Q. What was the name of the strange movie theater on the East Side that featured "love seats" when it opened many years ago?
 
A. It was called the Park Avenue Theater, and opened in 1946 with the film "Anna and the King of Siam." It was one of the few movie theaters ever to operate on Park Avenue. 
 Lying on the east side of the avenue between 59th and 60th Streets, the 587-seat theater was, according to a news release, "subservient to the principles of luxury and comfort of the same order the prospective clientele enjoys in its own home."
Foremost among the Park's dubious luxuries was the smoking mezzanine, equipped with 125 love seats designed to accommodate two people in "homelike lounge-chair comfort." Instead of vulgar advertisements, the lobby was adorned with "sculpture, rare jewels, ceramics and glass, as well as paintings." The lounge area had tables for backgammon, gin rummy or bridge, and in the ladies' lounge, a beauty technician, trained by Charles of the Ritz, aided patrons in "the art of makeup."
Best -- or weirdest -- of all, the Park Avenue Theater offered "seats without waiting," which it somehow sold by subscription a year in advance. Each patron received a plastic ID card with a seat number engraved on it, and upon arriving at the theater simply took the appropriate place in the auditorium.
The Park's self-conscious excesses were a dismal failure. Within a year, the subscription plan was abandoned and the theater was sold, said Richard J. Sklenar, director of the Theater Historical Society of America in Elmhurst, Ill. In the late 1950's the theater was still doing business, he said, showing low-budget films made by Universal International Pictures.
 
Classical Medicine
 
Q. The upper sections of four monumental Corinthian columns, each about seven feet tall, sit in the courtyard outside the men's shelter at Bellevue Hospital. Why?
 
A. The weathered capitals are all that remain of the Cornell University Medical College building, which stood across First Avenue from Bellevue from 1900 until 1968. "I salvaged them," said Dr. Arthur Zitrin, an emeritus professor of psychiatry at New York University School of Medicine, a Bellevue affiliate.
Designed by Stanford White, the Renaissance-style building at East 28th Street and First Avenue was occupied by Cornell until 1932 and by the N.Y.U. School of Medicine from 1933 until 1955, when Dr. Zitrin studied there. N.Y.U. was followed by an unlikely succession of tenants, including a training school for flight attendants. It was leveled in the Bellevue South urban renewal.
Contemplating the rubble in 1968, Dr. Zitrin noticed that the upper sections of eight tall columns -- which had stretched across the First Avenue facade -- had survived the demolition. With Dr. Arthur C. Fox, a fellow alumnus, he arranged with the demolition company to extract four. The six-ton relics were transported to the courtyard of what was then the Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, where Dr. Zitrin was director.

Electricity on the F Train
 
Q. Last Saturday, as I rode the F train, I noticed that the conductor spoke in an uncommonly seductive voice, smooth and velvety, with the hint of a French accent. When he whispered "East Broadway," some women in my car looked as if they were going to faint. Can you tell me who the voice belongs to?
 
A. Antoine D. Mingot. He works from noon to 8 P.M., Saturday through Wednesday, making two complete trips on the F train from Coney Island in Brooklyn to Jamaica, Queens, and back. He spoke French and Creole while he was growing up in Jacmel, in southern Haiti, and learned English after he arrived in New York in 1977. He does not sing.
After Mr. Mingot started working as a conductor for the Transit Authority six years ago, he noticed that his voice -- which might be described as a blend of Teddy Pendergrass and Yves Montand -- had a disconcertingly amorous effect on many of his passengers.
"At first I thought it was something about the P.A. system," he said modestly. Now, even when he is far from the F train and out of uniform, people recognize his voice, though his accent seems to confuse them. "They think that I'm German, French, Israeli . . . Swedish," he said.
Mr. Mingot is somewhat abashed by the effect of his voice, and insists that its so-called seductive qualities are entirely unintentional. "I'm not trying to be sexy," he said. Mr. Mingot lives with his wife, Rosaline, in Valley Stream, N.Y., and they are expecting the birth of their first child. DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

Bye-Bye Pants, Hello Lounge
Plunging into the current of his neighborhood's gentrification, Joseph Lipstein closed his men's clothing store, Pants World, at 222 East 14th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, and opened the 222 Lounge at the same location a month ago. 
 The lounge seats 75 people and has six beers on tap. In what he described as "an uptown look on the Lower East Side," Mr. Lipstein furnished the lounge with sofas, two decorative fireplaces (one of which holds a jukebox) and seven-foot palm trees in the back.
"Small mom and pop stores like the one I had are disappearing and have no way of staying alive in New York," Mr. Lipstein said with a sigh. After 21 years in business, he found it impossible to compete with Bradlees, Kmart, Gap and other chain stores that have been moving into the neighborhood.
Mr. Lipstein's family immigrated from Cuba in 1961 and shortly thereafter his grandfather, father and uncle opened the family's first store on the block, Herman's Shoe Store, at 224 East 14th Street, which closed in 1984.
 
Bringing Back the South Bronx With Burgers and Fries
The South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, or Sobro, has teamed up with the McDonald's restaurant chain to build two restaurants in the South Bronx. Construction began in mid-January on a McDonald's at 19 West 183d Street, at Davidson Avenue, in University Heights, in a building built and owned by Sobro. The restaurant is to open next month. In December, McDonald's signed a lease on an empty lot, which the development corporation bought from the city, at 164th Street and Third Avenue in Morrisania. McDonald's plans to begin building next month, pending the receipt of a Buildings Department permit.
Sobro was founded by six New York banks in 1972, "when the Bronx was burning, to stem the tide of business flight," said Bill Bollinger, the corporation's assistant vice president for planning and development. The organization has bought or leased and developed several South Bronx properties for industrial, commercial and residential uses.
 
Two Partners From Egypt Offer Upscale Pizza
Pizza by the slice has yielded to designer pies with the opening of Giorgio's Pizza at 38 Union Square East, between 16th and 17th Streets, three weeks ago.
Among the specialties are pizza topped by portobello and shiitake mushrooms, and goat and gouda cheeses baked in a brick oven. The place was formerly Prima Pizza, a standard pizza place.
This is the second Giorgio's, owned by Mohamad Albakry and Adnan Hassan. They also run the Giorgio's at Second Avenue and 70th Street, with the same concept of brick oven pizza served from the counter. The partners, originally from Egypt, met while working at a restaurant in the Netherlands and embarked for the United States eight years ago.
"Everyone outside America has the American dream," Mr. Albakry said. "That's what happened with us."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: VINEGAR HILL;
The 2d Battle of Vinegar Hill

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Once an enclave for Irish immigrants, Vinegar Hill is named for a battle site in Ireland. That seems appropriate, given that during the last five months, this tiny, cobblestoned waterfront district between the Manhattan Bridge and the old Brooklyn Navy Yard has been shaken by a battle of its own.
On its face, the combat has been over whether to change zoning in the area, where quaint, historic residences coexist with manufacturers and warehouses, from primarily manufacturing to primarily residential, as the City Planning Department proposes. But the combatants say it raises larger issues about the city's future: how to balance livelihoods and quality of life, whether to focus on residential space or manufacturing, and how to preserve history and character while protecting and promoting commerce. 
 Vinegar Hill is roughly nine square blocks, with perhaps 225 residents and about 19 commercial or manufacturing buildings, as well a sprinkling of mom-and-pop stores. A year ago, the neighborhood was named a historic district, a move that followed the destruction of several local historic buildings by businesses wanting the lots for commercial purposes. One particular demolition, of a 135-year-old church by Tocci Brothers, a waste-treatment company, angered residents.
"We are in danger of losing the neighborhood to the waste industry," said Margo Hirsch, who, like most Vinegar Hill residents, supports rezoning.
Paul Tocci, the president of Tocci Brothers, said he thought he was doing the neighborhood a favor when he tore down the abandoned, decaying church. He now uses the lot for equipment storage, but city officials said the rezoning was motivated in large part by the fear that Tocci Brothers would start treating waste on the lot, across the street from a row of historic houses.
Mr. Tocci said he felt residents were trying "to impose their will on our properties." Other business owners expressed concern that the rezoning would limit their ability to expand and limit the resale potential of their properties.
On Jan. 21, the City Planning Commission voted in favor of a modified rezoning plan that redrew the boundary slightly and created a manufacturing island in the center, removing several businesses from the residential zone. Mr. Tocci's lot was left in the residential zone.
"We bent over backward to accommodate business concerns," said Joseph B. Rose, the City Planning Commissioner. The goal, Mr. Rose said, was to "maintain the balance that has historically existed in this community, which mixes residential and industrial uses in a harmonious way."
Last week, however, neither side seemed particularly happy with the compromise. Some residents said they were disappointed by the residential zone's smaller dimensions.
The rezoning plan must still be approved by the City Council. Mr. Tocci said that should the Council approve the plan, he would consider filing suit to stop it. AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: Forget the Money. Show Us You Care.

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
NOW that the Super Bowl is over, football players can sit back and dream about the higher salaries that are guaranteed as part of the National Football League's recent $17.6 billion eight-year television deal. And the spiraling salaries are certain to prompt greater demands from athletes in other sports, too.
But will the quality of play improve as contracts grow fatter? Will players hustle more? Perhaps it's time to change the way professional athletes are paid. Why not borrow a page from corporate America's playbook and compensate athletes like chief executives, with a heavy emphasis on pay for performance? 
 Most everyone agrees that the current system for paying pro athletes is out of line. It's not so much what athletes are paid -- the talent of a Michael Jordan is rare, after all. It's how.
Players often get millions in long-term contracts that are guaranteed regardless of whether they win or lose or put out real effort. Ken Lehn, a finance professor at the University of Pittsburgh, found in the 1980's that the average number of days that professional baseball players spent on the disabled list jumped from 4.7 a season to 12.6 after they signed long-term contracts.
Outsized pay for superstars can also make teamwork difficult to foster. Matthew C. Bloom, an assistant professor of management at the University of Notre Dame, found that the most successful baseball teams from 1984 to 1993 had a narrower range of pay among all the players.
There's already some pay for performance in sports. There's a strong incentive for players to perform well to negotiate a better contract when their current one expires. (Even though playing for individual statistics alone is not always in the best interest of the team.)
And some incentives are built into contracts now. But as a percentage of base salaries, they amount to little more than a tip -- less than 3 percent of total payroll for Major League Baseball, for example. And even the larger carrots often reward quantity of work, not quality. Darryl Strawberry, for instance, recently signed an incentive-heavy contract with the New York Yankees that calls for potential bonuses adding up to more than half his base pay of $750,000 depending on his number of plate appearances: in effect, he'll be getting paid extra just to show up.
"Players are not hungry enough under those contracts to really perform," said Robert D. Tollison, an economics professor at George Mason University.
The same complaints used to be made of chief executives. But in the 1980's, big shareholders started pushing to tie executive pay to performance. Stock options, which reward executives for higher share prices, became hugely popular. It made sense in theory, although the bull market has rewarded a lot of executives for simply putting in the occasional sleepless afternoon. Incentive pay would probably work better in professional sports. There's always a winner and loser, so people aren't richly rewarded for mediocre work. And it is much easier to track individual contributions.
So why not give incentive pay -- real incentive pay -- a try with athletes? "There should be some way to distribute money to players based on their performance both as individuals and for the team as a whole," said Paul C. Weiler, a Harvard law professor and an expert in sports and labor law. Here's how it might work:
Teams could give players more modest base salaries that still reflect their relative value; the rest of their pay could then be put at risk. Half their potential earnings would be based on targets customized to their role on the team (Dennis Rodman the rebounder versus Michael Jordan the scorer). The potential to earn the other half would be based on games won.
Teams could reduce guaranteed pay, but give players a stake in the company. Pat Riley, the Miami Heat coach, has a 10 percent ownership stake. Why not give a percentage to players? That would be an incentive to stick around longer and help build the franchise, rather than take the money and run. Teams whose stock is publicly traded, like the Boston Celtics and the Florida Panthers, could even give their players stock options.
Teams could also give players a share in the ticket revenues. Attendance clauses are not unheard of in sports. Teams that sell out their seats all season long could instead give players bonuses based on games won. If the team is losing, ticket prices would drop. But if the team is winning, they would go up.
What fan would object to paying a modest success tax for their team?

HEADLINE: Dives No Longer, New Gay Bars Let In the Light

BYLINE: By DAVID COLMAN 

 BODY:
ALMOST every gay man, it seems, has a story about the first time he opened a door and stepped across one of his life's major thresholds -- into a gay bar.
However liberating crossing that threshold may have been over the years, many men remember that the atmosphere left much to be desired.
Throughout the city, across the country, gay bars have seemed to thrive under some perverse set of rules decreeing that there be no comfortable seats, no natural light, derelict bathrooms and an aroma of stale beer and smoke. Those who wonder why Bette Davis's line "What a dump!" from the 1949 film "Beyond the Forest" is such a camp staple probably have not set foot in many gay bars. 
 But the end credits may finally be rolling on this scenario. A new generation of gay bars like G and Baracuda, both in Chelsea, and Hell, in Greenwich Village, have all but jettisoned dark and dingy interior designs for cleaner, airier, more creative spaces. Others, like Splash, also in Chelsea, and Dakota, in Murray Hill, are following suit with renovations, keeping pace with popular restaurants and coffee bars, like Candy Bar and Big Cup, both in Chelsea.
Plushest of all the bars is the Jungle, which opened in January on West Street (12th Street) in Greenwich Village. Despite a foreboding exterior, the inside boasts leopard-print carpeting, upholstered armchairs and zebra-patterned booths draped in mosquito netting.
What outwardly seems a new movement in decor mirrors a broader change in attitude among patrons of gay bars: a self-confidence about being openly gay, a rising economic prosperity and less fear of harassment.
Traditionally, gay bars have been windowless dives that cloaked patrons in anonymous darkness while protecting them from the scrutiny of passers-by. The most significant feature of G, at 223 West 19th Street, is not the juice bar serving protein shakes, the sleek blond wood paneling or the modular seating in the front room, but the enormous arched windows, inset with french doors, which give onto the street.
"We're kind of saying that we're not afraid to have people look in and see that this is a gay bar," said Jim Bartholomew, the architect who designed G and Che 2020, a restaurant, also in Chelsea. "It seemed like we always had the dregs of places to go out. We wanted to create a place that was more comfortable, more elegant and worthy of your time."
Evan Lobel, a Wall Street portfolio manager who was socializing at the bar recently, said: "It's not about hiding in the shadows. Most bars have been sort of about that. It's optimistic."
The popularity of these new watering holes illustrates that many gay men appear to be embracing some of the values and freedoms of mainstream society, from which they have often been excluded. Although such bars still function as they always have -- as pickup places -- they are now also attractive meeting places for friends, where a gay man can bring a heterosexual acquaintance without fear of complaint and even where gay couples can go, free from a heavy cruising scene.
At a time when more gay men seem to be establishing lasting relationships, many welcome the change in bar culture.
"We're catching up in our subculture," said Thomas K. Duane, a City Councilman who represents Chelsea and Greenwich Village and who is openly gay. "Things seem to be much more relationship-oriented, less about transient relationships. People are much more open to be with someone now, even introducing them to their families."
There is no end of difference between the clean, well-lighted places flourishing in New York and their sometimes notorious predecessors. At Baracuda, at 275 West 22d Street, the back room is a large open space furnished with colorful thrift-shop sofas and chairs, presided over by harlequin-patterned walls and a shimmery 1960's-era curtain of Plexiglas disks. It is a far cry from the back room at the owners' previous establishment, Crowbar, a club in the East Village that closed in 1996. There in a featureless grim space, beneath a dim bulb, men could engage in virtually anonymous sex, former patrons said.
In the last decade, many gay sex clubs and back rooms -- a feature of gay bars once synonymous with sex -- have closed, having come under pressure from health authorities and from gay organizations concerned about the spread of AIDS.
But the more wholesome-looking digs have not been universally embraced. The closing of back rooms has been attacked by Sex Panic, a vocal gay group that advocates sexual liberation, for representing a crackdown on the freedom of gay men. The organization's stance has itself been taken to task by some gay people like the writer Larry Kramer.
Others have groused that the newer bars -- like the obsessions with muscles and clothing that symbolize the Chelsea gay scene -- bespeak a growing complacency among some gay men about political issues. For those who came of age with John Rechy's influential 1977 book, "The Sexual Outlaw," which linked gay sex (in some states a criminal act) with civil disobedience, the seedy-bar esthetic, with its liquor, cigarettes, drugs and sex, has been sacrosanct.
By contrast, Prof. Andrew Ross, the director of the American studies program at New York University, described a new attitude among some gay men as being "very comfortable with consolidating good middle-class taste in the public establishments that they frequent and own."
Jaime Adner, a screenwriter living in Los Angeles after having left New York three years ago, was surprised by the changes he observed during a recent visit to G. "It's very homogeneous, very Banana Republic," he said. "All the commodities that have been marketed to gays are here. We've bought it."
Most other patrons interviewed at G seemed less cynical. Asked whether gay men were embracing bourgeois values, Jack Newman, an enrollment director at a music school, said, "That's what we've always claimed to be fighting for, and now we have it."
Mr. Lobel, the portfolio manager, said: "Any radicalism is a function of marginalization. As the gay community is moving into the mainstream, we're growing up, and we're starting to take responsibility for ourselves." Part of taking responsibility, he added, is moving beyond casual sex with multiple partners and cultivating a social life more in the tradition of heterosexual couples -- boyfriend included.
Mr. Duane says that having a steady boyfriend can be a political statement, too -- about the right of gay men to go public with their choice of partners. "It used to be that straight people didn't like to imagine us having sex at all, and gay men didn't tell their co-workers, families, even close friends if they were involved," he said. "So sure, you can say you're gay, but the way you prove it is by having a boyfriend. We no longer have to be 'confirmed bachelors.' "
Cliff Bradshaw, an owner of Hell, at 59 Gansevoort Street (Washington Street), where the chandeliers and blue-gray banquettes are more speak-easy than dungeon, and Big Cup, the coffee bar, at 228 Eighth Avenue (21st Street), made no apology for the atmospheres that he and his business partner have created. He had less than fond memories of dark cruise-oriented bars of old.
"I was not the poster boy for a homosexual," Mr. Bradshaw said. "I was a tall, skinny, lanky kid with glasses, and those places were intimidating to me. I don't believe in doing that to people. Nobody has to be intimidated to come here."
SOME people are skeptical that there really is less cruising going on in the new places. Bob Pontarelli, an owner of Baracuda, said that the existence of "nicer" gay bars doesn't necessarily mean that the clients have different priorities. " 'Nice' is a weird word, because it implies that people are behaving themselves," he said. "I don't think the community has sanitized itself. Everybody still has the same interests and desires, and they're still finding them satisfied, but they're just doing it in more comfortable environments."
Still, these environments are attracting an element traditionally held to be a bane to cruising: heterosexual customers. Mr. Bradshaw said that at his two establishments, heterosexuals make up about 30 percent of the clientele. "Come in here on Sunday, and see the strollers," he said of Big Cup, a brightly lighted place with a dessert case and periodicals strewn about and where no alcohol is served. "We even have P.T.A. meetings."
