HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
The Costs of Doing Business

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
THE convenience of mutual fund ownership increasingly comes at a higher and higher price.
Basic expense ratios -- the day-in, day-out charges for overhead and investment talent -- have steadily crept up in recent years. Separate marketing costs, known as 12b-1 fees in the language of financial regulation, can add as much as $100 in annual expenses to a $10,000 investment. And when a fund offers multiple classes of shares, one group of investors may pay more for the same merchandise than the next group pays. 
 But that isn't all: After two decades of gains by no-load mutual funds, the load industry -- that is, the companies that sell their funds with sales charges, or loads, through brokers -- is marketing its funds aggressively.
Shareholders get nothing of value from these higher costs, and indeed receive lower overall investment returns, critics contend. "Studies show that mutual funds that charge high fees don't continue to perform well," said Steven Heston, assistant professor of finance at Washington University's Olin School of Business in St. Louis.
Loads and 12b-1 fees are used to pay the brokers who sell the funds -- meaning that in the fund business, the cost of sales is borne by the customer, not the funds. Craig Israelsen, associate professor of consumer and family economics at the University of Missouri, said a direct result of these expenses was lower shareholder returns.
"Over a five-year period that ended Dec. 31, 1996, pure no-load funds had average annual returns of 13.1 percent, and load funds returned 11.7 percent," he said. "Expenses come directly off of returns."
In 1980, when mutual fund assets totaled $134.8 billion, the average annual expense ratio among both stock and bond funds was nine-tenths of 1 percent, said D. K. Malhotra, assistant professor of finance at the Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science, who has published articles on the subject in financial journals. At the end of last year, when assets were $4.5 trillion, that average had increased to 1.1 percent.
"Clearly, fund companies have not shared economies of scale with the investor," he said.
Peter DiTeresa, associate editor of Morningstar Investor, the newsletter of Morningstar Inc., noted that the growth of mutual fund supermarkets at firms like Charles Schwab, Fidelity Investments and Jack White had come at a price.
The supermarkets make it easy to buy and sell the shares of various fund complexes. But to participate in a supermarket, fund companies must pay the sponsoring firm. Jack White charges funds an annual fee of 25 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, for assets of its customers. Fidelity charges 35 points, and Schwab says it bargains for a rate from 26 and 34 points.
As a participating mutual fund, "You have to cover that 35 basis points somehow," Mr. DiTeresa said. "It either comes out of your pocket, or you're going to have to add it to the expense ratio."
SOME mutual funds do not participate in these marketplaces for just this reason.
Homestead Value, a $380 million fund that has Morningstar's highest ranking, five stars, has an expense ratio of eight-tenths of 1 percent -- little more than half the industry average for equity funds -- and it spurns Schwab and Fidelity. It is available, however, though Jack White.
"We don't want to pay a high price for being part of these distribution outlets," said Peter Morris, the fund's co-manager. "We're attracting business the way it is; the other way is an expensive way to go."
Fee structures have become increasingly complex among funds with loads, often depending on the class of shares purchased.
The differences express themselves mostly in the loads themselves, which are one-time charges, and 12(b)1 fees, which are collected annually.
It is common for load-fund complexes to have four pricing tiers. The Oppenheimer Discovery fund, for example, has the following four levels:
* Class A shares have an upfront load, or sales charge, of 5.75 percent. The annual expense ratio of 1.22 percent is lower that the ratio for class B and C shares, reducing the cost of long-term ownership.
* Class B shares impose a back-end load which starts at 5 percent for shares that are quickly sold and declines to nothing after six years. The expense ratio, 1.99 percent, is cut as the shares convert to class A when the back-end load ends.
* Class C shares have a smaller rear load, 1 percent, but the relatively high expense ratio, 2.03 percent, continues forever, making them most suited to short-term ownership.
* Class Y shares of Oppenheimer Discovery are no-loads, sold only to institutions.
"Different investors like to pay for the advice they receive in different ways," said Jim Ruff, president of Oppenheimer Funds Distributors. "We want to manage the money," he said. "We don't want to get into how the client pays the registered representative for advice."
Similarly, at Dean Witter Health Sciences, the front-end load on class A shares is 5.25 percent, but the 12b-1 fee is only 0.25 percent. Class B and C shares have 1 percent annual charges, but maximum back-end loads of between 1 and 5 percent. Class D shares, which are for institutional investors, are purely no-load. Its expense ratio is lower, too, 1.31 percent, compared with 1.57 percent for the A shares, 2.25 percent for the B and 2.31 percent for the C.
Investors can avoid such decisions by buying no-load funds directly from a fund company. But many turn to brokers for advice and wind up buying load funds, which have never lost their dominance in the marketplace.
According to the Investment Company Institute, among equity and fixed-income funds, load funds accounted for 54.9 percent of total assets as of Nov. 30, while no-load funds had 45.1 percent.
Increasingly, load funds charge lower upfront fees than they did 15 years ago -- typical commissions of less than 6 percent currently, compared with more than 8 percent then. But the 12b-1 fees, which were adopted in their current form in 1993, actually increase the total cost of fund ownership.
"Since I first started in the business in 1977, loads have come way down, but the 12b-1 fees are getting more and more prominent," said Mark Mershon, the president of Triple Check Financial Services, investment counselors in Montrose, Calif.
Some funds, meanwhile, are losing their no-load status altogether. The no-load Mutual Series funds managed by Michael Price were bought by Franklin Resources and now carry loads for purchases by new investors.
INVESTORS are being charged more in other ways, too.
Many no-load funds are being sold by so-called fee-only financial planners, who impose their own charges. For an investor with a $100,000 portfolio, the payment of a 1 percent management fee to a planner is equivalent to accepting $1,000 less in annual returns.
Nor can no-load funds be relied on to be free of charges. Funds can call themselves no-loads if they impose 12b-1 fees of a quarter of 1 percent or less.
When the stock market is delivering double-digit average annual growth, as it has for more than a decade, fees of 1 or 2 percent don't loom particularly large. But if fixed-income investments, where returns are typically in the single digits, were to outperform stocks -- as they have in recent months -- the issue of fees would take on more urgency.
"This year, you'll find more money flowing into bond funds," said Professor Malhotra. "Expenses there have a large impact on returns to investors."
And even in equity funds, he said, expenses are the sole performance variable that individuals control.
"Returns you cannot predict; they are very volatile in nature," he said. "But with expenses, certainly you can predict. Lower expenses mean more returns to investors."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE -- BUZZ;
Shocked, Shocked That We're Shocked

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
THE SETTING: A few of the bars and bistros favored by the city's expatriate French population, where the choice chatter focuses on the details and detritus of the Presidential sex scandal, the allegations of some sort of sexual relationship and cover-up between President Clinton and Monica Lewinsky, a former White House intern.
The denizens of the French quarter say the controversy has left them deeply concerned. In their own way, of course. 
 THE BUZZ: "Oh, my God, yes, I'm shocked," said Francois Raud, 37, who was enjoying a plate of cassoulet and a bottle of Bordeaux at the bar at Provence, a French restaurant on Macdougal Street in SoHo. "Just three girlfriends? In eight years? And he's the President? He is obviously not a good lover."
(Mr. Raud could not explain his exact accounting. "One is named Paulie, no?" he said.)
The bartender, Marc Rinet, agreed with his customer.
"She's a woman, and he's a man, so?" said Mr. Rinet, a French native who sported a blue bandanna and a red and white shirt. "I think it is comedic, crazy to want to fire a President just for sex. It is not sex with animal."
Both men pointed out that the French people openly accepted the flings of Francois Mitterrand, the late President, who fathered a child by his mistress, Anne Pingeot. "And Clinton is much better-looking," Mr. Raud said.
"It is droit du seigneur," said Mr. Rinet, explaining his country's singular history of personal politics. "The right of kings."
"But, of course, Americans are too prude for that," Mr. Raud added, with a nudge and a wink.
For some of the younger crowd hanging out at Jules, a candlelit bistro at 65 St. Marks Place in the East Village, the President's troubles seemed more clever than clumsy.
"I don't know if he did it, but if he did it, he did good," said Romain Brisson, a student from Provence who is studying photography in New York. "Because everybody is talking about it."
Some were even less couth.
"It is good news," said Pascal Jatteaux, an unemployed visitor from Marseilles. "It proves he is not a homosexual."
"For me, it is not a problem," Mr. Jatteaux continued. "It is only a problem for his wife."
Others saw the whole affair (or alleged affair) as indicative of deeper problems in the nation.
"There are serious problems in the world, and the American papers are full of this?" said Natalie, who refused to give her last name. "I feel like saying, 'What's wrong with you?,' the same way you tell someone who is crazy."
For other Frenchwomen, the issue was slightly more oblique.
"I am confused by it," said Emile Luguern, 23, a waitress from Paris who works at Cafe Gitane on Mott Street in Little Italy. "Is it illegal in America to have a love affair?"
No, it was explained, it is only illegal to lie under oath.
"But everyone lies about love affairs," answered Ms. Luguern, with a note of disbelief. "Why would you tell the truth? That would be completely amazing."
At Provence, the boys at the bar said that while the characters in the President's latest ordeal were new, the story was familiar.
"Sex and politics are from the basement of the world, from the beginning together," Mr. Raud said. "What do you expect?" JESSE McKINLEY

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Why Do People Quit Their Jobs? Because They Can

BYLINE: By DAWN GILBERTSON 

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
MIKE MITCHELL was perfectly happy last spring in his job as an employee communications specialist here for the Phelps Dodge Corporation.
He liked his boss, had a lot of independence and felt challenged. He had just had his one-year review and it was positive. He received a raise. 
 Even so, Mr. Mitchell quit in July, accepting a position as marketing communications manager with AG Communication Systems, a Phoenix-based joint venture of Lucent Technologies and GTE.
Mr. Mitchell, 35, initially resisted AG's overtures, as he had those of other companies that approached him. But this offer proved irresistible. He is making 20 percent more than in his previous job, works in a hot industry, telecommunications, and is rounding out his resume with advertising and marketing skills.
"Because I was happy, I needed to be swayed that this was a significantly better opportunity than where I was," he said.
Figuring out how and why people quit their jobs has long puzzled managers. But in these days of low unemployment -- 4.7 percent nationally -- answering the question has become paramount as employers try to retain workers.
The effort may be difficult. Consider this dispatch from the front lines: 53 percent of American workers expect to leave their jobs voluntarily within the next five years, according to a recent poll by Louis Harris & Associates.
"It's amazing -- the fact that employees have this kind of propensity" to quit, said Peter Hom, a management professor at Arizona State University who studies turnover and is co-author of a human resource management book, "Employee Turnover" (South-Western College Publishing). "I've never seen it expressed in these numbers before."
David Opton, executive director of Exec-U-Net, a Norwalk, Conn., networking organization, sees it first-hand. Mr. Opton, whose business caters to executives with six-figure salaries, says 60 percent of its 5,000 members have jobs. When the business was founded nearly 10 years ago, all the members were unemployed.
"They see more options," he said, including the opportunity to become "Me Inc." -- a reference to self-employment.
Still, the idea that good-paying jobs are plentiful, and going begging, may be difficult for some workers to grasp. Economists point to a recent decline in the Labor Department's "quit rate" -- the share of the unemployed who left their jobs willingly. As unemployment falls, the quit rate normally rises; but the rate fell significantly in the last quarter, from 12.8 percent in September to 10.3 percent in November, before rebounding to 10.8 percent in December. Some economists attribute the fall to the uncertainty of looking for work in a job market still rife with downsizing, though they note that comprehensive information on quitting is not available.
EVEN if some employees are skittish, an increasing number seem to be learning the lesson that their services are more in demand. The message for managers is equally clear: many employees have designs on, or will be drawn to, the exit door.
Some turnover is unavoidable: People relocate, for example, or start a family and opt to stay home.
And some turnover is desirable. Few managers balk when a chronically late or absent worker walks out the door, or when a prima donna exits stage left.
But in general, voluntary turnover is expensive and time-consuming. It's a rare manager who doesn't cringe -- inside at least -- when an employee gives notice. The boss knows that the weeks ahead will be filled with recruiting, training and, until a replacement is found, a sag in production. The situation can also hurt morale, as other workers are expected to pick up the slack.
What are worried managers to do so they don't need to keep a corporate headhunter on speed dial?
To start, management professors and other experts say, they should discard the traditional thinking on how and why people quit -- the idea that an employee grows dissatisfied with his job, stews about it, slowly looks for a new company and leaves when a better offer comes up.
Plenty of people still take this route to the door but, Professor Hom said, "we are finding that there are all kinds of ways of abandoning the workplace."
Understanding these circumstances and which ones are prevalent in an organization is crucial to keeping valued employees, he and others say.
Thomas Lee, a professor of human resource management and organizational behavior at the University of Washington in Seattle, has studied employee departures since 1990, reviewing turnover patterns in professions including nursing, engineering and accounting. He and his colleagues concluded that no formula could predict whether a particular employee is going to quit. But they did determine four general themes, or "paths," to quitting, three of them considered nontraditional.
The common thread in those three paths could be called "shocks to the system."
"It's a jarring event, expected or unexpected," Professor Lee said. "It's something that prompts the deliberation process."
On the first path, the event prompts a natural next step in an employee's career script. For a nomadic engineer bent on working on the latest projects, it might be a job offer from a rival company with a challenging assignment, Professor Lee said. For a salesman with management aspirations, it might be acceptance to business school. Or it might be as simple as an employee's long-planned trip around the world, as one nurse gave as her reason for quitting.
Though a manager may appear helpless in situations like these, steps can be taken to try to retain the employee. To discourage job-hopping, for example, the engineer's company could assign him other projects and tie pay to their completion. The salesman's boss could suggest an executive M.B.A. program that accommodated a new work schedule. The nurse could have been offered a sabbatical.
The second path involves what Professor Lee calls an abhorrent event: something that drives an employee to quit hastily, often without another job in the wings. Common causes include ethical breaches, sexual harassment and inadequate training.
He cited the case of another nurse, who quit after she was thrown into assisting emergency surgery, work for which she was ill-prepared. "It was the straw that broke the camel's back," he said.
Indeed, some such events hardly seem dramatic -- but they cause frustrations that make employees leave. An employee's placement on a poorly planned work team is an example. According to K. Dow Scott, director of workplace studies at Loyola University in Chicago, a successful team helps reduce turnover because people feel committed to the group. Work on an unsuccessful team, however, can send an employee packing.
If employees "don't have high expectations for their teams," he said, "that increases their likelihood of quitting."
In such cases, a good system for airing grievances is essential, Professor Lee said, so potential problems are known before an employee has reaches his or her limit.
The third path involves a shock from the outside, often in the form of an unsolicited job offer. Professor Lee says this route is of particular concern to businesses in hot job markets, because workers with "high potential or proven records are more likely to be enticed with attractive external alternatives" and might be harder to replace.
Mr. Mitchell falls into that camp. He sent a resume to AG at the urging of a former colleague, who worked there. He expected that would be the end of it.
Indeed, when AG called for an interview and offered him a job almost on the spot, with a 10 percent raise and slightly better retirement benefits, Mr. Mitchell declined.
But a couple hours later, he said, AG executives called back, offering even more money. "At that point I said, 'I really need to consider this,' " Mr. Mitchell recalled.
His boss at Phelps Dodge said she wanted him to stay but could not match the offer. Mr. Mitchell gave his notice.
Faced with such situations, companies have a few options, Professor Lee said. One, of course, is to match the salary. "For some people, money is everything," he said.
But not for everybody. In a recent survey of managers by the Society of Human Resource Management, 89 percent of the respondents cited salary as a reason for employees' leaving. But close behind on the list was the potential for career advancement, cited by 85 percent, and employees' feelings that they were not appreciated, 79 percent.
FOR Steve Gomez, it came down to career ambitions. In 1996, Mr. Gomez quit his job as a marketing director for the Dial Corporation, the consumer products company based in Scottsdale, Ariz., because he did not see a future there.
Dial had hit a financial rough spot, leaving little money for his projects. And nobody was suggesting alternative assignments.
"I like to look a couple years down the road and say, 'Where am I going to be with this company?' " Mr. Gomez said. "It just didn't seem like, long term, there would be anything there for me."
Mr. Gomez, who is 40, quit to work for a start-up laundromat chain in Arizona. Early last year he took a new job, as director of ethnic marketing for the Schering-Plough Corporation in Madison, N.J.
Professor Hom of Arizona State acknowledged that it was difficult for managers to "gauge the genuine feelings and cognitions" of employees. He and others suggest that managers stay in touch with workplace morale by conducting opinion surveys and exit interviews, not to mention one-on-one discussions with workers. This is especially important in light of his research that shows that once employees start job searches, they are as good as gone.
The bottom line for companies, Professor Lee said, is relatively simple. "You have some people who you believe are just so important," he said. "Figure out what's important to them."

HEADLINE: Cruising the Corridor

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
CHUCKIE and his crew were cheap. That's what the ladies at the topless bar said after the bachelor party filed out into the darkness. Chuckie was to be married in two days, and he and the boys from the Sanitation Department had had a good time. Meanwhile, the dancers who had endured the groping and the unsociable things said about their ancestors received $1 tips. "Not a player in the bunch," one lady said.
The Fiddle and Bow has a long history on the Roosevelt Avenue corridor in Queens, and it is has an unsophisticated atmosphere of domestic beer and Plexiglas mirrors. It is a long shot from the Times Square and Chelsea scenes that Dominic Briggs, a trash man from Long Island who was among Chuckie's group, once prowled. 
 "It's no secret that they really cleaned Manhattan up," Mr. Briggs said, a tall man with large, bovine hands that were working over a beer bottle. "Naturally, you're never going to get rid of everything. So it's pretty simple mathematics that the night life is going to move somewhere else."
And if the Thursday night crowd at the Fiddle and Bow, or the cars from New Jersey and Long Island lined up on Roosevelt Avenue, or the Spanish-speaking pimps, or the whispers and catcalls of "girls" and "cocaine" are any indication, then north central Queens has become the preferred destination for debauchery.
Though the police have put a lid on the visibility, the scene has moved behind the blackened windows along the Roosevelt Avenue corridor. The action takes place between 65th Street in Woodside to the west, across Jackson Heights and ending around 108th Street in Corona to the east.
But the corridor is more than that. To spend 48 hours on Roosevelt Avenue is to stand in the revolving door between the American dream and the raw naked hustle of storied New York. The place where America meets the world, and the people of the world meet Jim Beam. It is less a neighborhood anymore than a vast disembarkation zone. It may offer early hints of what New York is to become, a sanitarium for the unwashed masses to gather their faculties before fanning out across the country.
The ill-lighted corridor beneath the elevated tracks of the No. 7 train has absorbed and regurgitated such a huge wave of immigrants and refugees in the last quarter century -- more than any other area in New York, according to Census statistics -- that some residents call it the new Ellis Island, with its grimy underbelly drawing it the moniker Outer Borough Babylon. As capitalism would have it, nefarious elements compete not only with the police but also with one another. Every few blocks, it seems, has its own economy, language and criminal enterprises. The Mexicans have arrived. Its mafia element, authorities say, is dripping in from the streets and jailhouses of Los Angeles, filling a vacuum left by the once-dominant Colombians and creating a skittishness among the Puerto Rican and Dominican gangs.
Add to this mix a cat-and-mouse game between a police force bent on sweeping the sidewalks clean and an underworld determined to occupy the cracks.
After 2 A.M., the beat cops go home, and many on the avenue know this. Except for the taco stands, the streets are mostly empty. Outside the club doors, across from the police van on 92d Street, young Mexican men pass out small tickets with brothel addresses in bold lettering. The police know this. "It's a funny thing," says Officer John Romano of the 115th Precinct. "It used to be the Colombian gangsters who worked the brothels, now it's Mexicans."
At 3 A.M., Chuckie and his eight-man crew head to a cathouse on 84th Street below a beauty salon.
The brothel is a basement affair of cinder blocks and paneling, and consists of one large room and perhaps a dozen small cubicles with doors. The johns enter single file, go to the cash register and pay a man $25. They are given a paper ticket or receipt to be given to the women before services rendered. A few men order Heinekens and sit on folding chairs, the room lit by a stark fluorescent tube. The women, perhaps 12 of them, very young, parade about in tight skirts and negligees chirping in Spanish or awkward English, waiting to be called.
A shrine to the Virgin Mary is displayed prominently in a corner, and must be of great import, because another cubicle could easily have been constructed in its place. The basement stinks of Spaghettios and tobacco.
Elisa, 22, comes from the central Mexican state Aguascalientes. The daughter of poor farmers, Elisa said that like everyone else she knows, she came for a better life. And like most every other immigrant loitering around the bottom rungs of American society, she says, "I want to make money to go home."
She said she had been in New York for two years. She came illegally in a trunk and has been working in her present occupation for six months. She is a moonfaced woman with pleasant features who neither drinks nor smokes. "I would like to be married and have babies," she said behind one of the paneled doors in a room with a bed, chair, night stand, ashtray. "But not like this. Who would want me like this?"
She gets $12 for every ticket she returns, plus tips. "It's not so bad," she says. "Always condoms and no kissing. I'm very safe that way." A very good night is $150, she said. "And a car home."
Mr. Briggs did not go through with it, and sat in a metal chair, wringing the life out of a bottle, waiting for Chuckie the groom.
Elisa emerged from the basement at 5:15 in the morning wearing blue jeans, a down coat and a vinyl handbag. Daylight had not yet arrived and a black Lincoln Town Car was waiting to take her somewhere. She kissed the driver on the lips.
Down the avenue at 73d Street, on the island below the tracks, a family of rats were breakfasting on the grains left for the pigeons.
 
Hoping for the Irish To Come By
 The men without working papers start to line up at 6:30 A.M. Hundreds of them. They come from everywhere: India, Guatemala, Poland, Ecuador. To stand along the intersection of 69th Street and Roosevelt. Waiting for work on the streets. It is a tough street, the men say. Not one of a dozen can say who "Ruservelt" was, but they can point out the bloodstains of an Asian boy who was stabbed in the head on New Year's Eve.
They huddle against the cold and the rain and inside the Uruguayan bakery. They laugh at the image of Bill Clinton on the front page of The Daily News. His calamity is worse than theirs, at least, they say.
"I'm hoping for some Irish to come by," says Herman Gavilanes, 33, an Ecuadorian from the capital city, Quito. The Irish pay twice as much as other Americans, he says. Maybe $100 for eight hours of hauling bricks on their backs or breaking up cement slabs or carting Sheetrock up a five-story walkup. "They understand," Mr. Gavilanes says.
When a van does pull up, it is swarmed by 50 men, each undercutting the next, driving down the wage. Every man knows this is not a good negotiating tactic, but it's the way it is when so many are desperate.
Mr. Gavilanes, who appeared three years ago, is an educated man who studied at a university. But since he has not had regular work in three months, he has failed to send money home and has bounced from couch to couch to train. The police prohibit sleeping on the subway trains anymore, and to do so may well earn you a size 11 in the backside. A lean, handsome man with gray flecks of hair, Mr. Gavilanes is ashamed of having to pull at sleeve cuffs and pick through bags of clothes. His father is ashamed. He said his children are hungry.
He was a chauffeur in Ecuador and had to leave his home and wife and three children when inflation devastated the economy. He has never met his youngest son.
"I am lonely," he said. "If you don't see your wife in two years, you are going to visit the sick girls," the prostitutes. "But besides that," he said, "I try to stay indoors at night. There are the Mexican gangs, and they are very hard."
Above the street where the day laborers congregate is Resumen, a Spanish weekly newspaper owned and edited by Fernando F. Rojas. The office opens promptly at 11 A.M. and Mr. Rojas is at the window, his silk tie undone, staring down at the dripping wretches in the rain.
"This neighborhood has always had its immigrants and a little bit of an underground class," said Mr. Rojas, excusing his English, which is excellent, however. "But that's all changed." The streets are bursting now. "It's noisy and wide open, now," he says. "Every man for himself."
No one knows the corner better than Mr. Rojas, who fled Castro's Cuba in 1959 and for 30 years has been running his paper from this small yellow office. Last Friday, he was preparing his papal coverage.
"Bad things go on for bad reasons here," Mr. Rojas said. "Nobody sells drugs or robs because they are hungry. That's the old country. Here it's for shoes and clothes, and they think that's what an American does."
There were slightly more than 100,000 people living in the corridor around 1970, 90 percent of European white heritage. By 1997, the Census estimated that there were 137,000 legal residents in the area, with less than 46 percent of European white heritage and that more than two-thirds of the overall population was foreign born. Many houses and apartments are now subdivided, and packed with families and extended families and illegal immigrants trying to make their way.
"The shift was so massive, so quick, that in a generation the place has become a bubbling cauldron of foreign groups," said Andrew Beveridge, a sociology professor and demographer at Queens College. "It's become a turnstile. The first stop U.S.A. And those who do well move on and others keep coming to take their place."
 
Traces of Los Angeles On the Avenue

Many hard-working people have come, but so, too, has the crime. Billions of dollars worth of cocaine flowed through Jackson Heights in the last 15 years. Travel agents and wire transfer centers laundered the cocaine profits back to Colombia.
"The Colombians ran things here for 10 years or so," Mr. Rojas said. The cartels ran things into the early 90's until their leaders were either killed or imprisoned. Then money transfer operations were limited to $700 transactions without having to file statements with the Federal authorities. The fronts along Roosevelt began to close down.
"There was a lot of blood, and I think the Colombians lost their stomach," Mr. Rojas said.
It appears that the Mexicans are taking their place, Federal investigators say. Federal drug agents in Queens searched an 18-wheel tractor-trailer with Texas plates last March and found nearly 3,600 pounds of cocaine concealed inside a load of carrots.
This was the largest cocaine seizure in New York in a decade, and resulted in the arrest of Geraldo Gonzales, a Mexican, and eight others identified by law-enforcement officials as major cocaine traffickers. The arrest led to a search of an apartment in Corona, which yielded what investigators said was $1.3 million in narcotics profits from Mr. Gonzales's operation. It was the first time in New York that a Mexican cocaine trafficking gang had been caught in a criminal endeavor long dominated by Colombians and Dominicans, said an investigator who worked on the case, speaking on condition of anonymity.
"Most cocaine makes its way through Mexico," the investigator said. "In the 80's it was all Colombians. But since '95, the Mexicans have been paid to transport it. And they're being paid in cocaine and in turn selling it through their own networks."
It is either a sophisticated business decision on the part of the Colombians to deal only with distribution and leave it to the Mexicans to take the risks, or the Mexicans are taking it upon themselves to fill the vacuum left when extradition treaties and arrests crippled the Colombians, the investigator said.
"Either way, Queens is a major thoroughfare of narcotics, and in terms of new ways to launder, we're looking at a lot of these new Mexican restaurants along Roosevelt Avenue that seem to have very few customers," the investigator said.
 
The Police Response: Taking On Crime Inside
 "Just three years ago, the place was Dodge City," said Capt. Anthony Izzo, the commander of the 115th Precinct in Jackson Heights, the neighborhood in which he grew up. "Through diligence and circumstance, it's a much nicer place to live."
Maybe just as important as the Colombians' losing ground, Captain Izzo said, was the crackdown on quality-of-life crimes. The police no longer tolerate urinating in the streets, or prostitutes conducting business in the alleyways, or dope dealers on the streets. Major crime dropped 14 percent.
"This is the most diverse community in the city and probably the world," Captain Izzo said. "The primary concern here is to hold the streets down so women can walk with their babies."
The next step, he said, is to take on crime inside the buildings. Jackson Heights is the neighborhood where 50 deaf Mexicans were discovered being held in indentured servitude last summer in a one-family house, living in squalor and forced to sell trinkets on the trains. And even though 30 prostitution houses were shut down last year, they don't disappear, the police admit, they just move around. And then there is the cocaine.
The Mexican gangs from Los Angeles have started filtering into New York, taking over the indoor prostitution rackets and the dope dealing. They are the next target. "It's always dangerous going inside," the captain said with resignation. "But we're ready for them. There won't be a Welcome Wagon."
Over the past six months, graffiti tags have appeared in the corridor: M-18, Vida Loca, Mara Salvatrucha and Logan Cali-30, Latin-American gangs with their beginnings in East Los Angeles and probable ties to the Mexican drug cartels. Authorities began to notice the growth of Mexican-American gangs when a rash of screwdriver stabbings were reported last summer.
"We suspect a connection between these gangs and the Mexican Mafia," said Mariela Stanton, the chief of the anti-bias and youth gangs bureau for the Queens District Attorney's Office.
"It's too soon to know how many are here, but we know they are migrating from Los Angeles because the pickings are relatively easy here," she said.
About six months ago, while New Yorkers were in a hysteria over reports that the Bloods and the Crips gangs were spreading east -- an exaggeration, law-enforcement officials now say -- Los Angeles judges had begun issuing injunctions against convicts suspected of gang activity. They were prohibited from congregating in known gang hot spots, wearing gang colors or carrying beepers. With heavy police pressure and the threat of prison time, some gang members have left Los Angeles and fanned out across the United States in search of virgin territory.
"They frequent the corridor, but they don't tend to be violent," said Capt. James McCool, commander of the Criminal Intelligence section of the New York Police Department. "They're involved in prostitution, drugs and fraudulent documents."
As the Mexicans move into new territory, they upset the existing balance of power in the neighborhoods. Things aren't violent yet, said Ramon Escalante, 24, sitting on a crate underneath a garage awning waiting out the afternoon rain to cook himself a fix of heroin. Mr. Escalante said he is a member of the DeePees, the Dominican Posse, whose territory begins east of Junction Boulevard along the corridor. It is also the territory tacitly shared with the mostly Puerto Rican Latin Kings. Three years ago, an armistice was reached between the gangs when too many young men died and the police brought the whip down.
Ramon Escalante said: "You got the Mexicans coming in thinking they got it locked down. If the authorities don't take care of it, we going to do it ourselves."
Still, that did not stop Mr. Escalante from patronizing the long-distance telephone office to pick up a dime bag of black Colombian heroin from the Mexicans. Business is business, and a pincushion needs its needle.
 
The Old Crowd Recalls a Different Time
 Nearing 6 o'clock at O'Hanlon's Bar, the crowd starts to file out of the last Irish pub on the corridor. It's getting dark, the rain now the color of mercury. An old man stares through the window, making sure his pal with the cane makes it into the cab. The last man in is Don Hall, 60, an out-of-work printer, delivering a depressing monologue over a glass of whisky on the rocks.
"It's all ruined," he said. "I lost my job. Meanwhile, someone from another country comes and gets the grants, the money, imports his family. In the meantime, what do they do for me? My pop was killed in World War II, a brother in Korea, a brother in Vietnam. There are no more real Americans. Veterans Day, hah! You can't count eight men walking in the parade. Forget the Alamo. No one wants to know. America is no more. Walk around here at night if you dare. You better carry a gun, I'm telling you. It's not red, white and blue. It's about green. No one knows. What I got to say don't sell papers."
The bartender nodded his head favorably. Mr. Hall put his money on the counter and made his way to the door. "It was a hell of a place to be a kid," he said. He adjusted his cap and was gone.
A man with mirrored glasses came in after him, ordered a beer and sat silently in the corner.
 
Drinking Whisky, Remembering Inflation
 Herman Gavilanes, the day laborer, had procured some whisky. Jim Beam. He had to steal away from the place he was staying, on a couch in the home of Christians who took pity on his sleeping on the trains. They do not approve of whisky. The rain had turned to sleet. At 10 P.M., Mr. Gavilanes trooped over to the apartment of friends who had grown up with him in Ecuador.
Three men lived in the two-room Corona apartment, the beds doubling as furniture. Football played on the television and a rendering of Christ on the wall. One man works as an asbestos remover, another an ironer of clothes, the third a dishwasher. All have wives and children and dreams, all waiting for them back home.
"I was a policeman in Ecuador," said the asbestos remover, Miguel Narvaez, 56. "Inflation caused my pension to go from $1,000 a month to $150. I had no choice to come. The United States is a good place. I have sent my children to university. But now there are too many men here and not enough work. I am tired and I will go home. I have not seen my wife in eight years."
In the corner, Mr. Gavilanes was greedily drinking the liquor with cola. His problems are worse, he said. But he does not discuss them in groups. He wanted to drink and get on with the happiness. Between the men, the bottle was emptied in less than an hour. Mr. Gavilanes, soporific but aggressive, was asked to leave. They kittied up $23 for him.
Walking through the sleet, Mr. Gavilanes spoke of his empty dreams, of nothing realized. Passing the gay bars and the fancy nightclubs with meringue spilling out and the Indian restaurants with their strange smells, he chose what he said was a Mexican mob joint on 97th Street. Nothing sobers a man up, he says, like a good Mexican beer. The waitress was a pretty woman with wings tattooed on her ankle.
He ordered a bowl of pig's feet and a Corona. He devoured the rubbery soup, lighted a cigarette and suddenly burst into tears. "I am ruined," he sobbed. "God help me. I have holes in my pants and I sleep on the trains while my children go hungry."
He had embarrassed himself in front of a room full of men, who were staring by now. For the second time that evening, he was asked to leave. The bulk of the train rumbled high above Roosevelt, the sleet falling like stones. His lean, huddled figure slipped into the night.
The next morning at sunup, there he stood on 69th Street, waiting for work, his eyes glistening. Broke again, and hung over.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 750 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Whither the Customer In an Airline Alliance?

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
THE airline alliance proposed last week between Northwest and Continental drew praise from Wall Street analysts, yet the deal -- in which Northwest has agreed to buy control of Continental for about $311 million in cash and $208 million worth of stock -- leaves a number of unresolved questions for consumers.
For example, how will the alliance affect flight operations and service? 
 Continental promotes its leadership for two consecutive years in the J. D. Power & Associates customer satisfaction survey for flights of more than 500 miles. It also has one of the best on-time records. Some industry observers say this reputation might erode through affiliation with Northwest, which has been beset recently by customer complaints and poor on-time performance.
Indeed, last year Northwest fell sharply in the Power survey, placing "below the industry average," according to a Power spokesman, in both long and short flights. In 1996, the carrier placed second to Continental on long flights, and was first in short flights.
"Continental could be the big loser in this alliance, if Northwest begins imposing its standards," said Joe Brancatelli, who is a columnist for Trip.com (www.thetrip.com), a World Wide Web site for business travelers. In a recent column, Mr. Brancatelli excoriated Northwest's customer service and vowed not to fly the carrier again.
Others say such a situation is unlikely. "Northwest's outlay is a little over $311 million, less than a quarter of their liquidity," said Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst with Paine Webber. "So it's hard to see how a 25 percent reduction in their cash position could remotely affect service standards."
Joseph Berman, an analyst with Avmark, an airline consulting company in Arlington, Va., said that contrary to Northwest's low standing in Department of Transportation rankings, which are based on customer complaints, the airline has gotten "a bum rap" -- especially since hiring a new head of customer service less than a year ago.
Continental does not appear worried. "We think we understand the formula for achieving customer satisfaction," said David Messing, a spokesman for Continental. "We think Northwest also understands the formula, and they're working very hard to achieve it."
Northwest said it, too, was committed to providing excellent customer service. "We made a significant investment to address these issues," Kathy Peach, a spokeswoman, said. "The difference in the ratings among airlines is very small."
The carriers' frequent-flier programs are expected to be linked by June 1. While many details are still to be worked out, the prospects seem to benefit the consumer.
"This alliance offers frequent-flier members a lot more choices than in their individual programs, especially since there's so little overlap in their routes," said David S. Stempler, president of the Air Travelers Association in Washington. Adding KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Northwest's partner, extends that frequent-flier reach even further, he said.
Continental's program is considered among the industry's most generous: its elite level -- which confers upgrades and other benefits -- is reached at 20,000 miles flown, and accrued miles face no time limits on their use. With some exceptions, Northwest's program requires 25,000 miles flown for similar perks; miles expire after three years.
Mr. Messing said the two programs would probably function "the way our program with America West does." Travelers enrolled with either Continental or America West can redeem miles earned flying on the other airline.
Signals of an airline's service quality range from the condition of airplane interiors to in-flight food. But Mr. Stempler said the surest indication was the number of flights canceled for reasons other than weather.
"Carriers with reliable service usually spend a lot of money having mechanics and spare parts available at airports away from their hubs," he said. "That way they can fix minor mechanical problems there on the spot, even if it causes delays." Airlines that cut back, he said, must cancel flights to take planes back to their maintenance bases.
Another sign might be any sharp change in top staff. "This transaction does represent a change of control that will result in the immediate vesting of all management stock options at Continental," Mr. Buttrick said. "In effect, the golden handcuffs come off, so management of Continental Airlines will be freer to pursue other opportunities."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3100 words

HEADLINE: Second-Guessing The Economic Doctor

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ALL over Southeast Asia, people are complaining that a cabal of heartless bureaucrats at an institution many have come to loathe -- the International Monetary Fund -- is worsening their economic misery. Here in Washington, the I.M.F. isn't a lot more popular, but for very different reasons.
Almost every night in Thailand, a stream of television commentators chafe at the humiliation of witnessing their country's leaders negotiate every element of national economic policy -- from interest rates to budget deficits -- with economists who work largely in secrecy out of the I.M.F.'s offices off Pennsylvania Avenue here. 
 Outside a McDonald's in Jakarta, Indonesia, last month, a clutch of young professionals argued that the fund, which had just forced President Suharto to terminate government subsidies that kept the price of fuel and food low, is simply a tool of an American, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin.
"There's a rumor that this is all a game started by America," said a 27-year-old advertising executive named Doli, repeating a version of an oft-heard conspiracy theory in which Washington secretly plotted to destroy Asian competitors. "America should not have let the rupiah keep dropping," he said, dismissing suggestions that Indonesia might bear some responsibility for the 80 percent plunge in its currency.
Indeed, throughout Asia these days, people talk about the I.M.F. as if it were a branch of the Clinton Administration, and as if it -- with Washington's connivance -- aspires to run the region today the way Gen. Douglas MacArthur ran it a half-century ago. Around Asia, one hears variants of the same lament: The fund is imposing too many conditions, often the wrong ones, and providing too little real financial support in Asia's moment of need.
Seven thousand miles away, on Capitol Hill, the I.M.F. is also a target of growing criticism -- but for exactly the opposite reasons. Here, the call is for far more American intrusiveness in I.M.F. programs, and a far smaller American contribution to solving Asia-style crises. At the extreme ends of both parties, there are calls to kill off the I.M.F. altogether. While that is hardly likely, Congress has the opportunity in the next few months to send a message that will be heard in markets around the globe. It will be debating the question of whether the United States should fulfill its commitment to provide $18 billion in additional contributions to the fund so that it can handle new outbreaks of the kind of the economic contagion that is still whipping through Asia. If Congress balks, few doubt that the rest of the world will, too.
Rarely in its 52-year history has the fund been under such concerted attack from so many quarters. Liberals complain that its actions in Asia chiefly benefit the likes of Citicorp and J. P. Morgan, to say nothing of Japan's biggest banks, often at the expense of workers -- both abroad and in the United States -- whose jobs are threatened by its policies. Conservatives say that the emergency help for South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand interferes with free markets, and that they undercut American jobs by encouraging the afflicted countries to export their way out of trouble. Many economists say the I.M.F.'s prescriptions are only making things worse, though because they are economists, they disagree forcefully on what prescriptions would make things better.
CAUGHT in the uncomfortable middle is Mr. Rubin. For three years, since the United States stepped in to rescue Mexico, he has been struggling to get nations around the world to prepare for future crises by bolstering their contributions to the I.M.F. and agreeing that international consortiums, not the United States, serve as the lender of last resort. In Asia, the I.M.F. has taken the lead -- with plenty of behind-the-scenes coaching from Mr. Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers -- although the United States has committed several billion dollars in backup financing, called a "second line of defense," to South Korea and Indonesia. (None has been disbursed.)
The backup financing is chiefly an exercise in market psychology, intended to reassure investors that the United States is willing to play a big role in stabilizing markets. But that same act of symbolism only incenses many American lawmakers, who ask why taxpayers should bail out faraway nations. The Administration fears that the more it supplements the I.M.F., the greater the risk that Congress will pull the plug on contributions altogether.
The public case for deeper American participation was made by President Clinton in his State of the Union address on Tuesday, when he argued that a prosperous Asia would help American exporters. "These countries are our customers," he said, "and if Asia sinks into recession, they won't be able to buy the goods we'd like to sell them."
The private case, one of Mr. Clinton's top aides noted recently, will have to be made by Mr. Rubin. "Basically, it comes down to this," the aide said. "Bob is going to have to say: 'If the Asian meltdown comes to Wall Street, do you want the blame?' "
On the streets of Bangkok, Jakarta and Seoul, the I.M.F. era looks pretty grim -- and the popular sentiment, right or wrong, is that the I.M.F. is making it grimmer.
The search for a scapegoat is understandable: Economic activity has ground to a halt. The cranes towering over half-completed buildings don't move, and tens of thousands of workers who headed back to their hometowns last week for the end of Ramadan and the Chinese New Year have been told not to return. The Thai stock market, which had a market capitalization of $133 billion in 1993, the height of the Southeast Asian boom, is now worth about $22 billion. When it comes to buying overseas goods, Indonesia's currency buys 20 percent of what it did a few months ago. The crisis, in short, has hit the streets.
"Things are a lot worse than people expected, and they could get worse yet," said Teera Phutrakul, who runs an investment firm along one of Bangkok's busiest commercial streets. "That's because of a lot of bad decisions made here in Thailand. But now, along comes the I.M.F. to impose some discipline, and it's very, very politically convenient. The Government can say, 'We have no choice -- Michel Camdessus made us do this,' " he said, referring to the I.M.F.'s managing director.
In Thailand, though, Mr. Camdessus comes off a lot better than President Clinton and Mr. Rubin, whom many in the country's leadership contend were indifferent to Thailand's call for help last summer and only got serious about the Asian crisis when it began to sweep through the continent and around the world. "The Thais felt quite hurt that they saw no signs of support from the U.S.," Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said after returning from a recent tour through Asia. "It left some wounds" -- including some suggestions from Thai officials that they may not be so accommodating the next time the United States needs to move its military forces through Thai air bases.
The I.M.F. program in Thailand is typical of the institution's approach in Asia. Weak financial institutions are being closed down. Interest rates have been pushed up sharply, so that investors have an incentive to buy the local currency. To comply with the I.M.F.'s mandate against budget deficits, the Thais have cut their spending by roughly 30 percent, killing many social programs and public-works projects.
Financial firms are being required to use internationally accepted accounting procedures and to disclose far more data than they ever have before. The new rules are intended to expose the kind of under-the-table deals that have long fueled Asian economies while enriching the politically connected. Real regulation is being imposed, including bank supervisors who are supposed to make sure that money is being lent to sound projects, rather than to cronies.
But this new regime of openness in business, and a war on crony capitalism, requires a huge cultural change in the way Asia has always operated -- a change that is hard to impose from half a world away. And it carries with it a lecturing tone that is already stirring up a popular and political backlash.
The United States, of course, is celebrating any changes that move the Asian economies closer to the American model of capitalism and further from the Japanese model. But for ordinary people, the benefits of such a shift are difficult to see through the swirl of fleeing foreign money and plummeting currencies.
So it is hardly surprising that many Asians are seizing on criticisms of the I.M.F. Jeffrey D. Sachs, the Harvard economist who is a longtime critic of the fund, attracts more Asian reporters than a Hong Kong pop star when he shows up at conferences to make his case that the policies are only making matters worse. High interest rates and rampant bank closures, he says, have simply frozen economic activity. "Even healthy companies cannot get letters of credit to make the exports they need to generate revenue," he says. "Does this make sense?"
OTHER critics, however, say the problem is the I.M.F.'s inability to handle the huge overhang of private, dollar-denominated debt that local companies cannot pay back. In South Korea, this problem is being addressed through an accord with foreign banks that resulted in a tentative deal last week, but there has been no equivalent process in Thailand and Indonesia.
Still other I.M.F. critics, including George Soros, the international financier, say the real problem is the absence of global regulation of global markets. In their view, the international economic and financial order created in the aftermath of World War II, at the Bretton Woods Conference in New Hampshire, needs to be overhauled. That system, of which the I.M.F. and its sister institution, the World Bank, are central elements, worked well for most of the last half-century. But today, these people argue, it has been overwhelmed by 24-hour trading and needs to be updated so it can keep up with the terrifying speed at which money flows in and out of countries.
All of this has left the I.M.F. reeling. It has adjusted its programs slightly to quiet some of the criticism. But its defenders, including Mr. Rubin, say that while Asia is burning, no one should be reorganizing the fire department.
I.M.F. officials, meanwhile, are starting to answer their critics. "None of this will be easy," Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official in the I.M.F., said in a speech last week. The currency depreciations, Mr. Fischer said, have not "occurred by I.M.F. design" and clearly have gone too far. But "without I.M.F. support as a part of an international effort to stabilize these economies, it is likely that these currencies would have lost still more of their value," he added.
Turning to Congressional critics -- whom he was careful not to name -- he said, "Simply letting the chips fall where they may would surely cause more bankruptcies, larger layoffs, deeper recession and even deeper depreciations than would otherwise be necessary to put these economies back on a sound footing."
THE I.M.F.'s troubles in Washington start with the conservative right in Congress, which has long mixed a suspicion of Wall Street and big banks with a streak of isolationism. To some on the right, the problem with the I.M.F. is not just the way it has dealt with the Asian crisis, but the institution's very existence.
Republican critics, like Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina and Representative Ron Paul of Texas. say I.M.F. bailouts have proved ineffective and, worse, have distorted the workings of the free market.
They are a form of welfare for the rich, these skeptics contend, insulating banks and investors from losses they deserve to suffer for misjudging risks in overseas markets. Furthermore, the critics say, the rescue efforts sow the seeds of future disasters by reassuring lenders and investors that even if they repeat their mistakes, the fund will always be there to cushion the blow.
By this line of reasoning, the much-hailed Mexican bailout was actually a failure, encouraging investors to roll the dice again in Asia.
"The I.M.F. is welfare for the very rich investors, and serves only to keep afloat reckless political institutions which have policies that destroy their own economies," said Mr. Paul, once the Libertarian Party's candidate for President and perhaps the most vocal Congressional critic of the fund.
"The big bankers and investors quite correctly support the notion of less government and economic liberty when we talk about their profits, but when losses occur they are quick to call for the Government to socialize the burden," he said on Wednesday, introducing a bill calling for the United States to leave the fund.
While the Clinton Administration views Mr. Paul as the enemy, in private, some officials concede half his point. It is virtually impossible to salvage an ailing economy without also benefiting the banks and investors that poured cash into it. Before the Asian storm clouds turned into a typhoon, Mr. Rubin often raised alarms about the "moral hazard" of encouraging reckless investments.
EVEN now, Mr. Rubin takes pains to distance himself from saving big banks and burned investors. "I would not give one nickel to help any creditor or investor," he said recently, noting that the Asian crisis had hurt profits at J. P. Morgan, Chase and Citibank. But in the next breath, Mr. Rubin noted that the issue is "complex" because "any action to force investors and creditors involuntarily to take losses" would cause all investors to pull their money out of a country -- just at the moment that it needed fresh capital.
Conservatives, however, are hardly the I.M.F.'s only critics in Washington. Some liberals argue that the agency does not demand enough in the way of political and social changes in return for its aid. They want to make the assistance contingent on improvements in human rights, working conditions and environmental standards.
"The American people are going to be very skeptical of any plan to bail out international speculators and repressive regimes that simply encourages them to repeat the same pattern of abuse and excess all over again," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip. "We cannot support a bailout that imposes an economic stranglehold on working people, tramples democratic rights, ignores the underlying causes of instability and then asks the American taxpayer to foot the bill."
The I.M.F. is increasingly sensitive to the criticism that it is props up dictators. In Indonesia, it has forced the breakup of monopolies and an end to Government aid to business ventures run by President Suharto's family and friends. But it has steered clear of making political demands -- that Mr. Suharto, for example, lift the repression in East Timor, which was seized two decades ago. And it has not uttered a word about the delicate question of political succession, even though that is the central issue affecting Indonesia's economic future.
"We can attack crony capitalism," a senior I.M.F. official said. "But it's a stretch to make an economic case for an end to human-rights abuses, beyond urging 'good governance.' "
The Administration hopes to steer clear of these arguments in its effort to persuade Congress to approve $18 billion in new American contributions to the I.M.F. But members of both parties say the price it might have to pay is a severe restriction on its freedom to use the Exchange Stabilization Fund, a $40 billion American kitty for dealing with international currency crises. Now, the Administration can lend the money at its discretion -- just as it did to Mexico in 1995. That prompted Congress to impose a restriction on the use of the exchange stabilization fund that expired just as the Asian crisis broke. Legislation introduced last week would reimpose such a restriction, requiring Congressional approval for dipping into the fund for more than $250 million.
IF Congress worries that I.M.F. bailouts are out of control, Asia worries that Washington secretly runs the I.M.F. And despite Washington's denials, the Asian concerns are not exactly baseless.
The United States has the strongest voice within the fund, an 18 percent voting share, three times that of any other country and enough to wield a veto over major decisions by the fund's board. Moreover, it is often able to persuade other big industrial countries to vote with it, giving Washington a 40 percent voting bloc. Early in the Asian crisis, a senior Administration official boasted this fall, one phone call from Mr. Summers changed key conditions on the Thai bailout.
Still, American power is not absolute. The United States pushed the I.M.F. to provide additional financial aid to Russia two years ago to help prop up the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin, but the agency's management refused, saying it had lent Russia all that its rules allowed.
Other countries have carved out their own spheres of influence. France considers development of French-speaking nations its prerogative, and Britain has championed an initiative to reduce the debt loads of poor nations.
But when a big crisis arises, the United States usually takes charge, as the fund's handling of the most recent crisis in Indonesia illustrated.
Last month, the United States and the fund worked together to send Mr. Camdessus, Mr. Summers, Defense Secretary Cohen and Mr. Fischer, the I.M.F. official, to Jakarta to pound home a crucial message to President Suharto. In a series of meetings over two days, they pressed upon the Indonesian leader the need to agree to tough terms for emergency loans -- and to implement them promptly.
I.M.F. officials said it was no accident that they all carried the same message to Jakarta -- a message that had also been backed up by phone calls from President Clinton to the Indonesian leader.
"We agreed there had to be a major effort," said a senior Fund official. "We had to get to Suharto, and we had to get him to realize the seriousness of the situation."
That message was put together in the White House at a meeting presided over by President Clinton, with Mr. Rubin, Mr. Summers and a range of State Department and National Security officials in attendance. Soon Mr. Suharto received calls from leaders around the world, politely telling him he had no choice.
"A remarkable coincidence of timing," a senior American official deadpanned during Mr. Summers' trip to Jakarta.

A bank worker in Seoul, South Korea, protested austerity measures imposed as a condition of an I.M.F. loan. (Photograph by Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)(pg. 1);Treasury Secretary Rubin finds himself caught in the middle of a debate on the International Monetary Fund. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. 9)
 
Charts: "Many Ailments, One Prescription"
The International Monetary Fund, typically working in concert with Washington and other Western capitals, has prescribed the tough medicine of austerity as the cure for one sick economy after another. Now the Fund is under attack on many fronts: in Congress, by economists, and on the streets of Asia.
 
CASE
Mexico, 1994-95
 
SYMPTOMS
Collapse of the peso amid rampant imports, dwindling foreign reserves and high inflation in an overheated economy.
 
PRESCRIPTION
Austerity, including a clampdown on credit and wages, in exchange for loans and guarantees led by the United States and backed up by the I.M.F. and other institutions.
 
CONSEQUENCES
Widespread bankruptcies. Massive job losses. Increased income inequality, poverty and social strife. But the peso stabilized relatively quickly, and within months Mexico regained the trust of foreign lenders.
 
CASE
Indonesia, 1997-98
 
SYMPTOMS
Collapse of the rupiah amid an explosion of foreign debt and a sharp stock market slide.
 
PRESCRIPTION
Austerity and economic restructuring -- including an end to special deals for businesses linked to President Suharto's family, the forced break-up of monopolies, the closure of failing banks and tight limits on government spending -- in exchange for billions in aid from the I.M.F., the United States and other industrial nations.
 
CONSEQUENCES
Remain to be seen. Analysts expect inflation, unemployment and bankruptcies to skyrocket. The military stands ready to put down social unrest as political opposition to Mr. Suharto begins to emerge. The I.M.F. projects a stagnant economy this year, but renewed growth in 1999. Meanwhile, the rupiah continues to fall.
 
CASE
South Korea, 1997-98
 
SYMPTOMS
Collapse of the won and the stock market under staggering foreign debt in a sheltered economy built on crony capitalism.
 
PRESCRIPTION
Austerity and economic restructuring -- including deep cuts in public spending, tight credit, markets thrown open to imports and foreign investment and the removal of government props for bloated conglomerates -- in return for the biggest I.M.F.-led bailout ever.
 
CONSEQUENCES
Remain to be seen. Growth is screeching to a halt, and analysts expect a boom in unemployment and bankruptcies. Social unrest remains possible, but the stock market has rebounded and the won has steadied. (pg. 1)
 
"A World of Troubles"
International Monetary Fund programs take a variety of forms, depending on the depths of a country's economic woes and its ability to repay loans. But hardly a corner of the world has gone without I.M.F. assistance in the last five years. World Map shows countries where the International Monetary Fund has intervened in the last five years.
 
Program A
Stand-by Arrangements
Cover periods of one to two years and focus on macro-economic policies, like monetary and exchange rates, though they can promote restructuring.
 
Program B
Extended Fund Facilities
Programs of three to four years intended to overcome balance-of-payments difficulties and restructure economies.
 
Programs C or D
Structural and Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facilities
Low-cost loan programs to support economic restructuring of low-income countries.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Read Between the Lines for a Partisan Message

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON used the word Democrat just once in his 74-minute State of the Union address last week -- exactly the same number of times he mentioned the word Republican. They were twinned in a sentence warning Saddam Hussein that the nation was united in demanding that he comply with United Nations weapons inspections.
But the term bipartisan appears eight times -- a none-too-subtle signal to the public that Mr. Clinton wants to put himself above the petty party brawling that preoccupies lesser politicians. 
 Despite the subliminal above-the-fray subtext, this year's State of the Union speech was a highly partisan document that laid a minefield for Republicans and shows how adept the President has become at casting an aggressively partisan message in the nonpartisan terms that are now the fashion of the day.
In the past the President made a Republican thunder-stealing proposal to put more police officers on the street. Last year, the President and his wife, Hillary, played host to a conference on child care at the White House.
In the State of the Union, Mr. Clinton proposed that any budget surplus be reserved for propping up Social Security, thereby setting a trap that Republicans will have difficulty evading.
Mr. Clinton has given himself a ready answer for virtually any Republican plan this year. A capital gains tax cut? Not until the nation's sacred pension fund is safe. More money for the military? Not this year. Roads and bridges? That's robbing the future.
 
A Beauty of a Plan
 The President also proposed $21 billion in new spending to hire 100,000 teachers and build new classrooms for the children of the baby boomers. He wants to expand Medicare to cover 55-to-64-year-olds who have lost their jobs or their health insurance. He proposed a bill of rights for the 150 million Americans who are members of managed health care plans.
Reform the Internal Revenue Service. Hike the minimum wage. Keep guns out of the hands of young criminals. Subsidize child care for working families. Support international efforts to salvage the Asian economies. Clamp down on smoking by teen-agers.
What's not to like?
The beauty of the President's plan is that all of his expensive programs are supposedly financed without increasing the deficit or drawing down the surplus, but not one dime is left for any Republican priorities. Of course, all this depends on a Republican Congress closing corporate tax loopholes that it has rejected several times before, and enacting a huge tobacco tax that is hypothetical at best.
Republicans complain that Mr. Clinton's program will cost $50 billion a year and predict that most of it will never pass. But every time they vote down an Administration proposal, Mr. Clinton will be able to mount the pulpit and decry it as an assault on children, moms, schoolteachers, laborers or poor granny in the nursing home. Demonizing the opposition worked wonders for Mr. Clinton two years ago when Republicans proposed a modest reduction in the rate of growth in Medicare spending.
"These things just torture the Republicans," Paul Begala, one of Mr. Clinton's top political advisers, said with glee. "They'll either pass them or they'll wish they had."
Mr. Begala noted that if Republicans vote with the President -- and four out of five Americans -- on tobacco taxes or gun control, they jeopardize two of their chief sources of funding, the cigarette companies and the National Rifle Association.
Mr. Begala also suggested that the Republicans' only other avenue of attack -- questions about Mr. Clinton's morals -- are unlikely to sway an electorate that appears to like his policies and continues to reward him with high approval ratings. After the State of the Union Speech, a CBS News poll recorded its highest approval of Mr. Clinton's Presidency -- 73 percent. For the moment, at least.
 
A Progressive Agenda
 The White House believes Mr. Clinton is on solid ground in advancing what is for them a broad "progressive" agenda; polls show that the public by a large margin believes that any budget surplus should be used to shore up Social Security and Medicare or to pay down the nation's $5 trillion long-term debt. White House polling shows that less than 15 percent of the public believes that across-the-board tax cuts are warranted now.
Taking a well-worn page from the Republican playbook in response to the President's message, Trent Lott, the Senate Majority Leader, said Mr. Clinton was proposing to take America back to the discredited era of Federal activism.
"The choice is between Big Government or families. More taxes or more freedom," Mr. Lott said, choosing starkly partisan terms at time when they are turning off the public.
The Republican consultant Kenneth M. Duberstein, who served as White House chief of staff in the Reagan Administration, tipped his hat to Mr. Clinton's clever political positioning. He said few of the President's programs would ever be enacted -- but that's not the point.
"He gave a very appealing, politically refined, poll-driven State of the Union address that trots out a lot of popular ideas to grow Government," Mr. Duberstein said.
"This is to provide aid and comfort to liberal Democrats in Congress who are up for re-election," he added. "This is a campaign document; it is not necessarily a governing manuscript."
Another factor is at work in the President's new embrace of old-fashioned Government activism. As the Monica Lewinsky sex-and-perjury scandal plays out, he is going to need all the support he can muster from party loyalists, whom he has often spurned in the past, as he staked out a centrist position. Mr. Clinton will need a core of Democratic support.
 
Rally Round
 Thus he endorsed Senator Edward M. Kennedy's call for an increase in the minimum wage and proposed an expensive program supported by Representative Richard A. Gephardt to aid workers displaced by foreign trade deals.
After all, it only takes 34 votes in the Senate to acquit a President in an impeachment trial.

HEADLINE: In a Reversal, More Blacks Are Moving To the South

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Reversing a half-century exodus from the South, blacks are returning to the region in record numbers, attracted by an improved economy and a more hospitable racial climate, a new study says.
In the first half of the 1990's, the South gained 368,800 black residents, according to the study, while the Northeast lost 233,600 blacks, the Midwest 106,500 and the West 28,700. 
 "For the first time in any five-year period, the South saw net gains of black migrants from the Northeast, Midwest and West," said William H. Frey, a sociology professor at the University of Michigan and the report's author.
"Black professionals and blue-collar workers, as well as blacks who have retired, are reversing decades of migration from the South by moving to the South's economically vibrant rural and urban areas," Mr. Frey said.
The analysis appears in the February edition of "Population Today," published by the independent Population Reference Bureau in Washington.
"Certainly economics is important in migration, but the racial climate has also changed in the South," Mr. Frey said in a telephone interview. The black out-migration between 1910 and the late 1960's was largely a result of the South's hostile racial climate, coupled with the economic pull of Northern cities, he explained.
"Two things have changed since the 1970's: the deindustrialization in Northern manufacturing, the central cities, and the very different racial climate in the South," Mr. Frey said.
In the 1980's the South began to gain black migrants from the Northeast and Midwest, Mr. Frey said, and in the first half of this decade, as California's economy weakened, migration also occurred from the West.
"Most black migrants to the South are of working age, and about one-fifth are college graduates," Mr. Frey said, and they contributed to the growth of the black middle class in cities like Atlanta and Charlotte, N.C.
He reported that the South's population grew faster than any other region's from 1990 to 1996, registering 46 percent of the nation's total growth. In that period, 65 percent of the nation's black population growth occurred in the South.
