HEADLINE: Europe Envies America;
Now, Teen-Agers Turn to Crime

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
IN Berlin, a youngster is robbed on the street by knife-wielding teen-agers who covet his designer-labeled American backpack. In London, a headmaster is stabbed to death by a pupil outside his school. In the Netherlands, a 30-year-old man is trampled to death by teen-agers because he tried to talk them out of tipping other people's motorcycles into a canal. In Strasbourg, France, young people are blamed for setting 100 cars afire last New Year's.
What has happened to Europe's youth? 
 Across much of the continent, governments, police and social workers are challenged by a phenomenon they have difficulty explaining, still less combatting: While overall crime figures are down, crimes by teen-agers are increasing relentlessly. They range from shoplifting to mugging and even to murder.
Embedded in this grim chronicle is a particular irony: the United States, long viewed by many Europeans as a criminal nesting ground, is cast increasingly as a potential model for crime control, thanks to policies like New York City's crackdown on minor offenses and California's life-imprisonment laws for three-time convicted felons. Those practices, Europeans believe, have begun to erase crime from the political agenda across the Atlantic.
While the street-chic of juvenile crime still looks to America for its basketball shoes, baseball hats and baggy pants, Europe's elders see other attractions: In the past few weeks, high officials from Paris and Frankfurt -- Germany's most violent city -- have traveled to New York to examine America's recipe for fighting crime.
This isn't to say, of course, that the actual crime figures for America and Europe have been reversed; however frightening Frankfurt's murder rate is for Germans, it is still only one-sixth the murder rate in New York, where 13.4 murders are committed each year for every 100,000 residents.
What disturbs Europeans, though, is the trend line -- a rise in crime among European youths at the very moment that violent crime among America's teen-agers has begun to drop a bit (even if the drop is far less than the drop in overall American crime). Throughout the 1990's, indeed, violent crime by young Germans has been running ahead of similar crime in the United States.
In 1993, according to German figures, violent crime among German teen-agers, measured by the number of youthful suspects per 100,000 people, was almost 50 percent higher than similar crime in the United States. And just last December, the French police reported a 14 percent leap in juvenile crime in 1996, adding to an 18 percent increase the year before.
Each of Western Europe's nations has its own dynamic, drawn from an explosive mix of racial tension, poverty, envy, drug abuse, broken families, unemployment and alienation. But beyond that there is a broader malaise: Europe is entering a "post" period -- post-welfare state, post-cold war, post-industrial society, post-baby boom.
The days when the middle classes, at least, could guarantee their offspring better, more prosperous times are over. And just as unemployment -- particularly among the young -- seems to have become endemic, slick advertising and peer pressure have come to exert enormous pressure to acquire the unaffordable and perishable icons of the consumption era: this season's sneakers, this month's CD. Why else would the single most prevalent crime among young people in Germany not be drugs but shoplifting?
 
Broken Pledges
 And the postwar years have left some of Europe's societies singularly ill-equipped to cope.
In Britain, schools designed in the heyday of the welfare state to provide every child with a solid education stand today as forlorn reminders of unredeemed pledges. According to British police figures released late last year, semiliterate school-age truants accounted for 40 percent of street crime in London.
In Italy, the judicial system is so broken that almost half the 50,000 people in prisons are awaiting final sentencing. Yet even there, the statistics show a near-doubling of juvenile convictions for violent crimes between 1991 and 1995.
In France, suburban housing projects in some cities have become known as the liberated zones of drug dealers, preying on the unemployed descendants of North African immigrants and the perennially jobless.
Yet the idea of a "three strikes and you're out" crackdown still causes misgivings, colliding with the stubborn sense that Western Europe should have more liberal values than America on how best to treat convicted criminals.
"The security wave breaking over Europe comes from America," the commentator Jean-Gabriel Fredet wrote in the French magazine Le Nouvel Observateur, arguing that prescriptions of mandatory harsh punishment contradict a traditional leftist view of the delinquent as the marginalized victim of "iniquitous" and "exclusive" consumer societies.
In Britain, where Tony Blair's New Labor party has promised a crackdown on juvenile crime, critics argue that America has overcome its crime problems only by creating a prison population of 1.6 million, which reflects a far higher incarceration rate than that of Britain, with a prison population of 60,000.
The politics of crime, of course, is never just about law-breaking. It is also about social values and political agendas: Cracking down on voteless youngsters scores points with an older electorate that feels threatened by rebellious youth. It is also about race.
When Manfred Kanther, Germany's hard-line Interior Minister, unveiled a nine-point plan for "Security Year 1998," much of it assumed that crime equaled illegal immigration. Cut down on unwanted foreigners, the argument went, and you will reduce crime. The idea, however, does not tally with the figures: According to Germany's own police, juvenile crime, which seemed to be on the retreat in the 1980's, is now increasing more rapidly among German citizens, particularly eastern Germans, than among foreigners.
It is in France that juvenile crime is most closely linked to postwar demographic shifts that have not only transformed housing projects into criminal ghettos but have also brought some Europeans up short against their histories: Once colonial powers, Britain and France seem to have failed singularly to absorb those former underlings who seek a new home in the mother country.
Much of the torching of cars in Strasbourg and other French cities is blamed by the authorities on disaffected young people of North African descent; not too long ago, Britain's top police official rekindled suspicions of police racism by bluntly stating that most of London's muggers were black.
 
Looking Abroad
 But does the leveling off in juvenile crime achieved in the United States mean that American get-tough policies are appropriate on this side of the Atlantic?
For some Europeans -- particularly in Germany with its memories of Nazi and Communist dictatorship -- the balance between civil liberty and public order may never be allowed to tip very far in favor of the police and prosecutors. And many cling to the notion that young criminals need crime prevention programs, personal help and rehabilitation as much as punishment.
In Odense, Denmark, crime fighters have instituted such far-reaching and intrusive cooperation between the police, social workers and government officials that crime-fighters routinely visit the parents of young people to warn them that their offspring might be on the brink of criminal associations.
After a visit to New York last month and a meeting with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Petra Roth, the mayor of Frankfurt, was asked if American practices could make the leap to Europe. "A lot is not transferable," she said, citing the idea that "the poorest and the weak" needed help more than punishment. "I'm going a European way," she said.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By David Rampe

 BODY:

DEALS
Another Goliath or Two
The upstart Compaq Computer has agreed to buy the declining Digital Equipment for $9.6 billion, the largest takeover ever in the computer industry. Compaq is the No. 1 maker of personal computers, and the deal marks the ascendancy of PC's over the behemoths that dominated computing in the 1970's. It also suggests that the future of the industry lies not only in small computers but also in networks of machines that span a full range of sizes, prices, scale and power, all linked together . . . SmithKline Beecham ended merger talks with American Home Products. It said its new partner would be Glaxo Wellcome; combined, they would be the world's biggest drug company. 

AT&T
Churchill's Lesson
AT&T, a little bloodied, has re-entered the ring. C. Michael Armstrong, right, its chairman since November, plans to cut 14 percent of the company's jobs, but has also announced plans to offer cheap phone calls over the Internet and wireless phones that will receive calls free. The company says it will spend billions to upgrade its communications network and to introduce a wireless phone with a battery that lasts eight days. The estimated 15,000 to 18,000 job cuts were described as important medicine for the company, which is still reeling from an onslaught of competition. In battle form, Mr. Armstrong recalled Churchill's view of early victories in Africa. "This is not the end," Mr. Armstrong said, paraphrasing the wartime leader. "This is not even the beginning of the end. It is perhaps the end of the beginning." (Article, page 5.)
 
ECONOMY
Fed Sees a Silver Lining
Asia's financial meltdown will soon be felt in the United States, Alan Greenspan has predicted. "Before spring is over," he said in testimony before Congress, tumbling currency values will cause "reductions in demand for our exports and intensified competition from imports." That points to a moderating of economic activity in the United States, and moderating doesn't bother the Fed chief a bit, because the economy is exceptionally healthy and a slowdown would squeeze out any risk of inflation derailing the seven-year-old expansion. The remarks left the strong impression that the Fed was likely to hold interest rates steady for months to come. In the fourth quarter, the economy grew at a 4.3 percent annual rate; growth for the full year was 3.8 percent, the best since 1988. Inflation registered its smallest yearly increase -- less than 2 percent -- in three decades.
 
MARKETS
Earnings Give a Lift
Wall Street cast off recent worries about Asia. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed to a new high during the week, as the markets drew confidence from solid fourth-quarter earnings at companies like Walt Disney and Ford and from the prospects for lower inflation. "Investors went back to the tried-and-true blue chips," said Robert Freedman of John Hancock Funds in Boston. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week at 7,906.50, up 205.76 points for the week.
 
STATE OF THE UNION
Clinton Changes the Topic
President Clinton ignored the sex scandal that threatens his Administration when he addressed Congress in a 74-minute State of the Union address that proposed billions of dollars in new spending on popular programs. The money would come from closing unspecified tax loopholes and from tobacco taxes that are not certain to be enacted. With tax receipts already pouring in from the strong economy, Mr. Clinton asked that "every penny" of any budget surplus be reserved "until we have taken all the necessary measures to strengthen the Social Security system," rather than indulging in a free-for-all of new spending and tax cuts.
 
ASIAN CRISIS
Some Breathing Room
South Korean banks have won agreement to extend payment on $24 billion in short-term loans. The Seoul Government agreed to guarantee repayment of the loans, which have been the focus of intense concern because a failure to pay threatened to topple the country's damaged economy. Next Korea will need to sell a multibillion-dollar bond issue. Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest, has set aside $777 million to cover potentially soured loans in Asia -- the most yet by a Western bank as a cushion against possible defaults. "It is inevitable that other banks will follow," an analyst in London said.
 
JAPAN
Changing the Guard
Japan's Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, right, and his department's top bureaucrat stepped down, unsettling the powerful ministry as it copes with a bribery scandal and tries to steer the nation out of an economic quagmire. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto chose as Mr. Mitsuzuka's replacement a longtime legislator, Hikaru Matsunaga, who started his career as a public prosecutor. The other departing official, Vice Finance Minister Takeshi Komura, may have had more influence on Japan's economic life than anyone else in the country, even the Prime Minister.
 
UNDER INVESTIGATION
Media Secrets
Federal prosecutors are investigating whether an American unit of Reuters commissioned computer specialists to steal confidential information from Bloomberg's corporate computers. At issue is whether Reuters obtained pieces of Bloomberg's computer operating code, the backbone that governs how the company's data terminals work. The two companies -- by far the largest in the financial-terminals business -- have been battling for investment institution customers. Reuters said it was cooperating with the inquiry.
 
AIRLINES
Fight for Dominance
Northwest beat a bid by Delta to get control of Continental, creating a giant airline network to compete with the country's biggest carriers, United and American. Northwest and Continental plan to maintain separate identities and managements, but they will merge flight schedules. The deal may usher in new consolidations, as small carriers form alliances to compete against strong national and international ventures. (Article, page 11.)
 
SUPERSELLERS
Grisham Time, Again
If bookstores somehow missed out on the Christmas bounty, they get a second chance next Wednesday. That is when the ninth John Grisham novel comes out, with 2.5 million hardcover copies landing at chains, small shops, supermarkets and airports. The new opus, "The Street Lawyer," will get a big marketing push from Doubleday to further stoke interest. Full-page ads will print half the book's first chapter and offer the rest via E-mail. Mr. Grisham is a brand name, and virtually review-proof. The latest plot concerns a young lawyer and a homeless man.
 
GREEN TREE
Never Mind the Bonus
Green Tree Financial, a big lender for mobile homes and a high-flier on Wall Street, is encountering stormy weather. It is restating its reported earnings following a change in its accounting methods and is taking charges totaling $390 million against the value of some asset-backed securities. The stock has plunged and the chairman, Lawrence M. Coss, is being forced to repay part of his whopping $102 million bonus for 1996.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Fairness and Riding a Golf Cart

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
I WAS all for Casey Martin's losing his case and not being allowed to ride a cart in PGA tournaments -- until 1964.
I was all for Martin, who has circulatory problems in his right leg that hinder his walking, to be defeated in his lawsuit against the PGA in his trial that begins tomorrow in Eugene, Ore. -- until that dramatic, scorching 98-degree last day in the United States Open at the Congressional Country Club in Washington in 1964. 
 The most stirring golf story of fortitude and stamina is generally told about Ken Venturi's victory in the Open in 1964. As Arthur Daley wrote in this newspaper about that event: "The slim little guy in the white linen cap looked wilted and worn. In the blistering heat . . . he walked with the leaden steps of an old man, the strength sapped from him. He had virtually collapsed after the morning round and a physician accompanied him on the final tour of the course, watching with anxiety.
"Some inner force kept driving Ken Venturi onward until he had reached his date with destiny."
The greatest argument, espoused recently by such golfing deities as Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, against Martin's using a golf cart in tournaments is that stamina is a major part of golf; sometimes a golfer has to walk as many as five miles and up and down hills.
Venturi had struggled mightily to complete the day's final rounds, which were then a single-day 36-hole conclusion.
The following year, the PGA decided to break that test of stamina into two days of 18 holes each. It did so because television wished it, for commercial purposes. "The stamina has been removed," Daley wrote in 1965. "Only the skill remains."
While Palmer and Nicklaus disagree -- and, apparently, Venturi does, too, since he will be testifying for the PGA with the other two -- the Congressional began to put a different slant on things.
In recent years, some equipment changes in golf have also made a difference in the play. The Big Berthas, for example, the metal clubs that have added some 30 yards to many players' drives. It has made players of all sizes hit longer without cranking up, and expending the kind of energy they needed when using hickory-shaft clubs, or even the graphite cudgel. And it contributes to lesser players hitting straighter.
The P.G.A. Championship was also changed, from match play to medal play, because of the demands of television.
An argument is that all these changes were across the board, and all players were equal because they were playing the same number of holes on the same days, and they could use whatever clubs they wanted to use.
In turning down the PGA's request to dismiss the lawsuit, and sending it to court for trial, Tom Coffin, the Federal magistrate, said that the PGA Tour is a public entity and that under the Federal Americans With Disabilities Act it must provide reasonable accommodations for someone with a permanent disability. Golf courses during tournaments, he said, are "places of public accommodations" as defined by the disabilities act.
Coffin added: "What is the PGA Tour? It is an organization formed to provide and operate tournaments for the economic benefit of its members. It is part of the entertainment industry, just as all professional sports are."
His reasoning here isn't compelling. After all, when talking about professional golfers, one speaks of self-employed businessmen, not amateur performers. And what is most important is the level playing field -- even if it is one, in this instance, with hillocks and valleys. But that doesn't go to the heart of the issue, which is this: Does use of a cart change the nature of the game of golf?
No one is certain. But some presume, and heavyweight golfers like Nicklaus and Palmer must be respected, that the physically disadvantaged Martin would have a golfing advantage.
Others presume that Martin would have a golfing disadvantage, because walking loosens up the body for the next shot, instead of riding in a carriage that stiffens the limbs.
But rule changes have transformed most sports. Tennis is not the same since the oversized racquet. Baseball is not the same since the designated hitter and artificial grass. Football is not the same since receivers can wear gloves.
Yes, yes, say the critics, but it's fair for everyone. One player using a cart is a different story.
With that the case, then, as Marie Antoinette might have said, let them all ride in carts if they wish.
As for the PGA Tour executives upholding the bastion of tradition in the Royal and Ancient Game, it should exclude Casey Martin only when the true test of stamina -- 36 holes on the final day of competition -- is returned.
Which will be never, because the PGA takes its marching orders -- a felicitous phrase, no? -- from television.

Rothstein for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Florida Tomato Pickers Take On Growers

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: IMMOKALEE, Fla.

 BODY:
Jose Rocillo, who first came here from Mexico in 1981 to do farm work and at 67 still picks tomatoes, can look around this town of migrant workers these days and say that things are better. The streets are cleaner, he says, and there is less crime.
But financially, Mr. Rocillo is caught in a time warp. Seventeen years ago he made 45 cents for each bucket of tomatoes he picked; now he makes 35 cents. He used to save and send money back home, he says, but now the pay, less than $10,000 a year, is barely enough to live on. 
 "Things are more expensive and the job pays less," Mr. Rocillo said recently as he sat on a rock drinking juice at the store parking lot where buses let out workers whose shirts were stained with the green of tomato at the end of the workday. "You make enough to eat poorly."
The plight of about 2,500 nonunionized tomato pickers here -- mostly Haitian, Mexican and Guatemalan immigrants -- is similar to that of other farm laborers in the nation whose wages, in real or inflation-adjusted terms, have fallen over the last two decades. But in this, the second-largest tomato-growing area in Florida, the state that produces nearly half of the nation's winter tomato crop, workers seeking higher wages are staging work stoppages and hunger strikes, and meeting with public officials and concerned residents to call attention to what they see more as a human rights issue than a pay dispute.
In mid-January, former President Jimmy Carter, whose Carter Center in Atlanta is devoted to resolving conflicts, added his voice to that of Gov. Lawton Chiles and Roman Catholic church officials who have urged a dialogue between growers and workers.
Mr. Carter's intervention ended a 30-day hunger strike by six workers, but the growers have yet to respond to demands for discussions. So far the 10 tomato companies that operate here have maintained through their trade association that their wages compare favorably with those of growers around the country, and they contend that they are going through hard times because of increased competition from Mexican tomato growers under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The Florida Fruit and Vegetable Association, which represents the farmers, estimated that foreign competition had forced more than half of Florida's tomato farms out of business in the last five years, shrinking the industry to 80 farms from 200. Only since 1995, when a settlement agreement set a minimum price for Mexican imports so that domestic growers could remain competitive, has the industry gained some stability, the companies say.
"Farms are holding on in a very tight competitive market," said Ray Gilmer, a spokesman for the group. "Volume out of Mexico remains very high. The only farms that are able to survive are the very large farms that can achieve economies of scale."
But good times and bad times in farming have made no difference to those at the lowest rung. Agricultural economists and some surveys have found that over the last two decades the wages of the nation's more than two million farm workers have declined, some by 20 percent or more, after accounting for inflation. They attribute the decline to factors like a surplus of workers and the diminishing clout of labor unions. Also, it is estimated that 40 percent of agricultural workers are in the United States illegally and are thus easier to exploit.
Immokalee, a town of about 20,000 people in southwest Florida with one of the biggest and poorest labor reserves in the state, sits in sharp contrast near wealthy municipalities like Naples. Tomato pickers in Immokalee say all production costs have gone up except their pay, with growers covering their higher costs by saving on pickers.
Depending on the time of the picking season, which runs from September to May, workers can make as much as $100 a day or as little as $30, they say, but by year's end most of them average a salary of $8,000 to $10,000, well below the poverty level of $13,300 for a family of three. That is enough for a life style of crowded housing conditions, often in trailers, with no telephone, no car and no meat on the table most days. There are no health, vacation or pension benefits, either.
Pressing their case through the Coalition of Immokalee Workers, a grass-roots group with about 750members, the tomato pickers are seeking an average raise of 20 cents a bucket, to 60 cents, which they say would have a negligible impact on tomato prices. They also want to end a practice called "day and a dime," which pays a flat wage for the day plus 10 cents per 32-pound bucket picked. Coalition members say that the system encourages workers to pick more but that at the end of the day it pays less than the piece rate.
"Our focus is to restore our salary to the equivalent of what it was 20 years ago -- that's 20 cents more per bucket," said Lucas Benitez, 22, a former picker who now works for the coalition. "We're not asking for an increase or any benefits."
Last year 2,000 workers signed cards supporting the coalition's call for a raise. In December, 700 to 1,000 workers participated in three one-day strikes, a calibrated action that is used sparingly because most workers cannot afford to miss a day's pay. But only one grower has even acknowledged the workers' request to meet.
That grower, Gargiulo Inc., one of the biggest, agreed to raise the pay per bucket by 10 cents, to 50 cents over the next year, an action the coalition says shows that its salary demand is one growers can afford. Gargiulo and other tomato growers in the area contacted for comment did not return telephone calls.
Mr. Gilmer, of the growers' group, said a recent survey of tomato growers in the area showed workers making $6 to $12 an hour, with the average worker making $8 to $9 -- higher than the national average for farm workers of $7.31. But coalition members counter that the figures are inflated and that the implied annual salary, more than $16,000 for a 40-hour week, 52 weeks a year, is not representative because picking is not a regular job. If the growers wanted to pay workers an annual salary, the coalition says, pickers would gladly accept less, like $15,000.
Greg Asbed, a coalition staff member, said: "You can work anywhere from one to seven days a week, for two to ten hours in a day, due to weather conditions, crop conditions and availability of labor. But there's still an unspoken contract between growers and workers, which is, 'You be there every day even if I don't have work for you.' What needs to be done is to make it a viable occupation by increasing the wage for when they do work."
The coalition, which has some victories to its credit, including exposing harsh working conditions and dissuading a company from lowering wages by staging a five-day strike in 1995, plans to step up actions with more hunger strikes, boycotts and even union organizing if the growers continue to ignore them. The pickers are also planning to send a delegation to Washington to meet with members of Congress and the Department of Labor.
Workers like Mr. Rocillo support the coalition's work -- he participated in two of the work stoppages -- but harbor no hope of a better life. In the end, he said, "the ones that rule are the companies."
After trying his luck in the Carolinas picking cucumbers and earning even less because of rains and the small size of the crop, Mr. Rocillo is staying put and plans to work "as long as the body takes it."

But the workers have begun to press their case. "You make enough to eat poorly," said Jose Rocillo, 67, a picker. (Photographs by Phillipe Diederich for The New York Times)

Britain to Press Case Against Iraq at U.N.

Ties on Iran's President
Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, is by far the most popular man in Iran. But just a few months after his election, he is surrounded by extraordinary obstacles. He lacks a knowledge of economic affairs, and is without a political apparatus. He is confronted by powerful enemies, and the constitution gives supreme authority to another ayatollah. 1
 
Asian Crisis Is U.S. Opening
Asia's financial crisis may well result in a greatly expanded American business presence in Asia. Experts say the Americans may find an open door in banking and other areas. 1

NATIONAL 14-22
 
The Clinton Story: Blurring the Boundaries
For almost two weeks, newspapers and news shows have been dominated by the story of accusations that President Clinton had a sexual relationship with a former White House intern. The story, which has been rife with sensational elements, appears to many in journalism to have blurred the boundaries between mainstream and tabloid news. 1
 
Democrats who only days ago feared that the White House sex scandal would cripple their candidates in a midterm election year now say that, to their amazement, the crisis may be galvanizing party loyalists and bolstering efforts to raise money. 1
 
The lawyer for the former White House intern Monica S. Lewinsky has conceded that his client sometimes embellishes the truth and disputed some of the more sensational second-hand accounts of her relationship with the President. 18
 
The upheaval swirling around the President has brought his original team of loyalists back to the lunch spots of power in Washington. And where a subpoena was once a Scarlet S to be borne in shame, it is now so common that the bonds among the victims of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, are almost worthy of a support group. 18

Ailment Strikes Bald Eagles

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Could It Be? The Red Sox and the Cubs in the 1998 World Series? Nah.

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Think of how the fans of the Boston Red Sox and the Chicago Cubs must have felt last October when the fledgling Florida Marlins won the World Series in only their fifth year of existence. Hardly a Red Sox fan is alive who was there when the team last won a World Series. That was 1918, and the team the Red Sox beat was the Cubs, whose adoring but masochistic fans have waited in vain since 1908 for another championship.
To their credit, the 1998 descendants of those distant winners have gone about their business in a manner opposite the champion Marlins. They have actually tried to put together teams that can win. 
 Can the Red Sox and the Cubs win it all? The instant answer to that question is of course not. Why should this year be any different from all of the others that have been played since they last won the World Series? All right, forget the World Series for the moment. Can the Red Sox and the Cubs win their division titles? Considering the circumstances in their respective divisions, it is not beyond the realm of possibility.
First, the moves the teams have made this winter.
The Red Sox have made the biggest splash of the off season, trading for Pedro Martinez, the National League Cy Young award winner, then making him the highest-paid player in baseball history. They also added Dennis Eckersley, who can still get batters out in the ninth inning.
The Red Sox, who finished 20 games out of first place last season, had to do something with their pitching staff. Theirs was one of the American League's worst last season, struggling with a 4.85 earned run average. In contrast, Martinez breezed through the National League with a 1.90 e.r.a.
Martinez will not be a one-man staff, but he will be the anchor of the rotation, just as Eckersley figures to be the closer. Tom Gordon, who was moved into that role last season after the Red Sox traded Heathcliff Slocumb, wants to continue as the closer, but the Red Sox didn't sign Eckersley to be a setup man.
As important as adding the pitchers, the Red Sox began making peace in the family last week by completing a four-year, $25 million contract with John Valentin. Ousted as the team's shortstop a year ago, Valentin had wanted to be traded and had expected the Red Sox to want to trade him, but he's happy now and hopes that the club can make peace, too, with Mo Vaughn, his fellow Seton Hall star and infield mate.
First baseman Vaughn has a contract for this year, so he will continue to be an imposing force in the Boston lineup. But Valentin knows that a contract extension would make Vaughn happy, too, and could only bode well for the team's chances.
Despite a report that quoted General Manager Dan Duquette as saying the two sides had agreed to financial terms but not length, Tom Reich, Vaughn's agent, said there has been no agreement on anything.
"The only sure thing," Reich said, "is Mo cares plenty for Boston. We haven't talked for two months about this contract and nothing was ever resolved. When it broke off, there had been no components agreed to. I wouldn't be surprised if there weren't some discussions in the near future because it's still where Mo wants to be."
A happy Vaughn and Valentin are important to the Red Sox because they are key parts of the offense that was one of the league's best last season.
The Cubs have apparently grown tired of being lovable losers. They have gone out this winter and shaken up the team that finished not only last in its division, but also tied for the National League's worst won-lost record. They haven't made the kind of economically dramatic moves the Marlins made a year ago, but they have been busy.
With Ryne Sandberg retiring a second time, presumably for good, the Cubs acquired Mickey Morandini from Philadelphia to play second base, and they have installed a new shortstop as well, Jeff Blauser, who brings with him the Atlanta experience of six successive post-season appearances.
Two other newcomers are heavy hitters. Henry Rodriguez, the new left fielder, hit 62 home runs and drove in 186 runs the last two seasons. Rod Beck, the new closer, has amassed the second most saves in the major leagues the last five years.
The Cubs play in a division that has no apparently dominant team. The defending champion Houston Astros suffered a major loss when Darryl Kile, their No. 1 pitcher, fled to Colorado. The St. Louis Cardinals have been viewed as the division's best team on paper, but not even Manager Tony La Russa is predicting a first-place finish this year. The division has a new team, the Milwaukee Brewers, but no self-respecting N.L. franchise is going to allow an American League defector to win the division title in its first year.
The Red Sox will have tougher division rivals to deal with, particularly the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles. But the Yankees right now have half an infield manned by Luis Sojo and Scott Brosius, while the Orioles have lost their closer, Randy Myers, and their winning manager, Davey Johnson.
Should the Red Sox and the Cubs reach the playoffs, could they meet in the World Series? Get serious.
 
Still Available: Mark Lemke
 Pitching has been the key to the Atlanta Braves' six-year run of post-season appearances, but once they reached those October games, they often found Mark Lemke getting a big hit or driving in a critical run. Now, after eight years, Lemke is no longer Atlanta's second baseman.
He is a free agent, and he is one of the few free agents still seeking a job. Of the 138 players who filed for free agency last November, only 10 continue to look for jobs. "We're talking to a lot of teams right now, waiting for the right situation," Lonnie Cooper, Lemke's agent, said. "We've had some serious discussions with some teams, but nothing has reached the point of being formal. It only takes only one club and one offer. A few teams are waiting for certain things to happen."
In other words, Lemke's immediate future could depend on if, when and to whom the Minnesota Twins trade Chuck Knoblauch.
The Yankees, Cooper said, are not a possibility for Lemke. "Right now, they're pretty pleased with their roster," the agent said.
 
Mightier Than Jordan
 Two years ago yesterday, Ken Griffey Jr. became the highest-paid player in baseball ($8.5 million a year). Now he doesn't even make the top 10. In fact, if Bernie Williams wins his salary arbitration case with the Yankees, the top 10 will consist entirely of players who earn $9 million or more a year.
Griffey, however, can claim a distinction not many athletes can: he outdid Michael Jordan. In the recently completed balloting for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, Jordan led all players with 1,028,235 votes, a paltry sum compared with the 3,514,340 votes Junior received in last season's baseball All-Star election.
But Griffey didn't just outpoll Jordan; he received more votes than were cast in the entire N.B.A. voting. That total was 3.3 million, less than one-third of baseball's 1997 total of 10.65 million.
 
Rose Shadows Shoeless Joe
 The latest attempt to have Shoeless Joe Jackson removed from baseball's ineligible list so that he can be voted into the Hall of Fame would have a greater chance of success if Pete Rose were not also on the ineligible list. If baseball's executive council cleared Jackson, Rose and his supporters would use that move to hound baseball to do the same for him, and the cases are not the same.
Hall of Fame officials, on the other hand, are being disingenuous by saying the matter is out of their hands because their rules do not permit entry by a player on the ineligible list. They changed the rule to its present reading to keep Rose off the writers' ballot, and if they so desired, they could change it back.

HEADLINE: Worsening Financial Flu in Asia Lowers Immunity to U.S. Business

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Picture Mom, Dad and the kids in an upper-middle-class Asian family in 10 years' time:
After loading up with cash at the corner Citibank, they drive off to Walmart and fill the trunk of their Ford with the likes of Fritos and Snickers. On the way home, they stop at the American-owned Cineplex to catch the latest Disney movie, paying with their Visa card. In the evening, after putting the kids to bed, Mom and Dad argue furiously about whether to invest in a Fidelity mutual fund or in a life insurance policy issued by American International Group. 
There's only one way to settle the dispute: they stalk off to sign on to their respective America Online and Dow Jones accounts, each to gather evidence of the other's stupidity.
Well, it may not happen exactly like that, except in the dreams of the United States Commerce Department. But many experts believe that one of the most far-reaching consequences of the Asian financial crisis will be a greatly expanded American business presence in Asia -- particularly in markets like banking that have historically been sensitive and often closed.
"This is a crisis, but it is also a tremendous opportunity for the U.S.," said Muthiah Alagappa, a Malaysian scholar at the East-West Center in Honolulu. "This strengthens the position of American companies in Asia."
Market pressures -- principally desperation for cash -- and some arm-twisting by the United States and the International Monetary Fund mean that Western companies are gaining entry to previously closed Asian markets.
And the timing, from the United States' point of view, is perfect: regulations are being eased just as Asian banks, securities firms, even airlines are coming on the market at bargain prices.
As a result, while American companies are hurting now because of the turbulence in Asia, American banks and insurance companies and others could eventually emerge as beneficiaries of the crisis.
"Most of these countries are going to go through a deep and dark tunnel," said Jeffrey Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management. "But on the other end there is going to be a significantly different Asia, and it will be an Asia in which American firms have achieved much deeper penetration, much greater access."
"You would have seen a lot of this anyway over the next decade or so," Mr. Garten added. "But it's going to happen at an order of magnitude and with a degree of speed that nobody could have conceived of just six months ago."
Still, it will take time for American companies to build their presence, and no one knows how they will do in unfamiliar markets. Moreover, even if they thrive, this may not do much for the American trade accounts or for American employment, for the Fords sold in Asia will be mostly made in Asia, and virtually all of the bank and insurance company staff will be local as well.
One central question is whether an increasing American presence will spark antagonism toward the United States, which is seen as pushing its commercial interests as the price for throwing a lifeline to Asian economies.
The United States insists that the main beneficiaries of open markets will be local residents -- who will probably get new kinds of insurance and banks that offer better service. But the changes may set off alarm bells about economic colonialism.
"All our stocks and companies are dirt-cheap," said Jusuf Wanandi, the head of a research institute in Jakarta, Indonesia. "There may be a tendency for foreigners to take over everything." Perceptions that this is happening, Mr. Wanandi warned, could lead to a "new nationalism."
And now the gates are giving way.
 
Early Evidence Of Asian Acquiescence
Among the most important beneficiaries as Asian markets open are the American financial service companies, especially those like Citibank that have already been building their presence in Asia.
Opportunities are also expected for industrial companies like General Motors or large retailers like Walmart that operate in sectors where barriers to entry have been common. All these companies, whether banks or other businesses, bring superb technology and cost-control procedures to the new markets, but they will be hampered by lack of local experience.
"There is a place for everyone," said Emilio T. Antonio, director of the Institute for Economic Policy Research at the University of Asia and the Pacific in the Philippines. "Local firms know the market much better than foreign firms, and so they may have an advantage in some areas."
"Look at fast food here in the Philippines," he added. "There is a local firm, Jolibee, that went head-to-head with McDonald's, and Jolibee seems to be doing better. So foreign firms have an edge in some areas, but they won't take everything."
Asian countries have been steadily opening their economies in recent years, but they have generally been much more willing to admit McDonald's than Citibank. Governments in the region have sometimes owned banks and almost always controlled them, and leaders frequently regarded pinstriped American bankers as uncontrollable, untrustworthy and unpredictable barbarians at their gates.
A clear indication that the Asian crisis would further the American agenda came in December, when 102 nations agreed to open their financial markets to foreign companies beginning in 1999. It is unclear how the pact will be carried out, but it marks an important victory for the United States, which excels in banking, insurance and securities.
Fundamentally, that agreement and other changes are coming about because Asian countries, their economies gasping, are now less single-minded in their concern about maintaining control. Desperate for cash, they are less able to pick and choose, less able to withstand American or monetary fund demands that they open up. More broadly, in some countries there is a disgust at the old corporate oligopolies and a movement for free competition.
In South Korea, as a direct result of the crisis, the Government is talking about selling two of the biggest banks to foreigners, and teetering local securities firms are searching for foreign takeovers. Under an agreement with the monetary fund, foreign banks will be able to compete in Korea beginning this year, and the Government is considering ways to ease the restrictions that prevent foreigners from buying Korean land. Walmart is studying whether to open outlets in the country.
In Thailand, under pressure from the I.M.F., the Government was forced to scrap a regulation that limited foreign corporations to a 25 percent stake in financial companies. Citibank has signed a memorandum of understanding on the purchase of a major bank, First Bangkok City Bank. Thai Government officials have predicted that foreign companies will soon dominate Thailand's financial sector.
Indonesia has said foreign banks can take a stake in a new bank that will be formed from several weaker, smaller ones. The national car project is also losing key benefits, which effectively opens up the auto market to foreign competition.
Almost two weeks ago Hong Kong, already the most open market in Asia, resolved an 18-month domestic negotiation by announcing the end of a local company's monopoly on long-distance telephone service. The result will be virtually complete liberalization of the territory's telecommunications market.
As for Japan, it agreed on Friday to a landmark package, resisted for many years, to liberalize air travel links to the United States. The aviation agreement will mean more opportunities for American airlines, which are much more efficient than their Japanese rivals.
In the financial arena, Merrill Lynch is talking about buying part of the branch network of Yamaichi Securities, a Japanese giant that collapsed in November. In December, Fidelity Investments opened counters in Japanese banks to sell mutual funds to Japanese customers, and foreign companies succeeded last year in doubling the amount of Japanese money that they manage, to a total of more than $20 billion.
This activity in Japan does not all arise directly from the Asian financial crisis, and the aviation accord had been under discussion for years. But the new moves do reflect Japan's long economic downturn and a growing sentiment within Japan that, at least in theory, the way to restore growth is to open markets and foster greater competition.
One consequence of that changing mood is the "big bang" opening of Japan's financial markets, beginning April 1, which is intended to reinvigorate the national economy. The big bang is expected to create new opportunities for American and European banks and securities firms.
"I agree with the big bang," said a Japanese banker, "but I'm not so sure about the timing. I'm worried that the American banks will come in and take over everything."
 
U.S. Apples in Japan: No Barrel Spoilers
It may be instructive to recall the similar gloom when American apples were first admitted to Japan three years ago. Despite predictions that cheap American apples would wipe out Japanese apple farmers, it turned out that many Japanese consumers did not much like American apples. So American apples have gained an important presence in Japan, but the market is still dominated by Japanese apples.
Still, American banks and securities firms have some major advantages over their Thai, Indonesian and even Japanese counterparts; it may be that in a decade American banks will be almost as common in Asia as McDonald's. American financial institutions are well served by their technology, product range, marketing skills and ruthless efficiency.
"Asian financial institutions are out of date for the present task," said Masaru Yoshitomi, a prominent Japanese economist at the Long Term Credit Bank Research Institute. "The efficiency of those Asian institutions has to be increased."
In Tokyo, for example, Citibank has gained customers in part because it is the only major bank whose cash machines operate all the time. Other banks' cash machines are turned off at night.
In addition, with domestic financial institutions crashing left and right, these days consumers have much more faith in the solvency of international banks.
The United States Government insists that it is not a predatory beast forcing its companies on Asia, and many officials and outside economists alike argue that the policies of greater openness advocated by Washington are good for the countries on the receiving end. Although Washington pushed for more open markets, American officials say, that effort has been secondary to the effort to bail those countries out.
"Narrow self-interest was not a major element in our approach," said Stephen Bosworth, the American Ambassador to South Korea. "I think the driving force of our approach to the region has been that we believe that the best thing that can happen for American economic interests is to be dealing with strong, healthy economies in Asia."
Not everyone is so confident of American motives. A United States business expansion in Asia has long been regarded as a nightmare by nationalists in the region. Thus, for some nations trying to preserve their identity and autonomy, the American market-opening pressures smack of economic colonialism.
"We must realize the great danger facing our country," Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia declared in a televised speech a few days ago. "If we are not careful we will be recolonized."
 
No to American Shoves, Yes to Globalization
 Still, at least for now, much of Asia seems to accept the growing presence of Western financial institutions as an inevitable consequence of globalization. Mr. Yoshitomi, the Japanese economist, said that although the United States had been "stupid and colonial-style" in pushing its interests during the crisis, the new opportunities for American banks were primarily the result of economic factors, not of American shoves.
"It's already taking place, and it's a quite clear trend," Mr. Yoshitomi said of the increasing presence in Asia of American banks. "It's a result of the economic crisis and of market forces."
Even in Korea, which has often been deeply suspicious of United States trade intentions, there is surprisingly broad acceptance of the opening of financial markets as a reflection of broad market forces and not just American machinations.
"We think the entry of U.S. banks and other financial institutions into Korea is just a sign of the times," said Choo Won Suh, chairman of the Korea Federation of Bank and Financial Labor Unions, although he is clearly apprehensive.
"I hope that U.S. banks that acquire Korean banks will respect the culture and practices of Korean banks," he said. "I cannot speculate on how many Korean bank workers may be laid off after being taken over by a U.S. bank, and I am aware of the fact that layoffs will occur."
While most analysts agree that Western companies will have historic opportunities, some say the question is whether they will be aggressive about seizing them.
Asia is now being buffeted by turbulence, with its political and economic prospects profoundly uncertain. And Western companies are cautious about announcing major investments in countries that could still declare a formal debt moratorium or erupt in riots.
A result is that American companies are apprehensive about investing in Asia, just when some specialists emphasize the bargains to be had. Stock prices and currencies have now plunged so far that it may cost less than one-fifth last summer's prices to buy an Indonesian or Thai company.
"This is the best time," said Divyang Shah, an economist in Singapore for IDEA, a financial consulting company. "It's like a fire sale."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Western companies are gaining entry to previously closed Asian markets. A familiar logo on a Seoul street signals a new Korean accord with the International Monetary Fund to open competition to American banks. (Paul Barker for The New York Times)(pg. 8)

HEADLINE: Schools Aren't Factories, Pupils Aren't Products;
Bonuses to Families

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As well meaning as the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce's plan is to supplement salaries to superintendents, principals and teachers if they are able to raise student academic performance, it is good money in a wrong place (front page, Jan. 27). 
 The home is the most effective environment to develop children's interest in reading and learning. Therefore, bonuses should be given to families whose children's academic performance improves to standard levels. This is an economic incentive to families, particularly those at the lower economic level, and could be a catalyst for more parent involvement in their children's education.
Such a program would be more costly than the $30 million proposed by the partnership, but it would require fewer remedial teachers and security people in future years and would result in fewer disciplinary problems.
 
BERNARD SCHARFSTEIN
Hoboken, N.J., Jan. 28, 1998

HEADLINE: Britain to Urge U.N. to Find Iraq in Violation of Arms Terms

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sunday, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Stressing that Britain and the United States are united in their commitment "to prevent a brutal dictator from acquiring weapons of mass destruction," Britain is seeking a Security Council resolution to find Saddam Hussein "in breach of his obligations" to the Council, Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said in London on Saturday.
After a meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Mr. Cook suggested that such a resolution -- which could be introduced next week and would come before any military attack on Iraq -- might be coupled with an expansion of the oil-for-food program. 
 Under that plan, Iraqi oil is sold to buy food, medicine and other relief items needed by ordinary Iraqis.
"The objective is to find as tough a resolution as is possible making it clear that Saddam Hussein is in breach of his obligations and the authority of the Security Council is on the line here," Mr. Cook said.
Ms. Albright met with British officials before traveling here for talks on the Middle East peace effort.
While the United States and Britain say they need no further authority for an attack, such a resolution could provide additional legal and international support.
Among the permanent members of the Security Council, the United States and Britain most strongly support a military option. France has moved closer to that position while Russia, which has sent envoys to Baghdad, and China have pressed for continued diplomatic efforts.
At the same time, Mr. Cook said, in views similar to those expressed by French officials, it is important to demonstrate that the world is confronting Mr. Hussein's intransigence over United Nations weapons inspections and not trying to punish ordinary Iraqis.
President Jacques Chirac of France, while supporting the American view that force might be necessary as a last resort, has proposed quadrupling the oil-for-food program to allow $4 billion worth of oil to be sold every three months.
While repeating the American view that the time is fast running out for diplomacy, Ms. Albright said the United States supported the idea of a resolution, and said Washington had proposed the oil-for-food program in the first place.
"It shows we care more for the Iraqi people than Saddam Hussein does himself," she said. "There is not a civilized person in the world who would use women and children as human shields."
A unified statement from the Security Council condemning Iraq could be useful, Ms. Albright said.
"We would welcome such an act," she said, "because I do think it's important to send the strongest possible signal to Saddam Hussein that he is in breach and in contravention to the will of the international community."
But she also said the United States would be prepared to act alone, if necessary, to try to force President Hussein to allow United Nations weapons inspectors to do their job in Iraq without conditions.
If they are not allowed to do that job, American officials have said, the United States and Britain will try to destroy as many of the suspected weapons sites as possible and damage Mr. Hussein's "ability to threaten his neighbors."
Both Mr. Cook and Ms. Albright said they preferred a diplomatic solution that would let United Nations inspectors continue their work.
With Iraq's nuclear program essentially dismantled and its ballistic missile program nearly so, Mr. Cook said, "it is very important that we not leave the job half done," and insure that Iraq's chemical and biological warfare programs are also destroyed.
How that can be accomplished if an attack on Iraq causes Mr. Hussein to expel United Nations inspectors is not clear.
But American officials say that Mr. Hussein is not letting them do their jobs now in any case, and that if diplomacy is not working, force or the threat of force might.
Mr. Cook suggested that his meeting with Ms. Albright was "part of intense efforts to find a diplomatic resolution to the current crisis."
But Mr. Hussein cannot be allowed to continue to produce enough anthrax every week for two warheads and to produce VX nerve gas "on an industrial scale," Mr. Cook said.
"The best prospect of a diplomatic solution," he said, "is to leave Saddam Hussein in no doubt about our resolve to win this struggle, and that all options remain open to us."
Mr. Hussein has about two weeks to ponder his options, Mr. Cook said.
"We've been at diplomacy for several months," Ms. Albright said, "and it looks as though diplomacy is not working, and that is the basic issue and problem."
While the United States is content for others, like the British, French and Russians, to take the lead now diplomatically, she said, "there is no doubt in my mind that the time for diplomacy is fast expiring."
After arriving in Jerusalem Saturday evening, Ms. Albright spent about four and a half hours with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over dinner.
Most of the discussion was on the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace process, but she also briefed the Israelis on the Iraq crisis, said her spokesman, James P. Rubin.
Dinner broke up at 1:30 this morning, and Ms. Albright canceled a planned press conference and went to bed.
American officials traveling with Ms. Albright said her meetings were a follow-up to the Washington sessions President Clinton held with Mr. Netanyahu on Jan. 20 and Mr. Arafat on Jan. 22.
The Americans are proposing a phased withdrawal of Israeli troops from a portion of the West Bank in parallel with specific Palestinian moves to improve their fight against terrorism and their security cooperation with Israel.

HEADLINE: Flushing Out the Foul And the Frustration;
A New Vista for a Dead-End Canal

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
For more than 35 years, as Cobble Hill, Park Slope, and other Brooklyn neighborhoods of brownstone and old brick have revived, a mile-long corridor through the middle of the area has continued to crumble, collect weeds and drive people away.
The dead zone extends for several blocks along the banks of the malodorous Gowanus Canal, a dead-end waterway -- nicknamed "Perfume Creek" and "Lavender Lake" by nearby residents -- that was carved in the 1860's to drain swamps and provide a passage for barges but that today serves mainly as a catch basin for sewage when rainstorms overwhelm treatment plants. 
 Now the canal is due for a big flush.
An 87-year-old pump and a long-forgotten brick tunnel that can funnel relatively clean water from New York Harbor through the stagnant canal have been repaired after lying unused since the early 1960's.
By June, city environmental officials expect to complete the last step in the $10 million project: clearing 2,000 tons of pollution-tainted mud from the spot where the tunnel meets the canal.
The pump, powered by a 12-foot-diameter bronze propeller, will begin to churn, sending up to 300 million gallons of oxygen-rich water coursing along the waterway every day, reviving the ecology, and possibly reviving prospects for the long-suffering neighborhoods around it.
After decades of skepticism that anything would be done to clean the Gowanus, community groups and business owners along its banks are talking seriously of renewal, even of canal-side coffee bars, bird-watching and kayaking.
No one expects an instant transformation. The new flow of water will only dilute, not eliminate, pollution. Sewers will still overflow into the canal after heavy rains.
But George Magnifico, who owns an electronics company on the banks of the canal, said he might finally achieve a long-delayed dream: piloting his 48-foot powerboat, the Elegant Annie, from his Long Island home to work. "Once that flow starts, the Gowanus Canal is going to become the Gowanus River," Mr. Magnifico said. "This would be a great place to keep my boat. I could see a marina over here really easily. I can see people fishing."
Some residents of the Gowanus neighborhood are reviving dreams of a Brooklyn-style variant of Venice. Chief among them is Salvatore Scotto, a lifelong resident.
"It's been agonizingly slow, but we are going forward," said Mr. Scotto, a founder of the Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation, a private group seeking to build housing and bring new businesses to the canal corridor. He has been hearing promises of a canal cleanup from City Hall since the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay.
At the turn of the century, the canal bustled with barge and tug traffic, but its waters were insufferably fouled by sewage, oil and industrial pollution.
Around 1910, city sanitation engineers traveled to Milwaukee and Chicago to examine pumping systems that flushed polluted waterways.
For just under $1 million, the city carved a 6,300-foot tunnel through the sandy underpinnings of Red Hook and Carroll Gardens, creating a brick-lined conduit linking the harbor with the canal's end. A salvaged ship's propeller driven by an electric motor could run forward or backward, flushing the canal in either direction, synchronized with the tides.
The "flushing tunnel" was turned on with much fanfare on June 21, 1911, with parades of boats and automobiles celebrating the prospect of fresh air and clean water.
But in the 1960's, the shaft driving the propeller broke. It was never fixed because city engineers concluded that a sewage treatment plant planned for Red Hook would eliminate the infamous aroma of the Gowanus once and for all by capturing contaminants before they spilled into the waterway.
But even after the treatment plant opened in 1987, the canal remained a smelly backwater. City officials say that that should change in June, when the pump should begin pulling water from the harbor 24 hours a day and sending it coursing through the canal.
For some residents, half a lifetime has come and gone as they have sought to transform abandoned lots, truck graveyards and warehouses along the waterway.
Many sidewalks along the canal remain cratered and cracked, discouraging all but the most determined dog walkers. At one vacant lot recently, the only activity was in an overturned van, where several homeless people had encamped.
A few businesses have moved in, like Mr. Magnifico's company, Amtronics, which builds small parts for electronic appliances and employs 65 people. But the canal has always been a detriment.
Mr. Magnifico said he has explained to prospective employees, as they eyed the opaque water, that the canal was due for a change. But the change has never come.
The water is cleaner than it was 25 years ago, when scientists detected organisms that cause typhoid and cholera. But on hot summer days after a rain, residents and city officials say, the smell is the same.
Mr. Scotto said the city never took the canal cleanup seriously because officials were always focused on reviving industrial activity rather than parks or bike paths.
"New York City never learned to use its waterways for people," Mr. Scotto said. "Maybe they're finally beginning to understand that the Industrial Revolution is over."
Officials of the City Department of Environmental Protection said that the repairs to the pump and tunnel were delayed by a variety of factors, including a prolonged search for a contractor able to build a new propeller for the flushing system.
The city also had to comply with a complicated array of state and Federal environmental regulations covering dredging and the discharge of pollution into coastal waters like New York Harbor.
The flow in the canal and in Gowanus Bay, the inlet where the water re-enters the harbor, will be tested for a year to be certain that no pollutants trapped in the canal's silty bottom are stirred up.
Some environmental groups and some residents remain concerned that the pumping program will not eliminate the core problem causing the smells -- the occasional release of raw sewage into the canal every time the city sewers become overburdened with runoff from storms.
Mr. Scotto's organization has called for construction of underground tanks to capture sewage overflows before they enter the canal. But city officials said that would be far too costly.
Some environmental groups also say that the amount of monitoring of the resurgent canal is insufficient, with no checks planned for bacteria or other harmful organisms or chemicals.
Past tests of mud from the canal bottom have found lead and other harmful heavy metals, more than 10 kinds of insecticides, high levels of PCB's -- an industrial chemical that is suspected of causing cancer -- and harmful sulfides produced when sewage decomposes.
Other groups have urged that the entire waterway be dredged, to remove decades of toxic deposits and to make the canal more fit for boat traffic. But as with the rest of the harbor, there is still no consensus on how to deal with contaminated mud.
Over all, in an informal survey of some New York City environmental groups, it was hard to find anyone totally opposed to reactivating the pump. John C. Muir, the executive director of the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment, a private group, said: "Should they not turn it on? I'd be the most unpopular man in Brooklyn if I said that. No one wants that. We've waited far too long for clean water.
"The Gowanus is the back of beyond as far as the waterfront goes," said Mr. Muir, a distant relative of the naturalist John Muir, who founded the Sierra Club. "It's not only been a hidden secret, it's been a dirty secret."
Even with the canal in its current condition, with oxygen so rare that no fish can live in the water, trees still take root in the oil-soaked banks, Mr. Muir said. With a new pulse of harbor water starting this summer, he said, "the birds and fish will return." And soon after, he predicted, the canal will be reclaimed by people in nearby neighborhoods, where the only park, Carroll Park, is primarily asphalt.
Mr. Scotto's group has counted 250,000 people residing within a short walk of the canal, many of whom are eager for space to walk and for untainted air to breathe.
"Clean it and they will come," Mr. Muir said. "My favorite image is of a row of willow trees with their fronds trailing in the water showing the current passing. It could really happen."

Cleaner water will soon flow into the end of the Gowanus Canal, in Brooklyn, flushing it out after more than 30 years. A tunnel, long out of order, will be opened in June to let water flow from New York Harbor into the canal. Map of Brooklyn shows the Gowanus Bay and the Flushing tunnel.
 
1. INSTALLATION OF PROPELLER
The water will be pulled by a new propeller. The original, from a ship, broke down in the early 1960's and was never fixed.
 
2. DREDGING
To let the water flow from the tunnel, 2,000 tons of mud and sewage will be removed.
 
3. TUNNEL OPENING
After dredging, the artificial current coming from the tunnel will let water circulate through its 1.2-mile length.
 
PUMP MOTOR
A 400-horse- power motor drives the propeller.
 
FLUSHING TUNNEL
The tunnel, constructed in 1910, will draw 300 million gallons of water a day from New York Harbor into the canal.
 
During heavy rainstorms, runoff from sewers in the area goes into the canal. The clean water flowing from the flushing tunnel will wash the waste water out.
