HEADLINE: BENEATH THE TURBAN: A special report.;
Mullah Who Charmed Iran Is Struggling to Change It

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran

 BODY:
The mullah wore beautiful shoes.
Simple, elegant black leather shoes with laces, not the rough slippers favored by Iran's ruling class of clerics. 
 The shoes complemented the crisp gray pin-striped robe and matching black cloak and turban. So did the string of small turquoise-colored prayer beads that he dangled in his left hand.
During a recent chance encounter with an American guest in the glittery presidential compound, President Mohammad Khatami was radiant, even regal. As is the custom between Iranian Shiite clerics and women who are not close family members, he did not shake hands.
But unlike the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the leader of Iran's revolution of 1979, and his successor, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who sat far away and turned their gaze from this visitor during interviews years ago, Mr. Khatami smiled broadly and looked straight at his guest in an armchair close by.
The 54-year-old cleric spoke passionately about the need for women's advancement and for communication among cultures. He showed off his English, saying that he reads it better than he speaks and that he reads a lot.
"We say we love all the people in the world and we want them to love us in return," he said. "Resentments should be turned into kindness and love."
All-we-need-is-love may not be enough. Granted, Mr. Khatami is by far the most popular man in Iran, a soft-spoken, speed-reading, Internet-literate leader who has dared to say that many revolutionary policies must change.
But five months after taking office, he is finding extraordinary obstacles as he moves within the constraints of the Islamic Republic in which he believes. He admits that he knows little about the economy, whose direction is determined by a five-year plan that he inherited. He lacks a political apparatus or party to give cohesion to his goals. He is confronted by powerful political enemies who are determined to deprive him of the power to shape policy and to reach out to the United States.
Most crucial, under Iran's Constitution Ayatollah Khamenei, the "Supreme Leader" of the Islamic Republic, is more important than the President, with control over the armed forces, the judiciary and the security, intelligence and broadcasting services. On many issues, the two men have sharply different views.
And in the eyes of the Clinton Administration, Mr. Khatami has yet to prove he has the power or the will to curb groups and individuals engaged in activities the United States defines as terrorism and in programs to develop nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and a ballistic missile capability.
He has yet to articulate his view on Ayatollah Khomeini's decree that the British writer Salman Rushdie insulted the prophet Mohammed in a novel and should be put to death.
"More than at any time in our revolution we need a person like Mr. Khatami," said Ezzatollah Sahabi, a layman who was a member of Iran's ruling Revolutionary Council early in the revolution and now runs an opposition magazine. "He has tremendous popular support, but it is not organized. The other side has all the power. He is under tremendous pressure."
 
The Early Years
Envied Upbringing In a Clerical Family
Behind a wall in the small, dusty village of Ardakan in central Iran is the spacious mud-colored house with a stone terrace where Mohammad Khatami was born. His mother, the daughter of a wealthy landowner, was only 15 when she married his father, a learned ayatollah who became the leader of Friday Prayers in the provincial capital, Yazd, and one of the country's most beloved religious leaders.
Sitting in the house in Yazd where she lives with one of her daughters, the President's mother, 77-year-old Sakineh Ziai, tells this story: Years before the revolution, the security police summoned Ayatollah Khatami for questioning. "But as he entered all the people bowed to him and kissed his hand," she said, laughing. "The authorities told him to go home."
The Khatami family lived an exceptionally comfortable life for a clerical family. In addition to the large residence in the center of town, they owned a summer house a few miles away with a lush garden of pomegranate trees and an enormous, deep concrete pool -- for water storage, but, more important, for swimming.
"We had no restrictions on anything," said Maryam Khatami, the President's 48-year-old sister, who is a schoolteacher in Yazd. "We could spend as much as we wanted."
Still, the Khatami children were encouraged to earn their own money, said Ali Khatami, 44, the President's brother, a businessman who lived in Fort Lee, N.J., for a year and a half while he was getting his master's degree in industrial engineering. "We made good money on the pomegranates," he said.
Unlike other clerics, Ayatollah Khatami allowed his family to listen to the radio (the news, not the music) and to read -- poetry, novels, newspapers, even books banned by other clerics.
As a child, Mohammad Khatami talked about becoming a doctor. But it was clear his father wanted him to become a cleric.
He went to Qom when he was a teen-ager to study religion; but when he wanted to study philosophy as well, his father sent him to the best university in the field, in Isfahan. It was there he was exposed to Western ideals of freedom and civic responsibility could be incorporated into Islam. He also became a disciple of a firebrand preacher named Ayatollah Khomeini.
Although some clerics avoided the military, Mr. Khatami fulfilled his two-year mandatory military service as a junior lieutenant in the Shah's army. "He looked at the military as an education he should have," said his sister Fatimeh, 60, a women's rights advocate for Ardakan. "It wasn't considered support for the Shah."
As was the custom in religious families, his marriage was arranged by his family, recalled his wife, Zohreh Sadeghi, 48.
The First Lady is an articulate woman, the daughter of a famous professor of religious law. Seated in an armchair in the sumptuous Pink Palace, which used to belong to Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, she opened her head-to-toe chador to reveal a printed head scarf, tinted brown hair and a black tailored jacket with white piping. She was wearing a heavy layer of foundation and a hint of blush.
"My father went and spoke to him and then he came to our house," she recalled, giggling. "I met him just once before we married. I do not remember how long our meeting was, but it was longer than 10 minutes. I fell in love at first sight." Two months later, they were married.
Mr. Khatami played only a peripheral role in the revolution. As the head of Iran's cultural center in Hamburg, he organized Iranian students studying abroad and wrote leaflets in opposition to the Shah, learning German along the way.
Although he briefly served as head of a publishing house and was elected to the first Parliament after the revolution, it was only after he was appointed Minister of Islamic Guidance and Culture in 1982 that he earned a national reputation for easing restrictions on films, music, art and literature.
During that decade, he was obsessed by his work. "In comparison with other fathers I can say he never in his life had enough time to be with his children," said his daughter Leila, 22, a mathematics major in Teheran and the oldest of his three children.
But he was not strong enough to prevail, and in 1992 the Parliament forced him to resign. In an impassioned resignation letter, he complained of threats and ill will and called the "creation of "a superior culture" a "weighty responsibility" that, he said, had become impossible for him.
"He did what he had to do," said his sister Zahra Khatami, 32, a schoolteacher in Yazd. "When he felt he couldn't continue, he resigned."
He was banished to the National Library in Teheran and faded from public view. He developed a passion for the Internet, envisioning a time when Iranians in remote villages could log on to the information contained within the library walls.
He also wrote two books. In one, "Fear of the Wave," he proclaims Islam superior to Western thought, but acknowledges that the West offers something "that is one of the basic needs of human beings: freedom." Because of this freedom, he adds, the West enjoys strong economic, political, military, scientific and technical power.
His other book, "From the World of the City to the City of the World," is a survey of several Western philosophers, including Plato and Aristotle. "No intellectual who studies philosophy and politics can deprive himself of these two sources," he wrote.
 
The Path to Power
A Victory Achieved The Western Way
Mr. Khatami was not supposed to become President. Ali Akbar Nateq-Noori, another mid-level cleric with the same rank -- Hojjatolislam -- and the powerful Speaker of the Parliament, was the designated winner who enjoyed the endorsement of the religious establishment and the majority of Parliament and the bazaar merchants.
By contrast, Mr. Khatami entered the race reluctantly, after no other viable opposition candidate surfaced and after he received permission from Ayatollah Khamenei. More than 230 other candidates put their names forward, but in the restrictive, elitist system of Iran's clerical politics, only four, including Mr. Khatami, were not struck down.
Many of his close family members were initially unhappy with the decision. "I didn't agree with it," said his daughter Leila. "I didn't want my father to become father of all the people."
Initially, he was supported only by an odd coalition: the former radical revolutionaries who seized the American Embassy in 1979 and the reform-minded officials and technocrats close to President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who was not eligible for re-election for a third term.
But Mr. Khatami ran a Western-style people's campaign, traveling around the country, giving lengthy interviews and addressing many of his remarks to young people and women. He talked about his hobbies -- table tennis and swimming -- his favorite philosophers and how he wished his wife knew how to drive.
Mr. Khatami had other advantages. Iranians resented the official endorsements of Mr. Nateq-Noori. Pledges by both Ayatollah Khamenei and President Rafsanjani that the election would be free caused a larger turnout. And unlike Mr. Nateq-Noori, who wears a white turban, Mr. Khatami wears a black turban, the sign of a direct descendant of the prophet Mohammed.
Still, his political advisers were stunned that his views resonated so loudly, so quickly.
"We thought we were speaking to the intellectuals, and that it would take years to succeed," said Reza Khatami, 38, the British-educated brother of the President, who is a kidney specialist, Deputy Minister of Health and one of his closest political advisers. "But we were wrong. The people got the message."
Even toward the end of the campaign, the consensus in Iran was that Mr. Nateq-Noori would win. But Mr. Khatami was so confident that the day before the election he prepared his acceptance speech.
At midnight on election day, after it became clear that Mr. Khatami had won, his sister Maryam called him at his home in Teheran to congratulate him. But he was already asleep.
"Tell your father to sleep calm tonight because it will be his last night of sleep," she recalled telling his daughter Leila.
 
The Cares of Office
Will the Changes Be Enough?
Mr. Khatami's aides acknowledge that he is extraordinarily pressured as he pushes his platform: the rule of law, tolerance for opposing views and the creation of a civil society. When he feels unfairly criticized, he issues public reminders, warnings even, that he has the people of Iran behind him.
When the Iranian soccer team qualified in December for next year's World Cup -- in which it will face the United States team -- Iranians poured into the streets of Teheran to celebrate. They wrapped themselves in the Iranian flag, danced and bought candies and flowers for strangers. Some women even threw off their head coverings in full view of the police, who went home. The event was a stunning demonstration of the power of the people in the face of authority, a power that could be mobilized in Mr. Khatami's favor should he be threatened.
The man who most threatens Mr. Khatami's success is Ayatollah Khamenei, 58, a cleric who lacks both the religious credentials of Ayatollah Khomeini and the charm of the new President. People close to Ayatollah Khamenei seem to resent that he gets so little favorable press coverage abroad. "Iran is not just Mr. President," said Abbas Maleki, an English-speaking former Deputy Foreign Minister who is now working for Ayatollah Khamenei. "The leader -- he's artistic. He knows about culture and civilization, I believe more than Mr. Khatami."
Years ago, Ayatollah Khamenei was not so rigid in his views, but he began to turn inward after he succeeded Ayatollah Khomenei, who died in 1989.
"He used to be very reasonable, very open-minded," said Mr. Sahabi, the opposition figure, who has known Mr. Khamenei for more than three decades. "He played the sitar. But the clerics around him became more defensive. They monopolized power. Little by little he became distant from us."
Aides to both Mr. Khatami and Mr. Khamenei insist the two get along well. Both are clerics only a few years apart, men of ideas and descendants of the Prophet who are opposed to political ties with the United States and are determined to strengthen Iran's Islamic system of government. But they have different roles under the Constitution, different styles and different constituencies.
"President Khatami has never considered himself going beyond the Leader," said Ayatollah Abbas Ali Amid-Zanjani, an expert on Iran's Islamic Constitution. "But Mr. Khatami believes that the more freedom we have and the more rationally we treat the West, the more we will have an enlightened future. There are many high officials in our country who are not very enthusiastic about this idea. They are afraid it will turn into a wolf-sheep relationship."
The Khamenei and Khatami families are close, a relationship that was forged when Ayatollah Khamenei, as a teen-age religious student in Mashad, became a devoted disciple of Mr. Khatami's father. Mr. Khamenei made special trips to Ardakan to visit and the Khatami family vacationed with the Khameneis in Mashad.
"He was a unique person and there was a special closeness between us," Mr. Khamenei wrote about Ayatollah Khatami after his death. "Even though we were 30 years apart, our ideas were just the same."
As President, Mr. Khatami consults with Ayatollah Khamenei at least once a week. But he does not tell him everything. Aides insist that Mr. Khatami's "message to the American people," including his proposal for cultural ties with the United States, via an interview with CNN in early January, was shared with Ayatollah Khamenei only in broad terms.
Nowhere do the two men disagree more than on their view of the United States. Where Mr. Khatami sees the benefits of using the best from the Americans, Ayatollah Khamenei wants to prevent the return of cultural colonialism, particularly because Iranians are already so hooked into America.
"Go talk to the Iranian people and see how many of them want to go to the U.S.," Mr. Maleki said. "Then go to the American people and ask them how many want to go to Persepolis. In this area we don't have the upper hand."
Mr. Khatami has succeeded in lifting some restrictions on publishing and the arts. The Iranian newspapers are more open. Women are wearing makeup and showing some of their hair. Even the Revolutionary Guards are smiling.
But even his supporters ask how long he can keep the confidence of the people in a country where housecleaners earn more than college professors, inflation is running at 30 percent, about 20 percent of the population is unemployed and more than half the population is under 21.
"People are not poking their noses into other people's business as much," said Saied Rajaie-Khorasani, an adviser in the Foreign Ministry. "But the President has not been able to bring about very significant change. The red lines have not changed."
A heavy air of uncertainty hangs over the people around the President, and there is an unwillingness of his ministers and aides to commit themselves to fixed positions.
Even the First Lady seems to feel that uncertainty. During the interview, she suddenly interrupted herself to comment about the flower arrangement on the table beside her.
Sticking up in the middle of the bowl of yellow, purple and white flowers was a single pink rose. She appeared to notice that attached to it was a hidden microphone. "There is a microphone here," she announced. "Is somebody listening to what we're saying?"
The official interpreter omitted the comment from her translation. In the hallway outside, three men with headsets were recording the interview.
So creating a civic society that begins with more openness at home and abroad takes time. Mr. Khatami himself is not certain he will prevail.
"Politicians speak to the outer level of the spirit," he said in the conversation in his office. "There is a need to have more in-depth dialogue, with a deep meeting of minds. This is my hope. But maybe I'm not capable of carrying it out."

PUB-DATE: February 1, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Hong Kong, Feeling Flu-ish

BYLINE: By Ian Buruma; Ian Buruma is working on a book about Chinese political dissidents. His most recent article for the Magazine, about Poland's Jewish community, appeared in August.

 BODY:
On first sight, nothing much has changed in Hong Kong since the British colony -- or "territory," as late colonial officials preferred to call it -- was returned to China at midnight on June 30. No one has been arrested for his political views. The People's Liberation Army keeps out of sight, inside the Prince of Wales Barracks. The corporate skyscrapers still glitter in the wintry sun, and the history of British rule still casts its shadows. The noonday gun, originally from a Jardine Matheson opium brig, is fired every day as a ritual token of respect to the Royal Navy; in Victoria Park, a bronze Queen Victoria watches serenely over picnickers and annual Tiananmen massacre mourners.
For the moment, political anxiety has been masked by bad economic news. Property prices are crashing, tourists are staying away from an overpriced city and the stock market has lost almost half of its value in less than six months. In some neighborhoods, real-estate offices dominated the shopping streets only a year ago. Now many of them are boarded up. And since the Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the U.S. dollar, services are becoming prohibitive for people from countries with debased currencies -- that is, all of Southeast and East Asia. I have lunch with a Western stockbroker who used to be one of Hong Kong's greatest boosters, a regular talking head in the international media, telling the world that the place would continue to go up and up. Now, fresh out of a job, he looks pale as he says Hong Kong could be in for a very rough time. 
 The most ominous development has been the collapse of Peregrine Investments Holdings, Hong Kong's cockiest brokerage house. It went bust because of one colossal loan ($260 million) to a dodgy entrepreneur with connections to the daughter of Indonesia's strongman, President Suharto. This was the kind of deal that made much of Asia tick, and Peregrine rich. Peregrine's founder, Philip Tose, was one of the noisiest promoters of capitalism, Asia-style, based on authoritarian rule and crony connections. Now this system looks highly vulnerable, if not bankrupt. Hong Kong, under British control, with its relative fastidiousness about the rule of law, was neither as raw nor as corrupt as other countries in the region. But now that Hong Kong has been handed back to Beijing, whose politics and economics are as unaccountable and corrupted by cronyism as any in Asia, things could unravel fast. Hong Kong's economic future depends to a large extent on the political future of China. The question is, To what extent can Hong Kong affect that future?
After the hand-over in June there was a brief attempt to blot out the symbols of colonial humiliation with a crude coat of modern Chinese patriotism. Hong Kong TV stars turned out for variety shows wearing Chinese Army uniforms and singing patriotic songs. A propagandistic movie about the Opium War was screened around town. And Hong Kong's Chief Executive, a shipping tycoon named Tung Chee-hwa, spoke incessantly about the need to uphold "Chinese values."
But this layer of patriotic paint never really took. It was too ham-fisted, too plodding, too plain boring. Hong Kong is a speedy Cantonese town with its own distinct brand of Westernized Cantonese pop culture. Official patriotism is a northern product, a mixture of Soviet-style agitprop and Beijing arrogance. Neither goes down well in the capitalistic south. People find it absurd to hear Tung ramble on awkwardly in Mandarin to please the northern comrades. And he was widely ridiculed recently when he decided to hold a vote by asking delegates to clap hands, Communist-style.
And yet Hong Kong is now indisputably a part of China. The fortified border blocking Hong Kong off from the "mainland" still functions to keep unwanted Chinese masses out, and Hong Kong democrats in -- to contain their infectious ideas. Hong Kong, as a special administrative region of the People's Republic of China, is governed in Hong Kong, but ruled from Beijing. Politics, or indeed the economy, in Hong Kong cannot be separated from China's. But this is still a one-sided affair. Hong Kong's citizens, despite exhortations to feel patriotic, are not allowed to engage themselves with the way China -- and thus ultimately Hong Kong -- is ruled.
Hong Kong, then, can perhaps best be described as a Chinese colony. Yet it is a very strange colony; for Hong Kong, allegations of "self-censorship" in the press and a very limited electoral system notwithstanding, is still far freer and more democratic than the imperial metropole. Colonies are normally shaped after the metropolitan models. Legal and political institutions are imported to the colonies from the center. But in the case of Hong Kong and China, many hope it will be the other way round, that tiny, sophisticated Hong Kong will show huge, backward China the way toward freedom and prosperity. It is an odd proposition, which might conceivably work -- if tiny Hong Kong doesn't get crushed first.
The uncertainty of Hong Kong's relations with China has always made this city of refugees and fortune hunters prone to panics. These panics are a useful barometer of economic confidence. The Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the U.S. dollar because of a sudden run on the banks in 1984, when the end of British rule was announced. I am told about the latest panic by Liu Kinming, a fine local journalist with a sharp eye for the bizarre. We meet at the Mandarin Hotel, which, in the Christmas spirit, smells of roasted chestnuts. We order cappuccinos. Liu tells me about the "cake run."
In the fall, a Japanese food store based in Hong Kong went bankrupt. The store rented space to a chain of bakeries called St. Honore. It is customary in Hong Kong to give wedding guests coupons to buy cakes. These coupons are often hoarded. Perhaps vague memories of revolutions, civil wars and famines still haunt Hong Kong; in a crisis, people tend to cash their hoards in, all at once. So after the collapse of the Japanese store, long lines began to form at branches of St. Honore. And people emerged from the shops staggering under piles of cakes. Some could barely carry their loads, let alone eat their way through them. But eating wasn't the point. When the apocalypse comes, you cash in. Liu shakes his head. "Crazy!" he says. "Just crazy." His face creases in a melancholy grin. "I am still a self-hating Chinese," he says. Why? "Well, because Chinese people will come out to get their cake, but not to defend their freedom."
Liu is a little harsh on his fellow Hong Kongers. There are still people prepared to promote democracy and defend civil liberties. And when the occasion feels right -- the Tiananmen Square protests, say -- Hong Kong's citizens will come out en masse.
The most vociferous defender of democracy in Hong Kong is Emily Lau. She was a councilor in the elected Legislature under the last British Governor, Chris Patten. When that Legislature was replaced in July by a handpicked so-called provisional legislature, Lau was out of a job. But donations picked up in street collections enabled her to keep a tiny office for her party, the Frontier, in a seedy part of Kowloon. Lau is a handsome, tireless, noisy and sometimes abrasive woman who irritated the British authorities and fills the Chinese Government with loathing. She is also the most popular politician in Hong Kong.
One of the myths about Hong Kong, long cherished by British officials and Hong Kong businessmen, is that "ordinary people" don't care about politics. To watch Lau operate in the poor suburban housing projects where her constituents live is to see the myth explode. On a damp, gray Sunday afternoon, I watch her take part in a public meeting about police brutality. We are in a small shopping mall, surrounded by massive tower blocks. Discarded plastic bags whip by in the wind. Posters and newspapers tacked onto notice boards offer evidence of police abuses: people being held without charge, beatings, forced confessions. A microphone is passed around as people discuss the problem. A similar scene in China is impossible to imagine.
At another meeting, earlier that same day, I am introduced to a keen supporter of Lau's party. He is a man in his 60's, slim, casually dressed in corduroy pants and a maroon sweater. He says he is about to retire from the police force, on which he has served for 30 years, and wants to run for election as a district board councilor. I later ask him why. He answers by telling me a story.
He has an old relative who likes to drink tea every day at the same time in the same tea shop in Kowloon. One day, several cops burst in and arrest the old man, believing him to be a drug pusher. They have no evidence, but hoping to get a confession they give him a terrible beating. When he is finally released, the man can hardly walk. "And that," the retiring police officer says, "is when I realized that without democratic rights, we are delivered to brute force."
He had presented the Hong Kong problem, or the China problem, or indeed the human problem in a nutshell. The immediate question in Hong Kong is, Whom must democracy be defended against? I heard many people, including senior civil servants, say that the people they fear most are not the Chinese leaders in Beijing, but the local leaders in Hong Kong.
There is no question that Tung Chee-hwa and some of his closest advisers are skeptical, to put it mildly, about democracy. Their skepticism comes in the guise of "Chinese values" but is in fact a throwback to British colonial myths. Leung Chun-ying, 43, is a good example of the kind of man Tung likes to have around him. Leung, who oozes a rather unattractive self-confidence, says that before the hand-over there had been "too much pandering to public opinion by the Legislature." In future, he says, "it will be an advice and consultation body only."
This is what Tung means by a more "executive-style Government." He wants to "depoliticize" Hong Kong. This is also what he means by "Chinese values," harking back to an idealized Confucian patriarchy. The Singapore of Lee Kuan Yew is his model, a city-state run by an autocratic elite of business-minded mandarins whose aim is not to protect individual rights but to impose their idea of the collective good. Lee has often behaved as though Singapore were too small for him. But Tung never ran anything more than a business. And that, according to people who work closely with him, is how he intends to run Hong Kong, too, as a paternal corporate boss.
Tung likes to describe himself as a Chinese patriot. Patriotism in Communist China is a code word. President Jiang Zemin once put it nicely: "In contemporary China patriotism and socialism are in their nature indistinguishable." There is much speculation in Hong Kong about whether Tung and his advisers are members of the Communist Party. Some may be. But nobody seriously believes that these business tycoons are socialists. Tung's patriotism is indistinguishable from Jiang Zemin's in at least one respect, however. Both believe that democratic politics and parliamentary debate are divisive, subversive Western practices. This is where the Communist autocrat and the capitalist plutocrat find common ground. It is also precisely the kind of Government that fostered the economic crisis in Asia: rule by unaccountable business cronies.
One of the sharpest minds in the democratic ranks is Margaret Ng, a lawyer who will run in the legislative elections in May. She speaks in the precise, clipped English of a London lawyer. She is worried about the erosion of the rule of law in Hong Kong and the lack of popular representation. Ng sounds almost nostalgic for the late British empire. "Consultation," she says, "was part of the colonial style. But under British rule, we had the moral high ground. So they had to be careful to take all opinions into account. Tung's idea is that now Hong Kong rules itself, there is no more reason to consult."
The problem faced by British-trained democrats like Ng, or Martin Lee, the leader of the Democratic Party, is that the "patriots" often dismiss them as Westernized remnants of the colonial period. As Ng puts it: "The British regime still had to take us seriously. This Government can ignore us as leftovers of the British gang."
So it might be tempting to contrast the "Westernized" democrats, who thrived briefly under Chris Patten's belated democratic reforms, with the Chinese "patriots," like Tung and his men, who might be less democratic but are more in tune with Chinese culture and the feelings of ordinary Chinese people. But in fact, as Emily Lau's supporters show clearly, such a contrast would be wrong. When they were given the right to vote, in 1991 and 1995, "ordinary Chinese people" voted for the democrats and not for the patriots. And as far as educational and professional background is concerned, Tung and his advisers are as Westernized as Lee or Ng. Tung himself was educated in Britain and lived in America. Tung's most senior councilor is the 80-year-old Sze-yuen Chung, a longtime British colonial official who argued in London against handing Hong Kong back to China before becoming a last-minute patriot and dropping the "Sir" before his name.
What separates the democrats from the patriots is neither culture nor patriotism but politics. Christine Loh, a well-known politician in the democratic camp, once told me that Hong Kong needed to be "de-colonialized." She meant that Hong Kong's citizens had to be weaned from their colonial subservience. But it isn't Hong Kong's people who need to be weaned; it's their self-appointed and Beijing-approved leaders. Tung's belief that Hong Kong must be "de-politicized" is precisely what the old colonial order was about: a "territory" without politics, ruled from afar, but managed by local grandees. Tung's patriots are a mixture of old colonial grandees and aspiring new ones. Their focus has merely shifted from London to Beijing. Or as a former employee of the last British governor said about Sze-yuen Chung, "From a garden party in Buckingham Palace to a banquet in Beijing, without even stopping on the road to Damascus."
In fact, Chung never really needed a conversion. Hong Kong was effectively managed by Chinese tycoons for a long time under the British. It was they, as much as the British, who resisted any attempts to introduce democratic institutions. Like most businessmen, not just in Hong Kong, they saw politics as an unnecessary hindrance to the main purpose at hand, the production of wealth. Beijing wishes Hong Kong to continue just as it was under the British before Patten came along with his dangerous notions about giving every working citizen the right to vote. But in fact, official Chinese patriotism could pose a greater danger to the long-term production of wealth than an increase in local democracy would.
The democrats will be tolerated by Beijing only as long as they remain a minority, insulated in Hong Kong. By devising a complicated electoral system, which cuts by two-thirds the number of seats chosen by direct vote, Hong Kong's rulers have made sure the democrats will remain a minority in the Legislature. The other seats are chosen by corporate votes and pro-Beijing committees. And while the businessmen make deals in China, and the patriots cultivate their contacts in Beijing, the democrats are not even allowed to cross the border. So the democrats may worry about local tycoons (and their Beijing masters) destroying Hong Kong, but it is the businessmen who talk about "new opportunities" and about Hong Kong changing China.
To hear some businessmen talk, the border between Hong Kong and China might as well not exist. Their optimism could well be misguided, but it makes a change from the lawyerly gloom of some democrats. I meet Daniel Ng at my hotel. He is the man who set up McDonald's in China. Ng is proud to have been the first foreign businessman to go to Beijing right after Tiananmen. McDonald's did well. The first hamburger joint opened in 1990, in Shenzhen, just across the border from Hong Kong, and another opened a year later in Beijing. Ng is a fixer, a man who knows how to operate in China's cowboy economy. No rule of law? "There's no use complaining about that," he laughs. "You take advantage of it." Corruption? Bureaucracy? "Sure. You just deal with it. I relish outmaneuvering them every day."
Ng is not as crass as he might seem, however. He knows China has a terrible human rights record. In fact Ng is in favor of direct elections in Hong Kong and China. He might even support Emily Lau. But he thinks Hong Kong can change China by example, by testing things out: "We are beneficial to China, by being ourselves, by showing them how to deal with foreigners, without being a bully or a coward. With an election here, we can even show them that democracy is O.K."
I decide to take another look at the border between Hong Kong and Shenzhen, where there are now nearly 30 branches of McDonald's. I wanted to see Hong Kong from the other side, so to speak. The first time I peered across that border, through binoculars, in the 1970's, Shenzhen was a village surrounded by rice fields. China was the dark, forbidden land beyond the watchtowers and barbed-wire fences. The fences are still there, and so are the towers. But now a brand-new city of skyscrapers looms as you enter the train station on the border. You walk out the other side of the station, into China, past a sign saying "Love the Motherland!" And the first thing you see is a huge billboard with the Marlboro man. My hotel is about a five-minute walk from the station. In that five minutes I am offered a young girl at least a dozen times: "Hello, you, hello. . .miss, you want miss?" In Shenzhen, I was told by a Hong Kong businessman, everything is for sale, including the government.
Shenzhen is a town of fixers and deal-hunters. It is strictly controlled, yet as wild as Tijuana. Young people from all over China go down to work there, to get away from their families, to make money and contacts and perhaps to go abroad. The least-educated ones work in the factories, manufacturing electronics for Chinese, Western or Hong Kong companies. They live in crowded concrete dormitories outside town, which are freezing in winter, stifling in summer. They make the equivalent of about $150 a month. The prettier girls often leave to make easier money. The prettiest might find businessmen from Hong Kong to set them up as weekend mistresses. And the ones who don't make it beg in the streets or make their children beg for them.
A popular meeting place for young people with cash is the Henry J. Bean's bar at the Shangri-La Hotel. There I meet Simon Fang from Beijing. He is a stocky regular kind of guy who seems to know everybody in Shenzhen. We talk with one eye on an American basketball game on a TV screen. Simon has done all right. His main business now is to book musical acts from other parts of China. He offers me a tour through the city, which he describes as a "nowhere sort of place." We set off on his Japanese motorcycle. His choice of things to show me is interesting: an American fitness club, a new department store and the largest McDonald's in town.
Back at Henry J. Bean's we meet up with a friend of Simon's, another Shenzhen success story. Richard Xia, a compact man with narrow, intelligent eyes, is also from Beijing. After graduating from college, he moved to Shenzhen, where he worked for a company, learned English and applied to school in the United States. It took him three years to get a visa. After several years of study and work on the West Coast, he is living in Hong Kong, trading metals in China. Like Daniel Ng, he points out the lack of legal protection in China and the propensity of Chinese partners to break contracts. "It happens all the time," he says. But the margins are good, so you live with it. And he repeats the businessman's mantra: "China will change, have more freedom. Hong Kong will have a big influence. Things will be better in both places -- they will meet somewhere in between."
Simon Fang and Richard Xia act and talk like young Chinese in Hong Kong, or Taiwan. What makes China so exciting and disturbing at the same time is the discrepancy between Fang's and Xia's get-up-and-go optimism and the other stories one hears, of mass executions, corrupt officials and the gulag with millions of prisoners. Shenzhen clearly has been influenced by Hong Kong, but so far only on a crude, material level. I don't really see how Hong Kong can meet China halfway. For Shenzhen to become more like Hong Kong would be a step forward. But for Hong Kong to become more like Shenzhen would be a retrogressive step into a more brutal, more lawless form of capitalism, the kind of economics that is coming unstuck in the rest of Asia.
We end the night in a disco called House. There are male and female hookers in the lobby, hookers at the bar on the first floor and hookers going in and out of private rooms, where businessmen from China and Hong Kong make a lot of noise and drink Cognac and expensive French wines. The music is deafening, the green strobes are blinding and the dance floor is packed with a sweating, heaving mass of dancers. When my eyes get used to the light, I notice an odd detail. In every corner, and in front of every door, armed men in uniform stand guard: strict control in the midst of anarchy. I watch three tall Chinese girls in bikinis dancing on a stage. They move like gymnasts, without much feeling but with frenzied, almost demonic energy.
If "right" means favoring authoritarian government, then the Hong Kong right is pro-Beijing. Workers are not only cheaper in China but also enjoy fewer rights than their counterparts in Hong Kong, and this suits many Hong Kong businessmen just fine. It is not surprising, then, that the most radical opposition to Beijing comes from the left -- from independent trade unionists and various left-wing activists.
Lau San-ching is a Trotskyite. He is also a Chinese patriot of the unofficial kind. In the early 1970's, he became active in the student movement against colonialism in Hong Kong and "bureaucratism" in China. In the late 1970's, he went to China to join the Democracy Wall activists, one of whom was Wei Jingsheng. But his true hero was Wang Xizhe, a Marxist who believed that the Chinese Communist Party could be reformed to produce "democratic socialism." Wang was jailed for this incendiary idea, and so was Lau, who spent 10 years in a Chinese prison. He is back in Hong Kong, where he has formed a union for welfare workers.
A slight, thoughtful man with a high-pitched voice, Lau explains why he is, in a way, more of a patriot than the liberal democrats -- let alone the tycoons. "We can't divide Hong Kong from China," he says. "We must criticize both. The Chinese are afraid that the liberals will use Hong Kong as a counterrevolutionary base. But actually Martin Lee and the others are afraid of China. When I went to China 20 years ago, I went as a Chinese, not a Hong Kong-ese." Lau feels he is fighting the same enemy in China and Hong Kong: business-led authoritarianism.
It is difficult to imagine a man like Lau posing much of a threat to Beijing. And yet Lau and his allies prick the Chinese leaders where it hurts. The patriotic and socialist slogans that justify Communist rule seem especially hollow when they are attacked by patriots who stand up for the welfare of workers. And the welfare of workers is a very sore point, with ever more millions of jobless Chinese roaming the cities. Spontaneous, popular patriotism, as opposed to the official kind, is something Beijing fears. Waves of popular nationalism have turned against discredited Chinese Governments for at least 100 years, or longer, if you count rebellions against the Manchu or Mongol dynasties. Hong Kong has played an important role in such rebellions and could do so again. When a million Hong Kong citizens -- that is one out of six people in the territory -- demonstrated in 1989 in support of the students in Tiananmen Square, this was a demonstration of Chinese patriotism as well as political solidarity. Lau insists that the Communist Party does not represent the Chinese people. In that view he is not alone.
Once a week, millions of people in China can tune in to Radio Free Asia to hear one of the most remarkable voices in Hong Kong. It belongs to Han Dongfang, the founder, during the Tiananmen Square protests, of the first independent labor union in China. His message on the square in 1989 was that the plight of factory workers was the biggest, most explosive issue facing China. The students didn't take him seriously enough -- what were workers' concerns compared with those of intellectuals? But the Chinese Government knew that Han was right, and therefore very dangerous. He spent 22 months in jail, where he almost died.
Han was sent to the United States for medical treatment -- the usual tactic when a dissident becomes too famous. But then he did something unusual. He returned to China, was refused entry and decided to stay in Hong Kong, even after the hand-over, knowing he would be high on Beijing's hit list. Han denies having any political ambitions, or even being a political dissident. And yet labor is a highly political issue. In his newsletter, The China Labor Bulletin, and his weekly radio broadcasts, he keeps people informed on the problems of workers in China: unemployment; lethal working conditions; pitiful wages; abusive, sometimes murderous bosses, and so on. And he advises people who call the radio station from all over China on ways to improve their conditions.
Han lives with his wife and two sons on an island off Hong Kong called Lamma. It is cheaper than central Hong Kong and popular with young Westerners, journalists and others not on corporate salaries. We take the boat together as darkness falls. Behind us are the skyscrapers of Hong Kong -- the international banks and hotels and business headquarters -- a neon blur of corporate logos. A Christmas reindeer blinks red, white and gold from I.M. Pei's Bank of China building. Ahead of us is the ocean dotted with islands, beyond which lies the coast of China. Beyond that sprawls the Chinese continent, with its lurching economy and threatening chaos. We are in China, but it doesn't yet feel like it. Han tells me how strange it is to go home, to spend Christmas with his children, who will receive gifts. When he grew up in Beijing, where his mother was a construction worker, he never possessed a single toy.
"The most important thing," he says in a sudden fit of passion, "is that we must get organized ourselves. We cannot rely on the intellectuals. The Communist Party was the work of intellectuals. We helped them come to power. And look what happened to the workers. We are poor and oppressed." I ask him whether he fears being arrested. He answers that the Hong Kong government still sticks to the law. "As long as that is so, I'm not afraid. I'm not breaking any law. But I am prepared for the worst all the time."
The next day a senior civil servant tells me that "one Han Dongfang in Hong Kong is enough." This statement says much about the predicament of Hong Kong. Freedom of speech is indeed still protected by law. And the Hong Kong government is not worried about Han's activities in Hong Kong. But it is worried about upsetting China. For if China gets upset, Hong Kong's liberty is at risk. And even if China isn't upset, that it might be is a perfect excuse for Hong Kong's own authoritarians to limit dissent.
It is of vital importance to the future of Hong Kong and China that they don't get away with it. For Hong Kong is the only part of mainland China where all shades of opinion can still be openly expressed. And as long as this is so, Hong Kong could indeed have a positive influence on China. The businessmen, as the practitioners of sophisticated capitalism, should see the importance of this as much as the radical activists: the price would be high for businessmen, too. Without the rule of law, they would be vulnerable to the corrupt, strong-arm tactics that prevail in cowboy capitalism. Without open government and a strong judiciary, Hong Kong would slowly come to look more and more like Shenzhen.
Things could be worse. China's economy is highly unstable, and in the event of a crash, its problems would spill over into Hong Kong, making it hard to remain insulated from popular rebellions and violent crackdowns. The freedom to speak would be among the first things to go. But possibly, just possibly, things will play out the other way around. Political reforms in China might lead to more open forms of government. Then the Hong Kong democrats would finally be able to break out of their isolation and follow the businessmen into China, where they would have at least as important a role to play. In such an event, China will need as many Martin Lees and Han Dongfangs as it can get.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1343 words

HEADLINE: Hot Spots

BYLINE: By Alan Ryan; Alan Ryan is the author of "John Dewey and the High Tide of American Liberalism."

 BODY:

The Warrior's Honor
 Ethnic War and
 the Modern Conscience.
 By Michael Ignatieff.
 207 pp. New York:
 Metropolitan Books/
 Henry Holt & Company. $24.95. 
 It is not easy to categorize Michael Ignatieff. He has no academic position, but he writes something very like moral philosophy. He has been the host on an up-market television talk show, but so much more thoughtfully than 90 percent of those who have worked in the same genre that it would be absurd to describe him as a television journalist. Twenty-five years ago, he was a historian of ideas, and a talent for historical exposition marks everything he writes today. Cultural commentator is near the mark, but perhaps public moralist would be the proper description, if only it were not so likely to be misread -- if only it did not convey the impression of someone who gazes on the world around him with pursed lips and censorious eyes.
"The Warrior's Honor" inspires such anxious reflections because it is itself a mix of reportage, history of ideas and moral and political speculation. It consists of five essays, reprinted and sometimes reconstructed, from lectures and from articles in magazines like The New Yorker and Social Research. All but one of its chapters are no more than two or three years old. The opening essay, "Is Nothing Sacred?," dates back to 1985, but its doubts about the ethics of television journalism are as apt after Somalia, Rwanda and Bosnia as they were in the aftermath of the Ethiopian famine. In any case, it makes an appropriate start, because one of Ignatieff's themes is the feeling of impotence that has overtaken the rich, liberal, militarily powerful Western world in the years since the fall of Soviet Communism. Thanks to television, the inhabitants of Western Europe and the United States daily have their faces rubbed in the horrors perpetrated in the collapsing states of sub-Saharan Africa, the Balkans, Chechnya and Afghanistan. It is impossible that they should not respond by wanting to do something to prevent those horrors. It seems equally impossible to intervene in ways that do not make matters worse.
The structure of Ignatieff's argument is simple, and to my mind irresistible. The collapse of the Soviet empire left no competitor to the United States as a global superpower; the United States was part of, though indisputably also the leader of, an alliance of liberal states with the economic and military resources to impose their will on any government in the world. It was no surprise that George Bush could hail the dawn of a new world order -- one dedicated to peace and prosperity, the protection of human rights, the inviolability of national integrity and the reconciliation of national minorities.
President Bush may have despised the L-word, but the idea of a new world order was, as Ignatieff insists, an essentially liberal one. Consistent conservatives, after greeting the end of the cold war with a sigh of relief, would tend to think that the United States Government's job was to protect United States citizens against foreign invaders, terrorists or whomever else, that death and destruction in other countries were none of their business and especially none of their Government's business. Washington should not be acting as combination cop and nursemaid to the rest of the globe. Faced with the worldwide enthusiasm for religiously and ethnically driven civil war, the conservatives' wish to keep out of other people's quarrels looks like basic common sense.
Liberals of the stripe of Ignatieff (and myself) are therefore on shaky ground. The essays in "The Warrior's Honor" explore that ground with admirable sensitivity to its shakiness, but without emerging onto anything firmer. A chapter entitled "The Narcissism of Minor Difference" starts in a command post in eastern Croatia, where Ignatieff tries to get a Serbian militiaman to tell him what he has against his former Croatian neighbors. The man "looks scornful and takes a cigarette pack out of his khaki jacket. 'See this? These are Serbian cigarettes. Over there,' he says, gesturing out of the window, 'they smoke Croatian cigarettes.' "
Feeling, perhaps, that this is not a large enough issue over which to kill one's neighbors, the young militiaman returns to the topic. "Look, here's how it is. Those Croats, they think they're better than us. They want to be the gentlemen. Think they're fancy Europeans." But, he continues, Serbs and Croats are all really just Balkan garbage. As Ignatieff says, this sort of incoherent wavering between thinking that our neighbors are alien and thinking that they are exactly like us is commonplace in these situations. It is not only puzzling, of course, but damaging to the kind of theories that social scientists are so fond of. Contrary to Samuel Huntington, Ignatieff says, it's hard to believe that a deep theological and civilizational rift had opened up in eastern Croatia.
All the same, it is not easy to know what rift had opened up, and why it should be so hard to close. Ignatieff comes as close as common sense allows, I think, when he suggests that there is a two-stage process. One is what he calls the Hobbesian stage; to the other he gives no name, but the inspiration comes from some of Freud's reflections on the horrors of World War I.
Thomas Hobbes, pondering how atrociously ordinary people behaved during the English civil war of the 1640's, said that when government collapsed, what followed was a war of all against all, in which no holds were barred. Deprived of the protection of government, men would do anything to preserve themselves.
Freud's addition to that discomforting thought was that even when physical security was in place, we were inclined to protect ourselves psychologically by pushing our personal insecurities onto others. It is always easier than it seems to get neighbors to kill each other. The fantasies of blood libel that Bosnian Serbs retailed about Bosnian Muslims were the fantasies that Rhinelanders had centuries earlier retailed about the Jews they had murdered. To ask whether Serbs now or Rhinelanders then really believed any of the nonsense they spouted is beside the point. The fantasy expresses the emotions it justifies, and nothing more.
If this is what we are all vulnerable to, what can prevent ordinary social tensions from degenerating into the hells of Rwanda or Algeria? Under the guise of reporting on a tour of Africa with the former Secretary General of the United Nations, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and a visit to Kabul in Afghanistan to see how the International Committee of the Red Cross was faring under the rule of the Taliban guerrillas, Ignatieff tries to persuade us not to succumb to mere moral disgust. Even Boutros-Ghali came very close to doing exactly that on occasion, pointing out to the warring groups in Angola that it was their own people they were killing, and that the rest of the world had no obligation to save them from their self-inflicted fate.
But if we decide, as we might, that we owe the duty of simple humanitarianism to societies that now cannot govern themselves and are in the process of collapsing into the vilest sorts of internal violence, what can we do? It turns out that the title of this little book is almost a joke against its contents. Ignatieff's consideration of the Red Cross's attempts to render war, including civil war, less horrible without taking sides, without impugning anyone's right to fight and without attempting to assure anything other than the physical security of those caught up in conflict leads only to one thought: appeals to honor are hollow. Telling a teen-age boy with a Kalashnikov that a real warrior would not kill children and women and would not rape, torture or mutilate his victims cuts as little ice as handing him the collected works of John Stuart Mill. We end where we began, with the liberal looking at the horrors on the television screen, longing to act, but at a loss to know how, where and with what resources. Happy new millennium.

SECTION: Section E; Page 7; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1019 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Tug of War Between Economic Philosophies: Free Market vs. Government

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE COMMANDING HEIGHTS
The Battle Between Government and the Marketplace That Is Remaking the Modern World
By Daniel Yergin and Joseph Stanislaw
Illustrated. 457 pages. Simon & Schuster. $26. 
 With the title phrase "The Commanding Heights," Daniel Yergin and Joseph Stanislaw are referring to a speech delivered by Lenin in 1922 at the Fourth Congress of the Communist International, in St. Petersburg, then called Petrograd. Defending his New Economic Policy, which permitted a resumption of small trade and private agriculture, Lenin acerbicly assured his audience that although the policy allowed markets to function, the state would still control the "commanding heights," or the elements of the economy that really counted. As the authors then add, "All this was before collectivization, Stalinism and the total eradication of private markets in the Soviet Union."
The phrase made its way around the world, and in time, political leaders everywhere came to agree with Lenin's course, Mr. Yergin and Mr. Stanislaw argue. Spurred on by the high prestige of the Soviet experiment, the seeming failure of free-market economies in the 1930's and the devastation left by World War II, governments around the world took control of the strategic parts of their national economies, their major enterprises and industries.
"By the beginning of the 1970's," the authors conclude, "the mixed economy was virtually unchallenged and government continued to expand. Even in the United States, the Republican Administration of Richard Nixon sought to implement a massive program of detailed wage and price controls."
Yet by the 1990's, the tide was running the other way. The Soviet Union had collapsed; the Berlin wall had come down; England had largely dismantled its welfare state; the United States had undergone the Reagan revolution; even China had turned partly to the marketplace. "Instead of 'market failure,' " write Mr. Yergin and Mr. Stanislaw, "the focus was now on 'government failure' -- the inherent difficulties that arise when the state becomes too expansive and too ambitious and seeks to be the main player, rather than the referee, in the economy."
What brought about this reversal, the authors want to know, and are the answers sufficiently absolute to predict what will happen in the future? In their view, the proximate causes seem clear enough. Both of them energy analysts -- Mr. Yergin wrote "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power" and is president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates; Mr. Stanislaw directs the company's international practice from its Paris office -- they do a thorough, and absorbing, job of analyzing economic trends around the globe.
They point to overwhelming debts and deficits, to chronic inflation and unemployment and to the pressures for globalization arising from the technological revolution. They cite the cumbersomeness of statism and contrast how the "implosion of the Soviet system -- the great lodestar for central planning -- discredited statism of all kinds" with how "the rise of prospering East Asian economies pointed toward a different balance between state and marketplace and underlined the virtues of participation in the global economy."
Their chronicle is repetitive in a sense, since it tells over and over the same story of disillusionment and enlightenment, from Britain to India to Poland to Bolivia to Italy. Yet what makes their book worth reading are the individual cases. For instance, they profile Keith Joseph, the British politician who arguably, the authors write, "did as much as any other single person around the world to reshape the debate about government and marketplace" and whose "agenda, in turn, was articulated and put into effect by his most important student, Margaret Thatcher."
And they touch upon the career of Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian man of letters who had written an admiring doctoral dissertation on the Colombian novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez. After Vargas Llosa had moved to the right politically and had come to disagree with Garcia Marquez's support of Castro, the two men got into an argument in a Mexico City theater, and Vargas Llosa punched the novelist, which, the authors write, "is something that one hardly ever gets to do to the subject of one's doctoral dissertation."
Yet despite the implicit celebratory tone with which they tell their story, Mr. Yergin and Mr. Stanislaw offer no clear answers to their ultimate questions: "Will the apparent triumph of the market endure? Or will government's role expand once again?" For one thing, they don't even try to analyze why the marketplace failed in the 1930's, except through their biographical sketch of Keynes, who, of course, argued that classical economics rested on the mistaken assumption that the balance between supply and demand would assure full employment, and that the state must compensate for the imbalance through the stimulus of deficit spending.
For another thing, the authors never really refute Keynesian theory, except by summing up the views of Friedrich von Hayek, the Austrian economist whom they call the pre-eminent "advocate of free markets," who said, in the authors' words, that Keynes's great work, "The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money," "was not a general theory of economics at all but rather a dressed-up specific theory to get around a political impasse in Britain."
Yet in summing up Hayek's views, and those of the philosophically related Chicago school of economics, Mr. Yergin and Mr. Stanislaw offer us little more than a rehash of the great theorist of laissez-faire capitalism, Adam Smith.
The authors conclude that the future depends on people's confidence in market systems and whether it will be reaffirmed or eroded. But this guarantees nothing. So we are left with the sense that whatever the future holds, the only predictable thing is that events will happen first and then theories will be advanced to explain them.
And finally books like "The Commanding Heights" will be written to help us see more clearly what exactly happened.

HEADLINE: Financial Times Cuts Its Price On U.S. Newsstands by a Third

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
In its continuing effort to attract North American readers, The Financial Times of London cut its newsstand price in the United States on Friday to $1 from $1.50.
That price is still higher than those of most of its daily competitors -- The Wall Street Journal, for example, sells for 75 cents -- and C. Stuart Arnold, managing director of The Financial Times for the Americas, is adamant that the newspaper is not mounting a price war. Instead, he said yesterday, the price cut is just part of an effort to more than double North American circulation to 100,000 readers by 2000. 
 "We realized that when you are priced so much above the competition, you are artificially limiting your market," Mr. Arnold said.
The newspaper's push for market share has been brewing since the summer of 1996, when Marjorie Scardino became the new chief executive of Pearson P.L.C., which owns The Financial Times and is part- owner of The Economist Group. Ms. Scardino, who had recently used a combination of pricing and promotion to double The Economist's North American circulation to upwards of 300,000, almost immediately committed well over $200 million to the international expansion of The Financial Times.
"Until Marjorie came in, we had not targeted the United States for a circulation push," Mr. Arnold said.
The paper, which Mr. Arnold says is profitable in the United States, is scheduled to open a third American printing plant this spring in Chicago. It has increased its advertising and has mounted a big push to get the salmon-colored newspaper displayed next to local papers, rather than off in a corner with miscellaneous publications. The efforts increased circulation by 37 percent in 1997, reaching 47,800 as of this month. More than 43,000 of those readers are in the United States.
Only a fifth of The Financial Times readers pick up the paper at newsstands, and the newspaper has no plans to cut its home subscription price of $225 a year, or about 73 cents a copy. But, Mr. Arnold said, half of the new subscribers last year became familiar with the paper by buying it on newsstands. Thus, if the lower newsstand price woos more readers, many of them may be converted to subscribers.
No representatives of The Wall Street Journal could be reached for comment yesterday. Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for The New York Times, said, "We welcome all voices in the newspaper market, and we don't expect their price cut to affect The New York Times."

LENGTH: 1262 words

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Finds It Isn't Immune to Asian Distress

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Leung Pak Lau thought that life was pretty good. Then, Asia's economic and financial wreckage landed on his red-and-silver taxi.
A slight man in his mid-50's, Mr. Leung owns his own cab -- a fervent aspiration once, but now a choice he rues. 
 "Business is definitely bad these days," he said, piloting his stick-shift Toyota through the clotted streets of the Wanchai shopping district. What upsets him most is that when he bought his taxi license five months ago, he says, it cost $3.1 million (Hong Kong), or $397,000 (United States). "Now it's only worth about $2 million" (Hong Kong) or $256,000 (United States).
Shored up by hefty budget and trade surpluses, and $92.8 billion (United States) in foreign-exchange reserves, Hong Kong's economy has proved more robust than others in Asia. Its companies have comparatively small debts, and there are essentially no empty office towers. But the ripples of Asian distress are lapping at Hong Kong's shores.
Already, a major investment bank and a small brokerage firm have gone under. Retailers are hurting; unemployment is rising, and real estate development, a pillar of the economy, is slowing. Though some of this is a result of regional collapse, Hong Kong is being buffeted primarily by a problem of its own making: the territory's monetary policy.
The Hong Kong dollar is rigidly pegged to the United States dollar at a rate of roughly 7.8 to 1, a link that has forestalled currency instability here but has also begun to rattle some sectors of the economy. Even Tung Chee-hwa, the man chosen by Beijing as Hong Kong's chief executive, acknowledges that maintaining the link is causing problems.
"In the course of defending the linked exchange-rate system," Mr. Tung, a former shipping entrepreneur, told the Beijing-picked legislature about two weeks ago, the following situations will undoubtedly arise: the "Hong Kong dollar interest rate goes up; property prices come down; the stock market lingers at low levels; our tourism is in the doldrums; consumer spending sentiment diminishes; our economic growth in 1998 will slow down significantly, and our unemployment figures will be on the rise."
Yet Mr. Tung has repeatedly declared that the link with the United States dollar will be maintained at all costs. "It is vital for us to defend the linked exchange rate," he told the legislators. "This is a basic policy to maintain the economic stability and prosperity of Hong Kong."
Likewise, Deputy Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China has told visiting officials that Beijing will defend not only the value of the Chinese currency but also Hong Kong's decision to preserve its peg to the United States dollar.
Although no one is talking about alternate monetary policies, the ramifications of keeping the peg are evident in the domestic economy.
Mortgage interest rates have already touched 12 percent, making monthly payments more expensive, depressing property prices, raising costs for retailers, dampening the stock market -- even undermining the value of taxi licenses, which are usually bought with bank loans that now carry sharply higher rates.
Not only has Mr. Leung's cab license slumped in value, but Hong Kong's famously, and many say ridiculously, high-priced real estate is taking a battering in the face of mounting interest rates. With prices now 20 to 30 percent below peaks of barely three months ago, several important companies' debt levels are stirring anxiety in the stock market, where property and development concerns are pillars of the benchmark Hang Seng index.
One of the territory's largest real estate developers, Sun Hung Kai Properties, has announced that it is halting work on 10 construction projects because of the current economic climate. And as the economy begins to contract -- the Government predicts a growth rate this year of 4 percent, down from 5.5 percent last year, and private analysts are more pessimistic -- a growing number of investment banks and brokerage houses are cutting jobs that were added in the boom years.
The brashest and newest of the breed, Peregrine Investments Holdings, collapsed recently. BZW Asia has disappeared after being acquired by Credit Suisse First Boston; Schroders Securities Asia Ltd. laid off 220 employees here after it shut most of its brokerage business, and Societe Generale Crosby has laid off employees and cut the salaries of senior executives.
On Jan. 19, a small brokerage firm, Capital Asia Pacific Ltd., filed for bankruptcy, endangering the life savings of hundreds of investors, 300 of whom besieged Government offices for three days seeking some sort of rescue.
Mr. Tung, who met the investors, said, "I am sympathetic for them and believe they deserve help." After a week of silence, the Government announced a rescue package for smaller investors.
Other businesses are feeling pain as well. Hong Kong's airline, Cathay Pacific, badly bruised from vast rows of empty seats on flights around Asia, has begun shedding workers, starting last week with 750, of whom 220 will be laid off here in Hong Kong.
Along Hong Kong's shopping thoroughfares, the mood is increasingly gloomy. In the mannequin-filled window of World Signs, a women's clothing store in Causeway Bay, a huge sign reads: "Up to 70 percent Off."
"People don't seem to care about shopping," said Alice Liu, the shop's manager. "They used to buy new clothes for the holidays, for Christmas and Chinese New Year, but this year it really doesn't matter. People can go without new clothes."
The situation has become so bad that Hong Kong's retail industry has called on landlords to cut rents by 40 percent. "The retailers in Hong Kong are having an extremely difficult time," said Philip Ma, the chairman of the Hong Kong Retail Management Association, a group that represents businesses employing more than half of the industry's 200,000 workers.
So far, none of Hong Kong's major landlords have responded to Mr. Ma's plea. However, the Hong Kong Housing Authority announced that it was freezing rents on commercial establishments in public buildings.
Public confidence in the economy is at a two-year low, according to Ming Pao, a leading Chinese daily, which conducts quarterly surveys of public opinion. "Economic confidence has fallen to the level of 1995," the paper said recently, "when China and Britain were in the midst of severe political conflict."
Despite rising public anxiety, however, most Hong Kong companies are not deeply enmeshed with other Southeast Asian economies; China is Hong Kong's backyard, and that is where most companies have invested. "Most Hong Kong companies have their operations, their manufacturing facilities, in China rather than Southeast Asia," said Richard Margolis, a first vice president at Merrill Lynch (Asia Pacific). "They just don't have the exposure, and that includes Hong Kong's banks."
And then there is tourism, which once helped fuel Hong Kong's economy, as visitors deluged every shop from China Arts and Crafts to Gucci to the night markets of Kowloon. Although official data are lagging behind, figures for November show a 22 percent decline in tourist arrivals from those of November 1996.
That seems destined to fall further when data arrive for December and January; both months have been battered by news of "bird flu" and a continuing regional financial meltdown. The Government estimates that 8 percent of the territory's gross domestic product is derived from tourism and that 360,000 people work in tourist-related businesses. All that is in jeopardy now.
