HEADLINE: Memos Said to Detail Reuters Effort to Obtain Bloomberg Data

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Federal prosecutors have obtained more than 100 written communications between an American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and a consulting company that investigators believe was hired to steal information from the computers of a competitor, Bloomberg L.P., people in touch with the investigation said yesterday.
The communications from the subsidiary, Reuters Analytics Inc., include memos and other records requesting detailed information about technical programs for analyzing investments, these people said. 
 The consultant was then said to have electronically broken into Bloomberg's corporate computers and obtained the information. Afterwards, it was passed to Reuters, at times directly to the parent company's London headquarters, they said. Prosecutors were said to have also obtained the consultant's responses.
The computer consulting company, whose name could not be immediately determined, was said by people in touch with the investigation to have been founded by a former employee of Bloomberg. They said that the company is based near the Stamford, Conn., headquarters of Reuters Analytics.
Prosecutors obtained the documents during an undercover investigation of Reuters Analytics that has lasted about a year. In the investigation, at least one confidential informant helped the Government obtain an array of evidence, including tapes.
Robert Crooke, a spokesman for Reuters America, declined to comment.
The written communications are the first documentary evidence known to have been obtained by prosecutors in the case. Such written communications, including messages sent by E-mail, would be potentially critical evidence, because they could be used to establish which executives were connected to the purported scheme.
Already, Reuters has placed three executives in the subsidiary on paid leave in the wake of the scandal. According to people with ties to Reuters, they include Hubert Holmes, the unit's head, as well as Jeff Walker and James Feingold, two executives in the unit.
In telephone calls, Mr. Holmes and Mr. Feingold declined to comment. A home telephone number for Mr. Walker could not be obtained.
More than $6.5 billion is spent annually to keep computer terminals on the desks of Wall Street spewing out up-to-the-second bond and equity prices and currency values and offering complex analytical tools that combine years of historical and contemporary data to predict current trends.
Reuters Holdings, the largest and oldest competitor in the financial information services business, had more than a century's head start when Michael R. Bloomberg founded Bloomberg L.P. in 1981. But Reuters's brash competitor developed new analytic tools that Wall Street professionals regarded as well suited to their needs in an era of derivatives and other increasingly complex securities transactions.
According to people in touch with the investigation, prosecutors have obtained evidence that Reuters was stealing information from Bloomberg's operating code, the underlying software that governs the functioning of Bloomberg's data terminals.
As the head of Reuters Analytics, Mr. Holmes reported directly to senior executives at the parent company in London. For several years, he reported to David Ure, an executive director responsible for marketing and technical policy. Since late 1996, he has reported to John Parcell, who is executive director responsible for the financial information product line.
Executives in London maintained direct contact with the analytics division, occasionally traveling to Stamford to meet with Mr. Holmes and other executives. In recent months, investigators have been examining the travel of London executives to the subsidiary and their contacts with its American executives as part of an effort to determine if they knew of the purported scheme, people in touch with the investigation said.
Since announcing the grand jury investigation on Thursday, Reuters has declined comment on the extent of the inquiry. Reached by E-mail in Davos, Switzerland, where he was attending the annual World Economic Forum, Mr. Bloomberg, who is the chairman and chief executive of Bloomberg L.P., also declined comment. "Sorry, have nothing to add to obvious story," he wrote.
From its earliest days, Reuters Analytics has been faced with accusations that it used unsavory business practices to obtain other companies' technologies.
The subsidiary was originally an independent company with a mission to develop technology to compete with Bloomberg. It was acquired by Reuters after the settlement of a bitter 1993 lawsuit, in which the founders of the predecessor company, Capital Markets Decisions Inc., accused Reuters of secretly hiring its programmers and using their proprietary knowledge to build a clone of Capital Markets' software.
Mr. Holmes, Mr. Walker and Mr. Ure, the London executive, all played roles in that earlier dispute.
Mr. Crooke, the Reuters spokesman, said that the court records had to speak for themselves. Many of Reuters's documents are missing from the public record. However, in the records that do exist and in interviews at the time of the suit, Reuters executives denied all of the allegations made by Capital Markets Decisions, saying that no effort had been made to obtain any confidential information from the small company.
In 1989, Reuters, in its efforts to move further into the business of analytics, turned to J. Stephen Levkoff, a senior vice president at Smith Barney who had previously developed analytics systems.
Reuters asked Mr. Levkoff to develop a product equivalent to the Bloomberg terminal, and he agreed to join Reuters as a consultant through his own independent company, Capital Markets Decisions, according to the court documents.
Bloomberg had made rapid inroads into Reuters's business by offering fund managers and other institutions a data terminal that allowed traders to aggressively analyze purchases and sales of investments. Reuters had no such product, known as an analytics system, and did not have the programming expertise to develop one.
After his discussions with Reuters, Mr. Levkoff left Smith Barney to run Capital Markets Decisions, which would create a new analytics system for Reuters to sell.
According to the contract, Capital Markets Decisions would receive royalty payments on each terminal installed, and Reuters would supply its data for the system.
By 1991, Capital Markets Decisions had developed and released its system, known as Decision 2000 and nicknamed the "Bloomberg Killer." That year, Reuters began installing the new units on customers' desks.
Relations between the two sides began to break down in early 1993. According to court records, after repeated disputes about the contract between Reuters and Capital Markets Decisions, Mr. Levkoff and Mr. Ure renegotiated it, with handwritten revisions. But, when pressed for a final draft of that agreement, Mr. Holmes refused to provide it, according to an affidavit by Mr. Levkoff.
In 1993, Reuters declared Capital Markets Decisions in breach of contract for what it said were a variety of failures. But Mr. Levkoff believed the declaration was made in bad faith, as "an effort to break the contract or wear us down into selling the business to Reuters," according to court records he filed in the case. That would give Reuters ownership of the system, eliminating the need for royalty payments.
Employees of Capital Markets Decisions began hearing from Reuters employees that their company faced imminent demise. According to the court papers, employees began leaving Capital Markets Decisions without telling their colleagues where they would be working.
According to Mr. Levkoff's affidavit, a showdown occurred during a dinner with Mr. Holmes on Sept. 18, 1993, at the Homestead Inn in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Holmes produced a draft letter, declaring Reuters's intent to terminate the contract immediately, despite a negotiated term that required six months' notice. Mr. Holmes informed Mr. Levkoff that Reuters had been working on Capital Markets Decisions' termination for a year, and had already paid a law firm $500,000 as part of the effort, the affidavit says.
During the meeting, according to Mr. Levkoff's affidavit, Mr. Holmes told him that several Capital Markets Decisions employees who had disappeared were working for Reuters. A number of employees with Capital Markets Decisions signed affidavits saying that Mr. Walker was personally involved in the effort to hire them.
One Capital Markets Decisions programmer, Tom Kokoska, had secretly joined Reuters after leaving Capital Markets Decisions for Bloomberg. To conceal Mr. Kokoska's work, he had taken the job under a pseudonym, Joe Pope. Memorandums written by Reuters executives at the time show the name Joe Pope was even used on internal communications. And an affidavit by another Capital Markets Decisions executive describes how a friend of Mr. Kokoska could reach him only at Reuters by knowing to ask for Joe Pope.
Why the subterfuge? According to Mr. Levkoff's affidavit, Mr. Holmes told him it was because Mr. Kokoska was working for almost a year on a secret project to make a clone of Decision 2000. Once it had used the knowledge of former Capital Markets Decisions programmers to make its own system, Reuters could take over the business, Mr. Levkoff said.
Mr. Kokoska did not return a telephone call to his home seeking comment.
But, as described in Capital Markets Decisions records filed in the United States District Court in Manhattan, Reuters, whose needs had spurred the creation of Capital Markets Decisions and its flagship product, was secretly hiring away some employees who understood its software. In turn, according to an affidavit by Mr. Levkoff, they were using that knowledge to develop a similar product.
Mr. Levkoff said in his affidavit that he was told of the effort by a Reuters executive. As a result, Mr. Levkoff said, the value of Capital Markets Decisions would be reduced, allowing Reuters to buy the company at a low price. That would give Reuters use of the Decision 2000 product without paying royalties.
Before the Homestead dinner was over, Mr. Holmes presented a copy of an agreement for Reuters to buy Capital Markets Decisions. Mr. Levkoff said in court papers that Mr. Holmes told him that with the clone project under way, Decision 2000 was no longer considered a valuable asset. "Every day that goes by, Decision 2000 is worth less to Reuters," Mr. Levkoff quoted him as saying.
Mr. Levkoff said in his affidavit that he refused the deal because Reuters was offering a lowball bid; Mr. Holmes stated in an affidavit that a deal was agreed upon.
On Oct. 19, three weeks after the Homestead Inn dinner, and after Mr. Levkoff rebuffed a second offer to buy his company, Reuters severed all communications links, including real-time data feeds, that Capital Markets Decisions needed to get access to the operational Decision 2000 product to update the data used by customers. It also changed the number for the Decision 2000 help desk, which had been at Capital Markets Decisions.
Mr. Levkoff brought suit, seeking $30 million in damages. After much battling, he won the right to depose many of the principals in the case.
But Reuters reversed course. It reached a confidential settlement, in which it purchased Capital Markets Decisions for an undisclosed sum that was acceptable to Mr. Levkoff. He then left the company.
Under the supervision of Mr. Ure, Mr. Holmes, along with Mr. Walker, began working with Reuters latest subsidiary, the newly named Reuters Analytics.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Battle Plan for Gulf War II

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
If Saddam Hussein does not cave in to the sound of sabres rattling, the U.S. has little choice but to make good its military threats. What would Gulf War II be like?
Phase I would be an air attack heavier than the missile pinpricks that encouraged Saddam to challenge U.N. inspections. The word picked up at this year's World Economic Forum is that bombers would hit air defenses, military command and control facilities, perhaps a sampling of biowar sites. The mission would be to render Iraq unable to put anything in the air. 
 Saddam's counterattack would be psychological: to display the bloodied bodies of children on CNN (even if he had to stage explosions at hospitals himself), thereby to turn U.S. opinion against further bombing. Appeals to the Arab street would encourage demonstrations and terrorist attacks.
Phase II would be a bombing pause. Russian and French envoys to Baghdad would say the mad Americans cannot be restrained unless some compromise is reached. Mr. Clinton would maintain his resolve to win unconditional inspection. His bottom line: unrestricted inspections, often headed by American experts.
If that test of Saddam's submission was finessed by attempts to protract negotiations, Phase III would begin: sustained bombing of all suspected weaponry sites, including palaces occupied by civilians used as hostages. Industrial and oil facilities would be taken out as in Gulf War I.
This time Saddam would not only play on our revulsion at the pictures of innocents' bloodshed, but might escalate the war, aiming Iraqi missiles with poison gas at Israel and posing as a holy warrior.
This time, with no Arab cooperation to lose, the U.S. said it would not appeal to Israelis for restraint. Retaliatory commando raids might be an early option; if Saddam turned totally suicidal and tried germ warfare, he would invite a nuclear response.
But if Saddam chose televised victimhood, and was not overthrown in a coup by officers unhappy at Republican Guard losses, what then? He would be wounded, his people impoverished, but Iraq would remain triumphantly unoccupied with Saddam in command -- building his weapons of mass destruction and buying the missiles to deliver them.
For us, to fail to win would be to lose. If the U.S. went to war and stopped short of victory, it would be beaten. The measure of victory in Gulf War II: trying Saddam as a war criminal and showing Iraqis how to hold elections. That means we should be prepared to go to Phase IV: invasion.
If it comes to that, are we ready? No; the ground troops are not in place, and the will to send ground troops is not yet in the Clinton Administration.
Because Saddam knows Clinton is unprepared to go all the way to land war, he is willing to absorb aerial punishment until we give up. Only if we show our readiness to go all the way might we avoid the need to do so.
Because Clinton feels the need to act under a multilateral cloak, he cannot be expected to ask Congress for an old-fashioned declaration of war. However, since limited war is what he proposes to wage -- with casualties to be expected -- he must ask Congress, where the war power still resides, for an enabling resolution.
He'd get it and then some. Speaker Newt Gingrich made a brilliant speech in Davos yesterday urging the final disposition of Saddam. Congress should follow his lead and direct the President to take all air, sea and land action to conclusively remove the threat that this dictator will acquire weapons of mass destruction.
A week's serious Senate Foreign Relations debate would increase pressure on Saddam while preparing Americans for sacrifices. Dissenters could take their stand and -- should the majority support the use of all necessary force to remove Saddam -- the President would receive the constitutional mandate he needs for a fight to the finish.
I ran into Hillary Clinton at the Sara Lee reception last night. Though our brief chat was socially privileged, she told me that what we needed was not just allies to express concern but to make commitments. She's right.
If her husband is willing to tell the world what is at stake, and how long the road may be, he will find allies in Congress, in public opinion and in key capitals to join him in a commitment to save millions of lives threatened by this generation's Hitler.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bracing for the Asian Shock Wave

BYLINE: By James K. Galbraith; James K. Galbraith is an economist at the University of Texas. His next book is titled "Created Unequal."

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
So far, American workers have been helped, not hurt, by the Asian economic crisis. Prices are down; products like computers and televisions are cheap as rarely before. American stocks haven't fallen, and few working Americans had investments in Asia. More important, the crisis has eliminated fears of inflation and kept interest rates stable, so that our economy continues to grow and unemployment continues to fall.
But this Indian summer of the American Expansion could end soon. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, predicted last week that the economy, hindered by increased competition from Asian imports and declining exports, would begin to slow by June. My colleagues at the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group, estimate that the drop in exports to Asia will cost more than a million American jobs next year. Falling Asian currencies also mean a rising dollar, which will hit the pay of those Americans -- like garment and electronics workers -- who compete directly with their Asian counterparts. 
 Worse could happen. Some American banks, weakened by losses in Asia, may be forced before long to tighten credit at home. The falling prices that now seem so appealing will dampen profits and raise real interest rates, discouraging consumers from spending on cars and appliances. And if the economy then slows, the Federal deficit will start to grow. Given the hard line on the budget that's now in vogue, new debts will surely panic politicians into new spending cuts -- accelerating the economy's decline.
In his State of the Union Message last week, President Clinton urged Congress to respond to the Asian crisis by supporting the International Monetary Fund. But the I.M.F. alone cannot forestall the grim chain of events that might lead to a recession. Its loans, while necessary as a cushion against debt defaults, will never be large enough to restore Asia to its former role as an engine of global growth.
The shock waves from Asia are thus certain to hit American workers. The question is whether we are ready to parry the blow. There are a number of steps that our Government could take to strengthen both our own economy and the world's.
Since 1993, American households have fueled growth through steadily increasing consumer spending, and they have the debt to prove it. Higher wages would help sustain their purchasing power, and for this reason a new increase in the minimum wage is a good idea. But lowering interest rates is the easiest and fastest way to keep consumers in the game. Such a move would counteract the tendency of falling prices to drive up real interest rates, helping businesses as well as workers. It would also help to keep the dollar from rising, and so strengthen our workers in world competition, while helping to ease the crisis abroad. The Fed should cut interest rates now, before the crisis reaches here.
But lower interest rates and higher wages may not themselves be enough to keep our economy growing. Against this contingency, the Government should start preparing now to resume its historical role as the demander of last resort. It should consider strong measures to increase its investment in schools, transportation, parks and museums. It should also be ready, if necessary, to cut taxes for those Americans who never benefited from the credit boom -- for instance, by expanding the earned-income tax credit again.
As for the balanced budget: too bad. But if the economy slows, we'll have deficits again anyhow. Better to act first.
One lesson of the crisis in Asia is that we need, here at home, a Government that works actively to develop our economy -- by raising wages, cutting interest rates and issuing the public debt necessary to meet public needs and to sustain full employment. Only then can we build a stable economy that responds to crises before they engulf us all.

HEADLINE: The Era of Big Government Lives Anew

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I remember President Clinton's saying not long ago that the era of big government was over. Well, it wasn't then and it will not be if he gets the new or expanded Federal laws, taxes and programs he proposed in his State of the Union address (front page, Jan. 28). In his speech he claimed that the Government is smallest in 35 years and that taxes for the typical middle-class family are the lowest they have been in 20. 
 Federal revenues as a share of the gross domestic product are at an all-time high, with the Government gobbling up almost 20.8 percent of every dollar produced. That's slightly higher than the 20.7 percent in 1981 and 1969 (when the Vietnam War surtax was in effect).
By only one measure -- the number of Federal employees -- is the Government smaller. That's because of military downsizing and the reduction of civilian support staff.
Twenty years ago government at all levels took 33 percent of the average American's income, according to the Tax Foundation. Today, that figure is 35 percent. President Clinton can't take all the credit for the Federal Government's share. He had help from the Republican-controlled Congress.
 
PAUL ECCLES
San Diego, Jan. 29, 1998

HEADLINE: HUD Asks Money for Housing And Jobs for Urban Homeless

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In its biggest budget request in 10 years, the Department of Housing and Urban Development will ask Congress on Monday to approve huge increases for programs to expand housing and job opportunities for low-income people in cities across the country.
As part of President Clinton's budget, the department is seeking $25 billion for the 1999 fiscal year, an increase of 4 percent over 1998.
But the core of the request is $1.8 billion in new spending for programs designed primarily for helping cities compete with adjacent suburbs, which have had more success in recent years creating jobs and stable neighborhoods through economic development. According to the Clinton Administration, only 13 percent of the 14 million jobs created in the last five years were in cities. 
 "Cities have been at a competitive disadvantage with outlying counties," Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday. "This will help level the playing field."
A major component of the budget request is a new $400 million program, the Community Empowerment Fund, which would combine several smaller programs to distribute grants to states and local governments as a way to leverage $2 billion in loans. The Administration is predicting that the fund would help create 280,000 jobs.
In announcing the fund at a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors on Friday, Mr. Clinton said it "will provide capital to businesses who recognize the potential and the possibilities of the inner cities."
"This is the right way to help our cities," he added. "It is not a handout."
Other major components of the budget proposal include $585 million for more than 100,000 new housing vouchers for low-income people and a 40 percent increase, to $1.15 billion, in programs to fight homelessness.
While acknowledging the ambitious nature of the budget request, Mr. Cuomo said he expected a favorable reception in Congress, largely as a reward for the department's efforts to eliminate fraud and abuse from housing programs and to reduce the department work force to 7,500 by 2002. Currently, the department employs 9,200, compared with 13,550 five years ago.
Representative Jerry Lewis, Republican of California and the chairman of the housing subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, said he shared Mr. Cuomo's optimistic assessment, saying, "The Secretary's feelings about the budget are justified."
Mr. Lewis also said he believed that the proposed budget reflected the proper emphasis, highlighting help for urban areas, although he expressed some reservation about the overall efficiency of municipal public housing agencies. "I do have questions about them," he said. "Some do a good job. Some don't."
The new money sought for housing vouchers would provide 50,000 new vouchers for welfare recipients looking for work and 34,000 additional vouchers for homeless people moving from shelters to permanent homes, with the rest for elderly, disabled and low-income people on voucher waiting lists.
Additional money for the homeless would include programs to pay for education, job training and substance abuse treatment for people moving into permanent housing.
Other areas of the budget request would provide increased spending to eliminate lead paint hazards, to develop unused urban industrial sites known as "brownfields" and to raise the loan limit for Government-insured home mortgages.
"People are moving out of the cities," Mr. Cuomo said, reflecting a trend that has continued for decades. "But if the cities fail, the suburban districts fail. This budget solidifies the balance."

HEADLINE: How Good Is It? As Good As It Gets, Governors Say

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

 BODY:
By President Clinton's proud reckoning on Tuesday night in his State of the Union Message, these are good times in America. But by the reckoning of most of the nation's governors, that was understatement.
In a series of State of the State addresses last month that were striking for their relentlessly upbeat and optimistic tone -- even discounting that 1998 is a re-election year for many governors -- the chief executives of some 40 states painted a picture of a nation that not only is enjoying good times but in many cases, as they see it, is enjoying the best times ever. 
 Thanks mainly to the nation's booming economy, governors who a few years ago were bemoaning intractable problems, shortages of money and the need for sacrifice, now crow about spending new cash surpluses to solve old problems, about cutting rather than raising taxes and about giving out instead of rationing government goodies.
But most of all, the State of the State speeches of 1998, based on a review of most of those delivered thus far, were speeches about good times on a roll like seldom before.
As Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, a Republican whose 16 years in office make him the nation's senior governor, put it in his Jan. 13 address:
"We've come a long way. Today we stand stronger and taller than ever before. The condition of our state is as good as we've ever had it."
Then Mr. Branstad, who is not running for re-election, offered some persuasive proof. "Consider just a few facts," he said, beginning a litany that could have applied as easily to New York or Texas or California as to heartland Iowa.
"In 1997," he went on, "unemployment fell to the lowest level in history, and the number of working Iowans rose to the highest level. The number of jobs created by new businesses rose almost 19 percent. We had one-third fewer Iowans on welfare than four years ago. Land values increased for the 11th consecutive year. We created one of the best student-to-computer ratios in the nation and within a year every school district will be hooked up to the information superhighway. We ended the year with a state budget surplus of over $800 million -- the state's best fiscal position ever. And today every Iowa taxpayer is paying 10 percent less in state income taxes."
Other governors offered a similar message, even the governors of some states that traditionally have been depressed, economic laggards, like West Virginia. The detail and the wording varied, but not the ultimate conclusion.
"The state of our state is sound," said Gov. Tony Knowles of Alaska, a Democrat. "Our course is the right one. The future for most Alaskans is bright."
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican, said: "The most visionary, vibrant and vigorous state in America. We are young. We are bold. We are strong."
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat, boasted, "We are now one of the premier economies in the nation, perhaps the world."
The Governor of Delaware, Thomas R. Carper, a Democrat, declared, "Our economy is as strong as an oak."
Gov. Cecil H. Underwood of West Virginia, a Republican, said, "We can now sing a song of hope."
Problems remain in all states, of course, ranging from low test scores in public schools and overcrowding in prisons to crumbling highways and hard-core, left-in-the-dust pockets of the poor, the homeless and the chronically unemployed. And in most of this year's State of the State speeches, governors acknowledged such difficulties, a few with acute bluntness.
For example, Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano of Hawaii, a Democrat, spoke of struggling to lead a state tossing about in "stormy waters" and grappling with "unprecedented" problems, mainly because its main industry, tourism, has been hard hit by competition from other vacation destinations and by a sharp decline in visits by Asians, who have their own economic crisis to deal with. He warned: "What lies ahead may be the most difficult challenge our state has ever faced."
Yet despite such admissions of problems, taken as a whole the 1998 State of the State speeches portrayed a nation that, near the dawn of the 21st century, was graced from sea to shining sea by such wealth and plenty that one governor, Gary Locke of Washington, a Democrat, waxed wondrously not only about a state grown ever bigger, ever better and ever richer but also a state suddenly infused with a "growing sense that we are entering a time of moral renewal, a time when more and more Americans are coming home to the values of service to others, respect for our elders and sacrifice for our children."
In many of the speeches, governors called for increased spending on early childhood development, health care for the very young and day care programs for working parents, a reflection of the importance the nation's leaders are now according to recent studies indicating that the earlier a child's education begins and the more stable it is, the better the adult will turn out.
Many of the speeches also contained proposals for increased spending on highways, a reflection not only of growing concern about the aging of the nation's road network but also a reflection of the change in the way many of the nation's businesses now do business -- that is, many no longer maintain expensive warehouse inventories but instead depend on efficient communication and transportation systems to deliver goods within hours of need.
There were calls in a good many speeches for increased training of schoolchildren and workers in computer skills, lest a state be left in the electronic dust of the next century. And there were warnings in many speeches that a state that did not successfully recruit its share of high-technology companies could find itself left in the century's electronic dust.
Finally, this being an election year -- and an election year in flush economic times -- many of the speeches contained proposals for tax cuts. But many were for modest cuts, such as reductions in taxes on new cars.
That relatively cautious fiscal approach -- many of the spending proposals made in the speeches were equally cautious -- reflects a wariness from the last recession. It hit many states at a time when they had no budget surpluses to tide them over hard times, having spent heavily in the years leading up to the recession.
"They learned a hard lesson," said Raymond C. Scheppach, the executive director of the National Governors Association. "Now most are deliberately spending less than they take in each year to make sure they have a cushion for the next bad period, which inevitably will come."
But, meanwhile, the good times roll on.
In his State of the State speech to South Carolinians, Gov. David M. Beasley, a Republican, boasted that "there's never been a more exciting time to be a South Carolinian," then added:
"Our economy is going gangbusters. Just last year, more companies invested than ever before -- the most international business, the most new investment, the most expansions. Since 1995, job creation has risen 75 percent and we created more jobs last year than ever before, paying an average of over $30,000 a year. Unemployment is at its lowest point in nearly three decades. Consumer confidence is the highest on record."
On the West Coast, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, another Republican, struck a similar high note in his address, not only saying that the grinding economic recession of the early 1990's was a fading piece of history in California but declaring that the Golden State had forged ahead to become "the powerhouse of the Pacific, a beacon of industry and innovation that is lighting the path to an age of unimaginable incandescence."
But perhaps it was an East Coast governor, George E. Pataki of New York, still another Republican, who drew the strongest contrast between the state of American states in early 1998 and the state that existed during the darkest days of the recession.
In 1992, his predecessor in Albany, Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, lamented despairingly in his State of the State address that "New York, like other states, is struggling with a powerful force it cannot control, a national recession." Then, his rhetoric taking an even darker turn, he compared New York with a hostage in the hands of Middle East terrorists, struggling to maintain dignity in an all but hopeless environment.
There was none of that in Mr. Pataki's 1998 report on the state of New York State. Boasting about the state's sharp economic turnaround in recent years, he contended that hope had replaced hopelessness and despair, then said, "We have restored the dream. New York stands at the dawn of its greatest day."

HEADLINE: Aliens Would Get Food Stamps Back In Clinton Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
In the budget he is to present to Congress on Monday, President Clinton will call for spending $2.5 billion in the next five years to provide food stamps to the hundreds of thousands of legal immigrants whose benefits were cut off by the sweeping Federal welfare law of 1996.
The welfare law removed 935,000 immigrants from the Federal food stamp rolls, according to Government estimates. While the states with the largest immigrant populations, including New York, California, Texas and Florida, have partly filled the void with their own programs, nearly 700,000 poor immigrants are still without food stamps. 
 And in New York City, where officials say 65,000 immigrants have lost the benefits, the President's plan takes on an even greater importance.
Since the day that he signed the 1996 bill, Mr. Clinton has advocated restoring some aid to legal immigrants who have not become citizens. With the Federal budget nearing balance and a strong economy pumping unanticipated tax dollars into the Government's coffers, the time is ripe, his aides argue.
But the proposal is expected to ignite a heated debate on Capitol Hill over its cost and over the role of the Federal Government in assisting noncitizens. Already, word of the President's plan has generated strong opposition from House conservatives, who charge that Mr. Clinton is trying to undermine the 1996 law by bits and pieces.
"Noncitizens should look to themselves, their families and their sponsors, not the American taxpayers, for financial support," said Representative Bob W. Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia, who is chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the food stamps program.
But in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been strenuously lobbying to restore the benefits. Officials there say that some families who lost their food stamps have been pushed to the brink of hunger, placing new burdens on already stretched food pantries.
The fight over restoring the aid could also spill over into New York's already contentious Senate race. Advocates of Mr. Clinton's plan are trying to prod Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato into carrying their fight to the Republican leadership, as he did last year in pushing to restore other welfare benefits for legal immigrants.
The advocates warn that Mr. D'Amato, a Republican who is running for his fourth term, will incur the wrath of immigrants who have obtained citizenship if he fails to lead the food stamp battle in Congress.
"He is pivotal," said Josh Bernstein, a policy analyst for the National Immigration Law Center in Washington.
Mr. D'Amato, who voted for the 1996 welfare bill, said in an interview that he supported Mr. Clinton's plan, although he had not seen details. "I will be joining with my colleagues to try to win this battle," he said.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is seeking the Democratic nomination to challenge Mr. D'Amato, said he also supported Mr. Clinton's plan, though he wanted better Federal oversight of the food stamp program to prevent fraud and waste.
Except for a few small groups, including military veterans and recent refugees, the 1996 welfare law ended food stamp benefits for almost all immigrants, a number put at 935,000 by the Department of Agriculture. But more than a dozen states, including New York and New Jersey, have created locally financed programs that are helping to feed more than 240,000 immigrants -- leaving almost 700,000 without benefits.
The New York program provides food stamps to children, the elderly and disabled immigrants who came before Aug. 22, 1996, the day Mr. Clinton signed the welfare bill. The program has restored food stamps to about half of the state's 150,000 immigrants who had lost their benefits. The New Jersey program, which is similar to New York's, returned benefits to 10,000 of 16,000 households. Connecticut has not established such a program.
But advocates for the poor say that despite local programs, many immigrants are stretching their meager resources to feed their families by substituting canned goods for fresh produce and getting groceries from food pantries.
White House officials and people involved in budget negotiations say Mr. Clinton will call for restoring benefits to the elderly, the disabled and families with children. His plan would also provide assistance to some Hmong refugees. The Hmong are a Laotian mountain tribe that was allied with the United States during the Vietnam War. The Clinton plan would extend to seven years from five the time that refugees are eligible for food stamps after arriving in the country.
In his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton made an oblique reference to his plan, saying, "I also want to thank Congress for restoring some of the benefits to immigrants who are here legally and working hard, and I hope you will finish that job this year."
The plan is expected to cover many, perhaps most, immigrants who were in the country before Mr. Clinton signed the welfare bill. But White House officials said there was not enough money to cover all those immigrants.
Advocates for the poor say that if Mr. Clinton's plan is approved, states like New York could supplement the new Federal money with their own funds to provide food stamps to all immigrants. Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki said that he was unlikely to support giving food stamps to able-bodied, childless adults. But Tony Coles, a special adviser to Mr. Giuliani, said the Mayor would probably endorse that idea. New York State splits the cost of its $83 million immigrant food stamp program with local governments.
"The Mayor would support anything that would maximize coverage for legal immigrants," Mr. Coles said. "He will not be satisfied until we get 100 percent restoration."
Congressional sources who have reviewed portions of Mr. Clinton's budget said it would also significantly increase aid to New York City for job training programs, education, AIDS treatment and hospitals. Mr. Clinton is expected to propose eliminating Federal operating subsidies for Amtrak, but he will also call for a 44 percent increase in Federal aid to the city's mass transit system, the sources said.
Democrats say Republicans will be under pressure to support the food stamp plan to inoculate their party from charges of being anti-immigrant. Perhaps sensing that possibility, even Republican supporters of the President's proposal have begun questioning Mr. Clinton's motives.
"It's just a throwaway line in a speech," said Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican from the Miami area. "Unless he pushes it, it's not going to happen. And he's not pushing it."
But some moderate Republicans said they thought the plan had a strong chance of passing, though perhaps in restricted form. "We have a good cross-section of members supporting this," said Representative James T. Walsh, a Republican from Syracuse who sponsored similar legislation last year. "If it went to a vote on the floor, we'd get it."

HEADLINE: INVESTIGATING CLINTON: THE OVERVIEW;
Lewinsky Would Take Lie Test In Exchange for Immunity Deal

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. and JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Monica S. Lewinsky, the former low-level aide at the center of the current White House investigation, is willing to submit to a polygraph examination in exchange for complete immunity from prosecution, her lawyer said today.
The lawyer, William H. Ginsburg, whose tone in a blitz of five television appearances sounded less hostile to President Clinton than it was just a few days ago, said Ms. Lewinsky would voluntarily take the test to prove the truthfulness of her account of a relationship with Mr. Clinton. 
 On the airwaves and behind the scenes today, a delicate dance between Mr. Ginsburg and Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor, was being played out. Mr. Ginsburg predicted that Mr. Clinton would emerge virtually unscathed from the political and legal frenzy.
"It'll go away; it'll pass," he said in one of his television appearances. "The President will remain in office, he'll do a good job, we'll all, hopefully, have a sound economy, keep our jobs, and I think everything's going to be fine."
To emphasize that point, Mr. Ginsburg portrayed his client today as a witness more sympathetic to the President than was assumed. This gambit might be intended to pressure Mr. Starr to moderate his hard-line attitude toward her as a potential witness. Mr. Ginsburg also said for the first time that he had spoken with White House lawyers.
Mr. Ginsburg said Ms. Lewinsky, a 24-year-old former White House intern, would submit to a polygraph exam only if Mr. Starr promised not to charge her with lying in an affidavit she provided for the sexual misconduct case against Mr. Clinton filed by Paula Corbin Jones.
However, Mr. Starr is balking at granting blanket immunity to Ms. Lewinsky until he is certain that she is a credible witness, lawyers involved in the talks say. Ms. Lewinsky's testimony is critical to the independent counsel's effort to establish whether Mr. Clinton carried on an extended sexual affair with Ms. Lewinsky and then sought to have her lie about it under oath.
In past discussions with Mr. Ginsburg, lawyers for Mr. Starr, reflecting doubts about Ms. Lewinsky's reliability as a witness, have said she should take a polygraph exam before they will consider accepting her offer to tell them everything she knows.
The difference over the timing of the polygraph exam has become a stumbling block to an agreement between the independent counsel and Ms. Lewinsky, lawyers involved in the case said today. Some members of Mr. Starr's legal team are also concerned that Ms. Lewinsky's "proffer," the summary of her proposed testimony, does not reflect some snippets of conversations that she claimed to have had with Mr. Clinton on 20 hours of tapes secretly recorded by a friend.
But one lawyer insisted that the omissions "are not significant."
Mr. Ginsburg provided the proffer verbally to Mr. Starr's legal team on Jan. 26, and since then there has been little communication between them.
The negotiations are further complicated by the Government's difficulty in acquiring evidence to corroborate accounts of Mr. Clinton's relationship with the woman and any effort he may have made -- including referring her to a lawyer and helping her find a job -- to persuade her to remain silent about it.
Vernon E. Jordan Jr., a close friend of Mr. Clinton, referred Ms. Lewinsky to a Washington lawyer and recommended her to three corporations based in New York for employment. Mr. Jordan was subpoenaed by a grand jury here but has not yet testified.
Mr. Ginsburg acknowledged today that he may not know the complete story, because he knows only what Ms. Lewinsky has told him, some of which contradicts what she may have told friends about the matter. Nor does he know what Mr. Clinton is prepared to say about his dealings with Ms. Lewinsky.
The President has emphatically denied having had sexual relations with Ms. Lewinsky or telling her to lie, but the White House has declined to elaborate on the accusations.
"I don't know the whole truth," Mr. Ginsburg said in an interview on the Fox television network. "I don't think anyone knows the whole truth, because I don't think anyone has seen all the pieces of the puzzle."
In her Jan. 7 affidavit in the Jones case, Ms. Lewinsky swore that she had not had a sexual relationship with the President. Mr. Ginsburg has hinted that she is prepared to tell a significantly different account if she is fully protected from prosecution, rather than granted more limited, or "use," immunity.
"If the prosecutor elects to give full immunity or a promise not to prosecute, you still tell your story, only in a little more relaxed and comfortable fashion," Mr. Ginsburg said in another of the television interviews he gave this morning. "And maybe the prosecutor can get more details than with someone who is under use immunity."
Over the last several days, Mr. Ginsburg has also denied or played down many of the more sensational details of Ms. Lewinsky's relationship with Mr. Clinton that purportedly were captured on tape-recorded telephone conversations between Ms. Lewinsky and a friend and co-worker, Linda R. Tripp, 48.
Mr. Ginsburg's recent tone contrasts markedly with his remarks when the scandal broke two weeks ago. Then he said the President would be a "misogynist" if the accusations of his relationship with the intern were true. He and his young client appeared to pose a lethal threat to Mr. Clinton's Presidency.
Again and again today, Mr. Ginsburg insisted that he had heard nothing on the proffer from Mr. Starr's office and that he intended to travel with Ms. Lewinsky to California to visit her father, Bernard Lewinsky, who lives in Beverly Hills. In an interview late today, Mr. Ginsburg denied that the trip was intended to signal an ultimatum to Mr. Starr.
"There's no strategy involved here," he said. He added that Ms. Lewinsky had been virtually imprisoned in her apartment in the Watergate complex here and needed a chance to escape the hothouse that Washington has become for her.
He insisted that Ms. Lewinsky is a "very reliable young lady" but that he is not going to let her tell her version of events to Mr. Starr's investigators without a firm promise of immunity.
But as in interviews late last week, Mr. Ginsburg suggested that much of what has been said about the case -- some of it in Ms. Lewinsky's own words on Ms. Tripp's surreptitious tapes -- may prove to be exaggerated or false.
"Seriously, all 24-year-olds and all 18-year-olds and 19-year-olds tend to embellish," Mr. Ginsburg said on CBS. "None of us can stand the scrutiny of dredging up our past in the wonderful way that the press does it."
On the talk-show circuit, Republicans continued to question Mr. Clinton's conduct and credibility. Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said that if Mr. Clinton engaged in a sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky and then lied about it to the nation, "it's an egregious breach of ethics."
"So if that happened to have happened, then, you know, we've got a big problem on our hands," said Mr. Hatch, who in his spare time composes gospel hymns. "We have perhaps the first Presidential canoodler in history."

HEADLINE: Rural Elderly Create Vital Communities as Young Leave Void

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: RED CLOUD, Neb.

 BODY:
The Elm Street Center for the elderly was hopping the other day, a beacon of warmth and activity amid the frozen bleakness that is winter in this farming town. The lunch crowd had arrived.
At one table, widows in their 80's and 90's were dismissing their families' suggestions that they were at an age where they should be thinking about giving up their homes. 
 "One of my sons-in-law wanted me to move to Aurora -- I have four grandchildren there -- and go into a retirement place," said Myrtle Wilmot, 88, who arrived as a bride in 1927 and raised six children on a farm, without electricity or running water. "I told him, 'I'm not ready for retirement. Do you know what I'd give up if I left here?' "
Why does she need to go to Aurora, Neb., 90 miles away, anyway?
"Red Cloud," Mrs. Wilmot said, "is a retirement place."
It is one that was created gradually, by subtraction, as generations of young people sought jobs and opportunity elsewhere, leaving their parents, grandparents and great grandparents behind. Now, while many old people around the nation pack up their homes and move to Florida, North Carolina and Arizona, Mrs. Wilmot and her friends are aging together in a familiar, faded town.
The transformation is happening throughout the farm belt. In Nebraska, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas and other Midwestern states, the proportion of elderly is higher than the national average, according to the Census Bureau, primarily because of the exodus of young people. And the five states with the highest proportion of "oldest old" -- those 85 and older -- are all farm states: Nebraska, Iowa, the Dakotas and Kansas.
Across the Plains, small towns are graying. Some are dying, but others, like Red Cloud, are holding on.
"From a demographic perspective, they look like retirement communities of the Sun Belt," said Raymond T. Coward, dean of the School of Health and Human Services at the University of New Hampshire, who has studied the rural elderly. "They are, however, quite different and distinct cultural and social environments in which to grow old."
In towns like Red Cloud, where nearly half of the 1,105 residents are over 65, it is the older people who are sustaining the economy. On Sundays after church, Elavoni's restaurant here is packed with widows. The kitchen at the center for the elderly in Guide Rock, 10 miles east, keeps the local Food Mart in business.
The amenities that are part of planned retirement communities -- new hospitals, plenty of doctors and home health care workers, fitness centers, shopping malls -- are hard to come by in small rural towns. Jan Ferebee, 72, and her friends who enjoy water aerobics have to drive 40 miles from Red Cloud to the Y.M.C.A. in Hastings for classes.
But for all that may be missing here, older residents talk more about the community that Red Cloud remains for them.
"My neighbor just got back from visiting her family for a month in California," Mrs. Wilmot said. "She said she didn't realize how much it meant to be in a small town where everybody knows you and you know everybody.
"I know what it means. When I walk down the street, people call me by my name."
 
Someone To Watch Over Them
 It also means that after years of paying into the small-town version of Social Security -- volunteering at church, shopping on Main Street, cooking for the sick, being a good neighbor -- Mrs. Wilmot and her friends can count on people looking out for them.
"You got somebody in your neighborhood who's older, needs help, we do it," said Mrs. Ferebee's husband, Ralph, who is 75 and spent 40 years working for the local soil conservation district.
When it snowed recently, he took out his snow blower and cleared the driveways of his widowed neighbors, Naomi Doughman, Mary Lou McCracken and Sadie Rickard.
"They call me up and thank me and bring me stuff to eat which I can't eat," said Mr. Ferebee, who watches his cholesterol.
The blizzard that dumped 26 inches of snow in October was too much for Mr. Ferebee's snow blower. "Our younger neighbors came with shovels," he said.
At 83, Velma Splattstoesser has buried two husbands. But the calendar in her kitchen is full: Bridge games, trips to Hastings, meetings at the United Methodist Church, Sunday dinners at Elavoni's.
"We chum around," Mrs. Splattstoesser said of her friends.
 
Lots of Experience Toughing Things Out
 Mrs. Splattstoesser's age, and her white hair, might make her invisible in a bigger place. But in Red Cloud she is known, among other things, for her door-to-door campaign to raise money for the center.
"In a city everyone over 80 is kind of lumped together," said Mrs. Splattstoesser's daughter, Mitzi Aldrich, a social worker, who lives in Oklahoma. "It's more personal in a small town. You have a name, a background, a special place in the community."
When it comes to formal support services, Red Cloud, the Webster County seat, offers its older residents more than a lot of other small towns. The center makes up for the lack of public transportation by providing low-cost rides. Red Cloud has a 16-bed county hospital and two doctors. It is hard to find skilled doctors to live here, a three-hour drive from Lincoln, the nearest big city.
With the falling birth rate, the hospital stopped delivering babies about six years ago, and began offering home health care for the aging population. There is a well-run nursing home, with 44 residents, including Nettie Seems, who was born in a sod house 105 years ago.
More typical, though, is Guide Rock, with 240 people, and no medical facilities. "You have to be tough to live there," said Jerry Ryan, executive director of the Midland Area Agency on Aging, which includes Webster County.
The people of Webster County, in south central Nebraska, are used to toughing things out. They are the descendants of pioneers from Virginia, Norway, Germany and Czechoslovakia, whose struggle to carve new lives out of the wind-whipped land was immortalized in the novels of Red Cloud's most celebrated native, Willa Cather.
"The first wheat we ever planted looked beautiful in June," said Helen Hoit, 91, recalling the bitter harvest of 1935. "Then three hot windy days, and we didn't have any wheat crop. It all shriveled up."
Mrs. Hoit and plenty of others survived such droughts, as well as dust storms and the Depression. They raised children, went to church on Sunday and built Red Cloud.
As they got older, their sons took over the farms, and they made the ritual move to town, where the roads were better, and they could be nearer to stores and neighbors.
Now, many of the women are navigating widowhood together.
"The dust storms were bad, but we had each other," said Mrs. Hoit, whose husband, Leo, died in 1985, not long after their 57th anniversary. "Losing your husband is worse because you're alone for a while. I had never even stayed at home at night alone until he stayed in the hospital.
"You never, never, forget," she said. "You learn to carry on."
When her husband was alive, the couple would spend winters in Yuma, Ariz. "After he passed away, I just stayed put here," she said. "Yuma's one of those towns that's spread out all over the creation."
At the center, where the two friends were having lunch the other day, Mrs. Splattstoesser said admiringly of Mrs. Hoit: "She still mows her lawn -- with a push mower."
 
Young People Leave; Elderly Fill the Void
 By all accounts, Red Cloud has a high proportion of remarkably vigorous older people. "It seems like 75 isn't old here," said Terry L. Hoffart, administrator of the Webster County Community Hospital.
Studies show that older people who have a meaningful role in their communities are healthier, mentally and physically. "That's what rural communities do," Dr. Coward said. "When everyone else leaves, somebody needs to be mayor, head of the cemetery committee, and the school board. Older people step up, and do those jobs very well."
Mr. Ferebee happens to be chairman of the cemetery board. When their children were young, he and his wife helped to build a lodge for the Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts. Mrs. Ferebee recently helped raise $5,000 for badly needed renovations to the lodge.
The declining population means that everyone's labor is needed. There is no forced retirement in Webster County.
At 89, Eunice Fritz is the county school superintendent, an elected, part-time post she has held since 1974.
Worrell Reichstein, 72, drives the county snowplow.
Geri Shipley, 68, delivers meals to frail elderly people, making her way on icy roads even on the coldest days.
Jessie McDole, 77, puts in a five-and-a-half-day week at her late husband's welding shop. She was there the other afternoon, feeding the wood stove and visiting with her friend Yvonne Stephens, who runs the center.
The two women laughed about Mrs. McDole's refusal to set foot inside the center. "I'll do that when I'm old," said Mrs. McDole, who had insisted on giving Mrs. Stephens the chair in her office and was perched on a stack of books on the cold floor.
Gerontologists have a term for people like Mrs. McDole: the hardy elderly. "They make things work, even from the scarcest resources," Dr. Coward said.
That is pretty much the story of the six-year-old center, where women were working on a yellow quilt the other afternoon, one of a series they are making to sell for money to buy a dishwasher for the kitchen. Other quilts, and crafts, have paid for new windows.
Mrs. Stephens also raises money for the center by renting it out for weddings, family reunions and graduation parties -- at a bargain $35 a day. Teen-agers hold dances there at no cost.
 
The Future Wears A Youthful Face
Red Cloud, with Willa Cather's restored childhood home and other landmarks drawing thousands of tourists each year, is luckier than many other small towns. It is still alive.
Many real estate agents have begun to sell Red Cloud to former residents as a place to retire. They point out that Red Cloud even has a golf course, and a family membership costs only $325.
But there are worrisome signs. The senior class at the high school is down to 29 students -- half the size of the class 30 years ago -- and there is talk of closing it and building a consolidated county high school.
At 78, Reese Gates has watched her town, Inavale, eight miles west of Red Cloud, disappear, its main street shuttered, the high school closed.
"I wish we had something that would bring the young people back," said Mrs. Gates, who lost her husband last spring, and drives to the Red Cloud center for lunch and company.
Her friends in Red Cloud say they are grateful their town still has young families: the people missing from most retirement communities, and the ones who will insure Red Cloud's survival after the older generation is gone.
One of the joys of her days, Mrs. Splattstoesser says, is washing her dishes and looking out her kitchen window at the children playing across the street. "I hear them laughing and calling to each other," she said. "I'd just rather live where there are children."

HEADLINE: Shore City Tries Cutting Red Tape to Grow

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH, N.J.

 BODY:
Over the years, this once-vibrant vacation spot watched both its sandy beaches and its tourism erode. Then came the fire in 1987 that destroyed the city's fishing pier, the boardwalk and an amusement park called Kid's World.
Now, after a decade that left it faded and abandoned, this stretch of Atlantic coast is on the brink of a comeback and, curiously enough, the cutting edge of urban planning. Five developers are negotiating with the city to build housing, a restored pier, an entertainment center, restaurants and shops all connected by resculptured streets lined with trees, walkways and bicycle paths. 
 But Long Branch's redevelopment plan, designed by the architects and urban planners who created South Street Seaport in Manhattan, has won attention not for its ambitious scope but because it persuaded the state to streamline its usually laborious approval process. In preparing a master plan that sets guidelines for developers, city officials incorporated all the state's development regulations into local zoning laws. That strategy guarantees that developers who meet local guidelines automatically comply with state law.
"We have paved the road for them," Mayor Adam Schneider said. "With this plan, you don't have to go out and hire a very sophisticated attorney. You don't have to go out and hire a very sophisticated architect. You don't have to hire a planner and an engineer and spend two years negotiating with the state. Their eyes light up."
In January, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman trumpeted Long Branch as a model for fast-track state approval of local development. "We'll create one of the greatest incentives state government can offer a town," she said in her inaugural address. "A pledge to get out of your way." She added: "We've tried it in one town, and it's working. Let's make sure it works everywhere."
For developers and municipalities, the Governor's pledge is a tantalizing prospect. New Jersey is the most densely populated state in the country and has the second-highest per-capita income, creating a seemingly boundless appetite for residential and commercial construction.
In late January, the Commissioner of New Jersey's Department of Environmental Protection signed into law a blanket permit for Long Branch's redevelopment plan. The arrangement, the first of its kind, is unusual because the state has granted approval based not on the developer's design for a specific building or project but rather on the city's master plan.
While Long Branch's approach will trim the bureaucratic process for developers, reaching the agreement with the state took more than three years of difficult planning.
The effort was spearheaded by Long Branch Tomorrow, a public-private partnership formed in 1993. The Thompson Design Group in Boston, which was hired by Long Branch to draw up the redevelopment plans, advocated a redevelopment plan that would comply with state law from the outset and would make even greater demands on developers for preserving the character of the city as a historical summer resort town.
But neither the partnership nor the designer expected the idea to be served up as a model for state policy. The primary goal was simply to succeed where previous efforts at redevelopment had failed.
"We didn't come up with this from a policy perspective," said Pratap Talwar, a senior urban designer at Thompson, which has long experience in complex waterfront projects. "We went out and did surveys and interviews with developers of every scale, finding out what were the barriers to entry, why wouldn't they embrace a plan that had so much public support and clear opportunities to make money?"
An attempt to revitalize the oceanfront in the mid-to-late 1980's, for example, resulted in a Hilton Hotel but nothing else after the plans bogged down in the approval stage.
But drafting a plan that would have both public and private support in Long Branch entailed its own complications, Mr. Talwar said. Mayor Schneider and two of his top aides, the business administrator, Howard H. Wooley Jr., and planning director, Carl Turner, flew to Boston to look at an initial model expecting Long Branch to be reborn as a glorious summer resort.
To their surprise, the Thompson plan included a large residential component. "We said: 'Where is the Ferris wheel? Where are the amusements?' " Mr. Wooley recalled. "We had seen it as a commercial, touristy kind of thing. They thought a year-round residential community would be a better approach." But Mr. Talwar and others prevailed, insisting that relying on seasonal tourism and commerce had been a main reason for Long Branch's decline.
From the project's inception, Long Branch had undertaken an enormous effort to attract attention and resources, with local officials seeking out allies in various state agencies like Environmental Protection, Transportation and Land Use Regulation. Only later did state officials realize that Long Branch might be onto just the sort of new policy initiative that Trenton was looking for.
One of the officials Long Branch sought out two years ago was Richard Kropp, who had recently become the director of New Jersey's Land Use Regulation Office. Invited from Trenton to hear about the ambitious plans, Mr. Kropp listened with surprise to the outline for revitalizing 140 acres of underdeveloped waterfront, realizing that at each step Long Branch had taken care to meet the state's strict specifications for coastal development.
Those regulations, included in the Coastal Area Facility Review Act, had often cast shoreline development projects into a long and arduous application process for state approval. The Whitman administration, particularly Mr. Kropp, had been thinking about ways to marry state and local interests without compromising the standards. "We had been looking for opportunities like this and this just fit the bill," Mr. Kropp recalled. "This just kind of fell into our lap as an excellent way to proceed."
But while there is growing interest in the Long Branch project, developers, local officials and urban planners say it may be difficult to replicate it as a model and perhaps impossible to meet Governor Whitman's goal of bringing expedited approval to projects statewide.
"You can't go to Hoboken or Union City or Parsippany and say, 'Do what Long Branch did and feel strongly about it,' " Mr. Talwar said.
The five developers negotiating in Long Branch said they hoped the approval process would be as smooth as officials had promised, but most expressed some skepticism.
"My experience is that nothing really plays out in detail until you are going through the process," said Mario Procida, president of a Bronx contractor that is seeking to put up commercial buildings in Long Branch as part of the redevelopment project. "Clearly the word is that it is an expedited approval process. If it is, it certainly will facilitate things."
Peter S. Reinhart, senior vice president and general counsel of K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, which is negotiating to build residences, said the Long Branch plan might save time for developers but had added more work for the city.
"You are switching around the layers of a layer cake, but you still have to eat the whole cake," Mr. Reinhart said. "I don't know how you speed it up without reducing the number of layers and permits over all. The overall time probably isn't any shorter; it's just who spent it."
But Mr. Kropp expressed confidence that the Long Branch plan could be a model. "What we are concerned about is that we are going to have a line formed," he said. "Everybody is going to want to do this."

Map of Long Branch, N.J.: Long Branch lost its boardwalk and fishing pier in a 1987 fire. (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Albright Rebukes Israeli and Palestinian Leaders

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright scolded Israeli and Palestinian leaders today for delaying the fundamental decisions necessary to revive peace talks between them.
"We have been stalled at this point in the peace process, negotiating the same issues, for a long time -- frankly, far too long," Ms. Albright said at a news conference, in an exasperated tone. "There is far too much at stake for this to go on." 
 The issues at stake are difficult and complex, she noted, and she said both Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, had agreed to send envoys to Washington next week for further discussions.
"But I must say I had hoped we would get further on this trip than we have," Ms. Albright said. "It is no longer enough to simply talk about wanting peace. It is time to make the difficult decisions and exercise the leadership necessary to achieve it."
Ms. Albright also tried to calm Israeli fears over possible Iraqi missile strikes by renewing the United States' promise to help defend Israel against any Iraqi attack. She threatened "swift and forceful" retaliation against Iraq if it attacked Israel or any of its neighbors.
But what came across strongest today was her impatience with the slow and hesitant response of Israelis and Palestinians to the American call for courage and leadership.
In four hours of conversation on Saturday night with Mr. Netanyahu and two hours in Ramallah today with Mr. Arafat, Ms. Albright was even more direct, a senior American official said.
"With both of them, she said in different ways that 'I'm sick and tired of both of you putting forward a huge stack of complaints about each other, because we're really at a time for fundamental decisions to be taken,' " the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Her talks were intended to follow up on President Clinton's discussions in Washington with Mr. Netanyahu on Jan. 20 and with Mr. Arafat on Jan. 22. The Americans are proposing a phased withdrawal of Israeli troops from part of the West Bank in a parallel effort to specific Palestinian moves to improve their fight against terrorism and their security cooperation with Israel. The two men returned home demanding detailed changes in the American plan, and American officials said they had offered "further refinements" at these meetings.
Ms. Albright, asked if she got "good answers" on this trip, said astringently, "I received some answers." She said the two leaders "are doing what President Clinton asked them to do -- to think through the ideas he presented to them, and they are increasingly realizing that they must make the hard decisions."
But after these meetings, American officials said, significant differences still remain over the size, timing and quality of the Israeli withdrawal, as well as over how to judge Palestinian security efforts and cooperation at each phase.
Both sides also disagree over whether a later withdrawal, as called for in the Oslo peace accords between Israel and the Palestinians, should take place even during new talks on a final settlement between the parties. Israel argues that it would not be necessary, while Mr. Arafat and the Americans insist that Oslo be fulfilled.
In a sign of some progress, Israel is now considering a first withdrawal that would total about 15 percent of West Bank land, officials say -- less than what Mr. Arafat wants but more than Mr. Netanyahu had appeared willing to offer.
This was also a day when some of the inevitable contradictions of Ms. Albright's trip, let alone current American policy in the Middle East, became visible. The Secretary has been threatening war on Iraq while trying to bring peace to the Israelis and Palestinians, and so far on this trip, the edge has gone to war.
In October and November, as the Iraq crisis built and moderate Arab nations boycotted an American-sponsored Middle East economic summit in Doha, Qatar, American officials said the stalemate in peace talks and Mr. Netanyahu's delaying tactics were damaging Washington's standing among Arab nations. The Israelis reacted angrily, saying they should not be blamed, but American officials insisted that there was a connection, especially in Arab public opinion.
Today, however, Ms. Albright said the two main challenges of her tour -- to insure that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq complies with unhindered United Nations weapons inspections, and to promote progress on the Palestinian-Israeli peace efforts -- were separate. "While these two problems are going on simultaneously, we have to deal with them independently, and we have to make our views on both known very clearly," she said. "I am not making any connection between the two."
Her strong statements today promising American retaliation if Israeli is attacked seemed intended to reassure Israelis that they would not be victimized by American policy against Iraq. And in contrast to the position in 1991, when the Bush Administration pressed Israel not to retaliate against Iraqi Scuds, Ms. Albright said, "It is always up to each country to determine its own way to defend itself."
The United States would retaliate quickly if Iraq attacked Israel or other Arab countries, she said. "If they do in fact threaten their neighbors and do damage to them, our response will be swift and forceful," she said of the Iraqis. "They should have no doubt about that."
Ms. Albright also reacted positively to reports that the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, after a study of Iraqi relief needs, is recommending that the oil-for-food program be increased from $4 billion a year to $10 billion. Some $7.2 billion would be spent on Iraqi relief, doubling the current amount, while the rest goes for war reparations to Kuwait and to pay for the program.
 
Kuwait Backs U.S.
By The New York Times
KUWAIT, Feb. 1 -- The Emir of Kuwait assured Secretary of State Albright tonight that his country would support the use of military force against Iraq if necessary, senior American officials said.
A Kuwait Government statement issued after an evening meeting with Ms. Albright said that "Kuwait supports the firm U.S. stand" and that it holds Iraq "responsible for all the negative consequences that may result from continuing its intransigence and its failure to comply with international resolutions."
Ms. Albright met with the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Sabah, and the Crown Prince, Sheik Saad al-Sabah, to explain Washington's position on Iraq.
Ms. Albright "left the meeting well satisfied that she has the 100 percent support of the Government of Kuwait," said her spokesman, James P. Rubin.
 
No Uses of Bases, Saudi Says
 DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 1 (AP) -- America's closest ally in the gulf -- Saudi Arabia -- could also be its toughest challenge in building support for a military attack on Iraq.
Saudi resistance, spelled out in comments today by a senior Saudi official, complicates United States efforts to get full cooperation from countries in the region.
"Saudi Arabia will not allow any strikes against Iraq, under any circumstances, from its soil or bases in Saudi Arabia, due to the sensitivity of the issue in the Arab and Muslim world," the Saudi official said on condition of anonymity.
Even United Nations approval of an attack would not change the Saudi position, the official said.

Fraternal Rulers in Cuba

Repartitioning of Bosnia
Local governments in Bosnia that were elected by exiled refugees last fall have been unable to overcome a campaign to keep them from operating, United Nations officials say. In elections next September, people will be allowed to vote only where they live. Diplomats fear that unless more refugees manage to return to areas controlled by other ethnic groups this year, the ethnic partition could be irreversible. A4
 
Balloon in a No-Flight Zone
Three Europeans seeking to fly nonstop around the world in a balloon spent five tense hours over Iraq, drifting briefly into the no-fly zone, their mission-control center in Geneva reported. They and their balloon, which crossed into Iraqi airspace without permission but later received clearance, drifted on to Iran. China, which is on their path, has so far denied them permission to enter its airspace. (AP)

NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
For Some on Madison Ave., The Aftershock Lingers
Madison Avenue might seem to be back to normal two months after falling bricks from an office tower closed a stretch of the street and forced residents to leave their homes. But a closer look at the block most affected -- the west side of Madison Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets -- revealed something quite different. Seven residents have not been allowed to return to their apartments, and some businesses have not been allowed to reopen. And none of the affected tenants or businesses have been reimbursed for out-of-pocket expenses, now totaling more than $20,000 for some individuals. Building inspectors plan to examine four apartments today. B1
 
An Illegal Trade in Legal Drugs
Doctors at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens have begun to worry about a drug trade they have not seen before: legal pharmacies that illegally dispense drugs to treat more common maladies, like the flu or ulcers. Health experts wonder if such illegal dispensing of prescription drugs could play a role in a growing bacterial resistance to antibiotics. There is also concern that illegally dispensed medications can cause fatal allergic reactions or simply worsen a patient's condition. B1
 
Protesting Police Cameras
More than 200 people rallied in Washington Square Park against the Giuliani Administration's increasing use of surveillance cameras to fight crime, saying the practice infringed on privacy. The hourlong protest came a month after the police installed two cameras on light poles along the southern edge of the park to discourage small-scale drug dealing. B3

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Man Gets State Money For Casino Bus Shuttle

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
An unemployed casino blackjack dealer received more than $60,000 in state funds Friday under a program intended to increase the number of minority residents who own minibus shuttles for gamblers in Atlantic City.
The dealer, Keith Davis, who is black, was the first beneficiary of the program, which was established by state casino officials in April after studies showed that most people who own Atlantic City shuttle franchises are white and from out of town. 
 Mr. Davis, 36, made a $300 down payment on the minibus, leaving state officials to cover the remaining purchase costs, as well as the price of license plates, a registration title, legal fees and membership dues in the Atlantic City Jitney Association, said Frances M. Santoro, the economic development director for the State Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, which sponsored the program. Mr. Davis is one of 15 minority residents who will receive state money to buy shuttle franchises by the end of this year, Ms. Santoro said.
