HEADLINE: That's Entertainment: Variety Goes Bicoastal

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
For Matthew C. Blank, the president and chief executive of Showtime Networks in New York, securing a copy of Daily Variety from Los Angeles has been an exercise in patience. A delivery service takes a day or even two to get him the newspaper. When he wants to read a Variety article first thing in the morning, he has to wait for his Los Angeles colleagues to wake up and pad over to their fax machines in their pajamas.
"I've always felt like a second-class citizen compared to my brethren in California," Mr. Blank said. "This is a deal-a-day type of business. And the Hollywood trades and Daily Variety in particular fill an important gap in your information stream." 
 Beginning on March 16, Mr. Blank will have it much easier. Daily Variety will be available for home delivery and newsstand sales in the New York region by 6 A.M. Monday through Friday.
A weekly Variety has been published in Manhattan since 1905. Now its daily West Coast edition, which has chronicled the entertainment industry for 65 years and made "box office returns" a part of the vernacular is coming to New York with a "Gotham" edition.
"It will be terrific to have it available in New York," said Ron Silver, the president of Actors' Equity. "It's essential."
Daily Variety Gotham, as it will be called, will feature increased coverage of topics specific to New York, like Off Off Broadway theater, Wall Street, sports, fashion, even economic development as it relates to entertainment. To handle this new load, Variety is hiring three additional reporters in Manhattan and three editors in Los Angeles. But Variety executives said the new edition would not be dramatically different from the Los Angeles version.
The motivation behind Daily Variety Gotham seems to be less creating a new New York paper than it is making the tried and true Daily Variety more accessible to people on the East Coast. "Think of it as a first edition," said Gerry Byrne, the vice president and group publisher of Variety. "Really what we're doing is nationalizing the daily."
Daily Variety expects to attract another 14,000 readers, Mr. Byrne said, bringing the daily's total circulation to about 43,000. He also said he hoped to attract advertisers in the New York metropolitan area. Last year, Daily Variety had advertising revenue of about $27 million, up from $12 million in 1992. And between the two publications, profit has increased from about $2 million to more than $20 million.
Daily Variety Gotham will be printed at the company's plant in Easton, Pa., where the weekly is produced. Variety will continue to publish its West Coast edition in Glendale, Calif.
Variety's executives said the moment seemed right for a New York edition, given the city's explosion in media consolidation, film and television production and independent film companies. "There is a quantifiable shift of talent to New York City," said Peter Bart, Variety's vice president and editor in chief.
At least three of the major movie studios report to Manhattan: Warner Brothers to Time Warner, Fox to the News Corporation and Paramount to Viacom. The networks are based in New York, as is most of the cable industry and book and magazine publishing.
And entertainment executives have become increasingly bicoastal, as has the industry itself. "There used to be a division between the talent and creative types on one coast and the money on the other coast," Mr. Bart said. "That's not true anymore."
In a sense, Daily Variety is coming back to New York. Its mother publication, the weekly Variety, was founded 93 years ago on West 46th Street by the Silverman family as a publication for the vaudeville business. In 1933, Daily Variety was started in California to track the film business, coining such expressions as cliffhanger, boffo, oater (a western) and ankle (to quit a job). In 1987, the family sold the company to Reed International, now Reed Elsevier, the British-Dutch company known mostly for its science and medical publications.
The New York edition is the latest in a series of new directions for Variety, including Variety Junior, started in October, which covers the children's entertainment business and comes out five times a year; On Production, re-introduced in November, which covers film, television and commercial production; and a Web site (variety.com) started last month.
Because Variety is aimed at the entertainment industry, it is difficult to anticipate the Gotham edition's competition. (In Los Angeles, it remains the 68-year-old Hollywood Reporter.) The trade press in New York includes Backstage, a weekly newspaper aimed at actors and stagehands, and a magazine started in September called In Theater, which the editor in chief, Kathy Henderson, described as "Entertainment Weekly for people who love theater."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Bart, Variety's vice president and editor in chief. (Steve Goldstein for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F. May Be Closer To Lending-Curb Idea

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund, looking for ways to avoid a future Asia-style financial crisis, may be moving in the direction of endorsing rules that would prevent another surge in foreign bank lending. Such a surge played a key role in the Asian crisis.
The Clinton Administration distances itself from such proposals, fearful they may draw criticism in Congress, which is considering an Administration request to approve $18 billion in financing for the I.M.F. The concern is that any attempt to discourage too much lending through controls may sound like tampering with free markets, a potential obstacle in Congress. 
 The possibility of an I.M.F. shift came Sunday in an interview with Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s first deputy managing director, who was here for the annual World Economic Forum. Mr. Fischer, who is second-in-command at the I.M.F., insisted that he spoke only for himself, not the organization's directors. But his remarks were the first public acknowledgment by an I.M.F. official that discouraging the flow of short-term loans might be a good idea.
"The I.M.F. recognizes the problem of surges of short-term capital across borders and the need to find ways to deal with that," Mr. Fischer said. He then suggested that "the Chilean scheme is one that needs to be considered." Chile discourages short-term loans from abroad by taxing those of a year or less. The goal is to encourage long-term investment.
The I.M.F. usually pushes member countries toward unrestricted open market systems. That is certainly a condition of the huge I.M.F. bailout loans now going to South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand. In a speech last September, however, Mr. Fischer said that capital controls could be acceptable in emerging-market countries, but only for a brief "transitional" period. Yesterday, he greatly lengthened the period.
For countries that can make them work, he said, "capital controls could be acceptable to the I.M.F. for a transitional phase until the financial system of a country is sufficiently strong to deal with surges in short- term loans from abroad." The implication was that a developing country might apply capital controls for years while it constructed a financial system with all the checks and rules that exist in industrial countries like the United States.
Recognizing the problem, Mr. Fischer said, "None of what I am saying is a reason for a country to delay fixing its financial system."
He was among hundreds of government leaders, chief executives, financiers, investment bankers, artists, scientists and economists gathered here for a six-day version of the kind of Renaissance weekends that President Clinton has popularized in the United States. The Asia crisis was the main topic -- its causes, cures and how to prevent another.
There was wide agreement, for example, on the need for a monitoring system -- run by the I.M.F. or some other organization -- that would track the finances of countries much more closely than any international agency now does. A rating system might also be developed, one that might prompt foreign lenders to raise interest rates for countries with poor credit ratings.
"If we have sound surveillance and the right regulations," Jacques Santer, president of the European Commission, said, "then of course the free movement of capital takes place without the same risk."
Excessive short-term borrowing from abroad has appeared on nearly everyone's list of precipitating factors. South Korean banks and corporations, for example, amassed huge debts in yen and dollars. When the South Korean economy slowed, and the nation's currency, the won, began to lose value, the South Koreans had trouble repaying the billions of dollars coming due each month to Japanese, European and American banks. The banks responded by refusing to renew the loans, doing further damage to the economy. The I.M.F. bailout is partly intended to get South Korea's credit system functioning again and to help assure repayment of foreign debts.
Mr. Fischer's concession is aimed at discouraging so much short-term borrowing. Joseph E. Stiglitz, chief economist at the World Bank, the I.M.F.'s sister organization, also spoke in favor of considering capital controls. As an example, he said the controls might take the form of a big tax deduction for loans longer than a year, and a much smaller deduction or none for short-term loans, to discourage their use.
"If you believe there is a sufficient systemic risk," he said, referring to the danger that the Asian turmoil might spread, even to the United States, damaging its economy and markets, "then you have to believe that there is a need for prior action."
But most of the people here oppose capital controls, viewing them as unwarranted interference in free markets. A global economy, they argue, functions on free and rapidly flowing capital. The Clinton Administration officials here, spending part of their time promoting the President's request to Congress for $18 billion in I.M.F. funds, shared that caution. The Administration is trying to sell its case on two contentions: the I.M.F. is necessary when a crisis does occur, and a crisis that endures, because of a weakened I.M.F., can cost American jobs.
"The issue of inhibitions on short-term capital is one that requires careful study," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary. "There is no question that where supervisory structures are inadequate or financial systems are immature, excessive inflows can create problems. But there are also real risks that controls can delay or prevent more fundamental adjustments."
Some, like Jeffrey Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management and a former investment banker himself, said that capital controls simply would not work.
"Global lending is so complex today," he said, "that to think you can block off one part and get the results you want is a level of hubris that is unrealistic. Capital finds ways to go flow around the stone."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
G.M. and Daewoo Agree to Consider Variety of Business Ties

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the Daewoo Group of South Korea announced today that they plan to go steady while negotiating a prenuptial agreement.
After publicly courting each other for weeks, the two said they had signed a memorandum of understanding to consider a wide range of business ties. G.M. is considering taking a large equity stake in Daewoo's auto business, said Alan G. Perriton, president of G.M. Korea Inc., G.M.'s South Korean subsidiary. The companies also said today that they had already agreed to marry some of their operations: Daewoo dealerships will repair G.M. vehicles in 10 South Korean cities. 
 If a deal were to be reached, a G.M.-Daewoo combination would represent a high-profile consequence of the economic crisis that has ravaged the economy of South Korea and some other Asian nations. Fallen currency values and heavy debts have left many South Korean companies eager for outside partners.
The memorandum will allow G.M. and Daewoo "to discuss the various business opportunities that we think exist between G.M. and Daewoo, especially here in Korea and the Asia-Pacific region," Mr. Perriton said in a telephone interview from South Korea. G.M.'s strategy is to capture 10 percent of the Asia-Pacific market during the next decade.
While G.M. had been wooing Kia Motors and other South Korean auto companies as possible partners, the pact reached today effectively forces G.M. and Daewoo to break off talks with any other suitors. "We've agreed between the parties that our focus will be on intensive talks with each other," Mr. Perriton said.
Wall Street analysts said it was premature to say what deal might result, but were generally positive about G.M.'s move, particularly since the Asian crisis has lowered prices in dollar terms for Asian assets. G.M. stock rose $2.5625, to $60.50 today, as the stock market rose sharply.
"G.M. can probably get good value for every dollar invested because of the currency devaluation," said Scott F. Merlis, president of Merlis Automotive International, an independent automotive research firm based in Westport, Conn.
Some analysts said G.M.'s best bet would be to gain control of Daewoo's auto operations rather than taking a small stake or entering into a limited joint venture with the company.
"Somebody from General Motors will have to occupy the main chair," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz L.L.C., a New York investment banking and brokerage firm. A good model for a deal would be Ford's stake in Mazda, she said, in which Ford controls the Japanese auto maker but only owns 33.4 percent of the Japanese company.
G.M., which sold fewer than 1,000 cars in South Korea last year, is eager to gain a bigger foothold in that country's auto market of 1.6 million vehicles, the largest market in Asia after Japan.
The discussions between the two companies will be wide-ranging. "We're open to consideration of any and all possibilities," Mr. Perriton said. Even buying the Daewoo Group's auto business outright would be possible, although that has not yet been discussed, he said.
While many American companies have been looking at South Korean companies, most have refrained from buying so far because many of the troubled companies carry enormous debt loads and have Byzantine ties to South Korean conglomerates. Mr. Perriton said G.M. had not ruled out taking on some Daewoo debt, one of the discussion points in the talks.
The two companies will also discuss whether Daewoo's dealerships will eventually sell G.M. vehicles in South Korea. At the moment, the devaluation of the South Korean currency, the won, has made imported cars and trucks prohibitively expensive for many South Koreans, but if the market improves G.M. may resume selling vehicles there, Mr. Perriton said. He predicted the slowdown in South Korea would last 12 to 18 months.
G.M. has, however, ruled out selling Daewoo's vehicles in its United States dealerships, Mr. Perriton said. The talks are also not expected to include the possibility of G.M.'s buying Daewoo's factory in Poland, he said. Talks are continuing over whether G.M. will buy a Daewoo factory in Ukraine, he said..
Daewoo and G.M. already have five 50-50 joint ventures in South Korea building batteries, wiring harnesses and other parts.
Daewoo and G.M. had a broad joint venture arrangement for 15 years, but that collapsed in 1992. Mr. Perriton insists that it would be different this time. "Since 1992 the whole global marketplace and the Korean marketplace have changed significantly," he said, and the two companies' interests are more closely aligned.
Auto analysts echoed his remarks. "There is much more common interest between the two companies than there was in 1992," Mr. Merlis said. "It is unusual for a remarriage to take place after a divorce, but it could work."

LENGTH: 597 words

HEADLINE: The President's Budget

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget shows admirable accommodation to political constraints. It sticks close to the tight limits set by last year's balanced-budget law and this year's Republican-controlled Congress. It generates a five-year string of surpluses without gutting important Federal programs to do so. It focuses more public spending where it is needed the most and deftly avoids squandering temporary surpluses on permanent tax cuts. The chief weakness is a speculative reliance on tobacco revenues and corporate tax hikes that may not materialize.
The Administration claims full credit for good budget numbers. It expects a surplus next year for the first time in 30 years, and to rack up over $200 billion in surpluses over the next five years. But a robust economy and the 1990 tax hike courtesy of George Bush account for much of the surplus. 
 The Clinton budget reflects sound priorities. It would increase National Science Foundation funding by about 10 percent, hire 100,000 more teachers and build or renovate about 5,000 schools. It would give welfare parents who go to work housing vouchers, and provide more tax credits for corporations that help build low-income housing. The Administration would ease the harsh 1996 welfare law by reinstating food stamps for many legal immigrants. Even those parts of the budget that are less well targeted, such as tax credits for child care, can be defended as a reasonable response to Congress's refusal to go along with a direct spending program. The budget plan does cleverly design this tax cut so upper-income families are ineligible to apply.
The most questionable part of the budget is a reliance on $13 billion a year from the tobacco industry to pay for Mr. Clinton's important new education and health initiatives. The speculative and uncertain payment might come either from an overall tobacco settlement approved by Congress or from imposing a new tax on the industry. Neither will be easy to achieve. Another danger is that linking a settlement to potentially popular programs may inadvertently give the tobacco lobby additional leverage in its campaign to gain immunity from future liability claims. But $13 billion is a small figure in the context of a $1.7 trillion annual budget, so even if the tobacco deal falls through, Mr. Clinton should be able to find other funds for his new programs.
The big fight will come over his proposed use -- or non-use -- of surpluses that the roaring economy is churning out but that Congress did not anticipate last year when it passed the five-year budget plan. Mr. Clinton says the entire surplus should not be used to cut taxes or raise spending until Congress reforms Social Security. That means he would use the entire surplus to pay off the Government debt, which would have the long-term impact of raising private investment and therefore lifting the economy. Mr. Clinton no doubt would prefer to use at least some of the money for his cherished public investment programs, but he knows the G.O.P. would choke over that idea.
By cloaking his plan under the guise of "saving" Social Security, though, the President has put an obstacle in the way of Republican plans to give away the money in a sweeping tax cut. The danger with a large tax cut is that early next century the budget is headed for large deficits as the baby boomers retire, cutting their tax payments and increasing their call on Medicare and Social Security. Taxes cut today would be very difficult to restore tomorrow, putting undue pressure on Congress to cut spending programs instead.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Decline Sharply as Stocks Rally in Asia and U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday, particularly among longer maturities, as the stock market surged on the heels of a rally in Asia, drawing investors away from bonds. The short end of the Treasury market, however, was also lower, but its losses were limited by a tame manufacturing report.
The selloff in bonds came on the eve of the start of a two-day meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers. Talks that the Fed might cut interest rates has faded in recent weeks, and with inflation still benign, most market participants expect no action at all this week. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 13/32 , or more than $10 for each $1,000 invested in bonds, to 1039/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.87 percent, from 5.80 percent on Friday.
The bond market was weighed down at the opening by a sharp rebound in Asian stock markets, which lured investors out of the relative safety of the Treasury market and back into equities.
Losses in bonds were somewhat trimmed after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its January index fell to 52.4 percent from 53.1 percent, weaker than expected. The prices-paid component of the index dropped sharply to 44.7 percent from 50.8 percent.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said the purchasing managers' report indicated a trade-related moderation but not a drastic slowdown in United States economic growth. The price-paid component provided further evidence that overall price inflation should not be a problem despite the recent increase in labor costs, he said.
In addition to the Fed policy meeting, this week the market will also have to contend with the January employment report on Friday. "I expect a gain of between 265,000 to 275,000 jobs, with unemployment at 4.6 percent, and provided that there is no change on the domestic and international news, the market should trade in a narrow band until Friday," said Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal & Company.
The Treasury's weekly sale of three-month and six-month bills yesterday came in as expected. Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: J. Scott Howard, Risk Management Expert, 53

 BODY:
J. Scott Howard, a risk management expert who was a vice president of J. P. Morgan & Company in New York, died on Jan. 14 at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long hospitalization for cancer. He was 53 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.
Mr. Howard spent 27 years with J. P. Morgan. His company called him a pioneer in its Riskmetrics service, a data-based system for weighing investment risks, for which Mr. Howard designed a demonstration and training model. 
 He earned a bachelor's degree in economics and a master's degree in international finance from New York University. He served in Vietnam as an Army sergeant.
Mr. Howard is survived by his wife, B. Sue Mesner Howard; his parents, Mary Rowan and John H. Howard of Newport, R.I.; a brother, Jay, of Seattle, and a sister, Rowan Morse of Portland, Me.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Bank Mantra: We're O.K., We're O.K. Right?

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 2

 BODY:
From the stratospheric heights of their board rooms in glass-and-steel headquarters far above the narrow streets of Tokyo, Japan's top bankers once gazed with pride on the vast commercial empires they helped build.
Now when they look out, they see mountains of bad debt. 
 Japanese banks are the biggest on earth but they are swaying frighteningly in the Asian financial typhoon. The possibility that a giant Japanese bank might one day come crashing down to the ground, sending shock waves around the globe, is a recurring nightmare, not just for Japanese bankers but for treasury officials and bank executives around the world.
Is that going to happen?
Probably not, most bankers and analysts say. But they do not say so with as much confidence as they would like.
When the United States and the International Monetary Fund rushed to bail out South Korea last month, their ultimate concern was less South Korea than its potential impact on Japanese and Western banks. Some of the Japanese banks are already wobbly because of a crushing burden of bad debts; indeed, the sum of bad debts held by Japan's banks is greater than the value of the entire economy of China, not to mention South Korea.
"It's very unstable," Alicia Ogawa, a managing director and banking analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. in Tokyo, said of the financial system in Japan. "Everyone knows there's a huge shoe that's got to drop. Nobody knows when, who's going to pay and who it's going to land on. So, of course, everyone's sort of frozen and trembling in the corner."
For all the worries about Indonesia or South Korea, Japan's economy is twice as large as that of the rest of Asia put together, and so many analysts say the key question that will determine the future of the Asian crisis is simply this: What will happen in Tokyo?
Sure enough, the new Finance Minister, Hikaru Matsunaga, promised this weekend that he would do his utmost to prevent any of the nation's top 19 banks from collapsing. Indeed, the money is there, for Japan is the largest creditor nation in the world, with assets that make the International Monetary Fund look like a pauper, and so it is not risking the kind of liquidity crisis that felled South Korea. With $800 billion in bonds, direct investment and other securities abroad, the Japanese Government is sitting on a comfortable cushion.
"Japan still has a heck of a lot of money," said Kathy M. Matsui, strategist at Goldman, Sachs (Japan) Ltd. "It's a cushion that most Asian economies don't have and it's the cause of a lot of Japan's problems. They know that they have a cushion and can engineer a soft landing."
Still, there are jitters lurking in the market. Though it is unlikely to happen, the nightmare that still haunts bankers and executives around the world is the failure of a large Japanese bank that provokes a run on deposits. That run could even spread to otherwise healthy banks that might in turn prompt a sudden liquidity squeeze and paralyze these giants and eventually the global financial system. Markets could be battered from New York to London. "There could be a systemic collapse, a meltdown," said James P. Fiorello, a banking analyst at ING Barings in Tokyo. "We're talking about a run that closes down proper banks."
The basic problem facing the Japanese banking system is bad debt, a mountain of it, and a subsidiary problem is that no one has a precise idea of how big the mountain is.
The banks report that they have $560 billion in bad or questionable loans, and they hold acres of boarded-up lots and half-empty buildings that they cannot sell but took possession of when loans went sour. When the stock and property prices fall, as they have been lately, the result is a further heap of bad loans piled on to the mountain.
Partly because of these bad debts, a few of Japan's major city banks are barely investment grade, and other banks are also being reviewed for possible downgrades by Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service.
The bad debts have led to a series of incidents that could be called bank runs, except that the depositors lining up are so orderly that they do not seem very alarming. The authorities are closing down credit associations and small lending institutions around the country, and the vaults at the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, are swinging open as they never have before to provide cash for banks that anticipate withdrawals from depositors.
For months now, the Japanese have been switching a tiny portion of their 1,000 trillion yen, or $7.7 trillion, in savings from wobbly banks to the nation's top institutions and the Government-run postal savings system. In December alone, Japanese flooded the postal savings institution with about 3.3 trillion yen, or $25 billion, about as much as the deposits at a major regional bank.
More important, the mountain of bad debts creates fears within the banking community that one of their number will fail, while holding money belonging to other institutions. So there is a fear that commercial banks would suddenly perceive one bank to be at risk and pull back their funds from it in the interbank market, the circulatory system for the financial world. The cutoff of funds could create a panic that would put healthy institutions at risk.
"Japanese banks are trendseekers, so if someone thinks one bank is dangerous, all the other banks pull the credit lines," said Naoko Nemoto, a financial analyst at Standard & Poor's.
Some worry that in a panic, money might be drained from even the big international Japanese banks, and those banks would then scramble for cover by pulling their lines from other institutions. The result could be a squeeze that would put strains on the banking system here and abroad even before Wall Street awakened.
The Bank of Japan has already begun to pour billions of dollars worth of yen into the markets, just to prevent a squeeze. Nonetheless, many banks have suddenly become aware of the fragility of their base of funding.
The Government has stated that no more major financial institutions will fail, and it is issuing a 30 trillion yen bank bailout and a 2 trillion yen tax cut. Financial analysts and bankers say that the system will hold but that a couple of the weakest banks may be shut down, merged or absorbed by other institutions, perhaps even in the next few months.
"It is not desirable that you just drive them into a rock," said Paul Heaton, a financial analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, about the weakest banks. "It is better that you drop off a few lifeboats along the way."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: MARKET PLACE;
The S.& P. 500 Breaks Through The 1,000 Mark

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The American stock market, resilient despite worries about Asia, soared past a milestone yesterday as the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose above 1,000 points for the first time.
The S.& P. 500's move to the millennium left the index more than twice as high as it was just three years ago, and served as a reminder that for the last year this index has been Wall Street's star performer, drastically outpacing the more widely followed Dow Jones industrial average. 
 The Dow also soared yesterday, rising 201.28 points, to 8,107.78, but it remains 1.8 percent below the high it set on Aug. 6, 1997. The S.& P. 500, which climbed 20.99 points, to 1,001.27, yesterday, is up 4.3 percent since Aug. 6.
That diversity of performance has both colored perceptions of the stock market and emphasized the way different types of stocks have reacted to the worries coming out of Asia.
"The Dow is the bellwether; you hear it on the radio," said Peter Canelo, an investment strategist with Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter. He contends that cash flows into stock mutual funds have been weaker than they were in early 1997 because of the perception that the stock market has not hit a high in almost six months.
The severe underperformance of the Dow began around the time that Asian worries started to emerge, a fact that is not coincidental. "The S.& P. gives a greater weight to defensive stock groups, such as drugs and foods and beverages," that would be hurt less if the economy weakened, noted Richard McCabe, the chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch. "The Dow is not weighted as heavily in the industries that have done the best."
Those groups have included stocks that would seem to have the least to fear from a falloff in Asian purchases and an increase in cheap Asian exports. Drug, telephone, media and entertainment stocks have all done well, while steel, oil and aluminum companies have been among the laggards.
From Aug. 6, the day the Dow peaked, through yesterday, only one-third of the 30 Dow stocks had risen, while two-thirds had declined. The strongest performers have been AT&T and Walt Disney, neither of which is in any danger of competition from cheap Asian imports or particularly vulnerable to the threat of a weak economy. The worst performer in the Dow -- Sears, Roebuck -- has its own performance problems that do not relate to Asia. But the others that are down at least 15 percent -- Union Carbide, International Paper and Boeing -- are either highly sensitive to the economy or in danger of losing sales to Asian customers.
By contrast, according to Bloomberg Financial Markets, 55 percent of the stocks in the S.& P. 500 have risen over the period. That index has a lower proportion of stocks that have alarmed investors for one reason or another in recent months.
The sharp variance in performance also highlights the fact that no index by itself can provide an accurate measure of the entire market. In fact, the S.& P. is the standout performer in the last year, compared with almost any other index. The Russell 2000, an index of smaller stocks, peaked in October and is still 6.6 percent below that peak.
In the nine months through the end of January -- a period that began just before the first hint of Asian problems emerged, with Thailand declaring war on currency speculators who it said were trying to drive down the value of the baht -- the S.& P. 500 rose 22.3 percent, while the Dow industrials gained 12.8 percent. The S.& P.'s outperformance, by 9.5 percentage points, is the greatest over any similar period since 1980.
Mr. Canelo argues that the Dow's period of underperformance may have ended -- it advanced 2.55 percent yesterday, compared with 2.14 percent for the S.& P -- because there is more optimism about an Asian recovery. He noted that the period of strong S.& P. outperformance coincided with a fall in the prices of industrial materials, a measure of worldwide industrial activity. Those prices now seem to be stabilizing and, in some cases, beginning to move up.
When the S.& P. rose above 1,000 yesterday, the move also emphasized just how rapid the rise has been in recent years. The index has doubled from the 500 level in less than 35 months. It took nearly nine years to go from 250 to 500. And the move from 62.50 to 125 required almost two decades, from Feb. 23, 1961, to Aug. 14, 1980.
In 1980, the S.& P. was hitting records while the Dow remained below the peak it had reached in 1973. That situation, however, was in some ways the exact opposite of the current one. That came as oil prices were soaring, amid worries of rampant inflation. At that time, the energy component of the S.& P. 500 was relatively high, and that helped drive the index to a record level. Now, energy stocks make up about 8.4 percent of the S.& P. 500, a little less than the 9.6 percent weighting of the three companies in the Dow that have major oil interests: Chevron, Exxon and DuPont.

HEADLINE: Purchasing Index Is Off on Export Data

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
A closely watched gauge of manufacturing activity unexpectedly cooled in January as export orders slumped for the first time in two years.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index declined to 52.4 last month from 53.1 in December, the group reported today. Analysts had expected a January reading of 53.3. 
 Separately, Commerce Department figures showed that growth in personal income and in consumer spending both slowed in December, winding up a strong year on a subdued note.
The broad economy remains resilient, though, analysts said, as the expansion moves into an eighth year. While the purchasing managers' index slid from the December level, a reading above 50 still represents growth. And the group's new-orders index increased in January, while the level of inventories remained little changed from December.
Taken as a whole, the figures suggest "there's not yet any reason to expect a significant weakening in manufacturing," said Christopher Low, an economist at HSBC Securities in New York.
The Commerce Department said that incomes rose by four-tenths of a percent in December after climbing by a revised seven-tenths of a percent during November. Spending rose by three-tenths of a percent in December after increasing an unrevised four-tenths of a percent in November. Analysts expected a three-tenths of a percent rise in personal income in December and a five-tenths of a percent gain in spending.
For all of last year, though, incomes rose 5.8 percent, topping the 5.6 percent increase of 1996. Spending in 1997 rose 5.4 percent, the strongest showing since 1994, after increasing 5 percent a year earlier.
The report also showed that disposable income, the money left over after taxes, increased five-tenths of a percent in December after rising seven-tenths of a percent during November. And the savings rate rose to 4.1 percent during the month from 3.9 percent in November.
In another report, however, the Commerce Department said spending on new construction rose at a slower-than-expected pace in December, as declines in public construction offset strength in private and residential building.
Construction spending rose a tenth of a percent, to a $611.8 billion annual rate. Analysts expected a gain of eight-tenths of a percent gain. That followed a revised decline of a tenth of a percent in November, previously reported as a decline of nine-tenths of a percent. For all of 1997, construction spending rose 5.6 percent, after rising 6.5 percent in 1996.

HEADLINE: District of Columbia Expects Surplus of at Least $100 Million

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
For all its potholes, real and metaphorical, the District of Columbia has received solid proof that the financial and management changes of the last few years are finally turning the city around.
Anthony A. Williams, the city's chief financial officer, said today that he expected an audit for the 1997 fiscal year to show a budget surplus of $100 million to $150 million. It was predicted that the District would finish the year with a $74 million budget deficit. 
 "Our three problems were financial, fiscal and economic, and we have made substantial progress on the financial and fiscal," Mr. Williams said in an interview. "We still have a lot to do to get our management together to address the problems of the local economy."
The District has been reeling from high crime rates, crumbling schools, poor delivery of services and an exodus of residents to surrounding counties in Maryland and Virginia that has depleted the city's tax base.
For those reasons and more, Congress created a financial control board, a panel of five officials appointed by President Clinton that began work in the spring of 1995 and is required by law to remain in place until the city has balanced its budget for four consecutive years.
Mr. Williams said the surplus, the city's first since 1993, was largely the result of tighter spending policies by municipal agencies, a better performance than expected by city tax collectors and a strong national economy that raised the projected levels of income and sales taxes.
Some city residents have recommended using the surplus to finance spending programs or cut taxes, but Mr. Williams said the money would most likely be used to help offset the city's cash deficit of $500 million. That, in turn, could save the District money by not requiring officials to restructure the city's long-term debt.
The surplus could also affect this year's mayoral race, largely as an inducement to Marion S. Barry Jr. to run again. Now completing his fourth term, the Democratic Mayor has remained undecided about whether to seek re-election.
Three members of the City Council -- Harold Brazil, Kevin P. Chavous and Jack Evans -- are expected to seek the Democratic nomination in September. But strong evidence that control of the city could be returned to the Mayor from the control board a year ahead of schedule could draw Mr. Barry into the race.
One Democrat who will not be in the race is Mr. Williams, who said last week he was considering running. Today, citing personal and professional considerations, he announced that he would not run.
"I've spent a lot of time and effort building this office with top personnel," he said. "But it's still very fragile. The last thing I would want is a long, protracted argument between the Mayor and the control board over my successor."

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
A Warning About Chaos From Asia

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's budget for foreign affairs is built on the assumption that prominent members of Congress will overcome their distaste for the United Nations and for American involvement in the bailout of faltering Asian economies.
The budget released today calls for an additional $18 billion in appropriations for the International Monetary Fund, which is overseeing the bailouts in South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand. 
 The budget report warned that without the extra money for the I.M.F., the chaos in Asia could spread to the United States.
"The U.S. economy is not immune," the report said. "These funds are urgently needed in case the emergency demand on I.M.F. resources depletes the I.M.F.'s liquidity so much that it cannot maintain international monetary stability."
But the request will face a tough fight in Congress, where many lawmakers oppose any increased American role in the Asian bailouts. The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said last weekend that he would oppose any request to raise American appropriations for the I.M.F.
There may be an equally bruising struggle over the Administration's request for $1 billion to begin repaying the nearly $1.5 billion that the United States owes to the United Nations in back dues. Mr. Helms and other prominent lawmakers have refused to free up the money without significant budgetary and administrative changes at the United Nations.
Legislation that would have allowed the Administration to pay some of the arrears stalled last year in Congress, "undermining U.S. diplomatic efforts to achieve budgetary reforms and leading to a serious loss of U.S. credibility in the U.N.," the budget report said.
The Administration called for the overall State Department budget to hold steady at about $5.3 billion, but proposed increases in several programs like financing for the Peace Corps, up 20 percent to $270 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Warning by Chip Maker Causes Its Stock to Tumble
National Semiconductor shares fell more than 16 percent after the maker of computer chips said results for the current quarter might fall below analysts' projections. 
 The warning reflected weakness in Asian markets and difficulties at Cyrix, a chip maker that National Semiconductor purchased last year. Page D2.
 
Rate of Growth May Be Slowing
The nation's manufacturing expansion pace unexpectedly eased in January, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in a widely followed monthly survey. In other signs of a possible slowdown, the Commerce Department said personal income, personal spending and construction spending grew at a slower rate in December. D2.
 
Bond prices fell sharply on a broad rally in stocks. But losses among shorter-term maturities were limited by the weaker-than-expected manufacturing report. D9.
 
Balanced U.S. Budget Proposed
President Clinton proposed the first balanced Federal budget in almost 30 years, cashing in on five years of cautious accounting and steady economic growth.. A1.
 
An additional $18 billion in appropriations has been proposed for the I.M.F., which is overseeing the bailouts of several Asian economies. A17.
 
The plan would use tax incentives for business to expand pensions and retirement plans, child care, energy-efficiency and corporate-sponsored education for workers. A18.
 
Drug Stocks Surge on Merger Talk
The merger discussions between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, announced late Friday, led to a voracious demand for stocks of other big drug makers on the possibility of more such deals. D2.
 
Possible Change in I.M.F. Position
The I.M.F. may be moving toward endorsing rules that would prevent another surge in foreign bank lending. Such a surge played a key role in the Asian financial crisis. D4.

G.M. and Daewoo Ponder Ties
General Motors and Daewoo of South Korea said they had signed a memorandum of understanding to consider a range of business ties, including a possible G.M. stake in Daewoo. D4.
 
Reuters Inquiry Deepens
Federal prosecutors are said to be investigating the relationship between an American subsidiary of Reuters and Cyberspace Research Associates, a New York company they believe was commissioned to steal information from Bloomberg. D6.
 
New Chief At Nabisco Unit
Nabisco replaced the head of its cookie and cracker division, which includes the Oreo brand as well as Ritz and Snackwell's, in what Wall Street took as a significant move to freshen a sluggish business. D6.

Fewer Stores to Sell Apple PC's
Hurt by slow sales, Apple said it was withdrawing its personal computers from several major store chains to focus on promoting sales through CompUSA. D6.
 
Bigger Iraqi Quota Proposed
U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan asked the Security Council to more than double the amount of oil Iraq can sell. A8.

HEADLINE: From a Friend Indeed, Clinton Awaits a Visit

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The trip was planned months ago, but it is hard to think of a world leader whom President Clinton would be luckier to have as his White House guest this week than Tony Blair.
He arrives in Washington on Wednesday for a timely four-day visit that is expected to put on further display the remarkable camaraderie between the popular 44-year-old New Labor Prime Minister and his embattled 51-year-old New Democrat counterpart. The visit also brings to the President's side the leader of the only nation to pledge military assistance in Iraq at a moment when a strike on Saddam Hussein appears increasingly imminent. 
 "I freely confess to you that I happen to have a high regard for Bill Clinton," Prime Minister Blair said today in a shirt-sleeves interview in his private office. "I am delighted to call Bill Clinton a friend, and I believe what's more important than anything else is that he does a good job as a President, and for that he deserves all our support, so it's as simple as that really."
Mr. Blair said he suspected that the sudden growth of support for the President during the last week came from voters' impatience with "arrogant politicians and arrogant media" who, he said, like to "try to reverse the outcome of elections." He fully expected to encounter a President "focusing on the big picture," he said, and not "sidetracked by all that stuff which may be interesting to some parts of the media." He added, "Politics shouldn't be run at the level of a gossip column."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair have frequently been compared because of the commonalities of their youthfulness, their appetites for policy discussions, their moving their parties more to the political center and their emphasis on government's shaping social policies in an era of global economic pressures and public distaste for taxes and spending.
In the area where the President is presently most vulnerable, the conduct of his personal and family life, Mr. Blair is unassailable, and British commentators in recent days have been speculating on how the Prime Minister might turn this to his advantage during the coming visit. The notion clearly makes Mr. Blair uncomfortable.
"I do not presume in any way to interfere with the American political process," he said. "I've made clear my support for the President, and let me say at once I've never pretended to be any better or different than anyone else."
Mr. Blair looks very much at home after nine months in 10 Downing Street, working with jacket off in a side room off the main entrance corridor. Putting his jacket on, he greets guests or Government ministers in the cream-colored Cabinet room next door, with its two fluted white columns at one end and three brass chandeliers spaced along the ceiling.
Busts of Benjamin Disraeli and William Pitt stare out from either side of the entrance as a reminder of what British prime ministers used to look like before the present informal incumbent. A portrait of a Labor Prime Minister, Clement Attlee, has been hung in the space that during John Major's term bore the likeness of a Conservative, Stanley Baldwin, and during Margaret Thatcher's years bore a picture of Churchill.
It is only five years since Mr. Blair -- then the shadow home affairs minister from a party that had lost four straight general elections -- went to Washington and watched the Democrats prepare for the first inauguration of their invigorating new leader, Bill Clinton. The two men didn't even meet then.
Mr. Blair returned to Britain and a year later became the leader of Labor with an aggressive agenda: to shed its socialist past and turn it into a center-left group willing to lend an ear to business and dedicated to capturing the middle class, which had seen the Conservatives as the only party that encouraged opportunity.
That transformation swept Mr. Blair and his party into office last May 1 with a majority of 179 in Parliament. He set out on an ambitious and activist program of social change and an attempt to settle the bloody conflict in Northern Ireland that have given him the highest job approval ratings of any British prime minister in history.
Mr. Clinton added London to his itinerary on a visit to Europe last June, and he and Mr. Blair emerged from 10 Downing Street to give a news conference in the Rose Garden that was much commented on for its quality of mutual admiration.
Two months ago, Hillary Rodham Clinton came to Northern Ireland and England with several Administration officials and spent a weekend at Chequers, the official retreat. Along with Mr. Blair and his wife, Cherie, who is a noted lawyer and part-time judge, a group of Cabinet members gathered for an extended discussion of common social policy challenges like juvenile crime, welfare to work, school class sizes, child care and public health.
Emblematic of this unusually close association, a similar session has been scheduled for the Presidential retreat at Camp David on Saturday, and Mr. Blair has chosen as his Government companions for the trip Cabinet members from the social policy field. He is to be feted at a dinner Wednesday night; have a working meeting at the White House and a visit to Congress on Thursday; breakfast at the State Department and give a news conference with the President on Friday, and possibly participate Saturday in the President's weekly radio address.
On Iraq Mr. Blair reiterated the British commitment, saying, "We will obviously want to give support in any way that is possible and feasible for us because we believe very, very clearly that at the end of the gulf war certain conditions were laid down for the way that Saddam Hussein conducted himself and those conditions have to be met, and if they are not met there will be far greater trouble in the world to come."
He praised Mr. Clinton's backing for British and Irish efforts to achieve a settlement in Northern Ireland, saying the President had been "absolutely as solid as a rock on it all the way through." In answer to a question about an accusation from a former United States Ambassador, Raymond G. H. Seitz, that the British suspected the White House of leaking security information to the Irish Republican Army in the early years of the Clinton Administration, he said, "I can't speak for the past because I am not in a position to do so, but as far as I am concerned, there are no problems on that score at all."
He said he saw Britain as a "bridge between the U.S. and Europe" and resisted the notion that Britain's perceived closeness to America prejudiced its relations with Europe. "It is not just Britain who stands as an American friend," he said, adding, "Europeans I can tell you, the ones that I talk to, are fully 100 percent behind a strong relationship with the U.S."
On Bosnia he said: "I would say to the American people that it is actually important that you are in Bosnia. It may seem distant and far away, but if we had let the possibility pass of getting involved there and we had let that civil war explode and spread, we would have had a real problem on our hands for the whole of Europe."

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: BUSINESS;
Companies Would Be Given Rewards for Retirement and Education Plans

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Businesses could receive tax incentives for expanding workers' pension, retirement and education plans under the budget President Clinton unveiled yesterday. The budget also would give tax breaks to employees who lose their jobs.
On the other hand, it would end several devices that moderately wealthy Americans use to avoid paying estate taxes and would impose 39 tax increases on businesses. 
 To help workers save, the Administration proposed letting them use payroll deductions to contribute to Individual Retirement Accounts. To encourage businesses to allow those deductions, and to get more businesses to adopt 401(k) and similar plans, the Administration proposed new tax credits of up to $2,000 per company over three years, aimed primarily at small businesses.
Only about one-fourth of American workers have 401(k) or similar retirement plans, according to the Employee Benefits Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington.
These proposals are likely to find favor with Republicans, who have championed expanding retirement savings plans.
The Administration proposed to extend a variety of business tax breaks, including a welfare-to-work credit, educational grants to employees and a research and experimentation credit. It would also make permanent a provision of the 1997 Taxpayer Relief Act that allows companies to treat the costs of cleaning up toxic waste sites as expenses that can be immediately deducted, instead of capital investments that must be amortized over many years.
The Administration also proposed a variety of tax credits for businesses that invest in energy-efficient equipment and roof-top solar collectors. Buyers of very highly fuel efficient vehicles could receive $4,000 per vehicle in tax credits in 2002. Those buyers are likely to be corporations.
For workers who lose their jobs, the Administration would eliminate taxes on the the first $2,000 of severance pay. It is unclear whether this would be a boon to workers or simply encourage companies to reduce the size of severance packages.
The Administration also proposed extending the current law allowing up to $5,250 a year in educational aid to be taken as a deductible expense by employers, but not be counted as income for workers.
The Administration wants to expand a tax break for investors in about 80 companies licensed under the Black Capitalism program begun 29 years ago by the Nixon Administration. Investors who buy shares of Specialized Small Business Investment Companies would be allowed to roll over $2 million in capital gains, deferring taxes so long as they held shares of the specialized companies. The current limit is $50,000 per year, a figure that critics say is too small to create a significant capital market for minority and immigrant entrepreneurs. Only one of these companies, Freshstart Venture Capital Corporation of New York City, has publicly traded shares.
The plans to increase 39 business taxes drew prompt criticism from Bruce Josten, executive vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "These are not the kinds of proposals that the greater business community is going to like because there are about $23 billion in new tax proposals that affect different slices and slivers of the business community," he said.
Mr. Josten, noting that President Clinton cited expanding exports as a major factor in the strength of the economy, also objected to a change in a tax on manufacturers that he said, "dings our exporters with $6.5 billion in new taxes and does so in a very convoluted way."
The estate tax proposals were completely unexpected, said Evelyn Capassakis, director of estate planning for the Coopers & Lybrand accounting firm. "It looks like they are taking the offensive against the Republicans, who want to repeal the estate tax," Ms. Capassakis said.
"The Administration is saying not only do we not want to repeal the estate tax, we want to tighten it up," she said.
One Administration proposal would require portfolios of stocks and bonds to be valued at market price, ending the growing practice of claiming discounts on publicly traded securities.
Few of the tax proposals are likely to get past Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, who said the budget was "a disappointment" and reiterated his pledge to continue closing loopholes, but to kill any tax increase.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 718 words

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Asian Blues

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: ZURICH, Oct. 29, 1998

 BODY:
World stock markets crashed to record lows today, setting off what economists are calling "the Millennium Depression." The meltdown was triggered by the collapse of the Brazilian, Argentine, Russian, Indonesian, Mexican and Czech stock markets. These peripheral markets were dragged down after another devaluation by China made Chinese products so cheap that everyone else in Asia had to devalue again, and other emerging markets could no longer compete. In Tokyo, the entire senior staff of the Ministry of Finance were arrested and charged with incompetence. Their failure to stimulate growth, so Japan could absorb more of Asia's exports, resulted in all these goods flooding the U.S. instead, creating a record U.S. trade deficit and prompting Congress to pass the Smoot-Hawley-Gephardt Protectionist Act. With the Dow average having lost 6,000 points in two weeks, President Clinton sought to boost his poll ratings with the U.S. public by again seeing Monica Lewinsky.
Far-fetched, I know, particularly when Asian markets seem to be bouncing back. But be careful. In the next few months China, Japan and the U.S., the three main engines of the global economy, will still need to take some extremely tough decisions. How well they do will determine whether the Asian flu is really over or becomes a ragin' contagion. 
 Let's start with China -- a key factor in unintentionally triggering the Asian meltdown. China devalued its currency in 1993 and 1994. As a result, countries like Thailand, Korea and Indonesia, whose currencies were pegged around the rising dollar, became much less competitive. Any of their companies whose cost structure got out of line with that of China got hammered, making it hard for them to repay loans. Since the crash of the Asian currencies, the Thais, Koreans and Indonesians are again much more competitive with China. They are all hoping to export their way out of this crisis the way Mexico did three years ago.
Memo to China: Your economy is slowing, the Shanghai real estate market is slumping, and overseas Chinese are not pouring money in as before. But don't devalue. Instead, cut your interest rates and speed up plans for major infrastructure projects. It will keep your economy growing, maybe with a bit of inflation, but it's better than undercutting your neighbors' chances for recovery.
As for Japan, it's the world's second-largest economy, but it is currently being run by Herbert Hoover Hashimoto. Japan has huge reserves it could use to absorb imports from the Asian tigers, all of which are on export-or-die strategies. But Japan's brain-dead leadership has failed to stimulate the Japanese economy. The Japanese people are home alone.
Memo to Japan: Cut taxes deeply, enough to really put some money in the pockets of your consumers. Get your Parliament to pass the proposed $225 billion package to clean up and restructure your banking system, which is like a walking skeleton spooking everyone in Asia, and open your markets more to Asian exports -- now, not in 2005.
As for the U.S., the President needs to use his soaring job approval rating to persuade Congress to make its promised $17.9 billion deposit to the I.M.F. and to revive the fast-track free-trade legislation. This is no time for America to turn inward. Congress is right to be wary of I.M.F. bailouts, but both J. P. Morgan and Deutsche Bank have just announced huge losses on their Asian loans, so the banks are taking a hit. Alan Greenspan could help by cutting interest rates half a percent in this deflationary time to signal that what the world needs now is growth, sweet growth.
In the late 1920's it was competitive devaluations among the commodities producers of that early industrial era, and the protectionist responses to them, that made the Great Depression great. Today we are seeing the start of a similar cycle, leading already to a deterioration in the competitive situation of Latin America and Eastern Europe.
"If the U.S., Japan and China do the right thing now, this Asian deflation can be contained, Latin America and Eastern Europe won't be dragged into it and we can have lower global interest rates and higher growth," argues Ken Courtis, an Asian economist for Deutsche Bank. "But if they do the wrong thing, there could be real trouble."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

PUB-DATE: February 3, 1998

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 997 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asian Markets Rebound, Some Up 10% or More

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, Feb. 3

 BODY:
A streak of good economic news and sustained market rallies have raised hopes that the Asian financial crisis, if still a long way from the end, may have at least reached the end of its panic-stricken beginnings.
Improved trade statistics, relatively mild inflation and market-opening changes have contributed to a sharp rise in stock and currency values, the most notable rebound since intense selling began last fall. 
 The economies of the worst-affected countries -- Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia -- are still at least half a year from hitting bottom, many economists say. Bankruptcies and unemployment will likely surge in coming months. But there are signs that market sentiment, which frequently runs well ahead of the broad economy, has stabilized.
Stock markets in Hong Kong, Jakarta and Singapore all rose by roughly 14 percent on Monday, the first trading day after the Lunar New Year and the holiday ending the Islamic fast of Ramadan. Thailand gained 12 percent and the Philippines, 10 percent. Stocks in Tokyo were up modestly, gaining just under 1 percent.
The buying extended into this morning, most notably in Malaysia, where stocks rose 22 percent -- nearly as much as the Dow Jones industrial average gained for all of last year. South Korean stocks, which defied the trend on Monday by falling more than 4 percent, were down one-fifth of 1 percent today at midsession. And in Japan, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 243.86 points, or 1.45 percent, to 17,020.68 early this afternoon.
"You don't have to be a hero to put your cash to work in Asia now," said Bernhard Eschweiler, vice president of J. P. Morgan in Singapore. "For the first time in seven months, there's some promise."
The markets were bolstered by strength in local currencies. Shares in many Asian companies trade at a fraction of their levels a year ago and are attractive to some foreign investors, provided local currencies remain reasonably steady against the United States dollar.
In currency dealing, the Thai baht led a regional advance on Monday, as traders reacted favorably to the Bangkok Government's lifting of exchange controls. The Malaysian ringgit, Singapore dollar and Philippine peso all rallied. The Indonesian rupiah, considered the most vulnerable currency because of the country's staggering foreign debt, rose more than 21 percent against the dollar after remaining steady all last week.
The broad advance in Asian markets contributed to a global rally that pushed stocks to record highs in Frankfurt and London and helped the Dow Jones industrial average gain 201.28 points, its first finish above 8,000 in nearly two months.
Asian markets have been rising in the last few days, led by South Korea and Thailand, two of the three countries under the care of the International Monetary Fund. The Thai baht, for example, has hovered at exchange rates between 50 and 55 to the dollar since early in January after shedding 50 percent of its value last year. The Stock Exchange Index of Thailand has advanced nearly 20 percent so far this year after spectacular declines in 1997. And those gains have taken place despite worsening troubles in Indonesia, leading some economists to talk of a decoupling of regional markets.
Some improved economic performances help explain the shift in market sentiment. The Philippines reported on Monday that its economy grew at a 5.8 percent rate last year, well above expectations. Inflation in Thailand and South Korea, seen as an inevitable consequence of currency devaluations, has proved more moderate than anticipated, at least initially.
Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand have all shown sharp reversals in their trade balances. Seoul on Monday reported its third consecutive monthly trade surplus, which reached $1.6 billion in January. After years of running enormous trade deficits, Thailand's surplus -- it exported $1 billion more than it imported in November -- is well above International Monetary Fund projections. Trade surpluses help build dollar reserves, adding to the stability of local currencies.
Still, sentiment could easily swing back to the negative. The good news on trade hides some bad news: The gains result more from falling imports than rising exports. Thai and Indonesian banks are making so few loans that even some established exporters cannot get the cash they need to produce goods. Uncertainty still shrouds most currencies, as companies are desperate to buy dollars to repay foreign debts.
Perhaps the biggest risks are in Indonesia, where talks over rescheduling $65 billion in short-term debt owed by private companies to foreign banks are far from complete. "Indonesia's strategic position is so great that any failure there will certainly start a new round of selling," said Nicholas Kwan, regional economist at Merrill Lynch in Hong Kong.
Markets generally welcomed measures announced last week to rehabilitate weak Indonesian banks and guarantee depositors and creditors of local banks. Indonesia is also taking steps to help domestic companies renegotiate their foreign debts.
But those debt negotiations are at an early stage, and some Western bankers say they are pessimistic that the talks will succeed any time soon. Unlike in South Korea -- which reached agreement last week with foreign banks to stretch repayment periods for much short-term debt of its conglomerates and banks, the Government in Indonesia has little formal control over some private businesses.
Political uncertainty and ethnic tension also keep Indonesia on edge. Hundreds of people violently protested against high prices in two cities there on Monday, news reports said. The police detained 30 demonstrators in Pasuruan, more than 400 miles east of Jakarta, after the protesters threatened to attack fuel sellers.
"With things so uncertain in Indonesia, it's hard to feel confident about the region generally," Mr. Kwan said. "Optimists could still easily get burned."
