PUB-DATE: February 3, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2436 words

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE REACTION;
Nation Through a Looking Glass, Smudges, Cracks, Distortions and All

BYLINE: By Carey Goldberg; The following article was reported by Carey Goldberg, Dirk Johnson and Sam Howe Verhovek and was written by Ms. Goldberg.

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Major national events often serve as mirrors in which the country sees itself reflected in surprising new ways.
But the remarkable recent surge of support for President Clinton following two weeks of lurid allegations and furious counter-charges has produced an especially startling and contradictory reflection -- one that has baffled many analysts and prompted ordinary voters to pause and ponder their own feelings. 
 Polls show that the American public 1) generally believes its President committed adultery in the White House and 2) approves of his job performance more strongly than ever. Asked to explain seemingly incompatible views, a priest in Chicago, a school board president in rural Wisconsin, a social worker in Houston, a comedy producer in New York, a former state attorney general in Maine and dozens of others in interviews around the country cited deep-seated changes in the country's mores and political culture.
Many Americans no longer expect their President to be a moral paragon, some said. In a good economy, low inflation far outranks accusations of low behavior, said others. Some pointed to more permissive views on morality and sexuality; others to heightened public alienation from politicians and the overheated media coverage.
Public opinion is notoriously fickle, of course, and the ultimate public assessment of President Clinton will depend on how the drama plays out.
But in many ways, the response to accusations that the President had an affair with a White House intern and asked her to lie about it has caused the nation to look in the mirror and observe changes that preceded and will long outlast the current scandal, much as the O. J. Simpson case provided a stark reflection of the nation's division on race.
"This is a moment when we can glimpse in the swirl of events a changing public mind," said Michael Sandel, a Harvard University professor of government who writes about American democracy.
"It is sad but true," summed up James E. Tierney, a former Attorney General of Maine, "that Americans do not look to their President for moral leadership."
Mr. Tierney, a Democrat, said, "After the immediate shock and revulsion, people thought about it and said, 'Well, he's not the moral leader of the country, and I never asked him to be. Then I look at the other things I care about and believe in, and clearly his policies are strong on those.' "
Americans, it emerges, tend to want a President more like a corporate chief executive officer, deft and unflappable, rather than an embodiment of all the country's lofty ideals.
"The morality issue, 30 years ago, would have been much greater," offered John J. Merian, 39, owner of a tuxedo store in Brockton, Mass. "So that's got to be a statement on our own society -- that we separate the personal from the office. We really don't care if he had this affair or that affair or the other affair, so long as he's doing a good job."
In recent years especially, Americans have heard more about real or alleged adulterous frolics by John F. Kennedy, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon B. Johnson to the point that Presidential historians say it is extremely hard to name a President with a pristine public image.
The knowledge that unfaithful husbands can be great Presidents contributes to reactions like that of Patricia Riley, 38, a freelance writer and divorced mother of two in Sunrise, Fla. "He's done so much for the country," she said of President Clinton, "more than anyone else in my lifetime. It's the first time I've never felt oppressed by the Government. I don't care who he sleeps with."
 
Distractions Like War Can Help or Hurt
Of course, scholars of public opinion say, there are always several factors in the equation of a President's overall approval rating, and how each is weighted depends on circumstances. George Bush enjoyed tremendous popularity during the Persian Gulf war because he was seen as an able military commander, but as soon as it was over, attention shifted to the economy, and his ratings plummeted.
In the case of President Clinton, a great many commentators and citizens borrowed the battle cry from his first Presidential campaign, "It's the economy, stupid."
Robert Creedon, a Massachusetts lawyer and state senator, said a cab driver reacting to the scandal the other day told him: "Look, we're the only superpower left on the earth. We've got money in our pockets. Who cares?"
Diane Swonk, an economist for the First National Bank of Chicago, said the most important element in the allegations is that they have not affected pocketbooks.
"The reality is that people have just refinanced their mortgages, gone out and bought big-screen TV's to watch the Super Bowl and can buy all the beer and pizza they want," she said. "If times aren't good, the President can do whatever he wants -- go out and win a war -- it's not going to be enough."
"And when times are good," she said, "nothing else matters."
Nothing else matters? Nothing?
 
Defining Morality, And Redefining It
Clearly, people draw a line about what they will accept. But where they are drawing it in this case is a source of concern for those who see an erosion of American moral standards.
The Rev. Anthony Brancken, a Roman Catholic priest on the southwest side of Chicago, said he was already worried by the loss of guilt and shame in American culture, the loss of clear distinctions between right and wrong, the drift toward "moral relativism" even in the Catholic church, where a school of thought known as proportionalism holds that there are few "illicit or immoral acts in themselves," and much depends on the circumstances.
It is a view, he said, that tends to mitigate sinful behavior.
And now, Father Brancken asked, "Have we as a nation become so corrupted that, as long as we get what we want, as long as times are good and the money rolls in, that we don't care what the hell goes on?"
Steven Klein, an independent anthropologist based near San Diego who studies American culture, sees the Clinton scandal as not only reflecting the trend away from strict morality, but accelerating it.
"We're really relinquishing the fundamental Judeo-Christian values and reverting more to the legal understanding that so long as you don't violate any laws or hurt anybody, it's O.K.," he said. "Although what's extraordinary to me in this case is that people are even ignoring that, and saying, 'Who cares if he committed perjury?"
'It's become a question," Dr. Klein added, "of how far down the public is willing to ratchet their standard of acceptability -- is there a floor? -- to be able to perpetuate the economic status quo they're enjoying, and Clinton's putting them into a squeeze play."
Part of the public's unwillingness to condemn, it seems, comes from the shifting-sand nature of attitudes toward sexuality. Several voters said they did not condone adultery, but they also used terms like "bad boy" and "rogue" to describe the President -- disapproving but tolerant terms. And polls have indicated that among young people and immigrants there is genuine bafflement by the fuss.
"We wouldn't have governments in Latin America if our standard was that there should be no extramarital affairs for politicians," said Maria Jimenez, director of an American Friends Service Committee project that provides services to immigrants in Houston.
In Chicago, Scott Helman, 22, recalled that when he was in high school near Columbus, Ohio, students were taught to chant the ways that H.I.V. could be transmitted: "Blood, semen, vaginal secretions, breast milk; blood, semen, vaginal secretions, breast milk . . . "
"I can't fathom that anyone my age would be embarrassed by any of this," Mr. Helman said.
Several people interviewed also noted that questions about Mr. Clinton's sex life had been raised well before he was elected, and so accusations of adultery changed little.
"I think when we elected him, we knew we were electing a philanderer," said Nathan Kelly, a student at DePaul University in Chicago.
If one aspect of the past week brought the greatest expression of concern, it was the indications of a truly daunting level of national cynicism about the people who run the country.
In Norman, Okla., David L. Boren, the former United States Senator who is now president of the University of Oklahoma, said that when he asked his freshman American Government class about the scandal, almost all the students said they believed President Clinton was lying, and they tended to respond:
" 'All politicians are crooks, very few of them tell the truth, few of them are faithful to their spouses, so why not have one who's smart and knows how to get things done?' " he said. "That's almost an exact quote. The attitude is, we really don't respect him, but what do you expect from a politician?
"To me it's deeply disturbing," he went on, recalling the awe he felt when he saw his first President, Harry S. Truman.
"In times of crisis, times of hardship," Mr. Boren said, "a level of trust between the American people and their Government, particularly their leader, is an essential element of what's needed in the country. We have passed from anger about what's going on in our political system to cynicism and alienation. And to me, cynicism and alienation are more frightening than anger."
That cynicism, however, appears to be working in Mr. Clinton's favor.
"Most people feel like we haven't got anybody that's any better to replace him," said Rick Aurit, 47, the school board president in Dodgeville, Wis. "So people are anxious to have this be over. They just want to say, 'All right, he did whatever he did. Now let's move on and get going with life.' "
Also at play, several people said, is the powerful American respect for privacy. Sex lives are nobody else's business; phone conversations between friends should not be taped; zealous prosecutors are frightening; private tidbits about celebrities' lives -- including those of Presidents -- are delectable and despicable all at once.
 
Keep Out of Our Bedrooms, Please
"I do think some of the carte blanche authority the independent counsel has runs against the grain a bit in this country," said Sidney Milkis, chairman of the politics department at Brandeis University. "In a country so obsessed with rights and protection and government encroachment and privacy, some of this independent counsel's activities turn people off a little bit."
A married woman in rural Illinois, who declined to be named, put it this simply: "I don't want people asking questions about the President's sex life because I don't want anyone asking about mine."
Genia Vookles, 60, a Memphis caterer and mother of three grown children, said: "It's between Bill and Hillary and not me and not the media, and if she can accept it why can't we? Some of these people throwing stones don't have real good track records in their own lives, either. I'm really sick of all the scandal."
She is not the only one. Polls have shown that a strong majority of Americans think the scandal has been covered too heavily -- or at least, that is what they say -- and many found much of the coverage irresponsible as well.
"I think this scandal has just been blown up by the media," said Lisa Lewicki, a student at DePaul. "They only focus on candidates' personal lives now, not how they do the job. This case with Clinton is the extreme of that. In a perfect world, we would elect people on their ideas, not their personal lives."
In view of such skepticism toward the media, and the universally acknowledged dearth of publicly accessible proof of any wrongdoing by the President, a great many people say they are withholding judgment about the scandal until they have the facts.
For those who do not want to believe ill of the President, then, there is no reason to force themselves.
"People have a really strong sense of fairness, that the case hasn't been made," said George C. Edwards 3d, director of the Center for Presidential Studies at Texas A & M University.
Clearly, some of the response reflects the remarkable ability of Mr. Clinton to bounce back from adversity. "If Bill Clinton was the Titanic, the iceberg would have sunk," said Paul Green, who writes books on Chicago politics.
Pollsters also note that the President's high ratings may be owing partly to the usual "bounce" that comes after any major event, like a party convention; this time, it was his State of the Union address that did it. They also point to a certain "rally round the flag" effect: a common spike in support for the President during a crisis -- even if he is the cause of it.
Analysts add that President Clinton is seen by many as an embattled underdog these days, and that is also likely to add to his support.
On a hopeful note, for those who had warned that the instantaneous nature of news these days would distort public opinion, there is some good news in the American slowness to judge the President, some say.
"Who's insisting on the core values of journalism?" asked Jeffrey Abramson, a visiting professor at Harvard and an expert on the new media and politics. "That you don't rush to judgment, that you investigate, that you differentiate between allegations and facts, that you wait for more facts, that you want corroboration, that you say we don't know yet? It's more the person on the street or call-in radio, where you expect hothouse tempers. There are hothouse tempers around but we're all surprised that this so far hasn't been the kind of hothouse issue with the public that it was supposed to be," he said.
"We keep hearing that the space it takes to form public opinion will collapse under the pressure of the new media," he said. "It's not happening."
But instead of hothouse, the atmosphere surrounding the scandal might be described as funhouse, with the country awash in lewd jokes, aided by the presidential material that has become the mainstay of late-night television shows. The bawdy show is illustrative in itself. Jay Leno, host of "The Tonight Show," said he now tells jokes he could not possibly have told on the air just 10 years ago.
But both Mr. Leno and a producer for David Letterman suggested today that their humor may even have helped boost the President's ratings.
"This makes him look like a party animal," said Rob Burnett, executive producer of "The Late Show With David Letterman."
"In some ways," Mr. Leno said, "this makes the President look like one of the people. Even if you argue all the proposals are crummy, at least with the Democrats you get sex."

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE OUTLOOK;
Money Is Hypothetical, But Agenda Is Very Real

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Eliminating the Federal budget deficit might help win President Clinton a place in tomorrow's history books, but his new tax and spending proposals just as clearly take aim at today's politics, offering a dissonant mix of conditional generosity and virtuous austerity.
Mr. Clinton has never been content to manage a Government of declining resources and influence, and he has more reasons than ever to want to be seen as active and engaged. So he took a budget that should show a modest surplus next year, thanks to a booming economy and the budget agreement he hammered out last year with the Republican-led Congress, and through a bit of legerdemain tacked on an expansive, shrewd set of spending proposals. 
 "We've done more than simply balance the budget, more than just line up numbers on a ledger," Mr. Clinton said today at a White House ceremony. "We have restored the balance of values in our policy, restored the balance of confidence between government and the public."
Mr. Clinton is sticking within the overall restrictions of last year's stringent budget agreement, and he has sought to burnish an image of fiscal prudence by insisting that any surpluses be put aside until the Federal Government solves the long-term problems of Social Security.
But to pay for new and expanded programs, including more teachers, classrooms, child care and medical research, Mr. Clinton has created two hypothetical pots of money, without which the budget would look a lot less generous.
The first is $65.5 billion that the White House assumes the Federal Government will reap over the next five years from a settlement with the tobacco industry -- a settlement that faces immense hurdles in Congress.
The other is $24 billion in measures to raise revenues over the next five years by closing tax loopholes and taking away tax breaks from powerful interest groups. Half of the tax proposals have been rejected by Congress in the past, and much of the other half will also generate intense opposition.
If those two pools of money -- plus another generated by cuts in a variety of programs, including veterans' benefits -- fail to materialize, the Administration will find it difficult, if not impossible, to pay for its new programs. And in the meantime, the White House budget is being criticized by the Republican leadership as a fantasy, if not a deception.
"I am having a great deal of difficulty understanding how the President of the United States can in a straight face tell the American people we're living up to last year's agreement, we're going to be in balance and have a surplus, but don't worry about a thing, we can spend $150 billion on new programs and tax credits and everything is going to be all right," said Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
Mr. Clinton is hardly the first President to use the budget to set out a political agenda, and it is hardly surprising that he would push his partisan program as hard as possible in a year when Democrats plan to mount an aggressive attack on the Republican majority in the midterm Congressional elections.
"Anyone who thinks the budget process is about accounting or numerology should know that it's not," said Martha Phillips, the executive director of the Concord Coalition, a non-partisan fiscal watchdog group.
"It's political," Ms. Phillips said. "It's about developing your vision for the next 5 or 10 years, and working backwards from there to make the numbers add up."
In his budget, she said, Mr. Clinton "is being a Democratic President leading his party."
Indeed, Mr. Clinton's budget encompasses an ideological view of Government very different from that of most Republicans. Democrats hail the economic benefits from eliminating the deficit -- lower interest rates and more economic growth -- but also focus on the increased flexibility that balanced budgets provide in addressing problems through new tax and spending programs.
Most Republicans, by contrast, see both economic benefits and an opportunity to reduce the size and influence of the Federal Government.
"Republicans are asking Americans to make a false choice between big government and less government," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader. "Democrats believe the choice is between smart government and idle government."
In spite of his troubles, from accusations about his relationship with a former White House intern to criticism that he was allowing his Administration to drift, Mr. Clinton has had considerable success in setting this year's political agenda.
If the tobacco settlement comes together, Mr. Clinton would have a good shot at enacting at least some of his spending proposals, few of which Republicans would want to be on record as voting against. Even without the settlement, Mr. Clinton will have given Democrats a positive agenda to take on the campaign trail. And by invoking the need to fix Social Security before parceling out surpluses, he has complicated the task of Republicans in advancing the centerpiece of their agenda, tax cutting.
The entire debate would become moot if the remarkably positive outlook for the economy and the Federal budget that is now shared by both parties proves to be a mirage. Neither the White House nor the Congressional Budget Office is counting on unrealistically high levels of economic growth or tax revenues to wipe out the deficit. Both have factored in a moderate impact from the financial turmoil in Asia. But neither is anticipating any major economic downturn. And even a moderate recession could leave the budget projections unrealistic, as could a substantial drop in the stock market.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
President Offers the First Budget To Balance in Nearly 30 Years

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton unveiled the first balanced Federal budget in almost 30 years today, cashing in on five years of cautious accounting and steady economic growth to offer new spending initiatives while holding out the prospect of a surplus for the first time since Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon.
With his opening bid in the annual political wrangle with Congress over the budget, Mr. Clinton proposed to increase Federal spending 4 percent, to $1.73 trillion, to hire 100,000 new teachers, provide more child care, bolster scientific research and offer narrowly distributed tax incentives. 
 In a ceremony in the East Room of the White House, Mr. Clinton tried to walk a line between hailing a new period of fiscal freedom and presenting himself as the squinty-eyed arbiter of budget discipline.
"This budget marks the end of an era," he said, "an end to decades of deficits that have shackled our economy, paralyzed our politics and held our people back."
Future budgets, Mr. Clinton predicted, would require no more cuts.
But, warning against a binge of Federal spending or tax cutting, Mr. Clinton also urged that any future budget surpluses be held in reserve until lawmakers shore up the Social Security system for the retirement of the baby boom generation.
"We don't need to take any short-term benefits," he said. "Before we do anything with that surplus, let's save Social Security first."
Particularly when Congress is controlled by the other party, any President's budget should be read less as a policy blueprint than as a series of bargaining positions, many of which will be abandoned or modified. Republicans were quick to stake out their own ground today, criticizing the President as returning to liberal, spendthrift ways.
"We can't go back to the days of skyrocketing Government spending," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. "But that's exactly what the President has proposed."
Republicans accused Mr. Clinton of calling for more spending than was permitted by the budget agreement of 1997, which envisioned a balanced budget by 2002.
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is the House Budget Committee chairman, said that the President had balanced the budget with "his old friend smoke and mirrors" and predicted that Congress would not pass most of Mr. Clinton's proposals.
But Mr. Clinton's political advisers believe that Republican lawmakers will find it difficult to ignore the President's proposals or to push the big tax cuts that they have long favored. Among some Republicans, proposals to hire teachers and expand financing for research are popular. In Democratic polling, aides said, the public overwhelmingly favored reserving surpluses to protect Social Security.
In a sign of how orderly the Federal balance sheet has become, the Treasury Department announced today that it expected to pay off approximately $80 billion worth of the Federal debt between April and June. It has made such payments before, but never one that large.
For Mr. Clinton's aides, the budget presented the President with another opportunity to portray himself as absorbed in governing, and to deflect accusations that he had an affair with an intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, and asked her to lie about it. Indeed, it showed him managing the very issue, the stewardship of the economy, that pollsters say has sustained his public support through numerous crises.
After using a thick felt tip pen to draw a large black zero and an exclamation point on a sign marked "1999 Federal Budget Deficit," Mr. Clinton strode from the East Room with the applause still ringing from Administration officials and Congressional Democrats, drowning out a reporter's shouted question about Ms. Lewinsky. The Federal budget was last balanced in 1969; the last proposed balanced plan was in 1971.
A year ago, with questions about campaign finance practices buzzing around the White House, Mr. Clinton also did not take questions when he announced his budget. But he made his announcement in a briefing room, with no buffering audience between him and reporters.
In his remarks today, Mr. Clinton praised the "values" of his approach to budgeting. "We've done more than simply balance the budget, more than just line up numbers on a ledger," he said. "We have restored the balance of the values in our policy, restored the balance of confidence between Government and the public."
In predicting budget surpluses for years to come, the Administration forecast continued moderate annual economic growth of 2 percent or more for the next five years. Economic growth has repeatedly exceeded the Administration's projections, surprising officials every year with more tax revenue than expected.
In keeping with their past budget practices, Administration officials said today that they had found a specific "offset" -- a spending cut or tax increase -- to pay for each new or expanded program. But the two major sources of offsets may not materialize.
One source is $24.2 billion in tax loopholes that the Administration hopes to close and subsidies that it wants to eliminate. But Congress rejected half of those proposed changes last year.
The second source is $65 billion in anticipated Federal revenue over five years from an increase in the price of cigarettes, which the Administration is expecting from a proposed settlement with the tobacco industry. Mr. Clinton has called for the price of a pack of cigarettes to increase by $1.50 over 10 years, though he has not specified how, whether through a tax or some other means. The money would be divided among the Federal Government, states, and other groups.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, warned that Congress may not approve any tobacco settlement.
"Frankly, I'm not standing here saying I oppose that settlement, but there is much being said up here that the settlement will never go through," Mr. Domenici said. "Where will the $65 billion come from?"
If tobacco money does not become available for this budget, Administration officials said, they would find other sources of revenue or trim their ambitions rather than resort to deficit spending.
Mr. Domenici argued that, in all, Mr. Clinton was proposing $150 billion in tax credits and spending. "If the President of the United States can increase spending and have tax credits worth $150 billion," he asked, "why can't Republicans have a significant tax cut in lieu of all the spending?"
That is likely to be the essence of the debate in coming months, with Republicans arguing for a big tax cut and the Democrats pushing for more, if limited, spending on Mr. Clinton's agenda. The White House has tried to box the Republicans in, hoping to maneuver them so that any effort to cut taxes would be seen as a threat to Social Security, and any resistance to a tobacco settlement would be seen as indifference to children's health.
"There are a number of Republicans who like the idea of saving the surplus for Social Security," said Rahm Emanuel, a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton. "There are a number of Republicans who like the idea of reducing teen smoking." But, he said, "The Democrats are unified in those positions, the Republicans aren't."
Most of the Administration's proposals had already been disclosed, as the President tried to seize the public's attention in recent weeks. They fit with the priorities that Mr. Clinton campaigned on in 1996, emphasizing the needs of children.
Mr. Clinton would spend $7.3 billion over five years to help states recruit and train 100,000 teachers, with the aim of reducing average class sizes to 18 in first through third grades. And he would spend $7.5 billion to subsidize child care for poor children.
Mr. Clinton is proposing to consolidate several Federal spending streams into three funds: the Research Fund for America, which would include spending by the National Institutes of Health, the Energy Department, and others; the Environmental Resources Fund for America, which would include certain spending by the Environmental Protection Agency and others, and the Transportation Fund for America, which would include the Transportation Department's highway money, as well as other programs.
In all, Mr. Clinton would increase spending by $4.7 billion on these programs, to $75.5 billion.
Mr. Clinton also hopes to restore some of the benefits that were eliminated when he signed legislation overhauling the welfare system in 1996. He would spend $2.7 billion over five years to restore food stamps for legal immigrants.
Critics of Mr. Clinton argue that it was the Republican Congress after 1994 that enforced fiscal discipline, and some analysts believe it is the strong economy, more than than anything, that has balanced the budget.
But for the Administration, the end of deficit politics is vindication of the economic strategy Mr. Clinton has pursued since taking office in 1993, and his economic team basked in the applause at the White House today. Gene Sperling, the director of Mr. Clinton's National Economic Council, said, "The strong deficit reduction drove down interest rates, and it allowed the economy to grow at a sustainable pace."
Mr. Clinton said today that some Democratic Congressmen had lost their jobs in the 1994 elections for having supported his 1993 economic plan, which passed without any Republican support. "Wherever they are today -- wherever they are -- I hope they know and remember that we passed that budget in '93 by one vote in the Senate and by one vote in the House and we did not have a vote to spare," he said.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE PROJECTED SURPLUS;
Clinton Sees $1.1 Trillion in Excess Revenue in Decade

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he foresaw budget surpluses totaling $1.1 trillion over the next decade, far more than the Congressional Budget Office anticipates.
In just five months, Mr. Clinton's forecast has become much more optimistic. He now predicts that the Government will run a surplus of $216 billion in 2007, which is $49 billion more than he predicted in September. 
 Several important changes have fostered this rosy outlook.
The Clinton Administration now anticipates slower growth in Medicare spending. And it foresees smaller increases in the Consumer Price Index, which would mean slower growth in Federal spending for benefit programs linked to inflation.
Moreover, the White House predicts stronger economic growth than the Congressional Budget Office expects. That, in turn, produces higher revenues and lower Federal spending, which together generate larger surpluses.
But the changes in the domestic economy have been modest. The basic factors -- surging revenues, low interest rates, declining welfare rolls -- were evident in September.
The biggest new development, the financial crisis in Asia, would, if anything, suggest that the outlook for the American economy, for Wall Street and for Federal revenues should be slightly less rosy now than five months ago.
Last September Mr. Clinton saw deficits in each of the next three years, with the first surplus in 2002. Now he foresees a surplus of $9.5 billion in 1999, rising to $258.5 billion in 2008. The Federal Government has not had a surplus since 1969.
The surpluses envisioned by Mr. Clinton in the next decade are two-thirds greater than those anticipated by the Congressional Budget Office: a total of $1.1 trillion, as against $660 billion.
In September, just as the fiscal year 1997 was nearing an end, Mr. Clinton predicted that the Federal Government would run a deficit of $37 billion in that year. Actually, the Government received a big influx of new revenue, and the 1997 deficit was just $22 billion.
Over the next decade, Mr. Clinton estimates that the Government will collect $21.1 trillion of revenue, which is $180 billion more than the Congressional Budget Office predicts.
And the President says the Government will spend $20 trillion, which is $266 billion less than the budget office anticipates.
Robert D. Reischauer, a former director of the budget office, said the Administration's estimate of more than $1 trillion in surpluses was not unreasonable if current policies remained in place.
But Mr. Reischauer said: "It's implausible to assume that we'll do nothing, that we won't change policy. Surpluses burn holes in politicians' pockets. It will be very hard to preserve these surpluses."
The President and Congress agreed last summer on legislation to eliminate the deficit, but they both predicted that the goal would not be achieved until 2002.
"Since then," Mr. Clinton said today, "the budget outlook has improved. Economic growth has continued to exceed expectations, and inflation has remained low."
Economists, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, say that the projected surpluses are no reason for complacency.
In a decade, just as the annual budget surplus soars over $250 billion, the first members of the baby boom generation can qualify for old-age benefits under Social Security, assuming they take early retirement.
The assets of the Social Security trust fund will grow rapidly in the next decade. But if no changes are made, Social Security officials say, the trust fund will begin paying out more in benefits than it receives in taxes, starting around 2012.

Recent discoveries by scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico have sparked debate about the protection offered to American troops by the current anthrax vaccine. A device discovered in a nearby hotel's parking lot launched two projectiles before the police were able to examine it, a police spokesman said. He said that groups opposing the airport's expansion were suspected of firing the rockets. (AP)

The Loyalist Volunteer Force, a Protestant paramilitary splinter group in Northern Ireland that has slain at least four Roman Catholics since Christmas, threatened to kill more Catholics in an "unholy war." With votes from 91 percent of the ballot boxes counted, Miguel Angel Rodriguez had 46 percent, compared with 44 percent for Jose Miguel Corrales of the current President's Party. Mr. Corrales conceded defeat. (AP)

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE FIRST LADY;
Far From Home, an Ideal Crowd at Last

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 2

 BODY:
For a First Lady who had spent the last two weeks fending off accusations of her husband's infidelity, it might have been the perfect audience.
Hillary Rodham Clinton was the star speaker tonight at the World Economic Forum, the annual gathering here in this luxury Alpine ski resort for chief executives and political leaders from around the world. And for a few hours, she was among kindred spirits. 
 Mrs. Clinton was applauded warmly for her speech, on "Individual and Collective Priorities for the 21st Century," in which she told of a need to strengthen "civil society." During the question period, no one even hinted at names like Monica S. Lewinsky or Paula Corbin Jones. Klaus Schwab, host of the gathering, introduced her as "the most remarkable, the most courageous woman of our times."
The First Lady offered very little beyond a bland appeal for cooperation among government, business and society. In the closest she came to a reference to the uproar in Washington, she warned elliptically that the American media might be undermining civil society by forcing a rush to quick judgments.
"The pressure for instant, simultaneous judgment," she said, "is turning people away from being active citizens."
Then, apparently referring to popular culture and entertainment, she went on to criticize "consumer capitalism" and a "media that stresses short-term capitalism."
Her audience was more than simply polite. It was also an audience made up largely of Europeans, many of whom said today that they could not comprehend why the possibility of sexual liaisons by a political leader would create such a furor. And it was an audience of executives like William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, who have had their own battles with unruly news organizations and who more than sympathized with the First Lady's decision to turn down all requests to speak with the press here.
"Obviously we are in a different world than yours," Michel Bon, chairman of France Telecom, said in an interview. "Look at the whole experience with President Francois Mitterrand, who had a mistress and a daughter by that mistress, who were living in an apartment paid by the Government -- and that was very good."
Mr. Bon, one of about 100 people invited to dinner with Mrs. Clinton on Sunday night, confessed that he had been charmed by her.
"You know," he said with a shy smile, "she really is very beautiful."
Mrs. Clinton arrived here on Sunday evening but, until her speech tonight, remained shielded from public view by the World Economic Forum's well-oiled machine for protecting celebrities who want their privacy. The conference hall here is inundated at all times by guards armed with machine guns. Although public attention is usually focused on the speeches and the seminars, the real talking and deal-making here take place in meetings and at meals behind closed doors.
When CBS News asked for permission to set up a camera in order to interview executives leaving after Mrs. Clinton's speech, Mr. Schwab, the host, flatly refused.
Although Europeans of all stripes routinely snicker at what they consider American prudishness, they have followed the Lewinsky episode with almost the same relish for detail as Americans. As the participants here relax between discussions of the Asian financial crisis or globalization, their conversations have inevitably drifted to the most recent comments by Ms. Lewinsky's lawyer and to speculation about President Clinton's ability to survive in office.
Perhaps as a result, Mrs. Clinton avoided both the fabulous skiing at Davos and most conference activities. After arriving here from Lucerne, where she had visited a school and allowed herself to be photographed with local children, she made a point of keeping out of the public eye. Today, a spokeswoman for the First Lady said, Mrs. Clinton stayed secluded in her hotel room in order to prepare her speech.
As in other recent appearances, she spoke calmly and betrayed no hint of anxiety. But she also showed no signs of humor. She made no jokes, and smiled only occasionally.
"There is no doubt that we are creating a consumer culture that could undermine both capitalism and civil society," she said in response to a question about the impact of American culture. Taking what appeared to be an oblique swipe at the frenzied coverage of the Lewinsky case, she denounced the "pressure for instant, simultaneous judgment."
She then appeared to shift her focus to the entertainment media. "Because we have a very broad understanding of the First Amendment," she said, American children are being exposed to an "unstoppable" message of "instant materialist pleasure."
The reaction here to Mrs. Clinton's speech was muted but positive. Indeed, the biggest status symbol of this conference for the rich and the powerful was an invitation to the dinner with her.
"After Reagan and Bush, the Americans should be happy to have people like Clinton and his wife, because at least they have brought some humanity to the Presidency," said Ursula Engelen-Kefer, deputy chairwoman of the umbrella group for German labor unions.
"It's ridiculous, absolutely ridiculous," Ms. Engelen-Kefer continued, echoing the amazement of others that even the possibility of a sexual affair could generate such a furor. "This happens all the time here. It's no big thing. The only moral question is whether politics and sex have become mixed up," or whether any sexual contact between Mr. Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky "was forced."
At least so far, Ms. Engelen-Kefer said, "the whole thing is a show."
Mrs. Clinton as well seemed to suggest a pragmatic approach to politics and governing, saying there was neither a perfect marketplace nor a perfect government.
"We have to work with human beings as we find them," she said.

HEADLINE: CUNY Shouldn't Farm Out Remedial Programs;
Just Like H.M.O.'s

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Giuliani Demands Community Colleges Drop Remedial Help" (news article, Jan. 30): The public should be wary of any such plan for the City University of New York. Because there is no wealthy consumer market for them, private institutions engaged in remediation will, like health maintenance organizations, have incentive to raise efficiency at the expense of quality and commitment. A private high school extension accepting a student receiving financial aid from the state has every incentive to keep that student in remediation as long as the state will pay for it. 
 Eventually the system will have to be regulated. So why give public money to private institutions requiring government regulation when CUNY is set up to do the job?
Enhancing remedial programs to provide individual attention to students would be a more logically sound approach.
 
ROB HOLLANDER
New York, Jan. 31, 1998
 
The writer is a member of the CUNY board of trustees' committee on academic policy, planning and research.

HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT RECEIVES MEASURED SUPPORT OF SAUDIS ON IRAQ

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 2

 BODY:
After six hours of talks with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in a lush desert encampment, the Saudi Government issued a statement of support tonight saying that if diplomacy fails and the United States attacks Iraq, the fault "would lie exclusively on the Iraqi regime."
The statement stopped short of unconditional approval of any use of force, and it urged "all diplomatic means to resolve the current crisis" with Iraq over its failure to cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors. But the position of the Saudi Government was encouraging as Ms. Albright travels through Europe and the Middle East seeking support for military action, the officials said. 
 "They're saying that if force occurs, it's not the fault of the United States but of Saddam Hussein," a senior American official said. "That matters. They're not saying don't use force like the Russians and some other Governments."
Privately, Western diplomats say, the Saudis have no problem with the use of force to punish Iraq as long as any attack is not merely symbolic but really hurts President Hussein, whom they regard as a menace.
While Ms. Albright has said that the United States is willing to act alone militarily against Iraq, she has used this trip to consult allies and line up support. Saudi Arabia is America's most important Arab ally in the region and a vital source of oil, and it is almost unthinkable that the United States would go to war against Iraq without at least its implicit support.
Ms. Albright -- who has been saying that any American military action against Iraq would be "significant" -- did not fully resolve how much access to its air bases the Saudi Government would give the American military. The United States would need air bases here in the event of prolonged hostilities with Iraq.
As Ms. Albright was being received lavishly by Crown Prince Abdullah at a desert encampment about 60 miles from Riyadh, where winter rains have covered the sand in green clover and small yellow flowers, the Russians were announcing a deal with Iraq to allow weapons inspections of eight presidential sites, but with unclear conditions.
By the time Ms. Albright was asked about the Russian initiative at a brief late-night news conference, Iraq had denied any deal, and the confusion worsened.
A senior American official, pressed on whether the Saudis, if necessary, would allow American airplanes to use Saudi bases to strike Iraq, said, "We don't think we're moving toward a no."
In the absence of bases there, fighter planes could operate from Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, from Bahrain and from three aircraft carriers -- one British and two American -- in the Persian Gulf.
Ms. Albright said she had had extensive talks on military issues and the question of bases with Crown Prince Abdullah. "He took them all on board, and wanted to consult with members of his Government," she said. "But based on my excellent discussions with the Crown Prince and the strong statement they issued, I have full trust and confidence in the Saudi Government."
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen is expected to arrive soon on a tour of Persian Gulf states, when the details of military rules of engagement will be discussed and the bases issue will presumably be resolved. The Saudis might agree to let their bases be used for support and communications aircraft, like Awacs planes, but not necessarily allow Iraq to be bombed from Saudi bases.
American, British and French planes now enforce a no-flight zone over the south of Iraq from a large Saudi base in the middle of the vast desert kingdom.
The United States already has 24,500 troops in the region, and more than 200 warplanes, plus aircraft carriers and Navy vessels equipped with cruise missiles. Bringing in more troops and weapons is being discussed as diplomatic efforts fail to win access for United Nations inspectors seeking to identify and destroy Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.
American officials are wary of Russian efforts at diplomacy because they fear a last-minute compromise that could prove illusory or temporary while allowing Iraq further time to hide or produce biological and chemical weapons without either inspections or punishment.
Various envoys are trying to get Mr. Hussein to back down. "I would like to see these initiatives work, but I do not want to see any kind of diversions come out of it," Ms. Albright said. "So I remain skeptical."
But a senior American official said later that the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, had discussed the outlines of the Russian proposal with Ms. Albright at their meeting on Friday in Madrid. At that time, Mr. Primakov was unsure whether Baghdad would even accept the proposal, the official said, "so we did not parse it too carefully."
Answering a question listing reported conditions proposed by the Russians, Ms. Albright said: "If those are the conditions, they do not meet the criteria, which are unfettered, unconditional access to all sites. Saddam Hussein knows that, and it is what the international community has called for in numerous resolutions."
"To have piecemeal inspections of groups formed ad hoc does not seem to me to meet the basic standard we have established," she said.
Although Ms. Albright "rejects all proposals that fall short" of the American standard, the senior official said, it will be up to the chairman of the United Nations inspectors, Richard Butler, "to decide whether he has the access he needs to get the job done."
But after seven years of sanctions, officials acknowledge, the world is tired of the strict boycott on Iraq, and Russia has taken a firm position against the right of the United States to use force against Iraq unilaterally. To mute criticism, the Americans have embraced a sizable increase in the oil-for-food program recommended by Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, and also supported by the British and French.
Clinton Administration officials have said Ms. Albright, on this trip, has been mindful of an early trip to Europe in May 1993 by her predecessor, Warren M. Christopher, to consult on a more aggressive American policy on Bosnia. Mr. Christopher was criticized for seemingly allowing the Europeans, who had troops on the ground in Bosnia, to veto Washington's plans.
So as she has sought support for the American position wherever she has gone, Ms. Albright has said at the same time that the United States will act unilaterally, if necessary.
Saudi officials have made it clear, Western diplomats say, that they would prefer to have the United States remove Mr. Hussein. Like leaders of other gulf governments, the Saudis are cautioning that if force is used, it must severely damage Mr. Hussein and his sources of power. "They want a sledgehammer, not a pin prick," a diplomat said.
The semiofficial Saudi newspaper Al Riyadh said today, "If the upcoming military strike is just going to be a television event or minor surgery, without achieving the overriding goal, Saddam Hussein will be the big winner -- because he will have been subjected to an attack which all the countries of the world and the nations of the region reject."
Speaking today at the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland, the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, argued that bombing Iraq might not be enough to stop the threat posed by Mr. Hussein.
"We cannot afford just a bombing campaign at the end of which he makes weapons of mass destruction," Mr. Gingrich said in a speech. "And we cannot afford to walk off and not try to stop him. Bring all your diplomatic pressure to bear in the next two weeks, and if he is not prepared to back down, support the United States in whatever level of action we have to take."
The Iraqi representative to the United Nations, Nizar Hamdoon, said today that he would issue an invitation through Mr. Gingrich to any members of Congress who might want to visit the presidential sites in Iraq. He said lawmakers would be permitted to bring along weapons experts. Iraq issued the same sort of invitation in November, but no country accepted it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright meeting with the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, at a desert encampment yesterday. She received a Saudi Government statement of support in the crisis with Iraq. (Saudi Press via Associated Press)(pg. A8)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: AIDS DEATHS DROP 48% IN NEW YORK

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 2

 BODY:
AIDS deaths in New York City plummeted by 48 percent last year, accelerating earlier gains attributed to improved drug therapies, health officials said at a scientific meeting here today. They said the declines crossed sex and racial lines, suggesting that the new therapies were reaching all segments of the AIDS population.
National figures for the first six months of 1997 also showed a similar sharp decline, 44 percent, from the corresponding period of 1996. Full national figures for 1997 will not be available until July. 
 The new figures mark the second year in a row in which AIDS deaths have declined after years of steady increases since the AIDS epidemic was recognized in 1981.
Theoretically, the decline in AIDS deaths could have resulted from prevention efforts or some unknown factor, the health experts meeting here said. But the likeliest explanation is expanded use of combinations of newer and older drugs that began to be introduced in recent years, New York City and Federal health officials said.
"This is a new era" in AIDS, Dr. Kevin DeCock, an AIDS official from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, said at a news conference. "We can't think that the end of the epidemic is in sight, but it certainly is the beginning of a new period." Dr. DeCock heads the unit at the centers that monitors AIDS cases in this country. "The challenge now is to improve prevention," he told the 3,400 participants in the meeting here.
Dr. DeCock and Dr. Mary Ann Chiasson, the New York City Assistant Commissioner for Disease Intervention Research, said they did not know how long the decline in deaths would continue or how low the numbers would reach.
One reason, the officials said, is that no one knows for how long the benefits of the new combination drug therapies will last.
Preliminary evidence suggests that many people who seemingly do well on the new combination therapy will eventually fall ill with AIDS-related symptoms, either because they are unable to adhere to the rigorous schedule of taking the medication or because the drugs somehow fail them.
In addition, officials do not know whether new cases of infection with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, are rising or falling, since many states, including New York and California, do not require them to be reported. Instead, they require only that full-blown cases of AIDS be reported.
But that may change. Last month, the nation's largest AIDS service agency, the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York, reversed its position and called for the reporting of H.I.V. infections, saying that while it was still concerned with maintaining the privacy of people with the virus, reporting of H.I.V. cases would provide a more accurate tracking of the disease.
In New York City, Dr. Chiasson said preliminary data for 1997 show that about 2,600 New York City residents died of AIDS in that year, a drop of 48 percent from the 4,998 deaths in 1996. The decline was 50 percent for men and 46 percent for women.
In 1996, the decline in male deaths far exceeded that for females, 31 percent and 23 percent, compared with 1995. "The gap is closing," Dr. Chiasson said in an interview here today.
In addition, researchers said, the decline in AIDS deaths in New York City was notable among both gay men and intravenous drug users. The researchers said there was a 41 percent decline among gay men and a 30 percent drop among people who contracted H.I.V. by injecting drugs with contaminated needles. A similar 30 percent decline was registered among people who became infected through heterosexual intercourse.
Some AIDS service organizations said that while the drop in AIDS deaths was heartening, it underlined -- rather than diminished -- the importance of the work they do and the need for it.
Because more people are living longer with the disease, they said, more people are seeking services ranging from help in getting housing to help in finding jobs.
"Demands for our services are climbing enormously," said Dennis DeLeon, president of the Latino Commission on AIDS, which is based in Manhattan. "There are a whole bunch more people around with this disease."
Mr. DeLeon said that while his organization received about 1,200 requests for help in 1996, it received more than 1,800 in 1997. Of the new death statistics, he said, "These figures are encouraging in terms of living, but it creates an extra responsibility on the part of programs like ours."
Stephen Soba, a spokesman for the Gay Men's Health Crisis in Manhattan, said that his group and others were shifting their efforts slightly to help people plot strategies for living with AIDS as opposed to plans for dying from the disease.
For example, Mr. Soba said, the legal department of the Gay Men's Health Crisis devotes more time to preparing wills than it did a few years ago and more to helping people with AIDS handle disputes with, or discrimination complaints against, employers or landlords.
"And we're offering seminars now on re-entering the workplace," Mr. Soba said. "That's something we wouldn't have been able to offer 10 years or even 5 years ago."
Despite the declining AIDS death toll in New York City, an average of 7 people per day died there of AIDS in 1997, compared with 19.3 only two years earlier.
Researchers in New York City determined the number of AIDS deaths by directly examining death certificates that doctors file with the city's Health Department. The national figures are reported to the Centers for Disease Control by local and state health authorities. Because there can be a lag in those reports, the C.D.C. has not yet compiled data for all of 1997.
Since the early days of the AIDS epidemic, New York City has been one of the hardest hit of American cities. Although it has only 3 percent of the nation's population, it has 16 percent of its AIDS cases. As a result, New York City has been a bellwether for AIDS trends nationwide.
Two studies being reported at the meeting here supported the view that the decline in deaths is related to use of combination drug therapies.
One study reported by Dr. A. D. McNaghten of the Centers for Disease Control showed a substantial survival advantage among people treated with combinations of three drugs. The risk of death was 2.5 times lower for people who were treated with a combination of three drugs instead of one. Also, prophylactic treatment for certain infections that complicate AIDS, like pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, pneumococcal pneumonia and a tuberculosis-like infection (Mycobacterium avium intracellulare) improved survival.
Dr. Atieno Reggy reported a study from the centers, the New York City Health Department and Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center that supported the thesis that the decline in AIDS deaths in New York City resulted at least in part from greater use of the new class of protease inhibitor drugs in combination with different types of older drugs.
However, the drop in AIDS deaths in New York City began in late 1995 before the widespread marketing of protease inhibitor drugs. The new study was not intended to address the drop in late 1995, Dr. Chiasson said.
Of the more than 100,000 New York City residents who have been diagnosed with AIDS, more than 66,000 have died, Dr. Chiasson said.
Nationally, the number of newly reported AIDS cases fell 12 percent, to 29,520, for the first six months of 1997, compared with 33,590 in the first half of 1996.
Many speakers pointed to the surge in H.I.V. infections in Africa and other areas where countries cannot afford the combination therapies.
Dr. David Katzenstein's team from Stanford University and the University of Zimbabwe in Africa reported what they said was the first scientifically controlled trial showing that educational and behavioral intervention tailored to the social, cultural and economic values of communities reduce the incidence of H.I.V. infection.
In the study, the incidence of new infections dropped by 33 percent, to 2.25 per person-years at factories where peers conducted educational programs, from 3.11 in the factories where no such programs were held.
Despite the optimism that the new figures are likely to produce, some experts are concerned that as death rates continue to fall, people will deem the disease less of a fatal threat and perhaps not be as careful in their sexual behavior.
"There's a great deal of concern that people will read these figures as an indication that caution can be dispensed with," said Mr. Soba of the Gay Men's Health Crisis.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 4, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about a decline in AIDS deaths in New York City referred imprecisely in some copies to the periods being compared for certain groups. The drop of 71 percent in AIDS deaths among men and 63 percent among women was in the last six months of 1997, compared with the last six months of 1995.
Declines for the following groups were also based on comparisons of the last half of 1997 with the last half of 1995: 83 percent for Asian-American men, 78 percent for white men, 72 percent for Hispanic men, 65 percent for black men, 73 percent for white women, 66 percent for Hispanic women and 59 percent for black women.

HEADLINE: Clinton Budget Well Received in the Region

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
With a muscular economy fueling projections of surpluses into the next decade, the budget President Clinton proposed today would increase Federal spending on an array of programs important to the New York region, with education, heating, defense and housing programs benefiting the most.
New York City would get $65 million to hire new teachers, the most of any city in the country, Congressional officials said. Connecticut's major defense manufacturers would receive billions of dollars in contracts for new submarines, helicopters and aircraft engines. New Jersey would see major increases for job training, community development and school construction. 
 The President's budget is a preliminary proposal that needs approval by Congress, where regional politics and special interest lobbying are sure to lead to major revisions.
But there was a bipartisan sense here today that the New York region generally fared better in Mr. Clinton's latest proposal than in recent Federal budgets. Democrats said the region's relatively strong showing was rooted in Mr. Clinton's renewed support for a more active Democratic agenda this year, particularly in health care and education. Many of those programs, by their nature, tend to benefit states like New York, New Jersey and Connecticut with large urban areas.
"This is a welcome change," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat. "This is the first time in a decade or more that New York has done well."
There were complaints, however. New York City hospital officials said Mr. Clinton had done nothing to soften deep cuts to Medicare in last year's budget and was proposing to finance programs for low-income children by increasing certain fines against hospitals.
Officials from shore areas said there was not enough money for beach-erosion projects.
And representatives from throughout the region complained that Mr. Clinton had proposed no new operating subsidies for Amtrak. Without extra money, Amtrak officials expect to dip into money, set aside for repairing tracks and buying new equipment, just to keep the trains running.
"Throughout this budget proposal, the Clinton Administration has been playing games, and the typical example is with Amtrak," said Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a Republican from Glens Falls, N.Y. "Congress put up the money for capital improvement that was paid for last year, and now the administration is going to short-arm Amtrak and divert that money toward operating expenses."
Mr. Clinton is proposing to finance many of his plans with money from litigation against tobacco companies, even though Congress has yet to enact legislation settling those suits.
"The question will be how will you pay for everything," said Geoffrey Brown, legislative director for the Northeast, Midwest Senate Coalition, a bipartisan research group financed by members of Congress from 18 states. "The budget assumes $9.8 billion in tobacco receipts. That could be a big assumption."
 One initiative that did better this year than in previous Clinton spending plans was the low-income home energy assistance program, which the President has often tried to cut. This time, Mr. Clinton proposed increasing the program, which goes disproportionately to Northeastern states, by $100 million. "That is very, very popular in cold weather states, and this means you won't have as many people choosing between heating and eating," Mr. Brown said.
Among the most ambitious of the Clinton proposals is a plan to provide long-term financing for school construction ($10 billion over 10 years) and hiring new teachers ($12 billion over 7 years) to reduce class sizes. Both programs would particularly benefit poorer districts, including New York City and Newark, school officials said.
"Over all, this is the largest proposed increase in anybody's recollection for primary and secondary education," said Jeff Simering, legislative director for the Council of Great City Schools, an advocacy group for the country's 50 largest school systems. "Getting it enacted is another thing."
A study of the Clinton budget by aides to Mr. Schumer and Representative Nita A. Lowey, a Democrat of Westchester, found that New York City would also receive substantial increases in Federal spending on job training programs, mass transit, AIDS treatment programs and health care research.
 The budget also includes money for several capital projects, including $12 million for redeveloping Pennsylvania Station, $5.5 million for improving the Gateway National Recreation Area in Queens and $2.5 million for renovating the Whitehall Ferry Terminal in Manhattan.
Under the President's plan, New York City would also benefit from an increase in financing for Department of Housing and Urban Development projects to improve opportunities for low-income city dwellers. Projections by the department found that the city's community development block grant would grow by 5 percent to $233 million; homeless assistance funds would increase by 40 percent to $61 million, and subsidies for public housing would rise by 5 percent to $542 million.
 In Connecticut, officials said the President's budget calls for buying billions of dollars in military hardware, including submarines, helicopters and jet engines built by Electric Boat in Groton, Sikorsky in Stratford and Pratt & Whitney in East Hartford.
"There is a decline in real dollars for defense nationwide," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat. "But Connecticut companies have done very well. Certainly in regard to the submarine programs, the waters ahead seem remarkably tranquil compared to what we have seen in recent years."

HEADLINE: U.S. Security Doctrine

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"U.S. Spy Agencies Find Scant Peril on Horizon" (news article, Jan. 29) highlights an absence of "lethal threat" to the United States but cites potential threats to world peace in "economic, ecological, technological, political and criminal phenomena that warplanes and smart bombs cannot combat." This analysis ignores the negative impact of weapons on economic and social development.
Weapons do not start wars, but their production and sale divert valuable resources from economic and social needs. Moreover, the desire to maintain a lead as potential adversaries acquire new weapons leads to a growing reliance on bigger, more sophisticated arsenals.
Some of these weapons reach the global market, which is already flooded with destructive capabilities. 
 Excessive militarization perpetuates political instability. It is time for the United States to rethink security doctrines that rely primarily on threat or force.
 
MERAV DATAN
New York, Jan. 31, 1998

HEADLINE: City Proposes a Gift for Jazz: A Swinging Hall of Its Own

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS 

 BODY:
After wandering in the desert of Lincoln Center for seven years, the organization's youngest constituent, Jazz at Lincoln Center, seems closer to finding a home of its own.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday at a news conference that projected new development plans for the New York Coliseum site at Columbus Circle would house a 100,000-square-foot space for the seven-year-old program, whose artistic director is the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis. 
 The project would include badly needed rehearsal rooms -- Jazz at Lincoln Center now rehearses opposite the Port Authority bus station at 41st Street and Ninth Avenue -- space for educational programs and, most important of all, a 1,100-seat concert hall with acoustics designed primarily for jazz. It would be the first such space anywhere.
The plan was put forward enthusiastically by the Mayor and officials of Jazz at Lincoln Center yesterday. But there are a number of hurdles. No developer has been chosen to rebuild the Coliseum site. Plans for the redevelopment would have to be approved by both the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that owns the site, and the board of Lincoln Center, which represents an array of organizations whose assent would also be needed.
The overall cost of the space would be $40 million to $45 million. Jazz at Lincoln Center would provide $20 million, of which, it said, $10 million has already been raised. The city has committed $18 million for the building.
"This is wonderful," said the Mayor. "It'll make the Lincoln Center area the greatest performance area in the world. It's a terrific new direction for Lincoln Center."
The new space would eliminate a host of problems faced by Jazz at Lincoln Center, which says it is the fastest-growing of Lincoln Center's constituent parts. Today, when requesting the use of Avery Fisher or Alice Tully Hall, it has to accept a place in the pecking order behind such groups as the Julliard School of Music and the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The new performance space would be used 50 to 60 percent of the time by Jazz at Lincoln Center. About 20 to 30 percent of the time, other Lincoln Center constituents could use the performance hall.
The announcement was greeted with enthusiasm by members of Jazz at Lincoln Center's staff. Jazz and Latin music programs held in Lincoln Center venues by Jazz at Lincoln Center have struggled with acoustical problems. In concert hall design, sound amplification is typically considered in terms of classical music.
The new hall, dubbed "Anonymous Donor Hall," by Jazz at Lincoln Center's chairman, Gordon Davis, would seat the same number of people as Alice Tully, but the distance between the stage and the back wall would be shortened by some 40 feet in an attempt to create more intimacy. And Jazz at Lincoln Center has started discussions with acousticians.
"I'm really excited about the prospect of a new hall," said Mr. Marsalis. "I travel the world playing places that were designed for classical music. Half the time I can't hear myself play because the spaces can't handle drums. So we're going to design a place that has swing, the way it looks, the way it sounds."
The space is a result of a collaboration of the city, the M.T.A. and Jazz at Lincoln Center. When the M.T.A. proposed a redevelopment initiative for the Coliseum last year, the Mayor demanded that any plan include a large theater space. The city looked to Lincoln Center, which had been planning to expand across Broadway from its campus. When that plan fell through, the city and Jazz at Lincoln Center started conversations.
"This sort of collaboration is exactly like the city and private sector collaborations that have made the cultural life of New York City," Mr. Davis said. "The Museum of Natural History, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the library system were all products of this sort of collaboration. But with the cultural significance of Jazz at Lincoln Center, the idea becomes not just a 19th-century idea, but a 21st-century idea."
Why would the city give such a valuable piece of property to the jazz program?
"The city came to us and asked us to fill the space with culture," said Mr. Davis. "The city realizes that culture is a big part of the economy. It's part of the city's identity, financially and politically."
Critics of the plan have suggested that the new home, two blocks from the southern tip of Lincoln Center, would remove the jazz program from the center's mainstream.
Mr. Marsalis scoffed at the idea. "They voted us in," he said referring to the constituents of Lincoln Center. "We spend time collaborating with them all. We're closer to the other constituents than we were before."

HEADLINE: NATO: A Debate Recast

BYLINE: By Howard Baker Jr., Sam Nunn, Brent Scowcroft and Alton Frye; Howard Baker Jr. is a former Republican Senator from Tennessee. Sam Nunn is a former Democratic Senator from Georgia. Brent Scowcroft was national security adviser to Presidents Ford and Bush. Alton Frye is senior fellow of the Council on Foreign Relations.

 BODY:
The looming Senate debate over NATO enlargement marks a historic encounter between good intentions and sound strategy. Despite momentum toward admitting three more members -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- the fundamental interests at stake demand probing examination of the specific candidacies, the approach that has brought the alliance to this fateful juncture and the troubling implications of that approach. Along with many who have worked to build a strong NATO, we harbor grave reservations about the pending expansion and the direction it points.
Far from being a cold war relic, NATO should be the cornerstone of an evolving security order in Europe. It provides the infrastructure and experience indispensable to coping with instabilities -- Bosnia today, and other troublespots tomorrow. NATO is vital to insuring arms control and maintaining the kind of industrial base that provides a solid defense. Perhaps most important, NATO provides the institutional home for coalitions to meet crises beyond Europe. 
 But a cornerstone is not a sponge. The function of a cornerstone is to protect its own integrity to support a wider security structure, not to dissipate its cohesion by absorbing members and responsibilities beyond prudent limits. A powerful NATO undergirds other institutions, including the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the Western European Union. It makes possible the Partnership for Peace to promote cooperation among countries that are not NATO members.
The rush to expand the alliance has put the cart before the horse. Advocates and skeptics of NATO enlargement agree that the transformation of Europe's security structure should be related to the transformation of its economy. As James Baker, the former Secretary of State, has testified, European Union membership "is just as important as membership in NATO for the countries involved," and "we must make clear that NATO membership for the countries of Central Europe is not a substitute for closer economic ties to the E.U."
In our view, it would have been preferable not to invite more countries to join NATO. At the very least, it would be desirable for the European Union to proceed with its planned expansion before NATO completes the acceptance of the new members.
The European Union has now decided to begin negotiations with six aspirants, including the three candidates NATO is considering. Linking NATO expansion to the expansion of the European Union would accomplish several things:
* It would underscore the connection between Europe's security and its economy -- and offer certification that entrants to NATO could afford to meet its defense obligations.
* It would permit the Partnership for Peace to demonstrate that it should be the proper association for countries outside NATO. So long as the option to join NATO remains open, it utterly undercuts the partnership as the preferred mode of cooperation.
* It would allow the United States and Russia to focus on the gravest security problem still before us, the formidable hangover of nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction. The cooperative framework provided by the NATO-Russia Founding Act may be useful, but frictions over NATO distract Moscow and Washington from profound common dangers. Even if everything goes right in expanding NATO, we will have misplaced our priorities during a critical window of opportunity to gain Russian cooperation in controlling nuclear arsenals and preventing proliferation. Russian antagonism is sure to grow if the alliance extends ever closer to Russian territory.
The Senate would be wise to link NATO and European Union expansion. If that link is made, it is essential to stipulate that admission to the European Union is not sufficient qualification for entry into NATO. NATO should weigh any future applicant against the contributions and burdens its membership would entail. What is called for is a definite, if not permanent, pause in this process.
By leading the charge for NATO expansion, the Clinton Administration may well elicit hasty proposals and considerable pressure to admit other countries. Other Central and East European countries are hoping that they, too, will soon be welcomed into allied ranks.
But a military alliance is not a club, and the Administration's rhetoric and policy risk converting NATO into an organization in which obligations are diluted and action is enfeebled. Pursuing that path may simultaneously spur Russian animosity and weaken the alliance's capability to contain it, if required. William Perry, the former Defense Secretary, and Warren Christopher, the former Secretary of State, acknowledge the problematic situation in which the country finds itself. In their words, "there is no consensus on the wisdom of the path taken so far by the alliance and spearheaded by the Clinton Administration."
While Mr. Perry and Mr. Christopher state that NATO should remain open "in principle," they contend that no additional members should be designated until the three current candidates "are fully prepared to bear the responsibilities of membership and have been integrated into the alliance." That reads to us like advice to slow this train down. We are in accord with that view, and with their argument that NATO should make the experience of Partnership for Peace membership for non-NATO members "as similar as possible to the experience of NATO membership."
We are dubious, however, that consensus can be found on the Administration's premise that NATO should be receptive to many additional members. That is a prescription for destroying the alliance. It guarantees future discord with present allies, few of whom are prepared to follow the Clinton policy to its logical end, the inclusion of Russia.
The task is to build a security structure in which Russia assumes a place commensurate with its geostrategic importance and its progress toward democracy and a market economy. With due respect, those campaigning to expand NATO confuse the longer term challenge of shaping a comprehensive security system with our continuing responsibility to sustain a robust NATO as our principal security bulwark.
The question confronting the Senate is not only whether to enlarge NATO, but how, when and on what terms. The imperative now is for the Senate to bring to bear the independent assessment mandated by the Constitution. In that assessment it has several options, including linking alliance expansion with enlargement of the European Union and laying down a marker against an excessively elastic NATO.
The Senate has constructive leverage to shape a wiser outcome than simple acquiescence in the President's plan. The widespread grumble that "NATO expansion is a bad idea whose time has come" is no basis for policy. This is not a dose of medicine one can swallow and be done with. It is a fundamental extension of American security guarantees, an ill-defined invitation for new members unrelated either to military threats or military capabilities.
A final caution to the Administration: It is no service to candor or consensus to invoke the shadow of Versailles, implying that resistance to NATO enlargement would be comparable to Senate rejection of the League of Nations. One doubts that senators will respond well to overdrawn analogies. As John Maynard Keynes noted at the time, the central failure of Versailles lay in the fatal miscalculation of how to deal with a demoralized former adversary. That, above all, is the error we must not repeat.
