HEADLINE: About New York;
A Bronx Plea: No Garbage In, Garbage Out

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE Great Garbage Tour stopped on 156th Street in Hunts Point last Saturday, the bus nearly groaning under the shifting weight of its passengers as they rushed to one side and huddled against misted windows. "Ooh!" they cooed as they beheld a commercial dump where a bulldozer crunched through dusty mounds of splintered wood, old tires and smashed plaster.
"Look, it's open on the top," Teresa Torres said, pointing to the lot, where powdery clouds floated in the sunshine. "And this is a nice one." 
 By the yard's open gate, two women hauled some mattresses out of a rental van. "Hey," said one of the passengers on the bus. "That's a good mattress!"
Not good enough for its owners, who dumped the mattresses, climbed into the van and drove off. That's the way it is in Hunts Point, where many of the castoffs of a consumer society are smashed, shredded, packed and shipped off for out-of-state burials. This Bronx peninsula, ringed by the Bruckner Expressway, is famous for its huge wholesale food market that feeds the region, but it is also home to dozens of auto graveyards and waste transfer stations. Dumps. It is also a community that has been besieged at times by vermin, putrid odors and high asthma rates from truck traffic and sludge treatment tanks.
People live here, too. And they are alarmed by the prospect of becoming the municipal garbage can, as the city considers private proposals to handle its waste after Staten Island's Fresh Kills landfill closes in 2001. Among those under consideration is a proposal by American Marine Rail to build a barge-to-rail transfer station in Hunts Point that would receive 5,000 tons, 40 percent, of the city's waste daily.
Rallying local opposition, community advocates chartered a big yellow bus and took their neighbors on a self-styled trashical mystery tour of the peninsula's more remote parts.
"I didn't even know this existed and I have lived here since 1958," said Mercedes Narvaez, as she walked along the Hunts Point waterfront that would house the American Marine Rail center. "And to think, you could be breathing fresh air from the water. In Baltimore, they have their harbor. That's beautiful. Something like that here, you know the money that would come here?"
Money used to come to Hunts Point, thanks to the factories that cranked out goods and unskilled jobs. Many manufacturers departed in search of cheaper labor, but the area's zoning for heavy industry stayed. In a postindustrial economy, it became a choice spot to unload everything from cars and construction debris to medical waste and paper.
Rob Jones, a principal owner of American Marine Rail, said that his company's plans would not increase diesel exhausts that foul the air and cause respiratory problems, since trucks would not be used. Instead, the waste would arrive by barge and depart by rail. He added that any agreement would provide for a percentage of revenue to be applied to local projects that would improve the quality of life.
LOCAL groups, including Mothers on the Move, which organized the tour, do not think that garbage, no matter how well handled, can improve anyone's life. The local community board has adopted a zero-tolerance policy on new dumps.
A spokesman for Borough President Fernando Ferrer said the Bronx already has more than its fair share of waste and would fight any new plan that increased the volume of garbage coming to the borough. Parse that closely, and it means the Hunts Point transfer station could be built, if existing dumps reduced their operations.
That possibility frustrates people on the peninsula who, after years of tolerating blight and crime, refuse to accept garbage from other boroughs as their reward.
"The neighborhood has changed for the better," Elaine Sosa said. "They renovated a lot of buildings. People are moving in. Stores are being renovated."
She has no regrets. So far.
"I'm even thinking of getting a house in the area," she said. "But that depends on the garbage."
A public forum is scheduled for later this month to gauge community opinion. In March, there will be city hearings on creating a uniform policy on where waste plants could be built. Residents are already planning strategies, circulating petitions and signing up to speak in public.
"It's difficult, but it's everyone's responsibility to educate each other," said Francisco Perez, a member of the Manida Street Tenants Association. "We want to throw out the garbage from here. And the politicians, too, if necessary."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Data Showing Economic Weakness Bolster Treasuries a Bit

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday after several economic reports came in weaker than expected, providing further evidence that inflation is not a threat to the bond market.
The 30-year bond was up 5/32, to a price of 103 22/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.86 percent, from 5.87 percent on Monday. 
 The index of leading indicators, reported by the Conference Board, and sales of new homes, reported by the Commerce Department, both were below economists' estimates for December. The reports caused some investors who had been betting on further declines in Treasury prices after Monday's losses to buy back borrowed securities yesterday to limit their losses, causing what is known as a short-cover rally.
The moves were limited, however, and analysts noted that the economy remained robust. Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the housing report should not "be interpreted as a sign of a significant slowdown in housing." New-home sales tend to be very volatile month to month, and the December decline followed a big gain in November.
Over the last few years, economists have several times said the housing market has topped out, only to see it bounce back. With the economy fundamentally sound, doing so now may again be premature, even if growth now slows.
"Looking ahead, these statistics portray an industry that is still strong, but one that has plateaued," Ms. Schaja said.
The index of leading economic indicators points to a similar trend. It was flat in December, suggesting slower growth for the first half of this year. In the previous two months the index rose a tenth of 1 percent, and economists had expected such a gain in December, too.
Investors will also be watching the outcome of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee's two-day meeting on monetary policy, which began yesterday. But market participants expected that the central bank would not make any changes in interest rates. Instead, they believe, the Fed will wait for the effects of the Asian economic crisis to slow American growth enough that no increases in rates are needed.
Perhaps more suspenseful for investors is the employment report for January, to be reported on Friday. Analysts expect the long bond's yield to remain in the 5.80 percent to 5.90 percent range through tomorrow.
This morning the Treasury will announce the size of its quarterly refunding of the nation's debt. Expectations are for the typical $14 billion of 3-year notes, $11 billion of 10-year notes and $10 billion of long bonds. It is possible that the amount in such securities will be reduced, however, as the budget comes closer to being balanced, and as the Treasury increases the use of inflation-pegged securities.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Air accord is likely to bring some lower fares to Japan and deeper discounts to the rest of Asia.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
THE full impact of last week's agreement to end most restrictions on air travel between the United States and Japan will not be known for at least a couple of years, airline analysts say. In the meantime, air fares between the two nations are expected to fall but not tumble, while fares to other Asian destinations could plummet -- but only if political, economic and environmental problems continue to batter the region.
"I don't believe fares to Japan will drop much below 10 to 20 percent, because they're already pretty competitive," said Kurt Bodmer, vice president of business development for Japan and Orient Tours in San Diego, a longtime tour operator to the Pacific. "But if you travel beyond Japan, to Hong Kong, Bangkok or Seoul, you may see dramatic reductions, because their tourist industries have been suffering." 
 Even though "competitive" might sound like an oxymoron in speaking of fares to Japan, Topaz International, the Portland, Ore., firm that audits fares, has come up with figures that may surprise some travelers.
While business fares last year between New York and London averaged 44 cents for each of the 6,900 round-trip air miles, New York-Tokyo flights averaged 37 cents a mile for each of the 13,400 round-trip miles. Similarly, 1997 business fares between Los Angeles and Paris (11,350 miles round trip) averaged 31 cents a mile, while fares between Los Angeles and Tokyo (10,900 miles) averaged 30 cents.
"Competition almost always leads to lower fares," said Joseph A. McInerney, chief executive of the Pacific Asia Travel Association. "And the air traffic agreement should increase leisure and commercial traffic to Asia, because airlines can use Japan as a hub to other countries."
The association, made up largely of airlines, hotels and tour operators, said that 586,808 visitors flew to Japan from the United States in 1996, a modest rise of 32,739 over the 1990 figure. In contrast, the 5.04 million Japanese who flew to the United States in 1996 was a 1.74 million increase over 1990. The association recently approved a marketing and public relations campaign to encourage Asian travel from the Americas, Europe and the Middle East.
"You should not only get lower fares from an open-skies agreement," said Lee Howard, president of Airline Economics, a consulting company in Georgia. "With many more airlines and flights, you can also expect better service."
While service between the United States and Asia is already an improvement over that on domestic flights within the United States, even in economy class, one question is whether service will remain at or near that level in the event of air fare promotional wars -- especially promotions modeled after the various "getaway" weekend and holiday fares that periodically put London or Paris within reach of the United States for $200 to $400 round trip.
The closest any carrier to Asia has come to that kind of fare is the $999 round trip to Hong Kong for two, offered in November by Hong Kong's flagship airline, Cathay Pacific. The cost, which included five nights at a hotel, was underwritten by Hong Kong hotels and the Government, in hopes of stimulating the former colony's lagging tourist industry.
No carrier has since come close to that rock bottom deal, which was limited to 20,000 passengers from America. But with Hong Kong and other Asian destinations still in financial trouble, Japan and Orient Tours is offering a seven-day round-trip package to Hong Kong through May 31 on Northwest Airlines from $798 a person, including five nights in a hotel. A similar package to Bangkok, Thailand, costs from $998.
Under the new accord, Delta, American and Continental, which together account for less than 10 percent of United States traffic to Asia, will be allowed 90 additional round trips a week to Japan, almost triple the current 46 flights. Two more carriers, presumably U S Airways and T.W.A., will also be allowed to fly to Japan within the next two years. Meantime, United and Northwest, which together command 90 percent of United States carriers' traffic to Asia, plan to increase flights.
Add to that the unrestricted number of flights to the United States by Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, the many opportunitiess now available to other Japanese carriers and the flights likely to be shared by United States and Asian carriers, and the stage appears set for a better day-to-day deal for Asia-bound travelers. This is especially likely if, as the International Air Transport Association has forecast, Japan's share of trans-Pacific traffic continues to erode, causing Japanese carriers to fight back with permanent low fares.
Meantime, bargains exist now.
"In our 40 years in the Pacific," Mr. Bodmer of Japan and Orient Tours said, "we've almost never seen such low fares as we're seeing these days."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Offices Plugged In and Ready to Go

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Plug 'n' Go program, established in six downtown Manhattan office buildings a year ago to help attract new, small information-technology businesses to the Wall Street area, has helped lease 183,000 square feet of space and is expanding to three additional buildings.
The program involves prebuilt, prewired office spaces, usually of up to 2,500 square feet, leased for short terms at beginning annual rents of $16 a square foot -- up from $15 last year -- about 20 percent below market rents for downtown space. Last year, 79 companies with a total of 635 employees leased space in the six buildings. 
 In addition to the lower rents, the companies move into space already wired to link up their computers, saving about $1 a square foot, the cost of wiring the space themselves. They also move into buildings with in-house Internet service providers, cutting Internet costs about 30 percent.
The companies can also share a T-1, or high-capacity, communications line, further reducing costs.
The program's success is "a combination of location, price and simplicity," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, the local business improvement district, which set up Plug 'n' Go in collaboration with the city's Economic Development Corporation. "There's a general sense that downtown is an emerging center of the information-technology industry. And with Plug 'n' Go, a company knows what it's buying right away, can plug into their space and move right in. Small companies don't have the capacity to sit around and allocate personnel and other resources to plan and build out space."
Sharon Greenberger, who manages the program for the alliance, said it "hit a price point" that other areas of the city cannot meet. "Rents are higher elsewhere," Ms. Greenberger said. "These companies are often start-ups, and many of them are very price-sensitive."
Dynamind, a new-media company that develops corporate Web sites, moved into 2,600 square feet at 90 John Street last year.
"We had formed Dynamind in Connecticut and connected the state's schools and libraries to the Internet," said Tom Kwon, chief executive officer, whose company was one of the first in the Plug 'n' Go program. "We started to work with large companies, and we needed to go into a marketplace where we could compete, which meant New York. The Plug 'n' Go buildings are prewired, so the technology was right there. The rent is not that much. There are the tax abatements. And our audience is right here."
The resurgence of the economy, the stock market and Manhattan office leasing in general have also helped to make the program work. The Wall Street area, hard hit in the real estate recession of the early 90's, is bouncing back.
"More and more, there's a concentration of similar companies down here -- and they want to be together," Ms. Greenberger said, adding that more than 700 information-technology companies are leasing space downtown.
A prime factor in that concentration has been the leasing of 55 Broad Street. That building, once occupied by Drexel Burnham Lambert and vacant for five years, was transformed by the Rudin real estate family into the New York Information Technology Center and has become a hub of computer-intensive companies.
"Fifty-five Broad played an instrumental role," Ms. Greenberger said. "A lot of companies want to be close to 55 Broad. A lot of them wanted to go into 55 Broad, but it's full."
The new buildings in the program -- 50 Broadway, 75 Maiden Lane and 83 Maiden Lane -- are each making 20,000 square feet available. Three of the original six buildings -- 11 and 32 Broadway and 55 John Street -- are each adding 20,000 square feet to the program, bringing the total to about 300,000 square feet.
The other three buildings are 90 and 111 John Street and 90 William Street. The buildings are all considered Class B, or older buildings, which have had more difficulty in dealing with vacancies, and this kind of specialized marketing is helping solve the problem.
The Economic Development Corporation and the alliance each provided $200,000 in marketing assistance to start the program last year. Each original building owner contributed $10,000. This year, the city has provided an additional $184,000. The business improvement district has put in $100,000, the new building owners, $12,500 each, and the three original buildings that added space, $10,000 each.
Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation, credited Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan, offering tax benefits for development, as "the very important first step that gave 55 Broad what it needed to get going."
He cited a Coopers & Lybrand study last October that showed that the new-media business had doubled in jobs and companies in Manhattan over 18 months.
The study showed that the number of new-media companies in Manhattan had almost doubled, to 2,128, compared with the 1,175 found in the first survey in early 1996, and that the number of jobs had jumped 105 percent, to 55,973.
Most Plug 'n' Go leases are for from three to five years.
Mendy Braun, manager of 11 Broadway, which had been largely vacant, said 21 Plug 'n' Go leases, totaling 42,000 square feet, had been signed in his building through December. "The leases range from 500 to 12,000 square feet," he said. "For me, it's a success."
Ms. Greenberger said she had received calls from other downtown building owners interested in the program. She said that of the 120,000 square feet available this year under the program, between 15 and 20 leases were out for signing on close to 40,000 square feet.
Mr. Weisbrod of the Alliance for Downtown New York said the program was likely to expand. "Almost all the buildings recognize the spinoff impact," he said. "The program puts these buildings on the map for other information-technology companies thinking of leasing space downtown, as well as for the companies in the program that will grow and expand into larger spaces."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Investor Optimism Over Earnings Sends Market Higher

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Continued investor optimism over corporate earnings helped Wall Street weather early selling yesterday as stocks finished higher for a second day.
Though markets overseas were mixed -- after their sharp gains on Monday helped the Dow Jones industrial average rise more than 200 points and the Standard & Poor's 500 index break through 1,000 points for the first time -- investors' belief that corporate profits have not been significantly hurt by Asia's economic slowdown translated into purchases. 
 Investors turned away from drug company shares, like Warner-Lambert and Bristol-Myers Squibb, which had been the market darlings on Monday as investors reacted to news of a possible merger of SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome.
But semiconductor issues like Intel, Altera, Motorola and Micron Technology were among the big gainers. Semiconductor companies had taken a hit at the end of the fourth quarter as investors feared that their exposure to Asia would lead to earnings disappointments.
But "when you put it all together in a global economy, it's not that bad," David Wu, a semiconductor analyst at the ABN Amro Chicago Corporation in San Francisco, said of the earnings reports of these companies.
Though companies experiencing earnings shortfalls have cited the economic weakness in Asia, it was "not the No. 1 reason for their problems," Mr. Wu said. He pointed to National Semiconductor, which said on Monday that sales and earnings in the current quarter would not meet forecasts, primarily because of production problems in one of its recently acquired units. Only a small part of an expected earnings shortfall during this quarter will be caused by trouble in Asia, the company said. At other semiconductor companies, like Linear Technology and Maxim Integrated Products, problems in Asia were offset by strength in the United States and European markets, Mr. Wu said.
Recovering from a downturn that kept the index lower through much of the day, the Dow industrials rose 52.57 points, to 8,160.35. The index now stands 98.96 points away from its record high of Aug. 6. The S.& P. 500 rose 4.73 points, closing at 1,006.00, another new high.
In two trading days, the Dow has gained 253.85 points, eclipsing last week's entire 205.76-point increase. The S.& P. 500 has done the same, rising 25.72 points this week, more than last week's 22.69-point increase.
Though it did not surpass the previous week's gains, the Nasdaq composite index roared ahead yesterday, climbing 13.45 points, to 1,666.34. Those gains put the Nasdaq within 79.51 points of its closing high of 1,745.85, reached on Oct. 9. The Nasdaq, which contains a heavy concentration of technology issues, is now up 6.11 percent this year, more than the Dow, up 3.19 percent, or the S.& P., which is up 3.66 percent.
"You could see that people were looking for things that hadn't participated in the rally," said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York. "People were looking for opportunities. They weren't really chasing the big winners."
Though the Asian financial crisis has had relatively little impact on the earnings of American companies thus far, it has caused Bond Procope and some other investment managers to focus more on companies with domestic operations that will not be greatly hurt by the Asian crisis.
At Bond Procope, that means buying companies like Suiza Foods, a dairy and refrigerated foods distributor, as well as Arbor Drugs, a Michigan drugstore chain.
At Provident Investment Counsel in Pasadena, Calif., Michael Powers, a portfolio manager, said the firm was looking for health care stocks and specialty financial companies like Associates First Capital, Household International and the MBNA Corporation. Those companies should have strong revenue growth despite the situation in Asia, he said.
As for the Asian markets themselves, despite their recent show of strength, some analysts continue to raise the caution flag. While last year's declines in Asia make those markets look inexpensive based on 1997 earnings, their future is still uncertain, said Leila Heckman, a managing director and head of the global asset allocation at Salomon Smith Barney.
"No one really knows what's going to happen to earnings" in the countries hit by the economic crisis, she said. "To be very enthusiastic on those markets is very premature. We don't know whether the Asian markets are going to be more like Mexico," which has recovered fairly quickly from the crisis caused by the devaluation of the peso several years ago, or "more like Japan," which has been in an economic slump for eight years.

HEADLINE: New Data Show the Economy Is a Degree Cooler

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A barometer of future economic activity was unchanged in December, but still suggested that economic growth would continue into 1998.
The index of leading indicators for December stood at 104.5, unchanged from the revised figure for November, the Conference Board, a business-sponsored economic research group, reported yesterday. Economists had expected the index to rise a tenth of 1 percent in December. 
 The pause ends five straight months of gains for the index.
"The leading indicators had a tremendous year in 1997, with the leading index advancing at twice its historical pace over the past 12 months," said Michael Boldin, senior economist at the Conference Board.
"With no change for the leading index in December, however, we see signs that economic growth will moderate in 1998," Mr. Boldin added.
Separately, the Commerce Department reported that sales of new single-family homes tumbled 9.7 percent in December, the sharpest monthly drop in more than two years.
The retreat came after a November gain that was the highest in 11 years and still left sales for 1997 at a 19-year high.
The 800,000 new homes sold last year marked a 5.7 percent rise from 1996 and the highest total since 817,000 in 1978. But the drop in December came despite continued declines in mortgage rates.
The Conference Board said 6 of the 10 components of the index of leading indicators rose in December, led by money supply.
Big-ticket orders to manufacturers, excluding military contracts, showed the biggest decline. The drop in orders was caused partly by canceled aircraft orders from Asia, said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio.

HEADLINE: Realtor to Pay $165 Million For 3 Helmsley Office Towers

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The SL Green Realty Corporation chipped off a piece of the vast Helmsley real estate empire Monday night by agreeing to pay $165 million for control of three midtown office towers, including the Graybar Building.
SL Green, a real estate investment trust based in Manhattan, said the purchase agreement covered the acquisition of 1466 Broadway and the long-term leaseholds of 25 West 43d Street and the Graybar Building, at 420 Lexington Avenue, a total of 1.8 million square feet of office space. The company said it expected to invest about $10 million in renovating and upgrading the three properties. 
 "They're good, solid real estate," Stephen L. Green, chairman of SL Green Realty, said. "You can't get better location than the Graybar Building, on top of Grand Central Terminal. And 1466 Broadway is in the eye of the storm in Times Square, probably the most exciting area in the world today."
The sale is the latest step taken by Leona Helmsley in dismantling the empire built by her late husband, Harry B. Helmsley, over five decades. She hired Eastdil Realty to organize the sale of the properties, some of which are entangled in a complex web of partnerships.
Mrs. Helmsley recently signed a contract to sell the 1.2 million-square-foot skyscraper at 140 Broadway to Larry Silverstein for $191 million. And over the next two weeks, she is expected to sell her stake in the landmark Flatiron Building, the Harley hotel chain, a package of residential properties, two land parcels, jewelry marts in Miami and Los Angeles, and possibly the New York Helmsley Hotel.
The Helmsley properties sparked intense bidding wars among developers, investment banks and foreign investors as the economy rebounded from a devastating recession in the early 1990's and as the office vacancy rate in midtown fell to 9.1 percent, the lowest point in more than a decade, according to Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company. Prospective buyers, who are jostling each other over virtually every property that comes on the market, are assuming that the economy will continue to improve and that office rents will rise sharply.
Mr. Green outbid several groups, including one led by Peter Malkin, a longtime partner in various Helmsley properties who recently ended a bitter feud with Mrs. Helmsley. Mr. Malkin had also lost out in the bidding for One Penn Plaza, a 2.4 million-square-foot tower next to Madison Square Garden that is being sold to Vornado Realty Trust for $420 million.
The purchase of the three Helmsley properties brings to 15 the number of properties in the SL Green portfolio. Mr. Green, who took his company public last year, recently paid $58 million for 800,000 square feet of commercial space at 17 Battery Place in lower Manhattan. Rather than chasing expensive trophy properties, Mr. Green has specialized in older commercial buildings in good locations.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Calvin Klein's new campaign casts off the old stark, dark look and dons a happy, healthy one.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
YEARS ago, "Garbo Talks!" and "Garbo Laughs!" were hot news from Hollywood; now, here's hot news from Seventh Avenue: Calvin Smiles!
The designer Calvin Klein, in a major departure, has decided to alter the imagery in his fashion campaigns significantly by putting on a happier face. That's noteworthy because of his influence on other marketers as well as on the popular culture. 
 Beginning with magazine advertisements and outdoor posters scheduled to appear next month, Mr. Klein and his company, Calvin Klein Inc. in New York, will present themselves with a more upbeat, positive tone and a more athletic, clean-cut look while retaining their trademarks of sensuality and cool eroticism. The 20-something male and female models in the campaign are socializing in groups rather than preening in isolation and appear gleaming rather than grungy. Many smile. Some even -- yes -- laugh.
"I think people will be surprised; they'll say: 'Omigod! This is not where he's been,' " Mr. Klein said in a telephone interview. "But I think young people, who are always looking for something new and interesting, are going to relate to this."
"The real big change for me is that I feel everything is prettier, healthier, cleaner, attractive," he added. "It's no longer the downtown, hip kind of thing that I've been doing for the last couple years. I think it's a fresh and clean kind of sexy, which seems sexier now than another dirty-looking model."
The changes will be visible in pitches for all offerings of the Klein empire, from the top-of-the-line Collection clothing to the midline CK sportswear to Calvin Klein jeans to licensed merchandise like eyewear, home furnishings, footwear and watches. Klein sells $4.4 billion worth of products annually around the world.
The shifts in the Kleinian Zeitgeist came after several other fashion advertisers started offering consumers bright-eyed, optimistic campaigns with well-scrubbed, beaming faces. The ads perhaps most emblematic of that trend are those for the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, in which well-groomed preppies cavort and cuddle.
"It's wonderful to see the reaction to people enjoying themselves," said Michael Toth, president and executive creative director at Toth Design and Advertising in New York and Concord, Mass., which until recently created those Hilfiger campaigns.
"What we call the SoHo elite were taking the road to see how serious and depressed they could be," he added. "We wanted to represent the other side of what life has to offer."
Others celebrating the pursuit of happiness in ads include the retailers Abercrombie & Fitch and Gap Inc. and the cosmetics giant Estee Lauder, which last year introduced a fragrance named Happy.
"It seems we're in a very positive state of mind right now," said Sam Shahid, president and creative director at Shahid & Company in New York, who formerly worked for Mr. Klein and now creates exuberant campaigns for Abercrombie & Fitch centered on barely dressed collegiate youths.
"The economy is good," he added. "People are having a good time. So we try to have a good time."
Richard Leonard, vice president at Zandl Group, a youth marketing consulting company in New York, said the trend was widespread among younger consumers, primarily girls.
"We're calling it 'sunny side up,' " Mr. Leonard said, "a focus on a positive, upbeat outlook. Anything cheerful is striking a chord with these kids. And we are seeing this trend growing."
Mr. Klein demurred at a suggestion that he was inspired by the success his competitors have achieved with cheery Americana.
"I wouldn't make the comparison," Mr. Klein said, because rather than being imitative, the change in his ad imagery "reflects the clothes, the styles, which instead of being hard edged are softer, prettier, more romantic."
The change has been foreshadowed by smiling models in recent ads for some Klein products, including men's underwear and the women's fragrance Contradiction.
But the coming shifts are far more extensive and they contrast markedly with the look that Mr. Klein, as he sought to push the envelope, has promoted for most of this decade: sullen, brooding and sometimes disheveled models. The stark, dark mood that has dominated those ads -- and the thin, occasionally gaunt appearances of some models -- led critics to castigate that school of advertising by labeling it "heroin chic."
"Clearly people were upset by 'heroin chic,' and people accused me of it," Mr. Klein said. "We thought it was creative, but it was perceived as drug addicts and messy. People don't want that now."
The new ads and posters show good-looking models in wholesome pursuits -- often outdoors -- that have rarely been associated with the world according to Klein. One depicts three models, including the Klein mainstay Christy Turlington, playing tug-of-war. In another, youngsters lie on a pier in their socks and underwear, waving their hands and feet in the air. In a third ad, men help load a potato truck. Others portray models hiking or walking in fields or the woods.
"I think kids are going to think this is really cool," Mr. Klein said of the campaign, photographed by Steven Meisel, "and are going to want to identify with this advertising."
As usual, the ads have been created by CRK Advertising, Klein's in-house unit.
Grouping the models together "reflects a far more social life style," said Alan Karo, the senior vice president at Klein who oversees CRK, "as we try to distance ourselves from the strike-a-pose-against-a-backdrop-in-a-studio look."
"We've kept the cool and sexy, and softened the edge, because that's what's happening in the marketplace," he added.
The campaign brings other changes. For the first time, Ms. Turlington and the other signature Klein model, Kate Moss, will appear together in ads. (Interestingly, combining the initials of their given names spells "CK.") And in one ad, Ms. Moss wears a revived version of the 1970's Klein jeans as introduced by Brooke Shields.
"You could play it today and be reasonably successful," said Robert L. Treifus, senior vice president for worldwide communications at Klein, referring to the once-notorious commercial in which Ms. Shields confided that "nothing" came between her and her "Calvins." Mr. Treifus likened the new campaign to that earlier work, which he described as "outgoing, aspirational, fun."
The ads will run in magazines such as Allure, Cigar Aficionado, Details, Marie Claire, Men's Journal, Out, Paper and W. A 16-page foldout will accompany selected copies of the March issues of Vogue, Elle, GQ and Vanity Fair.
The campaign "is obviously a departure, and a dramatic one," said Mitchell B. Fox, vice president and publisher of Vanity Fair.
"These images will tap into the sensibility of the target audience, how they see themselves, feel about themselves, now," he said.
The ads will also appear on bus shelters, on popcorn bags in movie theaters and, in another first, on popcorn boxes sold at Madison Square Garden.

HEADLINE: 5 Companies Are Seeking Inter-Continental Hotels

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
At least five hotel companies are bidding to buy Inter-Continental Hotels, the Japanese-owned company whose portfolio includes some 175 hotels and resorts such as the Inter-Continental New York, the Mark Hopkins in San Francisco, the Willard in Washington, Le Grande in Paris and the Mayfair in London, in nearly 70 countries.
The winning bid, in an auction that has been under way about a month and is in its second round, is expected to top $2.5 billion. But the bidding could go much higher, according to a person close to the negotiations, because Inter-Continental is one of the last major hotel companies -- and the only one currently available -- with upscale properties in most of the world's major cities. 
 Inter-Continental also has more than 20 mid-market Forum hotels in 15 European countries. And at a time when travel sets new records almost every year, both brands are well regarded by international travelers.
Bidders in the auction include Marriott International Inc., Patriot American Hospitality Inc. and the Meditrust Companies, the nursing home operator that recently bought La Quinta Inns. Also bidding are the large British companies Bass P.L.C., a holding company that is an owner of Holiday Inns, and the Ladbroke Group, owner of the Hilton International brand.
Conspicuously absent from the bidding, apparently, are the Hilton Hotels Corporation and Starwood Hotels and Resorts Trust, a real estate investment trust. Starwood, which is close to completing its $1.6 billion acquisition of the Westin chain, recently outbid Hilton for the ITT Corporation and its Sheraton hotel chain.
Founded by Pan American Airways in 1946 when there was a dearth of good hotels for its globe-trotting passengers, Inter-Continental was purchased from a British company in 1988 by the privately owned Saison Group, a retail conglomerate based in Tokyo.
Saison recently decided to withdraw from the hotel business in order to reduce its debt and concentrate on its retail business, according to Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper. Saison originally planned an initial public offering for Inter-Continental, prior to listing its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, but apparently decided that it would be more profitable to sell the business.
Two of the current bidders are real estate investment trusts: Patriot American, which recently bought the Wyndham Hotel Corporation for $1.1 billion, and is buying Interstate Hotels for $2.1 billion, and Meditrust, which was outbid by Patriot American for Interstate, but agreed to pay $2.1 billion for the 270 midpriced La Quinta Inns.
At a hotel industry conference in New York yesterday, Paul Nussbaum, the chief executive of Patriot American, said his company was looking at acquisitions totaling $3 billion. He added that he was looking for debt held by Asian companies, according to Bloomberg News Service, because the economic turmoil in the region had made it available at a good price.
None of the companies appear to have a decided advantage in the bidding for Inter-Continental.
Inter-Continental is also attractive because it owns real estate, in contrast to many hotel chains that manage or franchise properties but own few of them. That difference makes Inter-Continental doubly valuable to a real estate investment trust, especially a "paired share" trust, which is allowed to manage as well as own property, and can trade the separate management and real estate companies as a single unit.

HEADLINE: A Pathmark Project With a Difference

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
In East Harlem, a plan for a big new Pathmark supermarket gave rise to a protracted battle between a community development group and smaller shopkeepers afraid that their businesses would suffer, with politicians lining up on either side. But in the Bronx, where another community group is trying to build a giant Pathmark shopping center, local merchants are among its biggest supporters.
The $29 million project, near the intersection of the Cross-Bronx and Sheridan Expressways, has sailed through the first few steps in the approval process without the faintest sign of protest, winning unanimous approval by Community Board 3 on Jan. 13. On Monday, Borough President Fernando Ferrer forwarded it to the City Planning Commission with his tentative approval, conditioned upon a review of its financing. 
 Sprawling across 10 sloping acres east of Crotona Park, the site might seem perfectly suited to the kind of big-box stores that have cropped up all over New York in formerly industrial areas. Indeed, Pathmark plans a 24-hour, 55,000-square-foot store, its largest in the Bronx.
But executives at MBD Community Housing Corporation, the developer, have designed the center to serve shoppers from the closest neighborhoods -- Morrisania, Bronx River, East Tremont, and Crotona -- not the whole borough. Besides the Pathmark, they said, it will have a shoe store, a stationer, clothing shops, an electronics retailer and, if all goes according to plan, the first bank branch in all of Community District 3. Still, what is most striking about the project is the apparent absence of any real opposition despite the similarities to East Harlem, where the Pathmark finally broke ground last August.
James Smith, owner of Morales Discount and Hardware, a block from the development site, said most of the merchants he has talked to were looking forward to increased traffic created by the shopping center, not fearing it -- even the bodega owners along 174th Street.
"The stores that actually cater to their customers will do fine," he said. "All the amount of construction workers that are going to be here for the two years that it takes to get built -- they're going to be selling so much sandwiches, so much beer, so much soda. It's got to boost this area."
In East Harlem, it was the medium-size grocers who put up the stiffest resistance. But Stanley Sorkin, a spokesman for Krasdale Foods, which helped pay for the fight against the Pathmark in East Harlem and which supplies many medium-size grocery stores from its Hunts Point plant, said he was unaware of the recent progress on the Crotona shopping center plan.
Mr. Sorkin was hired last year to replace Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist who has fought against megastores across New York City but who was accused of racial polarization in the battle against the East Harlem supermarket. Mr. Lipsky said he had no plans to get involved in the Crotona project.
Mr. Sorkin declined to say whether his company and its customers would oppose the Crotona plan, which is being backed by the Retail Initiative, a bank that finances inner-city supermarket projects. The same group financed the East Harlem Pathmark.
Mr. Sorkin said medium-size grocers and their suppliers would be watching to see whether the Crotona Pathmark project receives any public assistance. The city's Economic Development Corporation, which owns the site, is negotiating to lease it or sell it to MBD Community Housing. But Charles Millard, president of the agency, said he expected any deal to be done "at a market rate."
Any additional low-interest loans or grants would be a major concern, Mr. Sorkin said. "These subsidies," he said, "have been very difficult to come by for the small-scale store owner. If there's public money involved in the future, it shouldn't just run to the large chains. Small retailers should be offered the opportunity to grow their businesses, too."
Carla Pennyman, development director at MBD, said the shopping center project and the choice of Pathmark as an anchor tenant were the outgrowth of a 1992 community planning effort with wide participation, in which residents overwhelmingly named a modern supermarket and other stores as high priorities.
For MBD, an outgrowth of the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes, a coalition formed in the 1970's by local residents unwilling or unable to move from their community, the shopping center represented a significant shift. Having built or rehabilitated 2,300 housing units over the years, MBD found itself having to meet the shopping needs of a neighborhood it helped to repopulate.
The site was the scene of a dim chapter in urban renewal efforts. In 1982, seeing -- some would say imagining -- a pent up demand for manufacturing plants in the Bronx, the Koch administration decided to clear 25 abandoned buildings there and build an industrial park. The city, expecting tenants to materialize, even paved a wide access road through the middle of the property.
A road to nowhere, as it turned out. Not a single company ever arrived.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Gifts to Neediest Cases Fund Set Record

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
With more than three weeks remaining in its annual fund-raising appeal, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund broke its previous record for total donations yesterday, making this the most successful campaign since the fund was established in 1912.
Contributions received yesterday pushed the fund's total for this drive to $5,195,966. The previous record was set in 1991-92, when Times readers gave $5,083,551. 
 During the current appeal, more than 10,000 people have contributed to the fund, many of them responding to daily articles in The Times that chronicle the struggles of New Yorkers who have fallen on hardship.
Although most donations are $25 to $50, an unexpected windfall of larger amounts came yesterday from trusts and estates that name the fund as a beneficiary. More than $350,000 has been received from estates and trusts this year, more than twice as much as during the last drive.
When the current three-month appeal ends on Feb. 28, every penny will be distributed to seven of the city's largest and most prominent charities. Nothing will be deducted to pay for administering the fund because The Times pays all overhead expenses.
The increase in donations this year may well reflect the healthy economy of the New York region and the nation. But the agencies that benefit from the fund said it also highlighted the generosity of a city often derided as callous and greedy. "It shows that even in good times, New Yorkers are aware that some of their neighbors aren't doing as well," said Stephen Solender, executive director of the UJA-Federation of New York.
Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, said he was heartened that donors were able to see past cheerful headlines about the economy. "It can be hard for people to believe there is so much suffering around them in the midst of budget surpluses and a soaring stock market," Mr. Coltoff said. "I'd like to think this year's record is a result of people taking more responsibility for the well-being of their neighbors."
Still, the agency executives warned against complacency. New York City's unemployment rate, about 8.7 percent, is among the highest in the nation, and more than two million city residents live below the poverty level.
David Jones, executive director of the Community Service Society of New York, said that there would be more suffering in the next five years as an expected 400,000 welfare recipients lost benefits. "People may be feeling euphoric about the economy, but if you are among the unskilled or the downsized, things are only going to get tougher," he said.
All of the agencies said that even though donations to the fund had risen, they had not kept up with the increased number of people seeking assistance. "There are still way too many people we're unable to help," Mr. Solender said. "We're not even close."
This is the 86th season that The Times has raised money to help the city's most desperate residents. A Christmas Day encounter with a homeless immigrant persuaded Adolph S. Ochs, The Times's publisher, to start the annual drive with articles profiling "The 100 Neediest Cases."
In many ways, the articles eight decades later are no different. This year, they told of people like Sylvian Brown, an immigrant from Barbados who has been unable to work since he lost his eyesight last summer. With help from the Neediest Cases Fund, Mr. Brown has been able to buy food for his children.
"This year's level of generosity boosts my faith in people and brings comfort to us all," said Megan McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. "Because as we all know, the giver may at one point become the recipient."
 
HOW TO HELP
 
Checks payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund should be sent to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087, or any of these

HEADLINE: Citadel of Russia's Wasteful Health System

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: TOMSK, Russia

 BODY:
Tucked carefully into a pine forest, bathed in the sparkling Siberian air and filled with enough amenities to make a country club look Spartan, the Pediatric Tuberculosis Center here seems to sit on the cutting edge of Russian medicine.
In a nation whose Government has concluded that half of the hospitals are too dilapidated to function, the center is in the midst of a robust development program. It has a dozen buildings, a school for patients and a staff of 134. 
 What the 500-bed hospital does not have, in this country where President Boris N. Yeltsin has called health care "our No. 1 national security crisis," are patients. Last year there were never more than 20 children here at a time. This month there are 13.
That is because the Tomsk hospital system is a citadel of waste. There are 88 hospitals in this city of 500,000, more than in Boston. Twelve of them treat TB patients alone. There is a major clinical center with 21 departments and four surgical branches, and a university medical center duplicates almost exactly what is offered in the municipal center.
The hospitals have enormous heating costs, fleets of cars, large, poorly trained staffs and patient services that overlap.
"If it was just one hospital burning money, then we could live with that," said Tatyana Grishina, a tuberculosis expert at the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences who has been to Tomsk to study the system here. "But it is not one hospital. And it is not just tuberculosis. It is the whole story of Russian medicine.
"People talk about reform all the time in Russia. But nobody wants it. Reform is one of the dirtiest words in the country."
Health officials here, and throughout Russia, still dole out scarce money based almost solely on the number of beds in each hospital, without regard to whether they are needed or how they are used.
As a result, the Pediatric Center will receive nearly $1 million in regional funds this year. With that money it will subject its 13 children to a needlessly expensive, anachronistic treatment regimen that the World Health Organization has long considered worse than useless.
There may be no better way to understand the immense obstacles that reforms face in the Russian provinces -- where they are needed most -- than to look at how a place like Tomsk deals with health care.
Compared with other cities in Russia it is neither backward nor unique. One of Siberia's oldest cities, filled with stately wooden houses that have withstood a century of snow, Tomsk used to live on an allowance dispensed from Moscow. All that has changed.
Industry has atrophied. The nearly free transportation system, essential in such a remote place, has virtually disappeared. Without it, half of the region has lost its access to decent medical treatment.
The money from Moscow may be gone, but the network designed by the Soviet Government -- grand, cumbersome, repetitive and blind to the perverse and often baffling economics of medicine -- lives on.
"This is more than a medical system," said Sergei Banin, Tomsk's No. 2 health official. "It is a social system. We are feeding the poor. We are providing thousands of jobs. We want an evolution here, not a revolution."
But there has been nothing gradual about the decline in the health of the Russian people.
Tomsk, like the rest of Russia, reels under a remarkable surge in infectious and parasitic diseases, and constant growth in cases of deadly heart disease, alcohol poisoning and cancer. Last year more people in Russia died from tuberculosis, which is entirely curable, than got the disease in the United States.
The Government now predicts that the Russian population will shrink by at least one million people each year for at least a decade. That has happened only a few times in history -- and until now always in countries engulfed by war, plague or famine.
Many people say national officials simply need to spend more on their citizens' health. Money would help, of course. Last year Russia spent only about $75 a person on health care; the United States spent nearly $4,000.
But increasingly, experts cite another statistic that may be more telling: Russia has 130 hospital beds for every 10,000 people, a figure matched in no major country on earth. The United States has fewer than 40 beds per 10,000 people.
"You could not invent a more ridiculous health care system than the one we now have," said Igor Linok, the chief administrator of the Tomsk regional health insurance fund.
Dr. Linok is a physician and an economist. It is his job to try to find a rational way to spread money across the Tomsk region, which has one million people in an area about the size of England.
"Everyone always says there is not enough money," he said. "We are poor, of course. But I don't even agree that there is not enough money. Look at the waste in this place."
Most countries no longer have TB hospitals. Tomsk has 12. With a rate of 80 cases per 100,000 residents here, the incidence has more than doubled in a decade. But hospitals do not help. The World Health Organization has long argued that tuberculosis can be treated better and less expensively with drugs at home.
Merlin, the British relief agency, has created a pilot program to supply drugs and the expertise to use them properly. It has had some success, but there has been a fight every step of the way.
"There are cultural expectations here that are almost impossible to overcome," said Gini Gleissberg, the Merlin coordinator in Tomsk. "Patients expect this long period of hospitalization. Lots of times a few months in a hospital beats being at home without work or money."
Three-quarters of the $4 million spent on tuberculosis treatment and testing here is wasted, Merlin says. Health department officials do not disagree. In 1996 a total of 532 children were discharged from various TB hospitals in Tomsk after average stays of a little more than three months. Tuberculosis had been diagnosed in only 23. The rest were there because their parents had the disease, or because they were suspected of being infected.
The New York Public Health Research Institute, with money from the financier and philanthropist George Soros, has offered to help Tomsk shift its health priorities.
The Soros plan, as it is called here, is simple. "Let's spend money on what works," Dr. Alex Goldfarb, who has been the plan's chief salesman, said in a recent interview. "And let's help people make that transition to a new way of life. But if there is no switch, there should be no funds. To get the money, people here need to get rid of those hospital beds."
That kind of talk drives many leaders in Russian medicine -- already sick of being told how to do their jobs by outsiders -- to open revolt.
"I thought humanitarian aid came without strings attached," said Aleksei Primyak, who runs the largest national tuberculosis center in Moscow and is seen as the official voice of the conservative medical establishment. "Who are these people to tell us how to treat our citizens?"
But the desperate competition for money has turned the medical system into a major political issue. And the problems are by no means limited to TB. "The hospital system," said Governor Viktor Kress, a reformer who is nonetheless wary of moving too fast, "is one of the greatest lobbies left in the land."
That is clear in Tomsk. The city has two large heart centers that can serve 1,000 patients each. They have similar equipment. The one operated by the national Government has better staff, but it is open to patients only five days a week.
"Don't have a heart attack on the weekend," said Vladimir Mashukov, the chief doctor at the Tomsk Institute of Cardiology, the national center. He says his budget "has been irregular and chaotic."
"We are hostages to the past," he said.
There are also four cancer centers here. And Tomsk, a university town with a branch of the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences, is considered progressive by most outsiders.
The Children's Sanitarium is exhibit A in any attempt to explain why health care in the provinces seems stuck in another era. "For the money we are spending on that place we could move all those children and their families to Israel and let them live by the Dead Sea," said Dr. Linok, the health economist.
The center is the perfect symbol for the failings of hospitals from one end of the country to the other. There are too many people on staff, but no alternative jobs for them. There are not enough patients, because patients -- or in this case, their parents -- do not want to report their illnesses for fear they will be locked in a sanitarium for months. The hospital duplicates services offered less than two miles away at the city's central TB clinic.
Of course, that is not the way they see it at the sanitarium.
"I am not a diplomat," said Anatoly M. Shatokhin, the affable chief doctor at the Pediatric Center. "I am a doctor. And I have to tell you that your system may work best for you, but ours works best for us. Children need to be nurtured. They need a setting in which to recover."
That means in a hospital, he says. Keeping people in a hospital for routine tuberculosis treatment, still normal here, is rare in the West. The cost of such treatment, an average here of $1,134 per cure, is more than five times the cost of using drugs on outpatients, according to the W.H.O.
"If you look at the numbers, the logic is obvious," said Olga Sharaburova, the chief tuberculosis doctor for the region. "But logic has never been used here yet. So you can understand why people wonder about it know."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Buffett's Company Is Amassing Silver, Pushing Prices Up

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, one of the best-known and most widely followed investors in America, has accumulated a large portion of the world's silver supply, helping to drive the price of the metal to the highest level in nine years.
In so doing, the company, Berkshire Hathaway, has made an investment that would be most likely to succeed if inflation returned, something that most investors view as unlikely. But it could also pay off if industrial demand for the metal continued to outstrip supply. 
 It is not the first time that Mr. Buffett has gone against the conventional wisdom; he has gained fame over the decades for his willingness to make large purchases of stocks he deems to be undervalued, and then to hold on to them.
But the word that so much silver -- more than 20 percent of the world supply by one estimate -- had been bought, inevitably recalled memories of the silver accumulation by Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas oilman, nearly two decades ago. Purchases by Mr. Hunt and his family sent the price of silver briefly above $50 an ounce in 1980, before the market plunged, leading to financial distress for the family, which had borrowed heavily.
Berkshire Hathaway said yesterday that since last summer it had accumulated silver now worth more than $850 million. Since it began buying silver's price has leaped more than 50 percent. The total stake -- 129.7 million ounces -- appears to be larger than the amount accumulated by the Hunts, though the Hunts controlled a far larger percentage of the world supply. But the dollar value of the Berkshire Hathaway stake is much lower because silver now sells for less than one-seventh of what it cost at the peak in 1980.
Berkshire said the silver amounted to only 2 percent of its investment portfolio, measured at cost. So there is no risk that it, like the Hunts, will be unable to meet its commitments.
The rise in silver prices has come even as the price of gold, which also gains luster when investors fear inflation, has weakened, and has drawn attention from investors. A trader in silver options filed suit in Federal court in New York last week contending that a commodities trading organization had been manipulating the price.
Berkshire said it had planned to disclose the purchases when its annual report was released next month. But it said it made the disclosure yesterday in response to the movement in silver prices.
Responding to the sharp rise, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has said it is monitoring the market closely. Last night, Geoffrey F. Aronow, the director of the commission's enforcement division, declined to comment on the Berkshire announcement, saying, "I am not in a position to comment on any particular situation."
William Byers, the director of futures research at the Wall Street firm of Bear, Stearns & Company, said Mr. Buffett realized that the demand for silver outstripped supply and was simply responding to that condition. "This is a situation that has been known for some time," Mr. Byers said. Mr. Buffett, he said, "recognized the fundamentals and he simply made another long-term investment."
Because a large part of the silver that Berkshire has bought has not been delivered, the announcement by Berkshire raised the possibility of some speculators' being unable to come up with the silver that is owed to Berkshire. But Berkshire said it would make accommodations in such situations, which, Mr. Byers said, made it clear that Mr. Buffett, did not want to "squeeze the market."
Berkshire said it began buying silver on July 25, a day when silver futures closed at $4.32 an ounce, and made its last purchase on Jan. 12, when the price closed at $5.475 an ounce. It said it had no plans now to buy or sell the metal.
Yesterday, the current silver futures contract, requiring delivery in March, closed at $6.615 an ounce, up 36.7 cents an ounce for the day and 53 percent higher than when Berkshire began buying the metal.
Mr. Buffett said that he had first bought silver more than 30 years ago, after the United States Government stopped making silver coins and stopped backing dollar bills with the metal.
But he said that in recent years his company had not owned the metal until July. The company's announcement said that "widely published reports have shown that bullion inventories have fallen very materially, because of an excess of user demand over mine production and reclamation," and that the company believed that a balance of supply and demand "was only likely to be re-established by a somewhat higher price."
Berkshire said that it had taken delivery of 87.51 million ounces of silver, and was owed another 42.2 million ounces under contracts that expire at varied dates through March 2. It said all the silver had been purchased in London.
The Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, where silver contracts trade in this country, knows of 103 million ounces in warehouses that it monitors. That is down from 172 million when Berkshire began buying. London warehouse levels are not publicly disclosed.
The figures would indicate that there is enough silver available to cover delivery. But Berkshire said that if any sellers "should have trouble making timely delivery, Berkshire is willing to defer delivery for a reasonable period upon payment of a reasonable fee."
In any case, the market now appears to be far larger than when the Hunts went on their buying spree. Reuters quoted one consulting firm, CPM Group, as saying that Berkshire's stake amounted to about 20 percent of the silver market.
At the peak of the Hunt buying, according to statements by Paul A. Volcker, then the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and a man intimately involved with efforts to bail out the Hunts after the price collapsed, the Hunts controlled about 110 million ounces of silver. At the time, Mr. Volcker said, there were about 170 million ounces of silver available. Those figures represent the amount of bullion in circulation, but do not include silver yet to be mined or in products like jewelry.
When the Hunts were accumulating their position, they and many investors believed that there was no way that rampant inflation could be checked and that the prices of hard assets like precious metals could only continue to rise.
Now, the opposite consensus prevails, with inflation deemed to be quiet and likely to stay that way, and many investors fearful that Asia's financial troubles will lead to deflation. Silver has aspects both of a precious metal, viewed by some as a storehouse of value, and as an industrial commodity. So while it could rise in the absence of general inflation, a big rise would be more likely if inflation in fact was rising.
Silver has recently traded in what is called backwardation, which is to say that silver for quick delivery costs more than silver for delivery some months later. So while silver for March delivery costs $6.615 an ounce, silver for delivery a year later, in March 1999, costs $6.39, or 3.4 percent less. That reflects concerns about a possible squeeze on current supplies, and is an indication of the fact that huge quantities of silver have been accumulated.
Such a condition is not uncommon in agricultural commodities, reflecting expectations of an anticipated harvest. But it is very unusual in a precious metal. In July, when Mr. Buffett began buying, silver for delivery a year later was quoted at a premium of 5.6 percent over the then-current quote.
Last week, a trader in silver options, Kerry Seale, a farmer from British Columbia, filed suit in Federal court in New York contending that Phibro, a commodities trading firm, had moved silver out of the United States to force up the price. He said he had lost $164,000.
Phibro -- which is owned by Travelers Group, in which Berkshire has a big investment -- denied the allegations. Berkshire said it had used only one broker for its purchases, but did not say if it was Phibro.

HEADLINE: Assemblyman Wins Vote for Flake's Seat

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Backed by the long-time incumbent and the Queens Democratic Party, Gregory W. Meeks, a State Assemblyman, won a contentious five-candidate race last night to succeed Representative Floyd H. Flake.
With all of the vote counted, Mr. Meeks, a 44-year-old former prosecutor, finished with a commanding 57 percent.
Mr. Meeks had put together a broad coalition of Democrats in the Sixth Congressional District, despite the presence in the election of two of his Democratic colleagues in the Legislature with longer tenures in elective office as well as a well-financed Republican. 
 Mr. Meeks's most prominent opponent was State Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., a veteran Queens legislator who served briefly in Congress 11 years ago, and had also raised considerable money and assembled a formidable campaign organization. After failing to secure the Democratic nomination, Mr. Waldon ran on the Conservative and Independence lines.
"This campaign had a mission," Mr. Meeks said, standing in a Queens restaurant amid a collection of some of the city's most prominent Democrats. "We presented our ideas for the future and we did it convincingly."
Mr. Meeks, a former head of the statewide Council of Black Elected Officials, pointed to his election as a significant event in the development of a new generation of black political leaders in New York City.
"My role, as a part of a new generation of African-American leadership, is to take us to the next phase of the civil rights movement: that is, the economic development of our community," he said.
Mr. Meeks, who was born in Harlem and grew up in public housing, is a graduate of Adelphi University and the Howard University School of Law. He is a former assistant district attorney in Queens and went on to become a judge of the State Workers Compensation Board.
Mr. Waldon had 21 percent of the vote. The remaining votes were split among three other candidates. Celestine V. Miller, a school district superintendent, ran on the Republican line and had 13 percent. Assemblywoman Barbara M. Clark, a Democrat who also failed to win her party's nomination, secured enough voter signatures to run on her own ballot line and won 9 percent. The last candidate was Mary Cronin, on the Right to Life line, who received 1 percent.
The special election in the Sixth District was one of several contests yesterday. In another, a special election in southern Brooklyn to fill the remainder of the term of former Assemblyman Jules Polonetsky, Adele Cohen, a labor union lawyer, defeated Joseph Kovac, a member of the Republican Party's executive committee in Brooklyn.
Mr. Polonetsky resigned in December to take a job as Commissioner of the City Department of Consumer Affairs.
Ms. Cohen, a Democratic district leader, captured 75 percent of the vote in the 46th Assembly District, while Mr. Kovac had just 25 percent.
On Long Island, the Republican Party retained two Assembly seats from Nassau County.
In the 17th Assembly District, Maureen O'Connell of East Williston, a 47-year-old attorney and registered nurse, defeated a Democrat, Mark Keefe, for the seat formerly held by Michael Balboni, a Republican who was elected to the State Senate last year. Ms. O'Connell, who narrowly lost a race in November for North Hempstead Supervisor, received 82 percent of the vote, and Mr. Keefe had 16 percent.
In the 19th Assembly District, Kathleen Murray of Levittown defeated JoAnn Flora, a Democrat, for the seat vacated by Charles O'Shea, who became Nassau County assessor last year. Ms. Murray, an attorney in the office of State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco, won with 73 percent of the vote to Ms. Flora's 25 percent.
Mr. Flake's former Congressional district stretches from Jamaica, South Ozone Park, Springfield Gardens and Hollis in Queens to portions of the Rockaway peninsula. With a 1990 population that was 22 percent white, 16 percent Hispanic, 6 percent Asian and 53 percent black, it is one of the city's largest black middle-class areas.
Although Mr. Flake's resignation became effective in mid-November, the campaign to succeed him had been in full swing since the summer, when he announced he would leave Capitol Hill before the end of the term to devote more time to his church, the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica.
In the weeks that followed, the jockeying for the job rekindled political animosities dating back more than a decade, when Mr. Flake and Mr. Waldon skirmished over the very same Congressional seat.
In 1986, Mr. Waldon faced Mr. Flake in a heated special election after the death of Representative Joseph P. Addabbo. Mr. Waldon won that contest, but two months after he went to Congress, Mr. Flake defeated him in the Democratic primary for the full term and went on to Congress in 1987.
Those two races produced bitterness that carried into yesterday's election. Mr. Flake was one of the most vocal supporters of Mr. Meeks.
In many ways, yesterday's election was the second major electoral battle this year involving the Congressional seat. Last month, the Democratic Party in Queens, in a vote of about two dozen district leaders, selected Mr. Meeks as its nominee.
That endorsement gave Mr. Meeks crucial support in the highly Democratic district in southeast Queens, but did not deter others from mounting an election-day challenge, including Mr. Waldon, a 60-year-old former police captain.
Mr. Meeks subsequently picked up a wide array of endorsements, including some Democratic officials who had initially supported Mr. Waldon, like Archie Spigner, the City Council deputy majority leader. And in spite of their own political feud, both City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and the Rev. Al Sharpton supported Mr. Meeks, as did H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.
Mr. Waldon remained in the race and on the ballot by securing nominations of the Conservative Party and the Independence Party.
Drawing on a large bank of volunteers, Ms. Clark collected more than 7,000 signatures to run on her own line, the 21st Century Party.
The Republican Party also played a strong role in the race. Ms. Miller, who was a Democrat until two months ago, ran with the party's help. She spent heavily and had the strongest presence on the radio, where her ads were broadcast frequently in the last week.
Although the campaign was a short one, it was nonetheless spirited. The candidates hired a battery of consultants, pollsters and advisers.
During the campaign, Mr. Meeks sought to present an image of a more youthful legislator who placed equal emphasis on the need for education reform and for economic development in the district.

HEADLINE: Schumer Opens Senate Race By Claiming Centrist Position

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
In the first major address of his Senate campaign, Representative Charles E. Schumer outlined a detailed agenda of tax cuts and education initiatives yesterday, trying to position himself as a centrist candidate willing to embrace ideas from both sides of the political trench.
The 50-minute speech at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University was filled with legislative proposals and notably devoid of partisan rhetoric, as Mr. Schumer, a Democrat who represents parts of Brooklyn and Queens, sought to style himself as more concerned with policy than with the knifed-edged tactics of modern electoral politics. 
 "I would like the tone of the campaign to be like this: positive," he said after the speech, which was not a formal announcement of his candidacy. Mr. Schumer has not held one of those splashy news conferences to kick off his campaign and has no immediate plans to do so. But he has left little doubt over the last several months that he is running for his party's nomination for the United States Senate.
While Mr. Schumer focused on policy yesterday, he also used his speech to outline how he intends to distinguish himself from his rivals in both parties, saying he would reject the big-government liberalism of some Democrats as well as the "clenched fist" style of the Republican incumbent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
"I thought Bill Clinton put it best after Democrats received the drubbing we so richly deserved" in 1994, he said in one of several admiring nods in the speech to the President and his moderate "new Democrat" agenda. (Mr. Schumer is currently running campaign commercials showing him stepping off a plane with the President.) "People don't want government off their backs, people want government on their side," he said.
Political consultants say Mr. Schumer must quickly establish a clear reason for his candidacy since he remains little known outside his Congressional district and, in recent opinion polls, has been running behind not only Mr. D'Amato but also the two other Democrats in the race, Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Vice-Presidential candidate, and the New York City Public Advocate, Mark J. Green.
The consultants said Mr. Schumer's speech was an attempt to put himself ahead of the pack on two major issues, education and the economy. "He wants his opponents to be me-too candidates," said Norman Adler, a lobbyist and consultant not involved in the race. "You stake out positions that others will agree with but you say it first, and all they are left with is saying, 'Me, too.' "
Mr. Schumer opened his speech yesterday by chastising both parties. "The old Democratic view that government is the answer to all problems is irrelevant," he said. "But the Republican view that all government is evil is also irrelevant."
In a five-point education plan, he called for giving all teachers a $2,000 annual tax credit and for forgiving student loans to college graduates who go on to teach in public schools. He proposed giving merit pay bonuses of $5,000 each for 20,000 teachers, increasing the authority of teachers and schools to remove students who are unruly or who sell drugs in class, and making it easier for schools to have single-sex classes or uniform dress codes.
Except for the merit bonuses, most of those ideas are strongly supported by teachers' unions, which have been engaged in a bitter fight with Mr. D'Amato because he has attacked the unions as obstacles to better education.
In his only reference to Mr. D'Amato in the speech, Mr. Schumer said, "Some political leaders think the way to improve the public schools is to bash teachers. I don't. You cannot improve the public schools with a clenched fist."
Mr. D'Amato's campaign office later released a statement applauding Mr. Schumer for supporting merit pay, which the Senator has also endorsed.
Mr. Schumer called for expanding two Clinton proposals that were enacted into law last year. One made college tuition tax deductible; Mr. Schumer proposes to increase the deduction and also allow deductions for room and board. The second created tax-free savings accounts for college tuition; Mr. Schumer's proposal would eliminate taxes on those accounts even after the money is withdrawn, provided it is spent on college costs.
In his four-point economic plan, he proposed giving rebates on the payroll tax to workers and their employers, giving tax credits of $2,000 to first-time home buyers in low-income urban areas and allowing workers to bring their pensions with them when they change jobs.
He estimated the cost of the entire package at $45 billion over five years, which he said could be paid for out of projected surpluses in the Federal budget. Portions of those surpluses should also be used to shore up the Social Security system and reduce the national debt, he said.
In other campaign developments, Mr. Green's office said he would formally kick off his campaign with a two-day, nine-city tour of the state starting today. And Emily's List, a political advocacy group for women that has an extensive fund-raising network, announced that it had endorsed Ms. Ferraro.
