HEADLINE: South Korea's Crisis Hinders Nuclear Deal With the North

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
South Korean officials have told the Clinton Administration that their financial crisis has left them unable to pay their full share of the construction of nuclear power plants in North Korea, the key element of a deal that halted the North's nuclear weapons program three years ago.
South Korea is expected to ask the United States and Japan to provide more help for the early stages of the project when they meet to discuss the accord in New York on Thursday. Congress, however, has refused to pay directly for the reactor construction. 
 American officials are concerned that any signal from Seoul that it is slowing the construction of the $5 billion civilian nuclear project could embolden North Korea to break its commitment to halt its nuclear weapons program. The South's effort to delay its payment is the most conspicuous example yet of how the Asian financial crisis is spilling over into American foreign policy problems.
South Korea's incoming president, Kim Dae Jung, has repeatedly said that South Korea is committed to carrying out the 1994 accord. But devoting tens of millions of dollars to the early stages of the project, when the Government is in the midst of an austerity campaign and workers are facing mass layoffs, has become what one senior South Korean official calls "a very delicate political problem."
After lengthy delays, the project is just getting under way. North Korean workers, in conjunction with engineers from the South, are clearing the site for the two nuclear plants.
Last week the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in Washington published an unusual notice in the Federal Register: a request from Combustion Engineering, a nuclear equipment producer, for a license to export two reactors, for "commercial operation of electricity," to North Korea. Ordinarily, exports of virtually any sensitive goods to the Communist country are barred.
The notice was something of a diplomatic gaffe, officials acknowledged. The 1994 accord calls for the reactors to be of "Korean style" to calm South Korean objections that Seoul was paying for reactors made by American companies.
American officials familiar with the sensitive negotiations said today that they suspect Seoul may be using the financial crisis to test Washington and Tokyo's willingness to pay a bigger part of the North Korean project. The South wants the Americans to commit money to building the light-water reactor, something Congress has refused to do, though the United States has spent about $100 million sending fuel oil to North Korea, to supplement its energy supplies. The money helped set up the organization that oversees the nuclear project.
"We have made it clear that we do not think Congress is prepared to fund the light-water reactor for the North under any conditions," one senior American official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. But "clearly we are doing a lot to help the South Koreans through their troubles," he said, referring the the American commitment to provide up to $3 billion in "backup financing" for emergency loans that South Korea is receiving from the International Monetary Fund.
It is not clear how North Korea will respond to South Korea's changed view of the financing. "The reactors are the quid pro quo for freezing the nuclear program," said Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control. "If the reactors don't go forward, we will confront at some point North Korean reluctance to do their part of the deal."
The 1994 accord defused a diplomatic confrontation with North Korea that came perilously close to an outbreak of hostilities along the demilitarized zone on the border, according to two recent studies.
For several years leading up to the accord, the United States insisted that North Korea halt its activities at a secret nuclear site called Yongbyun, where the Central Intelligence Agency had concluded the North was producing plutonium.
It was unclear at the time whether the North Koreans had the technology to use the plutonium at the core of a crude nuclear weapon. But there was considerable evidence that the North was working furiously to develop that technology, and may have possessed enough plutonium to produce two or more small bombs. In the spring of 1994, it began extracting more plutonium from the fuel rods of its largest reactor.
By June, as the crisis escalated, the United Nations was on the verge of imposing a virtual economic embargo on the North. In a series of meetings at the White House, President Clinton was preparing to approve a Pentagon recommendation to reinforce the 37,000 American troops based in South Korea. The Pentagon feared that North Korea could react to economic sanctions by launching a surprise attack on the South.
But that same month, former President Jimmy Carter went to North Korea on his own and negotiated the outlines of a settlement with President Kim Il Sung, the North's founder. President Kim died the following month, but a final accord was reached in October.
The bargain struck essentially froze the North's extraction of plutonium, allowing international inspectors to "can" the spent fuel rods, meaning encasing the waste safely, and keep them under constant surveillance.
In return, South Korea, Japan and the United States agreed to provide the North with two light-water reactors, which produce electricity without producing the kind of nuclear waste that can easily be turned into weapons.
The unspoken assumption guiding American officials at the time was that North Korea's regime, already reeling from famines, fuel shortages and the death of the country's longtime leader, would likely collapse before the project was complete.
But recently Mr. Kim's son, Kim Jong Il, formally succeeded his father, and the Government has muddled on, though its military power appears to have diminished over the past three years.
Meanwhile, South Korea and Japan have been haggling over how they will divide the cost of paying for the reactors. Japan has discussed an investment of upwards of $1 billion. Thursday's meeting was intended to move toward a resolution of that dispute.
But one American official said it was clear that "the financial crisis is going to keep us from solving this problem this year." But he said the problems did not threaten to bankrupt the organization that is buying the reactors and arranging the construction.
Because the Korean currency has decreased in value so dramatically, the cost of the reactors -- which are priced in dollars -- has soared. While South Korean officials say they will press for a larger contribution from the United States, Congress is even questioning the American contribution to the South Korean economic bailout.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 598 words

HEADLINE: A Matter of American Leadership

 BODY:
The roster of lobbyists marching up to Capitol Hill to make the case for giving the International Monetary Fund an infusion of $18 billion says something about the importance of the Administration proposal. The principal salesmen are Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. The Clinton Administration argues, correctly, that the fund, for all its flaws, remains the only institution that can snuff out financial crises abroad before they bury local economies and before they reverberate around the globe, striking even the United States. Without new money from Washington, the fund's other members are unlikely to contribute the reserves that the fund needs to bail out countries in financial distress.
After the Administration's humiliating failure to gain approval of "fast track" trade legislation last year, the I.M.F. vote takes on a larger political importance. America's partners wonder whether its commitment to the global economic order is waning. A second Congressional rebuke would send an alarming signal abroad that the United States is in further retreat. That is why the Administration's new sense of urgency is welcome, as is the decision by a pivotal Republican leader -- Jim Leach, chairman of the House Banking Committee -- to advance the cause. The $18 billion would not subtract money from other Federal programs because it is treated like a bank deposit. 
 Mr. Leach's novel contribution to the debate is his proposal to impose conditions on the I.M.F. designed to improve its mixed record. The bill calls for less secrecy in fund operations. Mr. Leach, for instance, wants the fund to make its bailout agreements public. He would also subject the fund's policy-making to review by independent experts.
The idea is to expose policy mistakes before they do damage. In Indonesia the I.M.F., by its own admission, cracked down too hard on banks, driving the economy into a needless tailspin. Had the policy been subjected to outside review and correction, millions of Indonesians, living on the margin of subsistence, could have been spared the loss of their jobs.
Critics also accuse the I.M.F. of protecting bankers better than workers or the environment. The Leach bill presses the fund to take account of worker rights and environmental conditions without imposing rigid remedies.
In the process of bailing out South Korea and other collapsed Asian economies, the fund has been forced to rescue foreign investors who made bad loans. It could not do otherwise. A country whose currency is under siege needs to attract foreign capital to keep factories and other business afloat. If the country defaults on its foreign loans, foreign investors will flee. But a bailout that holds some foreign investors harmless suggests that they can make imprudent loans with impunity. Mr. Leach properly wants the fund to devise ways to make foreign investors bear at least some loss before the I.M.F. comes to their rescue.
The fund's critics need to be reminded of its successes. It has kept the financial crisis in Asia from spreading to Russia, Brazil and the United States. It has pressured South Korea and Indonesia to wring crony politics out of their commercial banking transactions. The fund has also demanded pledges by each of the bailout recipients to adopt Western standards of accounting that will tell investors the true financial state of their banks and businesses. To deny the I.M.F. additional money now is to invite economic calamity and to undermine the vital interests of the United States.

HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
Rutgers Hires Mulcahy to Improve Sports Image

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY

 BODY:
Rutgers University, where athletic fortunes and finances have suffered in recent years, made a major move yesterday to get well again by naming a new athletic director. As expected, the job went to Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, who for 19 years has been the president and chief executive officer of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.
The appointment represented a victory for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who wanted Mulcahy for the state university post and had to overcome at least initial resistance from Dr. Francis L. Lawrence, the university president. In announcing the appointment at a news conference at the Hale Center, part of the Rutgers sports complex in Piscataway, N.J., Lawrence said that in the search for a new athletic director, Mulcahy's name "surfaced early and repeatedly." 
 Since 1979, Mulcahy has run the sports authority. It comprises the Meadowlands sports complex (Giants Stadium, Continental Arena and the Meadowlands race track) in East Rutherford, the Monmouth Park race track in Oceanport, the state aquarium in Camden and the new $250 million convention center in Atlantic City. The authority generates $1.2 billion a year for the New Jersey economy.
The 61-year-old Mulcahy will start his new job in April. Rutgers announced that he had agreed to a three-year contract paying $185,000 a year. His authority job pays $182,875.
One of Mulcahy's strengths is marketing. He helped bring 1994 World Cup soccer matches and the 1996 men's basketball Final Four to the Meadowlands. Critics of the Rutgers athletic program said Fred Gruninger, the departing athletic director, lacked the marketing skills needed in present-day college sports. Gruninger will retire in June after 25 years on the job.
Lawrence said of Mulcahy:
"They got the right person at the right time. He will be working with the coaches to try to make them successful. He will be out in New Jersey trying to get support for the program. He is experienced, so I don't have to wait three or four years for someone to develop."
Mulcahy is proud of his Meadowlands accomplishments, calling the complex "an American icon of college and professional athletics." He talked of developing at Rutgers "a model athletic program that will be a focal point of campus life and a centerpiece of state pride."
Whitman had kind words for Mulcahy.
"One of the things that will be very important, obviously. is to increase the image and to market it well," she said in a statement. "He absolutely knows that. He is unparalleled in his ability to do that kind of thing."
Rutgers can use the help. Its athletic program has lost $31.5 million over the last 10 years. The men's basketball team, once a national contender, dismissed Bob Wenzel as coach after last season's 11-16 record. Last fall's football team, coached by Terry Shea, finished with an 0-11 record, including losses by 59-19 to Virginia Tech, 48-14 to Texas, 48-0 to West Virginia, 50-3 to Syracuse and 49-7 to Temple.
Football attendance averaged fewer than 20,000 in a stadium that seats 42,000. In 1994, Mulcahy helped Rutgers raise $26 million to rebuild the football stadium and create other sports facilities.
On Dec. 17, with Gruninger having announced he would retire, Whitman met with Lawrence and strongly recommended Mulcahy for the job. Lawrence wanted a national search and appointed a search committee of eight administrators, faculty members and students, including himself.
Lawrence later played down suggestions that Whitman was trying to force the appointment of Mulcahy.
"We had a conversation that should be kept private," Lawrence said. "I think everyone was within his or her right to indicate support for a candidate. You have to allow for that democratic process involving members of our community. It happened, and we got the best person for the job. There are no tensions between me and the Governor. Absolutely not."
Whitman said that she "wanted to make sure that the process was kept open enough that it did not exclude somebody who was in the state."
Mulcahy lives in Mendham, where he was once the Mayor. He is a Democrat and was the chief of staff to Brendan Byrne, who appointed Mulcahy to the sports authority when he was Governor. Mulcahy has held the job under four Governors -- Byrne, a Democrat; Tom Kean, a Republican; Jim Florio, a Democrat, and Whitman, a Republican.
Raymond H. Bateman, the sports authority chairman, said Dennis Robinson, the authority's chief financial officer, would become acting president. He said Robinson had a "strong chance" to get the job permanently.
Mulcahy is a 1958 Villanova graduate with a degree in history. He was a Navy officer from 1958 to 1960.
Mulcahy is leaving the sports authority at a time when income has slipped because of increasing competition for the leisure dollar. Race track attendance and betting handles have fallen. The Devils hockey team renegotiated its lease two years ago and the Nets basketball team is trying to do the same.
But the downside at one place becomes the upside at another. As Shea, the Rutgers football coach, said of his new boss: "I think I really got an ally and an adviser in Bob Mulcahy, and hopefully a mentor. I think just his presence and his stature are going to help us in state in just spreading the word about what a great opportunity Rutgers University will be for some of this New Jersey talent that seems to want to leave the state at times."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, the new Rutgers athletic director, at the Hale Center on the campus in Piscataway, N.J. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 863 words

HEADLINE: Man in the News: Gregory Weldon Meeks;
Master of the Political Balancing Act

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
A week ago, at a boisterous, old-fashioned political rally in a Queens community center, Gregory W. Meeks stood on a stage as a Congressional candidate facing hundreds of supporters and surrounded by a host of Democratic officials, some of whom were not known for having much in common with regard to political philosophy.
On one side of Mr. Meeks was the Rev. Al Sharpton, who praised the contender for his vehement criticism of police brutality. On the other side was a former Congressman, Floyd H. Flake, the minister whom Mr. Meeks sought to replace in the House of Representatives, who lavishly hailed the candidate as an impassioned advocate for economic development. 
 That Mr. Sharpton and Mr. Flake -- who are cordial to each other but definitely cut from different political cloth -- shared the stage so easily was a testament to the appeal of Mr. Meeks.
Indeed, in a relatively short political career, Mr. Meeks, 44, has demonstrated an ability to attract the support of a broad spectrum of politicians. And fresh from a resounding victory Tuesday night that made him the newest member of Congress from New York, Mr. Meeks is apparently different things to different people.
To some, he is something of a charming firebrand and renegade, a man who often worked the streets of Far Rockaway, Queens, in campaigns against the Democratic Party machine. He has been a zealous foot soldier in the presidential campaigns of the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and in the various electoral contests of Mr. Sharpton.
To other observers, he has come across as a moderate, former prosecutor with respectable law-and-order credentials. He was known as a conciliator, finessing relationships and egos -- and amassing political comrades -- in his role as the former chairman of the Council of Black Elected Democrats.
"Meeks is attractive to many people because he represents a new generation of leadership in the African-American community," said Lawrence B. Seabrook, a State Senator and friend of Mr. Meeks.
"But he's also a good balancing act who can attract those from the left and those more to the right. He's seen as a progressive with one hand in the activist community and another in mainstream politics. That's why he can stand on a stage with the support of both the Rev. Sharpton and Peter Vallone."
The activist minister and the Speaker of the City Council were among the legions of prominent Democratic supporters Mr. Meeks attracted during the contentious, five-candidate campaign for the seat in the Sixth Congressional District vacated by Mr. Flake.
Mr. Meeks suggests that his appeal is based on his work as "a bridge builder" and his emphasis during the campaign on economic development in southeastern Queens, a hallmark of his predecessor, Mr. Flake.
"I'm one who understands that, particularly in the African-American community, the key is now economic," said Mr. Meeks, who is to be sworn in as a member of the House of Representatives today. "We have to move toward the economic redistribution of our community more than we have in the past. That's what I'm about."
Mr. Meeks's victory -- with 57 percent of the vote -- represents a sharp ascent in the career of a man who a few years ago was scarcely known outside his home base in Far Rockaway.
Gregory Weldon Meeks was born on Sept. 25, 1953, in Harlem, the oldest of four children, and grew up in two public housing projects in upper Manhattan.
His father was a taxi driver who also did maintenance work in the Shubert Organization's theaters and his mother was a housewife who waited until her children had reached their teen-age years before earning her college degree.
Mr. Meeks developed an interest in politics as a youngster, starting with leadership positions in student government as early as junior high school.
After graduating from Adelphi University, he went to Washington to attend law school at Howard University. Upon earning his degree there, Mr. Meeks returned to New York, where his family had relocated from Harlem to the Rockaway Peninsula.
It was there that he, with the urging and participation of his civically active mother, formed a community association aimed at getting streets repaired and obtaining improved city services.
That led him into grass-roots politics and he went on to establish a political club -- the Jesse L. Jackson Independent Democratic Club of the Rockaways -- and to immerse himself in several races, frequently, as he recalls, supporting insurgent candidates.
His professional career took him from being an assistant district attorney in Queens to a private law practice to being an administrative judge on the State Workers Compensation Board.
At the urging of his politically active friends, he mounted his first campaign for elective office in 1991, losing in a crowded Democratic primary for a seat on the expanded City Council. The next year, at the age of 39, he won a a newly formed Assembly seat, representing Far Rockaway.
"He's very smart and extremely hard-working," said Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, a Meeks supporter. "He's also a guy who believes in working with all the communities. I think he'll do all right."

HEADLINE: Las Vegas Journal;
At Hotel-Casino, Triumphant Shouts of 'Union!'

BYLINE: By SARA MOSLE

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 2

 BODY:
Joseph Daugherty is thinking about taking a vacation. As an organizer for the Culinary Workers Union Local 226 in Las Vegas, he has not taken a day off since Sept. 21, 1991, when 550 workers -- maids, cocktail waitresses, bartenders, cooks -- walked off their jobs at the Frontier hotel and casino to protest the resort's treatment of its employees.
"I used to tell my family on the East Coast that I'd see them when the strike was over," Mr. Daugherty said with a rueful smile. He did not realize that the walkout, the nation's longest in almost four decades, would end up lasting nearly six and a half years. 
 A minute after midnight on Sunday, the strike finally ended as the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Richard Trumka, the secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., led returning workers, national labor leaders, local politicians, union members and some 2,000 other revelers on a triumphant march around the craps and black jack tables, their shouts of "union" drowning out the tintinnabulation of the slot machines.
Strikers wept and hugged, but many looked dazed as they wandered through a place that was both intimately familiar and strange after so long. Raymond Turner, who had worked as a cook at the Frontier for 25 years before walking out, said, "I guess it looks the same, but it hasn't sunk in yet."
Like soldiers who recall their years of service with fondness, many strikers admitted to an unexpected emotion: they were going to miss the picket line. Mirna Preciado, who was returning to her job as a waitress that morning, said: "I'm glad we won, but I'm sad, too. I'm going to miss my friends."
During the strike, children graduated from their strollers to walk with their mothers on the picket line. Couples met and married. Seventeen strikes also died during the course of the walkout.
"We are like family," Ms. Preciado said.
Strikers had vowed to hold out "one day longer" than the Elardi family, which bought the Frontier from the Summa Corporation in 1989 and began taking actions like dismissing workers without cause, reducing wages and refusing to contribute to the pension fund.
In September 1995, United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, upheld dozens of charges of violation of labor law. In an uncommon display of solidarity, strikers walked the picket line around the clock for 6 years, 4 months and 10 days. Not a single striker crossed back over the picket line, and union members voted to double their dues to support a strike fund. Pickets credited Mr. Daugherty for helping to sustain morale.
Motorists would sometimes pelt them with rocks, eggs, ice cream and even a dead rabbit that had been shot. Occasionally, resort workers would spray the pickets from water hoses intended for cleaning the parking lot. And then there were the 120-degree summers and wintery nights.
"Joe was our glue," Ms. Preciado said. "We called him St. Joe."
John Wilhelm, secretary-treasurer of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International, said, "In my 28 years in labor, I have never met a more extraordinary leader than Joe."
Whenever union conventions were held here, members would join the picket line. Postal workers, teachers and state, county and municipal employees all marched with the strikers. A local doctor, Elias Ghanem, provided free medical service -- delivering 107 babies to their families.
Even management at other hotel-casinos sympathized with the workers. William Bennett, then the head of Circus Circus and now the owner of the Sahara, became so distressed with the strikers' plight that he provided three hot meals a day for more than five years at an estimated cost of $1 million.
Last fall, Phillip Ruffin, a businessman from Kansas, ended the standoff when he bought the Frontier for $167 million and agreed to sign a union contract and take back the employees with their seniority and pensions intact. (About 100 replacement workers lost their jobs.) Last week, Mr. Ruffin revealed that the strike had cut the Elardi family's business in half even though the economy was booming.
The Elardis, who live in Las Vegas, had argued that they could not make a profit if they paid union wages, but nearly every other major hotel and casino on the Strip was a union shop at the time.
For labor leaders, the victory was sweet.
"This strike is the most significant victory in American labor since the early C.I.O. days and Walter Reuther," said Gerald McEntee, the president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
And many other leaders have begun to point to Las Vegas as a model for organized labor. John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has called Las Vegas "the hottest union city in America."
In recent years, the Strip has been the scene of demonstrations reminiscent of the 1930's as thousands of workers, even tens of thousands, have taken to the streets to fight for better wages and benefits.
In the last 15 years, the culinary union has more than doubled its ranks, to over 40,000 members. Las Vegas is the fastest-growing city in the country, and the union is the fastest-growing local in the private sector. As Mr. Wilhelm of the hotel-restaurant union put it, service workers' jobs cannot be shipped overseas. He says Las Vegas's prosperity depends in large part on the union contract.
For his part, Mr. Daugherty, the organizer, said he might not take the vacation, after all.
"In labor," he said, "there's a saying that a union is only as strong as its next strike."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mirna Preciado, a waitress who along with more than 500 other workers went on strike against the Frontier hotel and casino in Las Vegas, Nev., in September 1991, celebrated the end of the walkout early Sunday. (Tyrone Turner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Joint Effort Seeks to Raise Fuel Economy of 'Light Trucks'

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced a research effort with automotive companies today to improve sharply the fuel economy of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans, using techniques borrowed from the Pentagon.
Secretary of Energy Federico F. Pena said the goal would be to increase by 50 percent by 2004 the number of miles that these so-called light trucks can travel on a gallon of gasoline or diesel. With sales of light trucks rising quickly, improved fuel economy for them would conserve energy while curbing emissions of carbon dioxide, the main gas linked to global warming. 
 The plan announced today involves Government work in partnership with the Big Three automobile companies and seven regional consortiums of component manufacturers and high-technology start-up companies.
The Energy Department and the Transportation Department will take over a research program on medium- and heavy-duty vehicles from the Defense Department. The research into heavy trucks will continue, with the goal of doubling the gas mileage of 18-wheel trucks. The military has already developed a Humvee that can go twice as far as previous models on a gallon of fuel, with better acceleration, quieter operation and less pollution.
"It's important for us to focus on light trucks and heavy trucks," said Mr. Pena, who said trucks were the fastest-growing segment of the transportation business. Gasoline consumption by cars is projected to show little change through 2020, while light truck consumption of gasoline is expected to rise steeply, according to a chart that Mr. Pena displayed. The new research effort into light trucks was mostly put together in the last two months, in response to rising sales of light trucks and growing public interest in them, Federal officials said.
The Government defines sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans as light trucks, though mini-vans and a few sport utility vehicles are actually based on car designs.
The Administration has asked Congress for $50 million for truck research, to be matched by at least $50 million from the auto industry. But if Congress rejects that request, the Administration plans to conduct light truck research anyway, on a smaller scale. The auto industry has said it would only produce high-mileage vehicles if they can be made for a price consumers would pay.
According to the Energy Department, about 2 million of the approximately 9.5 million barrels of fuel used daily for highway vehicles goes into trucks and buses, and nearly 3 million into "light trucks," many of which are household vehicles.
The United States agreed at an international conference last December in Kyoto, Japan, to curb its man-made emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that are believed to contribute to global warming. According to a research paper last autumn by an Environmental Protection Agency official, light trucks will account for the biggest increase in so-called greenhouse gas emissions by the United States over the next two decades.
The new program is meant to do for heavier vehicles what the Partnership for the Next Generation Vehicle, begun four years ago, is expected to do for cars. That program, undertaken by the Government, with the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and the Corporation, is meant to develop by 2004 a production-ready prototype of a 5-passenger car that would get up to 80 miles a gallon with no sacrifice in safety, performance, convenience or cost.
The new research effort and the existing Next Generation partnership are likely to use similar technologies. The main one, demonstrated in the Humvee, involves switching from an internal-combustion engine to a hybrid system, in which a small engine, running on gasoline or diesel fuel, operates steadily to run an electric generator and charge batteries or feed drive motors on the wheels.
When the vehicle needs extra power, it draws it from the batteries, and when it needs no power, for example, when it has stopped, the internal combustion engine keeps running to feed the batteries. Because the engine runs at nearly constant speed, it is cleaner and more efficient.
The Humvee, built by PEI Electronics, an independent company spun off by Chrysler earlier this year, will go approximately 18 miles on a gallon of diesel fuel instead of 9; accelerates from 0 to 50 miles an hour in seven seconds instead of 14, and can climb a 60 percent grade at 17 m.p.h. instead of 6 m.p.h. It can also run 20 miles on batteries alone, which suits the Pentagon's needs, because in that mode it is nearly silent and is also hard to find with a heat-detection system.
Advanced Vehicle Systems of Chattanooga, Tenn., showed off a 22-foot hybrid electric bus at the press conference here, with a turbine that runs on natural gas for recharging the batteries. It has greatly reduced emissions of the pollutants that cause smog and the ones linked to global warming.

HEADLINE: Big 3 to Make Cleaner Cars Than Required

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
General Motors, Ford and Chrysler said this evening that they would begin delivering cars next year that emit 70 percent less of some pollutants, in a deal with the Government on Federal pollution standards.
Their agreement, which was immediately praised by the Environmental Protection Agency, consummates a deal on smog that has been in the works for most of this decade. 
 The change is expected to help many metropolitan areas reduce the number of days that they violate Federal smog rules. While the replacement of older cars with newer, cleaner ones will not solve the air pollution problem in most cities; it will help counteract the effects of having more cars driving more miles each year.
In exchange for the action by the car companies, eight Eastern states and the District of Columbia will give up their right to adopt California's emission standards, which are even stricter. Congress gave California the right to enforce stricter standards than the Federal Government does and gave the other states the option to choose between the two.
Today's deal, first proposed by the auto companies as a standard for all states other than California, was written into a proposed rule by the E.P.A. last year. The E.P.A. allowed the states to decide whether they would accept it and all but New York, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maine did so. Then the E.P.A. gave the companies a chance to accept, and today the Big Three did.
The auto makers had said they feared a balkanized car market if the 49 states did not all agree to the standard.
Their proposal grew out of the 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act, which limited the flexibility of the E.P.A. in setting new standards for reducing automobile emissions. The auto makers hoped to persuade 12 Eastern states from Virginia to Maine along with the District of Columbia to reverse their decisions to adopt the California standards.
But the Big Three proposal collided with regulations already in force in New York and Massachusetts, which had the California rules and wanted to keep them. In addition, Vermont and Maine still want to adopt the California rules, and under the compromise reached today, will be allowed to do so.
The General Motors Corporation said it would accept the deal with only 45 states, and the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation followed within hours. The cleaner models that will be sold in the East in 1999 and the rest of the country two years later will produce 70 percent less of some pollutants than emitted by current models under the Federal standard. The California rule is even cleaner.
Jacques Nasser, president of Ford Automotive Operations, said in a statement tonight, "We are prepared to move forward with this historic cooperative agreement because it is simply the right thing to do."
Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the E.P.A., said in a statement that the new cars would be "a tremendous benefit for the American people and the American economy." Her agency had been trying to engineer the deal for years, because the E.P.A. is barred from requiring cleaner cars in the next five years.
Vice President Al Gore said in a statement that the agreement "demonstrates once again that Government and industry, working in partnership, can achieve cost-effective environmental gains."
The compromise must still win the approval of car companies based abroad, but Japanese manufacturers have generally indicated a willingness to produce cleaner cars. Federal officials say the other companies, which have a far smaller presence in the American market, are unlikely to single themselves out by objecting.
At Chrysler, which had been viewed as the hard-liner of the Big 3, Nicole Solomon, a spokeswoman, said, "The idea of offering cleaner cars nationwide makes sense."
California says tougher standards raise the cost of a car by $70 to $145 on average; the companies say the figures are slightly higher.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Manhattan Tops List Of Costly Real Estate

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Manhattan dominated an annual survey of the world's 10 most costly retail addresses, with Fifth Avenue ranking first and Times Square and Rockefeller Plaza landing on the list for the first time. East 57th Street and Madison Avenue also made the top 10.
Michael N. Hirschfeld, director of the Manhattan-based Equis Retail Group, a division of the Equis Corporation in Chicago, has conducted the survey for the last 10 years. The results, released yesterday, were based on interviews with landlords, tenants, other brokers and bankers. 
 Retail space on Fifth Avenue, which topped the roster for the fourth year, had an average annual rent per square foot of $580 a year. Times Square, which placed sixth on the list, just ahead of Rodeo Drive in Los Angeles, had rents of $340 a foot, while rents in Rockefeller Plaza, in tenth place, were $240 a foot.
East 57th Street between Fifth and Madison placed second with rents of $500 a foot, and Madison Avenue between 57th and 69th Streets came in fourth with rents of $375 a foot.
"Top global retailers have recognized the importance of establishing a presence on major shopping streets in the United States, and especially in New York City, resulting in increasingly higher rents," Mr. Hirschfeld said.
In a sign of Asia's troubled economy, the Ginza district in Tokyo dropped from third place in last year's survey to eighth place this year. Replacing the Ginza in the No. 3 spot was Oxford Street in London, which has benefited from increased tourism and a favorable economy in Britain, Mr. Hirschfeld said. LISA W. FODERARO

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology;
Cleaner Cars, No Magic Required

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NOW that the Big Three auto makers have agreed to a compromise under which they will produce cleaner vehicles than Federal regulations now require, cars will have new hardware, beginning next year in the Northeast and in 2001 in the rest of the country outside of California. But the differences under the hood are likely to be minor.
On Wednesday, the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation agreed to sell cleaner cars nationwide in exchange for an agreement by eight states not to adopt California's even stricter standards. The car makers had sought a standard for all states except California, but settled for a deal that allowed New York, Maine, Massachusetts and Vermont to enforce California's rules. 
 What does this mean to car buyers? Not much, because the manufacturers can make cars far cleaner without resorting to major new components. Instead, they have refined the existing parts, tweaking the catalytic converter and the fuel injectors. As a result, the changes have mostly been inexpensive and smooth. And some of these alterations may also improve a car's fuel economy and its performance.
Both the California standard and the new 45-state standard are fleet averages, goals that each car company can reach through different mixes of car categories established by the State of California. The categories, in increasing order of cleanliness, are "transitional LEV," LEV, "ultra LEV," and ZEV, for zero-emission vehicles. ZEV's would have to be electric-powered.
The changes needed to make a Federal-certifed car meet LEV standards are invisible to the customer. "Except for the price, there doesn't seem to be much difference," said Pete Iwanowicz, a clean air specialist in Albany with the Resource Renewal Institute, a nonprofit environmental group. Auto industry executives point out, though, that multiplied by millions of car sales, the aggregate expense would be billions of dollars.
One tool is to add to the catalytic converter a little more palladium, rhodium and platinum, metals called "catalysts" that foster chemical reactions without being consumed themselves. This would increase the efficiency with which the converter takes carbon monoxide, unburned hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides and turns them into carbon dioxide, water and nitrogen. The added quantities are so small that the added cost is well under $100.
Another approach is to build a catalytic converter with slightly more surface area. These converters are typically about the size of a one-pound coffee can, but they have several square feet of surface area because the inside is crammed with a honeycomb.
By making the walls of the honeycomb thinner, more chambers can be squeezed in. And if the walls are thinner, the converter heats up more quickly to the operating temperature.
It is a big challenge to get the converter to operating temperature as quickly as possible. Cold starts are the source of most hydrocarbons, which are unburned fuel, and carbon monoxide, which is partly burned fuel. Unless the catalyst comes up to operating temperature quickly, "you'll fail the test in the first few seconds, and the rest of it is a waste of time," said Kelly M. Brown, director of the vehicle environmental engineering program of the Ford Motor Company.
California officials said they originally thought that car makers would need electrically heated catalysts to meet the low-emission standards. But the manufacturers have found simpler, cheaper ways.
Some have moved the converter closer to the engine. This is a balancing act, because the converter needs to reach 1,500 to 1,600 degrees Fahrenheit to work well, but at 1,800 or 1,900 degrees it will be damaged. Moving it too close to the exhaust manifold increases the chance that it will be destroyed someday, perhaps when accelerating up a steep grade or while towing.
So, on some cars, engineers have built a small, heat-resistant converter that is installed close to the engine for quick warm ups, leaving a larger converter farther down the exhaust path.
Sam Leonard, an emissions expert at General Motors, said his company was considering another approach: attaching an air blower to the exhaust system. The air-fuel mixture is very rich on start-up -- too rich for the catalyst to handle -- but adding air would allow the hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide to burn up completely inside the catalyst. In the 1970's, some of the earliest cars with catalytic converters used that method, until catalyst technology improved enough to allow cars to meet Federal standards without the devices.
Another approach is to make the exhaust cleaner before it reaches the catalyst. With computer-controlled fuel injection, most cars are very good at staying at the perfect ratio of fuel and air for full combustion -- called stoichiometric -- when engine speed is constant. But to burn cleanly, the ratio must stay within 1 percent of stoichiometric, and most cars cannot do that as the engine speed changes rapidly; they go through brief periods of lean air, which causes engine hesitation, hotter combustion and production of nitrogen oxides, or rich periods, which hurt fuel economy and result in carbon monoxide and unburned hydrocarbons. Solutions include using more and better exhaust gas sensors, individual fuel-air controls for each cylinder, and fuel injectors that are assisted by air pumps, to atomize the fuel better.
All these changes come down mostly to money. In 1996, California estimated that the cost to take a Federal car to transitional LEV standards was $72; to the LEV level, $120, and to ULEV status, $145.
Mr. Leonard of General Motors said that $72 was about right for the transitional level; to reach LEV, he said, was an additional $100 to $200, and to reach ULEV, from $100 to $1,500 above that, depending on whether it was a small, four-cylinder car, which would require few changes, or an eight-cylinder vehicle that would have to be converted to natural gas or some other cleaner fuel.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
The Focus Narrows, As Stark Images Herald A Time for Seriousness

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
The Canadian artist Jeff Wall is playing his cards closer and closer to his chest. His third solo exhibition in New York, at the Marian Goodman Gallery on West 57th Street, centers on the big black-and-white photographs that he started making in 1996. Dour and poker-faced, they make the equally large back-lighted color transparencies that established his reputation in the mid-1980's look loud and gaudy by comparison.
Admired for their glowing colors, carefully staged dramas and complex compositions, these earlier efforts were an art theorist's dream. They combined elements of history painting, photojournalism, advertising and the movies, increasing social awareness without leaving art behind. They were sometimes a bit melodramatic, but they illuminated generalities of economic hardship, bigotry and class difference with specific evidence, and their imposing scale and sharp-focus artifice made you examine them in detail. This process spurred consideration of other things: the social structure, one's culpability within it, the relevance of art history to contemporary life and art. 
 Now Mr. Wall seems to be switching allegiances, or narrowing them. A fun's-over mood prevails in these new black-and-white works; even the color images displayed in Goodman's second gallery are relatively tamped down. Perhaps Mr. Wall has decided that hard-bitten subjects require a hard-bitten style. In any event, photojournalism seems to be the only source of inspiration here, and while the clues and discrepancies persist, the images never fill out in the mind.
For example, a casual viewer, especially a white one, might think that the fair-skinned black man standing in the gloomy hall of an office building is a janitor or repairman. A closer look reveals the leather briefcase at his feet and the car keys in his hand: he's working on a weekend.
Other details seem forced. In one photograph, a down-and-out woman stands at the back door of a derelict house. Her presence is supposed to be clarified by a small inset image, a close-up of a jagged hole in the door that shows the hand of a second person lurking within. But the gallery still had to explain that a drug deal is taking place. Meanwhile, another photograph shows the back of a uniformed maid leaving a sterile hotel room that has just been readied for the next customer. It recalls but doesn't add to the long photojournalist tradition of recording alienating work and the people who do it.
One work in the second gallery, in particular, illustrates how color increases both the dreary reality and the visual interest of Mr. Wall's images. The desolate landscape titled "17340 River Road, Richmond, B.C., Winter 1994" pictures a pitted yard crowded with several generations of unkempt houses, sheds and stressed-out cars that intimate similarly care-worn human inhabitants. In the background, a continuous line of silvery railroad cars gleams across the picture, part of a long freight train and redolent of commerce, efficiency and careful maintenance. To one side, visible behind a stand of leafless trees, is another metaphor for abundance and progress: the yellow heads of two giant steam shovels rising above a mountain of dirt like animals about to feed. The image is devoid of melodrama, but it would not have the same impact in black and white.
The photo-artists of Mr. Wall's generation have taught their audience to extract every possible ounce of meaning from their images. But that also makes viewers more aware of any decrease in the dosage, or drop in ambition.
Jeff Wall's work remains at the Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, Manhattan, through March 14.

HEADLINE: Rise in January Retail Sales Is Better Than Expected

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Retailers reported a better-than-expected increase in January sales yesterday, largely as a result of major post-holiday clearance promotions by specialty clothing stores that attracted bargain-hunting shoppers.
Same-store sales, or sales at stores open a year or longer, rose 5.9 percent, far higher than the 3.5 percent gain widely anticipated by many merchants. 
 Same-store sales are considered the best sales indicator because they exclude the effects of sales from new, remodeled or closed stores.
The Goldman, Sachs Retail Index, a widely followed barometer of retail sales strength, rose 4.4 percent from a year ago. Talbots Inc. led the gains, with same-store sales rising nearly 20 percent, far more than expectations of 3 percent to 5 percent, because of steep markdowns of winter and spring clothes and accessories.
"They're promoting the heck out of everything because their merchandise hasn't been what people want," said Harry Ikenson, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. "To get rid of merchandise, they're slashing prices."
Sales typically pick up in January as retailers mark down winter merchandise to prepare for the new fiscal year. Analysts said February sales will be a better indicator of retailers' earnings because that is when consumers start shopping for spring merchandise instead of bargains.
"People swept into the stores after Christmas, and by January they were shopped out," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report.
The better-than-expected results "were across the board, and to that extent it's a little more reassuring about the underlying consumer demand for retail goods," said Michael Niemira, a retailing analyst at Bank of Toyko-Mitsubishi/Schroder & Company.
Among other apparel retailers, Ann Taylor Stores Inc. sales rose 1.1 percent, after analysts forecast a decline of as much as 10 percent. The New York-based company said the gain was driven by more promotions and an early start to its fall end-of-season clearance sale, which was moved up from February.
Sales at Limited Inc. rose 6 percent, better than analysts' expectations of as much as 2 percent. The gains stemmed mostly from strong sales at Limited's 83 percent-owned Intimate Brands Inc., which includes Victoria's Secret lingerie stores and Bath and Body Works personal-care products stores.
Sales at Limited's women's business, which includes Limited Stores and Express, fell 5 percent.
Gap Inc.'s sales rose 13 percent, compared with an expected rise of 2 percent to 4 percent. Gap benefited largely from strong sales at its lower-priced Old Navy Stores.
Same-store sales at Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, rose 7.6 percent, compared with expectations of 4.5 percent. The Kmart Corporation's sales rose 4 percent.
The Dayton Hudson Corporation's same-store sales rose 4.6 percent, led by higher-than-expected results at its Target discount chain. Sales at Target climbed 5.7 percent, compared with forecasts for a 4 percent rise.
Upscale department stores such as Saks Holdings Inc. and the Neiman Marcus Group Inc., a unit of Harcourt General Inc., benefited from higher sales of luxury goods and designer brands.
Same-store sales at Saks rose 3.9 percent, in line with expectations. Sales at Neiman Marcus rose 3.7 percent.
Federated Department Stores Inc.'s sales rose 1.5 percent. Sales at the midpriced department store chain Sears, Roebuck & Company rose 5.4 percent. The J. C. Penney Company's sales, meanwhile, fell 5.4 percent, in line with forecasts.
Pier I said same-store sales rose 22 percent, ahead of analysts' expectations for a rise of as much as 13 percent. The gain capped what already has been a record year for the Fort Worth-based Pier I, reflecting a surge in home decoration spending by baby boomers.

HEADLINE: Prince Rupert Journal;
On a Menu of Despair, Salmon Is Just the Starter

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: PRINCE RUPERT, British Columbia

 BODY:
In winter this is a kingdom of gray, where ashen skies rule over steely waters and dour men fight the gloom by planning for "next season."
But unlike years past when the docks here rang with the sound of repair and the voice of hope, Prince Rupert's waterfront is now almost silent. Nobody is scraping the green rot from the old wooden salmon boats; there is no fresh paint, no new nets. 
 "We're the cheapest in town, and still nobody can afford us," said Rudy Morrison, a Kispiox band Indian who, with a friend, repairs wooden boats. This year he has no work. "It's pretty bleak," he said.
These are difficult days for this tough frontier town that has known more than its share of triumph and tragedy since its founding almost a century ago as the western terminus of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway. Fishermen are locked in a bitter dispute with competitors in Alaska, just 40 miles away, over rights to dwindling salmon stocks.
The struggle came to a peak last summer. Two hundred Canadian fishing boats blockaded an Alaskan ferry to protest the lack of progress on a fishing rights treaty.
That got Washington's attention all right, but instead of getting a new salmon treaty, the Canadians got sued by the Alaska government.
Alaska officials, who insist that American fishermen are taking only the salmon to which they are legally entitled, have offered to drop the suit if the Canadian fishermen agree to drop their countersuit and never take out their frustration on the ferry again. The Canadians have until Feb. 6 to make up their minds.
Whatever they decide, it's not just the Alaskan dispute that has got people here so depressed. Salmon prices are down. Competition from Chilean salmon farms is fierce. Bickering among commercial fishermen, sports fishermen and indigenous groups never ends. There's an outbreak of white spot disease that will severely limit this year's take. One of the few remaining canneries has just closed and production at another is down more than anyone can remember.
Then there's the big wood pulp mill that went bankrupt last summer; only an on-again, off-again provincial bailout can save the 763 jobs there. Several downtown stores have shut; hotels and gas stations are hurting. The fishermen's union had to raise money to buy Christmas presents for members' children.
When wolves were spotted prowling the outskirts of Prince Rupert last fall, many here saw it as a symbol of just how much had gone wrong in 1997.
"Frustration was probably at its high last summer," said Des Nobels, a salmon fisherman for most of the last 20 years. "Now we're into despair."
From the deck of the Vonni Dee, Mr. Nobels' tight little salmon boat, it's easy to see why. Docked right alongside is the Pamora, with big chunks missing from its wooden deck. Its owner, a longtime fisherman, finally decided to sell to the government's buy-back program, a Canadian effort to reduce the number of salmon fishermen.
Not far away there are "For Sale" signs on four other boats, including one so dripping with rot that its name is illegible.
"This dock should be rocking by now," said Mr. Nobels, one of the angry fishermen who circled their boats around the Alaskan ferry last July. He said Prince Rupert's fishermen would normally be busy making repairs by now, the sting of last year soothed by the prospects of a new season.
"Now they all dread the coming of another season," said the 44-year-old fisherman, who is so much a man of the sea that he has never owned a car. "It's like, 'What's going to happen now?' "
The optimism that usually buoys fishermen has traditionally been as natural a part of life here as the ocean tides. It enticed men like Bill Gilker -- who learned to walk aboard his father's troller, the Old Chum -- to make their own life on the sea. These days, he and his father, Dick, 66, take the Old Chum out together. But sometimes there is barely enough fish for one of them to make a living.
"It doesn't look good," said the younger Mr. Gilker, who is 40. "I can't make any plans."
More fishermen in Prince Rupert are collecting unemployment now than ever before. More are discouraged than ever before. Some are so fed up that they think about quitting, the way Bob Warren did just before salmon season last year.
"What with prices dropping and getting beaten to death by regulations and politics, there's just no life left in the industry," said Mr. Warren, 39, now the manager of the 7-Eleven store on Second Avenue. After 16 years in the industry, he sold his cherished boat, the Ocean Wave, for $20,000. His salmon license went for $120,000. The closest he's got to fishing since then is the herring bait he sells at the 7-Eleven.
"The whole thing just disgusted me," he said over a Diet Coke at a coffee shop near the waterfront.
The Mayor of Prince Rupert, Jack D. Mussallem, agrees that 1997 was a disastrous year, but some lessons were learned.
"After you get beyond the frustration, bravado and rhetoric that comes with that, you sit down and discuss the issues," Mr. Mussallem said. What it comes down to now is painfully clear. "We can no longer rely on salmon coming in here and being stuffed in a can," the Mayor said.
There's a plan to attract an aluminum smelting plant, and a pig iron foundry, but there are no guarantees. The Mayor also thinks it's possible to get small cruise ships to drop off and pick up tourists at the waterfront.
At the Fish Hall, site of the fishermen's union offices, more attention is also being paid to alternatives to salmon. Since many fisherman never made it to the 10th grade, adult education courses are held most days and union officials desperately try to find the men new jobs.
Even a traditionalist like Mr. Nobels, who still uses a wooden reel for his long lines, is thinking about syndicating the fishing column he writes for the local weekly, just in case the fishing runs out.
Today's residents of Prince Rupert seem to retain a bit of the optimism -- some of it ill fated -- that used to so embody this place that the local newspaper was originally called The Prince Rupert Optimist.
That was back in the days when Charles Melville Hays, an Illinois wheeler-dealer, decided to make this spot not only the terminus of his Grand Trunk Railroad but an important city that could rival another west coast port, Vancouver.
Today there's a bronze statue of Charlie next to city hall, and a plaque that explains how he went to England in 1912 and raised money for the further development of Prince Rupert.
He sailed back on the Titanic. In a memorial to him in The Optimist, now The Daily News, he was given Prince Rupert's highest accolade. They called him "a dreamer of high dreams."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Share Prices End Mixed, With the Dow Falling by 12.46

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices ended mixed yesterday for the second straight session as prices dipped again for many blue chips, but other signposts in the market pointed to increasing optimism.
The declines in some constituent stocks of the Dow Jones industrial average sent it down 12.46 points, to 8,117.25, after its 30.64-point drop the day before. But demand for other stocks has grown since last week, sending many prices higher. 
 Those gains reflect a change of thinking for many investors, who had been nervous that an economic crisis in Asia would hurt corporate profits in the United States this year and depress share prices.
But for much of this week, European and Asian stock markets have been soaring, a sign perhaps that the global economy may not suffer significantly from problems in Asia. That has been viewed as a source of support for American stock prices, which have been trading in a narrow range for the better part of seven months.
"We've seen a big mood shift this week," said Alfred Goldman, the director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards Inc. in St. Louis. "The mood has shifted from it's Armageddon in Asia to it's not that big a deal."
If the Asian crisis is indeed easing, and the countries in the Pacific Rim are successfully moving toward stabilizing their economies, that could further lift stocks in the United States.
Mr. Goldman said much of the money that flowed into mutual funds in January -- typically one of the heaviest months for cash inflows -- has been held by money managers awaiting the right buy signal on stocks. This week, he said, many of them got it after several Asian stock indexes soared by more than 10 percent Monday.
"Money is just flowing in from the sidelines," he said. "You can almost see the fear of some money managers who are saying, 'The boat is leaving the pier and we're missing it!' "
That kind of eagerness was evident earlier in the week, when heavy stock buying sent the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index above the 1,000-point level for the first time and sent the Dow Jones average above 8,100 for the first time since December.
The Dow average, which has gained about 5.4 percent in the last two weeks, is closing in on its Aug. 6 high of 8,259.31, and the S.& P. 500, which ended yesterday at 1,003.54, is just a few points off the high it reached Wednesday.
Some analysts believe share prices may be close to breaking out of the range that has restrained them.
"This is giving the market a good foothold near the 8,000 level," said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. "The real acid test here is holding above 8,000 for the last few sessions.
Mr. Peroni said many investors saw Dow 8,000 as a psychological barrier, and that rising decisively above that level would further increase investor optimism and market momentum.
Part of the energy for that momentum is coming from abroad. While Asia stock prices were pummeled in the second half of last year, prices have rebounded strongly.
In Japan, the Nikkei 225 average is up 17 percent. In Korea, the main index is up 40 percent, in Malaysia 39 percent and in Thailand 14 percent. European markets are also strengthening. The London stock market is up 9 percent, and the German DAX is up about 7 percent.
Edward Kerschner, the chief investment strategist at Paine Webber, has long held that American investors are exaggerating the economic threat Asia poses, arguing that 90 percent of S.& P. company profits come from Europe, the United States, Canada and Mexico, and that growth in Europe could compensate for some of Asia's slowdown.
"The market took Southeast Asia out of proportion," he said yesterday. "People believed that if Asia's a problem, earnings have to be a problem. And it doesn't have to be that way."
Regardless of the market's direction, investors have been active this year. Yesterday, another 700 million shares traded hands on the Big Board. This year, the average volume has been about 650 million shares, up from 526 last year.
And while the Dow, S.& P., and Nasdaq all dipped, broader indexes rose. The Russell 2000 index of smaller- company stocks gained a half percent to close at 444.06. On the Big Board more stocks rose than fell.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Marketers view the Winter Olympics as a commercial bonanza.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IF the Super Bowl is the annual American midwinter orgy of commercial culture, then selling during the Winter Olympics is a worldwide love fest.
The XVIII Olympic Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, begin with opening ceremonies tonight -- a mere 12 days after Super Bowl XXXII was played. And with the staggered schedule adopted by the International Olympic Committee, the Winter Games start just 18 months after the end of the 1996 Summer Games. 
 So are the scores of marketers running commercials during the 178 hours of Winter Games coverage scheduled on the CBS and TNT networks worried about viewers developing sports fatigue or Olympic overload? That seems about as likely as any of them signing Tonya Harding as a spokes-skater.
In a survey by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of WPP Group, 78 percent of respondents said they intended to watch the Olympics this month. That figure rose to 83 percent among respondents with a household income of $50,000 or more.
"We're attracted to the Olympics because of all the surveys we do that find consumers talking about 'the luster of the rings,' " said David F. D'Alessandro, president and chief operating officer at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston, a worldwide Olympic sponsor as well as an advertiser on the Winter Games telecasts.
"It's getting harder and harder for financial institutions to distinguish themselves," he added. "But we've been beating average industry growth by 15 percent on average since we started on the Olympics."
John Hancock and its agency, Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, have produced an unconventional campaign for the 1998 Winter Games. Two 60- and 90-second spots will run 41 times on CBS and TNT through the closing ceremonies on Feb. 22 to raise money for the Sarajevo Olympic Children's Fund. The goal of the campaign, produced in cooperation with the International Olympic Committee and the American Refugee Committee, is to help rebuild the city that played host to the 1984 Winter Games.
"The Olympics have always stood for the highest standards, hard work, the desire to exceed past achievements," said Sixtus Oechele, executive director for corporate identity at the Shell Oil Company unit of Royal Dutch/Shell Group in Houston. "Those standards are our standards, too."
"We saw a real bridge between what drives the athletes and the employees of our company," he added, "so we signed a contract to be the sole petroleum products advertiser for the Olympics on CBS."
Shell will introduce a $50 million campaign -- its first corporate effort since 1983 -- by the Houston office of Ogilvy & Mather, carrying the theme "Count on Shell." The commercials, evocative of the "Shell Answer Man" ads of the 1960's, offer booklets produced in cooperation with the National Safety Council; the spots will run more than 70 times on CBS as well as often on TNT, which is a unit of Time Warner Inc.
Another reason the Winter Games are appealing to so many advertisers is the huge female viewership, drawn by events like figure skating.
"We're doing a lot to increase our market share among women," said Gerry Donnelly, marketing communications manager at the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company in Detroit, which will run 175 commercials on CBS and TNT. "And when the Olympics are on, they really captivate women viewers."
With its Olympic advertising, the Ford division is changing campaign themes, dropping "Have you driven a Ford lately" after more than a decade in favor of "Built to last." That theme will be introduced in commercials featuring the actor John Corbett as a "story teller," relating tales of drivers and their Fords; the agency is the J. Walter Thompson Detroit unit of WPP.
"The campaign is about stories," Mr. Donnelly said, "and the Olympics, especially the Winter Olympics, focuses on personal stories about the athletes. It's a nice fit."
Nike Inc. will concentrate on women with new commercials saluting female athletes like the downhill skier Picabo Street and Cammi Granato, the captain of the United States women's ice hockey team. The spots, created by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of Omnicom Group, present tributes by student and professional poets.
"It's a great opportunity to talk about women's sports," said Nancy Monsarrat, category advertising director at Nike in Beaverton, Ore., "not only because there's a good-sized female viewership but also because it's one of the few events where you see women competing."
Many advertisers like Nike will feature hockey in their commercials, in part because this is the initial Winter Olympics for women's ice hockey. Among them are the AT&T Corporation, with a schmaltzy spot about Ms. Granato by the Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications in New York; the Coca-Cola Company, with Coca-Cola Classic commercials by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., carrying the theme "For the fans"; the McDonald's Corporation, with a spot by the DDB Needham Chicago unit of Omnicom starring the hockey players Brian Leetch and Wayne Gretzky, and Wendy's International, with commercials by the Bates USA unit of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. in New York that include cameo appearances by R. David Thomas, the chain's founder.
And many marketers are using the Winter Games as they do the Super Bowl, to show new commercials. One is the Anheuser-Busch Companies, with a humorous spot by Kupper Parker Communications in St. Louis that promotes moderation; it features animated bottles of Budweiser beers being driven home by a bottle of O'Doul's nonalcoholic brew.
Others presenting new work include the BellSouth Corporation, with spots by West Wayne in Atlanta; the Toyota Motor Corporation, promoting the new Lexus RX 300 and LX 470 sport utility vehicles with commercials by Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.; Visa International, with a spot about arts sponsorship created by the BBDO New York unit of Omnicom, and the Xerox Corporation, with commercials by Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York that pitch digital office technology and products.

HEADLINE: Fed Dropped Bias Favoring Rise in Rates

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Uncertainty over the impact of the Asian financial turmoil on the United States economy prompted Federal Reserve policy makers in mid-December to drop the presumption that their next move in interest rates would be upward.
All but one member of the central bank's 12-member policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, voted for no immediate change in rates, according to minutes released today. 
 The Fed has not changed rates since March, when the benchmark rate on overnight loans between banks was raised by a quarter percentage point to 5.5 percent. That stance continued at the committee's most recent meeting, this week.
But, before the December meeting, the panel had biased its policy in favor of higher rates -- that is, members assumed that their next action, when it came, would be to raise rates.
However, at the Dec. 16 gathering, panel members dropped the policy bias because they wanted to be in position "to respond flexibly in either direction to unanticipated developments."
Although some committee members "expressed a slight preference" for retaining the tilt toward higher rates, only one formally dissented, J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond.
He said he believed that even with Asia hurting the United States trade deficit the economy would continue to grow unsustainably fast and that at some point increased labor costs would lead to price inflation, the minutes said.
He advocated raising rates slightly right away to avoid a sharper increase later. But the rest of the panel worried that because a rate increase was unexpected, "even a modest firming action might well have outsized effects in financial markets."
An economic report today provided ammunition for those who believe that the Asian crisis will contribute to a slowdown in the American economy. The Commerce Department reported that factory orders fell by 2.5 percent in December, the biggest monthly drop in more than five years, to a seasonally adjusted $336 billion.
The decline was caused by a 63 percent drop in aircraft orders. Excluding the volatile aircraft sector, orders rose a moderate 1.6 percent, with strength reported in demand for autos, electrical equipment, industrial machinery, paper, chemicals and food products.
Economists said the drop in aircraft orders was one of the first concrete signs that Asia's problems were hurting the United States economy. Last week the Boeing Company said it expected Asian customers over the next three years to buy 60 fewer planes than expected before the financial crisis.
Despite December's blow to aircraft manufacturers, factories during all of 1997 reported a robust 5.3 percent increase in orders, compared with 4.6 percent in 1996 and 7.4 percent in 1995.
In another report today, the Labor Department said the number of applications for unemployment benefits inched up to 303,000 last week, an increase of 3,000 from the week before.
Still, claims have been relatively low in each of the last two weeks, on a seasonally adjusted basis, after three weeks at a somewhat higher level, ranging from 327,000 to 339,000.

HEADLINE: Trade Arbiter Favors U.S. In Key Ruling

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
After suffering its first major defeat in front of the World Trade Organization two months ago, the United States today won its biggest case yet: a ruling that European Union countries had illegally sought to evade a key provision of a 1994 trade agreement so their own high-technology industry might benefit.
The case concerned equipment that links computers together, particularly those made by Cisco Systems, Cabletron, 3Com and Bay Networks. The decision today establishes a precedent barring a strategy that countries often use to protect domestic industries -- moving products from one category of goods to another to be able to charge higher tariffs on imports. 
 In this case, European Union countries were seeking a way to keep tariffs on computer networking equipment and thus evade the 1994 accord, which cut tariffs on most computer equipment. Computer networking hardware and software were suddenly placed in a different category, "telecommunications equipment," which carried the higher tariffs.
Measured by the size of the business involved, this case was the biggest yet for the United States. Roughly $5 billion in computer networking equipment is sold in Europe annually, and United States companies account for about half the market, the United States trade representative's office said today. The higher tariffs cost customers of the United States companies $50 million, industry officials estimated.
Politically, the chief importance was that the United States won, at a time that the role of the World Trade Organization as the arbiter of trading rules is under intense scrutiny. Both liberals and conservatives have questioned whether the "dispute resolution panels" established under the W.T.O. interfere with national sovereignty by ordering changes in domestic regulations in nations around the world.
So far, the United States has prevailed in front of the panels in nine cases and has settled seven other cases. But it has lost four: three minor cases involving underwear, silk shirts and imported gasoline, and the case two months ago involving Eastman Kodak.
In the Kodak case, the defendant was Kodak's longtime rival, the Fuji Film Corporation, but part of the United States intent in bringing a complaint was to indict Japanese industrial policy. Kodak sought to prove that Japanese bureaucrats had worked to give Fuji an edge over Kodak in the Japanese market, making it more difficult for Kodak to get access to Japanese retail outlets. But the W.T.O. panel rejected the complaint, leading the trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, to declare earlier this week that the United States would begin more intensive "monitoring" of Japanese practices.
Compared with the Kodak case, the computer networking dispute was far more narrow and better defined. It centered on whether customs officials from Britain and Ireland reclassified certain imports to double the tariffs placed on them as they entered Europe. Other members of the European Union later followed that example, though last year the European Union signed another trade accord that will bring tariffs on all electronic products to zero on July 1, 2000.
"We thought this was a pretty blatant case," said Bob Michelet, the director of corporate relations for Cisco Systems in San Jose, Calif. "This was an issue that the entire industry was able to get together on fairly quickly."
Ms. Barshefsky said in a statement: "We are pleased the W.T.O. panel has ruled that these tariffs clearly violate W.T.O. obligations. It is clear that these unfair tariffs must be corrected."
The European nations must now seek to appeal the decision or enter a discussion with the United States over lowering the tariffs. If they fail to agree, the W.T.O. could authorize the United States to impose countertariffs against European goods.
