HEADLINE: California Merger to Form No. 3 S.& L.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Two large California savings and loans, one controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, the financier, agreed yesterday to merge, forming the nation's third-largest savings and loan, but leaving Mr. Perelman with a price well below what he recently hoped his bank would fetch.
Golden State Bancorp Inc., the Glendale, Calif., parent of Glendale Federal Bank, will acquire First Nationwide Holdings Inc., the San Francisco parent of California Federal Bank, in a complex transaction that values California Federal at about $2 billion to $2.5 billion. 
 When Mr. Perelman floated the idea of taking the privately held California Federal public late last year, some analysts and investment bankers suggested that an initial stock offering might value the institution around $3 billion, excluding debt.
Mr. Perelman and a partner, Gerald J. Ford, sold most of the savings institutions they had bought in Texas to the BankAmerica Corporation before jointly purchasing First Nationwide from the Ford Motor Company in 1994 for about $726 million. Last year, First Nationwide bought California Federal for $1.2 billion.
Although industrywide profits have been rising and the economic landscape is more favorable than it was earlier in the decade, savings and loans have still had difficulty keeping up to speed in the increasingly competitive mortgage business. Mortgage lending had traditionally been the savings and loan industry's bread and butter, and banks that were overly reliant on mortgages -- as was California Federal -- were considered less attractive takeover targets.
Indeed, a number of potential buyers who looked at California Federal in recent months passed on the savings and loan because of its heavy dependence on mortgage lending, according to bank advisers. In the end, that meant Mr. Perelman, who declined to comment, sold California Federal for a rock-bottom price.
"There's been a reluctance" among potential buyers to acquire large California savings and loans, said Mr. Ford, California Federal's chairman and chief executive, in an interview. "I would agree with that."
Nonetheless, the combination of Glendale and California Federal created a huge institution with assets of $51 billion. Glendale has made important gains diversifying recently into new businesses such as small- business and consumer lending. Tethered to California Federal, the new savings and loan could land on some buyers' radar screens in a couple of years. California's savings industry remained highly fragmented and analysts expected there to be further rounds of mergers as the business continued to consolidate in the state.
"This has the potential to create a West Coast powerhouse that could be an attractive takeover target for large institutions that want to expand into California," said Thomas O'Donnell, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney Inc.
The new institution will be called California Federal Bank and will be based in San Francisco. And Mr. Ford will be chairman and chief executive of the new institution. But following the merger, Golden State's shareholders will control 55 percent to 58 percent of the new institution, depending on how the company's shares perform before the merger's completion. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter of this year.
About 30 percent of the shares will be owned by MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., Mr. Perelman's investment vehicle, and 11 percent of the shares will be owned by Mr. Ford.
Calculating the share's performance includes weighing the value of warrants related to a lawsuit between Glendale Federal and the Federal Government. Glendale is seeking damages for a 1989 change in Federal accounting rules that erased paper assets called "supervisory good will" off its books. Glendale is seeking at least $1.8 billion in damages. The warrants will reflect the value of any proceeds from the litigation.
Depending on the outcome of the lawsuit, the two institutions estimated that Golden State shareholders could expect their shares to be worth $37 to $42. In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Golden State's shares rose $2.25, to $38.
The savings and loans said that they expected to cut expenses about $131 million by 1999, although they did not think that would require substantial layoffs. CalFed is currently the fourth-largest savings and loan in the country and Golden State is currently the sixth-largest. The two said that the merged institution would be worth about $4.3 billion if Golden State ended up holding a 58 percent stake in the new concern.
Credit Suisse First Boston Corporation advised Golden State and Goldman, Sachs & Company advised First Nationwide.

HEADLINE: Japan's King of the Mountain;
The Man Who Made Nagano Also Owns Part of It

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 5

 BODY:
It was a matter of just 130 yards. But for five years, local officials refused to extend the downhill ski course for the Nagano Winter Olympics to the customary length. Finally, last November, an angry Yoshiaki Tsutsumi publicly threatened to withdraw his support for the Games.
That was a bit like Zeus threatening to abandon Mount Olympus, and the officials quickly capitulated. Their change of heart wasn't surprising, and not just because Mr. Tsutsumi, 63, is the head of the Ski Association of Japan. He is also a man with vast political influence and a persona so feared and revered that the mere mention of his name sometimes turns powerful faces pale. And as someone who several times has been called the richest man in the world, he rarely takes "no" for an answer. 
 It was Mr. Tsutsumi who led the battle for the city where he once lived to play host for the Olympics. It was largely because of him that the Games will open there Saturday, after seven years and $22 billion in preparations, rather than in the more majestic -- and more accessible -- mountains of Utah that an opposing faction favored.
And it is because of him that local officials compromised, agreeing to let the downhill course slip into a national park. So now the course will drop a full 1,930 vertical yards, just 38 yards short of what the Olympic Committee wanted, making it nearly as challenging as the course four years ago in Lillehammer, Norway. For Mr. Tsutsumi, who has built up a property empire, including the Olympic ski slopes in Nagano, this is his great moment.
"He has quite unbelievable power, an enormous amount of backstage power in the political scene," said Lesley Downer, who has written a book on the Tsutsumi family. "He has his own way of running his empire, and he runs it in a ferocious way. He behaves like a god."
His style, though, couldn't be more different from the flashy marketing campaigns that Americans were treated to twice in the last two decades by promoters who clearly relished all the attention. Peter Ueberroth, a former travel executive who took the job as president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee for the 1984 Summer Games (and later became baseball commissioner), called his efforts "a crusade, a cause -- a cause for our country." And Billy Payne, president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games of 1996, publicly boasted that they would be "the greatest peacetime event in history."
In contrast, Mr. Tsutsumi shuns the limelight and remains a mysterious figure to most Japanese and a riddle to business analysts. While Forbes magazine ranked him as the richest man in the world for several years until falling property values and stock prices made him a mere multibillionaire after 1994, the hotel and real estate empire over which he presides is shrouded in secrecy.
Nobody knows whether he is worth $4 billion or $24 billion. He declined to be interviewed for this article, and his public relations staff agreed to introduce one of his aides only after extensive deliberation. Even then, the official appeared hesitant to comment on much, pointing to a semi-authorized book on Mr. Tsutsumi instead, and then insisted on not being identified.
What is known is that Mr. Tsutsumi's father, Yasujiro, sowed the seeds of the family's dominion. The elder Mr. Tsutsumi built up his property empire patch by patch, and railway by railway, until it bloomed into what is now known as the Seibu Group. He also sired a dynasty wife by wife, and mistress by mistress, that has evolved since his death 34 years ago into a complex web of rivalries and alliances.
Indeed, the patriarch shocked the Japanese business community when upon his death, he left the lion's share of his legacy to Yoshiaki, the eldest son by one of his mistresses. Yoshiaki and his mother's other children lived in a secret home close to his father in one of Tokyo's wealthiest neighborhoods, virtually hidden from public view.
One of the father's legitimate sons, Seiji, was reportedly 14 when he was first introduced to his older half-brother. The two men have developed a love-hate relationship, according to friends of both, and at times, that tension appears to have fanned the ambition in each of them. Seiji founded the Saison Group, which owns the Inter-Continental Hotels, and inherited the Seibu Department Stores from his father.
A seemingly quiet, even shy, man, Yoshiaki started out cautiously, but soon it became clear that the Tsu tsumi empire had only one emperor, and he was it. As his influence in Japanese business grew, many assumed he would follow in his father's footsteps and enter electoral politics, perhaps even becoming prime minister. They were wrong.
"He likes politicians very much," said Makiko Tanaka, a Member of Parliament and also the daughter of a former prime minister, Kakuei Tanaka. "I think he does not want to become a politician because he knows he does not fit into the political circles where there is a small village mentality. I think he is better suited to the business world because he is his own man, a king type."
Mr. Tsutsumi is a hands-on boss, sometimes drawing up the plans for a golf course himself. He certainly tests the golf courses, just as he dines frequently at his own restaurants. He once ordered that all the hotels' sugar packets be shrunk because he felt they were holding too much for a cup of coffee.
As his maneuvering to win Olympic rights for Nagano shows, though, he is a master manipulator who knows how to exercise influence behind the scenes. Though that city is known as "the roof of Japan," it is farther south than any other site chosen for the Winter Games, and its narrow roads and remote location gave ammunition to boosters of Salt Lake City. Indeed, even some of Mr. Tsutsumi's closest supporters marvel that he was able to pull it off.
"I was invited to see the facilities and accommodations in Salt Lake City, and frankly speaking, I was very much shocked because Salt Lake City has everything," said Shunichiro Okano, an old friend and an executive board member of the International Olympic Committee. "If I had seen these facilities before Nagano was decided on, I would have lost my confidence." (Salt Lake City will be the site of the 2002 Winter Games.)
Of course, his wealth made a difference, too. When Juan Antonio Samaranch, the head of the International Olympic Committee, came to inspect Nagano as a candidate for the Olympics, he and Mr. Tsutsumi and others in their group rode in a classy train specially chartered to take them from the Tokyo area directly to Nagano. On the way, according to reliable reports, Mr. Samaranch asked Tsutsumi to help raise money for the new Olympic Museum that Mr. Samaranch was building in Lausanne, Switzerland.
Mr. Tsutsumi came through, putting in about $1 million from his own pocket and helping to raise more than $10 million toward the museum's construction. So now, on the wall in the entrance hall of the Olympic Committee headquarters, right next to Mr. Samaranch's name carved into a stone plate is a similar plate with Mr. Tsutsumi's name as well as the names of more than a dozen Japanese companies.
Just how rich is Mr. Tsutsumi? That's a matter of dispute because most of his companies are privately held. But he is known to own nearly $4 billion worth of the Seibu Railway Company through his holding company, Kokudo, and perhaps as much as $10 billion worth. In addition, he owns mountains, valleys and pieces of land all over the country, as well as major shares of the Prince Hotels, an international chain, ski resorts, golf courses and other properties. Ms. Downer estimated in a book published in 1994 that he might be worth $22 billion, although some other estimates are much lower.
Sometimes, even the most basic information is hard to glean. Sadayuki Yokota, a public relations official of Kokudo, says there are 80 companies in Mr. Tsutsumi's fold. But one friend relates how Mr. Tsu tsumi once told him that with 200 companies, he would need a year to visit each one.
Whatever the exact number, his wealth and his many political connections make him a much-feared presence wherever he goes, leading some people to conclude that he surrounds himself with yes-men likely to feed him faulty information rather than risk his wrath. "He's a very lonely man -- like Howard Hughes," said Akira Hoshino, a close friend from boyhood who runs Hoshino Hotsprings Resorts in the Nagano area. "Whenever he wants to consult, the people he talks to are short-sighted. He sees way ahead. That makes him lonely."
Another friend, Chiharu Igaya, offers an illustration of why people are often intimidated by him. When Mr. Igaya was staying at one of Mr. Tsutsumi's hotels, he was served by the restaurant's captain late one evening. The next morning, at breakfast, Mr. Igaya noticed that the same man had suddenly become a water boy and he asked the man what had happened. It turned out that Mr. Tsutsumi also happened to be staying at the hotel.
"I made a mistake," Mr. Igaya, who is an executive board member of the International Olympic Committee, quoted the man as saying. "Mr. Tsutsumi got mad at me and I was demoted."
But Mr. Igaya, who says that on occasion he has dared to differ with Mr. Tsutsumi, adds that the billionaire also has a warm side. Once when Mr. Igaya's father got into a serious accident in northern Japan, Mr. Tsutsumi somehow heard the news and sent his own helicopter to transport the injured man to a Tokyo hospital.
Other friends and acquaintances say that he is a much more complicated individual than the rich kingmaker portrayed in the press. He has been called tough yet shy, creative yet unassuming, generous yet spendthrift, inventive yet dictatorial. His dress is rather ordinary, friends say.
But he is passionate about sports, they say. He owns a baseball team, the Seibu Lions. He holds a black belt in judo. The only photos on the table in his study are of his father and the man who introduced him to ice hockey when he was a boy, according to his friend, Mr. Okano. And even at his age, he loves ice hockey and remains a competitive skier -- in more ways than one.
"Ordinary skiers would ski down the mountains just to enjoy the beautiful scenery," said Hiroshi Tsu ruoka, a member of the Upper House of Parliament and a college classmate, describing trips to remote, relatively undeveloped areas. "But when he skied the mountains, he used to say things like, 'If this place were made into a ski slope, we could hold the Olympics here.' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, left, was instrumental in bringing the Games to Japan. With him are Eishiro Saito, center, of the organizing committee, and Goro Yoshimura, the Nagano Governor. In 1994, Forbes listed him as the wealthiest man in the world. Since then, Japan's economic downturn has taken a toll on his fortune. If he owns 40 percent of Kokudo, his holding company, as generally reported, Mr. Tsutsumi is worth at least $8 billion. If he owns all of it, as some suspect, he is near the top of the world's richest list, worth perhaps as much as $24 billion. HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Fall on Concern Over Jobs Data and Iraq

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices plunged yesterday, hurt in part by concern about today's employment report for January and by the prospect of a military confrontation with Iraq.
The short-maturity end of the market held up fairly well, as the long end of the market fell sharply. 
 Traders said that the political uncertainty that gripped the market late in January after reports of a sex scandal in the White House was back to haunt them again.
Adding to the selling pressure in bonds was a commodities rally, led by silver, in which the investor Warren E. Buffett has placed a big bet.
Also, crude oil prices have risen on talk of a United States attack on Iraq.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 30/32, to 102 24/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.93 percent, from 5.85 percent on Wednesday.
Meanwhile, in when-issued trading ahead of the Treasury's quarterly refunding of Federal debt next week, yields increased as investors priced in additional risks. The 3-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.36 percent, the 10-year notes at a price to yield 5.60 percent and the 30-year bond at 5.93 percent.
One of the principal reasons for the bond market slump yesterday was uncertainty about the economy.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said investors had been conditioned by comments from a variety of authorities -- including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman -- to expect slower economic growth, and hence, a smaller threat of inflation, this year. "Therefore, unless we see clear signs to this effect within the next couple of weeks, market unrest could follow," Mr. Chan said.
One economic report yesterday, on factory orders during December, showed a slowing economy. Another reading on the strength of the economy comes today, with the Government's report on the unemployment rate and payroll levels for January.
If recent reports on initial claims for unemployment benefits are any indication, the job market remains robust. Yesterday, the Labor Department reported that claims rose by 3,000 last week, but that was from a particularly low number, 303,000, in the previous week.
Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer for the First Albany Corporation, noted that the payroll data could be the first of a series of tests of the effect of the Asian crisis.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Rule Review Assailed By a New Republican Member

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
A major rift on the Federal Communications Commission opened yesterday as a new member of the its Republican minority sharply criticized the commission as failing to review its myriad telecommunications regulations adequately.
The Telecommunications Act of 1996 directs the commission to evaluate all of its telecommunications regulations every two years, beginning this year. Yesterday the F.C.C. said it had completed an internal review and it proposed initiatives aimed at altering or eliminating 31 rules deemed unnecessary or overly burdensome. 
 But a new member, Harold Furchtgott-Roth, a former chief economist for the House Commerce Committee, called the commission's effort inadequate, saying in an interview, "I find it very difficult to believe that this notice is going to be sufficient."
Referring to the section of the act that mandates the review, he said: "I don't think it's there just to do a paper shuffle. It's there for a purpose. Aside from simply following the law because that's what we have to do, I think there's a real public policy reason for that section to be there. And I'm afraid that if there's just a selective review of a few regulations we're not following the letter or the spirit of the law."
"The issue there is read the law," he added. "Don't try to get around it. Follow it. Do what it says."
Mr. Furchtgott-Roth said he was undecided what official action -- if any -- he would take if the commission's chairman, William E. Kennard, a Democrat, refused to broaden the review significantly.
Four of the five members of the commission, which consists of three Democrats and two Republicans, joined the F.C.C. last fall. The sole holdover is Susan Ness, a Democrat.
Mr. Kennard, himself a new member, has described the group's relations as cordial. Last month Michael K. Powell, the other Republican on the commission, publicly criticized the panel for making it too difficult for the Bell local telephone companies to win approval to offer long-distance service. Mr. Kennard agreed with parts of Mr. Powell's assessment and said the F.C.C. would try to work more closely with the Bells as they drafted their long-distance petitions.
But yesterday Mr. Kennard seemed to find no common ground with Mr. Furchtgott-Roth.
"This is the most comprehensive review ever conducted by the F.C.C.," Mr. Kennard said in an interview. The proposed revisions include altering the rules on the amount of electric power that can be fed into the public telephone network. Increasing the amount could allow consumers to use computer modems that transmit data at higher speeds than are now generally possible.
Mr. Kennard said that the review met the requirements of the law and that a focused approach would be more effective than an open-ended evaluation of the commission's regulations.
"The suggestion that we would take all of the rules that govern the agency and put them on a table and invite the public in to tell us which ones to do away with would be a very unproductive process," he said, adding that the F.C.C. had tried to do just that while he was the commission's general counsel in the mid-1990's. "You get a pile of comments, and it's not shaped and it's not targeted and it's useless."
Mr. Furchtgott-Roth said that neither he nor members of his staff had been invited to participate in the commission's review. Mr. Kennard said that Mr. Furchtgott-Roth had in fact been invited, and that a meeting between Mr. Furchtgott-Roth and David Solomon, the commission's deputy general counsel, had been scheduled for today to discuss the review.

HEADLINE: Alan Campbell, 74; Reshaped Civil-Service Laws

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
Alan K. Campbell, the architect of the most sweeping changes in the Federal civil-service laws since the Administration of Theodore Roosevelt -- changes aimed at making the Government more efficient and enabling it to dismiss employees more easily for failing to do their jobs -- died on Wednesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 74.
The cause was complications from emphysema, a family member said. 
 Mr. Campbell, chairman of the United States Civil Service Commission in the Carter Administration, was the primary force in guiding through Congress the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, which adapted private-sector management personnel and compensation practices to improve the Federal bureaucracy.
As the first director of the Office of Personnel Management, a position he held in 1979 and 1980, Mr. Campbell also implemented the act, prompting President Jimmy Carter to say that its effects were "among the most visible and far-reaching accomplishments of my Administration."
At midnight on Dec. 31, 1978, the 95-year-old Federal Civil Service Commission became defunct and was replaced by three new agencies that were, in a sense, Mr. Campbell's triplets: the Office of Personnel Management, the Merit System Protection Board and the Federal Labor Relations Authority.
Under the old law, a civil servant could be dismissed only for poor performance that damaged the overall performance of the agency, a standard so stringent that few dismissals were sought. But under Mr. Campbell's design, the new law made it possible for a supervisor to dismiss an employee if a reasonable person would conclude that the employee's performance was inadequate. To help reach fair conclusions, Mr. Campbell enlisted the aid of the Business Roundtable, a group of corporate leaders, to draw up reasonable job-performance standards.
Two years later, he accepted a job as executive vice president for management and public affairs at ARA Services, now known as Aramark, a service and management provider that operates worldwide in the food, business-uniform and education fields. Elected to the board in 1981, he was an active member until shortly before his death.
Alan Keith Campbell was born in Elgin, Neb., and went to Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash., but college was interrupted by World War II and service with the Navy in the Pacific. During naval training stateside, he met his future wife, Jane Owen. They were married in 1945 and remained so for 47 years, until her death in 1992. He is survived by their daughter, Kimberly C. Oxholm of Merion, Pa.; a son, C. Duncan, of Corvallis, Ore., and six grandchildren.
After graduating from Whitman in 1946, Mr. Campbell obtained master's degrees in public affairs, at Wayne State University in Wayne, Neb., and at Harvard University, and a doctorate from Harvard in political economy and government in 1952.
He taught at Harvard until 1954 and at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y., until 1959. He was the Deputy Comptroller for the State of New York for two years. Afterward, he was dean at the Lyndon Baines Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas and then at the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University.
His books included "Taxes, Expenditures and Economic Base: Case of New York City" (Praeger Publishers, 1974) and "Watergate: Implications for Responsible Government" (Basic Books 1974).
What honored him most, he once said, were the successes of his students, though he refused to take any credit for them: "The secret of education," he said, "is to admit good students and then try do them very little harm."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan K. Campbell. (Associated Press, 1977)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markdowns Help Retailers Lift Post-Holiday Sales
Post-holiday clearance promotions by specialty clothing stores helped overall retail sales rise 5.9 percent last month, far higher than the 3.5 percent gains widely expected. 
 But analysts said January sales results were not necessarily a telling barometer of how the year would go. Page D2.
 
Fed's Tone Shifted in December
Federal Reserve policy makers were concerned enough in December about the impact of the Asian crisis that they stopped assuming that the next move in interest rates would be upward. D2.
 
Korean Unions Allow Layoffs
In South Korea, the Government, unions and employers reached an accord to allow debt-laden companies lay off workers, a step seen as critical to rebuilding the economy. A7.
 
Top Sexual Harassment Settlement
The American subsidiary of the Swedish drug maker Astra said that it would pay nearly $10 million to settle sexual harassment charges brought by the E.E.O.C. on behalf of former Astra employees, in an agreement that dwarfs any prior award in such a suit. A16.
 
Keating Conviction Thrown Out
A Federal judge threw out for a second time the criminal convictions of Charles H. Keating Jr., a leading figure in one of the most costly savings and loan failures of the 1980's. D5.

Bond Prices Fall Sharply
Treasury prices plunged, hurt by concern about today's employment report for January and by the prospect of a military confrontation with Iraq. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 5.93 percent from 5.85. Stocks were mixed. D6.
 
Medical Billing Scheme
Bogus billing companies are sending invoices to unsuspecting health insurance companies using the names of patients and doctors without their knowledge, in a fraud that is estimated to have resulted in more than $1 billion in fake claims already. A1.
 
$2.6 Billion Bank Bid Seen
Regions Financial, an Alabama-based bank, is seen as the front-runner in bidding for First Commercial of Little Rock, Ark. D4.
 
2 Railroads In Merger Talks
Canadian National is negotiating to acquire Illinois Central, the two railroads said. But some analysts said the price under discussion -- less than $3 billion -- might lure other bidders. D3.
 
A Shift at Microsoft
Microsoft moved the group that develops its Web browser into the business unit for its Windows operating system, a reorganization that is certain to raise eyebrows in light of the company's antitrust battle with the Government over the bundling of Windows software with the browser. D3.
 
No New Mexican Investment by MCI
MCI decided to stop investing in Avantel, its long-distance venture in Mexico, because of regulations that require Avantel to pay large fees to Telmex. D18.
 
Criticizing F.C.C. From Within
A rift in the F.C.C. opened as a new Republican member criticized it as failing to review its myriad telecommunications regulations adequately. D2.
 
Germans Protest Joblessness
Protests against high unemployment were staged across Germany, even as the Government announced that while the jobless total hit a record in January, on a seasonally adjusted basis the number actually fell. A12.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE DIPLOMACY;
Push for Peace Shows Split Over Inspections

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 5

 BODY:
In the current crisis with Iraq, diplomatic emissaries have descended on Baghdad, all of them opposed to the heavy bombing that the United States has threatened and all of them willing to consider a compromise with Saddam Hussein to prevent it.
The negotiations underscore a vast divide over United Nations inspections of Iraq's military sites. 
 On one side are the United States and Britain, which are determined that United Nations weapons inspectors carry out resolutions that give them unlimited access to any site in Iraq until the country's nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and ballistic missiles are destroyed.
"It's a simple standard, and it has not yet been met in anything we have heard about," State Department spokesman James P. Rubin said today in Washington.
On the other side are the would-be mediators who represent Governments that believe to varying degrees that an imperfect diplomatic outcome is preferable to military action whose outcome is unknown.
The French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, whose Government is determined to negotiate a way out of the crisis, expressed that view in a radio interview today. He acknowledged that Iraq's position in its negotiations this week with a French envoy were "totally inadequate" but added, "There are the first signs of movement."
French officials have said publicly and privately that the goal of the diplomacy was to persuade Iraq to allow United Nations inspectors, accompanied by independent experts or by mutually acceptable diplomats, into eight Presidential sites that have been off-limits.
But they added that there must be a formula for the inspections that shows "respect" for the Iraqi state, suggesting that the inspectors will not have carte blanche to enter any building at any time.
Mr. Vedrine also ruled out French cooperation with military actions. France, he said, "does not intend to participate in a military action, and for the moment is trying to obtain a solution through diplomatic means."
The diplomatic divide on the weapons inspections masks a much larger issue: the future of Iraq's leadership. The goal of the American strategy, suggested in a speech several months ago by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, is to keep so much pressure on Mr. Hussein that he is replaced.
Mr. Hussein has complained about that repeatedly, saying that no matter what he does, it will never be enough to satisfy Washington and remove onerous economic sanctions against him.
Still, Iraqi officials have indicated a slight willingness to compromise on the weapons inspections, telling French and Russian mediators that Baghdad would allow an inspection of the Presidential sites but on condition that they are carried out only once and include representatives from the Security Council as well as the inspectors themselves, diplomats said today.
In Moscow, meanwhile, Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin said today that the diplomatic track seems to be working, as his envoy, Viktor Posuvalyuk, continued his peace mission with Baghdad.
"I'm an optimist," Mr. Yeltsin told reporters in the Kremlin today. "We cannot yet say with certainty everything is okay, that there will not be another upsurge. But nonetheless the peak has lowered somewhat."
But Mr. Yeltsin reinforced the warning he made on Wednesday that the use of force could lead to a global confrontation. "The most important thing is that we have stuck firmly to our position of opposing the military option," he said today. "It is not possible. It would mean world war."
In Baghdad today, Turkey's Foreign Minister, Ismail Cem, met with Iraqi officials, telling reporters that Mr. Hussein was receptive to "everybody's concerns to avoid a military confrontation."
And in Jordan, the Arab League Secretary, Gen. Esmat Abdel-Meguid, who had just come from meetings in Baghdad, warned that it was difficult for him to believe that "any Arab country would accept a military strike on Iraq."
The United States, Britain and officials close to Secretary General Kofi Annan are deeply skeptical of all the negotiating, but powerless to stop it. In a closed meeting with the Security Council on Monday, Mr. Annan offered to use his good offices to try to solve the crisis, but the Council has not taken him up on his offer.
He has said that he hopes there would be no military action during the Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan, which end on February 23, a tactic to buy time for diplomacy to continue, his advisers said.
In an interview with the London-based Arab-language Al-Hayat newspaper to be published on Friday, Mr. Annan acknowledged that there were no "brilliant options" in dealing with Iraq, adding that military action was "a last resort."
Asked whether military strikes could mean the end of longterm United Nations monitoring of Iraq's weapons programs, he said, "That cannot be excluded."
The feeling is shared at the United Nations. "With so many cooks, he is waiting to see if he can be helpful," said one official close to Mr. Annan. "He doesn't want to be another cook stirring the soup."
The French position, which is shared by many other countries, is that the current military threat by the United States is much more ambitious and dangerous than the strike that was planned just two months ago, and that it is unlikely to achieve the goal of allowing the weapons inspections to continue.
One senior French official close to President Jacques Chirac noted in a telephone conversation from Paris that Security Council resolutions have not always been followed rigorously, and that the trick is to find a clever way to satisfy both Mr. Hussein and President Clinton.
The French official paraphrased Mr. Chirac's phone conversation a few days ago with President Yeltsin this way: "You know, Boris, you and I both are trying to avoid a war over there. We must understand Bill. Bill wants to strike. Maybe you and I have a role to play."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Stern Finishes the Testimony In the Hearing for Sprewell

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Commissioner David Stern sounded confident yesterday after testifying for nearly five hours in Latrell Sprewell's arbitration hearing against the National Basketball Association and the Golden State Warriors.
"I'm very comfortable with our actions, and we're awaiting the outcome," Stern said in an interview after his testimony. "I think that my job is to protect this league and the 400-plus players who never get involved in activity that we're now litigating about. And I feel comfortable when I've accorded myself the way I'm supposed to." 
 The hearing grew out of a Dec. 1 incident in which Sprewell attacked his Warriors coach, P. J. Carlesimo, twice during practice. The Warriors terminated Sprewell's contract, and, three days after the incident the N.B.A. suspended him for a year.
Stern was the last of 22 witnesses to testify over eight days. The arbitrator John Feerick said that post-hearing briefs must be filed by the close of business next Friday, and closing arguments have been scheduled for 10 A.M. Feb. 16 in New York. After the closing arguments, Feerick will make a ruling, which is binding, within 30 days.
Horace Balmer, the league's vice president of security; and Jim Wilson, the assistant director of security, and Alicia Parker, the manager of security, both of whom helped Balmer conduct 23 interviews over two days, also testified yesterday at the Manhattan law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
"We're happy that Latrell has finally received his day in court," said Billy Hunter, the players association's executive director. "And that due process and a right to a fair hearing before an impartial arbitrator has been granted."
Hunter added: "It's been our contention all along that the league justified its suspension by mischaracterizing the second incident as a premeditated attack. They arrived at the decision because of an inadequate investigation. Had there been an adequate and thorough investigation, in all probability they would not have reached the decision they did."
Sprewell's lawyers also claimed that there was a conspiracy between the league and the Warriors after the club had originally suspended him for 10 days the night of the attack.
"The reality is that this is the longest suspension in the history of sports involving a physical altercation," Hunter said.
He added, "The termination of the contract by the Warriors was based on economics despite their claims to the contrary."
Stern, whose last previous comments on the incident had come in a press release announcing Sprewell's suspension on Dec. 4, stuck yesterday to his original contention: that Sprewell's second attack on Carlesimo was premeditated and therefore worthy of a one-year ban.
"The release speaks for itself as to why Mr. Sprewell was suspended, and I don't want to get into any argument beyond that," Stern said.
He was also emphatic about his feeling that, irrespective of Feerick's decision, it would not erode his authority as commissioner.
"This is not about the ultimate authority here at all," Stern said. He added: "There are areas on the court where the appeal is to me. And there are other areas like this where we have agreed that my authority is not the last word. So this is not about authority."
Sprewell, who testified last week, sat in on the hearing every day, including four days in Portland, Ore., last week. He said he planned to stay in New York over the All-Star Game weekend, but he is not allowed to attend the game.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Politicians and Diplomats Wrangle Over Iraq Crisis
Republican Congressional leaders demanded that the Clinton Administration provide more clearly defined objectives for managing and concluding the confrontation with Iraq. The Pentagon sent reinforcements to the Persian Gulf. In talks with the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, who is visiting Washington, President Clinton said the goals of the allies in dealing with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq were clear and identical: "unconditional and unfettered access" to suspected weapons sites by U.N. inspectors. A1 

The chief weapons inspector for the U.N., Richard Butler, told the Security Council that the proposals floated by Iraq to defuse the crisis were not good enough, according to diplomats at the closed session. A10
 
A vast divide over the intrusive U.N. inspections of Iraq's military sites is opening between the United States and Britain, on the one hand, and other countries that believe that an imperfect diplomatic outcome is preferable to military action, especially since the outcome is unknown. A10
 
Accord on Korean Layoffs
South Korea's President-elect struck a landmark agreement with business and unions that laid the groundwork for layoffs and brought the country a step closer to resolving its economic crisis. The unions seemed to have been persuaded that layoffs were essential to reviving the economy. A7
 
South Africa Deports Journalist
South Africa is deporting a prominent reporter who has written many articles that angered Government officials. Critics said the deportation looked like an attempt to silence an irritating journalist. The Government said that the journalist, Newton Kanhema, a Zimbabwean citizen, had falsely claimed on an immigration document to have lived in South Africa since 1991, whereas, it said, he moved there permanently in 1992. A9
 
Jobless Germans Protest
Unemployed Germans staged protests across the country as the Government announced a postwar record of 4.8 million people out of work. Chancellor Helmut Kohl was assailed in Parliament for what the opposition called failed economic policies. A12
 
China Gives Permission, Late
China belatedly granted overflight rights to three European balloonists, a day after its refusal forced them to abandon their effort to circle the globe. The change of heart came too late to help the crew of the Breitling Orbiter 2 balloon in its round-the-world attempt, but the balloonists promised to try again next year.
 (Reuters)
 
Yeltsin Defends Two Reformers
President Boris Yeltsin defended two embattled young reformers, saying that barring major failures they would stay in his Cabinet until his term ended in 2000. Mr. Yeltsin acknowledged that he was facing pressure to oust the two, Anatoly Chubais and Boris Nemtsov, both of whom had recently had their duties trimmed. (Associated Press)
 
NATIONAL A16-21
 
Lawyers Say Accounts Of Aide and Clinton Differ
President Clinton's personal secretary has told investigators that Mr. Clinton called her into his office last month and led her through an account of his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky that differed in one critical aspect from her own recollections, according to lawyers familiar with her account. The secretary, Betty Currie, is reported to have said that Mr. Clinton had sometimes been alone with Ms. Lewinsky. Mrs. Currie has told investigators that the President asserted in that January meeting that he had never been alone with Ms. Lewinsky and that he had resisted her sexual advances, the lawyers said. Mrs. Currie has also retrieved and turned over to investigators several gifts -- a dress, a brooch and a hat pin -- that the President had given to Ms. Lewinsky, the lawyers said. A1
 
The independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, said he would not consider granting immunity to Ms. Lewinsky unless she submitted to face-to-face questioning with prosecutors. A21

The Democratic fund-raiser Yah Lin Trie pleaded not guilty in Federal court to criminal charges that he funneled hundreds of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions to the Democratic Party during President Clinton's re-election campaign. A19
 
Tobacco's Focus on Blacks
A steady flow of tobacco-industry documents released in recent days is providing the broadest and most detailed look at how the industry lavishly marketed cigarette brands like Kools to some of its heaviest-smoking customers, blacks. A1
 
The Clinton Administration said that it would be willing to give tobacco companies limited protection from lawsuits if that were the only way to get legislation enacted to raise the price of cigarettes and force the industry to restrict advertising and marketing. A18

NEW YORK/REGION A21-23
 
Immigrants Say Guards Abused Them in Jail
Immigrants seeking asylum who were held at the Union County Jail in New Jersey testified that guards had beat them, stuffed their heads in toilets and squeezed their genitals with pliers. Two guards are being tried on assault charges and a third is charged with conspiracy. Defense lawyers called the testimony exaggerated and said their clients had to cope with a language barrier to control inmates who had been described as "rioters and hostage takers." A1

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS: NAGANO 1998;
Cold Shoulder Turns Into Warm Embrace

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: NAGANO, Japan, Feb. 5

 BODY:
A grocer runs out of his store to give apples to passers-by. A taxi driver offers to take his passengers out for drinks -- on him. A restaurateur exchanges a round of sake for a round of photographs he has asked to be taken with his entire staff. The temperature is frigid, but the hospitality could not be warmer here at the roof of Japan.
The 1998 Winter Olympics open here Saturday morning -- Friday night on American television -- with a welcome that has become both extravagantly international and stirringly local. 
 Once diffident about being the hosts for the final Winter Games of the 20th century, the residents of this jumbled, isolated city of 360,000 people have recently changed their minds and offered visitors a genuine embrace as they prepare for the biggest and most expensive Winter Olympics in history.
Curiosity about other cultures seems to mean as much to local residents as the Games themselves, which will run for 16 days, involve 2,450 athletes from 72 countries and carry a price tag that has been estimated by economists at a staggering $10 billion. The local friendliness and courtesy have been as available and hearty as the soba noodles for which this region is famous.
"Nagano is in the country, and now we have famous athletes from all over the world who will come and know about us," said Hiroshi Tazika, owner of the Ebisuya restaurant. "I have not felt a lot of positive benefits, not so many customers. But it makes me happy to meet people from the world."
Every once in a while, the Olympics transcend the corporate clutter, the politics, the elitism of the International Olympic Committee and the scourge of drugs, and are distilled to their essence -- people from around the world coming together for a sporting event and cultural exchange. But to linger on this theme for too long is to risk sentimentality.
The possibility of an American attack on Iraq has intruded on the message of peace that the I.O.C. hopes will be carried by these Games. Security tensions were heightened by a rocket attack on Monday at Narita airport outside of Tokyo. A group calling itself the Revolutionary Workers Association, which said it has opposed construction of a second runway at the airport, has claimed responsibility for the attack. The police said they had no evidence the attack was aimed at disrupting the Games, however. So far, though, the only security incident at the Olympics themselves involved a suspicious package that turned out to contain a toilet- seat warmer.
The Nagano Games arrive during a long economic downturn in Japan, and organizers have reneged on several pledges, such as paying the travel expenses of all athletes. The direct budget is about $800 million, 20 percent more than original estimates. The overall $10 billion estimate includes related costs, including construction of new highways and a bullet train from Tokyo. Some local residents are suffering from sticker shock.
One of the Games' most vocal critics and supporters has been a Buddhist priest, Taka-Kazu Fukushima, who holds a Ph.D. in chemical engineering and who did post-doctoral work 20 years ago at the University of Michigan. He said in an interview that shop owners were worried that the new bullet train would carry retail business to Tokyo and that local construction companies had been passed over for larger Tokyo firms. He also suggested that if the Olympic figure skating, speed skating and hockey venues proved to be white elephants after the Games, they should be demolished instead of maintained at exorbitant costs.
But Fukushima has also given English lessons to residents for several years; it is important, he said, for Nagano to open itself to the world through the Winter Games.
"We are so local, so small," he said, "and now we will be world famous."
Aside from Nagano residents' friendliness, the 1998 Winter Games may be remembered less for what they are than for what they are not.
For starters, these Games will lack the lurid, good-girl, bad-girl melodrama of Nancy Kerrigan and Tonya Harding that consumed the 1994 Winter Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway. This time, the figure skating protagonists are friendly teen-age rivals, Michelle Kwan and Tara Lipinski, who have been jousting with axels and lutzes instead of collapsible batons.
These Olympics are taking place amid more gripping stories in the United States like the Iraq crisis and a Presidential sex scandal. It remains to be seen how much a diversion a skater named Lipinski will provide from a former White House intern named Lewinsky.
The Nagano Games are also most decidedly not the Atlanta Games. Organizers have gone to great lengths to avoid the transportation hassles and the tacky commercialism that marred the 1996 Summer Olympics. There is an unmistakable, sometimes annoying corporate presence here, but banners hanging on streets carry subdued corporate messages. Unlike Atlanta, snow-covered mountains provide the landscape, not 96-foot-tall watches and Empire State building-size bottles of Coca-Cola.
The Atlanta Games suffered from "wild commercialism; it was uncontrolled," said Francois Carrard, executive director of the I.O.C. "This is much more disciplined."
While transportation remains the No. 1 concern among the organizers, the buses seem to be running reasonably on time, and the drivers are not getting lost. Some official vehicles are even equipped with computer maps that give drivers oral directions to destinations. In Atlanta, some bus drivers appeared to be using maps of Dallas.
Three new sports will be contested -- snowboarding, curling and women's hockey. In these final Winter Games of the century, the women's Olympic movement, once a snowball, is gaining the momentum of an avalanche. For the first time, an Olympics will take place with a woman -- Anita DeFrantz of Los Angeles -- positioned as vice president of the I.O.C. The I.O.C. also announced this week that no new sports would be added to the Winter or Summer Games unless both men and women participated.
As happened in Norway in 1994, these Winter Games are being held outside the shadow of the Summer Games to establish a separate identity. This has proved to be a huge financial success: a record $800 million has been raised for the Nagano Games from corporate sponsorships and international broadcast rights. The $300 million raised from corporate sponsorships alone is three times the amount raised for the Lillehammer Games. Some 160 countries will broadcast these Games, compared with 120 for Lillehammer.
If the Winter Games are no longer a warm-up act for the Summer Games, Nagano is at least taking a cue from the Summer Olympics about professionalism. The National Hockey League will shut down for two weeks while its players compete in the Winter Games. This attempt at worldwide marketing is uncertain, considering that the United States team will play its games around midnight on the East Coast.
The N.H.L. also faces the possibility of huge embarrassment should any of its players test positive for Sudafed or other cold medicines containing the banned stimulant ephedrine. Sports Illustrated reported last week that up to 20 percent of N.H.L. players use Sudafed to get emotionally charged for games.
"I think the Sudafed issue will be a problem in this tournament," Dr. Makoto Ueki, the chief of the Nagano Olympic drug-testing lab, told reporters during a tour of the lab.
After skipping the 1994 Games amid floods and food shortages, North Korea returns with a team of speed skaters. Countries participating in the Winter Games for the first time are Uruguay, Azerbaijan, Macedonia, Venezuela and Kenya, which sent a cross-country skier.
"We have a lot of Kenyans in winter countries like the U.S., Germany, Switzerland," said Francis Paul, assistant secretary of the Kenyan Olympic Committee. "If they see this and take up skiing, I think we will have a very good team in the future."
No country will be under more pressure to win medals than Japan, which has produced only one individual gold medal in the Winter Games and is counting heavily on its speed skaters and ski jumpers. "My nerves are feeling the pressure," said the speed skater Manabu Horii, a gold-medal favorite in the 500-meter sprint.
The Americans have sent 196 Olympians to Nagano, with gold medal hopes in figure skating, men's and women's hockey, snowboarding, aerials, moguls, luge, bobsled and speed skating. Eric Flaim, a speed skater competing in his fourth Winter Games, will carry the United States flag in Friday's opening ceremony.
In the end, though, the competition may take second place to the geniality of the host city and its residents. Fukushima, the Buddhist priest, said he noticed a change in local attitudes about a month ago, when residents realized the world was about to arrive on Nagano's doorstep, whether the city was prepared or not.
"They decided not to be afraid of foreigners," he said, "and that we had to welcome the people."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Housing Permits Are Up

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Housing permits in Connecticut for 1997 were up 17.4 percent, the biggest increase in eight years, state officials said yesterday.
For December, Connecticut municipalities authorized 622 new housing units, up 5.6 percent from the same time last year. 
 For the year, the total number of housing permits increased 17.4 percent, to 9,054 compared with 7,714 in 1996, the Department of Economic and Community Development said.

HEADLINE: Argentine Economy Reborn but Still Ailing

SERIES: A REGION AT RISK: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
The process known awkwardly as "globalization" is many things. It is the information society. It is the erosion of national sovereignty. It is footloose corporations taking investments where labor is most productive. It is the growing premium on technical skills -- and the growing plight of unskilled laborers.
It is also the daily flow across borders of more than $1.5 trillion, from investors seeking to maximize profits and minimize risk and moving, at times of crisis, with all the discernment of a herd. For them, Seoul and Sao Paulo, Bangkok and Buenos Aires are one interchangeable "funny world": developing nations that threaten the annual bonus. 
 "What you realize with the Asian crisis," said Ken Baxter, a Brazilian banker, "is that when there's a stampede in this postmodern world, you don't have time to say, 'Hey, look, cattle, you've got it all wrong!' "
Argentina, unlike Brazil, was supposed to have it all right. During the 1990's it adopted the International Monetary Fund program that Brazil has shunned. Ditching decades of anti-Americanism, it won the status of "major non-NATO ally" by hitching its sails to Washington's whims in a way many Brazilians consider demeaning. It tied its currency so closely to America's that the dollar is available in bank cash machines and Argentines think nothing of buying their burgers and newspapers with dollars.
The transformation was stunning, Argentina a paradigm of the newly globalized economy. The national airline, the postal service, banks -- all the enterprises, it seemed, that President Carlos Saul Menem could find -- were privatized or sold to international investors as the country embraced free-market capitalism with the vengeance it had once shown in nationalizing everything.
"We're a country of extremes," said Hector Sabato, director of tourism in the southern town of San Carlos de Bariloche. "The old theme of the invading Yankee has given way to the wonderful Yankee driving the global train that you'd better board immediately or you're finished!"
So the shock has been that much greater as globalization has shown its other face. Since the Asian crisis bit, plants have been idled, growth forecasts have been slashed and the Argentine stock market has plunged more than 25 percent -- although from historic heights.
"What's frightening," said Jorge Bustamante of Merchant Bankers Associates, Buenos Aires representatives of Salomon Brothers, "is that however much you scream you're not a region, not the developing world, you're Argentina, you're different, it doesn't matter."
Latin America resembles Asia in its acute dependence on international capital, but in other ways it is indeed profoundly different. The region has been through two financial collapses -- the debt crisis of the 1980's and the Mexican meltdown of late 1994. These battered the banking system and left sobered banks, now often in foreign hands. The scope for nasty surprises of the Korean or Indonesian variety has been curtailed.
"Hot money" -- the huge short-term capital flows at the heart of the Asian crisis -- has ceded its dominant place in Latin America to longer-term investment, of the kind now being made by the Ford Motor Company, RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, Nestle S.A. and countless others.
Yet such distinctions now appear to have only limited value. "The financial risks of globalization are a lot bigger than optimists imagined," said Paul Krugman, a professor of economics at M.I.T. "We are back to a volatile, predepression world economy of financial booms and busts quite different from the cold war years."
In Argentina, this volatility has now fueled opposition to what is widely considered neo-liberalism, or "capitalismo salvaje" (savage capitalism): the radical application of the free-market model personified by the United States. Unused to living with economic pariahs -- the millions in Brazil who have never found a way to join the economy -- Argentina is discovering what permanent exclusion from the job market means.
Already, a political reaction is evident. An alliance of opposition parties defeated President Menem's Peronist Party in congressional elections last October. If a new crisis enveloped the region, the reaction to neo-liberalism could be violent.
 
The Unemployed Poor
When Company Profit Means Personal Loss
At the headquarters of the Roman Catholic diocese in the city of San Salvador de Jujuy, a sign on the door reads, "We regret that we cannot attend the unemployed here." Bishop Marcelo Palentini is overwhelmed. He sits behind a computer, working a cellular phone and an electronic agenda, but he does not like the modern world.
In the province of Jujuy, he estimates, 42 percent are unemployed or doing menial work. People used to ask for raises; now they ask for jobs.
Jujuy long had a bloated state payroll, a massively subsidized state-owned steel company, and labor-intensive sugar, tobacco and fruit farms. Then, in the 1990's, the free-market revolution arrived.
The provincial bank was privatized. The power utility was privatized. The postal service was privatized. The steel company was sold to Citicorp Equity Investments S.A., an Argentine group 40 percent owned by Citicorp. The phones were bought by Telecom, a private international group. Agriculture was transformed by imported American machines, each replacing 80 laborers during the cane harvest. Things began to work better; workers began losing jobs. Unemployment soared, to about 17 percent.
Last year the unemployed let their resentment show. Angry people blocked 21 provincial highways for several days. They held hunger strikes. Several people were injured.
The protests eased only after the mediation of Bishop Palentini. He helped to hammer out an accord creating six-month "work contracts" for several hundred, who agreed to do menial jobs for $200 a month.
Privatization, the bishop says, is positive, "but capital must consider a social dimension."
Still, for the Peronist Governor of Jujuy, Carlos Alfonso Ferraro, privatization is just beginning. Sitting in an office adorned with photographs of Gen. Juan Peron and his wife, Eva, he explained: "Look, it's simple. There is an Americanization of the world. We cannot go in the opposite direction. At last we are going to make America here."
And what of the photos of the Perons, the very symbols of a state-dominated, nationalist Latin American model? Peronism means revolution, said the Governor. That meant nationalization in 1946 and privatization today. "The heart of Peronism is economic independence," he beamed, "and how could I be independent when my phones didn't work?"
When General Peron took power in the 1940's, he set about distributing Argentina's early-20th-century prosperity -- comparable to that of leading European countries -- to build a mass following. "Violence in the hands of the people isn't violence," he proclaimed, "it's justice!"
A Peronist cult grew. So, too, did the country's state industries, its rich labor unions, its debilitating militarist myths of salvation through violence and upheaval, myths that would maroon doomed soldiers in the Falkland Islands in 1982 and add the word "desaparecidos" (the disappeared) to the world's vocabulary. Elegant Buenos Aires with its gilt and statuary became an elegy for a nation plundered.
By 1990, in the words of Carlos Fedrigotti, Citicorp's chief executive in Argentina, "the place had simply collapsed beneath the waste, corruption and mismanagement of a welfare state gone wild."
Collapse took several forms. The postal service favored theft over delivery of mail. It could take a decade to get a telephone. The economy shrank by 12 percent during the 1980's.
Argentina's travails were those of a protectionist, coup-plagued continent. Because the economy had failed so completely, when the Berlin wall fell and President Menem abruptly decided to undo General Peron's legacy, the country was something close to a blank canvas. Abruptly, this faraway place "on the way to nowhere" -- as despairing Argentines loved to lament -- re-entered the world after a long hiatus.
With the economic reforms, growth surged, reaching 8 percent in the first nine months of this year. American investment, including that of George Soros, the New York financier, poured in. A dead dock on the banks of the Plate River was transformed into swinging Puerto Madero, where the steaks came with air conditioning and valet parking.
But if it has drawn the favors of international investors through its reforms, Argentina has also become plagued by new uncertainties.
To look into the vacant eyes of Roberto Angel Garcia, 53, is to understand something of the cruelty of the economic upheaval that competing with the world has meant for Latin America.
Mr. Garcia was dismissed in 1992 along with thousands of other workers from Citicorp Equity's Aceros Zapla steel plant in the town of Palpala. Long run by the armed forces, it was legendary for its padded contracts until privatization came. Then its work force was slashed to 709 people, from 5,000. The company now produces high-quality special steels and expects to start making a profit this year.
The change will no doubt bring benefits in the long term: postwar development shows that countries that open to trade ultimately do better. But Mr. Garcia is paying the price for the adjustment.
He was too young for a pension, too old to find other work. "They told us we were being fired because we were losing money," he said, "but nobody had ever talked about losses before."
Like other workers, Mr. Garcia received an indemnity on dismissal -- about $19,000. But nobody gave the workers any guidance on how to use the money. Mr. Garcia spent most of his on a four-wheel-drive Ford. Now he has one of the temporary work contracts, moving rocks to build a dam. He knows it will not last.
Industries could once afford to be inefficient, because high inflation, repeated devaluations and scant competition from imports masked their failings. But throughout Latin America, such industries suddenly find themselves in a desperate push for productivity.
To be productive -- to make more shoes or cookies per employee -- generally involves using fewer people and the better machines now available from elsewhere.
The job cuts tend to fall on the old -- for the purposes of Latin America's adjustment, this category begins at about 40 -- who then join the globally unemployable.
A garrulous union leader in Jujuy, Carlos Santillan, has become the mouthpiece of the unskilled outcasts.
"Menem thinks that by putting our country at the service of the International Monetary Fund, he brought us into the first world," Mr. Santillan said. "But workers have lost in a few years rights they fought for over a century. We're a colony here. All that is missing is to have Clinton come here and plant the American flag."
As he spoke, Mr. Santillan was organizing a strike by municipal workers whose monthly salaries, about $250 each, were more than a month overdue. A lumbering state bureaucracy, in Argentina as elsewhere in Latin America, has not kept up with economic change.
So bills from privatized electricity and phone companies come on time, but services are promptly cut when bills are unpaid -- even though state workers may not have received the salaries with which to pay them.
 
The Rich Consumers
Gliding Through Life In Shopper's Heaven
The global economy has a smell: a fresh fragrance stripped of any trace of the third world's dust and sweat. It has a sound: piped music and floors so clean they squeak. It has a color: the very white teeth of smiling saleswomen.
These qualities are evident at the Galeria Pacifico shopping mall, a Soros property. It is in central Buenos Aires but could be anywhere. People glide past a procession of name-brand stores: Hugo Boss, Timberland, Lacoste.
"Argentina is just beginning," said Eduardo Elsztain, chairman of Irsa, the company that has been the main vehicle for turning Mr. Soros into one of the biggest landowners in Argentina.
Irsa, 25 percent owned by Mr. Soros, has bought office towers, luxury hotels, shopping malls and a large area of Puerto Madero; a sister company, Cresud, has acquired more than 850,000 acres of mainly pampa farmland and more than 180,000 cows.
Galeria Pacifico is a soothing emblem of the change that upper-class Argentines embrace. Mr. Santillan, like the Zapatistas in Mexico, may raise his voice against the United States, but most of the newly globalized Argentines, with their 50 channels of cable television and their hunger for cellular phones (1.1 million sold in the last year alone) seem to have embraced America.
Indeed the single most potent symbol of their changed country is the dollar. For decades, Argentines used to start the day by checking the dollar rate. Inevitably the inflation-racked peso had fallen. Planning meant getting through the day.
Then, after yet another bout of hyperinflation, a currency board similar to Hong Kong's was established in 1991, and a rate of one peso to one dollar was established by law. Not a peso can be printed unless it is backed by a dollar.
Of course the dollar-peso convertibility carries a price. Argentina is expensive. Salaries -- about $700 a month in a factory -- are relatively high. It is hard for businesses to compete globally.
Moreover, the strong currency, in an open economy, sucks in imports. Entire industries -- toys among them -- have been wiped out by cheap imports from China, where a worker's wage may be no more than $40 a month. Argentina, with its exports to Brazil affected by the Asian-induced downturn there, faces a rising trade deficit in 1998.
To offset this, it is essential that international capital, already threatened by Asia, continue to flow -- which it will only do if Argentina's productivity continues to rise.
"With the United States as a reference, you have to run all the time," said Mr. Bustamante, the banker. "Convertibility means you can never relax."
To run fast enough for the demands of the global market, Mr. Menem now proposes doing away with the collective bargaining still controlled by labor unions and seeking greater ease in hiring and firing. That in turn will probably mean lower wages but greater productivity.
However, this proposed labor reform is controversial. Virtually nobody -- including the opposition alliance that triumphed in October -- wants to undo convertibility, close the economy or return industries to state control. In this sense, as the sociologist Felipe Noguera said, "It's not an either-or political world anymore."
The symbol of the opposition victory in congressional elections last fall was not a figure of the left or right, but Graciela Fernandez Mejide, a rights advocate. The alliance she leads could block labor reform, leading markets to punish Argentina.
"A country advances not just through sound economic rules, but also by having a justice system that cannot be bought," said Domingo Cavallo, the former Economics Minister who was the architect of Argentina's transformation until he quit in 1996 in protest against corruption. "This Government seems to tolerate impunity."
The problem is widespread in Latin America, as shown by the swiftly rising crime rates in Mexico City, Sao Paulo and Buenos Aires. Because a global economy puts a high premium on technical skills and ownership of capital assets, it tends to accentuate wealth and income differentiation.
Governments, however, may plead helplessness. How, they ask, can they raise corporate and other taxes to pay for more efficient bureaucracies, education, better health services, honest police forces, stronger justice systems -- things Latin America desperately needs -- if global investors are generally averse to higher taxation and government spending?
Throughout Latin America, the sheer pace of global economic change appears to have left slow-moving states behind, unable to control the process of which they are a part.
American capitalism is being abruptly introduced into states that, like Argentina, Brazil or Mexico, may not have the technology, or the legal or regulatory systems, to keep up. The result can be galloping corruption and a brutal frontier capitalism.
"Increasingly we see that states need markets, but markets also need states," said Nicholas van Praag, a spokesman for the World Bank. "It's not enough to say that markets can do it all. You need security, you need an education system that works."
In some developing societies, the World Bank has recently begun linking judicial reform to loans -- money that once went for railroads and is now thought to be better used for the training of judges.
 
The Global Colonizers
Even U.S. Giants Have Ups and Downs
Wal-Mart, Buenos Aires, on a Saturday morning: an Argentine flag flutters in the store and there is a sign reading, "Proudly in Argentina." Families stroll down the wide, bright aisles, past displays of Newman's Own salad dressing.
Wal-Mart has created almost 8,000 jobs in Argentina and Brazil since it moved into the two countries three years ago. But it is impossible to say how many lost jobs -- at small neighborhood stores or businesses -- have stemmed from the store's arrival.
What is clear is that it is changing the Argentine way of life: families buy their bicycles here, sometimes using dollars; the corner bicycle store is no more.
Such change prompts ambivalence. A 65-year-old man, Luis Osvaldo Pazzotta, recalls the now-bankrupt textile factory that stood on this site, complains about the recent bankruptcy of his own carpentry business and mutters, "This is the new world, and I have no place in it."
Fernando Descalzo, a young telecommunications engineer working for McCaw, has other views. He is delighted with his Wal-Mart shopping; his family is about to have a hamburger at the adjacent Wendy's. "We're dollarized, we're Americanized, but frankly I don't care," he said.
Wal-Mart, attracted by the opening of Latin American economies, has already invested more than $500 million in Brazil and Argentina, opening 17 stores. The number of stores is destined to double in 1998.
"The Americas are our well-deserved first priority for now," said Bob L. Martin, chief executive of Wal-Mart International. "Even with recent difficulties stemming from Asia, especially in Brazil, we are on track to make our first profits in 1998."
But, of course, Wal-Mart is not impervious to the risks of divided societies. In the last few months, five Wal-Mart stores in Brazil have been robbed by assailants operating in large groups and armed with assault rifles.
 
The Trendy Investors
Patagonian Pampas As Real Estate Craze
When Bill Clinton came to Argentina in October, he stayed at the Hotel Llao Llao near the Patagonian town of Bariloche. Long state-owned, the luxury hotel now belongs to Mr. Soros's investment vehicle, Irsa.
Mr. Soros is not alone. Patagonia is trendy: call it the nature reserve for the globally stressed. Argentina can still be bought for third-world prices, and if it becomes a first-world country the owners of property will make lot of money.
Drive past glittering lakes, on across a steppe so flat that it induces an effect known as horizontal vertigo, and there, just four hours from the Hotel Llao Llao, lies the ghost town of Cutral-Co.
Dust blusters through the windy streets. People stare into space. The airport, once served by Aerolineas Argentinas, is closed. Aerolineas has been privatized, and it makes no economic sense to fly here.
Y.P.F., the formerly state-owned oil company that contrived to lose $6 billion between 1982 and 1990, used to employ 5,000 people here. Now there are 500; Y.P.F. made $900 million in 1996.
Mario Acosta, a Y.P.F. manager, explained that when the old system was dismantled, everyone who was not a professional was laid off. "Before," he said, "uneducated people had a certain basic security. But that's finished in the modern world."
Orlando Mendes used to work at Y.P.F. He has found a part-time job in the city administration. But he cannot support his wife and two children on $200 a month, so every few months he takes a 24-hour bus ride to Buenos Aires, and buys shoes in a factory. The shoeboxes are piled on his children's beds.
"If I'm lucky," he said, "I'll get 16 pesos here for shoes that I bought for 10 pesos. We survive. But I don't like this life. Y.P.F. was a family. Now I arrive at the train station in Buenos Aires, and there are kids everywhere stealing, and frankly I'm afraid."
Something else is troubling Mr. Mendes. There are more fences going up in Patagonia, as the internationally wealthy install themselves on newly acquired estates. "I used to go and camp or fish, but now I hear that Ted Turner is here, Rambo there, the Terminator somewhere else. And I say, no, this is not my Argentina."

HEADLINE: Raise Interest Rates

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman's analysis of the Asian situation (column, Feb. 3) is on the mark. The disagreement I have is with his comment that the Federal Reserve should lower interest rates to keep our economy rolling and that this would help alleviate the economic situation worldwide. 
 Lowering interest rates would also lower the value of the dollar, which would make it more difficult for the ailing economies to export to the United States. An approach has to be taken similar to that of Paul A. Volcker when he was chairman of the Federal Reserve during the early 1980's. Interest rates were raised substantially to dash inflation.
However, I am certain that Mr. Volcker also had in mind significantly increasing the value of the dollar, thereby making exports into the United States accelerate to unprecedented levels. These actions prevented the world from entering into a global depression.
 
DAVID WEINSTEIN
Philadelphia, Feb. 4, 1998
 
The writer is a financial adviser.
