HEADLINE: Business, Asian Style: A Revaluing Of Values;
Some Say Market Collapse Shows Democracy Is Key To Growth, After All

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Ideas need champions. And Lee Kuan Yew, the patriarch and former Prime Minister of Singapore, has proved to be a particularly effective spokesman for "Asian values," a notion that has gained a wide and receptive audience over the last decade.
The concept of Asian values combines a work ethic, a respect for family and a deference to government authority -- a kind of Protestant ethic without the Western reverence for individualism. 
 To many Westerners as well as Asians, Asian values have offered a convincing cultural explanation for what appeared to be the best-of-both-worlds achievement of much of the region: attaining high economic growth while avoiding the rising rates of crime, broken homes and out-of-wedlock births so common in the West. Even skeptics saw some merit in the concept.
Still, the economic ascent of Asia seemed to occur without a corresponding increase in personal liberty, an independent judiciary or press freedom. The region's authoritarian tinge has been an apparent challenge to the more than century-old Western belief that free markets and political liberalism are inextricably linked, self-reinforcing trends.
Mr. Lee and some others went further: they defended the authoritarian arrangements in Singapore and other Asian nations as essential tools for promoting economic success.
Thus the current Asian economic crisis has precipitated a fallout not only in banks and financial markets, but also in intellectual circles, prompting a re-examination of the Asian-values concept and its implicit challenge to the linkage of capitalism and democracy.
"This crisis has certainly taken the wind out of the sails of the Asian-values argument that authoritarian states have an advantage in promoting economic progress," said Francis Fukuyama, a professor of public policy at George Mason University.
Like other critics, Mr. Fukuyama says the Asian-values concept was always too broad a generalization for a vast region of considerable diversity. Even the term was an overstatement, given that the advocates of Asian values were usually speaking of East Asia, specifically, the lands east of Thailand, basing their cultural and economic arguments on the experience of Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and tiny Hong Kong and Singapore.
Mr. Fukuyama is best-known for his 1989 essay "The End of History," in which he argued that the end of Communism in the East bloc showed that the global drift toward liberal democracy was inevitable. Now, in an article in the February issue of Commentary, he predicts that the economic shocks in Asia will hasten political change in the region.
"In short," Mr. Fukuyama writes in Commentary, "what the current crisis will end up doing is to puncture the idea of Asian exceptionalism." The sometimes harsh laws of economics have not been repealed in Asia, he adds, and neither have the laws of politics: "The well-documented correlation between stable democracy and a high level of development surely applies to a region where rising educational achievements and the complex nature of industrial or post-industrial societies will increasingly favor the rule of law and greater popular participation."
The idea that democracy and capitalism are tightly linked was first presented as a political theory by 19th-century English liberal writers like James Bryce. They were trying to explain the erosion of feudalism and the spread of democracy in Europe as the Industrial Revolution was under way. In the 1950's and 60's, American social scientists asserted that the link between democracy and capitalism helped explain the process of "modernization," as many third world nations began industrializing in the midst of the postwar economic boom. Capitalism's rising wealth, it seemed, led inevitably to democratization, materialism and strains on the social fabric -- all the forces associated with modernization.
By the late 60's, modernization theorists tended to question whether democracy and capitalism were as interrelated as once thought. Rising affluence clearly affected politics, but scholars observed that the linkage was complicated. As Samuel P. Huntington, a Harvard political scientist, put it: "Economic development makes democracy possible; political leadership makes it real."
For the last two decades, cultural theorists have gained ground in the world of ideas and popular opinion. The notion of "civil society," broadly defined as a culture that promotes a healthy economy and society, has been advanced by politicians ranging from Hillary Clinton to Pat Buchanan. And culture has been increasingly cited as the key determinant of economic and political outcomes.
"Culture is certainly the basis for most of what happens in terms of economic progress," said Joel Kotkin, the author of "Tribes" and a senior fellow of the Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. "And more broadly, it is the cultural virus that shapes most of what societies do and how they do it, politically, economically and otherwise."
 
A Path Similar To the West's
 In the culture-is-destiny camp, the Asian-values concept has been perhaps the most sweeping claim of all.
Cultures obviously differ, yet those differences, says Fareed Zakaria, managing editor of Foreign Affairs, mainly affect the path and pace at which global capitalism leads to political liberalization from one country to the next. But the process, he insists, is all but irresistible.
Asia's economic crisis, Mr. Zakaria believes, is a shock that will accelerate the process of political liberalization in the region. "None of this is neat, clean or all at once," he said. "But these countries are being forced to democratize along what is almost exactly the course of the West since the 18th century."
In the West, Mr. Zakaria observed, democracy typically means liberal democracy, a political system characterized by not only free elections, but also the rule of law, the separation of powers and the protection of basic liberties of speech, assembly, religion and property.
 
Middle Class As a Nudge
 But too often, he says, people fail to appreciate the lengthy, often turbulent history that led to liberal democracy in the West. In the 1850's, he notes, England had a legal system, but the aristocracy was all but exempt from the rule of law. The "crony capitalism" of patronage for favored business executives, now under fire in some Asian nations, he says, resembles the system exploited by America's industrial robber barons in the 1890's.
In an article in the November-December issue of Foreign Affairs, Mr. Zakaria surveyed the phenomenon of immature democracies, which have elections but not the wider freedoms associated with Western-style liberal democracy. He called these nations "illiberal democracies": countries in Asia, but also countries like Russia and Peru, where leaders bypass their parliaments to rule by presidential decree.
None of these governments, Mr. Zakaria asserts, will relinquish control willingly. But the rising wealth generated by market economies, he adds, will certainly loosen their grip on political freedoms over time.
"When a nation's economy liberalizes and starts to develop a sizable middle class, it begins a gradual progression that leads toward liberal democracy," Mr. Zakaria said. "No matter what Lee Kuan Yew may hope, the kids of Singapore today spend more than their parents and are less deferential to authority. With another 10 or 20 years of growth, most of these so-called Asian values will erode even further."
As evidence, Mr. Zakaria points to the statistics of Freedom House, a nonprofit organization that monitors political rights and civil liberties around the world, measuring the performance of nations in a complex rating system. He notes that virtually every country with a per-capita gross domestic product of $8,000 or more is in the top tier of the Freedom House rankings of political and civil freedom, with the only exceptions being special cases like the oil-rich emirates of the Middle East and Singapore (a tiny state of 2.8 million people, whose economic development happens to have been guided by a brilliant autocrat, Mr. Lee).
The Asian-values advocates reply that economic and political freedoms are not naturally linked. And the leaders of some Asian nations have relied on the regional cultural theory to justify restrictions on personal freedom.
At the World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna in 1993, for example, Singapore's Foreign Minister warned that "universal recognition of the ideal of human rights can be harmful if universalism is used to mask the reality of diversity." The Chinese delegation was more blunt, saying, "Individuals must put the states' rights before their own."
 
What Would Confucius Say?
 A central tenet of the cultural rationale for a distinctively Asian approach to human rights has been the assertion that Confucius was an authoritarian. Amartya Sen, a professor of economics and philosophy at Harvard University, has challenged this interpretation of Confucianism.
"Confucius did not recommend blind allegiance to the state," Mr. Sen observed in a lecture last year at the Carnegie Council on Ethics and International Affairs. "When Zilu asks him how to serve a prince, Confucius replies, 'Tell him the truth, even if it offends him.' The censors in Singapore or Beijing would take a very different view."
Mr. Sen derides the cultural argument for decoupling economic and political freedom. "The authoritarian readings of Asian values that are increasingly championed in some quarters," he said, "do not survive scrutiny."

HEADLINE: Study Finds Strokes More Common Than Previously Thought

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 6

 BODY:
Strokes hit about 200,000 more Americans a year than commonly believed, a new study has found. It tried to correct previous research by looking at black neighborhoods instead of just white communities.
The study, with other research, suggests that about 700,000 Americans a year suffer strokes, or about 40 percent more than the accepted estimate, and that the figures could double in the next half-century. 
 The authors of the new estimate said it more accurately reflected the nation's ethnic diversity and the frequency of second and third strokes. Dr. Joseph Broderick of the University of Cincinnati Medical Center described the results here today at a medical conference sponsored by the American Heart Association. They are also being published in the journal Stroke.
The current figure, adopted by the American Heart Association and others, holds that 500,000 Americans suffer strokes each year. This estimate is based on the Framingham Heart Study, which has followed the health of one virtually white, middle-class Boston suburb for almost 50 years. The only other long-running look at the incidence of stroke comes from Rochester, Minn., an affluent, overwhelmingly white community.
To make an estimate that more accurately reflects the racial and economic mix of the country, researchers from the University of Cincinnati looked at all the strokes recorded among the 1.3 million residents of the Cincinnati area in 1993.
The area's black population, 14 percent, and its median income, $31,000, are similar to those of the United States.
The study found 288 first-time strokes for every 100,000 people among blacks. When recurrent strokes were counted, 411 occurred for every 100,000 blacks.
This compared with 179 first-time strokes per 100,000 people among the white residents of Rochester during the late 1980's.
Dr. Broderick said that when extrapolated nationally, his findings suggested that Americans suffered about 500,000 first-time strokes and 700,000 total strokes annually.
Another study presented at the meeting by Thomas Taylor, an economist from the University of Iowa, used Census data and other studies to calculate the number of strokes likely in 2050.
Assuming 400,000 first-time strokes annually now, this study projects that the total will more than double to slightly more than one million during the next 50 years, though the population is expected to grow only about 50 percent.
The researchers said the aging of the population will be responsible for the increase. But, the projection also assumes no gains in preventing strokes.
Dr. Philip Wolf of the Framingham study said that although he was not sure whether the 700,000 estimate was correct, he believed the 500,000 figure was almost certainly too low, because it did not take into consideration the higher toll of strokes on blacks or the elevated stroke risk among whites in the South.
Dr. Michael Walker of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke said the new estimate should be "a wake-up call" of stroke's importance.
Although the risk of stroke is about the same for elderly blacks and whites, it is considerably higher for blacks than whites at younger ages. The reasons for this are thought to include more high blood pressure among blacks, and the effects of smoking, obesity, poverty and possibly genetic differences.

HEADLINE: Maintaining Local Flavor;
Will Too Much Success Spoil Blue Bell Ice Cream?

BYLINE: By KATE MURPHY 

DATELINE: BRENHAM, Tex.

 BODY:
Have you ever had Blue Bell ice cream? It depends almost entirely on where you live.
In Texas and a number of nearby states, chances are you've had a scoop. In some markets, more than half the ice cream sold is Blue Bell. Its regional might is so great that even though it is not available in most of the country, it is the nation's No. 3 ice cream. 
 What is the secret to Blue Bell's sweet success? To Howard W. Kruse, chief executive of Blue Bell Creameries Inc., it is simple. "We make the best ice cream in the country," he said as earnestly as an East Texas accent allows. "The milk we use is so fresh, it was grass yesterday."
But part of the formula is surely Blue Bell's homespun appeal, with constant reminders of its folkloric "little creamery in Brenham."
In fact, Blue Bell could be on the way to becoming the Coors of the 90's, as outsiders bootleg it in ice chests to where it is not available or, like the poet Maya Angelou, pay exorbitantly to get it by overnight delivery.
The question now is whether this almost cultish mystique can survive as Blue Bell strives to become a true national brand, gradually stretching its radius as it enters one new market after another.
A local favorite can easily make it big in the wider world, as Jack Daniel's whisky proves, or it can face a rougher journey, as Cape Cod potato chips, Nantucket Nectar juices, Krispy Kreme doughnuts and others have learned.
For one thing, cutting corners on quality can backfire. Harder to control, though, is that regional tastes vary. New Yorkers may not crave the same ice cream Texans do. And some products just can't make it if they lose their down-home image.
Blue Bell hopes it can cope with all this, partly by maintaining strict oversight on production, and still grow outside its regional base.
Founded in 1907 when enterprising townsfolk converted an abandoned cotton gin to churn farmers' excess cream into butter, Blue Bell had 1997 sales of $191 million, according to Information Resources Inc.
Although it is carried in just 14 percent of the nation's groceries, the ice cream ranks behind only the top seller, which goes under the Dreyers label in the West and Edy's in the East, and No. 2 Breyers, and is ahead of Haagen-Dazs and Ben & Jerry's.
With $3.3 billion in sales, the market for store-bought ice cream is filled with plenty of contenders defending their turf.
"There's a lot of competition out there, but we're willing to work at it," said Mr. Kruse, whose German ancestors settled in the rolling hills of Brenham, 70 miles northwest of Houston, in 1880. The privately held creamery has been under his family's control since 1919.
"Blue Bell does make a heck of an ice cream," confirmed Jerry L. Dryer, a dairy industry analyst and marketing consultant in Chicago, but "that's just a small piece of what it takes to make it nationally."
Tastes -- whether for ice cream or any other food or drink -- can vary widely. Cape Cod potato chips flew off the shelves in the Northeast, but in the 1980's, when the Anheuser-Busch Companies bought the brand and tried to take it nationwide, they gathered dust in many parts of the South and Midwest. "Just because a product has a loyal local following doesn't necessarily mean it will translate well into other markets," said Robert E. Spekman, marketing professor at the Darden School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia.
Blue Bell has seen significant taste variation within its relatively small sales area, which expanded outside Texas in 1989 to gradually encompass the other Gulf Coast states as well as Oklahoma and parts of New Mexico, Kansas and Missouri.
To cope, the company has, through test-marketing and trial and error, tailored flavors to suit local preferences. Banana Pudding is popular in New Orleans; Lemon goes over better in Dallas. Still, Blue Bell's flagship flavor, Homemade Vanilla, "has strong appeal wherever we've gone," said John W. Barnhill Jr., who as executive vice president and general sales manager is Blue Bell's second in command.
Another challenge is maintaining the homespun image that first made a product popular. Entenmann's baked goods lost that edge when a succession of corporate giants, including Warner-Lambert, Kraft Foods and now Bestfoods expanded distribution but failed to emphasize the brand's origin as a tiny Brooklyn bakery that delivered goods by horse-drawn wagon.
"Today it's just another brand without much distinction fighting it out in a very competitive market," said Lynn C. Dornblaser, editorial director of New Product News, a Chicago trade publication.
Even though Blue Bell has plants in three states that crank out 100,000 gallons of ice cream a day, it relentlessly advertises itself as the "little creamery in Brenham." The company spends 2 to 4 percent of its sales on advertising and bumps that up by another 25 percent per household locally when it enters a new market.
Along with print, radio and TV spots featuring grazing cows and barefoot country children, Blue Bell officials pay a neighborly visit to the mayor of each new city where they expand distribution, bearing a free gallon or two of ice cream.
The strategy mimics that adopted by the Brown-Forman Corporation in the 1950's to sell Jack Daniel's whisky nationally. For over 40 years, Jack Daniel's ads have depicted an old distillery in bucolic Lynchburg, Tenn. Founded in 1866, the distillery -- today a thoroughly modern plant that produces five million cases a year -- attracts tourists from throughout the United States, just as Blue Bell devotees flock to Brenham to watch ice cream cartons trundle along a fully automated assembly line. Both sites feature consciously quaint, Victorian-style facades, and Blue Bell also has an old-fashioned ice cream parlor.
But image is only part of it. Another danger is that the mass production needed to go national will change the taste. Ask anyone who remembers what an Entenmann's crumb cake or Famous Amos cookie used to taste like.
"It's hard-to-impossible to maintain the integrity of a product when you start producing it on a massive scale," Ms. Dornblaser said.
This is especially true when a company sells out to a larger concern. "Large corporations usually are more interested in the brand than the product behind it," said Jonathan K. Frenzen, clinical associate professor of new product management at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business. "Economics usually triumphs over taste considerations."
Take Krispy Kreme doughnuts, legendary in their native South. To cut costs, Beatrice Foods, now a unit of Conagra Inc., changed the 1937 recipe when it took over the product in 1976. After years of declining profits, a group of franchisees bought Krispy Kreme back in 1982. "The first thing we did was go back to the original recipe," said Scott Livengood, president of the Krispy Kreme Doughnut Corporation.
The company is again trying to expand nationally, with the goal of opening 70 new stores, for a total of 105, by year-end. But this time every outlet will receive the original doughnut mix directly from a central plant in Winston-Salem, N.C.
"Central control is essential to keeping up the quality," Mr. Livengood said.
Mr. Kruse at Blue Bell agreed. "Things are liable to change when you allow outside control," he said. Blue Bell declines at least six buyout offers a year and refuses to contract out production or delivery.
Its greatest difficulty in pursuing a wider market has been distribution. Like so many other small food and beverage companies, Blue Bell has had difficulty gaining supermarket shelf space. "Some stores have certain expectations," Mr. Barnhill said, referring to the under-the-table but perfectly legal practice of charging "slotting fees" -- payments grocery stores demand from companies to stock their products or to display them more prominently.
"Stores swear they don't do it, but they do," said Nancy Panos Schmitt, associate professor of marketing at Westminster College in Salt Lake City. "Shelf space is so pricey it keeps a lot of good products from getting to the consumer."
Kineret, a line of frozen kosher foods now owned by Hain Food Group, almost went bankrupt shelling out for shelf space when it tried to enter markets outside the Northeast.
And the founders of Nantucket Allserve Inc., based in Cambridge, Mass., initially had to beg mom-and-pop stores to stock Nantucket Nectars because they could not afford to get their juice beside Ocean Spray and Lipton in major grocery and convenience stores.
Blue Bell says it refuses to pay slotting fees and thus receives little or sometimes no shelf space in Kansas City area supermarkets, where it has no strong ties. Blue Bell has only 8 percent of the Kansas City market -- but over 50 percent of many of its other markets.
The company will stay in the region, though, in the hope that a familiar grocery chain will move in soon. "I wish we'd done a little more research before we went in there," Mr. Barnhill said. "We've been a lot more careful since then."
Blue Bell expects plenty of room in grocers' freezers when it makes its debuts in Atlanta next month and in Memphis in July. It would not disclose its long-range expansion strategy, but if history is any indication, Blue Bell will continue its conservative state-by-state creep, adding at least two big urban areas a year.
But as Blue Bell expands its territory and its ice cream becomes more widely available, will it lose its mystique? "That's what happened to Coors beer," says Mr. Frenzen at the University of Chicago.
Coors had something of a cult status in the 1970's, when it was sold exclusively in the Rocky Mountain region and on the West Coast.
When the Coors Brewing Company began to sell its product nationally in the 1980's, the furor quickly faded. Even though it was the same beer, "it wasn't special anymore," Mr. Frenzen said. "Scarcity has always been a source of perceived value."
Mr. Kruse is not concerned. "People are always going to want the best," he said.

HEADLINE: Whitman, Like Other Leaders, Must Pick Budget Surplus Plan

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman unveils her new state budget next week, she faces the same difficult choice as her fellow Republican Governors in New York and Connecticut: whether to spend or give back a huge budget surplus.
Senior Whitman administration officials announced today that they had revised tax revenue projections upward by $609 million for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30. And for the new fiscal year, beginning July 1, they estimated there would be an additional $710 million in tax revenues. That could give Mrs. Whitman about $1.3 billion to spend or return to taxpayers over the next 17 months. The state adopted a $16.2 billion budget last June. 
 State Treasurer James A. DiEleuterio Jr. said the state's strong economy and the boom on Wall Street contributed to the unexpected rise in tax dollars flowing into the state's coffers.
Mr. DiEleuterio would not say whether Mrs. Whitman intended to use the extra money for spending increases or tax cuts. The Governor is scheduled to outline her new spending plan to the State Legislature on Tuesday.
But Democrats were already offering Mrs. Whitman some ideas on what to do with the money.
"We favor a property tax cut, and we've offered a couple of good ways to slice it," said the assistant Senate minority leader, Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hoboken. "Personally, I would like a substantial boost in state aid for education to put the state share in the neighborhood of 50-50 with local school boards, where everyone knows it should be."
Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Democrat from Camden County, called today for expanding the state's property-tax rebate program. It now provides property tax rebate checks, up to $500, for senior citizens whose income is under $100,000 and for homeowners and tenants whose household income does not exceed $40,000.
Mr. Bryant said Mrs. Whitman and Republican lawmakers should use $400 million from the budget surplus for a property-tax-rebate program to all households with incomes between $40,000 and $100,000 for at least one year.
"There is no reason why we cannot make it the policy of the state to set aside a portion of revenue growth each year to fund the Homestead Rebate program," he said.
In Connecticut, Gov. John G. Rowland announced this week that he intended to put checks in the mail -- some for as much as $200 -- to taxpayers, returning $125 million of a state surplus that is projected to be at least $180 million.
The budget surplus is a record $1.8 billion in New York State. After three years of putting forth austere spending plans, Gov. George E. Pataki recommended a 7.6 percent spending increase and the acceleration of already enacted tax cuts in his new $71.9 billion spending plan.
Mrs. Whitman faces pressure to increase spending for the state's urban schools. A judge has recommended that New Jersey spend $312 million more annually for programs in urban schools. The State Supreme Court must now decide whether to force the state to do it.
In her inaugural address, Mrs. Whitman also promised to spend $200 million more a year to help preserve farmland and other open space.
Mr. DiEleuterio said that growth in the personal income tax accounted for the biggest increase in revenues for this fiscal year and the new fiscal year. The personal income tax is expected to generate $304 million more than anticipated in this year's budget, and another $520 million more in the new state spending plan.
Sales tax revenues are also expected to rise $170 million in this year's budget, and $208 million more in next year's budget.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Prices Rise as Fears About Asia and Interest Rates Ebb

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Bond prices rallied yesterday as investors seemed to dismiss the third surprisingly strong employment report in a row. Instead, they are still betting that the drag from Asia will slow growth in the United States enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.
Stocks also moved higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 72.24 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,189.49, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks jumping 8.92 points, also nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,012.46, a new high. For the week, the Dow was up 3.6 percent and the S.& P. 500 3.3 percent. 
 While both stocks and bonds gained yesterday, it is because the two markets diverge in their outlooks on Asia that the story becomes interesting. It appears that this week's stock rally was built, in part, on the belief that Asia's impact on the United States will be much weaker than feared.
"There is less concern about the impact on the American economy then there was in the fall," Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, said of the stock market. Recent analyses have suggested that many companies could be helped, he noted.
That change of sentiment, he said, can be seen in the rebound recently of so-called cyclical stocks, which are sensitive to economic cycles and would generally have earnings problems if the economy slowed down a lot. Since its low on Jan. 9, the Morgan Stanley index of 30 cyclical stocks is up 10.9 percent, with even some of its hard-hit members, like Caterpillar and International Paper, bouncing back.
Big bank stocks have also rebounded strongly, after falling sharply on fears that the Asian financial turmoil would cut into their trading profits and earnings, a concern that was confirmed in some fourth-quarter earnings reports released last month. The Keefe, Bruyette & Woods index of 24 money-center and leading regional banks is up 10 percent since Jan 23.
Yesterday, banks were leading the market again. J. P. Morgan led the Dow higher as rumors of a merger with Deutsche Bank sent the price of the stock up 4 3/8, or 4.1 percent, to 111 3/4. The bank would not comment, but several bank analysts dismissed the chances of such a merger. "It is not to be believed," said George Salem, a banking analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company.
The change in interpretation of the Asian impact has been helped by the recent rally in the stock markets of Asian countries that have been engulfed by the financial turmoil and whose economic growth is expected to slow significantly this year: South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and Hong Kong. The rally in the Japanese stock market has also helped.
Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers, said that while the worst of the economic impact from Asia was still to be felt, the rallies in markets in Asia, Europe and the United States might be an indicator that things will be better a few quarters down the road.
It is not illogical, he said, for European or American stocks indexes to be rallying. "We are looking over the valley -- the trough," he said.
But since the drag from Asia is still looming, there could be some rude surprises in the spring, when this year's first-quarter earnings begin to be released.
"The question is: is this the beginning of something that is going to go on and on?" asked Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. "I don't think so because we are going to by tagged" by Asia. Mr. McCabe of Merrill Lynch added: "We are going from the overpessimistic of the fall to the overoptimistic of the spring. Then we will take a look."
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year bond rose 5/32, to 102 29/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 5.92 percent, from 5.93 percent on Thursday. In the when-issued market, where there is trading ahead of next week's quarterly Treasury auction, the 3-year note yielded 5.40 percent; the 10-year note, 5.57 percent, and the 30-year bond, 5.92 percent.
The employment report released yesterday showed that 358,000 new nonfarm payroll jobs were created in January -- well above forecasts of 235,000. It was the third month in a row that job growth was stronger than expected. But after a brief selloff, the bond market rebounded and finished little changed on the day.
Neill M. Soss, the chief United States economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, attributed the rebound to bond investors who were counting on the drag from Asia to slow down the American economy.
And while he acknowledged that there was no significant sign of such a slowing yet, he said that the Federal Reserve had clearly indicated to investors that the central bank expected one. That makes it even easier to dismiss strong economic reports that would normally send bonds tumbling.
Mr. Soss noted that the Fed announced this week that it had changed its official policy outlook, which had presumed that its next interest rate move would be an increase. That stance, which is an important signal of the central bank's intent, is now neutral.
In addition, he said that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, indicated in Congressional testimony at the end of last month that the impact of Asia would not be fully known until this spring, which means any move by the Fed in not likely for several months. "The market can take comfort from that idea," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese House Votes to Bail Out Banks

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The Japanese Government took a stride closer toward bringing stability to Japan's volatile financial system as the lower house of Parliament approved legislation early today to spend about $240 billion to bail out banks.
Politicians say they hope that the legislation, which is expected to win approval in the upper house in about a week, will help dispel the uncertainty and pessimism that have plagued markets here since November, when four financial institutions collapsed. Since then, there have been repeated jolts of bad news, including rising corporate failures, weak economic performance, the arrests of Finance Ministry officials and the resignation last week of the Finance Minister. 
 The bailout is one of the biggest in history, and though it still has its critics, the expectation that the Government will finally spend money to maintain financial stability has helped calm the markets a bit recently and the currency has risen slightly. On Friday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues ended at 17,040.06, up 2.5 percent for the week, while the yen was quoted at 124.12 yen to the dollar, up from 126.85 yen last week.
"We absolutely need this bill to help out banks that are having problems raising funds on their own," Kimio Yamaguchi, head of the Finance Ministry's banking bureau, told the Parliament before the vote, according to Bloomberg News.
While the Government says it hopes the legislation will resolve the nation's financial crisis, many economists and analysts are skeptical that the measures are sufficient. Japan's economy has been faltering for seven years, in large part because the Government has been reluctant to move aggressively to manage the debt crisis. It finally acknowledged last month that banks were saddled with bad or questionable loans amounting to about $620 billion.
With such a heavy debt burden, banks have been trying to shrink their loan assets, and this has helped bring about a credit squeeze, which in turn has led to higher numbers of corporate bankruptcies and overall unease in the economy.
Two bills were passed early this morning, one of which would provide 17 trillion yen, or $137 billion, to guarantee deposits and strengthen the Deposit Insurance Corporation, or D.I.C., an entity similar to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. With the new law, which could go into effect later this month, the D.I.C. in Japan can also be called upon to help deal with the collapse of financial institutions.
The second bill, which has drawn more criticism, would make available 13 trillion yen, or $105 billion, to allow the Government to help strengthen the capital base of the banks. Essentially, it would buy subordinated debt of the banks or take a stake in them by buying their preferred shares, which carry no voting rights. The plan draws heavily from one used by the United States in the 1930's when the Government bought preferred shares in banks to help pull the nation out of the Depression.
The Government has not yet announced how it will determine which banks' shares or debt it will buy. But it has suggested it will follow the American approach and start by buying shares in healthy institutions to lend credibility to the program. Critics fear that the program will be used to bolster ailing banks that should be allowed to close down or be merged with other institutions.

HEADLINE: JOBS IN JANUARY WERE UP SHARPLY

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The economy created jobs at a surprisingly robust pace in January, the Government reported today, evidence that America's economic stamina has withstood any disruptions caused so far by the financial tumult in Asia.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics said the economy added 358,000 jobs last month, far above the 235,000 forecast by economists. 
 It was the third consecutive month that job generation has been exceptionally strong. With growing opportunities for work drawing more people into the labor force, the unemployment rate remained at 4.7 percent in January, just a notch above its quarter-century low.
The demand for workers also led employers to raise wages again last month. Average hourly earnings of production and nonsupervisory employees rose 4 cents, to $12.51. The gain left wages 3.8 percent higher than a year earlier, extending a trend that has given back to workers some of the earning power they lost to inflation in the last decade.
But economists said the wage increase was not enough to raise any concerns about higher inflation. And because the Federal Reserve has made clear that it expects the economy to slow in coming months as ripple effects from Asia reach the United States, investors disregarded the large jobs gains, betting that neither a rise in interest rates nor resurgent inflation is looming.
Stocks rose, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 72.24 points, to 8,189.49, leaving the index within 70 points of its record high set on Aug. 6. In the bond market, a sensitive barometer of inflation anxiety, prices edged up, pushing down the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond to 5.92 percent from 5.93 percent.
"Job creation is sturdy and we have effective price stability," said Paul McCulley, an economist at UBS Securities. "The bottom line is that we've got a lovely economy."
With potential inflation counterbalanced by worries about possible price declines, the Fed and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, have suggested that they intend to keep interest rates unchanged until the economy tilts clearly in one direction or another.
The job figures for January extended a surge in employment that began last fall, just when the labor market had showed signs of cooling. After accounting for a small downward revision today to December's figures, the economy has been creating jobs at a rate of 358,000 a month for the last four months -- and 381,000 over the last three months -- after averaging 242,000 for the first nine months of 1997.
The surge in jobs reflects a remarkable confluence of positive and self-reinforcing economic forces. Inflation has been almost nonexistent, and consumer confidence has been extremely strong. After a short, sharp drop when the scope of Asia's financial problems first became evident, the stock market has rebounded and corporate profits have remained healthy.
Long-term interest rates, an important indicator of economic stability, have fallen in the last few months. Lower rates have helped invigorate housing and other interest-sensitive sectors of the economy by making loans more affordable, and have allowed companies to continue investing heavily in more efficient equipment.
The likelihood that the Federal budget will soon move from deficit into surplus has further improved the outlook. The less money the Government needs to borrow, the more is freed for private investment.
President Clinton welcomed the job figures at a news conference today. His advisers said the results reflected not just the balancing of the budget, but also initiatives such as improved access to education and training and the opening of foreign markets to trade.
"There are enormous economic and social benefits from our nation's high-employment economy," said Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Some of the biggest employment gains came in the construction industry, which added 92,000 jobs in January. The increase reflected the strength of the housing industry, which has been helped not just by declining interest rates but also by unusually warm weather.
Service industries also showed solid job gains, as did manufacturing, which is expected to be hardest hit when the effects of the Asian crisis hit the American economy.
The major harm from Asia is likely to come from the plunge in the value of many Asian currencies relative to the dollar, a situation that is expected to lead to a surge of inexpensive imports into the United States, hurting American competitors. And the weakness of the Asian economies is also likely to lead to decreased demand for American exports.
"The economy has been running on the fumes of the strength from before the Asia shock," Mr. McCulley said. "Those fumes will exhaust themselves, and the manufacturing sector is going to start getting beat up in the spring."
The figures showed the unemployment rate for adult men declined to 3.8 percent last month from 4.1 percent in December, hitting the lowest figure for almost two decades. The rate for adult women rose four-tenths of a percentage point, to 4.4 percent.
For the first time, the Labor Department broke out unemployment by education level as well as gender, age and race. The analysis showed unemployment rates dropped steadily with higher levels of education. Among people with less than a high school education, the rate in January was 7.2 percent. Among high school graduates, the rate was 3.9 percent, and college graduates, 1.9 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

January Job Gains Reflect Economic Vibrancy
The economy created jobs at a surprisingly strong pace in January, evidence that America's economic stamina has withstood any disruptions caused so far by the financial crisis in Asia. 
 The data released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed the economy added 358,000 jobs last month, far above the 235,000 widely forecast and the third consecutive month that job generation has been exceptionally strong. The unemployment rate remained at 4.7 percent, near its quarter-century low, and there was no evidence of inflationary wage increases. Page A1.
 
Markets Rally to Close Strong Week
Stocks and bonds both advanced in reaction to the unemployment report, viewed by investors as evidence that economic growth remains healthy and inflationary pressures are benign. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 72.24 points, to 8,189.49, for a weekly gain of 282.99 points or 3.6 percent. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 8.92 points, to 1,012.46, its fourth record high in five days, and finished the week up 3.3 percent. The 30-year Treasury yield eased to 5.92 percent from 5.93. D4.
 
Japan Closer to Bank Bailout
Japan's lower house of Parliament approved a $240 billion bailout package for troubled banks, moving an important step closer to returning the financial system to health. The plan will help guarantee bank deposits, pay for cleanups of failed banks and provide capital to banks hobbled by bad debts. D3.
 
U S West Beats Forecasts
U S West said earnings before one-time items for the fourth quarter declined 4.6 percent. But the results exceeded analysts' estimates, and its shares rose. D4.
 
Italian Banks Seek Merger Talks
Two large Italian banks -- Istituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino and Istituto Mobiliare Italiano -- plan to discuss a possible merger. A combination would create a bank with $206 billion in assets and and a strong position in investment banking. D3.
 
Wall St. Skeptical Of Trump's Plan
Donald J. Trump confirmed a report that he had hired two investment banks to help him sell all or part of Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts. But gambling industry analysts, who expressed skepticism when he first proposed the idea last month, grew even more skeptical yesterday, arguing that the $1.7 billion price was excessive. Mr. Trump, meanwhile, said he was confident of a sale. D3.
 
$168 Million for Canada Chain
Canada's largest retailer, the Hudson's Bay Company, is acquiring the 112 stores of Kmart Canada for $168 million (United States.) Kmart Canada, controlled by an investor group, is Canada's No. 3 discount chain. D3.
 
VW Ad Draws Fire in France
The Roman Catholic Church in France is suing Volkswagen of France and its advertising agency over their use of "mocking" religious images to promote VW's new Golf model. One advertisement is modeled after Leonardo da Vinci's depiction of Christ's Last Supper. A4.
 
Wheeze of Relief in Germany
German lawmakers defeated legislation that would have subjected Germany's 17 million smokers to anti-smoking rules long familiar in the United States. Tobacco companies, which pay $14 billion a year in German taxes, had opposed the legislation. A4.

Fine Host in S.E.C. Inquiry
Fine Host, a food services company that dismissed its chairman and treasurer after disclosing accounting problems in December, said that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission. D3.

HEADLINE: Theater Megaplex Is Planned For Downtown White Plains

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Tishman Speyer Properties Inc. and Loews Theaters joined city officials today in announcing that the companies would open a 24-screen, 5,200-seat movie theater complex downtown, on the site of an abandoned building formerly occupied by Macy's.
City officials, who have long struggled to halt a retail decline in what was once known as the City of 1,000 Stores, said they were heartened by news of the $100 million construction project, which is scheduled to begin early next year and be completed by December 1999. 
 Mayor Joseph M. Delfino predicted that the new movie theater complex -- which would be one of the largest in the United States -- would serve as a linchpin for the city's growth.
"It's a major, major step in the overall revitalization of downtown White Plains and will play a crucial role in enhancing our position as the heart of Westchester County," the Mayor said.
In the summer of 1996, Macy's moved out of the building on Mamaroneck Avenue it had occupied in the center of downtown for 47 years and moved into the nearby Galleria Mall. After the relocation, the small downtown stores outside the mall struggled to survive. Both the Galleria and another mall here, the Westchester, have drawn shoppers away from the stores on Mamaroneck Avenue, the city's main thoroughfare, and its side streets, where some of the once prosperous stores now stand empty.
In addition to the movie theaters, Tishman Speyer/Travelers Real Estate Venture L.L.C., a recently formed joint venture, plans to include space for shops and several restaurants at the former Macy's site, said Steven Rubenstein, a spokesman for the project. The three-story building will be razed to make way for the new project, he said.
"Loews had been eyeing the site for some time," Mr. Rubenstein said, "but Macy's was still selling socks there."
Under the proposal, Loews, a Sony Retail Entertainment company, will lease 118,000 square feet in the new structure from Tishman Speyer for its 24 theaters. All told, the retail and movie theater components will encompass about 450,000 square feet. The new building will have a glass atrium facing Mamaroneck Avenue.
An earlier plan for a multiplex near the Metro-North Railroad station was approved by the City Council, but Mayor Delfino said that that plan was no longer being considered.
Tishman Speyer Properties, which has its headquarters in Manhattan, recently bought the Chrysler Building and the Kent Building, along with adjacent properties, between 42nd and 43rd Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues in Manhattan. It is also a co-owner and the managing agent of Rockefeller Center.
Loews Theaters has 1,020 screens under the Loews or Sony name in 140 locations in 16 states, including the Sony Theaters Lincoln Square megaplex at Broadway and 68th Street in Manhattan.
Neither Tishman Speyer or Loews would disclose the price paid to Federated Department Stores, the parent company of Macy's, for the property here. Tishman Speyer has also acquired property near the site, on which it is planning to build residential units. Details were not available for those plans.

GRAPHIC: Map of White Plains showing location of the new multiplex: A 24-screen complex would be on the site of a former Macy's.

HEADLINE: New Special Relationship: A Deft Defense of Clinton

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Tony Blair gave a whole new meaning this week to the "special relationship" that has defined British-American relations since Churchill and Roosevelt joined forces against the Nazis in World War II.
On a four-day visit here, his first to the Capital since his election last May, the cheerful British Prime Minister provided a much-needed emotional lift for the American President, who has been increasingly besieged over reports of a sex scandal. 
 And Mr. Blair, who last year gave valuable public relations advice to the royal family after the death of Princess Diana, offered such a ringing defense of Mr. Clinton that he seemed to be performing a similar rescue mission.
At their joint news conference today, Mr. Blair was asked if his forthright defense of Mr. Clinton was a "politically risky strategy."
"I've said it because I believed it and because I think it is the right thing to do," Mr. Blair answered without hesitation.
"In the end, you either decide in politics, when you're asked about people, you're going to say how you actually feel or you're going to make a whole series of calculations," he went on. "And my belief is that the right thing to say is what you feel. And I happen to think -- I don't know whether it's my place to say it or not -- that if you look at the American economy, you look at the respect with which America is held right round the world today, if you look at the standing and authority of the President, it's a pretty impressive record for anyone."
Mr. Blair had been interpreted to Americans as a protege of Mr. Clinton, a member of the postwar generation who copied Mr. Clinton's successful formula in moving his party to the center. But somewhere during this visit, the dynamic changed between the 44-year-old Mr. Blair and the 51-year-old Mr. Clinton, and Mr. Blair no longer seemed the initiate.
During their news conference today, Mr. Clinton's qualities of appearing relaxed, expansive and politically deft belonged to Mr. Blair.
Andrew J. Pierre, a professor of international relations at the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University, said that because of the timing of the visit -- as tensions build over Iraq -- Mr. Blair had "nothing to lose" in his strong defense of Mr. Clinton.
"To the extent that Blair builds up Clinton, it's money in the bank, it's political capital, and it won't be forgotten. When the day comes that Blair is in trouble -- and I'm not suggesting it will be the same kind of trouble -- Clinton will go out and support him."
"It's of value to Blair domestically because it puts him on the broader world stage, it gives British diplomacy a new elan to once again be in tandem with the leader of the free world," Mr. Pierre said. "And it's a godsend to Clinton. It gives him a few light hours."
Anthony Cary, a spokesman for the British Embassy, basking in the afterglow of the news conference, said: "It was no great surprise to us. People on the outside are saying that Blair was deliberately being an umbrella or a life raft, or that their relationship blossomed because there was a particular need on one side. But that is only because of the domestic context. There is a very good personal chemistry between them and a good fit of their agendas."
Today Mr. and Mrs. Clinton took Mr. Blair and his wife, Cherie, on a tour of the new memorial here to Franklin D. Roosevelt. Tonight the Blairs headed to Camp David for a private, informal dinner with the Clintons and the Gores. The Blairs are to fly back to London on Saturday morning.
During toasts at a formal dinner at the White House Thursday night, Mr. Blair spoke conversationally. Rather than stuffily pretending that nothing was amiss, Mr. Blair made direct reference to his host's troubles since reports surfaced that Mr. Clinton had been sexually involved with a 21-year-old White House intern.
In his toast, Mr. Blair described his afternoon visit to a high school in suburban Maryland and the enthusiastic crowd of more than 2,000 students.
"I know I'm not alone in supporting you," Mr. Blair said. "I know the American people support you too." The declaration gave the dinner audience of 240 luminaries a starting point for sustained applause.
Mr. Clinton, who offered his toast first, made no mention of his difficulties.

HEADLINE: President Clinton's Tobacco Numbers

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget assumes that $65.5 billion will be extracted from the tobacco industry over the next five years, either as voluntary payments from cigarette manufacturers or higher taxes on tobacco products. While he offers several enticing ways to spend the hypothetical money -- more biomedical research, day care subsidies and financing for smaller class sizes -- the most important aspect of this budget item is its size. Mr. Clinton has now put on the table the amount he thinks needs to come from the tobacco industry in order to deter smoking, particularly among teen-agers.
Public health experts have long argued that while many strategies are needed to reduce teen smoking, like curbs on advertising, the key is raising the price of cigarettes. In order to cut teen smoking by 50 percent, most health economists believe the price of cigarettes would have to increase by at least $1.50 a pack. Experts convened by the National Academy of Sciences have recommended even higher increases of $2 a pack. 
 Mr. Clinton's budget plan would move toward higher prices, but would not reach those goals. Assuming that cigarette makers would pass any new costs on to consumers, the proposed $65.5 billion payment from the industry would mean a $1.10 per pack price increase over five years, according to White House budget analysts. That increase might cut teen smoking by perhaps 30 percent, probably not enough to protect most vulnerable youngsters from picking up the habit. Even so, it is nearly doubles the price increase projected under the settlement agreement reached last summer between 40 attorneys general and the tobacco industry. That proposal would increase cigarette prices by only 62 cents over 25 years.
Getting even the lower amount will not be easy politically. There is already talk that a national tobacco settlement is dead because the industry is insisting on immunity from future civil lawsuits as a trade-off for payments, an element that many health advocates oppose. Indeed, recent disclosures from tobacco company documents of their aggressive efforts to target teen-agers make any talk of immunity increasingly unpalatable. But Mr. Clinton should not give up on the idea of comprehensive legislation that strongly regulates nicotine and significantly curbs tobacco consumption.
While he has rightly criticized the settlement backed by the attorneys general as too small, he has yet to unveil specific tobacco legislation. Instead, he has left the details to Congress. This hands-off approach is unlikely to generate the public support needed to force a reluctant Congress to place public health needs before the financial interests of cigarette makers.

President Clinton and the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, issued a new warning to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that he will face military action unless he complies with weapons inspectors and Security Council resolutions. A1 

Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen arrived in Germany to begin an 11th-hour mission to Europe and the Persian Gulf. A6
 
Marine Pilot Dies in Gulf
Two Marine Corps F-18 fighters collided over the Persian Gulf, killing one of the pilots, the Defense Department said. The other pilot was rescued. The fighters collided as they were returning to the carrier George Washington from what was described as a training mission for possible air strikes against Iraq. A6
 
Official Admits Jet Was Low
A top United States naval official acknowledged that the jet that sheared ski lift cables in northern Italy this week was flying below the approved minimum altitude. The pilot reportedly said that he saw the cable too late for evasive action to prevent the accident, which took 20 lives. A4
 
Strong Quake in Afghanistan
A powerful earthquake and aftershocks in remote northeast Afghanistan this week may have killed several thousand people and left thousands more injured and homeless, Afghan officials and international relief agencies said. A3
 
Bomber Kills Nine in Sri Lanka
At least nine people were killed when a suicide bomber detonated explosives strapped to her body at a military checkpoint in Sri Lanka's capital, the police and witnesses said. No group claimed responsibility for the blast, and the Government did not blame anyone, but security forces have been on alert for attacks by separatist Tamil Tiger rebels during festivities for the nation's 50th anniversary of independence. A3
 
Bosnian Suspect Arrested
Bosnian federation police arrested a Serb and charged him with assassinating a deputy prime minister during the Bosnian war, the authorities said. A Serb mob later retaliated for the arrest by abducting passengers on buses traveling to central Sarajevo, U.N. officials said. Most were later released. (Reuters)
 
Administrator Killed in Corsica
France's regional administrator for Corsica was killed on the Mediterranean island of Corsica after attending a classical music concert produced by his wife. The police said two men shot Claude Erignac in the head three times outside the theater, and a pistol was found at the scene.

HEADLINE: 15-Year Plan Is Adopted To Clean L.I. Sound

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: BAYVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 6

 BODY:
In another effort to clean up Long Island Sound, Federal and state environmental officials have adopted a 15-year, $650 million plan to upgrade sewage treatment plants along the New York and Connecticut shoreline.
The plan seeks to reduce nitrogen discharges that have been directly linked to a reduced level of dissolved oxygen in the Sound, which harms fish, lobsters and shellfish and the small organisms they feed on. 
 The project was approved unanimously at a meeting on Thursday of the Long Island Sound Policy Committee in Manhattan. The group also adopted a plan to reclaim and restore at least 2,000 acres and 100 river miles of habitat along the shore over the next 10 years.
The two initiatives fulfill commitments outlined in a larger conservation and management plan for the Sound that was adopted by state and Federal agencies in 1994, based on an initial study begun in 1988 amid fears that the Sound might be dying.
"Long Island Sound is tremendously valuable to all who live, work and vacation along its shores," said Jeanne M. Fox, an administrator for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which is working in partnership with New York and Connecticut on the project.
"These new actions should take us a long way toward healing the Sound and insuring its health for future generations," she said, noting that the Sound's 1,200 square miles contributed $6 billion to the economies of New York and Connecticut.
Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the E.P.A., said today that New York and Connecticut had already received around $500 million in Federal aid to upgrade its waste treatment plants. She said that much of the money had gone to New York City, where treatment plants in the Bronx and Queens supply more than 36 percent of the Sound's nitrogen.
"Federal funding for Long Island Sound projects for the next two years is already in place," Ms. Mears said. "Naturally, money for some of the projects will be coming from the states and local communities, and we expect to reach our $650 million goal in the next 15 years."
Much of New York's share is expected to be financed by the 1996 Clean Air Act, which included $200 million for Long Island Sound, officials said. How much local communities and taxpayers living in shoreline areas would have to contribute, remained in doubt, officials said.
The nitrogen reduction plan is aimed at what environmentalists consider to be the Sound's most serious problem, hypoxia. It occurs when nitrogen from sewage and storm water runoff from roadways, lawns, golf courses and farms fuel the growth of overabundant algae. When the algae die and decompose, the process depletes the oxygen, leaving an inadequate supply to support fish and other aquatic life.
The new plan calls for a 58.8 percent reduction in nitrogen, to be achieved largely through the upgrading of sewage treatment plants that contribute nearly two-thirds of the nitrogen that reaches the Sound.
There are 70 such plants throughout the Sound's watershed, most of them in New York City and Westchester, Ms. Mears said.
The habitat restoration plan, which will concentrate on more than 450 sites, is intended to complement the efforts to reduce nitrogen loads and improve dissolved oxygen levels in the Sound. More than two-thirds of the sites are in tidal and inland wetland areas. Other areas include beaches and dunes, coastal and island forests, bays, harbors, cliffs and bluffs.

HEADLINE: Scholars Bring Needed Context to Courtroom;
Historians Divided

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Jan. 31 Arts & Ideas page article on the Columbia University historian Robert O. Paxton suggests that unlike in France, historians here do not participate in trials. In fact, one of Professor Paxton's Columbia colleagues, the Barnard College historian Rosalind Rosenberg, was a key witness in a 1984 sex discrimination suit brought by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission against Sears, Roebuck & Company. 
 Professor Rosenberg argued that women have always been motivated by concerns other than economic ones and in the Sears case were underrepresented in high-paying commission jobs on account of their preference for less pressured positions. Alice Kessler-Harris, another feminist historian, countered that women have opted for higher-paying jobs when they became available.
The trial, which Sears won, spurred debates among historians about the meaning and obligations of feminist history. It also showed the difficulty of translating complex historical disputes into the simple language of legal argument.
 
FRANCESCA POLLETTA
New York, Jan. 31, 1998
 
The writer is an assistant professor of sociology at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Columbia Student Charged as Gambling Ring Member

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
It's not every day that the New York City Police Department's vice enforcement division finds its way to Columbia University. But on Thursday night, a team of officers descended on the college's Zeta Beta Tau fraternity house and arrested a 20-year-old economics major for what they said was his part in a $10 million-a-year sports gambling ring.
The student, Joseph Della Pietra, a junior at Columbia, was arrested outside the fraternity house about the same time that police officials raided other places in the city and on Long Island and arrested 15 other people. Law enforcement officials described the operation yesterday as a high-stakes betting business that was based in Queens and took bets from sports fans in nine states across the country. 
 The Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, whose office was involved in the five-month investigation, said yesterday that Mr. Della Pietra, 20, worked as a runner, taking bets and distributing winnings to about 20 to 30 Columbia students.
Another student, William Basso, who is in his third year at New York Law School, was also arrested and accused of taking bets from students and from people outside the school.
Mr. Brown said that students at other colleges and universities might have also been involved and that such rings often have connections to organized crime.
Mr. Della Pietra's lawyer, Joseph Tacopina, said yesterday that his client denied all the allegations.described Mr. Della Pietra as a hardworking college student who was from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.
Mr. Tacopina said his client had never called or visited the Bayside, Queens, base of the operation, the so-called wireroom, to which most of the bets were routed.
"He is sitting in a cell with 15 people, none of which he knows," Mr. Tacopina said. "He's just a college kid and he's upset to be connected to these people he doesn't know. Keep in mind that there are plenty of college students with an interest in sports who will place a bet every now and then on a football game."
Columbia officials said they were stunned by Mr. Della Pietra's arrest and would cooperate fully with the police and prosecutors. "We had no inkling that there was any gambling going on," said Virgil Renzulli, a public affairs spokesman for Columbia. "This came as a surprise."
Another public affairs spokesman, Fred Knubel, said that it was the first time in his 30 years at Columbia that a student had been accused of involvement with a gambling ring. He said the university had started its own investigation to decide whether to impose discipline, which he said could include suspension or expulsion.
Mr. Tacopina maintained his client's innocence. He noted that when investigators froze bank accounts and seized safe deposit boxes of some of the people arrested, they found the accounts to be hefty. Mr. Basso, for example, had more than $200,000 in his checking account, police officials said. "But that kind of evidence just won't be there with Joseph," Mr. Tacopina said. "All he's got is about $1,400 in a bank account. His role in this is nothing like what the prosecutor describes."
A phone number could not be obtained yesterday for Mr. Basso, and calls to New York Law School went unanswered.
The mood at Mr. Della Pietra's fraternity house yesterday was glum. The members would not comment on his arrest as they entered and left the three-story building on the edge of the Columbia campus. Two flags flew outside the fraternity house, a blue and white flag emblazoned with the fraternity's letters and a more foreboding black flag decorated with a skull and crossbones. It was not known whether the black flag is always displayed.
Zeta Beta Tau, one of 12 fraternities at Columbia, has 40 members and is is known to be favored by baseball players. Mr. Della Pietra is one of 25 members who actually live at the house. Investigators said they believed Mr. Della Pietra played baseball for Columbia, but school officials would not confirm that. Mr. Della Pietra's older brother, Christopher, was captain of the school's football team in the late 1980's.
District Attorney Brown said the gambling operation was based in a home in Bayside and in the back room of a pizza parlor in Massapequa, N.Y. Of the 16 people arrested, at least 6 of them worked primarily as clerks recording bets at one of the two locations, the police said.
Most of the others arrested were believed to be runners who would place bets for other people, the authorities said.
According to the police, the main bookmakers who ran the overall operation included Peter Bartolillo Jr., of Franklin Square, N.Y., and Todd Labarca and Richard Traschetti, both of Lindenwood, Queens. All 16 people have been charged with multiple counts of promoting gambling, and if convicted could be sentenced to as much as four years in prison. By midnight, 10 had been arraigned and released at the Queens County Court Building, and the remaining 6, including Mr. Della Pietra, were to be arraigned and released later.
The average bet taken was for about $40 or $50, officials said, and would be placed on college and professional sports. Most bettors were from New York or New Jersey, but others were from San Francisco, Boston, Las Vegas, Nev.; Arlington, Va.; Charlotte, N.C., and Harrisburg, Pa.
After the police received a tip from a bettor who was being threatened by members of the ring because he owed them money, they started tapping phone lines and investigating the operation last October. During the raids, police officials seized stacks of betting slips, $25,000 in cash and computers and fax machines. Mr. Brown estimated that the ring had $8.4 million in illegal profits.
"Illegal gambling is almost always operated with the involvement of organized crime," Mr. Brown said. "It's the fuel that fires the engines allowing them to operate in other illegal activities, like narcotics and loan sharking."
A police deputy inspector, Peter P. Clarke, said he believed that a big portion of the betting operation focused on colleges and universities. "I guess some college students have bad gambling problems, just like in general society," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A member of Zeta Beta Tau fraternity at Columbia University was accused of placing bets for other students in a ring that operated from coast to coast. Yesterday, the fraternity house was flying two flags. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)
