SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2694 words

HEADLINE: Sand, Silence and Solitude

BYLINE: By ELLEN WARNER; ELLEN WARNER is a photojournalist and portrait photographer based in New York.

 BODY:
"THE desert? No, I've been to Egypt 17 times, but I've never gone into the desert," said our travel agent, sounding rather puzzled. "You know, you see the desert right next to all the ruins."
When I persisted, she put me in touch with a travel agent in Washington, D.C., who had a branch office in Cairo. Talking with them several weeks before my trip last April, it became apparent that yes, they could get me a car and a driver to visit the oasis villages of the New Valley -- an area of the Western Desert about halfway between the Nile Valley and the Libyan border. But did I know, they asked without enthusiasm, that it would be very hot? 
 I decided to check further. Friends working for the Agency for International Development in Cairo suggested that I call Amr Shannon, a rally driver who took people on desert safaris. When I told him I'd always wanted to go to the desert and asked him what it was like, there was a pause and he said respectfully: "It is beautiful -- unlike anything else. You have to be there to feel it." I knew I had found my guide.
Then came the practicalities. Did we want one car or two? With one four-wheel-drive vehicle we could travel up to 25 miles off "the asphalt," the sparsely traveled road that connects the oasis towns. If anything happened to the car, it would be possible to walk back to the road, which meant civilization. On the other hand, with the addition of a support car we could travel 125 miles off the asphalt.
I consulted Richard, my English friend who on the spur of the moment had agreed to accompany me, and he said that he thought 25 miles would do it, so I agreed that we would be conservative.
The car would cost $200 a day, including our guide, Amr, and we would pay extra for gas and the food we took with us. Amr cautioned us to take sweaters and a warm jacket, as in April the desert can get below freezing at night.
We planned to spend a total of five nights in the Western Desert (as the Egyptians call the Sahara in Egypt) and the oases of the New Valley. The valley comprises the bulk of Egypt's Western Desert and the oases of Bahariya, Dakhla, Farafra and Kharga, which roughly parallel the Nile.
Four weeks from my initial telephone call to Amr, after several days in teeming Cairo, I got together with Richard and Amr, and we headed west in a Jeep packed with everything from tents, shovels and sand mats (which are placed under your tires for traction if you get bogged down in the sand) to basic food for the week. Our trip had been postponed a day because of bad sandstorms April, as it turns out, is the month of the khamsin, a warm wind that blows north from the Sudan.
There were a fair number of cars on the road during the first hour's drive out of Cairo as we passed new housing developments and a few industrial parks, but from then on we saw only about one car an hour. Our first destination was the oasis of Bahariya, 225 miles southwest of Cairo, where we planned to stop for lunch.
The land was flat, sand as far as the eye could see, often lightly covered with black pebbles of basalt, called "the pavement of the desert." Halfway to Bahariya something caught Amr's eye. He slowed down and turned off the road. There in front of us were petrified tree trunks from the days before the Sahara was desert.
Half an hour later he veered off again, this time to a field of shells dating from 40 million years ago, when what is now the Sahara was ocean. Translucent mother-of-pearl shells the size of my palm, which had once held soft oysters, peeled apart in my hand, shining like mica. Because of the lack of humidity in the Sahara, it is not uncommon to find shards of ancient pottery and other artifacts, as well as prehistoric remains such as these.
 CONTINUING toward Bahariya, the topography became hilly. Amr scanned the landscape, and we swerved off the road heading toward pebbly hills (actually formed by piles of petrified shells and marine life). Leaving the car at the bottom of one of these, we climbed to the top in the midday sun to find two chains of longitudinal sand dunes, the Ghard Ghorabi, stretching as far as the eye could see. I was awed by their majesty and mesmerized by their rhythmic waves.
The variety of dunes is astonishing. Some are only a few feet high; others reach several hundred feet and traverse hundreds of miles. A flat, rocky area can suddenly become a range of sand dunes. Their shapes are determined by several factors: the direction, strength and consistency of wind; the amount of sand; the hardness of the terrain, and the amount of vegetation. Dunes are constantly moving, propelled by the wind, sometimes more than 100 yards a year. Nothing can hold them back.
Oases are depressions in the plateau of the desert, usually ringed by steep sandstone escarpments. They can be large, often 20 miles long, and contain many villages. The houses of El Bawiti, capital of Bahariya and a typical oasis village -- where we had lunch -- are made of brick the color of the surrounding sand. The only color is on doors and windows painted wonderful pastel blues, turquoises, greens and yellows. It is common to see charming, primitive drawings of camels, jumbo jets and cars on the facades because all good Muslims make a pilgrimage to Mecca at least once in their lifetimes, and upon returning draw a picture on the front of their house illustrating the story of the trip.
We ate at Bayoumi's restaurant, where our meal was the same one we were to have at every restaurant in an oasis town -- vegetable soup (usually lentil), Egyptian beans, chicken, rice and a fresh vegetable (zucchini or yellow squash) in tomato sauce -- hearty and healthy. We were invariably the only tourists (we saw only one other couple during our week in the desert). The Egyptians are very friendly and respectful of visitors. When people did not want me to photograph them, the subjects (usually women) discreetly turned away or asked for baksheesh (a tip), but they were never rude or angry.
As it was now only a few hours until nightfall, we got back into the car to continue. For the more leisurely traveler, Bahariya boasts some modest ruins -- rock tombs over 2,000 years old, skeletal remains of Roman garrisons, a Ptolemaic temple and a Greco-Roman village.
The more mountainous terrain between Bahariya and Farafra begins to resemble a lunar landscape. We camped about 55 miles south of Bahariya in an area called Crystal Mountain. Here the ground is covered with hard sand and there are outcroppings, sometimes mountainous, of quartz that shine like crystals in the sun. We pitched our tents in the hollow between two of these hills and Richard and I took a walk across this moonscape.
At dusk we climbed an adjacent hill to watch the sunset. Without the distraction of electric lights from nearby humanity, the desert night sky is ablaze with stars. A book on stars, with a simple chart of the constellations, is a must for any desert safari.
It got cold, so we climbed back down close to the campfire and put on turtlenecks and jackets.
You can almost hear the quiet in the desert. Amr says that people either love the desert or are scared by its loneliness.
My own fear was more of scorpions and poisonous snakes, both of which come out at night. I worried about having to get up in the dark and stumbling on some hidden interloper. Amr said: "Snakes and scorpions only disturb you if you disturb them. Take a flashlight and be careful not to kick over any stones, and in the morning shake out your shoes to make sure nothing has curled up inside them."
Daybreak was spellbinding, with deep shadows and sunlight reflecting off the quartz outcroppings. After breakfast we drove south and after several stops arrived at the White Desert, so called because mounds of white chalk are blown by the sand and wind into strange mushroom-shape formations.
The Egyptian Desert is the driest part of the Sahara -- in Farafra, according to National Geographic and "The Sahara Handbook" by Simon Glen, it rained in 1945 and not again until 1973. The smallest of the oases, Farafra consists of several hamlets, some dependent on old Roman wells. We had lunch in one of the two roadside restaurants in the village, then started the 190-mile drive to the Dakhla oasis, along the most desolate and worst-maintained section of the road.
It crosses a corner of the Great Sand Sea, a vast area of flat sand and dune fields stretching westward to Libya. Now, truly isolated, we were lucky to pass a car every two hours. It was hot and there was a slight breeze, so sand was blowing into the car. I tied a handkerchief around my head covering my nose and mouth, but my nose clogged up and I found it slightly hard to breathe. Amr showed me how to snort water in through my nose, blow out and clear out the sand. That was the only moment when I felt a twinge of fear,in the isolation of the Great Sand Sea.
We had hoped to camp next to a dune field about 35 miles west of Dakhla, but by the time we arrived the khamsin wind had picked up. When it starts blowing before dusk, it means a sandstorm during the night, so we pressed on to the village of El Qasr in the Dakhla Oasis, where we spent two nights in rooms above the local cafe. We were disappointed not to be camping out but our little "hotel" gave us a new experience.
Each night the men of the village congregated there to smoke their water pipes, play dominoes, talk and watch a terrible Tarzan-type American soap opera with Arabic subtitles on TV. We were welcomed into the domino games and treated as part of the group. Dinner was brought to our domino tables, we were encouraged to smoke, and everyone was thrilled when one of us happened to win a game.
The food in the cafe was delicious -- dinners of the fare to which we had become accustomed and breakfasts of taamia (ground Egyptian beans with parsley and sesame fried in oil like little hamburgers), omelets, pita bread, white cheese, fresh fruit and tea.
In El Qasr, the most charming village we saw, mud brick houses with ornamented doorways and decorative friezes line narrow sandy alleyways. Their doors have lintels, beneath which one has to stoop because sand has spent centuries rising over the thresholds. The veils of the women and the djellabas (long robes) of the men waft gracefully with the breezes, adding an aura of tranquillity to the timeless feeling of the village.
 DAKHLA is the largest oasis in the valley, and the main occupation is farming. In the morning we watched men harvesting wheat. They cut the stalks with sickles, then girls collected the sheaves and gleaned the kernels left behind. The boys threw the wheat onto a wagon, which a donkey pulled to the village. It was a scene that could have taken place 3,000 years ago.
Heading for our last oasis, Kharga, 125 miles from Dakhla, we stopped at Balat to see the newly discovered pharaonic tomb of Pepi II, dating from 2200 B.C., and then what used to be a camel stand on the old track between Dakhla and Kharga.
There we saw prehistoric writing on rocks striped with very soft sandstone -- yellow, red, blue, green. When you rubbed it, the color came off onto your fingers. The women of ancient Egypt used this sandstone as makeup. We arrived in Kharga in time to visit the Temple of Amun-Re in the ruins of the ancient town of Hibis. Completed by the Persian ruler Darius I in the sixth century B.C., it bears a later inscription of Nekhtnebf, one of the last native pharaohs. It was decorated with pharaonic painting and hieroglyphs, and high up on the walls we could see the graffiti of 19th-century explorers.
When the light started to fade at the temple, we settled ourselves into the three-story Kharga Hotel -- where, aside from a few Russians there on business, we were the only guests.
Our last morning we visited the necropolis of El Bagawat, a Coptic Christian burial ground dating from the fourth to seventh centuries, its numerous mausoleums dotted over several small hills. They are made of mud brick, many with domes, decorated with primitive frescoes in bright colors, depicting biblical scenes, well-preserved by the dry desert air. St. George slaying the dragon and Noah's Ark seem to have been favorites.
 OUR last stop in Kharga was the Archeological Museum, which houses decorated coffins for mummies, glass, pottery, jewelry and other remnants of desert life from pharaonic times to the present. Surprisingly, perhaps because of the lighting and the way the objects are arranged, the exhibits here seemed to be better displayed than those in the Egyptian Museum in Cairo. Then we were pressed to reach Luxor, a five-hour drive, before nightfall.
Traveling at night in the countryside near Luxor is frowned upon by the Egyptian authorities because of the possibility of terrorist attacks. Since the killing last November of 58 foreign tourists were killed by Islamic militants in the courtyards of a Luxor temple, the Government has tightened security measures even further, and travelers may find that they are accompanied by a police escort in certain areas near Luxor if the authorities deem it necessary.
The road from Kharga to Luxor is desolate. Every hour or so there is a checkpoint, the soldiers stationed there the only signs of life along the way. We had our last picnic lunch between buttes in the middle of a "waterless sea" of sand. The last miles of desert seemed precious, and we began to wistfully conjure our next trip.
I now know that once the desert is in your bones, there will always be a pull to go back -- to hear the quiet, to see the night sky, to feel the power and rhythm of the dunes, to sense one's smallness in nature.
 
How to charter a ship of the desert
 
When to Go
The best time to visit the Western Desert of Egypt is during November and December, when temperatures are pleasant (generally up to 78 degrees in November and up to 68 in December) and the air is clear. In September and October and from January through April it is warmer, but traveling is still comfortable. April brings the risk of the khamsin, the wind that blows north from the Sudan and can produce sandstorms. From May through August it is too hot.
You will need a hat with a visor, walking shoes and plenty of sunscreen. Women should wear long-sleeved shirts and long trousers to respect the modesty requirements of an Islamic culture. A warm sweater and jacket are needed for the nights, when temperatures drop considerably. Also take a towel, washcloth and soap.
 
Guides
We traveled with Amr Shannon, whose telephone and fax number in Cairo is (20-2) 518-6130. Amr now charges $300 a day for himself as guide and driver for one to three people. He has an air-conditioned four-wheel-drive car that seats four. Each extra car is $300 a day. The price includes gasoline but not food, which he will provide and cook. If you want, you can shop with him for the food -- a good idea if you have the time.
Mohammed Marzouk, telephone and fax (20-2) 258-8083, is also based in Cairo. He takes a minimum of six travelers, using at least two four-wheel-drive cars. His charge of $65 a person a day includes gasoline, all meals, tents and sleeping gear. Mr. Marzouk also can organize a combination car and camel safari. The cars take the luggage, while the passengers go by camel. When you arrive at the campsite, the tents are ready. The cost of these trips depends on the tour, but Mr. Marzouk says that they cost less than the car-only version.
His cars are not always air-conditioned.
 
Lodging
If you want to sleep in a hotel instead of a tent, there is al-Qasr Cafe, Dakhla oasis. It's a simple place with good food. Guests sleep on a bed in their own sleeping bags. There are no private bathrooms. The cost is around $1.50 a person a night (calculating the Egyptian pound at about 35 cents). A hearty meal will cost around $2.
The Kharga Hotel, Kharga Oasis, lacks charm but is adequate. It's a three-story building that has about 60 rooms, with private baths that are equipped with showers but no tubs. The rates are $17 to $20, including breakfast.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
A Financial Crisis Yields Some Far East Bargains

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
AS Asian economies crumble, the race is on for the best travel deal. The leader at the moment is a British fellow in Bali who asked if he could pay his bill in rupiah. The hotel said yes, the guest scurried into town to change his money, and by the time he did, the cost of his stay had dropped $2,000.
Such deals don't come along every day. 
 Still, Asia's financial crisis is making parts of the region far cheaper than they have ever been for those paying in United States dollars or European currencies. In Thailand, the baht is worth roughly half what it was six months ago; in Indonesia, the rupiah is down 75 percent in value, and in the Philippines, 40 percent has been knocked off the peso's value in the last few months.
Hong Kong, alas, remains as pricey as ever, with the Hong Kong dollar chained irrevocably to the dollar at 7.8 to 1, a link that insures that hotels, restaurants and shopping are among the costliest in Asia.
"For those people who happen to have checked into hotels when rates were falling, they got a good deal," said Cynthia Rosenfeld, the director of Asian development for Club Med Asia.
"But by now, all the international hotels have switched to dollars, so you won't be staying at the Oriental in Bangkok for $60," she said, referring to one of the world's great hotels.
Even so, there are bargains for travelers who use a little ingenuity. Instead of booking a hotel through a travel agent, calling the hotel ahead yourself can generally result in a lower room rate. "Bargain," insisted Ms. Rosenfeld, "bargain."
A few calls around the region recently did find some genuine bargains: a room at the Shangri-La in Kuala Lumpur over the weekend for 200 ringgit a night, or roughly $48, and a weekend package at the leisurely and elegant Sukhothai in Bangkok for $117. Just a few months ago, each hotel charged well over $200 a night.
Travelers who prefer adventure to predictability cannot help but find Asia cheaper than those who go on package tours, although some of the things that come cheaper are not necessarily enough to warrant the trek from Europe or the United States.
In Jakarta last week, where the rupiah is wallowing at about 20 percent of its value just a couple of months ago, a pair of the newest Nike running shoes goes for about $25, about a quarter of what they will cost in New York.
And in Seoul, where the won is worth a fraction of its former hefty self, a full sushi dinner at the Grand Hyatt is now about $35, less than half of what it cost before the South Korean economy began to spiral out of control last month.
"Restaurants are much cheaper in Asia now," Ms. Rosenfeld said. "That's where the bargains lie. All services are going to be cheaper, like a massage at the Oriental, renting a car and driver in Kuala Lumpur, or eating out. Restaurants cannot keep reprinting their menus. They can't change their prices every day."
There are signs already, however, that some merchants, particularly in Thailand, are beginning to ask foreigners for payment in dollars. A recent survey by a Thai polling institute found that 40 percent of foreign tourists in Thailand had been asked to pay for goods or services with dollars; the survey also found that 57 percent of the tourists polled thought they had been cheated by taxi drivers, street stalls, hotels and jewelry shops.
Here in Hong Kong, once regarded as Asia's shopping paradise, there is little to tempt visitors -- or locals -- these days. At a stereo store in Causeway Bay, C.S. Lau, a salesman, was bemoaning the drop in sales, where state-of-the-art amplifiers and other high-end stereo equipment run into tens of thousands of dollars. "Sales have gone down 40 to 50 percent," he said ruefully. "We won't cut prices because of poor sales though. With our business, people who don't usually buy the stuff won't buy it even if it's cheaper."
At the Hong Kong Honma Golf Company nearby, Fan Chun Chung was equally depressed at the forest of putters, drivers and sand wedges that seemed to have sunk roots into the floor of his store. "Sales are down," he said, "no doubt about that. We are losing our Korean customers."
But there are some deals to be had. Clothing stores in particular are sporting "Sale" signs, with discounts as steep as 70 percent and 80 percent at some stores.
Nevertheless, Despite sporadic bargains, whether in clothing in Hong Kong or restaurants in Bangkok, the number of tourists from Europe and the United States is dwindling. Hong Kong is experiencing the worst tourism slump it has ever seen. And on a recent visit to the Thai island of Phuket, only a handful of bungalows were occupied at the Amanpuri resort -- a luxury hideaway where prices, cited in United States dollars, begin at about $450 a night.
Moreover, flights between Asian capitals are largely empty these days, causing some airlines to cancel flights, or in the case of Qantas, which recently canceled its South Korea route, cancel routes altogether. Even Japan Air Lines is considering reducing the 56 flights it runs between Japan and Hong Kong.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 10; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1162 words

HEADLINE: Food Technology Unit Comes to Ardsley

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
VELTROL, Litesse and Xylitol are hardly household words, yet they are everyday products found in the food and beverages on the shelves of the bakery, dairy, confectionery, processed meat and poultry, seafood, vegetable, alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverage departments of supermarkets across the United States.
For the uninitiated, Veltrol is a key ingredient in the development of compound flavors where a fruity characteristic is essential. Litesse is a polydextrose bulking agent used in reduced-calorie confectionery products and Xylitol? Xylitol is used in chewing gum and confections and recognized for its unusual dental benefits in preventing and reducing dental caries. 
 All three products have been developed by Cultor Food Science, one of the world's largest developers and marketers of high-performance food ingredients. Cultor Food Science is a business sector within Cultor Corporation, based in Helsinki, Finland, an international research and marketing organization focusing on nutrition, operating in more than 30 countries and distributing products worldwide.
Cultor's annual sales are approximately $1.8 billion, with Food Science generating about $480 million. Last November, Cultor Food Science moved to Westchester, opening a $15 million, 100,000- square-foot Customer and Technology Center in Ardsley, bringing 150 jobs to Westchester and accolades from the Westchester Partnership for Economic Development
At the ribbon-cutting ceremony, the menu, demonstrating the end use of Cultor ingredients, included offerings like reduced-fat, reduced- calorie-butter-cream cake; low-fat pumpkin ice cream, chocolate-raspberry-cream-flavored coffee and anise-flavored sugar cookies.
"Consumers are demanding more from food than ever before," said Joseph Dunne, the newly appointed president of Cultor. "They are more knowledgeable about food and nutrition, and they want better taste, fewer calories, higher nutrition and a longer shelf life. Basically, what we do is help our customers, food manufacturers and processors around the world satisfy consumer tastes by developing specialty ingredients, flavors and protectants for food and beverages."
The new Cutlor Food Sciences and Technology Center consists of two adjoining buildings: the Customer Building, which contains executive offices, marketing and all corporate operations, and the Technology Building, which includes research and development, technical services and technical development operations.
True to Finnish practice, on the lower level of the Customer Building isan employee fitness center with men and women's saunas, furtheringthe belief in the therapeutic effects of the sauna as a way to relax and refresh employees and guests.
"The company as it is today was formed in January 1996 by merging two industry leaders -- Cultor Ltd. and Pfizer Food Science -- into Cultor Food Science," Mr. Dunne said. "Our corporate offices were formerly in Manhattan, while technical service and R&D were located in Groton, and North American management offices were in Parsippany, N.J. Now everything is efficiently under one roof."
Explaining that the integrated campus provides interaction between product management and technical teams, Mr. Dunne said the buildings at the new center have been designed to facilitate interaction at every level of the company. The new complex not only contains state-of-the-art research and development laboratories and pilot plants but also "brings together skilled scientists and technologists from around the world with some of the most forward thinking business minds in the industry," he said.
On the top floor of the Technology Building, scientists in seven laboratories use sophisticated technology, including robotics, to discover new ingredients and manufacturing processes. The Sensory Labs are especially noteworthy. They provide a controlled testing environment for sensory evaluation of product attributes like sight, smell, taste and texture of foods, beverages and personal health care products. "We are more than ingredient vendors," Mr. Dunne said. "We offer value-added products and services. Working hand in hand with customers gives us the ability to have an impact on such things as product, particularly in helping food processing customers to develop reduced-fat, reduced-calorie foods, new flavors and innovative ingredients to keep food safe and fresh. We also assist with marketing strategies and regulatory approvals."
Mr. Dunne, who was born in Ireland 55 years ago, received his Ph.D. in biochemistry from the University College in Dublin, his post-doctoral experience at the University of California, San Diego, and Max Planck Institute in Dortmund, Germany.
"What I hoped to do was teach at a University," he said. "But teaching jobs were scarce in Ireland. When I came back from Germany, I was offered a temporary teaching job at the University College in Dublin for one year. But when, at the end of the year there was no offer of a permanent job there, I accepted an offer to become general manager of the Biochemical Technology Unit at University College in Galway. That position was half academic, half business."
His next job was all business and eventually brought him to the United States.
"I became technical director of Biocon Ltd., a global food-ingredient company in Cork, and then I went to the United States to Lexington, Ky., as executive vice president for Biocon U.S.A. It was a major move for all of us, my wife, Mary, and our children, but we liked it in the United States, especially the six years we spent in Sarasota, Fla., when I had the task of consolidating two companies we had acquired," he said.
After another consolidation, he became vice president and general manager of Quest International, a leading food-ingredient company. In 1994, he was named president with responsibilities for all flavor and food-ingredient business throughout the United States. "When I became president, and we moved to Chicago in 1995, I thought, Careerwise this is it, and it was very good," he said. "When I was approached to take over the president's job at Cultor, I must say, the global size and aspect of the company attracted me. Why not, I said to myself, have a final fling? And I accepted the job."
Recently the Dunnes were house hunting in Westchester. "We have seen houses in some of the most beautiful areas anywhere, from Irvington to Rye and places in between," he said. "I like to play golf, and I see that Westchester is the place to do it. Two of our sons already live in Manhattan. The third is in Hollywood, and our daughter is in college, so we don't need as big a house as we once did."
The Dunnes, who have family in Ireland, keep an apartment in Dublin, which they use for three weeks every summer.
"Economically, what is happening in Ireland is truly marvelous," Mr. Dunne observed. "A young, smart, hard-working, educated populous is transforming the country."

HEADLINE: The View From/Hastings-on-Hudson;
Children Along the Hudson Beseech Clinton to Aid the River

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
HERE is a letter written to the President by a 7-year-old who already has concerns about the world she lives in:
"Dear President Clinton, My name is Allison, and I am a second grader at Hillside School in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Our town is next to the Hudson River. We are studying the river this year. I have learned that the plankton starts the food chain, and if the river gets filthy the plankton will die. There will not be a food chain. 
 "The river is important to me because if you go to look at the river and it is dirty, you will not be able to see any reflection. Please say this river can be an American Heritage river."
Whether the Hudson has been chosen to be designated an American Heritage river under a new Federal program will be announced later this month, but if it is not, it will not be from lack of trying. Up and down the river, children and adults in waterfront communities are making their voices heard, hoping to convince the powers that be that the Hudson is, indeed, worthy of special consideration. And Hastings has been among the most vocal.
"The river is an integral part of everyone's life here," said Betsy Pausch, owner of a small advertising agency who lives and works in the village. "You see it every time you step outdoors."
The American Heritage River program was suggested in 1996 by Vice President Al Gore as a way to "see to it that environmental and economic concerns were not at odds with each other," said Ethan Carr, riverfront program director of Scenic Hudson, a nonprofit organization based in Poughkeepsie. The panel, he explained, would name 10 Heritage rivers. No new Federal money would be appropriated, but a new job, that of river navigator would be created for each river and the region it represents.
Each river navigator will act as a liaison between Federal, state and local agencies and nonprofit organizations to coordinate regulatory activities, oversee development and initiate projects. "This will make government work better, be more responsive to the people -- to paraphrase Vice President Gore, 'one river at a time,' " Mr. Carr said. The river navigator will work with individuals, government agencies and nonprofit organizations to balance the concerns of environmentalists in their quest to clean up the Hudson, and the navigator will also investigate former industrial sites on the riverfront for possible mixed-use residential, recreation and small business development.
Meanwhile, Hastings and other Hudson River communities keep hoping. In November, Ms. Pausch, Michelle Hertz, a sculptor and jewelry designer, and other Hastings residents organized a letter-writing campaign, encouraging friends, neighbors, school officials and students to write to the White House. Several hundred letters were sent.
"I have so many thoughts on the river, so many reasons I feel it is important to our community," Ms. Hertz said. "I go down to the waterfront all the time. In the early morning, the light makes the palisades look golden. In late afternoon, when the sun is in the west, it shines on the river and the water looks like melted, liquid silver, and the palisades are really dark above it. And the history -- I think of what it must have been like when the native Americans were here."
One of Ms. Hertz's recent sculptures is of a turtle, executed in clay, its shell divided into 13 segments. The work is entitled "13 Moons Over Hastings" -- Indians believed the year had 13 lunar cycles, Ms. Hertz said; in each segment is a relief of a Hudson River-related scene: the cliffs, the water and even a less idyllic picture of a factory belching smoke.
"Somewhere along the way in history, people started hurting the river," Ms. Hertz said. "They stopped caring for it and began using it for industrial development and dumping of toxic waste. The entire western border of our village is on the riverfront, and some of it is a park, but some still looks like an atomic bomb hit it; it still bears the scars of industry. People all along the river, not just here but up and down the Hudson, do not understand the importance of the river, and it got hurt along the way."
Young people in the community echoed her thoughts. One high school student wrote: "As a resident of a Hudson River town, I know how central the river is to our daily life and culture. Although a lot has been accomplished to restore the health of the water and its shores, much remains to be done. There are many groups working hard to reclaim the Hudson as a center of community life and recreation."
A third grader wrote: "I think the Hudson River is beautiful. My family and I enjoy the river in the spring, summer, fall and winter. I read that the Yellow River in China is polluted, and the children who live near it are sick and cannot learn. This makes me sad. I want to protect the Hudson River."
One of Ms. Pausch's children, 7-year-old Andreas, put in his letter to the President: "I learned that the Hudson River starts in the Adirondack Mountains. This river is important to me because if we don't clean it all up the fish will die. Please say this river can be an American Heritage River."
And, from one of Ms. Hertz's children, 4-year-old Douglas Friedman: "Dear President Clinton, When I am on the rocks in the park I look at the Hudson River and the beautifulist river is the Hudson River."

GRAPHIC: Photo: On Hastings waterfront: Betsy Pausch, kneeling, with sons Andreas and Thomas, and Michelle Hertz with her son, Douglas Friedman. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q&A/Peggy Post;
Etiquette on the Comeback Trail? Well, Yes

BYLINE: By KAREN BERMAN

 BODY:
WHEN Emily Post first published her etiquette book in 1922, she could hardly have imagined that her name would become a household word. But of course it did. Emily Post means etiquette.
After she died in 1960, her work was continued by her granddaughter-in-law, Elizabeth L. Post, and, since 1995, by her great-granddaughter-in-law, Peggy Post. Peggy Post, who lives in Fairfield County, took over the long-running "Etiquette for Today" column in Good Housekeeping magazine, and is the author of the 16th edition of "Emily Post's Etiquette," published by HarperCollins last year. 
 Ms. Post began her career as a flight attendant and spent 20 years in corporate management, consulting and sales. She began appearing at bridal shows on behalf of the Emily Post Institute in 1991, and in a recent interview, she discussed her Post persona. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Etiquette is often defined as traditional rules for behavior. How does that concept fit our changing world?
A. Etiquette is a set of guidelines, traditional guidelines a lot of the time. However, etiquette really is a code of behavior based on being thoughtful and considerate that makes our lives function more easily. The definition doesn't change, but guidelines have to change. Emily recognized that 75 years ago. She kept revising her books. Little things such as chewing with one's mouth closed really work. More modern ones have to do with computers. In fact, we need etiquette more than ever today.
Q. What are the most significant changes in the new edition?
A. There are quite a few. Because we are a global economy today, we travel. We don't want to offend our hosts, so I added a chapter on international issues. Common-sense reminders: Know as much as you can about your host's culture and traditions. For example, using your left hand in Arab countries can be offensive because that's the hand that's reserved for personal hygiene.
I wrote a section on working out of one's home. There's a section about casual day, which seems to be here to stay. I've put in some new guidelines for weddings. I expanded the chapter on families who are step-parenting. I expanded the telephone and computer sections.
Q. You've traveled for the Emily Post Institute for years. What regional differences have you noticed? Where does Connecticut fit in?
A. People ask me this a lot. I really don't like to generalize. Throughout the country there are a lot of polite, courteous, kind people and there are people who are rushed, or living in such crowded conditions that they may be downright grumpy. I find the more crowded the area, the more one might have to look for courtesy.
Some people say this is the worst area, from Boston down to Washington. I don't say that. I'm not from Connecticut, but I've lived here for 18 years. Somebody did a study comparing Connecticut mannerisms to mannerisms in the Midwest and tried to say we're ruder here. But I saw a bumper sticker on I-95 the other day. It said, "Courtesy is contagious, let's start an epidemic."
Q. What are the most frequently asked questions?
A. First people say, "Do people really care about etiquette any more?" I say that actually there's a resurgence in thinking about etiquette. There is an almost alarm feeling out there that, "Hey, we do need to do something."
Another question: Is there any hope for our children? We have gotten so informal today, and a lot of children just aren't getting some of the basics. Maybe it is a good idea to teach children how to hold a fork like a pencil instead of a shovel. Maybe it is a good idea to teach them how to introduce friends to each other. It's not just form or formality; it's also about caring and sharing, being responsible, feeling comfortable.
The biggest category of questions is about weddings. The stickiest involve the divorced family. Another question is who pays for what.
There's one other frequently asked question: "I've planned a function or party and I've asked people to R.S.V.P. I hear nothing. What do I do?" I say you can certainly call and say, "I hope you've received the invitation and I hope you can join us." You don't let your anger show.
Q. Are the questions the same in Connecticut as everywhere else?
A. Pretty much. People seem to have the same concerns.
A new thing that's popped up with weddings is cash bars. There are little pockets around here, and in other parts of the country, too. It really offends guests, across the board. I'm revising the wedding book now and saying these are the things that really upset people.
Q. How do you create new rules to respond to trends?
A. I do research. I see what people are asking in letters. I find out what people are doing. Then I apply what I think makes sense.
It used to be that guests did not wear white or black to a wedding. Now maybe the bride wants an all-black-and-white wedding. Yes, black is a somber color, but it can be a beautiful color for a sophisticated evening wedding. Yes, a guest may wear white, as long as she doesn't look like the bride.
Tuxedos traditionally were worn by men in the evening after 6. Today, 50 to 70 percent of rentals for daytime weddings are for tuxedos.
I've been asked about e-mail for thank-you notes. Those are handwritten, traditionally. But if you're sending a computerized longer letter and your thank-you is part of that letter, or if this is the only way a teen-ager is going to get into writing thank-you notes, it's not the end of the world.
Q. What is the biggest etiquette problem on the Internet?
A. The anonymity. So many times people say, "I got this rude message." A lot of people think it's fun to be a little more reckless because they don't feel they're talking to another person.
Q. In the past few years, we've seen dramatic societal changes. How do you frame your advice on male-female relations, same-sex couples and other sensitive topics?
A. I frame it on common sense and being considerate. I think the day of being shocked at different life styles is probably falling away -- it should at least. If you don't approve of what somebody else is doing, keep it to yourself. Don't assume you know how someone else should live.
The feminist movement has affected male-female relationships, especially in business -- women can have responsible jobs. That's also carried into male-female relations socially. It's a little more balanced out. I don't think it makes sense to get offended if a man holds the door for a woman. A woman may hold the door for a man. It's just a matter of being considerate.
Same-sex couples: same thing. It's here to stay. I was asked, "What does one do if you're invited to your friend's ceremony of union -- gay wedding." I said "Well, if it's your friend, be happy for your friend. Be sure you R.S.V.P. I'm sure you want to go to the wedding and you want to send a gift." Be considerate and respectful and that's the key.
Q. The new Etiquette acknowledges the changes brought by the women's movement, but often offers traditional rules -- a man walking on a particular side of a woman, for example. Why not create more new rules for our evolving roles?
A. I'm constantly creating new rules. I inherited a book, and I wanted to keep some of the old-time traditions in there. It really doesn't matter today who walks where, but it's fun to have a little tradition.
Q. Etiquette has been revised periodically, there have been 12 spin-off books, the magazine columns, a CD-ROM. It seems like a well-run family business.
A. It is. It's a pretty exceptional family. Emily wrote so many other books, she didn't want to write an etiquette book. She had to be talked into it. Then it just mushroomed. In 1946 she established the Emily Post Institute to keep her works going and to keep the integrity of the works. That was smart.
Emily's son Edwin, after she died, tried to be Mr. Emily Post and that didn't work.
Q. But by that time Edwin's son -- your father-in-law -- had married, and his wife, Elizabeth L. Post, got the job.
A. My mother-in-law said, "I can do that," and the whole family said, "You're hired." My mother-in-law carried on for 30 years. I met my husband 20 years ago. He said even back then, "You love to write. Maybe someday when my Mom retires you'll want to do this." My husband has three siblings. Everyone's involved in a different way, but everyone gets along really well.
The subject matter is timely right now. I keep saying to my mother-in-law, "How in the world did you do this 30 years ago, with the hippie movement and the Vietnam war?" People were not interested in traditional stuff. A wedding? People got married jumping out of an airplane. Now you can still do all those personal things, but people like to blend them with tradition. I'm lucky.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peggy Post with portraits of Emily Post, whose work she carries on. (Susan Farley for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Restoring Historic Union Station in Kansas City

BYLINE: By JILIAN MINCER 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
AFTER decades of deterioration, this city's historic Union Station at the southern edge of downtown is undergoing a $234 million renovation that will restore its former grandeur and install a lavish 285,000-square-foot science museum.
It took several months just to prepare the monolithic train depot for the project. Walls were demolished, the roof was repaired and 10 million pounds of debris and 35 miles of pipes were removed. 
 The new construction and actual renovation, which began last month, are expected to be completed in November 1999. Once restored, the station will look as it did when it was proclaimed the "great gate to the west" by President Woodrow Wilson at its opening on Oct. 30, 1914.
The limestone exterior has held up relatively well, but the interior will require extensive renovation. But once complete, the building will take visitors back to the turn of the century when huge, distinguished buildings like the station were constructed for public use.
The restored grand hall, with its 95-foot ceilings decorated with acorn rosettes and two 3,000-pound chandeliers, will be available for civic events and other activities. Beyond the grand hall will be an urban plaza (now the north waiting room) the length of a football field. The plaza, resembling a city park, will have a huge fountain, street lights and benches and lead to the entrance of what is to be called Science City.
The project will initially have 132,000 square feet of retail, office and restaurant space. But its primary tenant will be Science City. As its name suggests, the museum will be designed like a city, with multiple levels and even streets and alleyways.
Dozens of exhibits will offer visitors the opportunity to dig for fossils, prepare for a mission to Mars or crawl through a cavern over a stream and into a tree house. There will also be an exhibit tracing the evolution of trains from the 1860's to the present.
"We're truly trying to create a city for the visitor to explore," said David A. Ucko, president of the Kansas City Museum, which will develop and manage the new museum. "We're creating an adventure."
The museum also will have three theaters including an Imax-type theater and a planetarium. Hines/Mortenson of Kansas City, a construction and development partnership, was hired to manage the design and construction aspects of the project, which leaves most of the station's original architecture intact.
The plan also calls for the station to serve as a hub for cars, taxis and buses and, potentially, light rail in the future. Space has been reserved off the grand hall for an Amtrak station, now adjacent to the main depot. Additionally, a skywalk will connect the station with Crown Center, an 85-acre commercial and residential complex that is owned by Hallmark Cards.
Many in the city consider the station's renovation crucial to the revitalization of the downtown, which has seen significant new construction in recent years, as well as the renovation of office, residential and hotel space.
THE museum is expected to attract a million visitors a year and add close to $8 million to the metropolitan area's economy, according to a recent analysis.
"I believe the project will forever change the face of Kansas City," said Lisa Adkins, chairwoman of the Kansas and Missouri commission in charge of the public financing of the project. "It's taking a piece of the city that was deteriorating and transforming it into a jewel."
The original construction of the station brought together the efforts of competing train companies. At the end of the 19th century, Kansas City was becoming a national rail center and competing railroad companies began to consider their mutual need for a larger station.
A critical point came in 1903 when the old Union Avenue Depot on the city's west side was flooded and remained closed for 10 days. That incident helped persuade 14 railroad companies to form the Kansas City Terminal Railway Company to consider other locations for a station.
The companies quietly purchased land south of the city's downtown. Then they commissioned the renowned Chicago architect Jarvis Hunt to design the classical Beaux-Arts depot, which took four years to build. The entire project cost $50 million, more than two and a half times the budgeted amount.
When the station opened it was the nation's third-largest rail station after Grand Central Terminal and Penn Station in New York City, the latter demolished in 1963.
For its first 50 years, Union Station was one of the busiest in the nation and was the backdrop for numerous historic events. One, in 1933, was the infamous Union Station Massacre during which Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd and Adam Richetti gunned down several law-enforcement officials and their prisoner, Frank Nash, outside the station.
At its busiest during World War II, as many as 260 passenger trains and several hundred freight trains moved over the station's network of tracks each day.
EVEN though Kansas City remains one of the nation's busiest freight hubs, the passenger travel began to wane in the 50's and 60's as air travel became more popular. By 1983, after fruitless proposals to restore the station, it was closed without ceremony and two years later Amtrak opened a small station in an adjacent building.
In 1993, the legal title to the station was transferred to the Union Station Assistance Corporation, a private, nonprofit group, that is redeveloping the project in partnership with the Kansas City Museum.
At the same time, the museum was ready to open a badly needed science museum because the city was the only one of its size in the nation without a modern one.
About $82 million was donated by local foundations and businesses. Then in November 1996, voters in the five-county, bistate Kansas City metropolitan area approved a one-eighth-of-a-cent sales tax to raise $118 million for the project.
"I think it passed for a variety of reasons," said Andy Scott, executive director of the Union Station Assistance Corporation. "Citizens in both Kansas and Missouri have long wanted to do something together. This gave them that opportunity."
Even though the renovation has just started, the downtown has already begun to feel its impact. Property values just north of the station on the other side of the tracks in what is known as the Freight House district are climbing as dilapidated buildings are being transformed into art galleries and lofts. Indicative of this change, a partnership involving Lidia Bastianich, co-owner and chef at Felidia restaurant on New York City's East Side, recently decided to renovate the old freight house and open a restaurant there.
"The station renovation was a deciding factor," said Dave Wagner, managing partner and president of Lidia's Restaurant Group. He said they had considered the suburbs and midtown but chose the freight house because of the train station and its proximity to several of the city's largest hotels. The location is about 10 blocks from the Bartle Hall Convention Center.
The Union Station Assistance Corporation owns several nearby buildings that are connected through tunnels to the train depot. Those buildings are expected to be developed into a cultural and entertainment district in a second phase.
"It's like a beehive is starting," said Mr. Scott of the Union Station Assistance Corporation. "But it takes time to make honey."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Refinancing Underlying Mortgages

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
CO-OP boards in buildings with underlying mortgages are discovering something homeowners have been finding in the last few months: that it sometimes makes sense to borrow to pay off old loans even though it might cost money -- perhaps a lot of money -- to do so.
"We've been seeing an absolute rush of refinancings of underlying mortgages" -- mortgages on entire buildings -- said James G. Samson, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in co-op and condominium law. "I've been in practice now for 25 years and I've never seen this kind of lending." 
 Mr. Samson was describing a commercial version of the refinancing boom across the nation -- a phenomenon fueled by low interest rates and high competition among lenders. "I'm now seeing boards do these very sophisticated calculations and enter into some very sophisticated negotiations with their lenders," Mr. Samson said. "And the boards come out smelling like roses."
The sophisticated calculations, Mr. Samson said, actually boil down to finding an answer to one question: How long will it take for the savings from the new loan to pay for what it will cost to get it?
Mr. Samson explained that when such a cost-benefit analysis is conducted for a standard residential mortgage, the cost of the new loan typically includes application fees, processing fees, legal fees, title insurance, points paid to the lender and mortgage-recording taxes if the property is in New York.
When the loan to be refinanced is an underlying mortgage in a co-op, however, additional factors must be considered, the most significant of which is the prepayment penalty.
"It used to be that prepayment penalties were not all that bad," said William Greenberg, a certified public accountant in Manhattan who specializes in co-ops and condominiums. "But now, they're usually pretty stiff."
A prepayment penalty is the amount a borrower agrees to pay to a lender if the borrower wants to pay a loan off before the end of the loan term. And while prepayment penalties have all but disappeared in residential mortgages, Mr. Greenberg said, they are still common in commercial loans, such as co-op underlying mortgages.
In the past, Mr. Greenberg said, the prepayment penalty was just that -- a penalty of one or two percent of the outstanding balance that would be imposed as a way of discouraging borrowers from paying off their loans early.
Increasingly, however, prepayment penalties have been used by lenders to insure the payment of nearly all the interest due on a loan paid to term -- even if the loan is paid off early. That means that a borrower with a loan that had three years to go could be responsible for that three years' interest even if the loan were paid in full today.
"Traditionally, prepayment penalties discouraged refinancing," Mr. Greenberg said. "But now, with interest rates where they are, there's often enough spread between the old payment and the new payment to make up for the prepayment penalty."
For example, Mr. Greenberg said, a co-op client of his recently paid a prepayment penalty of more than $50,000 to refinance a new mortgage at a lower interest rate.
"They'll recapture the penalty in just a couple of years," he said, adding that in addition to obtaining the benefit of a lower monthly maintenance payment as a result of the lower interest rate, shareholders will also be able deduct their proportionate share of the prepayment penalty because it is considered mortgage interest for tax purposes.
"It's a question of calculating everything out," Mr. Greenberg said. "And it's worth doing the calculation if you can lock into today's rates for 10 years or more."
Gregg Winter, president of Winter & Company Mortgage Services, agreed. "You can't just stumble into a new underlying mortgage," Mr. Winter said, "but this is really an unusual time. It's conceivable that a co-op can go from a mortgage now at 9 or 10 percent interest to one that is 2 1/2 to 3 percentage points lower. That ends up being a huge savings, even with prepayment penalties and the cost of getting the loan."
For example, Mr. Winter said, a co-op client in Manhattan recently refinanced an existing $1 million mortgage at 9.5 percent interest with a $1.1 million mortgage averaging 7.187 percent interest over the next 10 years. Even though the co-op could have chosen a fully amortizing loan, it elected to take a 10-year balloon loan instead -- which means that the unpaid principal is due in full after 10 years.
And though the closing costs for the new loan were about $80,000 -- nearly $50,000 of which was attributable to prepayment penalties on the old loan -- the new loan still made good fiscal sense. The monthly payments on the new loan, Mr. Winter pointed out, are roughly $7,500 -- more than $5,000 less than the $12,644 monthly payments on the original loan.
"That means that even with a big prepayment penalty, it will only take about one year and four months to absorb the $80,000 in closing costs," Mr. Winter said.
It is also worthwhile in many cases, Mr. Winter said, to start negotiating for a refinancing with the holder of the existing mortgage. "You might be able to change a 10 percent interest-rate loan to an 8 percent loan -- and extend the term at the same time -- without paying any out-of-pocket penalties," he said.
Co-ops that are contemplating locking in a low interest rate by refinancing their underlying mortgage to a long-term mortgage, Mr. Winter said, should be careful to plan for future needs at the same time.
"Co-ops are like living organisms," he said. "They need care and they need maintenance, so it's unrealistic to believe that any borrowing today is alone going to be enough for things that need doing 20 or 30 years from now."
With that in mind, he said, co-op boards should obtain a line of credit -- in addition to the refinancing -- to insure having a source of ready cash whenever it is needed.
"Whenever you want to set up secondary financing like a line of credit, it's always easier to deal with it at the outset, when you're negotiating the first mortgage," he said.
Mr. Winter said that the benefit of having a line of credit -- as opposed to borrowing money only to place it in a reserve fund -- is that interest is paid only when the money is needed. "For example, you can tap into it on a monthly basis if you're paying a contractor for a long-term project," he said.
Finally, Mr. Winter said, now is an ideal time for co-op boards that have been carrying loans on which they pay only interest, not principal, to consider converting to self-amortizing loans, thereby insuring eventual elimination of the debt.
"Some people have the philosophy, 'Why should we pay principal just to make it nicer for people who will be here long after we leave?' " Mr. Winter said, adding that such a philosophy makes sense only in situations where the outstanding balance on the underlying mortgage is so small in proportion to the total value of the co-op that it has hardly any impact on the value of individual apartments.
More frequently, however, the opposite is true: high outstanding balances on underlying mortgages keep values of apartments lower than they might otherwise be while increasing the difficulty that will be encountered when individual shareholders and the co-op itself tries to borrow in the future.
"Some co-ops need to burn off some of that debt to increase the values in the building," Mr. Winter said. "And there's never been a better time to do that than now."

HEADLINE: Fascination in the Depression

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER

 BODY:
PRINTS line the walls of Herschel and Fern Cohen's stately colonial home. From floor to ceiling, stacked four or five high, up the stairs, down the hallway, in the office, bedrooms and bathrooms, hundreds of lithographs, wood engravings, woodcuts and etchings evoke images of the Depression era. Huddled masses, powerful workers, robust-looking "fat cat" capitalists, sharecroppers and coal miners, represented almost entirely in black and white, dominant the collection of realistic works.
This pre-eminent collection of American prints depicting the Great Depression is the passion of a Wall Street portfolio manager who focuses on the psychology of investors and their swings from optimism to pessimism. 
 The images of breadlines and sweatshop workers after the stock market crash of 1929 moved Mr. Cohen, 57, who has worked at Smith Barney Asset Management for 30 years, and his wife, an elementary school librarian in Roslyn, to canvas museums, galleries and auctions.
Part of the Cohens' vast collection, 104 prints from 89 print makers, is on display through April 19 at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington in "Visions of a Changing America: Depression Era Prints From the Collection of Herschel and Fern Cohen."
"I think there were three periods in this country's history that were unlike any other periods -- the Civil War, the Depression and World War II -- that just changed people's lives forever," said Mr. Cohen, who has a Ph.D. in physiological psychology and originally planned to be a college professor. "Art from the Depression is a window. It's a window into my parents' behavior. It's a window into how people think. I'm so fascinated by how people react to, exist in, come out of periods of unbelievable change and duress."
The "rush" Mr. Cohen feels from finding Depression images, and his obsession with collecting them, stems from his childhood.
"Something about these Depression images, they excited me," he said. "I love images with people. My parents were so Depression driven. They were wonderful people who would never take a risk."
His father started out in the 1930's selling used records.His mother quit high school to go to work to help support her family. Her father, a manual laborer, shoveled coal and gravel.
"All of our family lived in two-family houses plus attics," said Mr. Cohen, a Long Island resident who grew up in Cleveland. "My grandparents lived upstairs, my aunts and uncles lived next door, my cousins lived in the attic.Everybody pitched in and worked.
"There was one painting in the house and that was by a guy my dad had grown up with. There was no art in the house and no luxuries, period."
Like many collections, the Cohens' began accidentally. He knew nothing about art, she knew very little. While shopping for a rolltop desk, Mr. Cohen stumbled across American paintings in a gallery and bought one instead of a desk.
"It was 1976, the year of the Bicentennial," he said. "There were a lot of celebrations in the museums about American art. My interest was starting to peak and we really flipped for it. The great thing about this country is, even if your parents were immigrants, you kind of take the history of this country as your own. We fell in love with this American art of the 19th century. We made it a mission to go around looking at all this stuff and learning about it. We went to Washington, we started going to regional museums. We went to Vermont, Pennsylvania, all over. We just fell in love with American art."
As much as the Cohens loved paintings, especially urban landscapes, they could not afford them.
Visiting the National Collection of Fine Arts (now the National Museum of American Art) and the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, the Cohens were drawn to social realist and industrial prints. Twentieth-century renderings by artists like Howard Cook and Louis Lozowick were a natural extension of the Hudson River landscapes they loved. Mr. Cohen began to form a "wish list."
Immersing himself in his pursuit, he researched art at the public library and talked to local gallery owners about prints. He bought his first prints at an auction.
"The prints were really very, very inexpensive, which was perfect," he said. "For someone who came from a background of never spending money on any kind of luxury, I loved this stuff and I didn't feel like I was breaking the bank to do it. Nobody cared. They weren't popular. Especially the kind of stuff I liked.
"I liked the landscapes, but in their stacks I would see an occasional industrial scene or something with people in it and I loved it. Maybe they didn't know too much about it. I responded to them and I would buy them.
He added: "I could really decorate a house with them.I had no downside risk. I was always thinking: 'Is this really bad to do? Spend money on this?' I felt that since they were so relatively inexpensive and they were original art, what could my downside risk be?
"I never ever thought of this as investment. Talk about Depression era mentality. I always thought if I lose my job and things get bad and I needed to sell things, could I get something near my money back? It was a luxury. I always worried about security. That came from my parents, and that's a Depression thing."
Fifteen million people, or almost 25 percent of the work force, were unemployed during the Depression. Among them were 10,000 artists. Under President Roosevelt's Works Progress Administration, 5,000 artists secured jobs. Among the painters, sculptors and muralists were 300 print makers.
The works they produced, made in editions of 25, of which the artist could keep 3, examined the economic crisis around them. Prints of strike scenes and bread lines, tomato pickers and subway riders were distributed to schools, hospitals, libraries and museums.
"The Depression era art would be nonexistent had the Government not sponsored the W.P.A. program," said Mary Ryan, owner of a Manhattan gallery specializing in American prints from the 1920's to the present. "During the height of the Depression, there weren't people buying art," she said. "Some of the greatest artists who worked in the 20th century in America were kept employed by the W.P.A.."
Among Mr. Cohen's favorite images at the Hecksher show is Clare Leighton's "Bread Line, New York," a 1932 wood engraving showing long lines of people hoping for assistance, huddled under the elevated train tracks, a loan shop sign nearby, with the metropolis in the background.
In Albert Potter's 1932 linocut, "Brother Can You Spare a Dime," a man stands, hand outstretched, in front of a throng, while a skeleton hovers above the cityscape. The title was borrowed from the Rudy Vallee and Bing Crosby song, often thought of as the anthem of the Depression.
Mabel Dwight's 1935 lithograph, "Merchants of Death," a social commentary reflecting failed capitalism, portrays a skeleton leading a group of businessmen that evolve into vultures.
"Spiderboy," a 1936 etching by James Allen, shows a muscular construction worker perched on a steel beam high above the city. This glorified image of a worker reminds Mr. Cohen of his grandfather.
Anne Cohen DePietro, curator of the Hecksher Museum, said that the Depression era collection showed "America in transition from a rural economy to an industrial economy, from an agrarian-based society to the Industrial Revolution on into the big metropolises that were burgeoning in the 30's."
"It documents a period of very exciting transition in America and of great hardship as well as testimony to the resilience of the human spirit," she said. Continuing, she said: "Because they didn't have to worry about finding patrons to purchase their work, the artists were freed up to explore subjects that they would never have dreamed of having had the freedom to create if they were looking for patrons to buy. It opened the doors creatively."
Bent and stooped coal miners, covered in soot, trudge home after work, in Michael Gallagher's 1938 etching, "Scranton Coal Miners." Maxine Seelbinder, an obscure print maker, created depressing scenes of tenement life in the 1933 lithograph, "Housing Needed."
"By collecting in that period you can find these treasures that nobody cared about, nobody wanted," said Mr. Cohen, admiring one of Seelbinder's images on the wall of his home office. "There is no information available at any public library or print book about her. How pessimistic must you be if you only print six of them. She was obviously drawing what she really felt. God, I love this."
The 30's were also the "age of urban optimism," the era of the skyscraper, elevated trains and industrial architecture. Artists glorified the machine age and burgeoning steel industry.
"After the W.P.A. program was over, the work that was left was largely destroyed," Ms. Ryan said. "It was burned and discarded . A lot of work was used for pipe insulation and as scrap paper for Rikers Island inmates." Only a few prints remained.
Initially, Depression era art was viewed as a social realistic embarassment, and a reminder of a difficult time, said Ms. Ryan. It wasn't until the 1970's that people began to look at Depression era art anew. Although out of the mainstream of 80's art collecting, burgeoning interest in the last 20 years has dramatically increased their value.
In 1981, it was Ms. Ryan, whose gallery specialized in 1930's W.P.A. material, who validated Mr. Cohen's interest in the subset of collecting.
"It was love at first sight," Mr. Cohen said. "All of a sudden, I found somebody who formally liked the stuff that I had sort of been thinking about but had no information about. I hadn't seen any literature about stuff I liked. She would track down the artists and things I never thought about doing. I finally found someone to share the excitement with, somebody who knew what they were doing."
Ms. Ryan helped him define why he liked the Depression era art and sought out the same material. He started meeting the few other dealers and collectors around the country who share his passion.
The Cohens, who also accumulate doorstops, weathervanes and Americana, hope to keep their collection intact and growing.
"If I'm a collector, it doesn't make me happy that things went up, because there's always something else out there," Mr. Cohen said.

HEADLINE: Slow H.M.O. Bill Payments Strain Hospitals

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
SLOW payments by managed-care companies are causing financial strains for Long Island hospitals, which say that despite determined efforts they are unable to collect tens of millions of dollars of overdue bills.
The payment policies are also cutting drugstore profits, driving pharmacists out of business and adding to competition among drugstore chains that are increasingly relying on sales of nondrug merchandise. 
 Similar problems, which also affect doctors, are being seen in other parts of the New York metropolitan region. But as managed-care companies, or health maintenance organizations, transform health care, the problems are severe on Long Island, hospital and pharmacists' groups said.
For hospitals, time-consuming negotiations with the companies is creating extreme frustration. Hospital administrators said they often encountered runarounds, broken promises, half truths, arcane bureaucratic requirements and novel methods of evasion when they tried to collect for services often rendered months earlier.
"We spend an inordinate amount of time rebilling and calling," said Rick Annis, a senior vice president and the chief financial officer at the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System. "Some of the managed-care companies come out and meet with us about late bills, and after we show them the records they still say they are up to date on payments."
Mr. Annis said the late or unpaid bills totaled tens of millions of dollars for his system, one of the largest in the Northeast. "We can absorb it as long as they pay eventually," he added. "But we are having to fight them for the money they owe us."
The president of Southampton Hospital, Dr. John J. Ferry Jr., said he made four telephone calls in one day last week to a managed-care company to ask about a long-overdue bill. "The person I was calling was either on the phone or out," said Dr. Ferry. "The last time I called they said he was gone for the day."
Dr. Ferry said the experience was typical. One bill sent to an H.M.O. in August was not paid until last week.
The hospital documented a series of calls to H.M.O. employees who were frequently unavailable or said they had not received information mailed and faxed by the hospital more than once.
"Even if we were paid in a matter of weeks from the time we were told the check was cut, we would be happy," said Dr. Ferry. Instead, he said, "But after months of haranguing we are still hearing the-check-is-in-the-mail stories."
Dr. Ferry said uncollected payments were creating cash-flow problems that were a factor in a recent layoff of 15 of the 900 employees at the hospital.
A new state law lets hospitals collect interest if claims properly filed with a managed-care company are not paid in 45 days.The law also allows the state to fine the companies.
Hospital administrators said that they had hoped that the law would bring relief but that they continued to face challenges in filing so-called "clean" claims that complied exactly with all the companies' requirements.
The law may not apply in cases where the companies deem that bills are not clean, or properly filed, or when the companies dispute the need for services.
The executive vice president and chief executive officer of the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital Council, Peter M. Sullivan, said when managed-care companies refused to pay for treatment hospitals were forced to absorb costs.
Mr. Sullivan said slow payments pointed to an inherent conflict of interest for managed-care companies. "The H.M.O.'s take premiums from subscribers to provide payment when, as and if they need medical care," Mr. Sullivan said. "Any excuse they can find not to pay a provider for medical care enhances their profits."
Some critics have said that the time that managed-care companies are able to hold on to money and earn interest on it before they pay is a major profit center for them.
Mr. Sullivan and others said there was increasing worry about slow payments by Oxford Health Plans, one of the largest companies. The company has faulted computer problems. "The length of time that this was used as an excuse led one invariably to the conclusion there are serious management problems, or else they are not being completely candid," Mr. Sullivan said. Oxford did not return a call for comment.
Last week a group representing 500 doctors in Manhattan announced that it was seeking arbitration to speed overdue payments from Oxford. The group also wants clearer payment guidelines. Doctors' agreements with Oxford bar them from suing over grievances.
On Long Island, some hospitals have been reluctant to comment publicly on slow payments. Others denied that they were having difficulties. "We are not having that problem," said Richard E. Semple, a spokesman for the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Center in Patchogue.
Mr. Semple said the hospital, with 900 employees, had decided to eliminate 27 full-time positions, reflecting a freeze in Medicaid reimbursements. About 57 percent of its revenues are from Medicaid, he said.
Hospital officials and pharmacists said that as the state shifted Medicaid recipients to managed-care companies the problems would multiply.
Hospitals are under pressure to merge or form partnerships because of many sweeping changes in health care, particularly the advent of H.M.O.'s. Systems with several hospitals and treatment centers have greater leverage in negotiating favorable rates.
Reduced government payment for care and the state's deregulation of reimbursement rates on Jan. 1, 1997, add to the pressure.
For independent pharmacists, changes wrought by managed-care companies have helped reduce the average profit on prescriptions, from $6 eight years ago to $3, according to Craig M. Burridge, executive director of the Pharmacists Society of the State of New York.
Mr. Burridge said hundreds of independent pharmacies had gone out of business in recent years, including scores on Long Island. "If you keep having a net loss of pharmacies," he said, "it means longer lines and further distances to the drugstore. And you won't have that personal relationship with your pharmacist."
Pharmacists said they were working harder for smaller returns. "With the reduced profit on prescriptions, you have to do high volume to make a buck," said Kevin McQuade, a pharmacist and a partner at Town Drug in East Northport. "It is causing unduly high workloads, and accuracy and professionalism are out the window. But no one cares."
Pharmacists said they lost money when they filled some prescriptions. "It's impossible," said David Biren, a pharmacist and the owner of Smith's Pharmacy in Levittown. "That's why most stores that haven't closed are closing now. More independents are closing now than ever before."
Independent drugstores are frequently bought out and closed by chains that want customer records and good will that the independent store had built up. The chain then often offers jobs to the displaced pharmacists.
Independents who are remaining in the business say they have no choice but to agree to H.M.O. reimbursement rates if they want business from that group of customers.
In most cases, the independents never deal directly with the managed-care companies, but with pharmacy benefit managers that are agents for the companies.
Before managed care, a pharmacist's profit margin on prescriptions was the difference between the discounted wholesale price and the retail price. Now, H.M.O.'s, through the benefit managers, set what they pay pharmacists for prescriptions. A lower margin results, the pharmacists said, because the system reduces the spread between the discounted wholesale and retail prices.
Herbert I. Mindlin, a pharmacist and the executive director of the Long Island Pharmacists Society, said independents also had to pay wholesalers within 15 days to assure maximum discounts. He said the benefit managers took a month or longer to reimburse pharmacists.
Mr. Mindlin said managed-care failed to take into account the costs of containers, labeling and "any services that go into the dispensing of the product, including the public service aspect of talking to customers."
Pharmacists, he added, had to pay processing fees to benefit managers when filing for payments. "If they refuse the claim and you have to file again," he said, "you have to pay again." Independents were also barred by law from banding together to affect prices, Mr. Mindlin said. He said that that had put them at a disadvantage against chains that were treated as a single entity, adding to their leverage.
"The independents would be able to compete in the marketplace if there was a level playing field," Mr. Mindlin said. "Otherwise the economic conditions for them can only get worse."
As independents have declined, chains, including Genovese, CVS, Walgreens and Rite-Aid, have expanded, creating stiff competition among them. Gene Wexler, a vice president and the general counsel for Genovese, said chains were also earning lower profits on drugs because of managed-care policies. But Mr. Wexler said his company, headquartered in Melville, had also succeeded in resisting rates that it considered too low.
"One major third-party plan was demanding an unacceptably low reimbursement rate," Mr. Wexler said. "We said, 'We can't do that and we will not participate in the plan.' A few months later they came back with an acceptable offer."
In another sign of the profit squeeze, Genovese recently said it would cut up to 600 jobs and close or sell five stores, including one in Nassau. The 134-unit chain has 39 stores in Suffolk and 28 in Nassau. It has 5,300 employees.
