HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
REITs Moving More Aggressively Into the Market

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
SINCE its entry into the Long Island industrial market a year ago with the purchase of a 2.7-million-square-foot industrial portfolio owned by Lazarus Burman Associates of Syosset, First Industrial Realty Trust of Chicago has acquired 1.2 million additional square feet in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
"We have a lot more in the pipeline and expect to add two to three million square feet more by the end of the year," said Jeff Schwartzberg, senior investment officer for First Industrial's northeast regional office in Syosset, of which Jan Burman is the senior regional director. 
 "The Long Island economy has made a very successful transition away from defense and this market now has a positive absorption with more demand than there is space," Mr. Schwartzberg added. "A year from now we intend to own 6.5 million to 7 million square feet and dominate the industrial market in a major way."
Flush with cash and with access to huge lines of cheap credit, real estate investment trusts like First Industrial have become aggressive buyers of real estate in markets throughout the country, and Long Island is no exception.
The so-called REITs are publicly held companies that invest in income-producing properties using money raised through the sale of shares. Investors participate in rental income by receiving dividends and also can profit -- or face losses -- on fluctuations in the value of the real property.
But to meet Wall Street expectations, REITs are under constant pressure to acquire or develop additional properties, or their money sits idle.
Until the arrival of First Industrial, the only REIT of any size in the Long Island market -- other than retail REITs like Kimco Realty Corporation of New Hyde Park and the Simon DeBartolo Group of Indianapolis -- had been Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville.
Reckson, which came out with an initial public offering in May 1995, now owns or has under contract 19.6 million square feet of office and industrial space in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, of which 8.7 million square feet are on Long Island. About 25 percent of its portfolio is industrial space.
First Industrial, formed in 1994, focuses on buying and managing industrial properties. It has a 56.6-million-square-foot portfolio in 24 major markets that include Long Island, New Jersey, Detroit, Minneapolis, Houston, Tampa, Fla., Cleveland and Phoenix, among others.
"REITs right now are the darlings of Wall Street, and their access to capital is great, so they acquire more property in order to add to their net operating income," said Andrew J. Merin, the executive director of Cushman & Wakefield's Financial Services Group in East Rutherford, N.J.
WORKING with Cushman & Wakefield's Long Island office in Melville, Mr. Merin's group recently brokered the sale to First Industrial of the 613,000-square-foot Equipark industrial park on Veterans Memorial Highway in Ronkonkoma. In the deal, which closed in December, First Industrial paid the owner, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, $27,018,018.18 for 8 buildings on 52 acres, of which seven are vacant land ready for development. It had previously paid Lazarus Burman $139 million for its 39 buildings, which included one in Fairfield, N.J.
The unusual sealed bid offer for Equipark came about because the Hebrew symbols for the numerals 8 and 10 mean good luck, said Mr. Schwarzberg of First Industrial, "and I knew we had to come in around $27 million." He added, "I was told we won by $18,000."
Reckson has also gone on a spending spree in the last year. In addition to other acquisitions in the metropolitan area, it bought 2.013 million square feet in 13 office and industrial buildings on Long Island, together costing $164 million. It is also spending $18.8 million on major renovations in those buildings. "Being bigger enables us to see every tenant in the market and keep a strong pulse on what's going on," said Scott Rechler, Reckson's president.
"REITs are helping to fuel the market by buying up choice properties, renovating them and creating an enhanced facility," said Ralph Perna, executive vice president of Grubb & Ellis/Island Realty, commercial brokers in Melville.
But others say too much money may be chasing these properties and that may ultimately backfire for the REITs.
"I've had several deals I put offers in, but the REITs just gobbled them up and it didn't make sense to us to pay those prices," said Arthur D. Sanders, president of Spiegel Associates in Jericho, a major owner and landlord of industrial, office and retail space.
"When the other end of the real estate cycle comes, and there are greater vacancies and less income, I question whether the REITs' acquisitions at these levels will turn out to be sound," he added.
Joseph A. Farkas, senior vice president of the Manhattan and Long Island offices of CB Commercial, a national brokerage firm based in Los Angeles, said there was still plenty of room for private investors. "Reckson doesn't go after everything everyone else goes after, so there's plenty of opportunity for the entrepreneurial owner to be a player," he said.
For example, in a recent deal that CB Commercial brokered on behalf of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, the 125,000-square-foot Woodlands Office Park in Hauppauge was bought by the privately held Lighthouse Real Estate Ventures of Rockville Centre, Mr. Farkas noted. "It was not the multistory trophy asset that Reckson typically purchases," he said.
T HE great thing about REITs is that they liquify bricks and mortar," said Gus P. Nuzzolese, senior executive director at Sutton & Edwards, commercial brokers in Lake Success. And although REITs may be pushing up property prices, rent increases have risen only 10 percent over two years, "which isn't anything to get excited about," he said.
"There is still a substantial amount of private ownership in place, and tenants still have a lot of options," he noted. "There are 140 million square feet of office space on Long Island and no one will dominate that because you can't buy it all."
Furthermore, Mr. Nuzzolese said, should there be a downturn in the market, REITs are less likely to get hurt than private owners -- though their stock may go down -- because of their low debt service.
"The positive side is that REITs tap into the investor market and that's good news for Long Island because it helps stimulate the economy," said Theodore P. Sasso Jr., senior managing director of Insignia/ESG, commercial brokers in Syosset. "The capital they are freeing up typically belongs to a local owner and that money goes into the economy somewhere else."
One of the attractions for owners who sell to REITs is that deals can close very quickly -- it took 33 days to close the $27 million Equipark transaction, for example.
Another advantage is that owners who might otherwise face large capital gains taxes can defer those taxes.
"If the deal is properly structured, owners can transfer the property to a REIT and get their value out in the form of operating partnership units," said Seymour Zelanko, partner at Margolin, Winer & Evens, an accounting and business advisory firm in Garden City.
Owners of these units, which are limited partnership interests in a REIT, get the same dividend income and potential price appreciation as shareholders. But the transfer is considered a tax-free transaction and is not taxed until the units are sold, Mr. Zelanko said.
He predicted that Long Island's office and industrial properties would start attracting more national REITs because of the health of the market.
According to an end-of-year office market report by Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island, the average asking rent in Suffolk and Nassau was $24.30 a square foot at the end of December, compared with $22.81 a square foot 12 months earlier. During the same period, the overall office vacancy rate dropped from 13.4 percent to 10.6 percent.
Industrial space is showing the same rent rise and space decline. According to Sutton & Edwards, the vacancy rate in December was 11.09 percent, compared with 15.7 percent the year before. In the same period, Rents rose from $6.48 a square foot to $6.78.
"Long Island has become the kind of area investors seek out," Mr. Zelanko said. "And REITs are the ownership vehicle of choice in the 1990's and will be into the next century."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
For Danbury, a 354-Unit Mixed-Housing Subdivision

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: DANBURY

 BODY:
FOR the first time in recent memory a large residential subdivision is under construction in Fairfield County. A total of 354 of detached homes and town-house condominiums are being built in Danbury, moderately priced from $159,900 for a two-bedroom town house to $285,000 for a four-bedroom detached home.
Spreading over a 130-acre hilltop off Nabby Road, the project, called Sterling Woods, is situated a half-mile uphill from Federal Road, a main artery lined with a plethora of local and big-box stores, including Stew Leonard's food market, Home Depot, Borders Books and Circuit City. A quarter-mile away is the Stadley Rough Elementary School. 
 Convenient as all this will be for the residents, the stores fortunately cannot be seen from Sterling Woods. The developers floated helium balloons at the level of the projected housing to determine how much of the wooded buffer should remain in place to mask the stores below.
The stylish dwellings -- 77 detached houses and 277 town houses when the project is completed -- contain an unusually generous number of standard features. They include full, sometimes finished, walkout basements, fireplaces, central air-conditioning, landscaping and all appliances except laundry machines. There are also decks, patios and sometimes both, with a patio at ground level and a deck above it.
Two to six town-house units per building range in size from 1,288 to 2,320 square feet; single family homes vary from 1,677 to 2,377 square feet, excluding basements, and every residence has a one- or two-car garage. Town-house owners own no land, but homeowners have fee simple title to their lots, which are 6,000 to 13,000 square feet.
Common charges of $150 to $210 a month for condominiums and $222 for the detached homes cover insurance on the exterior of the buildings, trash collection, snow clearance and road and landscape maintenance.
"Every homeowner has a fractional interest in the community property and will be a member of a community association," said Paul J. Kuehner, partner with his brother, Carl R. Kuehner 3d, in Building and Land Technologies of Wilton, a family-owned business. They are developing the project jointly with Clay Fowler, principal of the Spinnaker Companies of Stamford.
Prices for the homes, which appear to be bargains compared with other Fairfield County towns more convenient to New York City, are average for Danbury, and reflect similar pricing in other northerly Fairfield County towns. "It's the cost of the land," said Carl Kuehner. "The difference between a multi-family attached unit in Danbury and the same unit in, say, Greenwich or New Canaan is about $25,000. The spread on a house could be as much as $100,000."
Since sales began 13 months ago, 86 homes and town houses have been sold, 18 are nearly finished, 14 are under construction and the rest are to be completed by January of 2001. A residents' pool, clubhouse with exercise room and a children's playground are expected to be completed in June and a series of jogging trails will be installed as construction proceeds.
DANBURY is considered by real estate professionals to be experiencing a major upturn. Its downtown has been undergoing redevelopment and it has approved more than half a dozen applications for residential subdivisions of six to 40 homes.
"An influx of corporate people from the expansion of Duracell in Bethel and new companies relocating here has pushed resales up in price and down in numbers," said Richard Jowdy of Danbury's Prudential Real Estate office. "So we are seeing new homes being built, up to the $500,000 to $600,000 range -- that's unusual for us."
According to the city's five-term Mayor, Eugene Eriquez, a three-mile stretch of Route 7 from Danbury south to Ridgefield is to be improved by the state's Department of Transportation. "It will take until the year 2000 to complete, but it will dramatically improve traffic flow to and from lower Fairfield County," said the Mayor.
Mr. Eriquez's popularity is partly due to keeping the mill rate, or the dollars of tax per thousand dollars of assessed value, at 19.3 for the last three years. Taxes at Sterling Woods vary from $2,400 to $3,730. Sterling Woods is attracting empty-nesters who are scaling down from a family home, and "there are a lot of single people relocated by I.B.M. or working at Boehringer-Engelheim in Ridgefield, or coming in from New York State on I-684," said Barbara Adelizzi, Coldwell Banker Real Estate's sales manager for the development.
In addition to a steady stream of buyers, she said, "we are getting requests from people who want to rent town houses. There is a great shortage of rentals in Danbury, consequently we are prepared to sell some units to investors."
Kim Spector, a financial planner at I.B.M. in White Plains, bought a Sterling Woods town house last November after living in Danbury for several years. "It's two minutes from the highway, and the kitchen is huge -- which I love," she said. Accustomed to the 50-minute drive to work, she said, "I wanted to stay in Danbury because you get so much more for your money than in White Plains or Stamford, and I love waterskiing and the beach at Candlewood Lake. But one of the main reasons I bought here was the resale value."
Maintenance-free vinyl siding, gas heat and fireplaces, and city water and sewers are additional resale advantages.
CONCERNS about demands on water pressure by the development and the school were allayed when the developers installed additional water tanks, and worries over emergency vehicles accessing the single entry-exit road were addressed by building a road halfway up the hill for emergency vehicles only.
The school's 438 pupils in kindergarten through grade 5 may not be subject to crowding because "we don't expect too many children in Sterling Woods," said Timothy P. Connors, Superintendent of the Danbury schools and a Sterling Woods townhouse resident himself. "If that happens, we have plenty of land for an addition," he said.
Joan and Lewis Addessi no longer have children at home, but they bought a Sterling Woods single-family house anyway, with a large open kitchen-family room for entertaining grandchildren. They moved in last month, after selling the Danbury home they had occupied for 38 years. The family owns the Addessi jewelry stores in New Canaan and Danbury.
"We looked from Ridgefield to Newtown and Milford," said Mr. Addessi. "We checked out other places the Kuehners had built, and finally we looked at each other and said, 'This is it.' The next place we move will be to St. Peter's Cemetery."
The Kuehners and Clay Fowler have worked together for eight years, producing luxury and moderately priced homes and condominiums in Wilton, Norwalk, New Canaan, Woodbury and Danbury; in Stamford, they have just broken ground for 30 luxury homes off Westover and Stillwater Roads, to be priced from $500,000.
Sterling Woods was started in the early 80's by George Davon, who built 87 still occupied and well-maintained condominium units that lie across from the new Sterling Woods entrance. Mr. Davon died before the project could be completed; the remaining acreage went into receivership and was repurchased at auction by Mr. Davon's company, Park Cliff in Manhattan, which sold it to the Kuehners and Mr. Fowler.
"A lot of developers would not do something as large as this because of the potential for recession during a long construction period," said Carl Kuehner. But, he reasoned, by increasing choices among four town-house and six detached-house models, and diversifying price ranges, a broad base of the market can be reached.
"For the first time in years we are seeing larger-plan development concepts again," he said, "and its an education for the consumer. The Northeastern Yankee is not accustomed to not owning everything in fee simple."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Town houses, left, in the Sterling Woods development in Danbury, which also has detached homes. Kim Spector at kitchen counter in her town house. (Photographs by Michael J. Doolittle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Confident Consumers Are Buying Large New Homes

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
HIGH consumer confidence and low mortgage interest rates are boosting the market for large new homes in the $500,000-and-up range.
With financing more readily available, builders are responding to what they say is a steady demand for such houses by starting new projects or expanding existing ones. Some builders are even creating "design centers," where prospective buyers can choose from many options and upgrades to customize their new homes. 
 The demand is coming mainly from young professional couples with children and from baby boomers who have held back from buying until now, as well as an increasing number of people transferred by their corporations, said John Udell. He is president of the New Homes and Land Division of Weichert Realtors, a brokerage in Morris Plains.
Forty-five projects, totaling more than 307 homes, are in various stages of development in the $500,000-and-over category in the state's 14 northern and central counties, according to the New Homes Division of Coldwell Banker, another brokerage based in Short Hills. Last year there were 30 projects with 220 homes.
That follows the uptick in new construction in New Jersey. Through last November, 9.8 percent more housing permits had been issued than the previous year's total of 22,146 for the same period, data from the state's Department of Labor show.
Other factors are also stoking the market for more expensive houses, industry analysts said. One is that the strong economy and bull market on Wall Street have left some buyers with increased incomes and many, sensing that corporate downsizing and layoffs are mostly over, are investing in bigger homes. The improvement in the state's overall housing market is also making it easier for people to buy and sell.
"As long as people at the bottom of the housing ladder can buy, there is a domino effect, allowing people to sell an existing home for a bigger one," said David J. Schoner, vice president of Coldwell Banker's New Homes Division.
Those factors were part of the reason Lisa and Daniel Adams decided that instead of expanding their 3,400-square-foot ranch in Morris Township, they would buy a bigger new house in the same town. "I had called the contractors and was ready to remodel, but I was out driving last month and fell in love with this new house," said Mrs. Adams. "So we said, 'Why blow up our house when this one has everything we want?' "
The couple -- she is the owner, and he is the manager of an engineering, plumbing and heating supply company -- are buying a 4,200-square-foot colonial in the $600,000 range at Hillside Meadows, a subdivision under development off Lake Road. They put their current home on the market last month and are confident it will sell, Mrs. Adams said, adding that she expected to close on the new house in May.
"We think it's a solid investment," she said.
As of the third quarter of 1997, 159,200 existing homes had sold for that year, compared with 148,800 during the same period in 1996. The average sale price also rose, to $192,400 from $191,600, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison.
Coldwell Banker puts the average sale price in the $500,000-and-over new-home category at $824,735 for the 58 houses sold in 1997 at the 45 projects it tracks. That is up from $808,820 for the 48 homes sold 1996.
Typically, builders offer many options and upgrades for potential buyers of their model homes. Buyers are spending $20,000 to $120,000 on such options, with additional rooms -- like conservatories and home offices -- marble floors and granite countertops among the most popular, Mr. Schoner said.
Land values have also risen, Mr. Udell of Weichert Realtors said. That, along with a dwindling supply of suitable sites and the state's long approval process for construction, will temper the pace of construction of such projects, keeping demand ahead of supply, he said, adding: "There will be upward pressure on prices."
For projects to be successful, Mr. Schoner said, they must be in upscale locations with records of appreciation, reasonable taxes and good schools. He said many of the projects are in areas accessible to employment centers along the Interstate 287 corridor in Morris, Bergen, Somerset and Monmouth counties
In the Somerset County community of Skillman, Toll Brothers of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., which focuses on luxury homes, is building Beden Brook Estates, close to Route 518. The 52 homes each sit on lots averaging 1.5 acres, and some back onto a golf course.
BASE prices for the four- and five-bedroom homes, with 3,400 to 4,050 square feet, are $447,000 to $520,000. But with options and lot premiums, the average price for the 31 homes sold since sales began a year ago has been $563,000.
"This market has been going strong for the past two years, but has ratcheted up even more in the past six months," said Frederick N. Cooper, vice president of finance at Toll Brothers. He attributes the increased sales to buyers' "confidence in the economy and in their employment."
Hillside Meadows in Morris Township, where the Adamses intend to live, is also finding demand among buyers. Since sales started in October, five of the 3,800- to 4,500-square-foot, five-bedroom homes, each on lots just under one acre,, have been sold, said Jay S. Grant of Grant Homes, L.L.C. of Mendham, the developer. The average sales price, including options, is $660,000.
"People are looking to spend money," Mr. Grant said, adding that they will invest in a larger home if they believe they are getting value for their money.
At another Morris County subdivision, off Pleasant Plains Road in Long Hill and called Autumn Crest, Sterling Properties L.L.C. of Livingston is also attracting buyers looking for bigger homes. Since the project opened last summer, 12 of the 18 homes, ranging from 3,600 to 4,300 square feet, have been sold for an average price of just under $600,000, including options, said Joseph Forgione of Sterling.
Pinnacle Communities Ltd. of Millburn will break ground on two luxury projects next month because "we see a hole in the market that we want to take advantage of," saidPaul R. Schneier, the company's director of operations.
One project, the Gates at Mahwah on McIntosh Drive in the Bergen County town of Mahwah, will have up to 14 houses, each on a lot averaging one to 1.5 acres and with 4,000 square feet of space. The other project, Beacon Hill, located at Somerville and Allen Roads in Bernards Township in Somerset County, will have 15 houses of similar size on minimum one-acre lots. Base prices are expected to start in the $600,000 range.
In Colts Neck in Monmouth County, Byron Hill Homebuilders of Marlboro is developing the Ridings, 22 homes on 47 acres on HeulittRoad. Landscaped pathways lace the development, providing bridle paths that lead to the nearby 200-acre Bucks Mill Park.
"We see growth in the luxury home market, particularly in Monmouth County, where there is a demand, but there is not much available," said Luther A. Gueyikian, the president of Byron Hill.
THE houses, which can be customized, sit on 1.5-acre lots and have 5,000 to 7,800 square feet of space. Since sales began a year ago, the base price has increased to $700,000 from $600,000, Mr. Gueyikian said, adding that 15 homes had been sold.
The Matzel & Mumford Organization of Hazlet is building a 42-home subdivision called Bedford Chase, on Beacon Light Road, just off Route 517 in Tewksbury Township in Hunterdon County.
"Buyers are looking for quality and for a good investment," said Roger Mumford, president of the company. "But they are not going to move unless the new house meets their life style." The company has built a 4,000-square-foot design center at its Hazlet headquarters to help buyers at all of its developments in what Mr. Mumford, called "personalizing their home."
Sales of Bedford Chase's 36 homes began just under two years ago, Mr. Mumford said. The homes, averaging 3,800 square feet with options and upgrades, have sold for an average price of $540,000, he said.

HEADLINE: Students' Research Pays Off in Patents

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: ARMONK

 BODY:
AS many of their elders struggle to figure out the most basic computer applications, two students at Byram Hills High School here were recently named among the 300 semifinalists -- but not among the 40 finalists -- selected in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search for their research in computers. More significantly, the students, August Petrillo and Philip Fong, both seniors, became the first students ever to have their work patented -- by International Business Machines, where they did their research. They , were, incidentally, the only Westchester students to reach the semifinals.
August, 17, whose paper dealt with identifying computer viruses, and Philip, 18, who developed a computerized method to analyze singing, are part of Byram Hills High School's Science Research Program. Now in its ninth year, the program has been nationally recognized for its success in producing science scholars. In recent years, the school has produced the highest number of Westinghouse science scholars in the county, with 11 semifinalists and 3 finalists. 
 Under the direction of Dr. Robert Pavlica, who initially developed the concept and holds a doctorate in biochemistry, students can pursue research projects in whatever scientific area interests them.
At Byram Hills, there are now 50 students enrolled in the program. Students earn three Regents credits for this three-year course, which is taken in addition to biology, chemistry and physics. As part of the course requirements, students are expected to find mentors in their field, apply for grants, conduct experiments and review scientific literature. Students are also expected to meet with Dr. Pavlica for an hour every 10 days and spend at least seven hours in independent research every two weeks.
The program has proved so effective at developing young research scientists -- even among students who had not previously taken much interest in traditional science courses -- that the National Science Foundation asked Dr. Pavlica to design a model that can be used throughout the United States. Such a program is now in use in several schools in Florida and California, and 74 high schools in New York State have adopted it.
"One of the things that makes this program work is that kids do what they love," Dr. Pavlica said. "I'm there to facilitate the process. With these students, I knew enough about computers to know that what they were working on was state of the art, and to let them go."
Both August and Philip are self-described computer aficionados, although they have many other interests. Philip, who has been admitted to the California Institute of Technology but is waiting to hear from other colleges before making his choice, is a member of the track team and the cross-county team. He writes for the school newspaper and is a member of the math team. August, who will enroll at Princeton University next fall, is captain of both the math team and the mock trial team. He plays varsity tennis and skis, edits the school's literary magazine and teaches a class in computer programming to younger students at the high school.
Since the school has a relationship with the I.B.M. Research Group in Yorktown Heights, which provides lab space, mentors and research guidance for the students, it was a natural fit for August and Philip to pursue their projects there. Philip worked with the speech-recognition group in the Human Language Technologies Department, while August worked with the Anti-Virus Lab Research Group. The students worked at their labs during summer vacation as well as after school, and they estimate that they have devoted close to 2,000 hours each to their projects.
"I don't sing," Philip said, when asked why he chose to research singing. "This was a cool project because it was different and new. The goal is to help people learn to sing by having the computer identify the different phonetic sounds that go into singing. The computer can analyze pitch, rhythm and pronunciation and identify someone's weak spots or problems."
Although Philip's work is somewhat analogous to the voice-recognition software programs that are currently on the market, enable someone to dictate into a computer, in many ways a more useful way of thinking about his work is envisioning a karaoke model.
I.B.M. applied for a patent on this work, Philip explained, because it is unique. "The idea doesn't exist," he said. "I couldn't find any research in this area -- and the actual technologies don't exist."
His mentor, Nelson Strother, a programmer at I.B.M. Research in Yorktown Heights, said: "This is a neat idea for a niche market. It's a neat way to stretch the limits of speech-recognition technology."
Philip, the eldest of three children, lives in Pleasantville. His father is an electrical engineer, and his mother is a pharmacist. He intends to study engineering in college because "I want to build something," he said, after expressing surprise that his work was selected by the Westinghouse judges.
August, the older of two children, lives in Bedford. His father is a businessman, and his mother is an English teacher. "I've been a computer person ever since kindergarten, when my family got an Apple," he said. "I thought it was interesting because you could program it to do whatever you want. It's so versatile."
"I was initially interested in working with artificial life, but when I couldn't find a mentor, I branched out to artificial intelligence," August said. "Prior to my junior year, I started working on my own stuff."
August's research offers an automated program that enables computer programmers automatically to identify macro-viruses, which can infect data files, documents and templates in a computer system.
One of his mentors at I.B.M. Research, Morton Swimmer, a project leader for the immune system group there, said: "Augie's work was excellent. Otherwise, we wouldn't have pursued the patent. It's central to what we were doing with the immune system. It has definite implications for the future. It's the direction that we see the anti-virus field going."
August plans to study economics at Princeton and work toward a graduate degree in business administration. "This is at the back end of computers," he said. "Before this research, everyone was doing this analysis by hand. As the number of viruses that were created rose, you needed an automated system. This program I created analyzes viruses that come into I.B.M. via the Internet. Everyone will need to use this research, because the virus growth rate is too high. If you don't have this technology, you can't survive in the virus field in the next few years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Philip Fong, left, and August Petrillo, Westinghouse semifinalists, with Dr. Robert Pavlica, center, at Byram Hills High School in Armonk. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Jersey Rust Belt Gets a Bit Brighter

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
DEMAND for industrial property is surging in northern New Jersey, prompting renewed interest in old and frequently decayed sections of once-vibrant manufacturing communities close to New York City.
Factory buildings in Hudson, Essex and Passaic Counties that sat idle for years because of the long decline in manufacturing are finding new uses. 
 "Old industrial properties that were looked on as eyesores are in demand again," said Scott Deutchman, a broker with SBWE Real Estate in Hasbrouck Heights. He said land values in places had risen so much that former warehouses in the Meadowlands were being converted to retail stores and companies are searching in towns like Harrison, Kearny, Newark and Paterson for old factories that can be converted to new uses.
"There has been so little building for so long in this state that we're running out of room," said Joseph R. Romano, executive vice president of Grubb & Ellis New Jersey. "Older, urban areas were seen as less desirable, but if you need 100,000 square feet of space to grow your business and you can't find it anywhere else, you have to look there."
Mr. Romano said the current situation provided a window of opportunity for some cities and towns of the northern part of the state to demonstrate that they have reduced crime to acceptable levels and are willing to accept businesses that would not be welcome in pricey suburbs before the next wave of commercial building gives companies the option of moving into campus-like sites farther south in the state.
According to figures collected by Grubb & Ellis, all the counties in northern New Jersey have vacancy rates for industrial property in single digits, with Bergen County the lowest at 6 percent in the fourth quarter of 1997, compared to 8 percent a year earlier. Vacancies for Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Passaic Counties have all dropped over the last year. In Hudson County, which includes such once-bustling but now decayed manufacturing areas as parts of Kearny and Harrison, the vacancy rate went from 9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996 to about 7.5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year and the other two in the mid-7 percent range, down from 7.9 percent in Passaic and 8.5 percent in Essex.
Real estate executives said it was not likely that vacancy rates could go much lower, since most of the property left was functionally obsolete, with low ceilings and floors without the capacity to accept heavier loads even if the roof was raised.
One indication of the renewed appeal of northern New Jersey's industrial areas is the recent announcement by a New York-based film production company, the Shooting Gallery, of plans to build a studio and back lot in Harrison, in Hudson County, on a 30-acre property dominated by the old Worthington pump plant. A former Western Electric factory complex in Kearny that once employed 25,000 people manufacturing telephone equipment is now being operated as warehouses for tenants who like the Hudson County location near the Turnpike, the rail access and the proximity to the Newark air and sea ports.
Even Paterson, the first planned industrial community in the country when founded at Alexander Hamilton's behest in 1791, but well past its prime as a manufacturing center, is showing signs of revival. Old mill buildings in the Passaic County city have been converted into offices, retail stores and housing. And plans are being discussed to bring mixed development to the badly deteriorated heart of the city's Federal historic district.
The old industrial complexes that are being redeveloped have something that is in short supply in or near New York City: space. Stephen Carlis, the chief financial officer of Shooting Gallery, noted that the old factory buildings on the site had 60-foot ceilings, which leave plenty of room for sets and lighting.
"The whole site has 30 acres of land, which is just not available in Manhattan," he said. Mr. Carlis said the company, whose best-known film is "Sling Blade," is planning to use the entire site as a back lot with facilities to do high-tech post-production work often lost to studio companies in California.
Another attraction, he said, was how close the site is to the company's principal offices in Manhattan. "It's only six miles away," he said. "We are still a New York film company. We have just expanded to New Jersey."
Space and location are the themes, as well, at River Terminal Development Company, a 300-acre site at the confluence of the Passaic and Hackensack Rivers in Kearny. The site, which combines an old shipyard with the former Western Electric complex, has 5.4 million square feet of warehouse and distribution space and 40 acres of vacant land to build more if the need arises.
PART of the need for ever-more space is ever-bigger trucks, said Alan M. Lambiase, real estate sales manager for the privately owned River Terminal company.
"If you go back a few years, trailers were about 40 feet long," he said. "Now that cargo box is as much as 53 feet, and when you add the tractor you are talking 80 linear feet." To back such a vehicle up to a loading dock requires from 110 to 140 feet of maneuvering space, something not easily done in more crowded locations.
Room to maneuver is becoming even more important because distributors do not like inventory piling up for long periods of time, tying up working capital. They want to move goods in and out more quickly, which means buildings are adding loading docks, forcing trucks to park more closely together.
"The old ratio was one dock per 10,000 square feet," Mr. Lambiase said. "Now it is one per 7,500 square feet and, in some cases, one per 5,000 square feet."
Most tenants at River Terminal are in some part of what is now called the logistics business, a combination of warehousing, distribution, repackaging and shipment preparation. "You can't really make any money just warehousing anymore," he said. "You have to do value-added work; it's almost like remanufacturing."
Tenants include companies that handle distribution for garment companies, department and specialty stores and those that deal with perishable products, such as frozen food. He said access to both the sea and airports was important to companies whose business is moving goods quickly and efficiently.
The background of the property teaches lessons in industrial development. The eastern half was once a shipyard and later a ship-scrapping operation operated by River Terminal's parent company, Hugo Neu Corporation, which remains in the scrap business in other locations.
On the western side stands a building that is 50 feet wide but 700 feet long. Corporate records show that the building was once a Ford Motor Company assembly plant, complete with a small test track that still exists in altered form. Today the building is operated by River Terminal as a warehouse for tenants that have large seasonal swings in their inventory.
Paterson, conceived by Hamilton and planned by Pierre L'Enfant, the French engineer who laid out downtown Washington, was intended to be the nation's first industrial park. In the late 1700's, the power of falling water was the most efficient way to drive machinery, and with the 77-foot falls on the Passaic River, there was plenty of water with a long way to fall. The name derives from William Paterson, then the governor of New Jersey.
The same forces that drove manufacturers out of Kearny and Harrison were present in Paterson as well, although manufacturing still represents the largest category of employment in the city. But unlike Newark, which has experienced a sharp drop in population, Paterson's has held steady at about 150,000, fueled by a diverse stream of immigrants. City officials estimate more than 50 nationalities are represented among recent immigrants.
Some recovery has taken place. Of the 500,000 square feet of space that was once vacant in the old Continental Can building, only 50,000 remain. A. & P. remodeled annother old mill building adjacent to one of its stores and moved in 500 office workers.
Detailed real estate statistics are not kept town by town, but Deborah Hoffman, executive director of the Paterson Economic Development Corporation, said she knew of only two industrial sites larger than 50,000 square feet that were available in the city.
In the federally designated Great Falls Historic District, where a series of canals once directed water to the wheels of mills that spun silk and produced the first practical revolver pistol, an industrial revival is not likely. So developers have converted some mills to housing and mixed uses, talking advantage of various tax breaks and subsidies.
"This area was economically dead in the mid 1980's," said Lawrence E. Regan, the president of Regan Development of Yonkers. Most of the old mills had long since ceased to operate and many had been heavily damaged by fire.
But it had been recognized as an Urban Enterprise Zone, which meant funds were available to help offset the costs of development. Mill buildings were converted into housing for artists and others, with retail stores to serve the residents.
DEVELOPMENT in a historic district must be done with an eye toward preserving at least some of the past while meeting the needs of today. Mr. Regan is proposing a $21 million mixed-use development along the Passaic River that would include stabilizing and perhaps restoring the partly destroyed Colt Gun Mill at the corner of Van Houten and Mill Streets in the heart of the district.
The mill was the first to produce a practical revolver pistol, commencing operations in 1836. But the weapon was complicated and expensive, so the New Jersey company went bankrupt in 1842 and the building subsequently was used for textile production. The revolvers that won the West came from Connecticut and other places.
Nevertheless, because the weapons industry is considered by historians as the precursor for all mass manufacturing in this country, the Federal Government has pledged $4 million to help restore some of the raceways, water wheels and buildings in the historic district to show how the United States took its first steps toward industrialization.
Mr. Regan's proposed development, which would follow earlier mill renovations for housing, would include 30,000 square feet of commercial space, planned to include an art gallery, cooking school and a cafe, and 65 two-family housing units. Forty-five of the units would be partially subsidized, 20 of them market rate.
Trying to build in a historic district is a stiff challenge, Ms. Hoffman said. "The developer just about needs an archeologist standing there every time he digs a hole," she said. "Regan Development has revised its plan five or six times to be sensitive to the community and to history."
George McLoof, whose Longstreet Development Company has also been active in the historic district, said the city's image as a tired mill town long past its prime was countered by reality.
"People are paying $30 to $40 a square foot for retail space along Main Street, and you don't see many vacancies," he said. "If someone closes, someone else opens up pretty soon." He said the city's industrial past meant its infrastructure was well developed. "There is a lot of underutilized electrical and gas capacity," he said.
Naturally, the past has left some problems as well. One of the few sizable development sites left in the city, an 11-acre parcel downstream from the historic district, includes the site of an old town gas plant operated by a predecessor of Public Service Electric & Gas Company.
Before pipelines were built to carry natural gas from states like Texas and Louisiana to the north, gas for cooking and lighting was generated by heating coal. It was often a sloppy process, and the ground below the old plant, which is adjacent to the river, is heavily contaminated with hydrocarbons.
One attempt by the utility to have a contractor solve the problem by digging up the soil and treating it failed, so it has been forced to take a different approach. "There are about 11 acres available for development with restrictions," said Warren Straubmuller, a project manager for Public Service. One of these restrictions in on residential development, where the lingering effects of pollution could be a health hazard.
The most contaminated soil will be treated and capped, he said, adding that "P.S.E. & G. will keep three acres as a gas distribution station," leaving eight acres available for others.
ONE drawback to development in urban locations is finding enough parking for cars. Mr. McLoof is working on a plan to build an entertainment center near the city's center that would include a multiscreen cinema, retail and office space and maybe a stage for live entertainment.
Since the block-square site is now a parking lot, he has to find a way to demonstrate to city planners that there will be adequate parking in the area if the open lot is supplanted by a building.
If finding a place to put a car after arriving in Paterson may be a problem, getting there is not. The city is split by the main east-west highway in the northern part of the state, Interstate 80. And there are access ramps in the city.
Like the other manufacturing centers in northern New Jersey, Paterson, Newark and the smaller cities and towns of the area are tightly linked with the rest of the national and international economy by a well-developed system of road, rail and ports.
"Logistically, there is no better place to be in New Jersey than Newark -- it just has an image problem," said Mr. Romano. "There is a reason why the older cities are located where they are."

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Speeding the Pace of Recycling in City-Run Housing

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
IN the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn, close to the Queens border, Jean M. Reynolds is becoming expert in a housing relocation technique known as checkerboarding.
The checkerboard player moves tenants from one apartment to another, usually in a different building, with the option to return when renovations are complete. 
 As one of the smaller and newer participants in the city's Neighborhood Rehabilitation Program, Ms. Reynolds, the community development director of the Cypress Hills Local Development Corporation, is growing adept at the technique. She began with a vacant building, at 296 Jerome Street. Tenanting it created some of the vacancies in other buildings that are due to be upgraded.
"I've found that many of the tenants don't want to go back to their old apartment, because they were overcrowded there," Ms. Reynolds said. "I've had to find alternative housing for them. Our goal is to make clean, decent housing. We'll fill the empty apartments through the lottery system."
There are five more buildings in her Cypress Hills pipeline. They are part of a much larger city pipeline of occupied tax-foreclosed buildings that have long been run by the city but are gradually being renovated by local nonprofit development companies, which will own and manage them.
The Neighborhood Rehabilitation Program, as the effort is called, is one of the two major city-sponsored rehabilitation programs that depend on the Federal tax-credit program for low-income housing. The other is the Neighborhood Entrepreneurs Program, which relies on local entrepreneurs to take the role of long-term owner-operators.
Together these programs account for about 70 percent of rehabilitation activity in the city's gradually shrinking inventory of tax-foreclosed housing. Using other Federal financing sources as well as its own money, the city also recycles multifamily buildings directly to tenant ownership, and rehabilitates one- and two-family houses for low-income owners.
Now the Clinton Administration is proposing to raise the level of financing under the tax-credit program by 40 percent nationwide. The fate of that proposal in the budgetary debate just getting under way in Congress is uncertain, but if it is enacted it would probably have a bigger impact here than anywhere else.
"We're the largest user of the tax-credit program in the country," said Richard T. Roberts, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development.
If the Clinton proposal becomes law, the city would probably be able to pick up the pace of the two big rehabilitation programs by 40 or 50 buildings a year over the current rate of about 120 buildings a year, housing officials said. The average number of apartments in tax-foreclosed multifamily buildings is 10.
Under the tax credit program, major corporations and well-to-do individuals earn about a 10 percent rate of return in the form of tax reductions over a 15-year period by contributing to low-income housing production. Investment houses market the credits to investors on behalf of both for-profit and nonprofit developers. The program began in 1987 with a three-year Congressional authorization, and in 1993 it was made a permanent part of the Internal Revenue Code.
The program has been capped at about $300 million a year for 10 years, allowing sponsors to undertake 75,000 to 90,000 housing units nationwide. The Administration proposes to lift this to about $420 million a year.
HOUSING recycling with tenants in place is a slow process. When Mayor Edward I. Koch started his 10-year housing plan in 1986, the inventory of foreclosed occupied apartments stood at about 52,000. The Giuliani administration's plan is to rid itself of the entire remaining 25,000 units over about 10 years.
Since 1988, tax-credit financing has been used in the rehabilitation of 12,100 units, both vacant and occupied. But in recent years its principal use has been in rehabilitating smaller occupied structures.
For the last five years there have been no new city takeovers, or vestings, and the plan is to divert directly to community-based ownership any buildings that are effectively abandoned by private owners, avoiding the vesting process and city management entirely. This has yet to happen, but it may for the first time in about eight months, housing officials said, depending on the results of a foreclosure action on 174 buildings in the South Bronx that is already under way.
The community development corporations that renovate buildings under the Neighborhood Rehabilitation Program work closely with the intermediaries that provide nonprofits with the capital raised through the tax-credit program -- the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, known as LISC, and the Enterprise Foundation.
The system has helped build the network of community-based management companies. In addition, the city supplies low-interest loans for construction, averaging at present about $60,000 an apartment.
William Traylor, senior program director for LISC in New York City, said that there were about 70 local development corporations in the city now, but only about 20 are of substantial size in the sense that they have completed and are operating hundreds of apartments. Many of their buildings were built new or rehabilitated under earlier, and far larger, Federal production programs.
LISC itself deals with about 40 nonprofits. Over time, Mr. Traylor said, nonprofit operators have learned to economize on operating and maintenance costs, which now average $4,100 an apartment per year, he said. The buildings pay no taxes and pay only 1 percent interest on their mortgage debt.
The tenants living in city-managed buildings must wait sometimes for years before the funding is available to start these rehabilitation projects, and they are not always thrilled by the dislocation it entails. But for many the wait is worthwhile.
Nilsa Rosa, a tenant with two children living for nine years in a Cypress Hills one-bedroom with a kitchen "smaller than a closet" and a stoppage in her kitchen sink for the last five years, was the final tenant to occupy the totally rehabilitated 15-unit walk-up at 296 Jerome Street in Cypress Hills when she moved in last week.
Ms. Rosa, who is 50, will be paying $286 a month, the public-assistance shelter allowance for a family of three, and will get a spacious second-floor two-bedroom apartment.
"It's beautiful," she said. "There's so much room. It's so clean." Four of the 15 tenants are on welfare; the rest are working families with incomes of $22,000 to $34,000 a year, said Ms. Reynolds, the development director of the Cypress Hill development corporation.
With Victor Morales of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, as the architect, the group will start the reconstruction of five additional buildings in Cypress Hills in June. Four of the buildings are six-unit walk-ups and one is an 18-unit walk-up at 209 Jamaica Avenue. The other addresses are 28-29 Fulton Street, 553 Glenmore Avenue, 211 Bradford Street and 779 Liberty Avenue, all city-owned and managed for about 15 years.
At present Ms. Reynolds has been working with tenants to prepare a relocation plan. "Initially some people were a little cynical," she said, "but eventually they become anxious to be relocated to new units, once you've talked with them on an ongoing basis and formed a bond."
Two of the buildings had been plagued with drug trafficking. Housing officials moved out the problem tenants before the community group became involved.
"The tax-credit program is the only program out there right now that targets our market," said Michelle Neugebauer, executive director of the Cypress Hills Local Development Corporation, which was formed in 1983. "We only have scattered abandoned properties, but they bring down the value of the whole surrounding neighborhood."
Ms. Neugebauer also noted that market-rate apartments in Cypress Hills now rent for about $750 to $900 a month, far more than many people living in the neighborhood can afford. "The program has created affordability," she said.

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
Porters, Maids and Barbers: Blacks and the Service Industries

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
When Cubit Brunson arrived in Jersey City in 1915 from a farm in South Carolina, he landed a job selling insurance to other blacks. His son Theodore became a collection manager for the Internal Revenue Service. Theodore's son, Neal, is a lawyer. Unlike Cubit Brunson, many African-Americans who migrated to Northern states had to build their family foundations with more menial labor. To celebrate February as Black History Month, the Afro-American Historical and Cultural Society Museum, 4,000 square feet above the Greenville Branch of the Jersey City Public Library, has assembled an exhibit titled "Blacks in the Service Industry." Ted Brunson, 75, who directed the museum since it was founded in 1977, passed the directorship on to his son last year. Neal Brunson, 35, spoke recently as he and his father gave a tour of the museum, which holds cultural icons ranging from sheet music of blatantly racist "coon songs" to an elaborately carved African tribal stool.
Q. Why an exhibit of blacks in the service industry? 
 A. At the end of the Civil War, most blacks worked in the service industry: maids, butlers, domestics, washerwomen, barbers, porters. And they came north because of the money. The war economy of the North enabled more people to hire more domestics and more servants and to pay them more money. So they came north to New Jersey. And one of the things we're focusing on is what happened when they got here. How did they earn a living when they got here? You talk to any African-American, and ask how many of your grandparents, how many of your grandaunts and uncles worked in the domestic industry. I bet you at least one out of two, one out of three worked in that field. And from that very humble type of job, they saved the economic life of black America. We would have gone bankrupt. African-American men often were day laborers. Day laborers did not work consistently. There was not consistent money coming into that community -- except the wife who was taking in wash, the wife who was working as a domestic or the men that were able to work as butlers and in other male service jobs.
Q. Was there competition for those jobs?
A. The competition was enormous. Blacks were predominantly barbers for the entire population prior to the migration of Italian-Americans. And as Italian-Americans came in, blacks were displaced from that. At the turn of the century when Atlantic City was a vacation hub, blacks were predominant workers in terms of waiters and busboys and the staffing of these hotels. When more migrants came from Europe, they were summarily displaced.
Q. Is there a parallel between blacks being displaced from jobs at the turn of the century and what some blacks say today about more recent waves of immigrants?
A. Absolutely. One of the reasons why I was fascinated with this period is, you have a lot of debate now about the affirmative action question. And you have some who pose the question of why blacks have not been able to reach a certain economic level. So I'm going back and taking a look at the economic forces that really drove this.
Q. What was Jersey City's history as a link in the Underground Railroad?
A. Frederick Douglass spoke here, there were a number of abolitionist meetings here. It was an important link because New Jersey had slavery. New Jersey didn't give up slavery until the 13th Amendment. So in New Jersey there always had to be a link with the abolitionist movement and the Underground Railroad to get people from New Jersey on through. STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;
Call It Sea Gate or Seagate?

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Observers of Mayor Giuliani's reputed ability to cow into submission employees, opponents and citizens, take note: the Mayor may have met his match, and his name is Kasper Price.
Mr. Price is the president of the Sea Gate Association, which represents the residents of Sea Gate, a private, gated community on the western edge of the Coney Island peninsula. 
 Since last summer, Mr. Price and his association have been engaged in a fierce boundary dispute with their neighbors and the city. The city emerged bloodied from the most recent round of legal sparring. Sea Gate came out smiling.
It all started with some chain links. Last summer, Sea Gate, determined to keep its private community private, erected a 10-foot-high fence to bar outsiders from a new strip of beach that the tides had caused to materialize at the back of some Sea Gate houses.
Their Coney Island neighbors were furious, and they quickly enlisted the help of city officials. After an investigation, the city concluded that not only had Sea Gate failed to get a city permit to construct the fence, but that the fence was on land that had been seized by the city in 1977 for nonpayment of taxes.
With the police looking on and Mr. Price fuming, city officials took the fence down. The Sea Gate Association promptly filed a lawsuit against the Mayor and the city.
On Jan. 22, Justice Joseph J. Dowd of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn issued a preliminary injunction barring the city from Sea Gate property.
He also said the city appeared to have violated Sea Gate's constitutional rights, because the association had never been notified that the land in question was on the tax rolls, let alone that taxes were owed. Due process had been denied, he ruled.
Mr. Price was exuberant, although the lawsuit has yet to be decided. "We're not only going to put the fence back up," he said, "we're going to sue for damages."
Jeannette LoSciuto, a Coney Island resident who had led the charge against the fence, called the judge's ruling incredible. There was overwhelming evidence, she said, that the city had owned the land since 1962, when it was seized under an urban renewal plan.
Warren Shaw, an assistant corporation counsel in the New York City Law Department's commercial and real estate litigation division, said the judge's ruling was "not a final determination."
"What's ultimately going to happen," he added, "no one knows." AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: Fancy Boxes From Europe, Wrapped for Americans

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR 

 BODY:
VOLVO has an exceptional sense of who buys its boxy, utilitarian cars. Mercedes has an equally strong sense of what customers want from its solid, sometimes stolid, luxury cars. Never have the two camps been close.
While Volvo loyalists depend on that company's reputation for safety and reliability, Mercedes traditionalists view the three-pointed star as a touchstone for Old World elegance, endurance and, of course, status. 
 Ah, status. What would a Mercedes be without it? For the most remarkable feature of the Mercedes E320 station wagon is its price, which starts at more than $47,000 and exceeds $50,000 with full leather, sunroof and the fancy traction and stability technology that defines luxury cars today. And that is for rear-wheel drive. A new all-wheel-drive option costs another $2,750.
For that money you would expect something more than a state-of-the-art, seven-passenger wagon, even if it is intended to cart children, plants and groceries. And, mostly, Mercedes delivers. The performance is spirited, the handling is agile and responsive and the appointments are not just convenient, they are virtually flawless.
What it does not deliver is that something extra -- grace, muscle, refinement -- that seduces you into the showroom and makes you downright joyful to part with a big chunk of Junior's college tuition.
While test-driving the E320, I kept thinking about Ford and Volvo wagons I have driven, asking myself what there is about this car that merits the extra money.
The answer, I concluded, is that the Mercedes is superior to those capable workhorses -- it is more powerful and more roomy -- but only if you value a little more raw performance up front and extra cargo space in the rear. The Mercedes has both, and for now it is alone at the top of the heap. Two German luxury wagons -- a restyled Audi A6 and the BMW 5-Series -- will make their American debuts later this year.
The E320's engine is a new, delightful 3.2-liter V6 -- replacing an in-line 6 -- with an efficient 221 horsepower and impressive fuel economy. It has two platinum-tipped spark plugs and three valves per cylinder, and roars out a stunning percentage of its peak torque at relatively low speeds, about 2,000 r.p.m. Merging onto a freeway, accelerating from a stop and jumping into a passing lane are not gambles.
The automatic transmission has five speeds, which is rare among station wagons. Like some other luxury gearboxes, it senses road grades and driving speeds and decides when to change gears. On the freeway, it stays in gear longer, for example.
I put the Mercedes through a mix of tasks, including suburban errands and a trip up the Taconic Parkway for a day of skiing. The weather was varied but frightful -- with rain and snow showers and slick, even icy, road conditions -- but the rear-drive wagon got us where we needed to go. It was helped by its standard traction control, which diverts power from wheels that are spinning to those that are gripping. A $990 option, the electronic stability program, reduces sliding or spinning of the driving wheels by selectively applying the brakes to keep the car going in the proper direction.
As the for the all-wheel-drive version, a colleague who drove the car through the Catskills reported that it was unperturbed by snow-packed lanes and muddy mountain roads.
Like every Mercedes, the E320 wagon felt solid and safe, and wind noise was minimal. There were two air bags up front and two in the front doors. In one panic stop, I benefited from a braking feature that adds full force to the brakes when it senses an emergency, based on how quickly the driver has depressed the brake pedal.
The interior had all the usual Mercedes luxury. A touch of walnut surrounds the cabin, which is pre-wired for a mobile phone and a little gizmo that integrates up to three remote controls (presumably for the driveway gate, the garage door and the horse barn). Storage pockets abound. The power front seats can be adjusted 10 ways.
The air-conditioner has separate controls for the driver and the front-seat passenger. A vent between the front seats blows hot or cold air to the rear passengers.
The Germans have clearly surrendered to Americans' demand for cup holders. This wagon had eight: two up front, two in the glove box door, two that slid out of the second-seat armrest and two for passengers in the rear-facing third seat. There was even a nice cup ring that sprouted from the center console and expanded to hold big containers.
So where are the flaws? For this amount of money, I'd prefer a two-piece tailgate, which would make it easier to tuck away small items. The seats, for all the automation, were not as comfortable as those in other luxury cars I've driven. The large, single windshield wiper never washed and wiped completely. The clock can be read only by the driver. The instrument panel light that monitors the traction control systems is a distracting, over-large yellow triangle.
But here's a safety concern: The cruise control is operated by a stalk to the left of the steering wheel, just next to the turn signal lever. If you are not careful, a flick of the stick activates the cruise control and sends you flying ahead. Oddly, there is not a light announcing that the cruise control is on.
Lately, Volvo has advertised its all-wheel drive wagon with a line, "Life, liberty and the pursuit of just about anything you please." But if you choose the Mercedes, you tell the world that you don't need to pursue anything. You have arrived.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
It May Be Time to Go for Gold

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
PRECIOUS metals are suddenly looking more precious. With last week's news that Warren E. Buffett was quietly amassing a hoard of silver, driving its price to the highest level in nine years, investors began to see a treasure trove, rather than a junk heap, in long-neglected precious metals and the mutual funds that invest in them.
In fact, gold was already rallying a bit, climbing above $300 an ounce recently, after trading at $278.15 on Jan. 12. It ended the week just under $300. Gold stocks also rose after the news of the activity by Mr. Buffett, one of America's most widely followed investors. 
 After last year, when the average gold fund tumbled 43 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company in Chicago, it almost seemed that these funds had nowhere to go but up.
No fund -- not even the once high-flying Midas -- escaped the carnage. All the gold funds did poorly, from fund families like Lexington Strategic Investments, U.S. Global Investors, USAA and Morgan Stanley.
Now, with Mr. Buffett accumulating silver, which, like gold, is a traditional inflation hedge, it is perhaps less surprising that some funds, like Oppenheimer Gold and Special Minerals, have been increasing their gold holdings. "Given the relatively steep decline in gold stocks last year, we believe that the risk-reward is now better for gold stocks than other minerals," Oppenheimer said in its January shareholder report.
It moved to 75 percent gold and 25 percent other minerals, from 65 percent gold and 35 percent others. "The gold holdings will be relatively stable because of our emphasizing senior producers with low cash costs and highly liquid shares," the report said.
Even more aggressive, Sogen Gold has nearly 98 percent of its holdings in gold stocks, seemingly unfazed by a slide in net assets to $31.4 million at the end of 1997, from $55.8 million a year earlier. In such a terrible year, it was the best performer among strictly gold funds, down 30 percent.
The fund's manager, Jean-Marie Eveillard, said, "Our attitude has been the same one we took four years ago," namely that the downside risk was modest because "the price had already declined considerably from its peak, so it's a long-depressed asset." An investment of $10,000 when Sogen Gold opened in September 1993 would have been worth $8,124 at the end of last year; the value of the same investment in a typical precious-metals fund would have fallen to $6,422, according to Morningstar.
Equally stubborn in its strategy is Van Eck Associates, which has maintained a 90 percent exposure to gold in its two gold funds. Last year, Van Eck International Investors Gold A was down 36 percent, while Van Eck Gold/Resources A dropped 39.3 percent.
Harry Bingham, a manager of institutional gold portfolios at Van Eck, pointed out that gold typically ran contrary to the market, especially during major moves or changes. "There's been a bull market for the last 15 years, and gold has been in a bear market with some great rallies in between," he said.
Mr. Eveillard agreed that "everything is cyclical -- bear markets and bull markets, so this one's not going to last." Secondly, he added, "From a commodity point of view, there has been an excess of demand over supply" of 500 to 1,000 tons a year, as demand for jewelry has exceeded production from mines.
Still, Mr. Eveillard said, "obviously, as long as the feeling prevails that everything is right with the world, the opportunity for gold prices to move up is modest." He added that he was prepared to ask shareholders to vote on abandoning the sector entirely at the end of the year if prices did not move up -- as he had said when he opened the fund in 1993.
Across the fund industry, however, many investors were already abandoning the sector last year. Assets of gold and natural-resources funds totaled $4.98 billion at year-end, according to AMG Data Services, a fund-tracking firm based in Arcata, Calif., down 37 percent from the beginning of the year. "The only sector that has had a larger percentage decline in asset base is the Asian emerging market," said Robert Adler, president of the firm.
Analysts cited two reasons for gold's slide last year: the near absence of inflation and the threat of central bank sales of gold reserves, which would overwhelm the market and cause prices to fall.
Now, the pendulum could swing. "There should be strong support for the price of gold," said Mark Wright, a senior analyst at Morningstar. "At current levels gold is selling cheaper than it costs to mine it. At some point, if gold stays at this level, companies will have to stop mining, and the prices will go up."
Doug Cohen, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said: "With gold rallying a bit, the panic selling from last year has subsided. Mutual fund redemptions seem to have bottomed out. Anyone looking to get into gold hasn't missed the opportunity yet. Most people are very cautious. On the whole, there's probably more upside reward than downside risk in the gold price at $300 per ounce."
Few analysts would advise investors to join a gold rush. As Mr. Eveillard said, "It's a very opaque market with many participants." Still, many favor modest holdings, particularly for investors looking for insurance against inflation, market swings or political instability.
Mr. Wright of Morningstar, like other advisers, recommends keeping a small proportion of a portfolio, from 2 to 5 percent, in gold. "The bottom line is again diversification," he said. "Even a 2 percent stake in precious-metal stocks should reduce the volatility of one's entire portfolio enough to compensate" should the overall market go down.

HEADLINE: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
From Lake Wobegon and Beyond, A Round Table on Economics and Finance

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN 

 BODY:
TO add some perspective to these turbulent financial times, we have convened three great thinkers: Mark Twain, Will Rogers and Garrison Keillor, voice of the public-radio show, "A Prairie Home Companion," and author most recently of "Wobegon Boy" (Viking, 1997, $24.95).
True, none of them runs a mutual fund or works as a Wall Street economist. And they have no comments about last week's rebound in Asia. But they do have a lot to say about how Main Street thinks about money. 
 (The comments of Mr. Twain and Mr. Rogers are taken from their writings. Mr. Keillor, who is quite alive, spoke with me recently in Manhattan.)
Q. Gentlemen, thank you for joining our financial discussion.
MARK TWAIN I've come loaded with statistics, for I've noticed that a man can't prove anything without statistics.
Q. Do your indicators suggest that it's wise to put money into the stock market right now? Some analysts are predicting a recession.
GARRISON KEILLOR In Lake Wobegon, where I'm from, we don't trust paper. Wealth is what's here on the premises. If I open a cupboard and see, say, 30 cans of tomato sauce and a 5-pound bag of rice, I get a little thrill of well-being -- much more so than if I look at the quarterly dividend report from my mutual fund. But then my mutual fund is one of the few in America that's losing money.
Anyway, if I had ever been tempted to buy the stocks of the corporations that owned the major networks, I wouldn't think of it after they paid $17.6 billion for the rights to broadcast football.
MR. TWAIN There are two times in a man's life when he should not speculate: when he can't afford it and when he can.
WILL ROGERS Don't gamble! Take all your savings and buy some good stock and hold it till it goes up, then sell it. If it don't go up, don't buy it.
Q. A lot of people on Wall Street took home multimillion-dollar bonuses in 1997. Is that wrong, considering that the average American's salary is around $30,000?
MR. KEILLOR We're skeptical of rich people in Lake Wobegon. A person can sleep in only one bed at a time. In the New Testament, rich people are not well spoken of. One of the few depictions of a person in hellfire is a rich man. One of the few persons who comes to Jesus and goes away disappointed is a rich young man. This has not had a big effect on Bill Gates or Donald Trump, but it has had a big effect on people from Lake Wobegon.
Q. Does that mean that religion plays a part in investment strategy?
MR. KEILLOR Happy Lutherans -- believers in splashing some water on babies and then not worrying about it, just come every Sunday and bring a hot dish -- are, of course, bullish on life in general. Dark Lutherans -- believers in the utter depravity of man --think that any upturn is momentary, sure to be followed by a long, grim slide.
Dark Lutherans feel that 6 percent is about all that a person can legitimately expect in annual return. Fifteen percent, to a Dark Lutheran, is a fantasy, and 30 is a hallucination. After 30 percent come the glaciers. Happy Lutherans, of course, accept whatever good luck comes their way as an omen of more to follow.
Q. Are you aware that there is a Lutheran Brotherhood Opportunity Growth fund? It's done considerably worse than the Standard & Poor's 500 over the last year.
MR. KEILLOR Lutherans are not smart about money. Look at how many of them are still in dairy farming.
Q. Do you think it is morally wrong to try to make a lot of money?
MR. TWAIN Like all other nations, we worship money and the possessors of it, they being our aristocracy. We like to read about rich people in the papers; the papers know it, and they do their best to keep this appetite liberally fed. "Rich Woman Fell Down Cellar -- Not Hurt." The falling down the cellar is of no interest to us when the woman is not rich, but no rich woman can fall down cellar and we not yearn to know all about it and wish it was us.
MR. KEILLOR It's vulgar to be concerned with money. That's the fundamentalist view that I grew up with, and also the English-major view that I graduated with. So, if you get a windfall now and then, you give away a bunch to your family, you throw fistfuls out to various charities and you salt the rest away in the seemliest way possible.
I put my money into a money market account that pays -- I forget what -- about 2 3/4 percent.
I never invested in the stock market. I put some retirement money into a mutual fund once, but I almost never look at it. The way I earn money is by writing. I'm a farmer of prose crops. If they thrive, I prosper, and if they don't, then I get by and get over it.
Q. So you believe that people who make a lot of money should give a large amount to charity, as Ted Turner did recently?
MR. ROGERS Americans are the most generous, kindhearted people on earth as long as they're convinced not one dollar of it is going for taxes.
MR. TWAIN In all the ages, three-fourths of the support of the great charities has been conscience money.
Q. How about saving money? America has one of the lowest savings rates of any nation.
MR. KEILLOR In Lake Wobegon we believe in salting money away, not only as an investment but also to remove it as a temptation.
MR. TWAIN Simple rules for saving money: To save half, when you are fired by an eager impulse to contribute to charity, wait and count 40. To save three-quarters, count 60. To save it all, count 65.
Q. Do you think most Americans mind paying their fair share of taxes?
MR. KEILLOR No. Cheating on your income taxes is not an honored tradition in this country. Before doing it you'd have to think long and hard about whether you want to be on the news, shielding your face with your hat while being led in for arraignment. It's something to contemplate, especially since most of us don't have hats anymore.
MR. ROGERS The income tax has made more liars out of the American people than golf has.
MR. TWAIN We've got so much taxation. I don't know of a single foreign product that enters this country untaxed except the answer to prayer.
Q. Everybody seems to be selling self-help books these days. They've taken over at least half the shelves in bookstores. Are we in a period of great economic growth but of personal or spiritual decline?
MR. ROGERS We don't know what we want, but we are ready to bite somebody to get it.
MR. TWAIN Be careful about reading health books. You may die of a misprint.
MR. KEILLOR Would one want to be seen reading such books as "How to Improve Sexual Potency in 15 Days?" Is this something you'd want your sister to find on your bedside table? They really suggest the sort of vapid, vaguely neurotic and helpless person no one wants to be.
And they're all scams. Each one more than the others. The problem is not with the American people. News magazines need a crisis to put on their covers every week. They need photos of our fellow Americans looking distraught and anxious. And, lacking an airline crash, they have to stimulate self-doubt and paranoia -- even if it means finding a substance in the crystals in every American's freezer and suggesting they are causing a drop in intelligence.
Q. Why do you think that two million Americans migrated from metropolitan areas to small towns last year -- reversing a decadelong transition from town to city?
MR. KEILLOR It's our old unrequited romance with ourselves. We honestly would like to believe that, if we lived where we could get to know each other better, we would become fast friends. This usually turns out not to be true.
Small towns are not characterized by deeper friendships but by people finding ways to manage the irritation and contempt that are the results of proximity.
Q. Many people feel that our society is too litigious. Do you agree?
MR. KEILLOR Litigation is like Elvis worship, something you read about in newspapers, something that doesn't touch many people.
Q. Our time is up, gentlemen. Any final words of advice?
MR. TWAIN There is an old-time toast which is golden for its beauty. "When you ascend the hill of prosperity, may you not meet a friend."
MR. ROGERS The only way to solve the traffic problems of the country is to pass a law that only paid-for cars are allowed to use the highways.
MR. KEILLOR I've said it before, but: Some luck lies in not getting what you thought you wanted but getting what you have, which once you have it you may be smart enough to see is what you would have wanted had you known.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk
