HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
'Married Filing Jointly,' and Liable for a Bundle

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
WHEN her husband asked her to sign their joint tax return that fateful day in 1969, Josephine C. Berman complied without a second thought.
Filing a separate return never entered her mind because she had no job or income. Moreover, had she balked, she said, "my husband would have hounded me and forced me" to sign a document about which she had scarcely any knowledge. 
 Yet Mrs. Berman's assent has resulted in 28 years of hounding by the Internal Revenue Service, which, in enforcing joint-liability provisions of the tax law, has slapped a lien on her house in South Orange, N.J., for its total value of $180,000 and has seized her individual retirement account.
Now 68 and one step from what she said would be abject poverty, Mrs. Berman contended that the case, which has also involved attempts to garnishee her pay, caused her to suffer a nervous breakdown and contributed to the loss of her job as a dental nurse after agents repeatedly questioned her boss.
"Over the past 28 years, I have lived with a black cloud shrouding me -- a constant reminder over my head," she said in a letter to members of the Senate Finance Committee, pleading for Congressional intervention. With her credit rating destroyed and her debt a social stigma, she added, "my very existence is continually threatened."
Virtually alone among developed countries, the United States makes married taxpayers individually responsible for the entire tax associated with a joint return, the kind filed by 95 percent of couples.
Usually, filing jointly has tax advantages. But not so in "innocent spouse" cases. There, typically, a wife is dunned years later for taxes related to business or other dealings of a husband from whom she is separated or even divorced. The situation can also apply to husbands found liable for the debts of their wives.
The wife is liable for her husband's unreported income, his overstated deductions and any amount he has acknowledged owing but fails to pay. Often, the husband has disappeared and the I.R.S. seeks payment from the wife, who, living in the matrimonial home, is usually easier to find.
"It's a bad law," often "egregious" in application, said David L. Jordan, a partner at Ernst & Young who for two years was acting chief counsel at the I.R.S.
Neither the I.R.S. nor anyone else keeps formal track of such cases, but Richard C. E. Beck, a professor at New York Law School who specializes in tax law, estimated that as many as 75,000 women a year are forced to pay obligations of ex-husbands because they had signed joint returns.
Joint liability was enacted in 1938, a time when fewer women held jobs and divorce was less common. It came out of administrative need: in a joint filing, the I.R.S. could not determine whose income was whose.
Now, joint liability is under attack from several quarters. An American Bar Association task force that studied the issue recommended sweeping repeal of tax laws that are based on it.
In its own appraisal last year, the General Accounting Office found that the I.R.S., which is not bound by how divorce decrees may assign tax responsibility, provides scant help for innocent spouses. The agency denies most of the few requests for relief it receives, the G.A.O. said; nor does the I.R.S. have any specific form or application process. Its publications provide little information about such cases.
With ambitious reorganization plans putting the tax agency in the spotlight, prospects for innocent spouses -- at least future ones -- have brightened.
In its last session, the House of Representatives passed a bill that would have made it easier for spouses to win relief from I.R.S. collection efforts. Among other revisions, the measure created a new category of not-entirely-innocent-but-far-from-guilty wife who would have to pay only the part of the tax that involved items the I.R.S. or the courts decide she should have known about.
The Senate, which did not act last year, may go even further this year. The Finance Committee has scheduled a hearing on the joint liability issue for Wednesday.
One possibility under consideration would allow wives to file amended returns in which they change their filing status to "separate" from "joint." Another would replace joint liability with proportional liability: Each spouse's tax would be calculated on a married-filing-separately basis, to figure the share each owed.
The Treasury, which a spokesman said Friday is "very concerned" about the issue, also expects to announce a series of administrative steps this week to facilitate relief for innocent spouses. These measures, which he would not specify, would be in addition to proposals in the Administration's budget to require the I.R.S. to alert married taxpayers of joint liability in its publications, to give those denied relief an appeal to the Tax Court and to bar levies while a case is in the Tax Court.
Such revisions would constitute a second significant attempt to ease the burden of innocent spouses. Spurred by some harsh Tax Court decisions, the Government in 1971 legislated remedies.
To win relief, the spouse must now show that the disputed liability is "grossly erroneous"; that the return showed a "substantial understatement" of tax due; that the spouse did not know, or have reason to know, of the understatement, and that, over all, it would be inequitable to hold her liable.
But tax experts and women seeking to qualify for relief say the law remains inflexible. "It's practically worthless," said Elizabeth R. Cockrell of Manhattan, who the I.R.S. says owes more than $600,000 for a former husband's disallowed tax shelters from 1979 to 1981. Her struggle has far outlasted the prison term a promoter of the shelter served for criminal fraud.
"There are four tests -- if you fail one you lose the whole case," said Ms. Cockrell, founder of a support group called Women for I.R.S. Financial Equity. "And hiring a tax lawyer is the last thing most of these women can afford."
Mrs. Berman, who is scheduled to testify before the Senate panel, traces her problems back three decades, to the return she co-signed in which her husband, Irving, deducted legal expenses from his duty-free liquor business that were later disallowed.
The couple are long separated but never officially divorced. Mr. Berman left in 1970, failed at various jobs and was unemployed for more than four years; he is, Mrs. Berman said, simply unable to pay what the I.R.S. says he owes. Mr. and Mrs. Berman have not kept in touch and efforts to reach Mr. Berman last week were unsuccessful.
Mrs. Berman faced a $62,000 tax debt which, with interest and penalties, now amounts to more than $300,000. Periodically, she agreed to waive the statute of limitations so the I.R.S. would not sell the house and evict her and her three children.
The I.R.S. made little effort to pursue Mr. Berman because the Berman home could be attached. "Once he left, they really targeted her -- and left him alone," said Douglas Berman, their 35-year-old son, who has seen his mother struggle with this burden since he was 7.
Especially galling, Mrs. Berman said, was the seizure in 1996 of her I.R.A., worth more than $35,000. That resulted in an early withdrawal penalty, and technically pushed her income high enough that she did not get a tax refund she had been counting on.
The I.R.S., citing confidentiality rules, declined to comment on the Berman case.
The current system is "bad for marital relations," said David Keating, a consultant to the National Taxpayers Union, a taxpayer advocacy group. "It's very difficult emotionally to say 'Honey, I'd like to file separately this year even though it will cost us a few thousand extra dollars.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Josephine Berman in her South Orange, N.J., home, on which the Internal Revenue Service has placed a lien. Her problems began when she signed a joint tax return. (Mike Peters for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The World;
A Promised Land of Frozen Milk and Honey

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: TOMSK, Russia

 BODY:
AMERICANS don't know much about Russia, but what they do know (or think they know) has been etched into their brains from birth: The place is a big, loutish and at times exuberant mess. It is the world headquarters of suffering. If the Czars and the Communists differed in every other way, they shared an ability to incite dread on an almost unimaginable scale.
Americans also know this: A big part of Russia is called Siberia. It's the worst place on earth, a five million square mile penal colony filled, from the Ural Mountains to the Sea of Okhotsk, with exiled zombies who would rather be dead. The American Heritage Dictionary has even turned the place into history's biggest descriptive noun: Siberia, a remote and undesirable locale. 
 But what if that weren't true? What if that remote locale, one of the last great swaths of unspoiled earth, turned out to be incredibly desirable? What if Siberia had the world's most important lake, its biggest gold mine and more diamonds, gas, timber and open spaces than any place on Earth? And what if people in Siberia were more independent than they are anywhere else in Russia?
 
Looking Ahead
What, in short, if Siberia was one of the most promising places on Earth?
"Nobody would believe a word of that," said Viktor Kress, the imaginative governor of the Tomsk region, in western Siberia, where the capital city has 500,000 residents and another 500,000 are spread out in dozens of the most inaccessible communities in the world. "Even in Russia people want the story to read: Siberia is the worst place there is. It drives everybody nuts when the truth turns out to be different."
It certainly has driven the people who run Russia crazy. Of course if Siberia is far from the worst place there is, it is also not paradise. It's too big and uncontrollable to be paradise. Siberia is so enormous that almost two million square miles would be left over if the entire continental United States was dumped in the center of it. Lake Baikal alone is larger than Belgium; more than a mile deep, it contains a fifth of the earth's supply of fresh water.
The vast distances make the cost of transporting even simple goods forbiddingly high. Many cities that were created and financed by the Soviets have no economic reason for their existence, and in a free market they are dying by the score. The weather is at least as bad as any myth can make it, and there is little money for anyone.
The money part may actually change soon. Siberian oil and gas are the main energy sources not just for Russia but for much of the former Soviet world. More than 75 percent of the hard currency earned by Russia last year came from oil exports, and nearly 95 percent of that oil came from Siberia. Japan and Korea are salivating over the prospect of sticking their earth movers into the ground there. In the past, Siberia was exploited greedily for Moscow, and by Moscow. When the Kremlin sages felt like it, they sent some money back from where it came.
That approach isn't going to work anymore. It was no coincidence that when Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, met last November with Prime Minister Hashimoto Ryutaro of Japan, the meeting was held in Krasnoyarsk, the geographic center of Russia. The Japanese want to drill, dig and cut Siberia to bits.
And the Russians, aware that they can no longer pay Siberian miners with surplus towels or pencils, have decided that they had better let the Japanese in. The environment here, pure in large part because the country has been too poor to destroy it, may face a fundamental challenge as a result. But in the nation's biggest region, where wages are lower than the national average and the disease and hunger rates are higher, jobs are going to matter more than preservation. At least for a while.
Last year, Boris Nemtsov, the Deputy Prime Minister who, among other duties, has the task of bringing in more Asian investment, stunned Japanese business leaders at a lunch in Moscow by announcing his home and mobile phone numbers. Just in case they had trouble reaching him.
There is only one problem associated with the tremendous wealth that awaits those who invest in Siberia's mostly northern deposits of oil, gas, coal, timber and other resources. They will have to go get it. It's not as easy as it seems. Most of Siberia's staggering cache of raw materials are refined far from where they are found. That is particularly true of paper and gems. In the past, when the market meant nothing and competition was a dirty word, nobody worried about the cheapest way to develop a product.
The economics of moving raw goods enormous distances are never promising.
"We have a huge chore ahead of us," said Leonid Manyenko, a timber executive who works for an international consortium here. "We have to get the products out of the ground and develop them. Then we have to ship to markets at a cost that will let us still earn a profit."
That's where the eternal battle between Siberia and those people in Moscow comes in. Siberians look at Moscow with about the same attitude that Wyoming cowboys have when they approach the Beltway. "There is a feeling that all they do is take," said Mr. Kress, referring to the federal government. "It's not completely true. But it is certainly not all that wrong either."
 
Stuck With Each Other
When the Soviet Union first dissolved, many people thought huge chunks of Siberia would desert too. That never happened and it looks less likely with each passing year.
There are too many connections and Siberia does not have the will or ability to break away from anybody. But Moscow has increased payments to the region, promised to help set up local political authorities that would actually have power to set utility rates and disperse money and, to some degree, it has stopped treating this part of Russia like an enormous wallet.
"Moscow has realized it can't make it without us," said Aleksandr Makarov, the mayor of this city. "We don't like to admit it, but we know the same is true for us. We need each other so we are going to work it out.

HEADLINE: The World: Fear Itself;
Again, Israel Worries About Iraq

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
WAITING to trade in her family's worn gas masks for new ones at a crowded distribution center, Orly Abarjil said she was fighting off anxiety.
"Sure it's scary," she said of the prospect, however remote, that Iraq might launch chemical or biological weapons at Israel in response to an American air strike. "I try not to think about it. We went through enough the last time." 

Recycling Trauma
 During the 1991 Persian Gulf war, Israelis put on gas masks and huddled in sealed rooms while 39 Iraqi Scud missiles with conventional warheads crashed into their country.
The trauma of those days resurfaced last week as the country engaged in a frenzy of speculation about its chances of being attacked again.
All the commotion flew in the face of facts that argued that an all-out attack was highly improbable. And after days of official silence in the hope of averting panic, the Israeli Government belatedly launched a media offensive to persuade the public that not only were the Iraqis unlikely to bomb the country, but that enough medicines and vaccines had also been stockpiled to meet any threat, even a distant one.
What the alarm obscured were the important differences between the current crisis and the reality of the Persian Gulf war.
At that time, Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, threatened Israel and later attacked it in the hope that an Israeli retaliation would drive Arab countries out of the American-led coalition arrayed against him. But Israel never responded, although it had every reason to defend itself.
Today, with no coalition facing Iraq and that country's weapons program curtailed, Mr. Hussein has made no threats and Iraqi officials declare publicly that they have neither the intention nor the capability of attacking Israel. What's more, if Iraq did actually launch biological or chemical weapons, the act itself would essentially refute its contention that it has none.
But these altered circumstances, which might allow Israelis to sleep peacefully at night, have gone largely unnoticed in the swirl of media hoopla and public jitters that has arisen over the last couple of few weeks.
 
A Panic Attack
 News programs and talk shows have overflowed with gulf war flashbacks and discussions of whether the country was prepared this time for a biological or chemical assault.
Newspaper tabloid headlines screamed: "Are We Ready?" "Is the Anthrax Vaccine Effective?" "Are Israelis Planning to Flee?"
Thousands of Israelis have overwhelmed gas-mask distribution points, waiting hours to replace their old masks.
The switchboard of the army's home-front command crashed when it was flooded by too many callers.
Some people readied gas-proof bomb shelters. Others went to drugstores to buy antibiotics.
There were also Israelis who were prepared to travel outside the country.
"We are whipping up an almost clinical psychosis that is much ado about nothing," said Joel Feldschuh, who was the Israeli air force's chief intelligence officer during the Persian Gulf war and who is now president of El Al, the national airline.
 
A Mind-Set
 "There is no similarity between what is happening today and what happened in 1991," added Mr. Feldschuh, virtually a voice in the wilderness on Israeli radio. "The Iraqis have no interest today to attack Israel. By stirring up this panic, we are digging ourselves into a hole. We're damaging the economy. What investor will want to come to Israel when we are making such a commotion? What tourist will want to come here?"
Doron Rosenblum, a social critic and satirist, argued that Israelis were caught in a mind-set formed during generations when Jews were persecuted abroad. Even though they are citizens of the most powerful country in the Middle East, they feel terribly vulnerable.
"It's a mentality of self-victimization," Mr. Rosenblum said in an interview. "We see ourselves as victims in a psychodrama in which the Holocaust can come back any day. We're behaving like a shtetl, not a state."
That stance can also have its political uses, enabling Israel to shed for a time an image of oppressor of the Palestinians and reclaim the more sympathetic role of a nation under Arab threat.
The theme was picked up by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, whose tough policies toward the Palestinians have been blamed for the collapse of peace efforts. The crisis with Iraq, he told high school students last week, was "a perfect reminder of what kind of neighborhood we live in."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The News Junkies' Treatment Program

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
PROPELLED by forces no one really controls, the nation has arrived at a point at which sensational news is crossed by throbbing, tangled skeins of gossip, titillation, rumor, speculation and revulsion.
Beginning with the O. J. Simpson case and continuing through the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, to the current fulminations of the White House sex scandal, a ritual has evolved that strictly governs the unfolding of a certain kind of Big Story. 
 First comes the revelation of something irresistibly fascinating yet seemingly unworthy of high-toned civic discourse. This is followed by a media firestorm, saturation coverage based on high ratings and seat-of-the-pants assessments of public appetites.
Then there's the morning after: the public wakes up aghast at the news organizations that forced it to sink so low, and the news organizations loudly confess their sins.
Behold a great nation locked in what clinicians might call a bipolar dilemma, with all of the signs of classic addiction: We know it's wrong, but we do it anyway.
But there may be a cure.
In the past two years, psychiatric clinicians conducting exhaustive field studies on the American news media have defined a new and potentially devastating behavioral disorder that is characterized by manic attention to stories about celebrity and/or sexual behavior, followed immediately by a depressive phase marked by episodes of severe guilt, group recrimination and feelings of inadequacy.
This illness has been identified in current clinical nosology as Media Overreaction Disorder (Recurrent Episodes with Hypomanic Specifiers). It is now under scientific peer review for inclusion as a mental disorder in the next edition of the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (D.S.M. IV r ).
We at Human Resources cannot stress enough the need to have you or your organization clinically evaluated for signs of this debilitating disorder.
There is no reason to be ashamed in seeking help! Remember, MOD Crisis Intervention Counselors on the staff of the Human Resources Department are standing by to assist you at this moment!
Among the treatments available NOW, all fully covered by health insurance, are:
* A Twelve-Step Program, MOD Anonymous, with activities such as organized keening and group conference calls to Mr. Richard Jewel in Atlanta.
* Intensive 28-Day Aversion Therapy in Media-Phobic Resort Environment. (Human Resources is currently accepting reservations for the spring session in sunny Algeria. Reserve early!) At the spring session, the keynote speaker will be recovering MOD sufferer Twombley (Scoop) Birkenstock, author of the best-selling, "I'm O.K.; You're a Damn Disgrace to the Profession."
* Weekly sessions of group role-playing therapy, supervised by a Certified MOD Addiction Specialist, during which participants are encouraged to renounce symptomatic MOD acting-out behaviors by impersonating any one of the Three Stooges. Activities include cathartic eye-poking and face-slapping while participants shout phrases like "Nyuk, nyuk, nyuk" and "Back off the story already, you moron!" and "Why, I resemble that remark!"
* Group Electro-Shock Treatment.
* Maximum-Security Hospitalization.
You, of course, must be asking, "How do I know if I am a MOD sufferer?"
First, remember this: Denial is an indicator of MOD! Before the next overhyped news story comes along, as it assuredly will in the next week or 10 days, learn to recognize the MOD Danger Signs!
The essential feature of Media Overreaction Disorder is an initial period of group binge behavior, followed by a sharp depressive onset in which MOD sufferers are tortured by feelings of low self-esteem.
Media Overreaction Disorder is indicated when a journalist or news organization exhibits, on any one (1) overhyped news story, two (2) or more of the following behavior patterns among these Clinical Diagnostic Criteria:
(1) Joins or assigns someone else to join an unruly mob consisting of at least 50 television cameras and 100 hyperventilating reporters, all shouting similar questions at a cowering person who is either famous or suddenly notorious and who is being hustled toward a public or private doorway. The shouted questions to include one or more of the following:
"Did you do it?"
"Did he do it?"
"What did (you/he/it) do, anyway?"
"Why did (you/he/it) do such an awful thing?"
"Are you genuinely sad or sorry about this (terrible tragedy/criminal indictment/embarrassing accusation)?"
"Don't you owe the American people an (apology/ explanation/environmental impact statement) to account for the (criminal/sexual/recreational) activity that has brought us all out here shouting questions in the rain?"
(2) Is unable to ignore or suppress urge to beat a story to death (or to assign another person to beat said story to death). Often (stays on the air/adds extra pages) long after anything useful on the subject at hand has been said or printed at least five (5) times.
(3) For television journalists, an irresistible compulsion to create, commission, or pose with bizarre graphic logotypes aimed at establishing the public perception that the overhyped story that has precipitated the episode of Media Overreaction Disorder is, in fact, Vitally Important to the Nation. Example: On-screen graphic logo showing cartoon of startled Uncle Sam with his hat flying off with the words above, in bold red letters: "Live Nude Girls!"
(4) For print editors, an obsession to label endless "sidebar" articles on arcane elements of overhyped event with pithy little headline "kickers." Examples:
"Who's Sorry Now?"
"The Damned"
"Throw the Bum Out!"
"Suffer the Little Children"
"Holy Cow!"
"He Said, She Said (Or So Somebody Claims)"
"Oral Arguments"
"The Widening Gyre"
"Can the Center Hold?"
"What Would Jesus Say?"
"Are the French Snickering at Us Once Again?"
"The Day the (Innocence/Trust/Music/Unemployed Royal Person) Died."
(5) Uncontrollable logorrheic urges, including the impulsive uttering on the air or printing in the paper of words or phrases that the (journalist/news organization) would never (employ/allow) in normal circumstances, even with a gun to (his/her/their/its) head.
Examples: "Semen-stained dress," "Princess of Our Hearts," "Low-Speed Chase," "The nation was (stunned/horrified/appalled/gravely insulted/titillated) today when . . ."
(6) Marked tendency, when confronted by the public with evidence of Media Overreaction Disorder, to blame others.
Examples: "Well, some dweeb on the Internet reported it first" and "Hey, just because Geraldo got it from an anonymous source doesn't mean it's necessarily asinine."
(7) Onset of the initial prolonged period of hysterical overreaction is followed by a period of profound depression, decreased self-esteem, hypersensitivity to ridicule and a feeling that "Now the People Are Fed Up With (Me/Us/Them)."
Typically, MOD sufferers then feel the need to convene together in group sessions characterized by interminable rationalizations, delusional self-examinations, finger-pointing, sonorous whimpering and chronic gaseous emissions, which, if left untreated, can persist for weeks.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Vive La Difference;
In Europe, a Sneer, a Cheer and a Lament

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
AMERICANS, Alexis de Tocqueville found to his bemusement in 1835, "consider marriage as a covenant which is often onerous, but every condition of which the parties are strictly bound to fulfill, because they knew all those conditions beforehand, and were perfectly free not to have contracted them."
Alexis, meet Bill and Hillary, and the rest of America. The present-day country bears little resemblance to the homogeneous "Anglo-American society" whose moralizing you found so oppressive. If the latest public opinion polls are to be believed, supposedly naive and innocent Americans turn out to be just as nonchalant and blase about marital peccadilloes, even Presidential ones, as Europeans have been for centuries. 
 Not that worldly Europeans didn't find plenty to gape about in the Monica S. Lewinsky shenanigans.
The French didn't know whether to sneer or leer, so they did both, with acres of coverage in newspapers and magazines that combined a delectation for juicy details with disdain for Americans for making such a fuss about them.
Then, with the news that polls showed, basically, that Americans didn't care if a little extramarital sex were going on in the White House as long as the President was doing his job, French commentators congratulated themselves that Americans were finally coming of age and becoming more like, well, the French.
The novelist Yves Berger wrote in Le Journal du Dimanche, "Everything begins to look as if the United States had finally acquired that wisdom and good sense which we in the Old World, especially France, have long prided ourselves on: the ability to recognize the distinction between public life and private life."
President Francois Mitterrand, who had a mistress and a child by her, was carrying on a long tradition. Aram J. Kevorkian, an American lawyer practicing in France, recalled recently that one President of the Third Republic, Felix Faure, died in the Elysee Palace in 1899 of heart failure at the turn of the century after exertions there with a female "connaissance," a word that can mean "acquaintance" or "consciousness."
"Does the President still have his connaissance?" his worried doctors asked, looking for signs of life. "She left by the back stairs," the dying patient moaned.
 
British Tough Guy
President Clinton certainly got no lessons in morality last week from the visiting British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, whose policy of letting his Labor Government ministers take their consorts along on official trips as if they were spouses has been criticized by the Archbishop of Canterbury. His Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, whose toughness in dealing with Iraq and with indicted war criminals in Bosnia is much admired by American diplomats, has also weathered scandal over his separation from his wife of many years, Margaret, and his open relationship with a woman he recently and unsuccessfully tried to hire as his private secretary.
Conservative governments in Britain have produced sex scandals seriatim, and though readers of the popular press gobbled up salacious minutiae, they seldom punished the sinners at the polls.
The Sunday Times recalled last week that the late 19th-century Prime Minister, William E. Gladstone, had observed that of 13 prime ministers he had known, 11 had been adulterers. Another, David Lloyd George, indulged in a brisk sex life, "some of it allegedly on the Cabinet table," the newspaper wrote. It should not come as a surprise that Europeans do not hold what they call "Zippergate" against Mr. Clinton, at this point.
 
What? Mature Americans?
A poll of 400 over-18 French women polled by the French Institute of Public Opinion at the end of last month showed that 83 percent of them sympathized with Mr. Clinton, rather than with his accusers. Two separate German public opinion polls showed 63 to 75 percent of the public there thought President Clinton should stay in office, even if it turned out to be true that he had sex with Ms. Lewinsky and urged her to deny it.
More of a surprise to Europeans, however, were American polls showing the same thing. "Are Americans really so fond of Bill Clinton? Not necessarily," Sylvie Kauffmann wrote in Le Monde recently. "They are, of course, aware of his weaknesses, which they have learned to tolerate; but they are satisfied with the economic situation of the country and want to maintain it, the same as they want to preserve the stability of the Presidency, the central institution of their political system."
This new American sophistication, or cynicism, whatever it is, is unsettling to Europeans, who have been gradually coming around to the traditional American view that lying or urging others to lie is unacceptable in their leaders.
"In the past, America often gave us great lessons in morality, and justly so," wrote Franz-Olivier Giesbert recently in Le Figaro's weekly magazine. "American justice was free to track down corruption wherever the trail led, right up to the top, while our judges were brought up short by a too-powerful executive branch."
But in the 1990's, the French have become more like Americans. Investigating magistrates have indicted hundreds of politicians high and low for corruption built on a decades-old system of financing political parties by systematically shaking down companies that bid on public contracts.
French prosecutors now go after corruption with a vengeance, and even Government ministers, previously immune, are theoretically accountable for crimes committed while in office. But the model, America, Mr. Giesbert lamented, has become "a caricature of itself, a mixture of Puritanism, denunciations, media voyeurism and procedural madness."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Robin Cook, Britain's Foreign Secretary, weathered scandal over a split with his wife, Margaret (left) and his link to Gaynor Regan. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By David Rampe 

 BODY:

MARKETS
S.& P. Leads the Way
The stock market breezed past another big round figure, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index breaking 1,000 for the first time. That left the index at double its level three years ago. It has been Wall Street's recent star, far outpacing the Dow Jones industrial average, which began to underperform around the time that Asian economic worries emerged. "The S.& P. gives a greater weight to defensive stock groups like drugs and foods and beverages," which are less vulnerable if the economy weakens, said Richard McCabe, chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch. The S.& P. ended at 1,012.45, up 25.04 points for the week, and the Dow continued to rally to 8,189.49, up 282.99 points on the week. With the Dow near its record, it seems to have a good foothold for a climb into a new range, one technical analyst said. 

GURUS
Buffett Strikes Silver
Warren E. Buffett surprised nearly everyone by placing a big bet on silver, and if the past is any guide, it will probably turn into a chunk of gold. His company, Berkshire Hathaway, has acquired almost 20 percent of the world's silver market, and in the few months since he began buying, prices have already soared 60 percent, to their highest level in nine years, just over $7 an ounce. After the news came out, the Buffett investment returned $52 million in one day alone. And it would really pay off if inflation returned, or if industrial demand for silver substantially outstripped supply. And Mr. Buffett, known for making big investments in things he considers deeply undervalued, may be making his move for the long term.
 
BIG BOARD
When the Lights Go Out
The Big Board took much of the bite out of its circuit breakers, a safety feature adopted after the 1987 crash to stop trading at times of panic plunges. The new system varies according to the drop's severity and time of day; if stocks were to collapse by 20 percent by 1 P.M. -- a truly historic drop -- trading would halt for just two hours, then resume. The S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., right, pushed for the change, on the conviction that open markets are preferable to the eerie calm of closed markets, which could foster a bigger panic.
 
THE FEDERAL BUDGET
Black Ink? What's That?
President Clinton's new budget held out the prospect of the first surplus since Neil Armstrong took a small step onto the moon. Mr. Clinton proposed a 4 percent increase in Federal spending to pay for 100,000 new teachers, provide more child care, expand scientific research and offer some tax incentives. The budget, he said, marks "an end to decades of deficits that have shackled our economy, paralyzed our politics and held our people back." But Republicans attacked Mr. Clinton for a return to what they called the liberal spending of the past.
 
GLOBALIZATION
The Poor Pay
The Asian crisis has shaken but hasn't toppled Brazil, the world's fifth-largest country, where very high interest rates support the currency but hurt the poor and the middle class. Tens of thousands of jobs have been lost. "People are suffering," Pedro Malan, the Finance Minister, acknowledged, "but they would suffer more if we did not do whatever it takes to preserve the currency." The unanswered question is whether policies mandated by international markets will spread prosperity or concentrate it. Brazil is symbolic of all of Latin America, where despite a decade of opening to the global economy, 40 percent of the people are poor and one in four survives on $1 a day or even less, according to the United Nations.
 
WHITE-COLLAR CRIME
The Government Bungles
In an extraordinary blunder, the Government leaked its strategy for prosecuting what it considers a disturbing invasion of Wall Street by organized crime. The memo lists the victims and potential witnesses in the case against reputed members of the Genovese and Bonanno crime families. Prosecutors tried to retrieve the memo, erroneously filed late last year in a court in Phoenix, before the defense obtained it, but it was too late. The Government then hurried to protect the victims and witnesses. The defendants are accused of inflating the stock of Healthtech International, which owns fitness centers . . . On another front, Government investigators are trying to unravel a scheme in which phony medical bills are being submitted to private insurers. Law enforcement officials say that the scheme has sprouted fast and that more than $1 billion in fake claims have been filed by fictitious companies, which operate for a few weeks, disappear, then reopen elsewhere under different names.
 
HEALTH INSURANCE
Oxford on the Defensive
Thousands of frustrated doctors joined a campaign against Oxford Health Plans, the big managed-care provider, saying Oxford was deliberately delaying payments. The doctors asked for an arbitrator to be named, to order the payments of claims and to establish clearer guidelines on payments. Dr. Charles Aswad, chief executive of the Medical Society of the State of New York, a group representing thousands of Manhattan doctors against Oxford, said: "A large percentage of the unpaid bills go back a year. The problem is not getting better; it's getting worse."
 
HOLLYWOOD
Script on Page 78
Buzz, a Los Angeles magazine, entered a novel arrangement to turn out articles with movie potential. Paramount Pictures is to bankroll suitable articles and would get a chance to option them before they are even printed. Eden Collinsworth, the founder of Buzz magazine, below, said the money will have no strings attached. The arrangement goes far beyond the experience of other magazines. Studios have optioned about 20 articles from The New Yorker in recent years, including one on the chance of a flu pandemic, and a handful from Outside magazine, including Jon Krakauer's piece on climbing Mount Everest, which became the best-selling book, "Into Thin Air."

HEADLINE: Union Square's Renaissance Began Before the BID

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your article makes me recall how all of this good work started. In the mid-1970's, when the area was in bad shape, Consolidated Edison had the chance to move its headquarters to midtown, to a new building, at a bargain price. Charles Luce, then chairman of Con Edison, decided not to, primarily because he felt that pulling out would mean a severe blow to the area. 
 But he also decided to do something about the problems. With the support of the 14th Street merchants' association, Mr. Luce and Dr. John Evert, then president of the New School for Social Research, formed a nonprofit corporation, Sweet Fourteen, which became the BID.
Con Edison was the largest contributor to Sweet Fourteen, which had office space in its building. Other major contributors at the time were New York Telephone, Guardian Insurance, Citibank, the United Mutual Savings Bank and the Kaplan Foundation.
 
KENNETH KOWALD
Richmond Hill, Queens
 
The writer retired in 1989 as director of consumer education with Con Ed.

HEADLINE: Brazil's Reformist Chief Rides a Bucking Bronco

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Across the street from the presidential palace, the knockdown, drag-out fight over Brazil's future was reaching fever pitch. Congress was awash in protesters out to block an important committee vote reducing social security benefits, the crucial issue foreign investors cite for Brazil to get its fiscal house in order.
The demonstrators destroyed a bullet-proof door to the committee chambers, forcing members to flee, while other congressmen blocked their colleagues from using a second room to take their vote. The president of the Senate, Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, warned the police to control the protesters, brought here by a powerful leftist labor union. 
 "If you have to beat them, beat them," the Senator said. "If you have to shoot, then shoot."
After seven hours, the committee approved the bill. Though the uproar could not be heard from his office in the Planalto Palace, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a leftist intellectual turned champion of the free market, had clocked another victory for Brazil's standing in the global economy.
As the man unleashing those passions, Mr. Cardoso is most responsible for turning Brazil into a global player, and forcing its people and industries to compete -- to varying degrees -- in a modern economy. Before winning the presidency, he served as Finance Minister, slaying 2,500 percent annual inflation with an economic plan featuring a new currency backed with dollar reserves. He has made low inflation the new religion of a people dizzy with rising prices.
"The most important thing is to maintain stability," he said in an interview in his office here today. "Because that's the best way to improve the living conditions of the population."
Mr. Cardoso, 66, is the man who most doggedly sells Brazil overseas, courting investors and pledging that the new economic plan will be sustained by reforms to the Civil Service and, most important, social security. Under the current pension system, eligible civil servants and police officers can collect payments equal to their full salaries after the age of 50, enjoying promotions and raises even after retirement. Unable to dismiss civil servants, many of Brazil's 26 states spend 70 percent to 90 percent of their budgets on salaries.
The country stands to save $10 billion a year from the reforms.
The author of a one-time bible of leftist political analysis, "Dependency and Underdevelopment in Latin America," Mr. Cardoso was exiled after its publication by the military dictatorship that ruled Brazil from 1964 to 1985. He lived in Chile, France and the United States, returning home after a general amnesty in 1979 and becoming a centrist Senator four years later.
As President, he walks an exquisitely fine line, publicly denouncing inequality while governing in coalition with parties representing the most conservative, moneyed interests in Brazil.
President Cardoso has set himself the task of undoing an overbearing state bureaucracy by auctioning off Government assets in the telecommunications, petroleum, electricity and mining industries, and by privatizing railroads, highways and the country's port system.
Faced with the turbulence in Asian markets, Mr. Cardoso erected what amounted to a fiscal beachhead to protect the currency, pushing through tax increases and other measures to raise $15 billion in Government revenues, raising interest rates more than 40 percent, and braking growth in the process. He is seizing on fears that the crisis will spread to push through the Civil Service and social security reforms that Congress had long delayed tackling.
The stakes, even beyond Brazil, are enormous. With its 163 million people, this is the world's fifth most populous nation. Its $750 billion-a-year economy is the world's 10th largest.
Bolivar Lamounier, director of the Institute for Economic, Social and Political Studies, a private research institute in Sao Paulo, said that President Cardoso had brought Brazil to the threshold of the modern era.
"We're undoing structures that were created 60 to 70 years ago and are defended by very powerful interests," Mr. Lamounier said. "But they have to be undone in order for the country to create something else."
Melvyn Levitsky, the United States Ambassador here, is also a fan of Mr. Cardoso, and has written articles praising him in an academic journal and a daily newspaper.
"I believe he really wants to change Brazil in a permanent way," Mr. Levitsky said here today. "He wants to change the nature of the relationship between the Brazilian state and the people."
Mr. Cardoso emphasized that point in the interview. "Brazil is not an underdeveloped country," he said, "it's an unjust country."
While many would say it is both, Mr. Cardoso calls inequality this country's "most serious" problem. "That's the point of departure," he said.
Indeed, while past Brazilian leaders have always pounded the nationalist drums when faced with criticism of Brazil, Mr. Cardoso is refreshing in his unembarrassed admission of the country's faults. He is the first President to acknowledge racism as a problem here, and early in his administration took a stand against child labor and indentured servitude, which riddle the sugar and charcoal industries.
Educators credit Mr. Cardoso with making strides in improving schools by establishing a direct relation between the federal Government and local school districts, in effect cutting out a level of corruption by state government. He has tied funds to improvements in attendance, and put televisions in schools around the country as a teaching aid.
But Mr. Cardoso has been faulted for overstating his progress toward reducing the inequalities he criticizes. Although incomes among the lowest-earning workers have risen only slightly during his administration, he is fond of saying that they increased faster than those of the top wage-earners.
But the larger truth, that Brazil ranks among the most unequal societies in the world, has not changed. According to the annual United States State Department report on human rights, issued last week, the top 10 percent of the population here collect 48 percent of the income, while the bottom 10 percent receive only 1 percent. There is no safety net for unemployed Brazilians, many of whom can be seen selling chewing gum or candy bars at stoplights.
The report noted that the minimum wage in Brazil, $105 a month, was about 25 percent of what was necessary to feed a family of four.
Mr. Cardoso rejected the report's criticism, saying that only 1 in 20 Brazilian workers earns the minimum wage or less. The I.B.G.E., a Brazilian economic institute, estimates the number at 1 in 6 workers.
President Cardoso also said that the causes of the minimum wage level were far different, and more difficult to correct, than human rights abuses.
Regardless, both remain problems in Brazil. The State Department report also detailed hundreds of cases of torture, kidnapping and execution-style murders by police officers, the overwhelming majority of whom remain unpunished.
Mr. Cardoso acknowledged that his accomplishments might lag behind his declarations, and said that was only to be expected. His efforts to improve the health system, he conceded, have floundered.
"Structural problems don't change in three, four years," he said. "You can only help along a tendency, create a body of policies, that can have an effect."
"Remember during the civil rights struggle in the United States," Mr. Cardoso said. "The talk was far ahead of the practice. If the talk was not more advanced, the actions would never change. That's why I talk so loudly about human rights, about the recognition of injustice."
Jose Genoino of the leftist Workers Party agrees that President Cardoso has done a good job with the economy and foreign policy, but complained that his steps to address social inequalities had been timid.
"Socially, the country is broken," Mr. Genoino said. "He doesn't have any policy to confront unemployment, to modernize democracy."
If the left has criticized the President for moving too slowly and protecting special interests, Mr. Cardoso counters that where politics may be powerless to alter the concentration of power and wealth in Brazil, the global economy will inevitably spread wealth and power to new groups.
He bears in mind, he added, that his predecessors who tried to modernize Brazil were forced out of office instead.
"You have to politicize problems, to build a consensus," he said. "If you advance without democracy, that's not easy either, because interest groups come along and help an eventual dictatorship take over."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Stakes Fiscal Ground in Pitch for Shoring Up Medicare

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee today endorsed President Clinton's call for future budget surpluses to be reserved for Social Security. But breaking with the President over the proceeds of a national tobacco settlement, Senator Pete V. Domenici insisted that tobacco money be devoted to shoring up Medicare.
Mr. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is an influential voice in fiscal policy, staked out his position in the weekly Republican radio address. 
 Agreeing with Mr. Clinton's stand on Social Security, Mr. Domenici said: "I would go one step further. Your budget would spend the $65 billion from a tobacco settlement on new Washington-based programs. But I believe we should save Medicare first. If there is tobacco money, it should go toward keeping the Medicare system solvent -- not for new Washington spending."
When Mr. Clinton unveiled his 1999 budget earlier this week and called for any budget surpluses to be preserved until the Government solves the long-range problems of Social Security, he made it much more difficult for the Republicans to use that money for tax cuts.
Congressional Republican leaders have increasingly conceded that they will have to follow his lead and devote most of any budget surpluses to Social Security or the national debt.
But by focusing on Medicare as well as Social Security, Mr. Domenici's proposal gives Republicans a way to outflank Mr. Clinton in appealing to two major constituencies, the elderly and the baby boomers.
Just as significant, the proposal puts an obstacle in the path of those of Mr. Domenici's fellow Republicans who are looking at a tobacco deal, which has yet to be negotiated, as a way to finance a new tax cut.
Speaker Newt Gingrich, among others, has said that if Congress imposes a cigarette tax as part of the tobacco settlement, that money should be used to pay for other tax cuts. And several House Republicans this week announced legislation to insure that any money from the tobacco settlement be guaranteed for smoking prevention programs, tax relief and paying the national debt.
Since taking control of Congress in 1994, the G.O.P. has gone into the annual budget fight with a focused agenda that has led to the Government shutdowns of 1995 and to the agreement struck with Mr. Clinton last summer to balance the budget and cut taxes.
But in the aftermath of the balanced budget deal, the Republicans have split over how to reshape their agenda for a period of prosperity and budget surpluses.
House Republicans hope to begin hammering out a unified position next week at a retreat in Williamsburg, Va. But the prospect of surpluses has exacerbated tensions among the party's tax-cutting supply-side wing, its deficit hawks who want to pay off the debt and its spenders who want more money for defense and for highway and bridge programs.
Some Republicans argue that the party's strongest course is to devote a significant share of money to reduction of the more than $5 trillion national debt. That would be a way to demonstrate to voters the fiscal discipline of the Republican Party.
Most Republicans also want to cut taxes. Conservatives want to eliminate the so-called marriage penalty that occurs when couples who file a joint return are pushed into a higher tax bracket. Some Republicans want the lowest tax rate broadened to apply to more taxpayers. Other Republicans are pushing for further reductions in the capital gains tax and estate tax.

HEADLINE: Democrats' Vote Opens A Racial Rift in Florida

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Democrats in the Florida House of Representatives made history last year when they elected Willie F. Logan, who is black, as chairman of their caucus and the man in line to be Speaker should the party regain the majority.
Last month, they began to write a different kind of history when they took that honor away and gave it to a white woman. Suddenly, a state party already plagued by difficulties faced a serious rift with black voters, one of the party's most loyal constituencies. 
 Political analysts say the Logan affair is a textbook case of the Democratic Party's challenge throughout the South, as it tries to hold its political base among blacks while reaching out to more conservative whites.
Since the switch from Mr. Logan, a wide group of political and civic leaders who are black have declared "political war" on the Democrats who ousted him and announced to Democrats in general that, as the head of Florida's N.A.A.C.P. put it, "This is payback time." They said they would encourage black voters to become "free agents," no longer beholden to a party.
And leaders of several labor unions have withheld money from the party, saying the treatment of Mr. Logan underscored the party's failure to include unions, minorities and other traditional supporters in its decision-making.
"The party is on life support right now," said Representative John C. Rayson, vice chairman of the Democratic legislative caucus and chairman of the delegation from Broward County, a Democratic stronghold.
Others are even more blunt.
"They're in the toilet," said Richard Scher, a University of Florida political scientist. "The party is just completely disintegrating."
The action by the House Democrats came at a time when Republicans already hold the majority in the State Legislature and early polls suggest that the Republican candidate for governor, Jeb Bush, could clinch a Republican sweep of the state government in the November election.
After more than a century of dominance, the Democratic Party is down to 70 seats in the 160-seat State Legislature, with 55 representatives and 15 senators. The Democrats have yet to present candidates for major offices like Secretaries of Education and State and they have raised less than half of what Republicans have amassed for this year's campaign.
The party erosion and the racial tensions are endemic in the South, where Republicans have gained ground among whites and Democrats have become increasingly dependent on blacks, political analysts say. The Democrats' problems, the analysts say, is the flip side to the Republican Party's relations with the Christian right -- how to appeal to the white middle-of-the-road voter while holding on to the core supporters, like blacks, who furnish most of their votes.
But the Democrats cannot afford to melt down in Florida, the nation's fourth largest state, which was a key to President Clinton's 1996 re-election. "It's extremely important to people like Al Gore," said Hastings Wyman Jr., publisher of the political newsletter Southern Political Report. "For the Democrats, Florida is the best hope for big electoral votes in the South."
And central to that vote are black voters, who account for about 15 percent of the state electorate. While total Democratic registration dropped in Florida over the last decade to the current record low of 46 percent, from 56 percent in 1988, blacks accounted for nearly half of all new Democratic registered voters in roughly the same period. (Forty-one percent of Florida voters are registered Republican.)
In fact, black voters now constitute about a third of all registered Democrats in the state.
"Quite frankly, Democrats can't succeed at all in this state without black voter support," said Jim Kane, chief pollster with Florida Voter, a nonpartisan polling organization in Fort Lauderdale. "It's not a help; it's crucial."
In 1994, Republicans achieved a majority in the Florida Senate and two years later they won the House. The end to Democratic one-party rule in Florida is attributed to such factors as defections from whites and the flow of more Republicans into the state, including Hispanic newcomers, as Florida experienced explosive population growth in the 1980's. Redistricting also played a role by creating minority legislative districts that gave blacks political muscle but left the white areas open for a Republican takeover, some analysts say.
The party, political analysts say, has been slow to react to its new minority status and rebuild. Florida's Democratic Governor, Lawton Chiles, survived the 1994 Republican electoral sweep across the country and two years later Mr. Clinton became the first Democratic Presidential candidate to win the state in two decades, partly because Floridians are fond of cross-over voting.
But now Mr. Bush, who lost to Mr. Chiles by a narrow margin, faces no primary opposition and leads in early popularity polls over Lieut. Gov. Kenneth MacKay, the front-runner among three candidates in the Democratic primary. As of Dec. 31, Mr. Bush had raised $3.3 million, against $1.8 million raised by the three Democrats combined.
In this political climate, many were stunned when House Democrats decided to replace Mr. Logan as chairman of the caucus and as Speaker-designate for the 1999-2000 legislative session, which meant he would have taken over if the Democrats regained their majority in this year's election. Those who voted to oust Mr. Logan said he had not been traveling enough to raise money and recruit candidates, and that he had spread himself too thin in an election year by pursuing a doctoral degree in economics at the University of Florida in Gainesville.
"This was never about race," said the woman who replaced him, Representative Anne MacKenzie of Fort Lauderdale. "This was all about trying to make sure we had the necessary tools to go to battle with the Republicans this November."
But Mr. Logan and other black legislators dispute that he was not an effective or committed leader. They say the bottom line is that Democrats in Florida are not ready for a black party leader.
"I was told by members of the caucus that there was concern of what an African-American leader could do to get them elected in conservative white districts," said Mr. Logan, 40, who represents the small South Florida city of Opa-Locka. Mr. Logan said he first ran for the leadership position in 1994 and that it had taken him until 1997 to win it, when he had no opposition. He said the vote had been unanimous but by last month 31 of the 55 caucus members had turned against him.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Florida vowed to support candidates running against the 31 House members, all of them white, who voted to oust Mr. Logan and to seek permission from its national board to make endorsements in political races, which is now forbidden. "We have to do something that hurts the Democratic Party sufficiently that it pays attention," said Leon W. Russell, the state N.A.A.C.P. president.
More important, both elected and civic leaders in the state who are black, after a recent meeting in West Palm Beach, have encouraged black voters to no longer blindly support candidates along party lines.
While Mr. Bush and Republican legislators aggressively court the disaffected Democrats, the Democratic leaders are engaged in damage control. This includes meetings with black elected officials, some of whom are making such demands as more state appropriations for economic development and youth programs in black areas. There are also meetings planned with constituent groups like the Florida Education Association/United, whose president, Pat L. Tornillo Jr., warned that the union of 60,000 school employees would not contribute to the party unless it was allowed to take part in decisions, like Mr. Logan's removal and how the party's money is spent.
Lieutenant Governor MacKay, who has publicly disagreed with how Mr. Logan was treated, agreed that there is a need for better communication within the party and noted that this was not the first time a major constituency group had "felt aggrieved" and "that there is no mechanism to talk the thing out."
"We're spending a lot of energy on these issues that we should be spending on a common cause," Mr. MacKay said.
With an election looming in less than 10 months, some doubt the party can recover in time. Even if the disaffection does not translate into support for Republicans like Mr. Bush, black voters may just choose to stay home election day to repay the Democratic Party.
"It's extraordinary to me how it can have such a poor sense of its own constituency to kick a key element right smack in the teeth," said Mr. Scher, the political scientist. "They basically told blacks they were no longer welcome."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: As the N.B.A.'s Stars Soar, The Quality of Play Falls Off

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
The N.B.A. All-Star Game, that annual enterprise in ego, athleticism and commercialism, will go off today at Madison Square Garden. The multimillionaires will laugh and dunk; the league's officials will step to the microphones and recount again how popular the sport has become.
What will go unspoken, publicly at least, is what many players, coaches, team officials and others who follow the sport are talking about among themselves: that the game -- the nuts and bolts skills of the players as well as the ability to create the sublime choreography of teamwork -- is ailing. 
 League statistics show that fewer and fewer players shoot very well, and coaches and team executives believe that the falloff results in part from the proliferation of teen-age players entering the National Basketball Association. A handful of teams have won barely one-fifth of their games, leaving players and coaches complaining that too many games on too many nights have been stripped of basic competitiveness. And any number of current and aging stars argue that the development of younger players, from high school through college, has been delayed or damaged by a culture caught up in promoting individual stars rather than teams full of complete players.
"The danger of the credibility of the game being at stake is something I think the league realizes," Michael Jordan said. Jordan, whose appearance in today's game was in jeopardy because he has come down with the flu, was honest enough to acknowledge that his own extraordinary ability may have contributed to the problems among the N.B.A.'s more ordinary participants.
"I guess some of this crept in because of myself and Charles Barkley," Jordan said recently. "With our ability to take over a game and sell ourselves as individuals, we have infected the game as much as we've helped it."
It's a concern that has been building for several seasons, but in recent months some of the game's most prominent players and coaches have spoken with remarkable bluntness about the diminished quality of all-round performance and thus of the N.B.A.'s nightly product.
"We all grew up with Jordan's 'Come Fly With Me' video," said Grant Hill, the Detroit Piston star whom many project as Jordan's heir. "We're the slam-dunk generation. Nobody would work on their skills at the playground. Everybody would just sit around and see if we could dunk. And if you could, you got respect.
"It's too bad, really, because we have lost a lot of the game."
Shooting percentages have consistently fallen in the past decade. After making nearly 48 percent of their shots 10 years ago, teams are now making less than 45 percent. What's more, fewer players are passing the ball. Ten years ago, teams averaged 51.2 assists -- passes leading directly to a score -- each game. Today, the number is 43.6.
The assist statistic is skewed to a degree because an emphasis on defense has reduced scoring, but clearly, players are relying more on themselves than on their teammates. In a world where finances are tied to flair instead of victories, every scintillating move counts.
Medium-range shooting, in particular, has taken a back seat to more flamboyant methods of scoring. A record 39,943 3-point shots were taken last season, nearly five times the number taken in the 1986-87 season (8,913) when there were just six fewer teams in the league. But led by the all-round exploits of Magic Johnson and Larry Bird, that N.B.A. thrived on the floor much more than this one.
Four rule changes implemented this season to increase scoring and offensive opportunities have not helped kick-start offenses. Teams averaged 96.9 points a game last season; they are averaging 95.2 points a game this season.
"Unfortunately in the N.B.A. at this point, we're trying to make up rules to hide deficiencies of players," Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy said.
"I think the players in Magic's era, the superstars, really understood the big picture," said Hill, the Piston's fourth-year guard. "I don't know if we understand the big picture, the up-and-coming young athletes. Maybe it's the money situation, the Generation X thing.
"But on the whole, we don't look at this as our league and that we all want to help propel it. It's more, 'What can I get? Me, me, me.' The crazy thing is if we help propel the league, the league will propel us."
The image of an N.B.A. player selfishly excluding his teammates has had a pervasive influence on everyone who plays. Portly middle-aged dentists wave teammates away at the Y.M.C.A. and want to go one-on-one until they dribble the ball off their foot. Young kids at the park would rather dunk on the people who guard them than share the basketball, win and hold court until dusk.
 
Inexperienced Coaches In the Early Years
Interviews with players, coaches and team officials point to the tutelage of today's player as one of the major culprits in the disintegration of basic skills. Inexperienced summer youth coaches, more interested in directing a player toward a college or an agent, have supplanted the influence of the high school coach.
Instead of honing their talents during the off season, emerging prep stars now tour the country's five-star tournaments, scrimmaging in front of whomever will pay for their travel and shoes.
"A good six to eight weeks every summer, that was my life," said Hill. "They weren't teaching camps, either. They were camps to expose your talent, like a cattle call."
Bringing the elite players together at such young ages and compensating them for their talent has led to a sense of entitlement by the time they reach college or the N.B.A., a feeling that they have somehow earned the right to the tricks of the trade before first learning the trade.
Pete Carril, the former Princeton coach who won more than 500 games without offering an athletic scholarship, said: "These people have eroded the influence of a good high school coach. And the game is suffering for it."
Jerry Reynolds, the personnel director of the Sacramento Kings, said: "A young talented player was once being taught by educators, people who didn't have a lot to gain financially and, strange as it may seem, people looking out for the best interests of the athlete. Between a good high school coach and a college mentor, that player could receive seven or eight years of real instruction. Today, that player has been catered to since he was 12 years old."
Reynolds used an example of one of basketball's most complete players to make his point.
"Let's put it this way: Oscar Robertson in the 90's wouldn't be a complete fundamental package," he said. "He probably wouldn't learn to use his left hand or know all the tricks that made him the player he was. That player today would be a great athlete. But he'd probably look more like a Penny Hardaway. Now Penny's a great player, but he's like a lot of stars today. He needs work."
The cycle can continue in college, where a growing number of coaches are under tremendous pressure to win immediately. As players are funneled in and out quickly, often staying for less than two seasons, the result is less teaching and more reliance on one or two stars to deliver a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.
"The coaches running some college programs today are more knowledgeable about how to dress than they are about footwork in the pivot," Reynolds said. "They're glorified insurance salesmen. They know how to meet parents and A.A.U. people. But they're not interested in the person."
The stable and nurturing days of a Dean Smith, who won more games than any other college coach before retiring from North Carolina before this season, are slowly giving way to the slicked-back and well-tailored screamer on the sideline.
"Most guys got into coaching not because of money, but because they loved to teach," said Larry Brown, the 76ers coach who played for Smith. "Unfortunately, they now see people like us getting paid far too much and given far too much credit. They might be getting into the game for the wrong reasons."
 
A Tale of Two No. 1 Draft Picks
The contrasting paths of the No. 1 picks in the 1996 and 1997 drafts illustrate the differences between two systems, one geared toward instant gratification and the other geared toward learning.
Allen Iverson, the 76ers' second-year point guard, traveled to the camps, became one of the most electrifying college players at Georgetown and left school for the N.B.A. after two seasons. Tim Duncan, the San Antonio Spurs' rookie power forward, grew up in the Virgin Islands, was not exposed to the all-star prep circuit and stayed for four years at Wake Forest.
While Iverson has had trouble incorporating his teammates and winning games for the 76ers, Duncan has flourished. The Knicks' president, Ernie Grunfeld, called Duncan the "best passing big man since Bill Walton." Duncan's teammates are more talented than Iverson's, but Duncan believes his adjustment was helped by growing up outside the United States and staying in college for four years.
He was not beholden to the American dream of growing up and becoming a professional athlete.
"People go out and start playing from 5 years old and think, 'Oh, if I ever get to that point,' " Duncan said. "And then someone comes along and says, 'You want to go to the league?' And the kid goes, 'Sure. I've wanted that all my life.' And you're gone, just like that. That wasn't the focus for 10 to 12 years of my life. I had a broader portfolio of things to do growing up.
"The fourth year matured me a lot more," he continued. "I'm not saying my experience was better, but it worked for me."
In the 1989-90 season, the league included 22 players under the age of 23. Today, 35 are under 23 in a league of about 400 players. Ten years ago, Moses Malone and Darryl Dawkins were the only players in the league who had bypassed college. In the past three years alone, four high school players have been drafted in the first round.
Some young phenoms have made the transition easily. But in many cases, younger and more athletic does not mean better.
"We would like to sit down with the players association and talk about what age a player is able to deal with the pressures," Commissioner David Stern said. "Obviously, not all of our young players have made the adjustment as well as Kobe Bryant and Kevin Garnett. It's something we're concerned about."
Iverson has become a prime example of too much, too soon. His shoe commercials and his ability to lose defenders with one crossover dribble have become more important than anything pertinent to the 76ers. He is not alone. Images of post-pubescent athletes are spread across the facades of buildings before they have proved their worth in the league.
Beginning with Jordan in the mid-1980's, the agent David Falk mastered a marketing strategy: forget the team, single out the player. He adopted the same plan with Iverson in the summer of 1996, before Iverson had even played a game in the N.B.A. During a meeting with Reebok executives to discuss Iverson's image, Falk told the group: "Allen Iverson doesn't have to play great. He has to be a great personality on the court. He's going to be a fantastic performer."
Whereas Jordan took the endorsements as a challenge to live up to his image, many young players do not.
"When you think about Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and myself and maybe some of the old players, the league didn't have to market those players," Jordan said. "Their games marketed them. Today, to some degree, the league is marketing players before their games are ready."
No one knows that better than Iverson's coach. "When the Bulls are playing Miami, it's Alonzo Mourning against Michael Jordan, instead of the great Chicago Bulls against the great Miami Heat," Brown said. "It sends a bad message."
 
Season of Futility For Numerous Teams
For the first time in league history, five teams are on pace to lose more than 75 percent of their games. At 4-41, the Denver Nuggets drew fewer than 8,000 fans at home Wednesday against Sacramento. They have a legitimate shot at eclipsing the worst record (9-73 by the Philadelphia 76ers in the 1972-73 season). Golden State and Dallas have won 8 and 9 games, respectively.
Awful teams have to sometimes resort to playing younger players. With bad instruction, on-the-job training can often produce hideous basketball.
"I don't know who you put the responsibility of correcting it on," Jordan said. "Do you go all the way back to your high school levels? To your college levels? Or can you do it on the professional level from an economical standpoint or from a coaching standpoint. I don't know."
More than 600 million people will watch the All-Star Game. New television contracts with NBC and TNT valued at $2.64 billion have created an economic windfall. Attendance is steady and the celebrity status of the game's elite players has pulled in a crossover audience.
"I'm trying to imagine the scenario 10 years ago," Stern said. "If someone were to come and tell me that most of the teams would be playing in new and planned arenas in front of full houses, that every playoff game would be televised on network television and the others would be seen on cable, that we would sign incredibly lucrative television deals and more people will be watching than ever before, well, then I would have said, where do you sign for such a situation because we wouldn't have believed it possible."
"Yes, there are problems. But the beauty of our league is there is a draft and hope springs eternal."
But picking the right players is only part of the problem today. Image and endorsement compete against the idea of five players functioning as a single unit. The current level of popularity enjoyed by the league was not only the result of intense marketing campaigns, but also basic skills that made the game enjoyable to watch, skills that have been severely eroded.
"Basketball is a real simple game," Bird said. "Once people realize there is only one Michael Jordan and nobody can be like him, maybe then you'll get back the ball movement and the passing."
