HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Stirring Up an Institution in the Borscht Belt

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

DATELINE: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y.

 BODY:
JOSEPH MURPHY was walking through the Concord Resort Hotel as if he owned the place. "This should all be carpeted," he said as he entered the cavernous hall off the lobby, his shoes hitting the hard tile floor like mallets. "And this," he said, waving his arm at an empty stretch of corridor, "should have trees. It's sterile!"
He glanced outside. The sun streamed in through picture windows, but where the windows were shrouded by faded curtains, the warm bath of light evaporated. "The lighting needs to be changed, too," he said, as he walked into the boardroom next to the synagogue. "I mean, we're talking a whole different atmosphere!" 
 He was just warming up. For the next several hours, Mr. Murphy, a real estate investor, would sit with a posse of architects, engineers and associates and discuss in detail the transformation of the grandest, most famous symbol of the gilded age of the Catskills.
Soon, Mr. Murphy's company, Value Re sort and Spa, will own the Concord. The venerated institution where the tradition of Catskills comedians flourished, where countless nice Jewish boys met their nice Jewish girls and where the idea of bigger being better and biggest best was practically invented, will be out of bankruptcy and out of the hands of the family that opened it 61 years ago.
After years of fighting the Borscht Belt grim reaper, the Concord is getting a second go. Sullivan County's largest employer (with 1,000 workers at peak season) is scheduled for radical reconstructive surgery. When it recovers, it may not recognize itself. The 1,200-room hotel, one of the 10 largest in the world, will have a new identity as what Mr. Murphy calls a "state of the art, world class resort."
THE faded pink carpet and red and green brocade love seats in the lobby, the boxy 60's-style chairs and square tables in the main corridor, the peeling wallpaper and dun-colored walls throughout: gone, gone, gone. In fact, Mr. Murphy's Manhattan-based company, which has owned the Barbizon Plaza, the Hotel Taft and the Senator Hotel, plans to change everything from the ceiling tiles to the wiring. Even the baroque chandeliers, longtime stars of the Imperial Dining Room, may get the hook.
The most historic changes will be in the hotel's philosophy. No longer will guests eat all their meals together in the 3,000-seat kosher dining room. No longer will there even be a 3,000-seat kosher dining room. The Concord will no longer be a kosher hotel. Instead, a 300-seat kosher dining room will be one of five new restaurants planned for the resort.
"This is the biggest convention-size hotel in the metropolitan area outside of New York," Mr. Murphy said. "But after the traditional resort guests started finding other places to go, there was no major attempt to redevelop. The natural attributes of the area are obvious. It takes about an hour and a half, two hours, to get here for 20 million people in the metropolitan area. And it's a tank of gas away from the 70 million people in all of New York State. We're saying, if you build it, they will come."
What Mr. Murphy plans to build on the 1,700-acre site includes two or three new golf courses added to the existing three, 24-hour restaurants, new cross-country skiing trails, a full-service spa and a golf school. This besides refurbishing the downhill ski slopes (the Concord has its own little mountain), the horse trails and the indoor and outdoor pools, skating rinks and tennis courts. He estimates that the renovation will add $30 million to $40 million to the $20 million to $30 million it will cost to acquire the hotel, and that it will bring in numerous new jobs.
Which makes it much easier for those here who have been lamenting the decline of the family-run Jewish resorts to take heart. In fact, the Parker family, which has run the Concord through three generations, as well as owners of the 11 remaining resorts and, not least, Sullivan County, which is owed more than $8 million in taxes by the hotel, are all celebrating Mr. Murphy's project.
So are the hotel's longtime employees, who number in the hundreds. "I say it's a wonderful thing," said Irving Cohen, the maitre d'hotel who has worked here for 59 years. "I can't see anything wrong with what Mr. Murphy is doing. And I'm too young to retire. I'm 80 years old and I can't retire yet."
Everyone knew something radical had to happen. The hotel's fortunes have been in decline for two decades. The guests still come; Friday night, 1,000 rooms were booked, and the lobby was packed with high school students from New York on their senior class trips and a singles group spilling out of the Night Owl Lounge.
But many more have stopped coming, and guests are often heard complaining about the hotel's lost looks and faded glory. Last February, after its major hope for revitalization -- casino gambling -- was rejected by the State Legislature, the hotel, saddled with up to $30 million in debt, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. It has been operating at a loss ever since.
In September, the Parkers received court permission to borrow an additional $800,000 to meet payroll and other expenses. In November, its troubles reached the critical stage. After a Rochester developer backed away from a contract to buy the hotel, Sullivan County officials asked Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of Federal Bankruptcy Court to order the Concord to file a Chapter 11 reorganization plan by Dec. 2 or face liquidation. The county planned to ask the judge to either appoint a trustee to run the resort or close it and sell its assets. That's when Mr. Murphy's company entered the picture.
Robert Parker, the Concord's chairman and chief executive officer, and his brother George, the general manager, plan to remain with the hotel as consultants. Their three siblings will retire -- happily, according to Robert Parker.
"In a way, we're sad, in a way, excited," Mr. Parker said. "I'm going to be with this for a number of years and I think it has a phenomenal future."
"We couldn't have continued to do it," he said of running the hotel. "Being in bankruptcy, we didn't have the financial wherewithal to make the improvements and changes that the hotel needs."
He blamed both external and internal problems for the hotel's failure. "Gambling in Atlantic City started a small downturn," he said. "The economic downturn hurt. Added to that, in the 80's our taxes doubled in three years and our insurance rates doubled. It becomes a tremendous snowball effect."
Things might have been done differently, George Parker said later, as he kibbitzed with guests in the Blue Jeans Cafe. But he would not say what those things were. "I have too many siblings to deal with to say anything now," he said. "Look, we had a great run. Sixty years. Business has to change with the times. This'll bring the business up to the 21st century."
